adaptation3.2: Doctors consider severe hyperkalemia a medical emergency and treat it immediately. They also give treatments to try to stop it from coming back.
adaptation3.3: Current treatments for ongoing hyperkalemia include avoiding things that can cause it to come back. Doctors advise not to eat foods or take supplements that are high in potassium and to stop using medicines that are known to increase the potassium level.
adaptation3.4: Some of the most commonly uses medicines that are known to increase potassium levels are a class of drugs that block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS blockers). The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is a hormone system that manages blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. Often as the first step, doctors stop giving patients these medicines to prevent hyperkalemia from coming back.
adaptation3.5: While stopping these medicines usually works well to lower the potassium level, patients miss out on the known kidney protection this class of drugs can give.
adaptation3.6: Newer medicines have now been developed that bind to potassium. These new potassium binders allow doctors to lower the potassium level in a different way. Doctors may now be able to lower potassium levels and still keep their patients on the RAAS blockers for the kidney protection these medicines give.
adaptation3.7: This research studies hyperkalemia and its effects. This work also shows the many (and new) ways of treating hyperkalemia and how the treatment can help the patients.

adaptation2.1: Hyperkalemia (high blood potassium) is common in those with long-lasting kidney disease. It is linked to higher risk of death and a harmful, irregular heart beat.
adaptation2.2: Severe high blood potassium is serious, requires immediate treatment, and should be actively prevented.
adaptation2.3: Current treatment for high blood potassium includes eliminating potassium in diets, supplements, and medications known to raise potassium.
adaptation2.4: Medication that blocks kidney-related monitoring of blood pressure and electrolyte balance are usually removed by clinicians to prevent the return of high blood potassium.
adaptation2.5: While removing kidney-related medication helps, patients do not receive the kidney-protecting benefits of the medication.
adaptation2.6: New potassium binders have greatly influenced high blood potassium monitoring. They allow the continued use of helpful kidney-related medication that may promote high blood potassium.
adaptation2.7: This article reviews the effects of high blood potassium and its treatment.

abstract.1: Hypokalemia (ie, potassium levels less than 3.5 mEq/L) occurs in fewer than 1% of healthy individuals, but is present in up to 20% of hospitalized patients, 40% of patients taking diuretics, and 17% of patients with cardiovascular conditions.
abstract.2: Hypokalemia often is asymptomatic; symptoms are more common in older adults.
abstract.3: Common symptoms are cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness or pain.
abstract.4: Management consists of intravenous potassium replacement during cardiac monitoring for patients with marked symptoms, echocardiogram (ECG) abnormalities, or severe hypokalemia (ie, level less than 3.0 mEq/L).
abstract.5: Oral replacement is appropriate for asymptomatic patients with less severe hypokalemia.
abstract.6: Hyperkalemia (ie, level greater than 5.5 mEq/L) also can cause cardiac arrhythmias and muscle symptoms.
abstract.7: Urgent management is warranted for patients with potassium levels of 6.5 mEq/L or greater, if ECG manifestations of hyperkalemia are present regardless of potassium levels, or if severe muscle symptoms occur.
abstract.8: Urgent management includes intravenous calcium, intravenous insulin, and inhaled beta agonists.
abstract.9: Hemodialysis can be used in urgent situations.
abstract.10: For patients with less severe hyperkalemia, renal elimination drugs sometimes are used, as are gastrointestinal elimination drugs.
abstract.11: For all patients with hypokalemia or hyperkalemia, drug regimens should be reevaluated and, when possible, hypokalemia- or hyperkalemia-causing drugs should be discontinued.

adaptation3.1: Hypokalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is less than normal. Potassium is a very important mineral in the body. Hypokalemia rarely happens in healthy people. It happens commonly In patients in the hospital, on diuretics, or with heart and circulation conditions.
adaptation3.2: Hypokalemia can happen without patients noticing anything wrong. Older adult more commonly notice some effect (symptom) of hypokalemia.
adaptation3.3: Common effects (symptoms) of hypokalemia are abnormal heart beats and muscle weakness or pain.
adaptation3.4: Doctors treat hypokalemia with IV potassium while monitoring the heart  in patients who have significant symptoms, EKG problems, or severe hypokalemia.
adaptation3.5: Doctors treat hypokalemia with potassium by mouth in patients without symptoms or if the hypokalemia is less severe.
adaptation3.6: Hyperkalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is higher than normal. Hyperkalemia can also cause abnormal heart beats and muscle symptoms.
adaptation3.7: Doctors must treat hyperkalemia right away if the blood potassium levels are too high, if EKG changes occur (no matter what the blood potassium levels are), or if severe muscle symptoms occur.
adaptation3.8: This urgent treatment includes IV calcium, IV insulin, and medicines given by an inhalers (called beta-agonists).
adaptation3.9: Kidney dialysis can be used in urgent situations
adaptation3.10: For patients with less severe hyperkalemia, sometimes medicines are used that can get rid of the excess potassium through the kidneys or the  bowels.
adaptation3.11: For all patients with hypokalemia or hyperkalemia, all drugs taken by the patient should be reviewed by their doctor. When possible, the drugs that cause hypokalemia or hyperkalemia should be stopped.

abstract.1: Hyperkalemia results either from the shift of potassium out of cells or from abnormal renal potassium excretion.
abstract.2: Cell shift leads to transient increases in the plasma potassium concentration, whereas decreased renal excretion of potassium leads to sustained hyperkalemia.
abstract.3: Impairments in renal potassium excretion can be the result of reduced sodium delivery to the distal nephron, decreased mineralocorticoid level or activity, or abnormalities in the cortical collecting duct.
abstract.4: In some instances, all 3 of these perturbations are present.
abstract.5: Excessive intake of potassium can cause hyperkalemia but usually in the setting of impaired renal function.
abstract.6: We discuss the clinical manifestations of hyperkalemia and outline an approach to its diagnosis and treatment.

adaptation3.1: Hyperkalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is higher than normal. Potassium is a very important mineral in the body.  Hyperkalemia can be caused by too much potassium coming out of the cells into the blood. It can also be caused when the kidneys are not getting rid of enough potassium from the body through the urine.
adaptation3.2: Hyperkalemia is temporary when too much comes out of the cells into the bloodstream. But, when the kidneys cannot get rid of enough potassium from the body, the hyperkalemia can last a longer time.
adaptation3.3: There can be a few different reasons why the kidneys don't function correctly to get rid of potassium.
adaptation3.4: In some people, all the reasons are present at the same time.
adaptation3.5: Taking in too much potassium through food or drink can cause hyperkalemia, especially if a person has a kidney problem.
adaptation3.6: In this paper, we talk about how hyperkalemia can effect you. We also talk about how doctors can diagnose and treat it

31268919.Title: Updates on medical management of hyperkalemia

abstract.1: Purpose of review: Hyperkalemia is a potentially fatal electrolyte disorder, more commonly present when the potassium excretion capacity is imparied.
abstract.2: Hyperkalemia can lead to adverse outcomes, especially due to severe cardiac arrhythmias.
abstract.3: It can also impair the cardiovascular effects of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASis) and potassium rich diets, as hyperkalemia frequently leads to their discontinuation.
abstract.4: Recent findings: Potassium is a predictor of mortality and should be monitored closely for patients who are at risk for hyperkalemia.
abstract.5: Acute hyperkalemia protocols have been revised and updated.
abstract.6: Randomized trials have shown that the new anti-hyperkalemic agents (patiromer and zirconium cyclosilicate) are effective hyperkalemia treatment options.
abstract.7: The use of anti-hyperkalemic agents may allow for a less restrictive potassium diet and lower RAASi discontinuation rates.
abstract.8: Summary: Hyperkalemia should be monitored closely for high-risk patients, as it is associated with adverse outcomes.
abstract.9: New therapies have demonstrated effective control, offering hope for potential use in patients that would benefit from diet or medications associated with an increase in serum potassium, indicating that the use of hyperkalemic agents can be associated with better outcomes.

adaptation3.1: Hyperkalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is higher than normal. Potassium is a very important mineral (electrolyte) in the body. Hyperkalemia is a potentially fatal electrolyte disorder. It more likely occurs when the body cannot get rid of potassium as well as it should.
adaptation3.2: Hyperkalemia can lead to serious problems. Especially because hyperkalemia can cause severe problems with the heart beat.
adaptation3.3: The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is a hormone system that manages blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. Drugs that block the RAAS (RAAS blockers) have good effects on the cardiovascular system (heart and blood vessels). But the RAAS blockers can cause hyperkalemia. High-potassium diets can also have good effects on the cardiovascular system. But doctors have to stop giving these RAAS blockers and also recommend low-potassium diets in patients with hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.4: Potassium can predict mortality. Potassium levels should be checked often in patients at risk for hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.5: The rules for treating hyperkalemia that occurs rapidly have been updated.
adaptation3.6: Patient studies have shown that the new drugs to treat hyperkalemia (patiromer and zirconium cyclosilicate) work well to treat hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.7: These new drugs may let doctors continue to use the RAAS blockers more often. Doctors may be able to recommend less strict potassium diets too.
adaptation3.8: Hyperkalemia should be closely watched for in high-risk patients because it can lead to poor outcomes.
adaptation3.9: New drugs have been shown to work well. There is hope that these new drugs can control the blood potassium levels in patients that would benefit from RAAS blockers and diets higher in potassium, leading to better overall treatment results.

32518860.Title: Current Management of Hyperkalemia in Patients on Dialysis

abstract.1: Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on maintenance dialysis have a high risk of developing hyperkalemia, generally defined as serum potassium (K+) concentrations of >5.0 mmol/l, particularly those undergoing maintenance hemodialysis.
abstract.2: Currently, the key approaches to the management of hyperkalemia in patients with ESRD are dialysis, dietary K+ restriction, and avoidance of medications that increase hyperkalemia risk.
abstract.3: In this review, we highlight the issues and challenges associated with effective management of hyperkalemia in patients undergoing maintenance dialysis using an illustrative case presentation.
abstract.4: In addition, we examine the potential nondialysis options for the management of these patients, including use of the newer K+ binder agents patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate, which may reduce the need for the highly restrictive dialysis diet, with its own implication on nutritional status in patients with ESRD, as well as reducing the risk of potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia.

adaptation3.1: Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on regular, ongoing (maintenance) dialysis have a high risk of developing hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia is defined as a potassium level in the blood that is higher than normal.
adaptation3.2: Currently, the main treatments of hyperkalemia in patients with ESRD are dialysis, eating a diet low in potassium, and avoiding medicines that increase the risk of hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.3: In this paper, we focus on the issues and problems associated with the treatment of hyperkalemia in patients on maintenance dialysis. We present a case to illustrate these issues.
adaptation3.4: We also discuss potential treatments, other than dialysis, for these patients. Newer drugs , such as patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate bind to potassium. These potassium-binding drugs may reduce the need for the very strict dialysis diet. Because the dialysis diet is very strict, there may be problems getting enough nutrition for patients with ESRD. These potassium-binding drugs may also reduce the risk of potentially life-threatening hyperkalemia.

32775988.Title: Impact of Dietary Potassium Restrictions in CKD on Clinical Outcomes: Benefits of a Plant-Based Diet

abstract.1: In patients with advanced-stage chronic kidney disease (CKD), progressive kidney function decline leads to increased risk for hyperkalemia (serum potassium > 5.0 or >5.5 mEq/L).
abstract.2: Medications such as renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors pose an additional hyperkalemia risk, especially in patients with CKD.
abstract.3: When hyperkalemia develops, clinicians often recommend a diet that is lower in potassium content.
abstract.4: This review discusses the barriers to adherence to a low-potassium diet and the impact of dietary restrictions on adverse clinical outcomes.
abstract.5: Accumulating evidence indicates that a diet that incorporates potassium-rich foods has multiple health benefits, which may also be attributable to the other vitamin, mineral, and fiber content of potassium-rich foods.
abstract.6: These benefits include blood pressure reductions and reduced risks for cardiovascular disease and stroke.
abstract.7: High-potassium foods may also prevent CKD progression and reduce mortality risk in patients with CKD.
abstract.8: Adjunctive treatment with the newer potassium-binding agents, patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate, may allow for optimal renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor therapy in patients with CKD and hyperkalemia, potentially making it possible for patients with CKD and hyperkalemia to liberalize their diet.
abstract.9: This may allow them the health benefits of a high-potassium diet without the increased risk for hyperkalemia, although further studies are needed.

adaptation3.1: In patients with advanced, long-standing (chronic) kidney disease (CKD), the kidney function continues to decline. This  decrease in kidney function leads to an greater risk of hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is higher than normal.  Potassium is a very important mineral in the body. Hyperkalemia is a important problem that happens mostly in people with long-lasting kidney disease.
adaptation3.2: Some drugs can also cause an additional risk of hyperkalemia, especially in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). One such class of drugs, is the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors (RAAS blockers). The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is a hormone system that manages blood pressure and fluid balance in the body.
adaptation3.3: When hyperkalemia develops, doctors often advise patients to go on a diet that is lower in potassium.
adaptation3.4: This study talks about the things that stop patients from following a low potassium diet. The paper also discusses what the effect of following a strict diet can have on poor patient outcomes.
adaptation3.5: Facts are showing that a diet that includes foods high in potassium is good for your health. These same foods may be good for your health because they also contain other vitamins, minerals, and fiber.
adaptation3.6: These benefits include lowering your blood pressure. The benefits also include lowering the risks for heart disease, blood vessel disease , and stroke.
adaptation3.7: Foods high in potassium may also prevent chronic kidney disease (CKD) from getting worse. High-potassium foods may also decrease the risk of death in patients with CKD.
adaptation3.8: Newer drugs, patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate, bind and get rid of excess potassium from the body. The use of these drugs may allow for renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAAS blocker) therapy in patients with CKD and hyperkalemia. Doctors using these drugs together may make it possible for patients with CKD and hyperkalemia to have more freedom with their diets.
adaptation3.9: This treatment approach may give patients the health benefits of a high-potassium diet without the increased risk for hyperkalemia. Further studies are needed.

adaptation2.1: In patients with full-body-spreading, chronic kidney disease (CKD), kidney deterioration leads to higher risk of high blood potassium.
adaptation2.2: Medications that block kidney-related monitoring of blood pressure and electrolytes worsen high blood potassium risk, especially in those with long-lasting kidney disease.
adaptation2.3: When high blood potassium develops, clinicians recommend a lower-potassium diet.
adaptation2.4: This work explores hurdles to continuing a low-potassium diet and its effects on harmful medical outcomes.
adaptation2.5: A potassium-rich diet may have multiple health benefits due to other vitamin, mineral, and fiber content in the foods.
adaptation2.6: These benefits include blood pressure reductions and lower risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke.
adaptation2.7: High-potassium foods may also reduce progression of and risk of death from chronic kidney disease.
adaptation2.8: Supporting treatment with new potassium-binding agents, patiromer and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate, may allow kidney-affecting medication and a less-restricted diet in patients with chronic kidney disease and high blood potassium.
adaptation2.9: New potassium-binding agents may allow the benefits of a high-potassium diet without risk of higher blood potassium. However, more studies are needed.

abstract.1: Hyperkalemia is an electrolyte abnormality with potentially life-threatening consequences.
abstract.2: Despite various guidelines, no universally accepted consensus exists on best practices for hyperkalemia monitoring, with variations in precise potassium (K+) concentration thresholds or for the management of acute or chronic hyperkalemia.
abstract.3: Based on the available evidence, this review identifies several critical issues and unmet needs with regard to the management of hyperkalemia.
abstract.4: Real-world studies are needed for a better understanding of the prevalence of hyperkalemia outside the clinical trial setting.
abstract.5: There is a need to improve effective management of hyperkalemia, including classification and K+ monitoring, when to reinitiate previously discontinued renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAASi) therapy, and when to use oral K+-binding agents.
abstract.6: Monitoring serum K+ should be individualized; however, increased frequency of monitoring should be considered for patients with chronic kidney disease, diabetes, heart failure, or a history of hyperkalemia and for those receiving RAASi therapy.
abstract.7: Recent clinical studies suggest that the newer K+ binders (patiromer sorbitex calcium and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) may facilitate optimization of RAASi therapy.
abstract.8: Enhancing the knowledge of primary care physicians and internists with respect to the safety profiles of these newer K+ binders may increase confidence in managing patients with hyperkalemia.
abstract.9: Lastly, the availability of newer K+-binding agents requires further study to establish whether stringent dietary K+ restrictions are needed in patients receiving K+-binder therapy.
abstract.10: Individualized monitoring of serum K+ among patients with an increased risk of hyperkalemia and the use of newer K+-binding agents may allow for optimization of RAASi therapy and more effective management of hyperkalemia.

adaptation3.1: Hyperkalemia is a condition where the potassium level in the blood is higher than normal. Potassium is a very important mineral (electrolyte) in the body. Hyperkalemia can sometimes lead to death.
adaptation3.2: Although there are many guidelines, all doctors do not agree on the best ways to take care of patients with different types of hyperkalemia. Types of hyperkalemia include acute (coming on rapidly), and chronic (long-lasting).
adaptation3.3: This study discusses the serious issues and needs in the care of patients with hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.4: Real-world studies are needed to understand how many patients have hyperkalemia that are not under research.
adaptation3.5: Doctors need to improve the overall care of patients with hyperkalemia. This care includes knowing the type of hyperkalemia,  how often to check the blood potassium levels, when to use the potassium-binder drugs that are taken by mouth, and when doctors can start the RAAS blocker drugs again. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is a hormone system that manages blood pressure and fluid balance in the body. Drugs that block the RAAS (RAAS blockers) have good effects on the cardiovascular system (heart and blood vessels). But the RAAS blockers can cause hyperkalemia.
adaptation3.6: How often blood potassium levels are checked depends on the patient. Doctors should consider checking the blood levels more often in patients with chronic kidney disease, diabetes, heart failure, or a history of hyperkalemia and in patients taking RAAS blockers.
adaptation3.7: Recent patient studies suggest that the newer potassium-binders (patiromer sorbitex calcium and sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) may help using the RAAS blockers and overall good treatment.
adaptation3.8: Confidence in caring for patients with hyperkalemia may increase as primary care and internal medicine doctors learn more about the safety of the newer potassium-binders.
adaptation3.9: More studies are required in order to know if strict low-potassium diets are needed in patients taking potassium-binders.
adaptation3.10: Each patient's blood potassium levels should be checked as needed in patients at increased risk for hyperkalemia. Doing this, and using the newer potassium-binding drugs, may allow the best use of RAAS blockers and better overall care of patients with hyperkalemia.

adaptation2.1: Hyperkalemia (high blood potassium) is an electrolyte issue with possibly life-threatening effects.
adaptation2.2: No agreement exists for treating high blood potassium. Guidelines vary based on postassium level and management of immediate or long-lasting high blood potassium.
adaptation2.3: This review identifies many issues and needs regarding high blood potassium.
adaptation2.4: Real-world studies are needed to better understand the real-world widespreadness of high blood potassium.
adaptation2.5: Improving treatment of high blood potassium, including classification, potassium monitoring, and specific medication use, is necessary.

9803200.Title: Diagnosis and classification of diabetes mellitus: new criteria

abstract.1: New recommendations for the classification and diagnosis of diabetes mellitus include the preferred use of the terms "type 1" and "type 2" instead of "IDDM" and "NIDDM" to designate the two major types of diabetes mellitus; simplification of the diagnostic criteria for diabetes mellitus to two abnormal fasting plasma determinations; and a lower cutoff for fasting plasma glucose (126 mg per dL [7 mmol per L] or higher) to confirm the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.
abstract.2: These changes provide an easier and more reliable means of diagnosing persons at risk of complications from hyperglycemia.
abstract.3: Currently, only one half of the people who have diabetes mellitus have been diagnosed.
abstract.4: Screening for diabetes mellitus should begin at 45 years of age and should be repeated every three years in persons without risk factors, and should begin earlier and be repeated more often in those with risk factors.
abstract.5: Risk factors include obesity, first-degree relatives with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia or previous evidence of impaired glucose homeostasis.
abstract.6: Earlier detection of diabetes mellitus may lead to tighter control of blood glucose levels and a reduction in the severity of complications associated with this disease.

adaptation2.1: New recommendations for classifying diabetes mellitus include using "type 1" and "type 2" instead of "IDDM" and "NIDDM" to identify the two major types of diabetes mellitus; simplifying the criteria for identifying diabetes mellitus to two unusual fasting blood scores; and a lower cutoff for fasting plasma glucose or blood sugar.
adaptation2.2: These changes help improve identification of those at risk from effects of high blood sugar.
adaptation2.3: Currently, only half of those with diabetes mellitus have been identified.
adaptation2.4: Testing for diabetes mellitus should begin at 45 years of age and be repeated every three years in those without health risks. Testing should begin earlier and more often for those with health risks.
adaptation2.5: Health risks include obesity, first-degree relatives with diabetes, high blood pressure, high blood fat, or prior signs of blood sugar imbalance.
adaptation2.6: Earlier detection of diabetes mellitus may improve blood sugar control and health issues from the disease.

14598876.Title: Clinical impact of the new criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus

abstract.1: In 1997 the American Diabetes Association lowered the threshold for diagnosis of diabetes from a fasting plasma glucose concentration of 7.8 mmol/l to 7.0 mmol/l and advised that the oral glucose tolerance test no longer be used in routine clinical practice.
abstract.2: In 1999 the World Health Organization endorsed the reduction in fasting plasma glucose threshold but recommended retaining the oral glucose tolerance test for anyone with impaired fasting glucose (6.1 mmol/l-6.9 mmol/l).
abstract.3: This Review discusses the impact of these changes on the prevalence of diabetes and examines the implications for individuals and specific high-risk groups.
abstract.4: The phenotype of those diagnosed with diabetes and the predictive value for the development of complications according to the different criteria are compared.
abstract.5: It is clear that these changes in diagnostic criteria have major importance both for individuals and for resource planning at a national level.

adaptation2.1: In 1997 the American Diabetes Association lowered the threshold for diagnosis of diabetes from a fasting (having not eaten food recently) blood glucose (sugar) level of 7.8 mmol/l to 7.0 mmol/l and advised that the by-mouth glucose tolerance test no longer be used in regular clinical practice.
adaptation2.2: In 1999 the World Health Organization supported the reduction in fasting blood glucose threshold but recommended keeping the by-mouth glucose tolerance test for anyone with affected fasting glucose (6.1 mmol/l-6.9 mmol/l).
adaptation2.3: This Review discusses the effect of these changes on the prevalance of diabetes and checks how it affects individuals and specific high-risk groups.
adaptation2.4: The physical effects of those identified with diabetes and the predictive value for the development of side effects according to the different criteria are compared.
adaptation2.5: It is clear that these changes in identification criteria have major importance both for individuals and for planning at a national level.

20150843.Title: Hemoglobin A1c for the diagnosis of diabetes: practical considerations

abstract.1: The International Expert Committee recommends that the diagnosis of diabetes be made if hemo globin A1c (HbA1c) level is greater, similar 6.5% and confirmed with a repeat HbA1c test.
abstract.2: The committee recommends against "mixing different methods to diagnose diabetes" because "the tests are not completely concordant: using different tests could easily lead to confusion".
abstract.3: Fasting plasma glucose, 2-hour postglucose-load plasma glucose, and oral glucose tolerance tests are recommended for the diagnosis of diabetes only if HbA1c testing is not possible due to unavailability of the assay, patient factors that preclude its inter pretation, and during pregnancy.
abstract.4: HbA1c testing has the advantages of greater clinical convenience, preanalytic stability, and assay standardization, but when used as the sole diagnostic criterion for diabetes, it has the potential for systematic error.
abstract.5: Factors that may not be clinically evident impact HbA1c test results and may systematically raise or lower the value relative to the true level of glycemia.
abstract.6: For this reason, HbA1c should be used in combination with plasma glucose determinations for the diagnosis of diabetes.
abstract.7: If an HbA1c test result is discordant with the clinical picture or equivocal, plasma glucose testing should be performed.
abstract.8: A diagnostic cut-off point of HbA1c greater, similar 6.5% misses a substantial number of people with type 2 diabetes, including some with fasting hyperglycemia, and misses most people with impaired glucose tolerance.
abstract.9: Combining the use of HbA1c and plasma glucose measurements for the diagnosis of diabetes offers the benefits of each test and reduces the risk of systematic bias inherent in HbA1c testing alone.

adaptation2.1: An international committee recommends diagnosing diabetes if hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), an iron-rich blood protein joined to a sugar, is at or over 6.5% with multiple tests.
adaptation2.2: The committee recommends not "mixing different methods to diagnose diabetes" because "the tests are not completely concordant [or consistent]: using different tests could easily lead to confusion".
adaptation2.3: Fasting blood sugar tests and blood sugar tests after simple sugar intake may help identify diabetes only if testing for HbA1c is not possible.
adaptation2.4: HbA1c testing is useful for greater convenience, accuracy, and uniformity, but as the single tool for identification, it may lead to measurement errors.
adaptation2.5: Unknown factors may alter scores of the iron-rich blood protein relative to the actual blood sugar level.
adaptation2.6: Thus, tests for this iron-rich blood protein connected to a sugar should be combined with other blood sugar values for diabetes identification.
adaptation2.7: If a score for HbA1c disagrees with the general reading, blood sugar testing should be performed.
adaptation2.8: A cut-off point at or over 6.5% for HbA1c misses many with type 2 diabetes, high fasting blood sugar, and impaired blood sugar sensitivity.
adaptation2.9: Using tests for HbA1c and blood sugar measurements identifies diabetes better than HbA1c tests alone.

22059988.Title: Detection of four diabetes specific autoantibodies in a single radioimmunoassay: an innovative high-throughput approach for autoimmune diabetes screening

abstract.1: Highly sensitive and specific radioimmunoassays have been validated for autoantibodies reacting with the four major autoantigens identified so far in autoimmune diabetes.
abstract.2: However, the analysis of this large number of autoantigens has increased the costs and time necessary for complete autoantibody screenings.
abstract.3: Our aim was to demonstrate that it is possible to detect the immunoreactivity against a combination of four different autoantigens by a single assay, this representing a rapid, low-cost first approach to evaluate humoral autoimmunity in diabetes.
abstract.4: By using this novel multi-autoantigen radioimmunoassay (MAA), in subsequent steps we analysed 830 sera, 476 of known and 354 of unknown diabetes-specific immunoreactivity, collected from various groups of individuals including type 1 and type 2 diabetes patients, autoantibody-positive patients with a clinical diagnosis of type 2 diabetes (LADA), prediabetic subjects, individuals at risk to develop autoimmune diabetes, siblings of type 1 diabetic patients, coeliac patients and healthy control subjects.
abstract.5: All sera reacting with one or more of the four autoantigens by single assays also resulted positive with MAA, as well as eight of 24 type 1 diabetic patients classified initially as autoantibody-negative at disease onset based on single autoantibody assays.
abstract.6: In addition, MAA showed 92% sensitivity and 99% specificity by analysing 140 blinded sera from type 1 diabetic patients and control subjects provided in the 2010 Diabetes Autoantibody Standardization Program.
abstract.7: MAA is the first combined method also able to evaluate, in addition to glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) and tyrosine phosphatase (IA)-2, insulin and islet beta-cell zinc cation efflux transporter (ZnT8) autoantibodies.
abstract.8: It appears to be particularly appropriate as a first-line approach for large-scale population-based screenings of anti-islet autoimmunity.

adaptation2.1: Certain precise measuring tools can measure specific, self-made proteins that tag four major markers of autoimmune diabetes (diabetes from the body mistakenly destroying its own cells).
adaptation2.2: However, analysis of these many self-made markers increases costs and time for measurements.
adaptation2.3: We aim to show a quick, low-cost approach for detecting these four self-made markers to check for antibody-related autoimmunity in diabetics.
adaptation2.4: With this new measuring tool, which is called a multi-autoantigen radioimmunoassay (MAA), we measured 830 blood samples, 476 of known and 354 of unknown diabetes type. These samples came from type 1 and type 2 diabetics, slow-progressing type 2 diabetics, prediabetics, individuals at risk to develop autoimmune diabetes, siblings of type 1 diabetics, gluten-sensitive patients, and healthy patients.
adaptation2.5: All blood reacting with one or more of the four self-made markers by other tools also reacts with MAA, along with eight more, type 1 diabetics whose blood did not react with other tools.
adaptation2.6: Also, MAA shows high accuracy for disease detection and no detection after analysing 140 unknown blood samples from type 1 diabetics and healthy patients.
adaptation2.7: MAA is the first to measure multiple self-made tagging proteins.
adaptation2.8: This new tool appears appropriate for checking if a person's cells mistakenly attack their own diabetes-regulating cells.

23109000.Title: Are the ADA hemoglobin A(1c) criteria relevant for the diagnosis of type 2 diabetes in youth?

abstract.1: Diagnostic criteria for diabetes in children have not been established with nearly the rigor as that employed in adults.
abstract.2: Recently revised American Diabetes Association (ADA) criteria allowed utilization of hemoglobin A(1c) (HbA1c) ≥ 6.5 % for diagnosis of diabetes.
abstract.3: A recent series of pediatric studies appear to show that HbA1c has lower sensitivity than Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) or oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).
abstract.4: However, FPG and OGTT have themselves never been validated in children.
abstract.5: Studies to validate diagnostic thresholds in children appear unlikely to take place.
abstract.6: Thus, accepting the major ADA diagnostic criteria appears to be the best course of action for the pediatric community.
abstract.7: One area in which correlation studies between HbA1c and FPG or OGTT might shed light is in the definition of criteria for intervention in 'pre-diabetes,' as the Diabetes Prevention Program Trial did not use HbA1c.
abstract.8: However, such treatment, and the exact diagnostic thresholds at which it should be initiated in children, remains unproven.

adaptation2.1: Standards of diagnosing diabetes in children have not been established with nearly the same precision as has been used in adults
adaptation2.2: Recently revised American Diabetes Association (ADA) guidelines uses the standard of  ≥ 6.5 % in the HbA1c test as a diagnosis of diabetes.
adaptation2.3: Recent studies in children show that the HbA1c test is not as accurate as other tests that measure glucose in the blood.
adaptation2.4: However, other glucose measuring blood tests have not yet been verified to work in children.
adaptation2.5: Future studies, to see which glucose measuring test is best in children, are unlikely to happen.
adaptation2.6: Accepting the ADA guidelines for diagnosing diabetes in children appears to be the best option for pediatricians.
adaptation2.7: Future studies on blood glucose tests should try to develop a guideline for doctors to treat ‘pre-diabetes’.
adaptation2.8: However, such treatment, and the best way to diagnose and treat ’pre-diabetes’, has not been proven.

abstract.1: Diabetes mellitus is a common disease whose complications are severe.
abstract.2: For decades, the diagnosis of diabetes and prediabetes was using only fasting glucose or glucose two hours during an oral glucose tolerance test.
abstract.3: Recently, it is possible to use HbA1c.
abstract.4: Each of these tests has advantages and limitations that must be well known by clinicians for better care for patients.
abstract.5: So they could use one, two or three of this tests to reach to a proper diagnosis.
abstract.6: The aim of this article is about the strong and weak points of these tests.

adaptation2.1: Diabetes mellitus is a common disease whose side effects are severe.
adaptation2.2: For decades, the diagnosis of diabetes and prediabetes was using only fasting (without food) glucose or glucose two hours during an by-mouth (oral) glucose sensitivity test.
adaptation2.3: Recently, it is possible to use HbA1c (a simple blood sugar test).
adaptation2.4: Each of these tests has pros and cons that must be well known by clinicians for better care for patients.
adaptation2.5: So they could use one, two or three of this tests to reach a proper diagnosis.
adaptation2.6: This article's aim is about the strong and weak points of these tests.

28639373.Title: Laboratory diagnosis of overt type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy

abstract.1: Objective: The objective of this study was to compare the use of hemoglobin A1C to oral glucose tolerance testing to diagnose overt type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.
abstract.2: The study used a nonexperimental descriptive design to compare the use of the hemoglobin A1C test results to oral glucose tolerance test results.
abstract.3: Methods: The study used a sample of 45 women at high risk for type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.
abstract.4: Participants were consented to draw a hemoglobin A1C with their ordered oral glucose tolerance testing for comparison of the two tests' ability to diagnose overt type 2 diabetes.
abstract.5: Results: Hemoglobin A1C tests were highly positively correlated with oral glucose tolerance testing for diagnosis of type 2 diabetes in women in the first trimester of pregnancy.
abstract.6: Conclusion: The research provides beginning evidence that the hemoglobin A1C should be considered as a first-tier diagnostic test for overt type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.

adaptation2.1: The objective of this study was to compare the use of hemoglobin A1C (a simple blood sugar test) to oral (by-mouth) glucose sensitivity (tolerance) testing to diagnose before-birth type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.
adaptation2.2: The study used a nonexperimental design to compare the use of the hemoglobin A1C test results to oral glucose tolerance test results.
adaptation2.3: The study's methods included a sample of 45 women at high risk for type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.
adaptation2.4: Participants volunteered to draw a hemoglobin A1C with their oral glucose tolerance testing for comparison of the two tests' ability to diagnose type 2 diabetes.
adaptation2.5: For the study's results, hemoglobin A1C tests were highly linked with oral glucose tolerance testing for diagnosis of type 2 diabetes in women in the first trimester of pregnancy.
adaptation2.6: In conclusion, the research provides beginning evidence that the hemoglobin A1C should be considered as an important diagnostic test for before-birth type 2 diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy.

30259503.Title: The importance of combined NGS and MLPA genetic tests for differential diagnosis of maturity onset diabetes of the young

abstract.1: Introduction: Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a rare form of monogenic diabetes.
abstract.2: Being clinically and genetically heterogeneous, it is often misdiagnosed as type 1 or type 2 diabetes, leading to inappropriate therapy.
abstract.3: MODY is caused by a single gene mutation.
abstract.4: Thirteen genes, defining 13 subtypes, have been identified to cause MODY.
abstract.5: A correct diagnosis is important for the right therapy, prognosis, and genetic counselling.
abstract.6: Material and methods: Twenty-nine unrelated paediatric patients clinically suspected of having MODY diabetes were analysed using TruSight One panel for next-generation sequencing (NGS) and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) assay.
abstract.7: Results: In this study we identified variants in MODY genes in 22 out of 29 patients (75.9%).
abstract.8: Using two genetic tests, NGS and MLPA, we detected both single nucleotide variants and large deletions in patients.
abstract.9: Most of the patients harboured a variant in the GCK gene (11/22), followed by HNF1B (5/22).
abstract.10: The rest of the variants were found in the NEUROD1 and HNF1A genes.
abstract.11: We identified one novel variant in the GCK gene: c.596T>C, p.Val199Ala.
abstract.12: The applied genetic tests excluded the suspected diagnosis of MODY in two patients and revealed variants in other genes possibly associated with the patient's clinical phenotype.
abstract.13: Conclusions: In our group of MODY patients most variants were found in the GCK gene, followed by variants in HNF1B, NEUROD1, and HNF1A genes.
abstract.14: The combined NGS and MLPA-based genetic tests presented a comprehensive approach for analysing patients with suspected MODY diabetes and provided a successful differential diagnosis of MODY subtypes.

adaptation2.1: The study's introduction states that the maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a rare form of single-gene-causing diabetes.
adaptation2.2: Being clinically and genetically diverse, it is often misdiagnosed as type 1 or type 2 diabetes, leading to inappropriate therapy.
adaptation2.3: MODY is caused by a single gene mutation.
adaptation2.4: Thirteen genes, defining 13 types, have been identified to cause MODY.
adaptation2.5: A correct diagnosis is important for the right therapy, recovery, and genetic counselling.
adaptation2.6: The study's material and methods include twenty-nine unrelated child patients clinically suspected of having MODY diabetes analysed with DNA sequencing.
adaptation2.7: As the results in this study, we identified different types in MODY genes in 22 out of 29 patients (75.9%).
adaptation2.8: Using two genetic tests termed NGS and MLPA, we detected both small mutation types and large gene deletions in patients.
adaptation2.9: Most patients had a different type in the GCK gene (11/22), followed by HNF1B (5/22).
adaptation2.10: The rest of the different types were found in the NEUROD1 and HNF1A genes.
adaptation2.11: We identified one novel gene type in the GCK gene.
adaptation2.12: The applied genetic tests excluded the suspected diagnosis of MODY in two patients and revealed subtypes in other genes possibly linked with the patient's clinical physical characteristics.
adaptation2.13: In conclusion, in our group of MODY patients, most gene types were found in the GCK gene, followed by changes in HNF1B, NEUROD1, and HNF1A genes.
adaptation2.14: The combined genetic tests presented a comprehensive way to analyze patients with possible MODY diabetes and provided a successful diagnosis of MODY subtypes.

abstract.1: Polyuria-polydipsia syndrome consists of the three main entities: central or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and primary polydipsia.
abstract.2: Reliable distinction between these diagnoses is essential as treatment differs substantially, with the wrong treatment potentially leading to serious complications.
abstract.3: Past diagnostic measures using the classical water deprivation test had several pitfalls and clinicians were often left with uncertainity concerning the diagnosis.
abstract.4: With the establishment of copeptin, a stable and reliable surrogate marker for arginine vasopressin, diagnosis of the polyuria-polydipsia syndrome has been newly evaluated.
abstract.5: Whereas unstimulated basal copeptin measurement reliably diagnoses nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, two new tests using stimulated copeptin cutoff levels showed a high diagnostic accuracy in differentiating central diabetes insipidus from primary polydipsia.
abstract.6: For the hypertonic saline infusion test, osmotic stimulation via the induction of hypernatraemia is used.
abstract.7: This makes the test highly reliable and superior to the classical water deprivation test, but also requires close supervision and the availability of rapid sodium measurements to guarantee the safety of the test.
abstract.8: Alternatively, arginine infusion can be used to stimulate copeptin release, opening the doors for an even shorter and safer diagnostic test.
abstract.9: The test protocols of the two tests are provided and a new copeptin-based diagnostic algorithm is proposed to reliably differentiate between the different entities.
abstract.10: Furthermore, the role of copeptin as a predictive marker for the development of diabetes insipidus following surgical procedures in the sellar region is described.

adaptation2.1: Polyuria-polydipsia syndrome consists of the three main effects: central or nephrogenic (kidney-related) diabetes insipidus (constantly-urinating) and primary polydipsia (great thirst).
adaptation2.2: Reliable differences between these diagnoses is needed as treatment differs greatly, with the wrong treatment potentially leading to serious side effects.
adaptation2.3: Past identification measures using the classical water deprivation test had several pitfalls and clinicians were often left with uncertainity regarding the diagnosis.
adaptation2.4: With the creation of copeptin, a stable and reliable surrogate marker for arginine vasopressin (blood vessel constriction), diagnosis of the polyuria-polydipsia syndrome has been newly evaluated.
adaptation2.5: Whereas unstimulated basal copeptin (specific protein) measurement reliably identifies nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, two new tests using stimulated copeptin cutoffs showed a high identification accuracy in differentiating central diabetes insipidus from primary polydipsia.
adaptation2.6: For the hypertonic (very salty) saline infusion test, water-sucking stimulation via a high salt amount is used.
adaptation2.7: This makes the test highly reliable and superior to the classical water deprivation test, but also requires close watch and the availability of rapid sodium measurements to guarantee the test's safety.
adaptation2.8: Alternatively, arginine infusion (adding a specific protein in) can be used to stimulate copeptin release, opening the doors for an even shorter and safer diagnostic test.
adaptation2.9: The test protocols of the two tests are provided and a new copeptin-based diagnostic method is proposed to reliably identify between the different entities.
adaptation2.10: Furthermore, the role of copeptin as a predictive marker for the development of diabetes insipidus following surgeries in the sellar region (an area of the head) is described.

abstract.1: The classification of diabetes was originally limited to only two categories called juvenile-onset diabetes mellitus, now known as type 1 diabetes mellitus, and adult-onset diabetes mellitus, now known as type 2 diabetes mellitus.
abstract.2: This has grown to a recognition of more than 50 subcategories caused by various pathogenic mechanisms or accompanying other diseases and syndromes.
abstract.3: The diagnosis of diabetes has evolved from physician recognition of typical symptoms to detection of ambient hyperglycemia and, thence, to the definition of excessive plasma glucose levels after an overnight fast and/or following challenge with a glucose load (oral glucose tolerance test or OGTT), and more recently, by measurement of glycated hemoglobin (A1c).
abstract.4: Screening has uncovered a much higher prevalence of diabetes in the United States and elsewhere, as well as its enormous public health impact.
abstract.5: Modern testing has defined individuals at high risk for the development of diabetes and pregnant women whose fetuses are at increased risk for mortality and morbidity.
abstract.6: Diagnostic glycemic criteria for presymptomatic diabetes have been set using diabetic retinopathy as a specific complication of the disease: A1c ≥6.5%; fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126 mg/dL; or plasma glucose measured 2 hours after an OGTT (2-hour PG) ≥200 mg/dL.
abstract.7: For patients with typical symptoms, a random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL is diagnostic.
abstract.8: The 2-hour PG yields the highest prevalence and A1c the lowest.
abstract.9: A1c is the most convenient and practical test, requiring no preparation, is analytically superior, and has the lowest intraindividual variation.
abstract.10: It is more expensive than the FPG, but the same or less than the OGTT.
abstract.11: The 2-hour PG is the most burdensome to the patient and has the highest intraindividual variation.
abstract.12: Standardized measurement of A1c is not available everywhere.
abstract.13: Confirmation of an abnormal test with the same test is recommended.
abstract.14: Studies in various populations show inconsistency among the glycemic tests.
abstract.15: Of people meeting the A1c criterion, 27%–98% meet plasma glucose criteria.
abstract.16: Of people meeting plasma glucose criteria, 17%–78% meet the A1c criterion.
abstract.17: These discrepancies occur because each test measures different aspects of hyperglycemia that may vary among patients.
abstract.18: While the risk of future diabetes is continuously associated with plasma glucose and A1c, the areas between the upper limits of normal and the diabetes cutpoints have been called “prediabetes” or “high risk for diabetes.” These have been defined categorically as A1c 6.0%–6.4% or 5.7%–6.4%; impaired fasting glucose (IFG), FPG 100–125 mg/dL; and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT), 2-hour PG 140–199 mg/dL. A1c 6.0%–6.4% increases the odds ratio (OR) for progression to diabetes (OR 12.5–16) more than the range of 5.7%–6.4% (OR 9.2).
abstract.19: In U.S. studies, the incidence of type 2 diabetes averages approximately 6% per year in people with IGT and can reverse spontaneously.
abstract.20: IFG is more prevalent than IGT in the United States, though IGT rises more sharply with age.
abstract.21: IFG increases the risk of future diabetes to various degrees in different countries, with odds ratios ranging from 2.9 to 18.5.

adaptation2.1: Classifying diabetes was originally limited to either juvenile-onset diabetes mellitus, or type 1 diabetes mellitus, and adult-onset diabetes mellitus, or type 2 diabetes mellitus.
adaptation2.2: Classification of diabetes now recognizes over 50 subcategories by disease-causing biological processes or accompanying diseases.
adaptation2.3: Diagnosing diabetes has grown from a physician recognizing typical signs to detecting high blood sugar to defining high blood sugar after an overnight fast and/or tolerance test with glucose (a simple sugar). Recently, the diagnosis involves measuring glycated hemoglobin (A1c), an iron-rich protein in blood joined to a sugar.
adaptation2.4: Testing now shows higher widespreadness of and enormous public health impact of diabetes in the United States and elsewhere.
adaptation2.5: Current testing has detected those at risk for diabetes and pregnant women whose fetuses are at higher risk for death and illness.
adaptation2.6: Diagnostic glycemic (blood sugar) criteria for before-symptom diabetes have been set using diabetic retinopathy (eye-affecting diabetes) as a specific effect of the disease: A1c ≥6.5%; fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126 mg/dL; or blood glucose (sugar) measured 2 hours after an OGTT (2-hour PG) ≥200 mg/dL.
adaptation2.7: For patients with typical symptoms, a random blood glucose ≥200 mg/dL is diagnostic.
adaptation2.8: The 2-hour PG (a type of blood sugar measurement) yields the highest prevalence and A1c (another test for diabetes) the lowest.
adaptation2.9: A1c is the most convenient and practical test, needing no preparation, is analytically betterr, and has the lowest variation.
adaptation2.10: It is more expensive than the FPG (a diabetes test), but the same or less than the OGTT (a diabetes test).
adaptation2.11: The 2-hour PG is the most burdensome to the patient and has the highest variation.
adaptation2.12: Comparable measurement of A1c is not available everywhere.
adaptation2.13: Checking an abnormal test with the same test is recommended.
adaptation2.14: Studies in various groups show inconsistency among the glycemic tests.
adaptation2.15: Of people meeting the A1c criterion, 27%–98% meet plasma glucose criteria.
adaptation2.16: Of people meeting plasma glucose criteria, 17%–78% meet the A1c criterion.
adaptation2.17: These discrepancies occur because each test measures different aspects of hyperglycemia (high blood sugar) that may vary among patients.
adaptation2.18: While the risk of future diabetes is continuously associated with plasma glucose and A1c, the areas between the upper limits of normal and the diabetes cutpoints have been called “prediabetes” or “high risk for diabetes.” These have been defined categorically as A1c 6.0%–6.4% or 5.7%–6.4%; impaired fasting glucose (IFG), FPG 100–125 mg/dL; and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT), 2-hour PG 140–199 mg/dL. A1c 6.0%–6.4% increases the odds ratio (OR) for progression to diabetes (OR 12.5–16) more than the range of 5.7%–6.4% (OR 9.2).
adaptation2.19: In U.S. studies, the incidence of type 2 diabetes averages approximately 6% per year in people with IGT and can reverse spontaneously.
adaptation2.20: IFG is more prevalent than IGT in the United States, though IGT rises more sharply with age.
adaptation2.21: IFG increases the risk of future diabetes to various degrees in different countries, with odds ratios ranging from 2.9 to 18.5.

abstract.1: Objective: To review the results of arthroscopic treatment of popliteal cysts in our centre and analyse outcomes including complications.
abstract.2: Patients: From July 2007 to July 2009, 11 patients with symptomatic popliteal cysts were treated arthroscopically.
abstract.3: All of them had preoperative magnetic resonance imaging to confirm the diagnosis, identify the valvular opening, and the associated intra-articular pathology.
abstract.4: We used the Rauschning and Lindgren criteria for evaluation.
abstract.5: Results: Intra-articular pathology like cartilage degeneration and meniscus tear were commonly associated with popliteal cysts.
abstract.6: All patients achieved symptomatic improvement after treatment and the recurrence rate was low.
abstract.7: No major complications were encountered.
abstract.8: We failed to identify (and correct) any valvular opening in one patient.
abstract.9: Conclusion: From our experience, we conclude that arthroscopic treatment of popliteal cyst with correction of the valvular opening and treatment of associated intra-articular pathology is effective and safe.

adaptation3.1: Popliteal cysts, or Baker's cysts, are abnormal enlargements of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee. In this study we evaluated the results for patients who underwent arthroscopic treatment (minimally-invasive surgery using fine instruments) treatment of popliteal cysts in our centre and analysed their outcomes, including complications.
adaptation3.2: Patients: From July 2007 to July 2009, we treated 11 patients with symptomatic popliteal cysts by arthtroscopy.
adaptation3.3: All of these patients had preoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to confirm the diagnosis, identify the valve opening of the cysts, and the associated tissue damage within the knee joint (intra-articular pathology).
adaptation3.4: We used the Rauschning and Lindgren criteria tp evaluate knee joint symptoms.
adaptation3.5: We found that intra-articular pathology like cartilage degeneration and meniscus tear commonly occurred with popliteal cysts.
adaptation3.6: All patients' symptoms improved after treatment and the cyst recurrence rate was low.
adaptation3.7: The patients did not experience any major complications.
adaptation3.8: However, we failed to identify (and correct) any valve opening in one patient's cyst.
adaptation3.9: We conclude that arthroscopic treatment of popliteal cyst with correction of the valve opening, and treatment of associated intra-articular pathology is effective and safe.

adaptation2.1: The objective is to review the results and issues of joint treatment of fluid-filled swellings or cysts in our treatment center.
adaptation2.2: From July 2007 to July 2009, 11 patients with typical fluid-filled swellings behind the knee were treated with minor joint surgery.
adaptation2.3: All patients had pre-operation imaging to confirm the problem, identify the source, and the associated joint symptoms.
adaptation2.5: Intra-joint symptoms like cartilage deterioration and tears were associated with fluid-filled swellings behind the knee.
adaptation2.6: All patients improved after treatment. Reappearance rate was low.
adaptation2.7: No major issues were encountered.
adaptation2.8: We failed to correct any swelling sources in one patient.
adaptation2.9: Minor joint surgery of fluid-filled pockets or cysts behind the knee with correction of the source and symptom treatment is effective and safe.

26137182.Title: Baker's Cyst: Diagnostic and Surgical Considerations

abstract.1: Context: Popliteal synovial cysts, also known as Baker's cysts, are commonly found in association with intra-articular knee disorders, such as osteoarthritis and meniscus tears.
abstract.2: Histologically, the cyst walls resemble synovial tissue with fibrosis evident, and there may be chronic nonspecific inflammation present.
abstract.3: Osteocartilaginous loose bodies may also be found within the cyst, even if they are not seen in the knee joint.
abstract.4: Baker's cysts can be a source of posterior knee pain that persists despite surgical treatment of the intra-articular lesion, and they are routinely discovered on magnetic resonance imaging scans of the symptomatic knee.
abstract.5: Symptoms related to a popliteal cyst origin are infrequent and may be related to size.
abstract.6: Conclusion: A capsular opening to the semimembranosus-medial head gastrocnemius bursa is a commonly found normal anatomic variant.
abstract.7: It is thought that this can lead to the formation of a popliteal cyst in the presence of chronic knee effusions as a result of intra-articular pathology.
abstract.8: Management of symptomatic popliteal cysts is conservative.
abstract.9: The intra-articular pathology should be first addressed by arthroscopy.
abstract.10: If surgical excision later becomes necessary, a limited posteromedial approach is often employed.
abstract.11: Other treatments, such as arthroscopic debridement and closure of the valvular mechanism, are not well studied and cannot yet be recommended.

adaptation3.1: Popliteal synovial cysts, also known as Baker's cysts, commonly occur in association with intra-articular knee disorders, such as osteoarthritis and meniscus tears.
adaptation3.2: At the tissue level, the cyst walls resemble synovial tissue (tissue that contains a protective fluid surrounding the knee joint), but with evident scarring (fibrosis), and there may also be chronic nonspecific inflammation present.
adaptation3.3: Osteocartilaginous loose bodies may occur within the cyst, even if they are not seen in the knee joint.
adaptation3.4: Baker's cysts can cause posterior knee pain that persists despite surgical treatment of the intra-articular lesion, and they routinely appear on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of the symptomatic knee.
adaptation3.5: Symptoms related to a popliteal cyst origin occur infrequently and may depend on the size of the cyst
adaptation3.6: A common normal variant of knee synovial tissue shows a capsule-shaped opening to the semimembranosus-medial head gastrocnemius bursa  ( a fluid-filled sac that lies between semimembranosus muscle and superficial muscle in the back part of the lower leg .)
adaptation3.7: This variant may lead to the formation of a popliteal cyst due to chronic leakage of synovial fluid caused by intra-articular tissue damage .
adaptation3.8: Management of symptomatic popliteal cysts is conservative.
adaptation3.9: An orthopedic specialist should first use arthroscopy to examine the intra-articular tissue damage .
adaptation3.10: If surgical removal of the cyst later becomes necessary, the surgeon may use a limited posteromedial approach , where an incision is made in the middle inner side of the knee.
adaptation3.11: Other treatments, such as arthroscopic removal of damaged tissue (debridement) and closure of the cyst valve , are not well studied and cannot yet be recommended.

29169352.Title: Arthroscopic internal drainage and cystectomy of popliteal cyst in knee osteoarthritis

abstract.1: Background: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of arthroscopic knee cavity internal drainage and cyst cavity debridement operation of popliteal cyst in knee osteoarthritis patients.
abstract.2: Methods: From August 2007 to March 2013, 58 knee osteoarthritis patients with popliteal cyst were treated with arthroscopic knee cavity internal drainage through posteromedial portal and popliteal cyst cavity debridement through superior posteromedial portal.
abstract.3: In all patients, preoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed to detect combined intra-articular pathology and the communication between popliteal cyst and knee cavity.
abstract.4: Clinical efficacy was evaluated through VAS score and Lysholm score.
abstract.5: Results: All patients had neither recurrence of popliteal cyst nor complaints of pain, swelling, or functional impairment at average 24 months follow-up after surgery.
abstract.6: Postoperatively, VAS score was decreased significantly and Lysholm score was raised significantly comparing preoperatively.
abstract.7: Conclusion: Arthroscopic knee cavity internal drainage operation through posteromedial portal and popliteal cyst cavity debridement through superior posteromedial portal is an effective minimally invasive surgery method for the treatment of popliteal cyst without recurrence in knee osteoarthritis patients.

adaptation3.1: Background:  Popliteal cysts, or Baker's cysts, are abnormal enlargements of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of arthroscopic (minimally-invasive surgery using fine instruments) knee cavity internal drainage and cyst cavity debridement (removing damaged and dead tissue) of popliteal cysts in knee osteoarthritis patients.
adaptation3.2: Methods: From August 2007 to March 2013, 58 knee osteoarthritis patients with popliteal cyst were treated with arthroscopic knee cavity internal drainage through posteromedial portal (small holes, or portals, made in the middle  side of their knees). and popliteal cyst cavity debridement through superior posteromedial portal (a portal above the posteromedial portal) .
adaptation3.3: All patients underwent preoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  to detect combined tissue damage within the knee joint and the communication between the popliteal cyst and knee cavity.
adaptation3.4: Patients received scores to numerically assess effectiveness of these treatments
adaptation3.5: Results: All patients had neither recurrence of popliteal cyst nor complaints of pain, swelling, or functional impairment on follow-up examination an average of 24 months after surgery
adaptation3.6: The pain (VAS) score decreased significantly and knee function (Lysholm) score increased significantly when compared with pre-surgery scores.
adaptation3.7: We conclude that arthroscopic knee cavity internal drainag eby the posteromedial portal method, and popliteal cyst cavity debridement through superior posteromedial portal are effective treatments for popliteal cyst without recurrence in knee osteoarthritis patients.

30088053.Title: Arthroscopic treatment of popliteal cyst using a figure-of-four position and double posteromedial portals

abstract.1: Purpose: The purpose of this study was to introduce a modified arthroscopic treatment technique for popliteal cyst and hypothesize that this modified technique would provide good clinical efficacy and low recurrence rate.
abstract.2: Methods: From January 2013 to January 2017, 34 patients with symptomatic popliteal cysts were treated with our technique.
abstract.3: A figure-of-four position and double posteromedial portals were used to achieve adequate enlargement of the posteromedial valvular opening between the cyst and the joint cavity and complete excision of the cyst wall.
abstract.4: MRI was used to detect the recurrence of the popliteal cyst, and the Rauschning and Lindgren score was recorded to evaluate the clinical outcome.
abstract.5: Results: All patients were followed up with a mean period of 14.8 months (range, 12 to 36 months).
abstract.6: Associated intra-articular lesions were found and treated in all cases.
abstract.7: Degenerative cartilage damage was the most common pathology, which affected 23 (67.6%) of the cases.
abstract.8: The Rauschning and Lindgren score improved significantly after surgery, and no evidence of recurrence was found from MRI in any case.
abstract.9: Conclusions: Our modified arthroscopic treatment technique, using a figure-of-four position and double posteromedial portals, is effective and safe for treating popliteal cyst.

adaptation3.1: The purpose of this study was to introduce a modified treatment technique using arthroscopy (minimally-invasive surgery using fine instruments for removal of popliteal or Baker's cyst). These cysts are abnormal enlargements of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee. We thought that this modified technique would be effective, so that cysts do not recur in patients who underwent the treatment.
adaptation3.2: From January 2013 to January 2017, 34 patients with symptomatic popliteal cysts were treated with our technique.
adaptation3.3: Patients in a figure-of-four position (lying on back with opposite leg crossed over the knee) had two small holes, or portals, made in the middle rear side of their knees to allow enough space to open the  cyst valve, drain and remove the cyst.
adaptation3.4: We assessed reoccurence of the cysts using MRI and assigned scores to evaluate the clinical outcome
adaptation3.5: Patients underwent follow-up examination an average of  14.8 months following the procedure (range, 12 to 36 months).
adaptation3.6: We found and treated lesions (damaged tissue and cysts) within knee joint in all cases;
adaptation3.7: Damage to the cartilage of the knee was most common,  occuring in 23 (67.6%) of the cases
adaptation3.8: Patients' scores improved significantly after surgery, and MRI showed that the cysts did not reappear in any case.
adaptation3.9: We conclude that our arthroscopic techninque is effective and safe for treating popliteal cyst.

30377698.Title: Is low dose radiotherapy an effective treatment for Baker's cyst?

abstract.1: Purpose: Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common disease, often associated with a Baker's cyst.
abstract.2: Besides osteoarthritis, also other joint pathologies of the knee can be causative for a Baker's cyst.
abstract.3: Radiotherapy is known to be an effective treatment for osteoarthritis, with an anti-inflammatory effect.
abstract.4: As the excessive production of synovia usually is associated with intraarticular inflammation, our hypothesis was that radiotherapy might positively influence the synovial production and reduce the volume of a Baker's cyst.
abstract.5: Materials and methods: We performed a prospective trial, including 20 knees receiving radiotherapy for knee arthritis.
abstract.6: Besides documentation of NRS (numeric rating scale), WOMAC (Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index) score and Knee Society Score, the volume of the Baker's cyst was calculated for a short- (6 to 12 weeks) and long-term (9 to 12 months) follow-up.
abstract.7: Ultrasonic volumetry was performed using an ultrasound device with a high-resolution multifrequency linear probe (6-9 MHz).
abstract.8: Results: Low-dose radiotherapy improved NRS, WOMAC score and Knee Society Score significantly.
abstract.9: The mean volume of Baker's cyst decreased from 22.3 ml to 10.7 respectively 3.1 ml during follow-up.
abstract.10: A decrease in volume of more than 25% compared to the baseline could be achieved for 75% of the patients in the short-term and 79% of the patients in the long-term follow up.
abstract.11: Conclusion: Radiotherapy of knee osteoarthritis is an effective treatment that decreases the volume of a Baker's cyst.
abstract.12: Most patients respond to the treatment.
abstract.13: Whether radiotherapy is an effective treatment for Baker's cyst without associated osteoarthritis has to be further examined.

adaptation3.1: Osteoarthritis of the knee is a common disease, often associated with Baker's cyst, which is an abnormal enlargement of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee
adaptation3.2: Other knee joint injuries or disorders can also cause Baker's cyst
adaptation3.3: Radiotherapy is an effective treatment for osteoarthritis because it targets inflammation
adaptation3.4: Inflammation increases the amount of fluid, or synovia, in the knee. So we asked if radiotherapy may reduce both the production of synovia and volume of Baker's cyst.
adaptation3.5: To answer this question, we performed a prospective trial, where we examined 20 knees receiving radiotherapy for knee arthritis.
adaptation3.6: We assigned scores for the degree of osteoarthitis and calculated the cyst volume for a short- (6 to 12 weeks) and long-term (9 to 12 months) follow-up.
adaptation3.7: We measured cyst volume by ultrasound,
adaptation3.8: and found that low-dose radiotherapy improved knee osteoarthritis scores significantly.
adaptation3.9: The average volume of Baker's cysts also decreased from 22.3 ml to 10.7 respectively during follow-up.
adaptation3.10: A decrease in cyst volume of more than 25% compared to the starting volume could be achieved for 75% of the patients in the short-term, and 79% of the patients in the long-term follow up.
adaptation3.11: We conclude that radiotherapy of knee osteoarthritis is an effective treatment that decreases the volume of a Baker's cyst.
adaptation3.12: Most patients respond to this treatment.

adaptation2.1: Knee osteoarthritis is a common disease, often occuring with Baker's cyst (a fluid-filled pocket behind the knee).
adaptation2.2: Besides osteoarthritis, other knee joint diseases can lead to an uncomfortable fuild-filled swelling behind the knee.
adaptation2.3: Radiation therapy treats osteoarthritis, with an anti-inflammatory effect.
adaptation2.4: As excess fluid in joints is linked with joint inflammation, radiation therapy may help fluid production in joints and reduce the size of the fluid-filled swelling behind the knee.
adaptation2.5: Our trial includes 29 knees receiving radiation therapy for knee arthritis.
adaptation2.6: Besides knee pain and function measurements, the size of the cust was measured for a short- (6 to 12 weeks) and long-term (9 to 12 months) follow-up.
adaptation2.8: Low-dose radiation therapy improves measurements for knee arthritis.
adaptation2.9: The size of the fluid-filled swelling behind the knees decreased.
adaptation2.10: 75% of patients in the short-term and 79% of patients in the long-term achieved a decrease in size of over 25% relative to baseline scores.
adaptation2.11: Radiation therapy of knee osteoarthritis decreases the size of a Baker's cyst.
adaptation2.12: Most patients respond to the treatment.
adaptation2.13: Whether radiation therapy treats Baker's cyst without associated osteoarthritis is unknown.

30639028.Title: Extra-articular endoscopic excision of symptomatic popliteal cyst with failed initial conservative treatment: A novel technique

abstract.1: To reduce the damage to posteromedial knee capsule, we developed a direct extra-articular arthroscopic approach for excision of symptomatic popliteal cysts.
abstract.2: This study aimed to demonstrate the surgical technique and present the 2-year follow-up results.
abstract.3: Cystectomy is performed by extra-articular surgical approach through a high posteromedial portal.
abstract.4: Twenty-one consecutive patients diagnosed of symptomatic popliteal cysts with failed initial conservative treatments were included.
abstract.5: At a median follow-up of 29.4 months, all knees had improved clinical function assessed by Rauschning and Lindgren knee classification (p<0.001).
abstract.6: The cysts were either disappeared (95.2%) or reduced in size (4.8%).
abstract.7: Only one (4.8%) patient had recurrent cyst, which was solved after ultrasound-guided aspiration.
abstract.8: This direct extra-articular arthroscopic technique could be a feasible alternative for treatment of symptomatic popliteal cysts.

adaptation3.1: Popliteal cysts, or Baker's cysts, are abnormal enlargements of the bursa (a protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee.  Arthroscopy (minimally-invasive surgery using fine instruments) is a treatment method for popliteal cysts. To reduce the damage to posteromedial (middle, side)  knee capsule associated with this treatment, we have developed a direct arthroscopic approach from outside the knee joint (extra-articular) for removal of symptomatic popliteal cysts.
adaptation3.2: This study aims to demonstrate the surgical technique and present the 2-year follow-up results.
adaptation3.3: Removal of the cyst (cystectomy) is performed by an extra-articular surgical approach, where a small hole is made in the side of the knee above the knee joint (a high posteromedial portal).
adaptation3.4: We included twenty-one patients diagnosed with symptomatic popliteal cysts who had unsuccesful previous conservative treatments in our study.
adaptation3.5: At a median follow-up time of 29.4 months, all knees had improved clinical function assessed by Rauschning and Lindgren knee classification criteria scores.
adaptation3.6: The cysts had either disappeared (95.2%) or reduced in size (4.8%).
adaptation3.7: Only one (4.8%) patient had a recurrent cyst, which was removed by ultrasound-guided aspiration.
adaptation3.8: This direct extra-articular arthroscopic technique could be a feasible alternative treatment for symptomatic popliteal cysts.

30884939.Title: Diagnosis and therapy of popliteal cyst

abstract.1: Popliteal cyst is a common peri-knee cyst, also known as a Baker's cyst.
abstract.2: With the current development of popliteal cysts, the pathogenesis is mainly due to increased pressure in the knee joint caused by various reasons, leading to a fluid-filled sac that can form behind the knee as a result of enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa.
abstract.3: The current diagnostic methods include X-ray computed, ultrasound, and magnetic resonance.
abstract.4: Among them, magnetic resonance imaging is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of popliteal cysts.
abstract.5: There are various treatments, including conservative treatment, traditional surgical resection and arthroscopic surgery.
abstract.6: In recent years, the focus of the treatment of popliteal cysts has gradually shifted from the simple removal of cysts to arthroscopic treatment of intra-articular lesions and the treatment of joint-cyst communication, and achieved a good effect.
abstract.7: However, there are still controversies about the most effective treatment, and the best surgery method is still uncertained.
abstract.8: It is hoped that high quality prospective studies will be able to directly compare different surgery methods, so as to select the best treatment for popliteal cyst.
abstract.9: This article reviews past literature research and describes in detail the epidemiology, pathological mechanism, clinical manifestations and signs, auxiliary examination, diagnosis and differential diagnosis and clinical treatment of popliteal cysts.
abstract.10: Different diagnosis methods and treatment methods are compared and summarized to provide basis for clinical diagnosis and treatment.

adaptation3.1: Popliteal cyst, also known as Baker's cyst, occurs in the knee region.
adaptation3.2: Popliteal cysts are caused by increased pressure on the knee joint which results in the abnormal enlargement of a bursa (protective fluid-filled sac) behind the knee to form a cyst.
adaptation3.3: Orthopedic specialists can diagnose popliteal cysts using X-ray computed tomography (CT scan), ultrasound, or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
adaptation3.4: MRI is the gold standard for diagnosis of popliteal cysts
adaptation3.5: Treatment options for popliteal cysts include conservative treatment, traditional surgery, and arthroscopic surgery.
adaptation3.6: In recent years, treatment of popliteal cysts has shifted from traditional surgical removal of the cysts to arthroscopic treatment of intra-articular lesions and the treatment of joint-cyst communication, with good results.
adaptation3.7: However, controversy remains over which treatment method is best.
adaptation3.8: High quality studies that directly compare different surgical methods should help select the best treatment for popliteal cyst.
adaptation3.9: This article reviews previous studies and literature, and describes in detail the epidemiology, pathological mechanism, signs and symptoms, lab and imaging results,  diagnosis and clinical treatment of popliteal cysts
adaptation3.10: We compare and summarize different methods to provide basis for clinical diagnosis and treatment of popliteal cyst.

30976834.Title: Successful arthroscopic treatment of refractory and complicated popliteal cyst associated with rheumatoid arthritis in combination with osteoarthritis: case series and literature review

abstract.1: Although popliteal cysts are most frequently identified in patients with osteoarthritis (OA), they may occur in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), in which serious complicated cases such as cyst rupture can be developed.
