adaptation2.2: As Parkinson's disease progresses, the effect of the long-lasting response to levodopa (common Parkinsons's medication) remains unknown since it is measured indirectly in treated patients.
adaptation2.3: We tried to describe the natural course of movement symptoms by measuring the OFF state when symptoms occur in patients never given treatment (drug-naïve) for Parkinson's disease. For 2 years, we also explored how daily levodopa affects the progression of movement symptoms in the OFF state after treatment wears off.
adaptation2.4: In this lengthy, observational study in sub-Saharan Africa, 30 patients with Parkinson's disease (age at onset 58 ± 14 years, disease duration 7 ± 4 years) began levodopa therapy and were later measured with a specific disease scale for Parkinson's.
adaptation2.5: Data were collected at start, 1-year, and 2-year follow-up.
adaptation2.6: First-time levodopa intake improved movement symptoms.
adaptation2.7: After 1 year, severity of symptoms of Parkinson's disease was lower after overnight withdrawal of levodopa than without it at all.
adaptation2.8: The lowered severity by levodopa was not altered by disease length.
adaptation2.9: After 2 years, movement signs after overnight withdrawal of medication was still 30% milder than movement signs with no treatment ever.
adaptation2.10: The no-symptom state after first-time levodopa was similar and related to the overnight typical-symptom state after 1 year.
adaptation2.11: Compared to the natural progression, levodopa reduces symptom severity via a 31% annual decline with some leeway due to disease duration.
adaptation2.12: We calculated that the response to levodopa involved a possible 60-65% benefit of total motor activity, regardless of disease duration.
adaptation2.13: While levodopa relates to movement fluctuations, the typical-symptom state after overnight levodopa withdrawal was less severe than without medication at all, regardless of disease duration.
adaptation2.14: A yearly decline in symptom severity during the typical-symptom state also exists.
adaptation2.15: We need more research to explain the mechanisms for the response to levodopa in Parkinson's disease.
adaptation2.16: Understanding how Parkinson's disease progresses and the response to levodopa may help create better treatments and better assess clinical trials for Parkinson's disease.

33165964.Title: Levodopa Versus Dopamine Agonist after Subthalamic Stimulation in Parkinson's Disease

abstract.1: Background: No clinical trials have been specifically designed to compare medical treatments after surgery in Parkinson's disease (PD).
abstract.2: Objective: Study's objective was to compare the efficacy and safety of levodopa versus dopamine agonist monotherapy after deep brain stimulation (DBS) in PD.
abstract.3: Methods: Thirty-five surgical candidates were randomly assigned to receive postoperative monotherapy with either levodopa or dopamine agonist in a randomized, single-blind study.
abstract.4: All patients were reevaluated in short- (3 months), mid- (6 months), and long-term (2.5 years) follow-up after surgery.
abstract.5: The primary outcome measure was the change in the Non-Motor Symptoms Scale (NMSS) 3 months after surgery.
abstract.6: Secondary outcome measures were the percentage of patients maintaining monotherapy, change in motor symptoms, and specific non-motor symptoms (NMS).
abstract.7: Analysis was performed primarily in the intention-to-treat population.
abstract.8: Results: Randomization did not significantly affect the primary outcome (difference in NMSS between treatment groups was 4.88 [95% confidence interval: -11.78-21.53, P = 0.566]).
abstract.9: In short- and mid-term follow-up, monotherapy was safe and feasible in more than half of patients (60% in short- and 51.5% in mid-term follow-up), but it was more often possible for patients on levodopa.
abstract.10: The ability to maintain dopamine agonist monotherapy was related to optimal contact location.
abstract.11: In the long term, levodopa monotherapy was feasible only in a minority of patients (34.2%), whereas dopamine agonist monotherapy was not tolerated due to worsening of motor conditions or occurrence of impulse control disorders.
abstract.12: Conclusions: This trial provides evidence for simplifying pharmacological treatment after functional neurosurgery for PD.
abstract.13: The reduction in dopamine receptor agonists should be attempted while monitoring for occurrence of NMSs, such as apathy and sleep disturbances.

adaptation1.1: No clinical trials with patients have been developed to compare medical treatments after surgery in Parkinson's disease (a brain disorder that affects movement and coordination).
adaptation1.2: The objective of this study is to compare the performance and safety of levodopa (a drug that enters the brain and helps replace missing dopamine, a chemical that carries signals between brain cells) versus dopamine agonist (a drug that imitates the actions of dopamine in the body) single therapy after deep brain stimulation (surgery that implants devices to stimulate certain areas of the brain) in patients with Parkinson's disease.
adaptation1.3: In this study, 35 patients who are planning to undergo surgery are randomly assigned to receive either levodopa or dopamine agonist after surgery.
adaptation1.4: All patients are evaluated in short (3 months), mid (6 months), and long-term (2.5 years) follow-up appointments after the surgery.
adaptation1.5: The key outcome (result) researchers planned to evaluate is the change in the Non-Motor Symptoms Scale, a scale to count and measure severity of non-motor (unrelated to movement) symptoms such as pain and tiredness, 3 months after surgery.
adaptation1.6: A second outcome is the percent of patients staying on only one drug, change in motor (movement) symptoms, and specific non-motor symptoms.
adaptation1.7: The analysis mainly focuses on the patients who were enrolled and randomly assigned to treatment.
adaptation1.8: Being randomly assigned into treatments did not significantly affect the key outcome from the Non-Motor Symptoms Scale between the two treatment groups.
adaptation1.9: In the 3-month and 6-month follow-up appointments, single therapy (only one drug) is safe and practical in more than half of patients, but it was more often possible for patients on levodopa.
adaptation1.10: The ability to maintain dopamine agonist as the only treatment drug is related to the best contact location.
adaptation1.11: In the 2.5 year follow-up, levodopa single therapy is feasible only in a small number of patients, whereas dopamine agonist single therapy is not tolerated (unable to handle side effects) due to worsening of motor conditions or occurrence of impulse control disorders (disorders in which temptations or thoughts cannot be resisted).
adaptation1.12: In conclusion, this study provides evidence for simplifying drug treatment after brain surgery for Parkinson's disease.
adaptation1.13: The reduction in dopamine agonists should be attempted while monitoring for development of non-motor symptoms, such as lack of motivation and sleep disturbances.

19.question: Does prescribing dopamine in the early stages of parkinson’s disease help patients?

abstract.1: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a recently developed class of drugs with significantly greater antidepressant efficacy than placebo.
abstract.2: Generally, in double-blind comparative trials, all SSRIs demonstrated antidepressant efficacy similar to that of the 'standard' tricyclic antidepressants amitriptyline and imipramine; a meta-analysis of controlled trials found the efficacy of the SSRIs to be equivalent to that of the 2 tricyclics.
abstract.3: Nevertheless, because of small patient numbers included in most studies that compare SSRIs with other antidepressants, no definitive statements about relative efficacy can be made.
abstract.4: In these studies it is simply possible to state that no statistically significant differences were identified between SSRIs and the comparative antidepressants.
abstract.5: Importantly, differences in clinical characteristics exist between the SSRIs-differences in elimination half-life (t1/2 beta) between fluoxetine and/or its metabolite (total t1/2 beta = 330 hours) and other SSRIs (t1/2 beta range = 15 to 30 hours), for example.
abstract.6: This has implications in terms of potential drug interactions and must be considered when patients have to be switched to treatment with monoamine oxidase inhibitors.
abstract.7: Studies with fluvoxamine have been conducted in both in- and outpatients, whereas trials with other SSRIs have been confined largely to outpatient populations.
abstract.8: Fluvoxamine has been associated with a high incidence of nausea (37%), although this may have resulted from high initial dosages (rather than upward dose titration protocols) used in early trials.
abstract.9: Of further interest, fluoxetine doses of 20mg may be sufficient to produce a satisfactory antidepressant response, and this SSRI may be particularly useful in patients with chronic retarded depression.
abstract.10: More clinical data are required before the efficacy of sertraline and citalopram relative to standard antidepressants can be clearly defined.
abstract.11: Preliminary data indicate that SSRIs are effective in the treatment of panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), eating (e.g. anorexia and bulimia) and personality disorders (e.g. anger, impulsiveness) and substance abuse (e.g. alcoholism); early results with fluvoxamine in the treatment of panic disorder and OCD, and with fluoxetine in the treatment of bulimia, personality disorders and alcohol abuse, have been encouraging.
abstract.12: SSRIs have a more favourable tolerability profile than tricyclic antidepressants and, unlike the tricyclics, are not associated with anticholinergic adverse effects, sedation, cardiotoxicity or weight gain.
abstract.13: SSRIs are associated with a relatively high incidence of nausea, particularly if high doses are used at the start of treatment.
abstract.14: However, the incidence of nausea appears to decrease as treatment is continued.

adaptation1.1: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are a recently developed type of drugs that works better as an antidepressant than a placebo, a type of substance that looks like a real pill but is not the real medicine.
adaptation1.2: In clinical studies, all SSRIs showed that they have similar effectiveness as standard antidepressants that are older types of medicines.
adaptation1.3: However, because of the small patient numbers in most studies that compare SSRIs with other antidepressants, no definite statements on how the effectiveness compares between the two types of drugs can be made.
adaptation1.4: In these studies, it is simply possible to state that no significant differences based on data analysis are identified between SSRIs and the other type of antidepressants they are being compared to.
adaptation1.5: Importantly, differences in medical features and measures exist between the SSRIs, including differences in the time it takes for the amount of the drug in the body to be reduced to half its starting amount between fluoxetine (a type of antidepressant also called prozac) and other SSRIs.
adaptation1.6: The findings from these existing studies may lead to other effects, including how two or more drugs react to one another which must be considered when patients are switched to treatment with an earlier antidepressant.
adaptation1.7: The structure of clinical studies differs between fluvoxamine, which includes inpatients and outpatients, and other SSRIs which mainly take place in outpatient settings.
adaptation1.8: Fluvoxamine is associated with a high frequency of nausea (37%), although this may be the result from patients starting with a high dose that are often used in early trials instead of the standard dose.
adaptation1.9: Additionally, fluoxetine doses of 20mg may be enough to produce a satisfactory antidepressant response, and this SSRI may be particularly useful in patients with chronic retarded depression, a depression disorder where symptoms include slow movement and toneless speech.
adaptation1.10: More clinical data are needed before the effectiveness of sertraline and citalopram (two other SSRIs) relative to standard antidepressants can be clearly defined.
adaptation1.11: Early data suggests that SSRIs are effective in the treatment of panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), eating (e.g. anorexia and bulimia) and personality disorders (e.g. anger, impulsiveness) and substance abuse (e.g. alcoholism). There are encouraging early results with fluvoxamine in the treatment of panic disorder and OCD, and with fluoxetine in the treatment of bulimia, personality disorders and alcohol abuse.
adaptation1.12: Patients are able to handle the side effects of SSRIs better than tricyclic antidepressants and, unlike the tricyclics, SSRIs are not associated with adverse effects of anticholinergic drugs that treat a number of health problems, sedation, damage to the heart, or weight gain.
adaptation1.13: SSRIs are associated with a high count of nausea, particularly if high doses are used at the start of treatment.
adaptation1.14: However, the frequency of nausea appears to decrease as treatment is continued.

adaptation2.1: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which increase serotonin, are recent, notable antidepressant drugs.
adaptation2.2: SSRIs show similar success to other common antidepressants like amitriptyline and imipramine.
adaptation2.3: Still, since the studies have small patient samples, no definite statements about the relative antidepressant success of SSRIs can be made.
adaptation2.4: In these studies, no difference was identified between SSRIs and other antidepressants.
adaptation2.5: Importantly, SSRIs have differences like effect duration among other antidepressant medications like fluoxetine.

adaptation2.9: 20 mg of flueoxetine may give a decent antidepressant response and be useful for those with long-lasting, movement-inhibiting depression.
adaptation2.10: More data is needed to define the success of other antidepressant selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors like sertraline and citalopram.
adaptation2.11: SSRIs like fluvoxamine and fluoxetine seem to help treat a variety of mental illnesses other than depression.

adaptation2.14: However, the frequency of nausea may decrease as treatment continues.

abstract.1: Twenty-five patients with a primary DSM-III-R diagnosis of panic disorder with or without agoraphobia were treated openly with the serotonin uptake inhibitor fluoxetine for up to 12 months.
abstract.2: For most patients, treatment was initiated at 5 mg/day to minimize adverse effects previously reported with initiation at higher doses.
abstract.3: Nineteen (76%) experienced moderate to marked improvement in panic attacks.
abstract.4: Four (16%) were unable to tolerate fluoxetine due to adverse effects.
abstract.5: Initiating treatment of panic disorder with low doses of fluoxetine may increase its acceptability and permit more patients to benefit from fluoxetine.

adaptation1.1: Fluoxetine is a type of antidepressant that is also called prozac. Twenty-five patients with a diagnosis of panic disorder, a type of anxiety with unexpected events of intense fear, who either did or did not have agoraphobia (an intense fear of open spaces or leaving the home) are treated openly with fluoxetine for up to 12 months.
adaptation1.2: For most patients, treatment is started at 5 mg/day to minimize side effects that is connected with starting the medication at a higher dose.
adaptation1.3: Nineteen (76%) experienced small to major improvement in panic attacks.
adaptation1.4: Four (16%) were unable to handle fluoxetine because of side effects.
adaptation1.5: Starting treatment of panic disorder with low doses of fluoxetine may increase its acceptability and allow more patients to benefit from fluoxetine.

adaptation2.1: Twenty-five patients with panic disorder were treated with the serotonin uptake inhibitor fluoxetine (a common antidepressant) for up to 12 months.
adaptation2.2: For most, treatment started with 5 mg/day to reduce side effects.
adaptation2.3: Nineteen (76%) showed improvement in panic attacks.
adaptation2.4: Four (16%) could not stand fluoxetine due to its side effects.
adaptation2.5: Using low starting doses of fluoxetine for panic disorders may improve its acceptability and use.

7852252.Title: Relapse in patients on long-term fluoxetine treatment: response to increased fluoxetine dose

abstract.1: Background: Although several studies have examined the long-term efficacy of antidepressants, relatively little attention has been paid to the management of relapses or recurrences during continued antidepressant treatment.
abstract.2: This study examined whether depressed patients who had recovered and then relapsed on fluoxetine 20 mg/day would benefit from an increase in fluoxetine dose.
abstract.3: Method: Eighteen patients who relapsed on fluoxetine 20 mg/day during long-term treatment with fluoxetine as part of a placebo-controlled study had their fluoxetine dose raised to 40 mg/day and were followed for at least 1 month (mean time = 4.7 months).
abstract.4: Results: Twelve (67%) were full responders, 3 (17%) partial responders, and 3 (17%) dropped out because of side effects (e.g., insomnia and agitation).
abstract.5: Of those patients who had either full or partial response (N = 15; 83%), 3 complete responders had a recurrence on 40 mg/day after a mean of 5.8 months and 1 partial responder had a recurrence 11 months later.
abstract.6: Overall, 11 (61%) of 18 patients maintained their response during their follow-up while taking the higher dose of fluoxetine.
abstract.7: Conclusion: An increase in dose of fluoxetine to 40 mg/day appears to be an effective strategy in the treatment of relapse among depressed patients who had initially responded to fluoxetine 20 mg/day.

adaptation1.1: Antidepressants are medications used to treat depression and other disorders and can improve mood, sleep quality, and concentration. Although several studies have examined how well antidepressants work long-term, there is little attention on how to manage relapses (the worsening of a medical condition that had previously improved) or recurrences (when symptoms return months or years after a person has recovered from the last episode) during continued use of antidepressant drugs.
adaptation1.2: This study examined whether depressed patients who had recovered and then relapsed on fluoxetine (a type of antidepressant also called prozac) at 20 mg/day will benefit from an increase dose of fluoxetine.
adaptation1.3: In this study, 18 patients who relapsed on fluoxetine 20 mg/day during long-term treatment with fluoxetine as part of a larger study had their fluoxetine dose raised to 40 mg/day and were followed for at least 1 month.
adaptation1.4: Twelve (67%) were full responders (patients who reached the expected improvement), 3 (17%) partial responders (patients who reached only part of the expected improvement), and 3 (17%) dropped out of the study because of side effects (e.g. insomnia and agitation).
adaptation1.5: Of those 15 patients who had either full or partial response, 3 complete responders had a recurrence on 40 mg/day after an average of 5.8 months and 1 partial responder had a recurrence 11 months later.
adaptation1.6: Overall, 11 (61%) of 18 patients still reacted to the drug during their follow-up while taking the higher dose of fluoxetine.
adaptation1.7: In conclusion, an increase in dose of fluoxetine to 40 mg/day appears to be an effective way to help treat relapse among people with depression who had initially responded to fluoxetine at 20 mg/day.

10917403.Title: Weekly dosing of fluoxetine for the continuation phase of treatment of major depression: results of a placebo-controlled, randomized clinical trial

abstract.1: Fluoxetine (FLX) has a unique pharmacokinetic profile.
abstract.2: Its major metabolite, norfluoxetine (NFLX), possesses FLX's antidepressant efficacy and a half-life of 7 to 15 days, suggesting the possibility of nonstandard dosing strategies.
abstract.3: This study examined the tolerability of a weekly dose and its equivalence to daily dosing of FLX for the continuation phase of treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD).
abstract.4: One hundred fourteen subjects initially received open-label treatment with 20 mg of FLX daily for 7 weeks.
abstract.5: Subsequently, 70 subjects with a score on the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) of 12 or less were randomly assigned in a double-blind design to one of three treatment groups: 20 mg FLX daily (N = 21), 60 mg FLX weekly (N = 28), or placebo (N = 21) and were followed for 7 weeks.
abstract.6: HAM-D scores and blood levels of FLX and NFLX were analyzed using a repeated-measures analysis of variance.
abstract.7: During the double-blind phase, blood levels for both FLX and NFLX differed across the treatment groups, yet no statistically significant difference in HAM-D scores was observed.
abstract.8: There was no difference in the dropout rate across the groups.
abstract.9: Subjects could not correctly identify the treatment group into which they were assigned.
abstract.10: Weekly dosing of FLX seems to be well tolerated and possibly as effective as daily dosing in maintaining the therapeutic response in subjects with MDD.

adaptation1.1: Fluoxetine is a type of antidepressant that is also called prozac.
adaptation1.2: There is the possibility that fluoxetine can be given to patients in dose amounts that is different from the regular doses of other medications.
adaptation1.3: In order to study the treatment for major depressive disorder, this study examined how well patients handled a weekly dose of fluoxetine and then monitored the same amount but given daily during a following phase of the study.
adaptation1.4: In this study, 114 patients first receive treatment with 20 mg of fluoxetine daily for 7 weeks.
adaptation1.5: Next, 70 patients are randomly assigned to one of three treatment groups: 20 mg fluoxetine daily with 21 subjects, 60 mg fluoxetine weekly with 28 patients, or placebo of an inactive substance that looks like the drug with 21patients and are followed for 7 weeks.
adaptation1.6: Scores for depression using a rating scale and blood levels of fluoxetine and norfluoxetine, another form of fluoxetine, are analyzed.
adaptation1.7: Blood levels for both fluoxetine and norfluoxetine differ across the three treatment groups, but there are no major differences in the scores for depression observed.
adaptation1.8: There is no difference in the rate of patients who dropped out of the study across the groups.
adaptation1.9: Patients cannot correctly identify the treatment group into which they were assigned.
adaptation1.10: Weekly dosing of fluoxetine seems to be handled well by patients and is  possibly as effective as daily dosing for treating patients with major depressive disorder.

12097783.Title: Treatment approaches to major depressive disorder relapse. Part 1: dose increase

abstract.1: Objective: Although continuing antidepressant treatment after patients have responded to medication has been shown to greatly reduce the risk of relapse, this risk is not eliminated.
abstract.2: A number of theories have been proposed to account for this apparent loss of efficacy.
abstract.3: A common initial approach to managing relapse is to increase the dose of antidepressant.
abstract.4: We prospectively evaluated the likelihood of response to increasing the fluoxetine doses in patients relapsing during a long-term efficacy study of two fluoxetine dosing regimens.
abstract.5: Method: Patients meeting the DSM-IV criteria for major depressive disorder with modified HAMD17 scores > or =18 and CGI-severity scores > or =4 were treated for 13 weeks with open-label 20 mg/day fluoxetine in a multicenter US study.
abstract.6: Responders (n = 501) were randomized to 20 mg fluoxetine daily, placebo, or 90 mg enteric-coated fluoxetine weekly for 25 weeks of double-blind continuation treatment.
abstract.7: If the patients relapsed during the continuation phase, they were offered a 25-week optional rescue treatment phase during which the study medication dose was increased as follows: (1) patients on placebo had treatment with fluoxetine 20 mg/day reinitiated, (2) patients on fluoxetine 20 mg/day had their dose increased to 40 mg/day, and (3) patients on a 90-mg weekly dose had their dose increased to 90 mg twice a week.
abstract.8: The results of the rescue phase for the latter two groups who relapsed while on continuation treatment with fluoxetine are reported.
abstract.9: Response was defined as a 50% reduction in the modified HAMD17 score since time of relapse and a CGI-severity score < or =2.
abstract.10: Additional efficacy analyses included HAMD and CGI-severity changes from baseline to endpoint.
abstract.11: Safety measures included assessment of treatment-emergent adverse events, vital signs, and laboratory measures.
abstract.12: Results: Overall, patients relapsing during the continuation treatment responded to an increased dose (57% of the 40-mg-daily group and 72% of the enteric-coated 90-mg-twice-weekly group).
abstract.13: Mean modified HAMD17 scores decreased from a mean of approximately 20 to below 8 and were maintained for up to 6 months in the responders.
abstract.14: Thirty-five percent of patients either did not respond or initially responded but again relapsed after augmentation of medication.
abstract.15: Conclusions: The patients relapsing after initially responding to fluoxetine can benefit from an increase in fluoxetine dose.
abstract.16: These results also generally support increasing dose as a first-line treatment strategy for a patient who has relapsed while taking a previously effective dose of an antidepressant.
abstract.17: Increasing enteric-coated fluoxetine 90 mg once weekly to twice weekly appeared to be as well-tolerated and effective in restoring response as increasing a daily fluoxetine dose from 20 to 40 mg.

adaptation1.1: Continuing treatment with antidepressants after patients have responded to medication has been shown to greatly reduce the risk of relapse, which is when a medical condition that had previously improved starts to worsen. However, the risk of a relapse is not completely eliminated.
adaptation1.2: A number of theories have been suggested to account for this possible decline in how well antidepressant medicines work.
adaptation1.3: A common first approach to help a patient who is relapsing is to increase the dose of the antidepressant medicine.
adaptation1.4: Researchers evaluated the chance patients will respond to an increase in the dose of fluoxetine (a type of antidepressant also called prozac) in patients relapsing during a long-term study of two different dosing plans of fluoxetine.
adaptation1.5: Patients who have major depressive disorder are treated for 13 weeks with 20 mg/day of fluoxetine in a large US study.
adaptation1.6: The 501 patients who responded to the medicine are randomly put into either the group receiving 20 mg/day of fluoxetine, the group receiving sham treatment that has the appearance of the drug but is not the real medicine, or 90 mg of fluoxetine weekly. They will be in these groups for 25 weeks during a part of the study called the continuation phase.
adaptation1.7: If the patients relapse during the continuation phase, they are offered a different 25-week treatment plan called a rescue phase where the study medication dose is increased as 1) patients on placebo will restart fluoxetine at 20 mg/day, 2) patients on fluoxetine 20 mg/day will have their dose increased to 40 mg/day, and 3) patients on the 90-mg weekly dose will have their dose increased to 90-mg twice a week.
adaptation1.8: The results of the rescue phase the patients in group 2 (who received 20 mg/day) and group 3 (who received the 90-mg weekly).
adaptation1.9: Researchers used scoring tools that measure depression severity and seeing how much the depression scores are reduced since the time of the last relapse.
adaptation1.10: Additional analyses to evaluate how well the medicine worked include changes in these scoring tools from the start of the study to the end.
adaptation1.11: Safety checks include assessment of unexpected side effects, vital signs (e.g. blood pressure, temperature), and tests done in a lab.
adaptation1.12: Overall, patients relapsing during the continuation treatment phase responded to an increased dose (57% of the 40-mg-daily group and 72% of the 90-mg-twice-weekly group).
adaptation1.13: The average score of the tool that measure depression severity decreased and was maintained for up to 6 months in the people who responded.
adaptation1.14: There are 35 patients who either did not respond or responded at first but then relapsed after increasing medication.
adaptation1.15: In conclusion, patients who relapsed after first responding to fluoxetine can benefit from an increase in the dose amount of fluoxetine.
adaptation1.16: These results also generally support increasing the dose as a first-line treatment plan for a patient who has relapsed while taking a previously effective dose of an antidepressant.
adaptation1.17: Increasing fluoxetine 90 mg once weekly to twice weekly appears to have side effects that patients can handle and is just as effective in restoring response as when daily fluoxetine dose is increased from 20 mg to 40 mg.

12352270.Title: Effects of adding cognitive therapy to fluoxetine dose increase on risk of relapse and residual depressive symptoms in continuation treatment of major depressive disorder

abstract.1: Patients with major depressive disorder remain at risk for relapse following remission and often continue to experience subthreshold symptoms.
abstract.2: This study examined whether depressed patients who had recovered and then relapsed on fluoxetine 20 mg/day would benefit from an increase in fluoxetine dose.
abstract.3: A total of 132 outpatients with major depressive disorder who achieved remission with 8 weeks of treatment with fluoxetine 20 mg had the dose increased to 40 mg.
abstract.4: They were randomized to receive cognitive therapy or medication management alone and were followed for up to 28 weeks for depressive relapse and change in depressive symptoms.
abstract.5: A total of 47 (35.6%) out of 132 patients did not complete the 28-week continuation phase.
abstract.6: Rates of discontinuation or relapse did not differ significantly between the groups.
abstract.7: Change in residual symptoms or wellbeing as measured by Hamilton Depression Scale score or Symptom Questionnaire self-report also did not differ between groups.
abstract.8: In this sample of outpatients in continuation phase treatment for major depressive disorder, the combination of cognitive therapy and fluoxetine 40 mg failed to yield any significant benefit in symptoms or relapse rates over fluoxetine 40 mg alone during 28 weeks of follow-up.

adaptation1.1: Patients with major depressive disorder (a mental health disorder where a person is in a constant depressed mood or has a loss of interest in activities) remain at risk for relapse (the worsening of a medical condition that had previously improved) following remission (a period of improvement where the patient is mostly asymptomatic) and often continue to experience subthreshold symptoms in which a person has  symptoms but the symptoms do not meet the full criteria for a medical diagnosis.
adaptation1.2: This study examines whether depressed patients who had recovered and then relapsed while on fluoxetine (a type of antidepressant also called prozac) at 20 mg/day would benefit from an increase in fluoxetine dose.
adaptation1.3: A total of 132 patients with major depressive disorder who achieved remission with 8 weeks of treatment with fluoxetine at 20 mg had the dose increased to 40mg.
adaptation1.4: They are randomly put in groups to receive cognitive therapy (a type of behavior therapy that focuses on challenging negative thoughts that can worsen emotional difficulties) or to receive medication only. Patients are followed for up to 28 weeks to check for depressive relapse and changes in depressive symptoms.
adaptation1.5: A total of 47 out of 132 patients did not complete the 28 weeks phase of the study.
adaptation1.6: Rates of stopping  the drug or relapsing did not differ significantly between the group receiving cognitive therapy and the group only receiving medication.
adaptation1.7: Changes in subthreshold symptoms or wellbeing did not differ between groups.
adaptation1.8: In this sample of patients being treated for major depressive disorder, the combination of cognitive therapy and fluoxetine at 40 mg failed to lead to any significant benefit in symptoms or in relapse rates over fluoxetine 40 mg alone during the 28 week follow-up period.

adaptation2.1: Those with depression may fall back after temporary improvement and still experience minor symptoms.
adaptation2.2: This work compares the rate of re-suffering depression and the frequency of depressive symptoms between patients treated with fluoxetine (an antidepressant medication) alone or with thought therapy.
adaptation2.3: 132 patients with temporary improvement from depression after 8 weeks with 20 mg of fluoxetine had the dose increased to 40 mg.
adaptation2.4: The patients randomly received either cognitive or thought therapy or medication management and were monitored for changes in symptoms or regression for 28 weeks.
adaptation2.5: 47 patients did not complete the 28-week phase.
adaptation2.6: Rates of non-completion or regression did not differ between groups.
adaptation2.7: Change in depressive symptoms did not differ between groups.
adaptation2.8: In this work, cognitive or thought therapy with 40 mg of fluoxetine did not give additional benefit compared to fluoxetine 40 mg alone during the 28 weeks of follow-up.

19445546.Title: Pediatric generalized anxiety disorder: epidemiology, diagnosis, and management

abstract.1: Pediatric generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive and uncontrollable worry about a variety of events and is accompanied by physical symptoms such as headaches, tension, restlessness, gastrointestinal distress, and heart palpitations.
abstract.2: Symptoms impose marked distress and interfere with social, emotional, and educational functioning.
abstract.3: GAD occurs in over 10% of children and adolescents, has an average age of onset of 8.5 years, and is more often reported in girls.
abstract.4: Common co-occurring conditions include separation anxiety disorder and social phobia.
abstract.5: Assessment involves a multi-informant, multi-method approach involving the child, parents, and school teachers.
abstract.6: A clinical interview should be conducted to assess for the three primary ways anxiety presents: behaviors, thoughts, and somatic symptoms.
abstract.7: Several semi-structured diagnostic interviews are available, and the Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule is increasingly used.
abstract.8: Rating scales completed by the patient, caregivers, and teachers provide useful information for diagnosis and symptom monitoring.
abstract.9: Several scales are available to assess patients for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th Edition) GAD diagnosis; however, instruments generally cannot distinguish children with GAD from children with similar anxiety disorders.
abstract.10: Both cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) have demonstrated efficacy for the treatment of pediatric anxiety disorders including GAD.
abstract.11: Evidence suggests that the combination of CBT plus sertraline offers additional benefit compared with either treatment alone.
abstract.12: With pharmacotherapy, systematic tracking of treatment-emergent adverse events such as headaches, stomach aches, behavioral activation, worsening symptoms, and emerging suicidal thoughts is important.
abstract.13: Recommended starting doses are fluvoxamine 25 mg/day, fluoxetine 10 mg/day, and sertraline 25 mg/day, though lower starting doses are possible.
abstract.14: Dosing can be adjusted as often as weekly with the goal of achieving a high-quality response, while minimizing side effects.
abstract.15: Long-term treatment with medication has not been well studied; however, to achieve optimal long-term outcome extended use of medication may be required.
abstract.16: It is recommended to continue medication for approximately 1 year following remission in symptoms, and when discontinuing medication to choose a stress-free time of the year.
abstract.17: If symptoms return, medication re-initiation should be considered seriously.

adaptation1.1: In children, generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) includes having more than normal and uncontrollable worry about different events and is also includes physical symptoms such as headaches, tension, restlessness, digestive problems, and a racing heartbeat.
adaptation1.2: Symptoms interfere with social, emotional, and educational experiences.
adaptation1.3: GAD occurs in over 10% of children and adolescents and usually starts at the age of 8.5 years. GAD is more often reported in girls.
adaptation1.4: Common conditions that occur with GAD include getting very anxious when separated from family or the main caregiver and social phobia, an intense fear of being in front of others or being watched or judged.
adaptation1.5: Multiple methods are used to test for GAD and includes the child, parents, and school teachers.
adaptation1.6: An interview is recommended to look for the three main ways anxiety is shown: behaviors, thoughts, and somatic (physical) symptoms.
adaptation1.7: Several interview formats to make a diagnosis are available. The Anxiety Disorders Interview Schedule is increasingly used.
adaptation1.8: Ratings scales are completed by the patient, caregivers, and teachers and provide useful information for diagnosis and symptom monitoring.
adaptation1.9: Several scales are able to make a GAD diagnosis which is a diagnosis based on the well-known handbook of mental disorders used by many providers; however, interview tools usually cannot make the distinction between children with GAD and children with similar anxiety disorders.
adaptation1.10: Cognitive-behavioral therapy, which is a type of therapy that focuses on challenging negative thoughts that can worsen emotional difficulties, is shown to be a part positive effect for the treatment of GAD. Additionally, a type of antidepressant called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) also show benefits for the treatment of pediatric anxiety disorders including GAD.
adaptation1.11: Evidence suggests that the combination of cognitive-behavioral therapy plus sertraline (an SSRI medication) offers additional benefit when compared with either treatment alone.
adaptation1.12: When using medications for treatment, it is important to monitor and track negative side effects that occur such as headaches, stomach aches, behavioral activation, worsening symptoms, and emerging suicidal thoughts.
adaptation1.13: Recommended starting doses of SSRIs are fluvoxamine 25 mg/day, fluoxetine 10 mg/day, and sertraline 25 mg/day, though starting with lower doses is possible.
adaptation1.14: Dosing can be changed as often as weekly with the goal of achieving a high-quality response, while minimizing side effects.
adaptation1.15: Long-term treatment with medication has not been well studied; however, to reach the best long-term outcome, extended use of the medication may be required.
adaptation1.16: It is recommended to continue medication for about 1 year after remission in symptoms, and to choose a stress-free time of the year when stopping medication.
adaptation1.17: If symptoms return, restarting the medication should be considered seriously.

31178367.Title: Optimal dose of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, venlafaxine, and mirtazapine in major depression: a systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis

abstract.1: Background: Depression is the single largest contributor to non-fatal health loss worldwide.
abstract.2: Second-generation antidepressants are the first-line option for pharmacological management of depression.
abstract.3: Optimising their use is crucial in reducing the burden of depression; however, debate about their dose dependency and their optimal target dose is ongoing.
abstract.4: We have aimed to summarise the currently available best evidence to inform this clinical question.
abstract.5: Findings: 28 554 records were identified through our search (24 524 published and 4030 unpublished records).
abstract.6: 561 published and 121 unpublished full-text records were assessed for eligibility, and 77 studies were included (19 364 participants; mean age 42·5 years, SD 11·0; 7156 [60·9%] of 11 749 reported were women).
abstract.7: For SSRIs (99 treatment groups), the dose-efficacy curve showed a gradual increase up to doses between 20 mg and 40 mg fluoxetine equivalents, and a flat to decreasing trend through the higher licensed doses up to 80 mg fluoxetine equivalents.
abstract.8: Dropouts due to adverse effects increased steeply through the examined range.
abstract.9: The relationship between the dose and dropouts for any reason indicated optimal acceptability for the SSRIs in the lower licensed range between 20 mg and 40 mg fluoxetine equivalents.
abstract.10: Venlafaxine (16 treatment groups) had an initially increasing dose-efficacy relationship up to around 75-150 mg, followed by a more modest increase, whereas for mirtazapine (11 treatment groups) efficacy increased up to a dose of about 30 mg and then decreased.
abstract.11: Both venlafaxine and mirtazapine showed optimal acceptability in the lower range of their licensed dose.
abstract.12: These results were robust to several sensitivity analyses.
abstract.13: Interpretation: For the most commonly used second-generation antidepressants, the lower range of the licensed dose achieves the optimal balance between efficacy, tolerability, and acceptability in the acute treatment of major depression.

adaptation1.1: Depression is the single largest contributor to non-fatal health loss worldwide.
adaptation1.2: New antidepressants, also called second-generation antidepressants, (medications used to treat depression and other disorders and can improve mood, sleep quality, and concentration) are the first-line option for managing depression using medication.
adaptation1.3: Their use is important to reduce the burden of depression; however, there is ongoing debate about their dose dependency (when the effects of a drug change when the dose of the drug is changed) and the best target dose (the dose that achieves a target effect).
adaptation1.4: We have aimed to summarize the best available evidence to inform this clinical question.
adaptation1.5: Researchers found 28,554 records by searching published and unpublished records.
adaptation1.6: Among those records, 561 published and 121 unpublished records that have complete text are reviewed, and 77 are included in the final analysis.
adaptation1.7: For SSRIs or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (a type of antidepressant that can increase the amount of serotonin, a mood stabilizer), the dose-efficacy curve (relationship between an effect of a drug and the amount of drug given) showed a gradual increase up to doses between 20mg and 40mg fluoxetine (a type of SSRI also called prozac), and a flat to decreasing trend through the higher doses up to 80 mg fluoxetine equivalents.
adaptation1.8: Some patients dropped out due to side effects.
adaptation1.9: The relationship between the dose of the drug and dropouts for any reason suggests the best acceptability for using SSRIs is in the lower licensed range between 20 mg and 40 mg fluoxetine equivalents.
adaptation1.10: Venlafaxine (a type of antidepressant) has an initially increasing  relationship between dose amount and drug performance up to 75-150mg, followed by a more modest increase, whereas for another antidepressant called mirtazapine, performance increased up to a dose of about 30 mg and then decreased.
adaptation1.11: Both venlafaxine and mirtazapine worked well in the lower range of their licensed dose.
adaptation1.12: These results performed well in several sensitivity analyses to assess strength and uncertainty in a study.
adaptation1.13: For the most common newer antidepressants, the lower range of the dose achieves the best balance between performance, tolerability (the degree to which drugs' negative effects can be handled by patients), and acceptability in the treatment of major depression.

33404081.Title: Low SSRI dosing in clinical practice-a register-based longitudinal study

abstract.1: Objective: Since several recent meta-analyses report a dose-response relationship for the antidepressant effect of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), we investigated how these drugs are dosed in clinical practice.
abstract.2: Methods: Through linkage of nation- or region-wide registers, we describe SSRI doses in 50,365 individuals residing in Region Västra Götaland, Sweden, with an incident diagnosis of depression and initiating SSRI treatment between 2007 and 2016.
abstract.3: The primary question was to elucidate to what extent these individuals had been prescribed a daily dose that according to recent meta-analyses is required to elicit the maximum antidepressant effect, that is >20 mg citalopram, >10 mg escitalopram, >10 mg fluoxetine, >10 mg paroxetine or >50 mg sertraline.
abstract.4: Results: In all, 21,049 (54%) out of 38,868 individuals <65 years of age, and 9,131 (79%) out of 11,497 individuals ≥65 years of age, never received an SSRI dose reported to exert maximum antidepressant effect.
abstract.5: These prescribing practices were seen for citalopram, escitalopram and sertraline, but not for fluoxetine and paroxetine, and were frequent in both primary and secondary/tertiary care.
abstract.6: Suggesting that doses here defined as maximum efficacy doses, when prescribed, are usually not intolerable, between 59% and 68% of individuals <65 years of age received such a dose also for the subsequent prescription, that is as frequently as in those prescribed a sub-maximum efficacy dose (52-69%).
abstract.7: Conclusion: Most patients being prescribed an SSRI to treat their depression never receive the dose that according to recent meta-analyses is most likely to effectively combat their condition.
abstract.8: The lack of consensus regarding effective dosing of SSRIs may have contributed to this state of affairs.

adaptation1.1: Several analyses using data from multiple studies have found a relationship between the amount of a medicine given (dose) and its effect in a type of antidepressant called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). The objective of this study is to investigate how these SSRI drugs are dosed in doctor's offices and health clinics.
adaptation1.2: Researchers describe SSRI doses in 50,365 people living in a specific region in Sweden, with a diagnosis of depression and starting SSRI treatment between 2007 and 2016.
adaptation1.3: The main question is to explain the extent these people are prescribed a daily dose that is expected to get a peak response that would not go higher with a higher dose, which is > 20 mg of citalopram, >10 mg escitalopram, >10 mg fluoxetine, >10 mg paroxetine or >50 mg sertraline - all SSRIs.
adaptation1.4: Overall, 21,049 (54%) out of 38,868 individuals <65 years of age, and 9,131 (79%) out of 11,497 individuals ≥65 years of age, never receive an SSRI dose reported to bring about a maximum antidepressant effect.
adaptation1.5: These dosing practices are seen for citalopram, escitalopram and sertraline, but not for fluoxetine and paroxetine, and are frequent in both general care and specialized care.
adaptation1.6: Between 59% and 68% of individuals <65 years of age received the maximum efficacy dose (the dose where an increased dose given would not lead to improvement) for the next prescription. That percent is as frequently as in those prescribed a sub-maximum efficacy dose which is the dose that has a lower response despite an increase in the dose amount.
adaptation1.7: In conclusion, most patients taking an SSRI to treat their depression never receive the dose that is most likely to effectively fight their condition based on detailed reviews of available data.
adaptation1.8: The lack of agreement on the effective dose amount of SSRIs may have contributed to this conclusion.

34269321.Title: Misophonia Successfully Treated of With Fluoxetine: A Case Report

abstract.1: Objective: A large number of people experience misophonia.
abstract.2: In 2013, the Amsterdam Study Group recommended diagnostic criteria for misophonia.
abstract.3: However, misophonia is not yet included in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders.
abstract.4: This report is the first report on drug use that directly affects misophonia and demonstrates a 14-year-old adolescent girl with misophonia successfully treated with fluoxetine.
abstract.5: Methods: The patient's misophonia symptoms had been continuing for approximately 2 years, and her quality of life was significantly reduced.
abstract.6: Psychotherapy conditions could not be applied, and fluoxetine 10 mg/d was started and increased to 20 mg/d after a week.
abstract.7: At the second-month follow-up, because of partial improvement, fluoxetine dose was increased to 30 mg/d.
abstract.8: Results: At the fourth-month follow-up, there was a 40% decrease in Amsterdam Misophonia Scale score with a 70% decrease in the children's global assessment scale scores.
abstract.9: By the 16th week, the overall functionality level was good at the end.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Fluoxetine may be used as an effective drug in the treatment of misophonia.

adaptation1.1: A large number of people experience misophonia (having a strong reaction to specific sounds).
adaptation1.2: In 2013, the Amsterdam Study Group recommended criteria, such as signs and symptoms, to diagnose misophonia.
adaptation1.3: However, misophonia is not yet included in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, a handbook for health care providers to guide the diagnosis of mental disorders.
adaptation1.4: This report is the first report on drug use that directly affects misophonia and shows a 14-year old girl with misophonia who is successfully treated with fluoxetine (a type of antidepressant also called prozac).
adaptation1.5: The patient's misophonia symptoms had been continuing for approximately 2 years, and her quality of life (a patient's ability to enjoy normal, everyday activities) was significantly reduced.
adaptation1.6: Fluoxetine 10 mg/day was started and increased to 20 mg/day after a week.
adaptation1.7: At the second-month follow-up with the patient, because of partial improvement, the fluoxetine dose was increased to 30 mg/day.
adaptation1.8: At the fourth-month follow-up, there was a 40% decrease in Amsterdam Misophonia Scale score (a rating scale to measure how severe symptoms are) with a 70% decrease in the children's global assessment scale scores (a score that measures overall level of functioning).
adaptation1.9: By the 16th week, the overall functionality level was good at the end.
adaptation1.10: In conclusion, fluoxetine may be used as an effective drug in the treatment of misophonia.

20.question: At what strength is prozac usually begun for a patient changing from another antidepressant?

18656819.Title: Approaches to the diagnosis and grading of hiatal hernia

abstract.1: Hiatus hernia refers to conditions in which elements of the abdominal cavity, most commonly the stomach, herniate through the oesophageal hiatus into the mediastinum.
abstract.2: With the most common type (type I or sliding hiatus hernia) this is associated with laxity of the phrenooesophageal membrane and the gastric cardia herniates.
abstract.3: Sliding hiatus hernia is readily diagnosed by barium swallow radiography, endoscopy, or manometry when greater than 2 cm in axial span.
abstract.4: However, the mobility of the oesophagogastric junction precludes the reliable detection of more subtle disruption by endoscopy or radiography.
abstract.5: Detecting lesser degrees of axial separation between the lower oesophageal sphincter and crural diaphragm can only be reliably accomplished with high-resolution manometry, a technique that permits real time localization of these oesophagogastric junction components without swallow or distention related artefact.

adaptation1.1: Hiatus hernia refers to when the upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest.
adaptation1.2: The most common type (type 1 or sliding hiatus hernia), looseness of the ligament that attaches the esophagus to the diaphragm, causes the part of the stomach that is closest to the esophagus to push up.
adaptation1.3: Sliding hiatus hernia is easily diagnosed by a swallowing test during x-ray, a flexible tube with a light and camera attached, or an esophagus test when more than 2 cm along an axis.
adaptation1.4: However, the movement of the junction between the esophagus and stomach doesn't allow for dependable detection of smaller abnormalities using a flexible tube with a light and camera attached or x-ray.
adaptation1.5: Detecting lesser separation between the esophagus and the diaphragm can only be done reliably with a high-resolution esophagus test, which allows a real time location of the parts of the junction between the esophagus and stomach without misrepresentation due to movement.

abstract.1: A Spigelian hernia (or lateral ventral hernia) is a hernia through the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurotic layer between the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the semilunar line laterally.
abstract.2: So far, about 1000 cases have been reported worldwide.
abstract.3: These hernias are difficult to diagnose as they do not present with a subcutaneous swelling and have high risk of going for strangulation.
abstract.4: We discuss the case of a 36 year old female who presented with history of pain and lumpiness in left lower abdomen, both of which decreased on lying down.
abstract.5: She presented to emergency with an episode severe pain at same site which subsided spontaneously.
abstract.6: Diagnosis was confirmed on CT scan, plication and onlay prolene mesh repair performed.
abstract.7: Spigelian hernias are rare, interparietal type of hernias which have high risk undergoing strangulation.
abstract.8: Knowledge of symptoms and signs is vital to diagnosis and treatment of these rare type of hernias.

adaptation1.1: A Spigelian hernia (or lateral ventral hernia involving bulging of digestive organs) develops through muscles found in the abdominal wall.
adaptation1.2: So far, about 1000 of these hernia cases have been seen worldwide.
adaptation1.3: These hernias are hard to diagnose, because they do not cause swelling and often can cut off blood supply to one or more essential organs (e.g., small or large intestine).
adaptation1.4: We look at the case of a 36-year-old female with a history of pain and lumpiness in her left lower stomach, both of which got better when she lay down.
adaptation1.5: She came to the emergency room with severe pain at the same place that went away on its own.
adaptation1.6: A CT scan showed a Spigelian hernia, and a doctor performed surgery.
adaptation1.7: Spigelian hernias are rare and often can cut off blood supply to one or more essential organs.
adaptation1.8: Knowledge of symptoms and signs is important to diagnose and treat these rare hernias.

28828685.Title: Modern diagnosis and treatment of hiatal hernias

abstract.1: Purpose: Hiatal hernias are a common finding on radiographic or endoscopic studies.
abstract.2: Hiatal hernias may become symptomatic or, less frequently, can incarcerate or become a volvulus leading to organ ischemia.
abstract.3: This review examines latest evidence on the diagnostic workup and management of hiatal hernias.
abstract.4: Methods: A literature review of contemporary and latest studies with highest quality of evidence was completed.
abstract.5: This information was examined and compiled in review format.
abstract.6: Results: Asymptomatic hiatal and paraesophageal hernias become symptomatic and necessitate repair at a rate of 1% per year.
abstract.7: Watchful waiting is appropriate for asymptomatic hernias.
abstract.8: Symptomatic hiatal hernias and those with confirmed reflux disease require operative repair with an anti-reflux procedure.
abstract.9: Key operative steps include the following: reduction and excision of hernia sac, 3 cm of intraabdominal esophageal length, crural closure with mesh reinforcement, and an anti-reflux procedure.
abstract.10: Repairs not amenable to key steps may undergo gastropexy and gastrostomy placement as an alternative procedure.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Hiatal hernias are commonly incidental findings.
abstract.12: When hernias become symptomatic or have reflux disease, an operative repair is required.
abstract.13: A minimally invasive approach is safe and has improved outcomes.

adaptation1.1: Hiatal hernias, which occur when the upper part of the stomach pushes up through the diaphragm into the chest, are often found by x-ray and using a long, thin tube with a camera to look inside the body.
adaptation1.2: Hiatal hernias may cause symptoms or, less often, can become trapped or twisted, cutting off blood flow to organs.
adaptation1.3: This review looks at the latest studies on the diagnosis and treatment of hiatal hernias.
adaptation1.4: We reviewed the strongest current and most recent studies.
adaptation1.5: We studied this information and put it in an easily reviewable format.
adaptation1.6: We found that hiatal hernias without symptoms develop symptoms and need repair at a rate of 1% per year.
adaptation1.7: Watching without treatment unless symptoms appear or change is suggested for people with hernias with no symptoms.
adaptation1.8: Hiatal hernias with symptoms and those with stomach acid reflux disease need surgery with an anti-reflux procedure.
adaptation1.9: Surgery has key steps.
adaptation1.10: When these key steps can't be done, stitching the stomach to the diaphragm and inserting a feeding tube is another option.
adaptation1.11: We conclude that hiatal hernias are often found when looking for something else.
adaptation1.12: When hernias cause symptoms or have reflux disease, surgery is needed.
adaptation1.13: A minimally invasive treatment is safe and has improved results.

adaptation2.1: Hiatal hernias, in which the stomach bulges into the chest, are common clinical findings.
adaptation2.2: Hiatal hernias can lead to unwanted symptoms, trapped or twisted intestines, and reduced blood flow to certain body parts.
adaptation2.3: This review examines the latest works on identifying and managing these stomach bulges into the chest.
adaptation2.6: No-symptom stomach or organ bulges into the chest acquire symptoms and need repair at a rate of 1% per year.
adaptation2.7: Watchful waiting is appropriate for these no-symptom organ bulges into the chest.
adaptation2.8: Hiatal hernias with unwanted symptoms and stomach acid reflux into throat need special, anti-reflux surgery.
adaptation2.9: Key surgery steps include: cutting out the bulging sac, 3 cm of the lower esophagus, closing the site with mesh, and an anti-acid reflux operation.
adaptation2.10: Repairs not possible with common surgery may need stitching and opening of the stomach instead.
adaptation2.11: Hiatal hernias are common.
adaptation2.12: When organ bulges lead to awful symptoms or stomach acid reflux, surgery is needed.
adaptation2.13: A small incision surgery is safe and has improved outcomes.

abstract.1: Inguinal hernia is the most frequently diagnosed hernia and during their lifetime one third of males are diagnosed with an inguinal hernia.
abstract.2: The age distribution is bimodal with the highest incidence in childhood and after 50 years of age.
abstract.3: Diagnosis is usually reached through clinical examination of a lump in the inguinal region although some patients can present with intestinal obstruction.
abstract.4: Inguinal hernia repair is the only definitive treatment and is one of the most common surgical procedures performed.
abstract.5: It is usually performed as an elective procedure in local, spinal or general anasthesia.
abstract.6: The repair constitutes of reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, often using a polypropylene mesh; either via an open anterior approach or posteriorly from within the abdomen with laparoscopy.
abstract.7: The most common complications following a hernia repair are recurrent hernia and chronic -discomfort but recurrence rates have improved with the use of mesh and laparoscopic techniques.
abstract.8: This evidence based review describes the -epidemiology and etiology of inguinal hernia together with the most common surgical procedures; focusing on recent innovations.

adaptation1.1: Inguinal hernia, a bulging of digestive organs occurring in the groin area, is the most often diagnosed hernia. During their lifetime one third of males are diagnosed with an inguinal hernia.
adaptation1.2: People are most likely to get an inguinal hernia in childhood and after 50 years old.
adaptation1.3: Doctors usually diagnose an inguinal hernia by a lump in the groin region although some patients can have blocked intestines.
adaptation1.4: Inguinal hernia repair is the only treatment and is one of the most common surgeries done.
adaptation1.5: Surgery is usually non-urgent and done under anesthesia.
adaptation1.6: The repair involves strengthening the area of the groin, often using a plastic mesh; either by traditional or minimally invasive surgery.
adaptation1.7: The most common complications after a hernia repair are the hernia returning and long-term discomfort, but the rate of a hernia returning has gone down with the use of mesh and minimally invasive surgery.
adaptation1.8: This data-driven review describes the spread, contributing factors, and causes of inguinal hernias and the most common surgeries, focusing on recent methods.

adaptation2.1: Inguinal hernias, or organ bulging at the lower ab area, is the most frequent hernia afflicting one third of males.
adaptation2.2: These lower-ab organ bulges occur most frequently in childhood and after 50 years.
adaptation2.3: Clinicians identify these inguinal hernias by a lump in the lower-ab area or when patients have intestinal blockage.
adaptation2.4: Surgery of the lower-ab organ bulge is the only treatment and is very common.
adaptation2.5: Surgery of the lower-ab organ bulge is usually performed with anasthesia.
adaptation2.6: The surgery involves reinforcing the lower abdomen wall with mesh.
adaptation2.7: While long-lasting discomfort and reappearing hernias or organ bulges may follow a hernia repair, the rate of reappearance has improved with mesh and small-incisions.
adaptation2.8: The article reviews the spread and causes of inguinal hernia along with common surgical treatments.

32328842.Title: Imaging modalities for inguinal hernia diagnosis: a systematic review

abstract.1: Purpose: The aim of the study was to determine which diagnostic modality [Computerized Tomography (CT), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), or ultrasound (US)] is more precise in terms of sensitivity and specificity in diagnosing inguinal hernia and sub-type of inguinal hernia (direct or indirect).
abstract.2: Results: Bubble charts depicting the size of each patient cohort and percentual range for both sensitivity and specificity showed that US was better than CT and MRI in diagnosing inguinal hernia.
abstract.3: Bubble charts for US and CT depicted high values within the studies that reported sensitivity and specificity in diagnosing type of hernia.
abstract.4: Conclusions: We found that US had the highest sensitivity and specificity.
abstract.5: However, it must be taken into consideration that performance is highly dependent on the operator's level of expertise.
abstract.6: Based on this systematic review, ultrasound may be the preferred imaging modality when physical examination is inconclusive, given that local expertise in performing US examination for hernia disease is adequate.

adaptation1.1: We aimed to find which diagnostic tool (CT, MRI, or ultrasound) is more accurate for detection and no detection in diagnosing a hernia (bulging of organs) in the groin area and sub-type (direct or indirect; based on location within the groin).
adaptation1.2: Results showed that ultrasound was better than CT and MRI in accuracy for detection and no detection in diagnosing a hernia in the groin region.
adaptation1.3: Results showed ultrasound and CT were very accurate for detection and no detection in diagnosing type of hernia.
adaptation1.4: We found that ultrasound was the most accurate for detection and no detection.
adaptation1.5: One must remember that the expertise level of the person using the diagnostic tool can determine how well the tool works.
adaptation1.6: Based on this review, ultrasound may be the best option when physical exam is uncertain, given that ultrasound is done acceptably at the local level.

abstract.1: Groin hernias are caused by a defect of the abdominal wall in the groin area and comprise inguinal and femoral hernias.
abstract.2: Inguinal hernias are more common in men.
abstract.3: Although groin hernias are easily diagnosed on physical examination in men, ultrasonography is often needed in women.
abstract.4: Ultrasonography is also helpful when a recurrent hernia, surgical complication after repair, or other cause of groin pain (e.g., groin mass, hydrocele) is suspected.
abstract.5: Magnetic resonance imaging has higher sensitivity and specificity than ultrasonography and is useful for diagnosing occult hernias if clinical suspicion is high despite negative ultrasound findings.
abstract.6: Herniography, which involves injecting contrast media into the hernial sac, may be used in selected patients.
abstract.7: Becoming familiar with the common types of surgical interventions can help family physicians facilitate postoperative care and assess for complications, including recurrence.
abstract.8: Laparoscopic repair is associated with shorter recovery time, earlier resumption of activities of daily living, less pain, and lower recurrence rates than open repair.
abstract.9: Watchful waiting is a reasonable and safe option in men with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic inguinal hernias.
abstract.10: Watchful waiting is not recommended in patients with symptomatic hernias or in nonpregnant women.

adaptation1.1: Digestive organs (e.g., intestines) coming out through a weak point or tear in the abdomen causes groin hernias and includes inguinal (groin area) and femoral (upper thigh area) hernias.
adaptation1.2: Inguinal hernias happen more in men.
adaptation1.3: Although groin hernias are easily seen in a physical exam in men, ultrasound is often needed in women.
adaptation1.4: Ultrasound is also helpful when a doctor thinks a hernia has returned, there is a complication after surgery to repair the hernia, or there is another cause of pain (e.g., groin mass, fluid collection in the scrotum).
adaptation1.5: MRI has higher accuracy for detection and no detection than ultrasound and is useful for diagnosing hidden hernias if a doctor thinks it is hernia even if an ultrasound does not show one.
adaptation1.6: Injecting a substance into the hernia sac to improve visibility in x-rays may be used in some patients.
adaptation1.7: Learning about the common types of surgeries can help family doctors improve care after surgery and look for complications, including the hernia returning.
adaptation1.8: Minimally invasive repair has a shorter recovery time, earlier return to daily activities, less pain, and lower return rates than traditional repair.
adaptation1.9: Men with inguinal hernias and with few to no symptoms can reasonably and safely watch the hernia without treatment unless symptoms appear or change.
adaptation1.10: Watching without treatment unless symptoms appear or change is not suggested in people with hernias with symptoms or in nonpregnant women.

34186459.Title: Complicated Littre's umbilical hernia with normal Meckel's diverticulum: A case report and review of the literature

abstract.1: Introduction and importance: A Littre's hernia (LH) is defined by the presence of Meckel's diverticulum (MD) in any kind of hernia sac.
abstract.2: Preoperative diagnosis of LH is a challenge because of its rarity and the absence of specific radiological findings and clinical presentation.
abstract.3: Surgery is the appropriate treatment of complicated LH that is an extremely rare condition with approximately 50 cases reported in the literature over the past 300 years.
abstract.4: Case presentation: A 46-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of abdominal pain.
abstract.5: Physical examination revealed an irreducible and painfull mass in umbilical region.
abstract.6: Abdominal computed tomography scan showed the protrusion of greater omentum and small bowel loop through the umbilical ring.
abstract.7: Laboratory tests were unremarkable.
abstract.8: After diagnosis of strangulated umbilical hernia, the patient underwent exploratory laparotomy: the irreducible umbilical hernial sac was opened with presence of incarcerated and strangulated omentum and uncomplicated MD.
abstract.9: Resection of incarcerated and ischemic greater omentum alone was performed.
abstract.10: The postoperative course of patient was uneventful.
abstract.11: Clinical discussion: Meckel's diverticulum (MD) is a vestigial remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct, representing the most common congenital malformation of the gastrointestinal tract.
abstract.12: Preoperative diagnosis of LH is very difficult and surgery represents the correct treatment of complicated LH.
abstract.13: Conclusion: LH represents an extremely rare complication of MD difficult to diagnose and suspect because of the lack of specific radiological findings and clinical presentation.
abstract.14: Surgery represents the appropriate treatment of abdominal wall hernias and complicated MD.

adaptation1.1: A Littre's hernia (LH) is characterized by Meckel's diverticulum (MD; a pouch on the wall of the lower part of the small intestine present at birth) in any kind of hernia or bulging organ sac.
adaptation1.2: Diagnosing LH before surgery is difficult because it is rare and lacks distinguishing features on x-ray and exam.
adaptation1.3: Surgery is the best treatment for inflamed LH, a very rare condition with about 50 cases reported in scientific papers over the past 300 years.
adaptation1.4: A 46-year-old white woman went to the emergency room after two days of stomach pain.
adaptation1.5: Physical exam showed an irreversible and painful lump near the belly button.
adaptation1.6: Stomach CT scan showed the tissue that covers the intestines and loop of the small intestine pushing out through the muscle that surrounds the belly button.
adaptation1.7: Lab tests were normal.
adaptation1.8: After diagnosis of a hernia near the belly button cutting off blood supply, the patient had abdominal surgery. Doctors opened the irreversible hernia sac and saw tissue that covers the intestines trapped and cut off from blood supply along with uninflamed MD.
adaptation1.9: Parts of the tissue that covers the intestines that were trapped or cut off from blood supply and were removed.
adaptation1.10: The patient recovered normally from surgery.
adaptation1.11: MD is the most common abnormality of the GI tract present at birth.
adaptation1.12: Diagnosing LH before surgery is difficult and surgery is the best treatment of inflamed LH.
adaptation1.13: We conclude that LH is a very rare complication of MD and is difficult to diagnose because it lacks distinguishing features on x-ray and exam.
adaptation1.14: Surgery is the best treatment for stomach wall hernias and inflamed MD.

34316351.Title: Acute traumatic abdominal wall hernia-value of the physical examination: case report

abstract.1: Acute traumatic abdominal wall hernia (TAWH) is a rare type of hernia that occurs after a low or high velocity impact of the abdominal wall against a blunt object with few cases reported.
abstract.2: Perforations of the hollow viscera commonly follow abdominal trauma and likely require surgery for hemorrhage and sepsis source control.
abstract.3: We report a case where a high velocity impact of the abdominal wall against the stump of a felled tree caused a TAWH with concomitant gastric perforation in a 20-year-old male patient who required exploratory laparotomy with primary repair of the stomach and fascia.
abstract.4: The physical examination findings without previous history of abdominal hernia and pneumoperitoneum in the chest X-ray made suspect our diagnosis and it was confirmed intraoperatively.
abstract.5: At 3 months postoperatively the patient has a strong abdominal wall.
abstract.6: It is imperative to emphasize the importance of the physical examination goal of not losing diagnosis of TAWH.

adaptation1.1: Acute traumatic abdominal wall hernia (TAWH) is a rare type of hernia that happens when the stomach wall hits a smooth object at low or high speed with few cases reported.
adaptation1.2: Tears in the stomach wall that allow stomach contents to spill out often result from stomach injury and likely require surgery for bleeding and controlling the source of the body's extreme response to the spillage.
adaptation1.3: We report a case where a high-speed impact of the stomach wall against a tree stump caused a TAWH with stomach tearing in a 20-year-old man who needed abdominal surgery and repair of the wound.
adaptation1.4: The physical exam, no history of stomach hernia, and air in the stomach suggested TAWH, which was confirmed during surgery.
adaptation1.5: The patient had a strong stomach wall 3 months after surgery.
adaptation1.6: It is important to not rule out TAWH based on the physical exam.

abstract.1: Internal hernias are rare, and a delayed diagnosis can lead to dangerous complications.
abstract.2: A 75-year-old male with no previous surgical history presented with right upper abdominal pain and vomiting.
abstract.3: On examination, he had guarding in the right hypochondrium with a positive Murphy's sign.
abstract.4: However, ultrasonography of the gall bladder was normal with dilated bowel loops.
abstract.5: Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) revealed a falciform hernia with evidence of obstruction.
abstract.6: Segmental resection of the gangrenous ileum was done with a double-barrel stoma.
abstract.7: Later on, stoma reversal was also done with no complications.

adaptation1.1: Internal hernias, bulging of digestive organs which cannot be seen from outside the body, are rare, and a delayed diagnosis can cause dangerous complications.
adaptation1.2: A 75-year-old man who had never had surgery had pain in the right upper stomach and vomiting.
adaptation1.3: He had tensing of the muscles in the right upper stomach with a physical exam test showing pain.
adaptation1.4: However, ultrasound of the gall bladder was normal with larger than normal bowel loops.
adaptation1.5: A CT scan showed a falciform hernia, caused by a weakening in the falciform ligament - or connecting tissue - of the liver, with signs of blockage.
adaptation1.6: The dead portion of the last part of the small intestine was removed with a temporary opening in the abdominal wall made during surgery.
adaptation1.7: Later on, the abdominal wall opening was reversed with no complications.

adaptation2.1: Internal organ (e.g., stomach) bulging is rare. Delayed identification can lead to dangerous issues.
adaptation2.2: A 75-year-old male patient with no prior surgeries had right upper ab pain and vomiting.
adaptation2.3: He had tension in the upper right ab area with pain in the same area.
adaptation2.4: However, medical imaging of the gall bladder was normal with bloated bowel loops.
adaptation2.5: Enhanced X-rays showed a possibly obstructing bulge of the ligament connecting the liver to the abdomen wall.
adaptation2.6: The dead part of the small intestine was surgically removed, while an alternate intestinal pathway was temporarily created and used.
adaptation2.7: Later, the alternate, temporary, intestinal pathway was reversed without any issue.

34540382.Title: Rare Presentation of Incarcerated Incisional Richter's Hernia of the Cecum

abstract.1: Richter's hernia, also called a partial enterocele, involves a protrusion of peritoneum with subsequent strangulation or incarceration of only part of the lumen of the anti-mesenteric portion of the small bowel through a fascial defect.
abstract.2: We report a rare presentation of incarcerated incisional Richter's hernia of the cecum in a 39-year-old female.
abstract.3: The patient presented with acute abdominal pain that gradually improved.
abstract.4: Physical examination revealed right lower quadrant tenderness and nodularity just above an abdominoplasty scar.
abstract.5: Subsequent computed tomography scan demonstrated a 1 cm by 1 cm hypovascular pocket arising from the cecum with protrusion into the anterior abdominal wall.
abstract.6: The hernia was successfully repaired surgically with resolution of symptoms.
abstract.7: It is essential for clinicians to be mindful of the diagnosis of Richter's hernia on the differential for abdominal pain as the risk of detrimental outcomes increases with delayed surgical intervention.

adaptation1.1: Richter's hernia, also called a partial enterocele, occurs when the tissue that lines your abdominal wall pushes out through a weak point or tear and traps or cuts off blood supply to only one side of one part of the small bowel.
adaptation1.2: We report a rare case of Richter's hernia trapped at the area of a healing surgical scar at the first part of the small intestine in a 39-year-old female.
adaptation1.3: The patient had sudden and sharp stomach pain that gradually got better.
adaptation1.4: Physical exam showed tenderness in the lower right corner of the stomach and nodules just above a tummy tuck scar.
adaptation1.5: A CT scan showed a 1 cm by 1 cm area with a small number of blood vessels coming from the first part of the small intestine pushing into the front abdominal wall.
adaptation1.6: Surgery to repair the hernia worked, and symptoms went away.
adaptation1.7: Doctors must consider the diagnosis of Richter's hernia as a cause of abdominal pain since the risk of harmful effects goes up with delayed surgery.

abstract.1: Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome (BHD) is an autosomal dominant condition characterised clinically by skin fibrofolliculomas, pulmonary cysts, spontaneous pneumothorax, and renal cancer.
abstract.2: The condition is caused by germline mutations in the FLCN gene, which encodes folliculin; the function of this protein is largely unknown, although FLCN has been linked to the mTOR pathway.
abstract.3: The availability of DNA-based diagnosis has allowed insight into the great variation in expression of FLCN, both within and between families.
abstract.4: Patients can present with skin signs and also with pneumothorax or renal cancer.
abstract.5: Preventive measures are aimed mainly at early diagnosis and treatment of renal cancer.
