adaptation1.6: Many products consumed by people and used in traditional medicine are shown to contain substances with properties described as anti-inflammatories that can relieve pain or swelling, antibacterial to prevent the spread of bacteria, and antiviral to fight viruses. Examples include vitamin C from fruits and substances in honey, garlic, onions, ginger, turmeric, and black pepper.
adaptation1.7: However, there is no strong scientific evidence or analyses with a lot data suggesting that herbs, spices, health-promoting food ingredients, or dietary supplements prevent infection of coronavirus. Additionally, there is little data that they minimize Covid-19 symptoms or can even be used to treat infections, including severe COVID pneumonia, sudden lung failure, a cytokine storm (when the body's immune system floods the blood stream with proteins called cytokines), clotting or scabbing disorders, or multiple organ failure.

adaptation2.1: Diet strategies for preventing COVID-19 (a breathing-related viral disorder) and pneumonia (an infection the inflames the lung air sacs) are being considered.
adaptation2.2: Unfortunately, as with drugs, human studies have not confirmed specific foods to be effective with COVID-19.
adaptation2.3: We know the immune system is key to reducing the severity of COVID-19. Perhaps by influencing it the right way, we can save humans with preventative steps.
adaptation2.4: Many studies show that certain foods used as medicine can beneficially activate the immune response in patients with many diseases, like cancer or AIDS (a disease from an immunodeficiency virus), and healthy people at risk of viral infections.
adaptation2.5: Natural substances are usually seen as valuable tools in the fight against viruses due to the structural diversity and safety of the substances.
adaptation2.6: Many products consumed by people and used in traditional medicine have substances with anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and antiviral properties like vitamins and other plant chemicals.
adaptation2.7: However, there is no evidence that herbs, spices, health-promoting food ingredients, or dietary supplements can prevent, reduce, or treat COVID-19 or other infections, including severe COVID-19 pneymonia, immediate lung failure, inflammatory molecule overproduction, blood clotting disorders, or multiple organ failure.

34579048.Title: Diet, Probiotics and Their Impact on the Gut Microbiota during the COVID-19 Pandemic

abstract.1: SARS-CoV-2 infection is associated with diverse clinical manifestations, immune dysfunction, and gut microbiota alterations.
abstract.2: The nutritional and biochemical quality of one's diet can influence the intestinal microbiota, which may play a role in the defense mechanisms against potential pathogens, by promoting a wide variety of immune-host interactions.
abstract.3: In the COVID-19 pandemic, besides the development of pharmacological therapies, a healthy balanced diet, rich with food-derived antioxidants, may be a useful strategy.
abstract.4: Many studies demonstrated that vitamins and probiotic therapies have positive effects on the treatment and prevention of oxidative stress and inflammation in COVID-19.
abstract.5: The ecology of the gut microbiota in the digestive tract has been linked to the transport function of the host receptor known as angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2), suggesting that COVID-19 may be related to the gut microbiota.
abstract.6: The angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE), and its receptor (ACE2), play central roles in modulating the renin-angiotensin system (RAS).
abstract.7: In addition, ACE2 has functions that act independently of the RAS.
abstract.8: ACE2 is the receptor for the SARS coronavirus, and ACE2 is essential for the expression of neutral amino acid transporters in the gut.
abstract.9: In this context, ACE2 modulates innate immunity and influences the composition of the gut microbiota.
abstract.10: Malnutrition is one of the leading underlying causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide and, including comorbidities, may be a major cause of worse outcomes and higher mortality among COVID-19 patients.
abstract.11: This paper reviews the research on dietary components, with particular emphasis on vitamins, antioxidants, and probiotic therapies, and their impacts on the intestinal microbiota's diversity during the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

adaptation1.1: Coronavirus infection (a viral, respiratory disease) is associated with different types of symptoms, as well as damage to the immune system and changes in gut microbiota, which are important microorganisms in the digestive system that process food and help the body use nutrients.
adaptation1.2: The nutrition and chemical processes of one's diet can alter the microbiota in the stomach, which may play a role in the body's ability to fight possible infections.
adaptation1.3: In the Covid-19 pandemic, besides developing medicines and vaccines, a healthy diet with antioxidants (vitamins, minerals, and other nutrients that protect and repair cells) may be a useful option.
adaptation1.4: Many studies show that vitamins and probiotic (good bacteria) therapies have positive effects on the treatment and prevention of oxidative stress (a condition that happens when antioxidant levels are low leading to cell and tissue damage) and inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) in Covid-19.
adaptation1.5: Research on the relationship between the gut microbiota in the digestive system and its environment is linked to the protein receptor of the cell surface that allows the virus to enter, called ACE2, suggesting that Covid-19 may be linked to the gut microbiota.
adaptation1.6: The protein and its ACE2 receptor that allows viruses to attach to cells play central roles in controlling the renin-angiotensin system (RAS), which is the system that regulates blood pressure and fluids in the body.
adaptation1.7: In addition, ACE2 has functions that act without influence by the RAS.
adaptation1.8: ACE2 is the receptor for the SARS coronavirus that causes COVID-19, and ACE2 is essential for the production of amino acids (molecules that form proteins) in the gut.
adaptation1.9: In this instance, ACE2 controls natural immunity or infection prevention and influences what substances make up the gut microbiota.
adaptation1.10: Malnutrition is one of the leading underlying causes of illness and death across the world and, including other health problems, may be a major cause of worse outcomes and higher deaths among Covid-19 patients.
adaptation1.11: This paper reviews the existing research on food and diets, with a focus on vitamins, antioxidants, and probiotics, and their impact on the gut bacteria during the coronavirus pandemic.

34586557.Title: From Molecular Pathology of COVID 19 to Nigella Sativum as a Treatment Option: Scientific Based Evidence of Its Myth or Reality

abstract.1: COVID-19 virus is a causative agent of viral pandemic in human beings which specifically targets respiratory system of humans and causes viral pneumonia.
abstract.2: This unusual viral pneumonia is rapidly spreading to all parts of the world, currently affecting about 105 million people with 2.3 million deaths.
abstract.3: Current review described history, genomic characteristics, replication, and pathogenesis of COVID-19 with special emphasis on Nigella sativum (N. sativum) as a treatment option.
abstract.4: N. sativum seeds are historically and religiously used over the centuries, both for prevention and treatment of different diseases.
abstract.5: This review summarizes the potential role of N. sativum seeds against COVID-19 infection at levels of in silico, cell lines and animal models.

adaptation1.1: The Covid-19 virus has caused a pandemic in humans and targets the organs and tissues that help people breathe. It also causes viral pneumonia which is an infection in the lungs.
adaptation1.2: This unusual viral pneumonia is quickly spreading to all parts of the world and is currently impacting about 105 million people with 2.3 million deaths.
adaptation1.3: Reviews describe the history of the Covid-19 virus, its genetic make-up, how it replicates, and how it develops with attention to Nigella sativum (N. sativum), a black seed from a plant that may be a possible treatment.
adaptation1.4: N. sativum seeds have been used for centuries, both for prevention and treatment of different diseases.
adaptation1.5: This review summarizes the potential role of N. sativum seeds against Covid-19 infection using computers and lab and animal experiments.

29.question: Is there any nutrition which can increase body immunity against covid 19?

32609390.Title: Discharged COVID-19 patients testing positive again for SARS-CoV-2 RNA: A minireview of published studies from China

abstract.1: In the ongoing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, one potential cause of concern is that some discharged COVID-19 patients are testing positive again for severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) RNA.
abstract.2: To better understand what is happening and to provide public health policy planners and clinicians timely information, we have searched and reviewed published studies about discharged patients testing positive again for the SARS-CoV-2 RNA.
abstract.3: Our search found 12 reports, all of which described patients in China.
abstract.4: Our review of these reports indicates the presence of discharged patients who remain asymptomatic but test positive.
abstract.5: However, it is unclear whether they are contagious because a positive reverse transcriptase - polymerase chain reaction (RT- PCR) test does not necessarily indicate the presence of replicating and transmissible virus.
abstract.6: Our review suggests the need for timely, parallel testing of different samples, including, for example, fecal specimens, from COVID-19 patients before and after they are discharged from hospitals.

adaptation1.1: In the current Covid-19 pandemic, one possible cause for concern is that some Covid-19 patients sent home from the hospital are testing positive again for (or have) coronavirus, which causes the respiratory lung infection of Covid-19.
adaptation1.2: To better understand what is happening and provide timely information to officials and doctors, researchers searched and reviewed completed studies about patients discharged or released from the hospital who test positive again for the coronavirus.
adaptation1.3: The search found 12 reports, all of which described patients in China.
adaptation1.4: The review of these reports suggests the presence of discharged patients who do not have any symptoms but test positive.
adaptation1.5: However, it is unclear whether they are contagious because a positive test for genetic traces of the virus does not necessarily indicate the presence of replicating and transmissible virus.
adaptation1.6: The review suggests the need for testing different samples at the same time, including, for example, fecal (poop) samples, from Covid-19 patients before and after they are sent home from hospitals.

32840002.Title: Persistence of SARS-CoV-2 nasopharyngeal swab PCR positivity in COVID-19 convalescent plasma donors

abstract.1: Background: Nucleic acid persists after symptom resolution and infectivity for many viral infections via delayed clearance of nucleic acid fragments, non-infectious particles, or transmissible virus.
abstract.2: For Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), the relationship between nasopharyngeal (NP) swab positivity, the development of antibodies against COVID-19, and clinical history are unclear.
abstract.3: Study design and methods: Individuals who recovered from COVID-19 and volunteered to donate convalescent plasma (CP) were screened by NP swab PCR, responded to a questionnaire, and were tested for anti-COVID-19 antibodies.
abstract.4: Results: A proportion of 11.8% of individuals tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 by NP swab PCR greater than 14 days after the resolution of symptoms of active disease, including one donor who had asymptomatic disease and tested positive by NP swab 41 days after her initial diagnosis.
abstract.5: Clinical history did not show a significant correlation with persistence of NP swab positivity.
abstract.6: Also, NP swab positivity >14 days from symptom resolution did not correlate with anti-COVID-19 serology results.
abstract.7: IgG anti-SARS-CoV-2 spike antibody strength correlated with hospitalization for COVID-19 using two different assays.
abstract.8: Total anti-SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid antibody strength correlated with time from symptom resolution to sample collection and symptom duration.
abstract.9: Conclusions: SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid is detectable long after the resolution of symptoms in a significant percentage of previously diagnosed individuals, which is important to consider when interpreting PCR swab results.
abstract.10: Persistence of PCR positivity does not correlate with antibody strength or symptoms of COVID-19.
abstract.11: If anti-spike antibody is used to assess CP potency, individuals who suffered severe COVID-19 disease symptoms may represent better donors.

adaptation1.1: For many infections from viruses, traces of the infection can remain in the body after symptoms and transmission (or spread) to others stop.
adaptation1.2: For Covid-19 (a viral, respiratory illness), the relationship between a positive (or virus-detected) nasal swab where a sample is taken from the back of the nose and throat, the development of antibodies (proteins in the body) that fight Covid-19, and the clinical history is unclear.
adaptation1.3: In this study, people who recovered from Covid-19 and volunteered to donate plasma (the liquid part of blood) are screened for genetic material of the virus using a nasal swab. These volunteers also answer a series of questions and are tested for Covid-19 antibodies.
adaptation1.4: There are 11.8% who tested positive for coronavirus, which causes COVID-19, using a nasal swab 14 days after symptoms stopped.
adaptation1.5: Medical history does not show a big association with ongoing positive nasal swab tests.
adaptation1.6: Also, a positive nasal swab >14 days after symptoms stop is not correlated with antibodies against Covid-19 in the plasma.
adaptation1.7: A test measuring the increase of antibodies against Covid-19 relates with being in the hospital for Covid-19.
adaptation1.8: Antibodies against Covid-19 corresponded with time after symptoms stopped to when the samples are collected and how long symptoms lasted.
adaptation1.9: In conclusion, traces of genetic material from coronavirus can be found long after symptoms end in a significant percentage of people who have been diagnosed, which is important to remember when reading swab test results.
adaptation1.10: Continuing to test positive does not correspond with antibody strength or symptoms of Covid-19.
adaptation1.11: If measuring antibodies is used to understand plasma strength, individuals who have had serious Covid-19 disease symptoms may be better donors or donators.

32935877.Title: Screening for SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in convalescent plasma in Brazil: Preliminary lessons from a voluntary convalescent donor program

abstract.1: Background: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) convalescent plasma (CCP) collection began in two Brazilian hospitals for treatment of severe/critical patients.
abstract.2: Methods and materials: Mild/moderate COVID-19 convalescents were selected as CCP donors after reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) confirmed severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and absence of symptoms for ≥14 days plus (a) age (18-60 years), body weight greater than 55 kg; (b) immunohematological studies; (c) no infectious markers of hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, human immunodeficiency virus, human T-lymphotropic virus-1/2, Chagas and syphilis infection; (d) no HLA antibodies (multiparous); (e) second RT-PCR (nasopharyngeal swab and/or blood) negativity; (f) virus neutralization test (cytopathic effect-based virus neutralization test neutralizing antibody) and anti-nucleocapsid protein SARS-CoV-2 IgM, IgG, and IgA enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays.
abstract.3: Results: Among 271 donors (41 females, 230 males), 250 presented with neutralizing antibodies.
abstract.4: Final RT-PCR was negative on swab (77.0%) or blood (88.4%; P = .46).
abstract.5: Final definition of RT-PCR was only defined at more than 28 days after full recovery in 59 of 174 (33.9%) RT-PCR -ve, and 25/69 RT-PCR +ve (36.2%; 13 between 35 and 48 days).
abstract.6: Neutralizing antibody titers of 160 or greater were found in 63.6%.
abstract.7: Correlation between IgG signal/cutoff of 5.0 or greater and neutralizing antibody of 160 or greater was 82.4%.
abstract.8: Combination of final RT-PCR -ve with neutralizing antibody ≥160 was 41.3% (112/271).
abstract.9: Serial plasma collection showed decline in neutralizing antibody titers and IgA levels (P < .05), probably denoting a "golden period" for CCP collection (≤28 days after joining the program); IgA might have an important role as neutralizing antibody.
abstract.10: Donor's weight, days between disease onset and serial plasma collection, and IgG and IgM levels are important predictors for neutralizing antibody titer.
abstract.11: Conclusions: RT-PCR +ve cases are still detected in 36.2% within 28 to 48 days after recovery.
abstract.12: High anti-nucleocapsid protein IgG levels may be used as a surrogate marker to neutralizing antibody.

adaptation1.1: Collection of blood plasma from people who have recovered from the viral, respiratory illness Covid-19, also called convalescent plasma, began in two hospitals in Brazil for treatment of severe patients.
adaptation1.2: People recovering from mild or moderate Covid-19 infection are selected as donors for blood plasma if they have had no symptoms for at least 14 days. Additional tests are done for other infections such as hepatitis and HIV and for antibodies (or infection-fighting proteins) for Covid-19.
adaptation1.3: Among 271 blood plasma donors, 250 have antibodies in the body to fight Covid-19.
adaptation1.4: In 77% of donors, no genetic trace of Covid-19 is found from a swab test and in 88.4%, none is found in blood.
adaptation1.5: At more than 28 days after full recovery, 59 out of 174 are negative (with no virus detected), and 25 out of 69 are positive (with virus detected), but 13 of these are between 35 and 48 days.
adaptation1.6: Additional tests are done to learn more about the level of antibodies in the blood.
adaptation1.9: Blood plasma collection showed a decline in antibodies that attach to the virus and keep it from entering cells.
adaptation1.10: The donor's weight, days between the start of the disease and repeated plasma collection, and antibody levels are important for predicting possible antibody concentration that can keep the virus from entering cells.
adaptation1.11: In conclusion, a positive test that finds genetic traces of the virus are still detected in 36.2% of cases within 28 to 48 days after recovery.
adaptation1.12: High levels of certain antibody proteins may be used to identify antibodies that can neutralize the virus and make it inactive.

33113040.Title: Recurrence of SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA in recovered COVID-19 patients: a narrative review

abstract.1: Many studies have shown that re-positive tests for SARS-CoV-2 by RT-PCR in recovered COVID-19 patients are very common.
abstract.2: We aim to conduct this review to summarize the clinical and epidemiological characteristics of these patients and discuss the potential explanations for recurrences, the contagiousness of re-detectable positive SARS-CoV-2 virus, and the management of COVID-19 patients after discharge from hospital.
abstract.3: The proportion of re-positive tests in discharged COVID-19 patients varied from 2.4 to 69.2% and persisted from 1 to 38 days after discharge, depending on population size, age of patients, and type of specimens.
abstract.4: Currently, several causes of re-positive tests for SARS-CoV-2 in recovered COVID-19 patients are suggested, including false-negative, false-positive RT-PCR tests; reactivation; and re-infection with SARS-CoV-2, but the mechanism leading to these re-positive cases is still unclear.
abstract.5: The prevention of re-positive testing in discharged patients is a fundamental measure to control the spread of the pandemic.
abstract.6: In order to reduce the percentage of false-negative tests prior to discharge, we recommend performing more than two tests, according to the standard sampling and microbiological assay protocol.
abstract.7: In addition, specimens should be collected from multiple body parts if possible, to identify SARS-CoV-2 viral RNA before discharge.
abstract.8: Further studies should be conducted to develop novel assays that target a crucial region of the RNA genome in order to improve its sensitivity and specificity.

adaptation1.1: Many studies have shown that testing positive again for (or having) coronavirus in recovered Covid-19 patients (patients recovered from the serious viral, lung infection of Covid-19) is very common.
adaptation1.2: This study aims to summarize medical and other key characteristics of these patients. The summary will discuss explanations for the return of the virus in recovered patients, how contagious people are after they have recovered from the virus but test positive again, and the care of Covid-19 patients after going home from the hospital.
adaptation1.3: The percentage who re-tested as positive in discharged Covid-19 patients is between 2.4 to 69.2%. Retesting as positive continued from 1 to 38 days after discharge, or release, from the hospital, depending on population size, age, and the type of samples used to test.
adaptation1.4: Currently, several causes of re-positive tests for coronavirus in recovered Covid-19 patients are suggested, including incorrect negative or positive test results; reactivation (when someone appears to have recovered but still has traces of the virus in the body); and being re-infected with coronavirus, but the process leading to these re-positive tests is still unclear.
adaptation1.5: Preventing patients who have recovered and are sent home from testing positive again is an important step to control the spread of the pandemic.
adaptation1.6: To limit the number of false-negatives tests (when a person tests negative but are actually positive for the virus) before being sent home, study researchers suggest doing more than 2 tests.
adaptation1.7: In addition, samples should be collected from multiple body parts if possible, to identify coronavirus DNA before discharge from the hospital.
adaptation1.8: More studies should be done to develop new tests that target a crucial part of the genes from the virus in order to improve its accuracy.

33224987.Title: Temporal Course of SARS-CoV-2 Antibody Positivity in Patients with COVID-19 following the First Clinical Presentation

abstract.1: Knowledge of the sensitivities of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) antibody tests beyond 35 days after the clinical onset of COVID-19 is insufficient.
abstract.2: We aimed to describe positivity rate of SARS-CoV-2 assays employing three different measurement principles over a prolonged period.
abstract.3: Two hundred sixty-eight samples from 180 symptomatic patients with COVID-19 and a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test followed by serological investigation of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies were included.
abstract.4: We conducted three chemiluminescence (including electrochemiluminescence assay (ECLIA)), four enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), and one lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) test formats.
abstract.5: Positivity rates, as well as positive (PPVs) and negative predictive values (NPVs), were calculated for each week after the first clinical presentation for COVID-19.
abstract.6: Furthermore, combinations of tests were assessed within an orthogonal testing approach employing two independent assays and predictive values were calculated.
abstract.7: Heat maps were constructed to graphically illustrate operational test characteristics.
abstract.8: During a follow-up period of more than 9 weeks, chemiluminescence assays and one ELISA IgG test showed stable positivity rates after the third week.
abstract.9: With the exception of ECLIA, the PPVs of the other chemiluminescence assays were ≥95% for COVID-19 only after the second week.
abstract.10: ELISA and LFIA had somewhat lower PPVs.
abstract.11: IgM exhibited insufficient predictive characteristics.
abstract.12: An orthogonal testing approach provided PPVs ≥ 95% for patients with a moderate pretest probability (e.g., symptomatic patients), even for tests with a low single test performance.
abstract.13: After the second week, NPVs of all but IgM assays were ≥95% for patients with low to moderate pretest probability.
abstract.14: The confirmation of negative results using an orthogonal algorithm with another assay provided lower NPVs than the single assays.
abstract.15: When interpreting results from SARS-CoV-2 tests, the pretest probability, time of blood draw, and assay characteristics must be carefully considered.
abstract.16: An orthogonal testing approach increases the accuracy of positive, but not negative, predictions.

adaptation1.1: There is not enough information on how well tests for coronavirus (which causes Covid-19 - a breathing-related illness) can correctly diagnose a positive case (which signals presence of the virus) beyond 35 days after the start of Covid-19.
adaptation1.2: This study aims to describe the percentage of positive coronavirus tests out of all tests, also called positivity rate, using three different measurements over a long period of time.
adaptation1.3: Researchers took 268 samples from 180 Covid-19 patients with symptoms. These samples are tested using an RT-PCR test that finds traces of genetic material of the virus and a blood test to look for antibodies (proteins used by the immune system to fight infection).
adaptation1.4: Researchers used 3 electrochemiluminescence assay (ECLIA) test formats that can look for multiple types of antibodies in the blood, 4 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) tests that test for antibodies for the coronavirus and can provide information about past exposure to Covid-19, and 1 lateral flow immunoassay (LFIA) test format that can detect active coronavirus.
adaptation1.5: After the first clinical sign for Covid-19 starts, the positivity rate and other measures to find the percentage of positive and negative (no virus) results in tests that are true positive, called positive predictive value, and true negative results, called negative predictive value, are calculated each week.
adaptation1.6: Combinations of tests are measured to better understand how the primary tests are working.
adaptation1.7: Maps are created to show how the different tests operate.
adaptation1.8: During a follow-up period of more than 9 weeks, a type of ECLIA and one ELISA antibody test showed stable positivity rates after the third week.
adaptation1.9: Except for ECLIA, the positive predictive value (percentage of positive tests that are true positives) of the other tests similar to ECLIA are ≥95% for Covid-19 only after the second week.
adaptation1.10: ELISA and LFIA have somewhat lower positive predictive values.
adaptation1.11: The IgM antibody that suggests a recent infection did not have enough information to do predictive calculations.
adaptation1.12: An orthogonal testing approach is when a person who tests positive are tested again with a second test. Orthogonal testing provided a positive predictive value of  ≥ 95% for patients who probably had the disease (e.g., symptomatic patients).
adaptation1.13: After the second week, negative predictive values (percentage of negative test results that are true negatives) of all but the IgM antibody test are ≥95% for patients with a low or moderate chance of likely having the disease before being tested.
adaptation1.15: When reading results from coronavirus tests, the estimate of the chance of having the disease before confirming with a test, the time that blood is drawn, and test characteristics must be considered.
adaptation1.16: An orthogonal testing approach when a person with a positive results receives a second test increases the accuracy of positive, but not negative, predictions.

33334398.Title: Estimating the false-negative test probability of SARS-CoV-2 by RT-PCR

abstract.1: Background: Reverse-transcription PCR (RT-PCR) assays are used to test for infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
abstract.2: RT-PCR tests are highly specific and the probability of false positives is low, but false negatives are possible depending on swab type and time since symptom onset.
abstract.3: Aim: To determine how the probability of obtaining a false-negative test in infected patients is affected by time since symptom onset and swab type.
abstract.4: Methods: We used generalised additive mixed models to analyse publicly available data from patients who received multiple RT-PCR tests and were identified as SARS-CoV-2 positive at least once.
abstract.5: Results: The probability of a positive test decreased with time since symptom onset, with oropharyngeal (OP) samples less likely to yield a positive result than nasopharyngeal (NP) samples.
abstract.6: The probability of incorrectly identifying an uninfected individual due to a false-negative test was considerably reduced if negative tests were repeated 24 hours later.
abstract.7: For a small false-positive test probability (<0.5%), the true number of infected individuals was larger than the number of positive tests.
abstract.8: For a higher false-positive test probability, the true number of infected individuals was smaller than the number of positive tests.
abstract.9: Conclusion: NP samples are more sensitive than OP samples.
abstract.10: The later an infected individual is tested after symptom onset, the less likely they are to test positive.
abstract.11: This has implications for identifying infected patients, contact tracing and discharging convalescing patients who are potentially still infectious.

adaptation1.1: A test called reverse-transcription PCR (RT-PCR) is used to test for infection for the coronavirus (which causes COVID-19 - a viral, respiratory illness) by looking for traces of genes from the virus.
adaptation1.2: The chances of getting an incorrect positive (or virus-detected) result is low when using RT-PCR tests, but false negatives (when a person tests negative - not having the virus - but they are actually positive) are possible depending on swab type and time since symptoms started.
adaptation1.3: The aim of this study is to determine how the likelihood of getting a false-negative test in patients with coronavirus is impacted by the time since symptoms started and the type of swab, a small piece of soft material sometimes on the end of a small stick.
adaptation1.4: Publicly available data from patients who received several RT-PCR tests and identified as positive for coronavirus are analyzed.
adaptation1.5: The likelihood of a positive test decreased with the time passed since the start of symptoms. Samples from the middle part of the throat are less likely to give a positive result than swabs from the throat and back of the nose.
adaptation1.6: The chance of incorrectly identifying an uninfected person because of a false-negative is reduced if negative tests are repeated 24 hours later.
adaptation1.7: For a small chance of a false-positive test (<0.5%), the true number of infected individuals is larger than the number of positive tests.
adaptation1.8: For a higher chance of a false-positive test, the true number of infected individuals is smaller than the number of positive tests.
adaptation1.9: In conclusion, the samples from the back of the nose called nasopharyngeal are more sensitive than the samples taken in the middle of the throat.
adaptation1.10: The later an infected individual is tested after symptom start, the less likely they are to test positive.
adaptation1.11: This finding may influence decisions on identifying infected patients, contact tracing, or disease tracking, and discharging or releasing recovering patients who are possibly still infectious and can transmit the virus.

adaptation2.1: Certain molecular tools called RT-PCR assays test for infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which can cause a threatening breathing-related illness.
adaptation2.2: RT-PCR tests are very specific and detecting a target when there is none (or a false positive) is low. However, not detecting a target when there is one (or a false negative) is possible depending on the swab and time since symptoms.
adaptation2.3: The authors' aim is to determine the likelihood of a false-negative test in infected patients is affected by time since symptoms and swab type.
adaptation2.5: The chance of detecting the target decreased with time since symptoms. Also, oropharyngeal (OP) or mouth samples are less likely to detect the target than nasopharyngeal (NP) or nasal samples.
adaptation2.6: The chance of incorrectly identifying an uninfected individual due to a false-negative test was reduced if tests showing no detection were repeated 24 hours later.
adaptation2.7: For a small false-positive test chance (<0.5%), the true number of infected individuals was larger than the number of positive tests or tests detecting the target.
adaptation2.8: For a higher false-positive test likelihood, the true number of infected individuals was smaller than the number of positive tests.
adaptation2.9: NP samples are more sensitive than OP samples.
adaptation2.10: The later an infected individual is tests after symptoms show, the less likely they are to test positive.
adaptation2.11: Time since symptoms has implifications for identifying infected patients, tracing spread, and releasing recovering patients who may still be infectious.

33337843.Title: A Convalescent of COVID-19 with RT-PCR Test Continues Positive in Stool

abstract.1: Background: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has affected more than 100 countries worldwide and the discharge criteria of patients with COVID-19 vary across different countries.
abstract.2: In China, patients with two negative respiratory viral RNA tests taken at least one day apart can be discharged with no further quarantine required.
abstract.3: Currently, PCR testing of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) in fecal sample is not routinely performed.
abstract.4: Methods: We present a patient with COVID-19, whose respiratory swabs became negative but fecal sample remained positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA.
abstract.5: Results: Stool sample collected on 27th of February was still positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA, 24 days after the first negative respiratory swab.
abstract.6: Conclusions: Based on the experience from the 2003 SARS epidemic, we recommend that fecal RNA testing of SARS-CoV-2 should be incorporated into the discharge criteria to minimize the risk of transmission from the gastrointestinal tract.

adaptation1.1: Covid-19 (a viral, breathing-related disease) has affected more than 100 countries around the world, and the basis used to decide when patients with Covid-19 can be sent home is different across countries.
adaptation1.2: In China, patients with two negative (or undetected) viral tests for Covid-19 taken at least one day apart can be sent home with no further quarantine (isolation) required.
adaptation1.3: Currently, testing of for coronavirus using a fecal or poop sample is not usually done.
adaptation1.4: This paper describes a patient with Covid-19 whose tests from swabs of the back of the nose and throat were negative but fecal sample were positive for (or had) coronavirus, which causes Covid-19.
adaptation1.5: The stool (feces) sample collected on 27th of February was still positive for genetic material of the coronavirus, 24 days after the first negative swab from the nose and throat.
adaptation1.6: In conclusion, based on the experience from previous epidemics of lung infections, researchers recommend that testing fecal samples for coronavirus should be included into the standard for sending people home to decrease the risk of transmission (or spread) from the digestive system.

adaptation2.1: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19), which is a viral breathing-related disease, has affected over 100 countries worldwide. The hospital release criteria of patients with COVID-19 varies across countries.
adaptation2.2: In China, patients with two tests detecting no virus and taken at least one day apart can be released with no further isolation needed.
adaptation2.3: Currently, testing of severe acute respiratory syndrome cornoavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which causes COVID-19, in poop samples in not regularly performed.
adaptation2.4: We show a patient with COVID-19, whose poop, but not nose swabs, shows traces of the virus.
adaptation2.5: Poop sample collected on 27th of February shows signs of the virus, 24 days after the first nose swab that did not detect the virus.
adaptation2.6: Based on the 2003 SARS virus epidemic, we recommend that poop testing for SARS-CoV-2 should be added to the hospital release criteria to minimize risk of spread from the digestive tract.

33368332.Title: Quantitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in nasopharyngeal samples from infected patients with mild disease

abstract.1: Diagnosis of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-COV-2) cases is based on the count of real-time reverse transcription-plymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) positive people.
abstract.2: Viral load by real-time RT-PCR has been suggested as a biomarker of the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.3: However, the association of viral load and severity of the disease is not yet resolved.
abstract.4: Nasopharyngeal samples from 458 patients were tested by RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.
abstract.5: Relative quantitation was made by the comparative threshold cycle (ΔΔCt ) formula between ORF1ab viral and RNase P housekeeping genes.
abstract.6: Absolute viral load was calculate using a reference positive control.
abstract.7: Most prevalent clinical signs were cough (75.8%), myalgia (66.7%), and fever (48.5%).
abstract.8: Hypertension (18.2%), neurological diseases (15.1%), and asthma and hypothyroidism (12.1%) were most frequent comorbidities.
abstract.9: Fever, either as an exclusive symptom or combined with others, was associated with high viral loads ( 2−ΔΔCt range, 35.65-155.16; 4.25-4.89 log10 RNA copies/test]).
abstract.10: During the first week after onset of symptoms in mild patients up to 60 years-old was detected the peak of viral load.
abstract.11: Children under 10 years old have a high viral load (313.84; 2.50) in the first 2 days postinfection with a sharp decline thereafter.
abstract.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years old mostly showed low and moderate viral load during the first 2 days postinfection (range, 0.03 to 17.24; -1.50 to 1.24).
abstract.13: Patients over 60 years old have high viral load up to the second week after the onset of symptoms (range, 25.32-155.42; 1.40-2.19), indicating the longer presence of the virus in them.
abstract.14: These findings suggest the viral load in nasopharyngeal swabs would help to monitor the SARS-CoV-2 infection in mild coronavirus disease 2019 cases.

adaptation1.1: Diagnosis of cases of coronavirus (a virus causing the lung infection known as Covid-19) is based on the count of positive RT-PCR tests, a type of test that looks for traces of DNA from the virus and signals positive if there is virus present.
adaptation1.2: The amount of virus in the body, called the viral load, measured by the RT-PCR test is seen as an indication of coronavirus infection.
adaptation1.3: However, the association of the amount of virus and the severity of the disease is not yet understood.
adaptation1.4: Samples from the back of the nose from 458 patients are tested by RT-PCR for coronavirus.
adaptation1.5: Additional tests are done to measure the viral load.
adaptation1.7: The most common signs are cough, muscle aches and pains, and fever.
adaptation1.8: High blood pressure, diseases affecting the brain and nerves, asthma, and hypothyroidism (not enough thyroid hormone in the body) were the most frequent conditions of other illnesses.
adaptation1.9: Fever, either as the only symptom or combined with others, is associated with high viral loads.
adaptation1.10: During the first week after symptoms start in mild patients up to 60 years-old is the peak of viral load.
adaptation1.11: Children under 10 years old have a high viral load in the first 2 days post-infection followed by a sharp decline.
adaptation1.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years old mostly showed low and moderate viral load during the first 2 days after infection.
adaptation1.13: Patients over 60 years old have high viral load up to the second week after the start of symptoms, indicating the virus stays present in them longer.
adaptation1.14: These findings suggest the viral load in swabs from the nose would help to monitor the coronavirus infection in mild coronavirus disease 2019 cases.

adaptation2.1: Detecting cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-COV-2), which causes a breathing-related viral disease, is based on the count of people which a certain molecular test (real-time RT-PCR) detects.
adaptation2.2: Viral amount by real-time RT-PCR may be a signal of the SARS-CoV-2 infection.
adaptation2.3: However, the link between viral amount and severity of the disease is unknown.
adaptation2.4: Nasal samples from 458 patients were tested by RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2.
adaptation2.7: Most common symptoms were cough (75.8%), muscle pain (66.7%), and fever (48.5%).
adaptation2.8: High blood pressure (18.2%), brain-related diseases (15.1%), and asthma and reduced thyroid function, which affects metabolism, (12.1%) were the most frequent associated conditions.
adaptation2.9: Fever, either alone or with other symptoms, was linked with a high virus amount.
adaptation2.10: The peak of the virus amount was detected in the first week after symptoms started in mild patients up to 60 years-old.
adaptation2.11: Children under 10 years have a high virus amount in the first 2 days after infection with a sharp decline after.
adaptation2.12: Cases between 10 and 49 years mostly showed low to medium virus amount during the first 2 days after infection.
adaptation2.13: Patients over 60 years have a high virus amount up to the second week after symptoms start, indicating the longer presence of the virus in them.
adaptation2.14: The virus amount in nasal swabs may help monitor the SARS-CoV-2 infection in cases of mild coronavirus disease 2019, a breathing-related viral disease.

33816325.Title: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 Viral RNA Load Status and Antibody Distribution Among Patients and Asymptomatic Carriers in Central China

abstract.1: This study aimed to monitor severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) viral loads and specific serum-antibodies (immunoglobulin [Ig] G and M) among confirmed patients and asymptomatic carriers from returning healthy travelers.
abstract.2: The throat swabs, sputum, and stool samples from 57 hospitalized coronavirus disease (COVID-19) patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers, among 170 returning healthy travelers were tested using reverse-transcription real-time polymerase chain reaction.
abstract.3: SARS-CoV-2 IgM/IgG antibodies were detected via serum chemiluminescence assay.
abstract.4: Sequential results showed higher viral RNA loads in the throat, sputum, and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptom onset among severely ill COVID-19 patients.
abstract.5: Shorter viral habitation time (1-8 days) was observed in the oropharyngeal site and intestinal tract of asymptomatic carriers.
abstract.6: The IgG and IgM response rates were 19/37 (51.4%) and 23/37 (62.6%) among the 29 confirmed patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers, respectively, within 66 days from symptom or detection onset.
abstract.7: The median duration between symptom onset and positive IgG and IgM results was 30 (n=23; interquartile range [IQR]=20-66) and 23 (n=19; IQR=12-28) days, respectively.
abstract.8: Of 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were asymptomatic carriers (8/170) within 2 weeks, and the IgG and IgM positivity rate was 12.8% (12/94).
abstract.9: IgM/IgG-positivity confirmed 3 suspected SARS-CoV-2 cases, despite negative results for SARS-CoV-2 RNA.
abstract.10: Compared with other respiratory viral infectious diseases, COVID-19 has fewer asymptomatic carriers, lower antibody response rates, and a longer antibody production duration in recovered patients and the contacted healthy population.
abstract.11: This is an indication of the complexity of COVID-19 transmission.

adaptation1.1: This study aims to monitor the amount of coronavirus (which causes COVID-19 - the breathing-related illness) in the blood, also called viral load, and the specific, infection-fighting proteins used by the immune system, called antibodies, among patients with coronavirus and healthy travelers who have the virus but no symptoms.
adaptation1.2: Samples from 57 hospitalized Covid-19 patients and 8 asymptomatic carriers (people who have the virus but no symptoms) are tested.
adaptation1.4: Among seriously ill Covid-19 patients, there is a higher viral load in the throat, sputum (lung), and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptoms start.
adaptation1.5: Among carriers with no symptoms, the viral load is found to stay for a shorter time period (1-8 days) in the throat and in the digestive system.
adaptation1.6: Antibodies to fight the viruses responded in 51.4% of confirmed patients and 62.6% among asymptomatic people within 66 days from symptom starting.
adaptation1.7: The average time between the start of symptoms and positive (or detected) antibodies is 30 days for the IgG antibody, and 23 days for the IgM antibodies, which often suggest a recent infection.
adaptation1.8: Of 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were asymptomatic carriers within 2 weeks, and the positive result among them for the IgG and IgM antibodies is 12.8%.
adaptation1.9: The IgM/IgG antibodies confirmed 3 suspected coronavirus cases, even though they tested negative for coronavirus using another test.
adaptation1.10: When compared to other viruses that impact the lungs, Covid-19 has fewer asymptotic carriers and has a lower antibody response. Covid-19 also has a longer period of time developing antibodies in recovered patients.
adaptation1.11: These findings highlight how complex transmission or spread is in Covid-19.

adaptation2.1: This study monitors virus amonts and naturally-created blood antibodies, which combat foreign viruses, of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which causes a breathing-related viral disorder, among infected patients and carries without symptoms from returning healthy travelers.
adaptation2.2: The throat swabs, mucus, and poop samples from 57 hospitalized patients with coronavirus disease (COVID-19), caused by SARS-CoV-2, and 8 virus carries without symptoms, among 170 returning healthy travelers, were tested with a molecular tool.
adaptation2.4: Results show higher virus amount in throat, mucus, and stool samples at 3-12 and 6-21 days after symptoms first showed among severely ill COVID-19 patients.
adaptation2.5: Shorter virus lifetime (1-8 days) was seen in the throat near the mount and digestive tract of carriers without symptoms.
adaptation2.6: Specific blood antibody detection rates were 18/37 (51.4%) and 23/37 (62.6%) among the 29 confirmed patients and 8 carriers without symptoms, respectively, within 66 days from start of symptoms or detection.
adaptation2.7: Average duration between start of symptoms and antibody results was 30 and 23 days, respectively.
adaptation2.8: Of the 170 returning healthy-travelers to China, 4.7% were infected showing no symptoms (8/170) within 2 weeks. Antibdoy detection rate was 12.8% (12/94).
adaptation2.9: Antibody detection confirmed 3 suspected SARS-CoV-2 cases, despite other test results not detecting the virus.
adaptation2.10: Relative to other breathing-related viral infectious diseases, COVID-19 has fewer carriers without symptoms, lower antibody response rates, and a longer antibody production duration in recovered and contacted healthy people.
adaptation2.11: These results show the complexity of COVID-19 spread.

34206895.Title: Long-Term Longitudinal Evaluation of Six Commercial Immunoassays for the Detection of IgM and IgG Antibodies against SARS CoV-2

abstract.1: The number of serological assays for SARS-CoV-2 has skyrocketed in the past year.
abstract.2: Concerns have been raised regarding their performance characteristics, depending on the disease severity and the time of the analysis post-symptom onset (PSO).
abstract.3: Thus, independent validations using an unbiased sample selection are required for meaningful serology data interpretation.
abstract.4: We aimed to assess the clinical performance of six commercially available assays, the seroconversion, and the dynamics of the humoral response to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.5: The study included 528 serum samples from 156 patients with follow-up visits up to six months PSO and 161 serum samples from healthy people.
abstract.6: The IgG/total antibodies positive percentage increased and remained above 95% after six months when chemiluminescent immunoassay (CLIA) IgG antiS1/S2 and electro-chemiluminescent assay (ECLIA) total antiNP were used.
abstract.7: At early time points PSO, chemiluminescent microparticle immunoassay (CMIA) IgM antiS achieved the best sensitivity.
abstract.8: IgM and IgG appear simultaneously in most circumstances, and when performed in parallel the sensitivity increases.
abstract.9: The severe and the moderate clinical forms were significantly associated with higher seropositivity percentage and antibody levels.
abstract.10: High specificity was found in all evaluated assays, but the sensitivity was variable depending on the time PSO, severity of disease, detection method and targeted antigen.

adaptation1.1: The number of blood tests that check for antibodies (infection-fighting proteins) for the coronavirus (which causes COVID-19, the lung infection) has skyrocketed in the past year.
adaptation1.2: Concerns have been raised on the performance of the tests, depending on the disease severity and the time of the test after symptoms start.
adaptation1.3: Therefore, confirming the performance of the test using an unbiased sample is required in order to understand and describe the antibody data.
adaptation1.4: Researchers aim to assess the performance of six available blood tests, the seroconversion (when the body starts producing antibodies), and how the body creates antibodies in response to coronavirus infection.
adaptation1.5: The study included 528 blood samples from 156 patients with follow-up visits up to 6 months after the start of symptoms and 161 blood samples from healthy people.
adaptation1.6: The total amount of antibodies increased and remained above 95% after six months when using certain tests to identify antibodies.
adaptation1.7: At early times after the start of symptoms, a blood test that looks for certain antibodies that suggest recent infection has the best ability to correctly diagnose a positive (or virus-containing) case.
adaptation1.8: Two types of antibodies, IgM and IgG, appear at the same time in most circumstances, and when performed together, the ability to correctly diagnose a positive diagnosis increases.
adaptation1.9: The severe and the moderate clinical forms have major associations with a higher number of positive tests and antibody levels.
adaptation1.10: The ability to correctly have a negative (or no virus) test among negative people is found in all evaluated blood tests, but the ability to correctly diagnose a true positive varies depending on the time after the start of symptoms and the type of test.
