adaptation1.1: Gabapentin is a nerve-related pain drug, which in humans is cleared from the body solely by the kidneys and is not attached to proteins in plasma (the liquid part of blood).
adaptation1.2: Because the clearance of gabapentin depends on the kidneys, how the body processes gabapentin is investigated in patients who do not make enough urine and who are on dialysis, a process of cleaning the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally.
adaptation1.3: Plasma samples are collected over an 8-day period after a single oral (by mouth) dose of gabapentin is given.
adaptation1.4: Plasma samples before and after being filtered, as well as dialysis fluid, are collected during dialysis sessions performed 2, 4, and 7 days after receiving the gabapentin dose.
adaptation1.5: An average maximum amount of gabapentin in plasma is achieved at 4.7 hours after the dose.
adaptation1.6: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma to be reduced by half on non-dialysis days averages 132 hours.
adaptation1.7: About 35% of gabapentin dose is recovered in dialysis fluid, and the average clearance of gabapentin in dialysis was 142 milliliters per minute.
adaptation1.8: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma to be reduced by half during dialysis is about 4 hours.
adaptation1.9: Gabapentin concentrations in the plasma increased about 30% during the first 2 hours after dialysis as a result of the drug being sent to other parts of the body.
adaptation1.10: It is recommended that patients with end-stage kidney disease who are on dialysis receive a starting 300-mg to 400-mg gabapentin dose.
adaptation1.11: Plasma gabapentin concentrations can remain stable by giving 200 to 300 mg of gabapentin after every 4 hours of dialysis.

adaptation2.1: Gabapentin is an antiseizure drug, which in man is cleared just by kidney removal and is not bound to blood proteins.
adaptation2.2: Because gabapentin clearance is dependent on kidney function, the drug activity of gabapentin was investigated in patients unable to make urine and maintained on artifical kidney machines or hemodialysis.
adaptation2.3: We took blood samples over an 8-day period after treatment of single 400-mg swallowed doses of gabapentin.
adaptation2.4: Blood and kidney solution samples were obtained during treatment sessions performed 2, 4, and 7 days after dosing.
adaptation2.5: An average maximum gabapentin blood level of 6.0 micrograms/mL was measured at 4.7 hours after the dose.
adaptation2.6: The time for half of gabapentin to clear on non-hemodialysis days was 132 hours.
adaptation2.7: Around 35% of the gabapentin dose was recovered in the fluid of the artificial kidney machine. The average hemodialysis clearance of gabapentin was 142 mL/min; around 93% of the standard dialyzer clearance.
adaptation2.8: The time for half of gabapentin to clear during hemodialysis was around 4 hours.
adaptation2.9: Blood gabapentin levels increased around 30% during the first 2 hours after hemodialysis due to drug redistribution in the body.
adaptation2.10: It is recommended that patients with kidney failure and on hemodialysis get an initial 300-mg to 400-mg gabapentin starting dose.
adaptation2.11: Blood gabapentin levels can be maintained by giving 200 to 300 mg of gabapentin after every 4 hours of hemodialysis.

abstract.1: Gabapentin is a new antiepileptic drug (AED) with an attractive pharmacokinetic profile.
abstract.2: It is absorbed by an active and saturable transport system, and has a high volume of distribution.
abstract.3: Gabapentin is not bound to plasma proteins, does not induce hepatic enzymes and is not metabolized.
abstract.4: At steady state, it has a half-life of 6-8 h, and is eliminated unchanged by renal route with a plasma clearance proportional to the creatinine clearance.
abstract.5: It is devoid of significant drug-drug interactions when administered with the established AEDs or with oral contraceptives.
abstract.6: Gabapentin used as an add-on AED significantly reduced the frequency of partial seizures and secondarily generalized tonic-clonic seizures in three large double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group clinical trails.
abstract.7: It is well tolerated, with transient somnolence and dizziness being the most frequent adverse effects.
abstract.8: Although the mechanism of action of gabapentin is not fully established, there is strong evidence to suggest a novel mechanism of action.
abstract.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve the quality of life of patients with epilepsy and is a welcome addition to the armamentarium of currently available AEDs for the treatment of patients with seizures of partial onset.

adaptation1.1: Gabapentin is a new drug to treat seizures that appears to work well for patients.
adaptation1.2: It is absorbed into the body by an active and fluid-filled transport system, and is able to be distributed to tissues in the body.
adaptation1.3: Gabapentin is not attached to proteins in the blood, does not create liver enzymes that can speed up chemical reactions in the body, and is not broken down.
adaptation1.4: When the amount of the drug in the body is the same amount that is being cleared, the time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or body to be reduced by half is 6-8 hours and is eliminated through the kidneys.
adaptation1.5: Gabapentin does not have any major interactions with other drugs when given with other standard drugs that treat seizures or with oral (by mouth) birth control.
adaptation1.6: In 3 clinical studies, gabapentin used as an add-on anti-seizure drug to assist the main treatment reduces the frequency of partial seizures (impacting half the brain) and seizures (impacting both halves of the brain).
adaptation1.7: The medicine is handled well by patients, with drowsiness and dizziness being the most common side effects.
adaptation1.8: Although the exact process of how gabapentin can lead to an effect is not fully understood, there is strong evidence that suggests a new process in the body.
adaptation1.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve the quality of life of patients with epilepsy (seizure disorders) and is a welcome addition to currently available drugs for the treatment of patients with seizures that start in one part of the brain.

adaptation2.1: Gabapentin is a new antiseizure or antiepileptic drug (AED) with attractive drug activity.
adaptation2.2: Gabapentin is absorbed by an active transport system. The drug has a large distribution.
adaptation2.3: Gabapentin is not bound to blood proteins, does not activate liver enzymes and is not broken down.
adaptation2.4: Normally, half of the drug is eliminated in 6-8 hours. It is cleared unchanged by the kidney with a blood clearance similar to standard kidney substance clearance.
adaptation2.5: The drug does not have major drug-drug interactions when used with other AEDs or swallowed birth control drugs.
adaptation2.6: Gabapentin used as an add-on AED greatly reduces the amount of partial seizures and partial seizures developing into standard serizures in three clinical trials.
adaptation2.7: The drug is well tolerated, with temporary drowsiness and dizziness as the most common side effects.
adaptation2.8: Although how gabapentin works is unknown, there is evidence for a new mechanism of its biological action.
adaptation2.9: Gabapentin is a unique and promising drug that could improve life for patients with epilepsy (a brain disorder causing seizures). The drug is a welcome addition to current AEDs for treating patients with seizures of partial onset.

abstract.1: The amino acid antiepileptic drug (AED) gabapentin (GBP) is indicated for adjunctive use in the treatment of partial seizures with or without becoming secondarily generalized in individuals older than 12 years.
abstract.2: GBP was about as potent as phenytoin in the maximal electroshock test, but had a different profile of efficacy than standard antiepileptics in a range of animal models.
abstract.3: Possible mechanisms of action include biochemical effects enhancing the ratio of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) to glutamate, ion-channel actions (direct or indirect), and/ or enhancement of nonsynaptic GABA release.
abstract.4: The anticonvulsant effect appears to depend on concentration of gabapentin in neurons, presumably by the L-system amino acid transporter that has been implicated in absorption from the gut.
abstract.5: Data from studies for U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval suggested a direct relationship of clinical response to dose and efficacy did not plateau at the doses used.
abstract.6: The maximally effective dose, relationship of efficacy to blood level, and maximum tolerable dose are not yet known conclusively.
abstract.7: Lack of significant binding to plasma proteins and lack of liver metabolism contribute to the absence of known limiting drug-drug interactions, particularly with other AEDs.
abstract.8: Excretion intact in the urine affords dose adjustment on the basis of creatinine clearance.
abstract.9: A half-life of approximately 7 h necessitates multiple doses daily for many individuals.
abstract.10: The medication is well tolerated, in general.
abstract.11: Side effects tend to be mild to moderate in intensity, most frequently affect the central nervous system, and resolve with time in many individuals.
abstract.12: GBP has been prescribed for approximately 70,000 individuals worldwide without untoward incidence of severe systemic toxicity to date.
abstract.13: Safety data continue to accumulate.
abstract.14: GBP has been labeled category C on the basis of effects on rodent fetuses.
abstract.15: Experience with use in pregnant women is limited and human teratogenic effects have not been reported.
abstract.16: Data from ongoing monotherapy trials will help to clarify the range of clinical utility of gabapentin.

adaptation1.1: The drug gabapentin (GBP) is an addition to the regular treatment of partial seizures with or without becoming generalized seizures in the entire brain in people older than 12 years.
adaptation1.2: Gabapentin has performed differently than other standard drugs that are used to prevent seizures in a number of animal experiments.
adaptation1.3: Possible processes that lead the drug to have an effect include the response of increasing the development of neurotransmitters (signaling molecules in the brain) and other cell functions.
adaptation1.4: The act of stopping or slowing the excessive rapid firing of neurons (brain cells) during seizures seems to depend on the concentration of gabapentin in neurons.
adaptation1.5: Data from studies for U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval suggest a direct relationship of medical response to the dose and success did not level-off at the doses used.
adaptation1.6: The maximally effective dose (the dose at which any higher dose would not lead to improvement), the relationship of its performance to blood level, and the maximum tolerable dose (the highest dose most people can handle) are not completely known.
adaptation1.7: Lack of attachment to plasma (or blood) proteins and lack of liver energy contribute to the absence of known interactions between drugs, particularly with other drugs that are used to prevent seizures.
adaptation1.8: Doses can be adjusted based on the amount of the drug found in the urine.
adaptation1.9: The time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or in the body to be reduced by half is about 7 hours, requiring multiple doses daily for many people.
adaptation1.10: In general, people are able to handle the medication and its side effects.
adaptation1.11: Side effects tend to be mild to moderate in intensity, most frequently affect the central nervous system (spinal cord and brain), and resolve with time in many individuals.
adaptation1.12: Gabapentin (GBP) is prescribed for about 70,000 people around the world without unexpected incidence of severe toxic effects so far.
adaptation1.13: Safety data continues to be collected.
adaptation1.14: Gabapentin has shown to have adverse effects on rodent fetuses.
adaptation1.15: Experience with use in pregnant women is limited, and adverse (or bad) effects or abnormalities in human fetuses have not been reported.
adaptation1.16: Data from ongoing single drug trials will help to clarify the range of the clinical use of gabapentin.

10219274.Title: Effects of age and gender on single-dose pharmacokinetics of gabapentin

abstract.1: Purpose: This study was conducted to evaluate the effect of age, age-related changes in renal function, and gender on the single-dose pharmacokinetics of orally administered gabapentin (GBP).
abstract.2: Methods: The pharmacokinetics of a single 400-mg oral dose of GBP were studied in 36 healthy subjects (18 men and 18 women) aged 20-78 years.
abstract.3: Serial blood samples and total urine output were collected for 48 h after the dose.
abstract.4: GBP concentrations in plasma and urine were measured by high-performance liquid chromatography, and pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated by noncompartmental methods.
abstract.5: Results: All subjects tolerated the drug well, with only mild symptoms reported.
abstract.6: No change in maximal GBP plasma concentration (Cmax), time at which Cmax occurred (tmax), or apparent volume of distribution (V/F) with age was noted.
abstract.7: A significant linear decline in apparent oral clearance (CL/F), elimination-rate constant (lambda z), and renal clearance (CLR) with increasing age was observed (p < 0.005).
abstract.8: Because total urinary recovery of unchanged drug (an estimate of F for GBP) did not change with age, the decline in CL/F and lambda z can be explained by the decline in CLR.
abstract.9: The only pharmacokinetic parameter that was significantly different between genders was Cmax, which was approximately 25% higher for women than for men (p = 0.016), consistent with gender differences in body size.
abstract.10: Conclusions: The results of this study suggest that changes in renal function are responsible for age-related changes in GBP pharmacokinetics.
abstract.11: Reduction of GBP dosage may be required in elderly patients with reduced renal function.
abstract.12: The pharmacokinetics of GBP are similar in men and women.

adaptation1.1: This study is conducted to evaluate the effect of age, age-related changes in renal or kidney function, and gender on the single-dose pharmacokinetics (or drug activity) of orally (by mouth) administered gabapentin (GBP).
adaptation1.2: The body's process of absorbing, distributing, using, and removing a single oral dose (by mouth) of gabapentin is studied in 36 healthy patients (18 men and 18 women) aged 20-78 years.
adaptation1.3: Blood and urine samples are continuously collected for 48 hours after the dose of gabapentin.
adaptation1.4: The amount of Gabapentin in plasma (or blood) and urine samples are measured, and other tests are done to understand how the body processes gabapentin.
adaptation1.5: All patients are able to handle the drug well, with only mild symptoms reported.
adaptation1.6: No change in the highest (peak) gabapentin amount, the time at which the highest gabapentin amount occurred, or apparent volume of distribution (the ability of various drugs to distribute through the body fluids) with age was noted.
adaptation1.7: A major decline in clearance of gabapentin that is taken orally, the rate of removal from the body, and clearing it through the kidneys with increasing age is observed.
adaptation1.8: The decline of oral clearance and rate of removal of gabapentin from the body can be explained by the decline in clearance by the kidneys.
adaptation1.9: The only measure that is very different between genders is the highest (peak) gabapentin amount, which is approximately 25% higher for women than for men, consistent with gender differences in body size.
adaptation1.10: In conclusion, the results of this study suggest that changes in kidney function are responsible for age-related changes in how the body processes gabapentin.
adaptation1.11: Giving a lesser dose of gabapentin may be required in elderly patients who have weaker kidney functions.
adaptation1.12: How the body processes gabapentin is similar in men and women.

15584938.Title: Pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in paediatric patients with uncontrolled seizures

abstract.1: Purpose: The pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in paediatric patients with uncontrolled seizures was studied.
abstract.2: Methods: Thirteen paediatric patients (mean age: 9.4 years) with uncontrolled partial seizures were included.
abstract.3: Patients received gabapentin orally until doses were individualized to 9.6-39.8 mg/kg/day.
abstract.4: Blood samples were obtained just prior to the dose and over 8 h after gabapentin was administered in the fasting state.
abstract.5: The plasma concentration of gabapentin was measured by a high-performance liquid chromatography assay.
abstract.6: Pharmacokinetic parameters for gabapentin were determined by non-compartment methods using multivariate regression analysis.
abstract.7: Results: Data from nine patients were suitable for pharmacokinetic analysis.
abstract.8: The C(max) from 0.9 to 5.8 microg/mL (mean: 2.6 +/- 1.7 microg/mL) and T(max) from 0.5 to 2.0 h (mean: 1.6 +/- 1.0 h).
abstract.9: The apparent clearance (Cl/F) ranged from 0.12 to 1.12 L/h/kg (mean: 0.50 +/- 0.29 L/h/kg), and the elimination half-life from 3.2 to 12.2 h (mean: 5.5 +/- 0.8 h).
abstract.10: Five patients experienced moderate (n = 4) to severe (n = 1) aggressive behaviour and another gained weight on gabapentin.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Our data suggests that gabapentin pharmacokinetics can vary substantially among paediatric patients.
abstract.12: Gabapentin was well tolerated in patients with uncontrolled partial seizures up to 6 months of therapy.

adaptation1.1: How the pediatric or child patients with uncontrolled seizures are able to handle gabapentin (a nerve-related pain medication) and the processes of absorbing, distributing, using, and removing it is studied.
adaptation1.2: In this study, 13 pediatric patients (less the 21 years old) with an average age of about 9 years with uncontrolled partial seizures are included.
adaptation1.3: Patients received gabapentin orally (by mouth) until doses are changed for each patient.
adaptation1.4: Blood samples are obtained just before the dose and over 8 hours after gabapentin is given during fasting, when all foods have been completely digested.
adaptation1.5: Blood concentrations of gabapentin is measured by blood tests.
adaptation1.6: Absorption, distribution, use, and removal of gabapentin in the body is analyzed.
adaptation1.7: Data from 9 patients are able to be used for analysis.
adaptation1.8: The maximum concentration of the drug and the time it takes to reach maximum concentration are estimated.
adaptation1.10: Five patients experience moderate (4 patients) to severe (1 patient) aggressive behavior, and another gained weight on gabapentin.
adaptation1.11: In conclusion, the data in this study suggests that how the body processes gabapentin can vary a lot among pediatric patients.
adaptation1.12: In this study, patients with uncontrolled partial seizures were able to handle gabapentin well up to 6 months of therapy.

28070716.Title: Pharmacokinetics and Saturable Absorption of Gabapentin in Nursing Home Elderly Patients

abstract.1: Pharmacokinetic data of gabapentin (GBP) in community-dwelling elderly patients show a significant effect of advanced age on GBP pharmacokinetics due to altered renal function.
abstract.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home (NH) patients to evaluate gabapentin absorption and elimination.
abstract.3: Our objective was to characterize the pharmacokinetics of GBP in elderly nursing home patients maintained on GBP therapy.
abstract.4: This was a prospective pharmacokinetic study in elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) receiving GBP for the management of chronic pain or epilepsy from seven nursing homes.
abstract.5: Pharmacokinetic parameters were estimated by nonlinear mixed-effects modeling.
abstract.6: A one-compartment model described the data and clearance (CL) was associated with estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) (p < 0.0001).
abstract.7: The GBP CL in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 L/h.
abstract.8: After adjusting for the effect of GFR, GBP CL was not affected by age, sex, body weight, or comorbidity scores.
abstract.9: No significant effects of body size measures, age, and sex were detected on volume of distribution.
abstract.10: Dose-dependent bioavailability of GBP was demonstrated, and the saturable absorption profile was described by a nonlinear hyperbolic function.
abstract.11: Prediction-corrected visual predictive check (pc-VPC) suggests adequate fixed- and random-effects models that successfully simulated the mean trend and variability in gabapentin concentration-time profiles.
abstract.12: In this analysis, the parameters of the hyperbolic nonlinearity appear to be similar between elderly and younger adults.

adaptation1.1: Data on how gabapentin (GBP -a nerve-related pain medication) is used in the body in elderly patients show a major effect of older age on how the drug works due to changes in kidney function.
adaptation1.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home patients to evaluate how the body absorbs and removes gabapentin.
adaptation1.3: The objective of this study is to describe how the body uses and processes gabapentin in elderly nursing home patients who are on gabapentin.
adaptation1.4: This study observed elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) receiving gabapentin for chronic (ongoing) pain or epilepsy (seizure disorders) from 7 nursing homes.
adaptation1.6: Data on gabapentin and the clearance of the drug are associated with the rate that measures how well the kidneys are working.
adaptation1.7: The gabapentin clearance in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 liters per hour.
adaptation1.8: After accounting for the rate that measures how well the kidneys are working, GBP clearance is not affected by age, sex, body weight, or other illnesses and their medications.
adaptation1.9: No significant effects of body size measures, age, and sex are detected on volume of distribution, the ability of various drugs to distribute through the body fluids.
adaptation1.10: The availability of the drug being dependent on dosage is shown, and how it is absorbed is calculated.
adaptation1.11: Additional calculations are done on the entire group to evaluate the performance of the drug and identify other individual factors that may impact the effect.
adaptation1.12: In this analysis, the patterns of the drug appear to be similar between elderly and younger adults.

adaptation2.1: Drug activity data of gabapentin (GBP) in community-dwelling elderly patients show a great effect of advanced age on GVP drug activity due to altered kidney function.
adaptation2.2: However, there are no data in elderly nursing home (NH) patients to measure gabapentin absorption and elimination.
adaptation2.3: We characterize the drug activity of GBP in elderly nursing home patients that are on GBP therapy.
adaptation2.4: This is a drug actvity study in elderly nursing home patients (≥60 years) given GBP for long-term pain or epilepsy (brain disorder causing seizures) from seven nursing homes.
adaptation2.6: A mathematical model showed the data and clearance (CL) was linked with estimated kidney filtration rate.
adaptation2.7: The GBP clearance in elderly nursing home patients was 2.93 liters/hour.
adaptation2.8: After adjusting for kidney filtration, GBP clearance was not affected by age, sex, body weight, or associated diseases.
adaptation2.9: No effects of body size, age, and sex were detected on amount of distribution.
adaptation2.10: Functional or active GBP amount is linked to dose amount.
adaptation2.11: Analysis suggests certain mathematical models successfully tracked the trend and variation in gabapentin amount over time.
adaptation2.12: In this analysis, certain measures seem similar between elderly and young adults.

28676198.Title: Treatment of Gabapentin Toxicity With Peritoneal Dialysis: Assessment of Gabapentin Clearance

abstract.1: Gabapentin is almost exclusively cleared by the kidney and thus presents challenges in patients with kidney failure.
abstract.2: Gabapentin is known to be effectively cleared by hemodialysis, but the efficiency of clearance by peritoneal dialysis (PD) has not been previously described.
abstract.3: We report a case of gabapentin toxicity in a patient on long-term PD who was treated with continuous automated cycling PD.
abstract.4: We find that continuous PD provides significant clearance of gabapentin.
abstract.5: With 2-L exchanges every 2 hours, we document an apparent elimination half-life of 41.33 hours, which is substantially shorter than the reported elimination half-life of 132 hours in the absence of kidney function.
abstract.6: Further, our patient's symptoms of gabapentin toxicity gradually improved and had fully resolved after about 36 hours of dialysis.
abstract.7: Gabapentin clearance by PD was estimated at 94% of urea clearance.
abstract.8: We conclude that intensive PD provides gabapentin clearance that approximates that of urea and is an effective but slow method to treat gabapentin overdose and toxicity.

adaptation1.1: The nerve-related pain medication gabapentin is cleared from the body almost entirely by the kidney. Because of this, patients with kidney failure face a challenge.
adaptation1.2: Gabapentin is known to be effectively cleared by hemodialysis, a process of using machines to clean the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally, but how well peritoneal dialysis (PD), a process that filters blood using the inside lining of the stomach, clears the drug has not been previously described.
adaptation1.3: Researchers describe a case of too much gabapentin in a patient with long-term peritoneal dialysis who is treated with continuous automated cycling peritoneal dialysis, which is when a mechanical device filters the blood at night while sleeping.
adaptation1.4: Researchers find that continuous peritoneal dialysis provides significant clearance of gabapentin.
adaptation1.5: The documented elimination half-life (the time it takes for the concentration of the gabapentin in the plasma or body to be reduced by half) is 41.33 hours, which is much shorter than the 132 hours reported in other studies in the absence of kidney function.
adaptation1.6: In addition, the patient's symptoms of gabapentin toxicity (often muscle weakness, drowsiness, and drooping eyelids) improved and fully resolved after about 36 hours of dialysis.
adaptation1.7: Gabapentin clearance in the body by peritoneal dialysis is estimated at 94% of urea (or waste protein) clearance.
adaptation1.8: In conclusion, intensive peritoneal dialysis provides gabapentin clearance and is an effective but slow method to treat gabapentin overdose and toxicity.

29018999.Title: Population pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in healthy Korean subjects with influence of genetic polymorphisms of ABCB1

abstract.1: The objective of this study was to perform population pharmacokinetic (PK) analysis of gabapentin in healthy Korean subjects and to investigate the possible effect of genetic polymorphisms (1236C > T, 2677G > T/A, and 3435C > T) of ABCB1 gene on PK parameters of gabapentin.
abstract.2: Data were collected from bioequivalence studies, in which 173 subjects orally received three different doses of gabapentin (300, 400, and 800 mg).
abstract.3: Only data from reference formulation were used.
abstract.4: Population pharmacokinetics (PKs) of gabapentin was estimated using a nonlinear mixed-effects model (NONMEM).
abstract.5: Gabapentin showed considerable inter-individual variability (from 5.2- to 8.7-fold) in PK parameters.
abstract.6: Serum concentration of gabapentin was well fitted by a one-compartment model with first-order absorption and lag time.
abstract.7: An inhibitory Emax model was applied to describe the effect of dose on bioavailability.
abstract.8: The oral clearance was estimated to be 11.1 L/h.
abstract.9: The volume of distribution was characterized as 81.0 L.
abstract.10: The absorption rate constant was estimated at 0.860 h-1, and the lag time was predicted at 0.311 h.
abstract.11: Oral bioavailability was estimated to be 68.8% at dose of 300 mg, 62.7% at dose of 400 mg, and 47.1% at dose of 800 mg.
abstract.12: The creatinine clearance significantly influenced on the oral clearance (P < 0.005) and ABCB1 2677G > T/A genotypes significantly influenced on the absorption rate constant (P < 0.05) of gabapentin.
abstract.13: However, ABCB1 1236C > T and 3435C > T genotypes showed no significant effect on gabapentin PK parameters.
abstract.14: The results of the present study indicate that the oral bioavailability of gabapentin is decreased when its dosage is increased.
abstract.15: In addition, ABCB1 2677G > T/A polymorphism can explain the substantial inter-individual variability in the absorption of gabapentin.

adaptation1.1: The objective of this study is to perform an analysis on how the nerve-related pain medication gabapentin performs in healthy Korean participants and to investigate the possible effect of genetic changes in the drug-resistant ABCB1 gene on how gabapentin is absorbed and distributed in the body.
adaptation1.2: Data are collected from other studies where 173 people received three different doses by mouth (orally) of gabapentin.
adaptation1.3: Only data on the drug design and performance are used.
adaptation1.4: How the body handles and uses gabapentin is measured.
adaptation1.5: Gabapentin shows a lot of variation or differences between people in how it is absorbed, distributed and released from the body.
adaptation1.6: Blood concentration of gabapentin is used to understand the process of distributing and eliminating the medication from the body.
adaptation1.7: How the dose amount impacts availability in the body is measured.
adaptation1.8: The oral clearance is estimated to be 11.1 liters per hour.
adaptation1.9: The volume of distribution was characterized as 81.0 L.
adaptation1.10: How quickly the medication enters the body remains steady.
adaptation1.11: Availability of the drug from the oral dose is estimated to be 68.8% at a dose of 300 mg, 62.7% at a dose of 400 mg, and 47.1% at a dose of 800 mg.
adaptation1.12: Clearing creatinine (a waste product that comes from wear and tear of the muscles) influences the oral clearance, and ABCB1 genes influence how quickly gabapentin is absorbed by the body.
adaptation1.13: However, genes showed no significant effect on gabapentin drug activity parameters.
adaptation1.14: The results of this study suggest that the availability of gabapentin to the body when taken by mouth is decreased when the dosage is increased.
adaptation1.15: In addition, changes in the ABCB1 gene can explain the major differences in how gabapentin is absorbed by the body between people.

32149389.Title: Cetirizine Reduces Gabapentin Plasma Concentrations and Effect: Role of Renal Drug Transporters for Organic Cations

abstract.1: Gabapentin (GBP) is an organic cation mainly eliminated unchanged in urine, and active drug secretion has been suggested to contribute to its renal excretion.
abstract.2: Our objective was to evaluate the potential drug-drug interaction between GBP and cetirizine (CTZ), an inhibitor of transporters for organic cations.
abstract.3: An open-label, 2-period, crossover, nonrandomized clinical trial was conducted in patients with neuropathic pain to evaluate the effect of CTZ on GBP pharmacokinetics.
abstract.4: Twelve participants were treated with a single dose of 300 mg GBP (treatment A) or with 20 mg/d of CTZ for 5 days and 300 mg GBP on the last day of CTZ treatment (treatment B).
abstract.5: Blood sampling and pain intensity evaluation were performed up to 36 hours after GBP administration.
abstract.6: The interaction of GBP and CTZ with transporters for organic cations was studied in human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells expressing the organic cation transporters (OCTs), multidrug and toxin extrusion proteins (MATEs), and OCTN1.
abstract.7: CTZ treatment resulted in reduced area under the concentration-time curve and peak concentration compared with treatment A.
abstract.8: In treatment B, the lower plasma concentrations of GBP resulted in reduced pain attenuation.
abstract.9: GBP renal clearance was similar between treatments.
abstract.10: GBP has low apparent affinity for OCT2 (concentration of an inhibitor where the response [or binding] is reduced by half [IC50 ] 237 µmol/L) and a high apparent affinity for hMATE1 (IC50 1.1 nmol/L), hMATE2-K (IC50 39 nmol/L), and hOCTN1 (IC50 2.1 nmol/L) in HEK cells.
abstract.11: At therapeutic concentrations, CTZ interacts with hMATE1 and OCTN1.
abstract.12: In summary, CTZ reduced the systemic exposure to GBP and its effect on neuropathic pain attenuation.
abstract.13: However, CTZ × GBP interaction is not mediated by the renal transporters.

adaptation1.1: Gabapentin (GBP) is a nerve-related pain medication that is mainly removed from the body in urine, and is also processed by the kidneys.
adaptation1.2: The objective of this study is to evaluate how gabapentin may interact with another medicine called cetirizine (CTZ) that is used to temporarily relieve allergies.
adaptation1.3: A clinical trial in patients with a shooting or burning pain caused by damage to the nervous system called neuropathic pain is conducted to understand the effect of cetirizine on how gabapentin is processed in the body.
adaptation1.4: In this study, 12 patients are treated with either one dose of gabapentin (called Treatment A) or with cetirizine for 5 days and gabapentin given on the last day of cetirizine (Treatment B).
adaptation1.5: Blood samples are taken and the level of pain is measured up to 36 hours after gabapentin is taken.
adaptation1.6: The interaction of gabapentin and cetirizine is analyzed.
adaptation1.7: Cetirizine treatment resulted a reduced time the body is exposed to the medication and reduced peak amount when compared with Treatment A (one dose of gabapentin).
adaptation1.8: In treatment B, the lower concentrations of gabapentin or GBP in the blood results in reduced pain.
adaptation1.9: GBP clearance from the kidneys is similar between treatments A and B.
adaptation1.10: GBP appears to bind less to some receptors or kidney target sites such as OCT2 and attach more towards others such as hMATE1 in certain human kidney cells.
adaptation1.11: At certain concentrations, CTZ interacts with transporters in the body that move materials across cells.
adaptation1.12: In summary, cetirizine  (CTZ) reduces the exposure to gabapentin (GBP) and its effect on neuropathic pain.
adaptation1.13: However, CTZ × GBP interaction is not influenced by the transporters in the kidney.

33118231.Title: Population pharmacokinetics of gabapentin in patients with neuropathic pain: Lack of effect of diabetes or glycaemic control

abstract.1: Aims: Gabapentin (GBP) is widely used to treat neuropathic pain, including diabetic neuropathic pain.
abstract.2: Our objective was to evaluate the role of diabetes and glycaemic control on GBP population pharmacokinetics.
abstract.3: Methods: A clinical trial was conducted in patients with neuropathic pain (n = 29) due to type 2 diabetes (n = 19) or lumbar/cervical disc herniation (n = 10).
abstract.4: All participants were treated with a single oral dose GBP.
abstract.5: Blood was sampled up to 24 hours after GBP administration.
abstract.6: Data were analysed with a population approach using the stochastic approximation expectation maximization algorithm.
abstract.7: Weight, body mass index, sex, biomarkers of renal function and diabetes, and genotypes for the main genetic polymorphisms of SLC22A2 (rs316019) and SLC22A4 (rs1050152), the genes encoding the transporters for organic cations OCT2 and OCTN1, were tested as potential covariates.
abstract.8: Results: GBP drug disposition was described by a 1-compartment model with lag-time, first-order absorption and linear elimination.
abstract.9: The total clearance was dependent on estimated glomerular filtration rate.
abstract.10: Population estimates (between-subject variability in percentage) for lag time, first-order absorption rate, apparent volume of distribution and total clearance were 0.316 h (10.6%), 1.12 h-1 (10.7%), 140 L (7.7%) and 14.7 L/h (6.97%), respectively.
abstract.11: No significant association was observed with hyperglycaemia, glycated haemoglobin, diabetes diagnosis, age, sex, weight, body mass index, SLC22A2 or SLC22 A4 genotypes.
abstract.12: Conclusion: This population pharmacokinetics model accurately estimated GBP concentrations in patients with neuropathic pain, using estimated glomerular filtrationrate as a covariate for total clearance.
abstract.13: The distribution and excretion processes of GBP were not affected by hyperglycaemia or diabetes.

adaptation1.1: Neuropathic pain is caused by damage to the nervous system (like brain and spinal cord) and is often described as a shooting pain, burning sensation, or numbness. Gabapentin is a common medication used to treat neuropathic pain, including neuropathic pain caused by diabetes.
adaptation1.2: The objective of this study is to evaluate the role of diabetes and controlling blood sugar on people taking gabapentin.
adaptation1.3: A clinical trial is conducted in patients with neuropathic pain due to type 2 diabetes (19 people) or a slipped disc in the neck or spine (10 people).
adaptation1.4: All participants are treated with a single dose of gabapentin by mouth.
adaptation1.5: Blood is sampled up to 24 hours after gabapentin is given.
adaptation1.6: Data are analyzed using computer models.
adaptation1.7: Other information are included in the model including weight, sex, kidney functions and other changes in genes that impact how the medication works.
adaptation1.9: The total clearance of gabapentin from the body depends on how well the kidneys are able to process and filter the drug.
adaptation1.10: The estimated total clearance of the drug (completely removed) in the population is 14.7 liters per hour.
adaptation1.11: No major association is found with having high blood sugar levels, a diabetes diagnosis, or with age, sex, weight or other factors evaluated.
adaptation1.12: This model studying how the drug is processed in the body estimates gabapentin concentrations in patients with neuropathic pain.
adaptation1.13: The distribution and clearance processes of gabapentin are not affected by having high blood sugar levels or diabetes.

adaptation2.1: Gabapentin (GBP), an antiseizure drug, can treat neuropathic or nerve-related pain, including diabetic neuropathic pain.
adaptation2.2: We evaluate the role of diabetes and blood sugar control on drug activity in the GBP population.
adaptation2.3: A trial was done in 29 patients with neuropathic pain, 19 from type 2 diabetes and 10 from lower back/neck disc herniation or bulging.
adaptation2.4: All participants swallowed a single dose of GBP.
adaptation2.5: Blood was taken up to 24 hours after GBP treatment.
adaptation2.10: Measurements for lag time, absorption rate, volume of distribution, and clearance rate were 0.316 h (10.6%), 1.12 h-1 (10.7%), 140 L (7.7%) and 14.7 L/h (6.97%), respectively.
adaptation2.11: No link was seen with high blood sugar, blood sugar levels, diabetes diagnosis, age, sex, weight, body mass index, or certain DNA sequences.
adaptation2.12: This model measuring drug activity accurately estimated GBP concentrations in those with neuropathic pain, using kidney drug filtration rate for total drug clearance.
adaptation2.13: The distribution and removal processes of GBP were not affected by high blood sugar or diabetes.

33.question: How long does it take for gabapentin to go out of the body?

22421952.Title: Use of methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta in stage 3, 4 or 5 non-dialysis chronic kidney disease

abstract.1: Background: Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) is indicated for the treatment of anaemia due to chronic kidney disease.
abstract.2: Its long half-life allows it to be administered once per month in maintenance therapy.
abstract.3: Objective: To evaluate the use, effectiveness and cost of PEG-EPO in a group of pre-dialysis chronic renal failure patients.
abstract.4: Method: Retrospective observational study in pre-dialysis patients who began treatment with PEG-EPO between May 2008 and February 2009.
abstract.5: The following data were gathered: age, sex, haemoglobin levels (Hb) and erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) dose and frequency.
abstract.6: The follow-up period was 12 months.
abstract.7: Results: We included 198 patients.
abstract.8: Mean Hb upon starting PEG-EPO in patients who had received no prior treatment was 10.8g/l, and 11.6g/l at 90 days (P<.0001).
abstract.9: In patients previously treated with ESA, mean Hb before starting PEG-EPO treatment was 11.2g/l, and 11.4g/l at 12 months (P=.846).
abstract.10: Hb values were higher than 12g/l (P<.0001) after 12 months of treatment in 25% of patients; of these, 45% had values above 13g/l.
abstract.11: We observed doses 39% lower than those indicated on the drug leaflet, resulting in a reduction in the originally expected theoretical costs.
abstract.12: Conclusions: The doses of PEG-EPO administered to patients with a prior history of ESA treatment were lower than those indicated by the drug leaflet, and Hb remained stable after 12 months of treatment.
abstract.13: A large portion of the patients had levels above the 13g/l threshold.

adaptation1.1: Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) is an injection that is often used to treat anemia (low red blood cells) due to chronic kidney disease.
adaptation1.2: It stays in the body long enough to be given once per month.
adaptation1.3: The objective of this study is to evaluate the use, effectiveness and cost of PEG-EPO in a group of chronic kidney failure patients who have not started dialysis, a process of using a machine to clean the blood of a person whose kidneys are not working normally.
adaptation1.4: This study uses data from pre-dialysis patients who started treatment with Methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta (PEG-EPO) between May 2008 and February 2009.
adaptation1.5: The following data are gathered: age, sex, hemoglobin levels (count of proteins that carry oxygen in the blood) and the dose and frequency of medication called erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) to help make red blood cells.
adaptation1.6: The follow-up period is 12 months.
adaptation1.7: The study included 198 patients.
adaptation1.8: The average hemoglobin levels when patients start PEG-EPO who had received no prior treatment is 10.8 grams/liter, and is 11.6 grams/liter at 90 days.
adaptation1.9: In patients who are previously treated with ESA medications to help make red blood cells, the average hemoglobin levels before starting PEG-EPO treatment is 11.2 grams/liter, and is 11.4 grams/liter at 12 months.
adaptation1.10: Hemoglobin levels are higher than 12 grams/liter after 12 months of treatment in 25% of patients. Among these patients, 45% have levels above 13 grams/liter.
adaptation1.11: Researchers observed doses 39% lower than those listed on the drug leaflet or description, resulting in less cost than originally expected.
adaptation1.12: In conclusion, the doses of PEG-EPO given to patients with a prior history of erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) treatment are lower than those noted in the drug leaflet. Also, hemoglobin levels remained stable after 12 months of treatment.
adaptation1.13: A large portion of the patients had levels above the 13 grams/liter threshold.

23636234.Title: Management of protein-energy wasting in non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease: reconciling low protein intake with nutritional therapy

abstract.1: Protein-energy wasting (PEW), characterized by a decline in body protein mass and energy reserves, including muscle and fat wasting and visceral protein pool contraction, is an underappreciated condition in early to moderate stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and a strong predictor of adverse outcomes.
abstract.2: The prevalence of PEW in early to moderate CKD is ≥20-25% and increases as CKD progresses, in part because of activation of proinflammatory cytokines combined with superimposed hypercatabolic states and declines in appetite.
abstract.3: This anorexia leads to inadequate protein and energy intake, which may be reinforced by prescribed dietary restrictions and inadequate monitoring of the patient's nutritional status.
abstract.4: Worsening uremia also renders CKD patients vulnerable to potentially deleterious effects of uncontrolled diets, including higher phosphorus and potassium burden.
abstract.5: Uremic metabolites, some of which are anorexigenic and many of which are products of protein metabolism, can exert harmful effects, ranging from oxidative stress to endothelial dysfunction, nitric oxide disarrays, renal interstitial fibrosis, sarcopenia, and worsening proteinuria and kidney function.
abstract.6: Given such complex pathways, nutritional interventions in CKD, when applied in concert with nonnutritional therapeutic approaches, encompass an array of strategies (such as dietary restrictions and supplementations) aimed at optimizing both patients' biochemical variables and their clinical outcomes.
abstract.7: The applicability of many nutritional interventions and their effects on outcomes in patients with CKD with PEW has not been well studied.
abstract.8: This article reviews the definitions and pathophysiology of PEW in patients with non-dialysis-dependent CKD, examines the current indications for various dietary modification strategies in patients with CKD (eg, manufactured protein-based supplements, amino acids and their keto acid or hydroxyacid analogues), discusses the rationale behind their potential use in patients with PEW, and highlights areas in need of further research.

adaptation1.1: Protein-energy wasting is a decline in the amount of protein in the body and leads to less stored energy. It is a condition present in early to moderate stages of chronic kidney disease and a signal that negative health outcomes may occur.
adaptation1.2: Protein-energy wasting often increases as chronic kidney disease gets worse, in part because of more inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) combined with too much breakdown of proteins and loss of appetite.
adaptation1.3: This leads to not enough proteins and energy, which may be held up by dietary restrictions from doctors and not enough monitoring of how the patient's nutrition impacts their health.
adaptation1.4: Worsening uremia, which is when there is too much waste in the blood, may make uncontrolled diets have a negative impact on chronic disease patients.
adaptation1.5: Too many waste products in the blood that would normally be removed by urine can have harmful effects, including an imbalance of free radicals and antioxidants in the body (which can lead to cell and tissue damage), endothelial dysfunction which is damaged functioning of the lining of blood vessels impacting the heart, and other conditions.
adaptation1.6: Nutritional interventions (changing diet and diet behavior to reach a health goal) in chronic kidney disease, when combined with other therapies unrelated to nutrition, create a number of strategies aimed at improving the internal systems of the body in the patient and the patient's health outcomes.
adaptation1.7: How nutritional interventions can work and their effects on patients with chronic kidney disease with protein-energy wasting is not well studied.
adaptation1.8: This article reviews the definitions and the process of protein-energy wasting in patients with chronic kidney disease who are not on dialysis, and examines when changes in the diet is appropriate and areas that need further research.

26391748.Title: Practical Approach to Detection and Management of Chronic Kidney Disease for the Primary Care Clinician

abstract.1: A panel of internists and nephrologists developed this practical approach for the Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative to guide assessment and care of chronic kidney disease (CKD) by primary care clinicians.
abstract.2: Chronic kidney disease is defined as a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <60 mL/min/1.73m  and/or markers of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
abstract.3: In clinical practice the most common tests for CKD include GFR estimated from the serum creatinine concentration (eGFR) and albuminuria from the urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio.
abstract.4: Assessment of eGFR and albuminuria should be performed for persons with diabetes and/or hypertension but is not recommended for the general population.
abstract.5: Management of CKD includes reducing the patient's risk of CKD progression and risk of associated complications, such as acute kidney injury and cardiovascular disease, anemia, and metabolic acidosis, as well as mineral and bone disorder.
abstract.6: Prevention of CKD progression requires blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg, use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers for patients with albuminuria and hypertension, hemoglobin A1c ≤7% for patients with diabetes, and correction of CKD-associated metabolic acidosis.
abstract.7: To reduce patient safety hazards from medications, the level of eGFR should be considered when prescribing, and nephrotoxins should be avoided, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
abstract.8: The main reasons to refer to nephrology specialists are eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m(2), severe albuminuria, and acute kidney injury.
abstract.9: The ultimate goal of CKD management is to prevent disease progression, minimize complications, and promote quality of life.

adaptation1.1: A group of internal medicine and kidney doctors developed a practical approach to guide the assessment (diagnosis) and care of chronic kidney disease by primary care doctors.
adaptation1.2: Chronic kidney disease is defined by using a glomerular filtration rate, a blood test that checks how well your kidneys are working, and/or other measurements or conditions that are a sign of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
adaptation1.3: The most common tests for chronic kidney disease include the glomerular filtration rate that is estimated from the amount of creatinine (a waste product from the normal wear and tear on muscles) in the blood and too much albumin (a blood protein) in the urine which is called albuminuria.
adaptation1.4: These tests for creatinine levels and albumin proteins should be done for people with diabetes and/or high blood pressure but are not recommended for the general population.
adaptation1.5: Managing chronic kidney disease includes reducing the patient's risk of the disease getting worse and risk of related complications, such as acute or immediate kidney injury or heart disease.
adaptation1.6: To prevent chronic kidney disease from worsening, managing blood pressure, using medications to treat high albumin levels and high blood pressure, measuring hemoglobin levels (red blood cells) for patients with diabetes, and correcting when there is too much acid in the body's fluids is needed.
adaptation1.7: To reduce the negative effect of medications on patients, the level of creatinine should be noted when prescribing drugs, and nephrotoxins which can damage the kidneys should be avoided.
adaptation1.8: The main reasons to send a patient to a kidney specialist are based on creatinine levels, severe albuminuria (too much protein in urine), and acute kidney injury (a sudden episode of kidney failure).
adaptation1.9: The main goal of managing chronic kidney disease is to prevent the disease from getting worse, to minimize complications, and to promote quality of life.

adaptation2.1: A group of specialists created this practical approach for Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative to guide analysis and care of long-lasting or chronic kidney disease (CKD) by primary care workers.
adaptation2.2: Long-lasting kidney disease is a low kidney filtration rate and/or markers of kidney damage for at least 3 months.
adaptation2.3: In clinical practice, the most common tests for CKD include kidney filtration rate of blood creatinine, a chemical waste, (eGFR) and high blood albumin, a blood protein, from the albumin-to-creatinine ratio in urine.
adaptation2.4: Measuring eGFR and albumin levels should be done in persons with diabetes and/or high blood pressure but not for the general population.
adaptation2.5: Managing CKD includes lowering the patient's risk of CKD worsening and risk of associated issues, like immediate kidney injury, heart disease, low blood level, high acid level, and mineral and bone disorder.
adaptation2.6: Preventing CKD progression requires blood pressure <140/90 mm Hg, certain blood pressure medications for patients with high blood pressure and albumin, lower blood sugar for diabetics, and correcting high body acid levels linked with CKD.
adaptation2.7: To reduce patient safety hazards from medications, eGFR should be considering when prescribing. Kidney toxins should be avoided, like a class of anti-inflammatory drugs.
adaptation2.8: The main reasons to contact kidney specialists are eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m(2), high blood albumin, and immediate kidney injury.
adaptation2.9: The goal of CKD treatment is prevent disease worsening, reduce issues, and better quality of life.

28434208.Title: Dietary interventions for adults with chronic kidney disease

abstract.1: Background: Dietary changes are routinely recommended in people with chronic kidney disease (CKD) on the basis of randomised evidence in the general population and non-randomised studies in CKD that suggest certain healthy eating patterns may prevent cardiovascular events and lower mortality.
abstract.2: People who have kidney disease have prioritised dietary modifications as an important treatment uncertainty.
abstract.3: Objectives: This review evaluated the benefits and harms of dietary interventions among adults with CKD including people with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) treated with dialysis or kidney transplantation.
abstract.4: Main results: We included 17 studies involving 1639 people with CKD.
abstract.5: Three studies enrolled 341 people treated with dialysis, four studies enrolled 168 kidney transplant recipients, and 10 studies enrolled 1130 people with CKD stages 1 to 5.
abstract.6: Eleven studies (900 people) evaluated dietary counselling with or without lifestyle advice and six evaluated dietary patterns (739 people), including one study (191 people) of a carbohydrate-restricted low-iron, polyphenol enriched diet, two studies (181 people) of increased fruit and vegetable intake, two studies (355 people) of a Mediterranean diet and one study (12 people) of a high protein/low carbohydrate diet.
abstract.7: Risks of bias in the included studies were generally high or unclear, lowering confidence in the results.
abstract.8: Participants were followed up for a median of 12 months (range 1 to 46.8 months).
abstract.9: Studies were not designed to examine all-cause mortality or cardiovascular events.
abstract.10: In very-low quality evidence, dietary interventions had uncertain effects on all-cause mortality or ESKD.
abstract.11: In absolute terms, dietary interventions may prevent one person in every 3000 treated for one year avoiding ESKD, although the certainty in this effect was very low.
abstract.12: Across all 17 studies, outcome data for cardiovascular events were sparse.
abstract.13: Dietary interventions in low quality evidence were associated with a higher health-related quality of life (2 studies, 119 people: MD in SF-36 score 11.46, 95% CI 7.73 to 15.18; I2 = 0%).
abstract.14: Adverse events were generally not reported.
abstract.15: Dietary interventions lowered systolic blood pressure (3 studies, 167 people: MD -9.26 mm Hg, 95% CI -13.48 to -5.04; I2 = 80%) and diastolic blood pressure (2 studies, 95 people: MD -8.95, 95% CI -10.69 to -7.21; I2 = 0%) compared to a control diet.
abstract.16: Dietary interventions were associated with a higher estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) (5 studies, 219 people: SMD 1.08; 95% CI 0.26 to 1.97; I2 = 88%) and serum albumin levels (6 studies, 541 people: MD 0.16 g/dL, 95% CI 0.07 to 0.24; I2 = 26%).
abstract.17: A Mediterranean diet lowered serum LDL cholesterol levels (1 study, 40 people: MD -1.00 mmol/L, 95% CI -1.56 to -0.44).
abstract.18: Authors' conclusions: Dietary interventions have uncertain effects on mortality, cardiovascular events and ESKD among people with CKD as these outcomes were rarely measured or reported.
abstract.19: Dietary interventions may increase health-related quality of life, eGFR, and serum albumin, and lower blood pressure and serum cholesterol levels.
abstract.20: Based on stakeholder prioritisation of dietary research in the setting of CKD and preliminary evidence of beneficial effects on risks factors for clinical outcomes, large-scale pragmatic RCTs to test the effects of dietary interventions on patient outcomes are required.

adaptation1.1: Changes in diet are often recommended for people with chronic kidney disease on the basis of evidence in the general population and in other studies of chronic kidney disease.
adaptation1.2: People who have kidney disease have prioritized changes in their diet as uncertain treatment.
adaptation1.3: This review evaluates the benefits and harms of dietary interventions (changing diet and diet behavior to reach a health goal) among adults with chronic kidney disease, including people with end-stage kidney disease treated with dialysis (a process that uses a machine to clean the blood because the kidneys are not working) or kidney transplantation or donation.
adaptation1.4: Researchers include 17 studies involving 1639 people with chronic kidney disease.
adaptation1.5: Three studies include 341 people treated with dialysis, four studies have 168 kidney transplant recipients, and 10 studies have 1130 people with chronic kidney disease at stages ranging from 1 to 5.
adaptation1.6: Among these studies, 11 evaluated dietary counselling with or without lifestyle advice, and 6 evaluated dietary patterns, including 1 study of a low-carb/low-iron with many plant-based foods diet, 2 studies of increased fruit and vegetable intake, 2 studies of a Mediterranean diet and 1 study of a high protein/low carb diet.
adaptation1.7: Risks of bias in these studies are generally high or unclear, lowering confidence in how true the results are in these papers.
adaptation1.8: Participants are followed up for about 12 months, but the time ranges between 1 to 46.8 months.
adaptation1.9: Studies are not designed to examine all causes of illness or heart disease events.
adaptation1.10: In very low quality evidence, dietary interventions or treatment have uncertain effects on deaths from any cause or end-stage kidney disease.
adaptation1.11: Dietary interventions to treat kidney disease may prevent one person in every 3000 treated for one year to avoid end-stage kidney disease, although the certainty that this result will happen is very low.
adaptation1.12: Across all 17 studies, outcome data for heart events are limited.
adaptation1.13: Dietary interventions in low quality evidence studies are associated with a higher health-related quality of life.
adaptation1.14: Adverse (unexpected and negative) events are generally not reported.
adaptation1.15: In some studies, dietary interventions lowered systolic blood pressure (top blood pressure number) and diastolic blood pressure (bottom blood pressure number) compared to a control diet.
adaptation1.16: Dietary interventions are associated with a higher estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), a blood test that measures removal of creatinine levels which are waste products from digestion and muscle breakdown. They are also linked to higher albumin (liver proteins that keep fluid in the bloodstream) levels in the blood.
adaptation1.17: A Mediterranean diet lowered LDL (bad) cholesterol levels.
adaptation1.18: In conclusion, dietary interventions have uncertain effects on death, heart events, and end-stage kidney disease among people with chronic kidney disease because these effects are rarely measured or described.
adaptation1.19: Dietary interventions may increase health-related quality of life, eGFR, and albumin levels in the blood, and lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
adaptation1.20: Large-scale clinical studies to test the effects of dietary interventions on patient outcomes are needed.

adaptation2.1: Diet changes are usually recommended in people with long-lasting or chronic kidney disease (CKD) since studies suggest certain healthy eating patterns may prevent heart-related events and lower deaths.
adaptation2.2: People with kidney disease have important diet changes as a treatment uncertainty.
adaptation2.3: This review explored the pros and cons of dietary treatment in adults with CKD including those with kidney failure treated with an artificial kidney machine or kidney transplant.
adaptation2.4: We included 17 studies with 1639 people with CKD.
adaptation2.5: Three studies used 341 people treated with an artifical kidney disease. Four studies had 168 kidney transplant receivers. 10 studies had 1130 people with low to severe CKD.
adaptation2.6: Eleven studies (900 people) evaluated diet counselling with or without lifestyle advice. Six evaluated diet patterns (739 people), including one study (191 people) of a carb-restricted low-iron, high plant-nutrient diet, two studies (181 people) of increased fruit and vegetable intake, two studies (355 people) of a Mediterranean diet and one study (12 people) of a high protein/low carb diet.
adaptation2.7: Risk of bias in the studies were generally high or unclear, casting doubts in the results.
adaptation2.8: Participants were checked for an average of 12 months.
adaptation2.9: Studies were not made to examine all-cause death or heart-related events.
adaptation2.10: In very-low quality results, diet interventions had uncertain effects on all-cause deaths or kidney failure.
adaptation2.11: In established results, diet treatments may prevent kidney failure in one in every 3000 people, although the certainty of this effect was very low.
adaptation2.12: Across all 17 studies, outcome data for heart-related evens was rare.
adaptation2.13: Diet treatments in low quality evidence was linked with a higher heart-related quality of life.
adaptation2.14: Side effects were generally not reported.
adaptation2.15: Diet treatments lowered systolic and diastolic blood pressure compared to a control or regular diet.
adaptation2.16: Diet treatments were linked with a higher kidney filtration rate and blood levels of albumin, a blood protein.
adaptation2.17: A Mediterranean diet lowered "unwanted" blood cholesterol levels.
adaptation2.18: Diet treatments have uncertain effects on death, heart-related events, and kidney failure among people with CKD since these outcomes were rarely measured or reported.
adaptation2.19: Diet treatment may increased health-related quality of life, kidney filtration rate, and blood albumin. Diet treatment may lower blood pressure and blood cholesterol levels.
adaptation2.20: Based on the importance of diet research for CKD and initial evidence of beneficial effects on health, large-scale studies to test the effects of diet treatments on patient outcomes are needed.

31573641.Title: Chronic Kidney Disease Diagnosis and Management: A Review

abstract.1: Importance: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the 16th leading cause of years of life lost worldwide.
abstract.2: Appropriate screening, diagnosis, and management by primary care clinicians are necessary to prevent adverse CKD-associated outcomes, including cardiovascular disease, end-stage kidney disease, and death.
abstract.3: Observations: Defined as a persistent abnormality in kidney structure or function (eg, glomerular filtration rate [GFR] <60 mL/min/1.73 m2 or albuminuria ≥30 mg per 24 hours) for more than 3 months, CKD affects 8% to 16% of the population worldwide.
abstract.4: In developed countries, CKD is most commonly attributed to diabetes and hypertension.
abstract.5: However, less than 5% of patients with early CKD report awareness of their disease.
abstract.6: Among individuals diagnosed as having CKD, staging and new risk assessment tools that incorporate GFR and albuminuria can help guide treatment, monitoring, and referral strategies.
abstract.7: Optimal management of CKD includes cardiovascular risk reduction (eg, statins and blood pressure management), treatment of albuminuria (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers), avoidance of potential nephrotoxins (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), and adjustments to drug dosing (eg, many antibiotics and oral hypoglycemic agents).
abstract.8: Patients also require monitoring for complications of CKD, such as hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hyperphosphatemia, vitamin D deficiency, secondary hyperparathyroidism, and anemia.
abstract.9: Those at high risk of CKD progression (eg, estimated GFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m2, albuminuria ≥300 mg per 24 hours, or rapid decline in estimated GFR) should be promptly referred to a nephrologist.
abstract.10: Conclusions and relevance: Diagnosis, staging, and appropriate referral of CKD by primary care clinicians are important in reducing the burden of CKD worldwide.

adaptation1.1: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is the 16th leading cause of years of life lost worldwide.
adaptation1.2: Appropriate screening, diagnosis, and care by primary care (family) doctors are necessary to prevent negative outcomes associated with CKD, including heart disease, end-stage kidney disease, and death.
adaptation1.3: Defined as an ongoing impairment in kidney structure or function for more than 3 months, chronic kidney disease affects 8% to 16% of people worldwide.
adaptation1.4: In developed countries, CKD is most commonly associated with diabetes and high blood pressure.
adaptation1.5: However, less than 5% of patients with early CKD report knowing about of their disease.
adaptation1.6: Among people diagnosed as having CKD, new risk assessment tools can help guide treatment, monitoring, and inform when to send patients to a specialist. These new tools include using the glomerular filtration rate, a blood test that checks how well your kidneys are working, and albuminuria, which is too much albumin (a blood protein) in the urine.
adaptation1.7: The best management of CKD includes reducing risk of heart disease, treating albuminuria, avoiding medications that are toxic to the kidneys, and changes to drug dosing, such as antibiotics.
adaptation1.8: Patients also need monitoring for complications with CKD, such as higher than normal potassium levels, too much acid in the fluids of the body, too much phosphorus in the blood, low vitamin D, overactive glands in the neck that produce parathyroid (calcium-regulating) hormone, and anemia (low red blood cells).
adaptation1.9: Those at high risk of chronic kidney disease progression based on tests that check how well the kidneys are working or too much albumin (a protein) in the urine, which is called albuminuria, should be quickly sent to a kidney specialist.
adaptation1.10: Diagnosis, determining the stage, and appropriate referral of chronic kidney disease by primary care doctors are important in reducing the negative impact of chronic kidney disease worldwide.

33388899.Title: Muscle-Bone Crosstalk in Chronic Kidney Disease: The Potential Modulatory Effects of Exercise

abstract.1: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a prevalent worldwide public burden that increasingly compromises overall health as the disease progresses.
abstract.2: Two of the most negatively affected tissues are bone and skeletal muscle, with CKD negatively impacting their structure, function and activity, impairing the quality of life of these patients and contributing to morbidity and mortality.
abstract.3: Whereas skeletal health in this population has conventionally been associated with bone and mineral disorders, sarcopenia has been observed to impact skeletal muscle health in CKD.
abstract.4: Indeed, bone and muscle tissues are linked anatomically and physiologically, and together regulate functional and metabolic mechanisms.
abstract.5: With the initial crosstalk between the skeleton and muscle proposed to explain bone formation through muscle contraction, it is now understood that this communication occurs through the interaction of myokines and osteokines, with the skeletal muscle secretome playing a pivotal role in the regulation of bone activity.
abstract.6: Regular exercise has been reported to be beneficial to overall health.
abstract.7: Also, the positive regulatory effect that exercise has been proposed to have on bone and muscle anatomical, functional, and metabolic activity has led to the proposal of regular physical exercise as a therapeutic strategy for muscle and bone-related disorders.
abstract.8: The detection of bone- and muscle-derived cytokine secretion following physical exercise has strengthened the idea of a cross communication between these organs.
abstract.9: Hence, this review presents an overview of the impact of CKD in bone and skeletal muscle, and narrates how these tissues intrinsically communicate with each other, with focus on the potential effect of exercise in the modulation of this intercommunication.

adaptation1.1: Chronic kidney disease is a common health condition around the world and impacts the overall health of a person as the disease gets worse.
adaptation1.2: Bones and muscles attached to bones are tissues highly affected by chronic kidney disease, which damages their functions and activities and contributes to poor quality of life.
adaptation1.3: Sarcopenia is a disorder that results in loss of muscle mass and function and is found to impact overall skeletal muscle health in chronic kidney disease.
adaptation1.4: Bone and muscle tissues are linked in the body, and together, they regulate systems in the body that help the body function and process and distribute nutrients.
adaptation1.5: The skeletal muscle cells release small proteins that regulate different parts of the body, including bone activity.
adaptation1.6: Regular exercise is found to be beneficial to overall health.
adaptation1.7: Also, the positive effect exercise is thought to have on bones and muscles, as well as on function and activity, leads to the suggestion of regular physical exercise as a way to help muscle and bone-related disorders.
adaptation1.8: The detection of bone and muscle proteins after exercise strengthens the idea of a cross communication between these organs.
adaptation1.9: This review presents an overview of the impact of chronic kidney disease in bones and muscles attached to bones and describes how these tissues communicate with each other, with a focus on the possible effect of exercise.

33439824.Title: The Management of Non-Dialysis-Dependent Chronic Kidney Disease in Primary Care

abstract.1: Background: Approximately 10% of adults in Germany have chronic kidney disease (CKD).
abstract.2: The prevalence of CKD among patients being cared for by general practitioners is approximately 30%, and its prevalence in nursing homes is over 50%.
abstract.3: An S3 guideline has been developed for the management of CKD in primary care.
abstract.4: Methods: The guideline is based on publications retrieved by a systematic search of the literature for international guidelines published in the period 2013-2017, and additional searches on specific questions.
abstract.5: It was created by the German College of General Practitioners and Family Physicians (Deutsche Gesellschaft für Allgemeinmedizin und Familienmedizin, DEGAM) and consented with the German Societies of Nephrology and Internal Medicine (DGfN, DGIM) and patient representation.
abstract.6: Results: Upon the initial diagnosis of CKD (glomerular filtration rate [GFR] <60 mL/ min), the patient's blood pressure and urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) should be measured, and the urine should be examined for hematuria.
abstract.7: Monitoring intervals are determined on an individual basis depending on the stage of disease and the patient's general state of health and personal preferences.
abstract.8: Nephrological consultation should be obtained if the GFR is less than 30 mL/min, if CKD is initially diagnosed (GFR 30-59 mL/min) in the presence of persistent hematuria without any urological explanation or of albinuria in stage A2 or higher, if the patient has refractory hypertension requiring three or more antihypertensive drugs, or if the renal disease is rapidly progressive.
abstract.9: The threshold for referring a patient should be kept low for persons under age 50; persons over age 70 should be referred only if warranted in consideration of their comorbidities and individual health goals.
abstract.10: Conclusion: The main elements of the treatment of CKD are the treatment of hypertension and diabetes and the modification of lifestyle factors.
abstract.11: An innovation from the primary care practioner's perspective is the assessment of albuminuria with the albumin-to-creatinine ratio.

adaptation1.1: About 10% of adults in Germany have chronic kidney disease, which is when the kidneys are damaged and can't filter waste and extra fluid from the blood.
adaptation1.2: The percentage of chronic kidney disease among patients being cared for by primary care doctors (family doctors) is about 30% and is over 50% in nursing homes.
adaptation1.3: A guideline has been developed for the care of chronic kidney disease in primary (family) care offices.
adaptation1.4: This guideline is based on existing, available data in articles published during 2013 - 2017 and also on additional searches of data on specific questions.
adaptation1.5: It is created by the German College of General Practitioners and Family Physicians and agreed with by the German Societies of Nephrology and Internal Medicine and patient representation.
adaptation1.6: At the first diagnosis of chronic kidney disease, the patient's blood pressure, as well as a urine sample that may indicate a kidney complication from high proteins, should be measured. The urine should also be checked for the presence of blood.
adaptation1.7: How often the patient should be monitored is based on the individual and depends on the stage of disease, the patient's overall health, and personal preferences.
adaptation1.8: A doctor who specializes in kidney disease should be consulted based on tests that check how well the kidneys are working, if there is blood in the urine, if the patient's blood pressure requires 3 or more drugs, and if the kidney disease is quickly getting worse.
adaptation1.9: The requirements and test levels to refer a patient under the age of 50 years for specialty care should be kept low. People over 70 should be referred only if necessary due to other illnesses and individual health goals.
adaptation1.10: The main parts of treating chronic kidney disease are the treatment of high blood pressure and diabetes and changing lifestyle.
adaptation1.11: A new assessment from the family doctor is a sign of kidney disease due to too much of a protein called albumin in the urine.

33993809.Title: Current treatment options for secondary hyperparathyroidism in patients with stage 3 to 4 chronic kidney disease and vitamin D deficiency

abstract.1: Introduction: Secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT) represents a complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
abstract.2: Vitamin D system is altered since early CKD, and vitamin D deficiency is an established trigger of SHPT.
abstract.3: Although untreated SHPT may degenerate into tertiary hyperparathyroidism with detrimental consequences in advanced CKD, best treatments for counteracting SHPT from stage 3 CKD are still debated.
abstract.4: Enthusiasm on prescription of vitamin D receptor activators (VDRA) in non-dialysis renal patients, has been mitigated by the risk of low bone turnover and positive calcium-phosphate balance.
abstract.5: Nutritional vitamin D is now suggested as first-line therapy to treat SHPT with low 25(OH)D insufficiency.
abstract.6: However, no high-grade evidence supports the best choice between ergocalciferol, cholecalciferol, and calcifediol (in its immediate or extended-release formulation).
abstract.7: Areas covered: The review discusses available data on safety and efficacy of nutritional vitamin D, VDRA and nutritional therapy in replenishing 25(OH)D deficiency and counteracting SHPT in non-dialysis CKD patients.
abstract.8: Expert opinion: Best treatment for low 25(OH)D and SHPT remains unknown, due to incomplete understanding of the best homeostatic, as mutable, adaptation of mineral metabolism to CKD progression.
abstract.9: Nutritional vitamin D and nutritional therapy appear safest interventions, whenever contextualized with single-patient characteristics.
abstract.10: VDRA should be restricted to uncontrolled SHPT by first-line therapy.

adaptation1.1: A disease of the parathyroid (calcium-regulating) glands in the neck that is caused by another disease is called secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT), with symptoms that include weak bones, kidney stones, and tiredness. SHPT represents a complication or bad effect of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
adaptation1.2: The vitamin D system is altered early in CKD, and not enough vitamin D is an established trigger of SHPT.
adaptation1.3: Untreated SHPT may become tertiary hyperparathyroidism (when too much of the parathyroid hormone is produced even when the original problem is corrected) with harmful consequences in advanced chronic kidney disease. However, the best treatments for acting against SHPT from stage 3 chronic kidney disease are still debated.
adaptation1.4: Enthusiasm on prescription of vitamin D treatments in non-dialysis kidney patients is lessened by the risk of low bone turnover (when the bone tissue is reabsorbed and replaced by a new bone), and positive calcium-phosphate balance that makes sure systems in the body work well.
adaptation1.5: Nutritional vitamin D is now suggested as first-line therapy to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism with low vitamin D blood test scores.
adaptation1.6: However, no high-grade evidence supports the best choice between which vitamin D product to prescribe.
adaptation1.7: Other areas covered in this review are the data available on safety and effectiveness (success) of vitamin D, vitamin D prescriptions, and nutritional therapy in restoring vitamin D to normal levels (via diet) and acting against secondary hyperparathyroidism.
adaptation1.8: The expert opinion is that the best treatment for low vitamin D levels and secondary hyperparathyroidism remains unknown due to some missing key information.
adaptation1.9: Nutritional vitamin D and nutritional therapy appear to be the safest interventions (treatments), when considering the individual characteristics of each patient.
adaptation1.10: Prescriptions for vitamin D should be limited to only uncontrolled secondary hyperparathyroidism by first treatment recommended.
