adaptation1.14: There is some evidence to suggest a difference in those needing blood transfusions or transfers when comparing mini- and standard PCNL, as well as differences in stone-free rates when comparing mini-PCNL with ureteroscopy for the treatment of lower pole stones, common kidney stones that are unlikely to pass on their own.

adaptation2.1: Mini percutaneous nephrolithotomy (mini-PCNL) is a tool to remove a variety of stones including: large kidney stones > 2 cm, lower kidney stones > 1 cm, kidney stones unaffected by shockwaves or surgical extraction, stones in complex tubes transporting urine, and large, unchanged stones causing inflammation in tubes carrying urine.
adaptation2.2: After lying down, an open-ended tube to collect urine, device to collect stone fragments, or device to block escape of stone framgents is inserted into the urine tube.
adaptation2.3: A thin tube is placed in the bladder to drain pee.
adaptation2.4: Guided sound waves are used to explore the kidney and reach the urine-collecting system with an 18 g surgical needle.
adaptation2.5: Once access is obtained, a small 0.5 cm skin cut is made and the opening is enlarged with wires.
adaptation2.6: A metallic or self-enlarging vacuum is placed with x-ray guidance.
adaptation2.7: A rigid, small tube with a lens is used to explore the urine-collecting system.
adaptation2.8: Once a stone is observed, options for breaking it up include using a device with sound waves and bullet energy, or special laser.
adaptation2.9: Using a tube with a scope can ensure full removal from the urine-collecting system.
adaptation2.10: A tube to keep the urine flowing can be placed against or with urine flow for drainage.
adaptation2.11: The opening is sealed with a special surgical sealant.
adaptation2.12: The accompanying video (Supplementary Video S1) shows guidelines for care after surgery and troubleshooting techniques for mini-PCNL along with the actual surgery.
adaptation2.13: There are a few trials comparing mini-PCNL with the standard treatment option.
adaptation2.14: There may be a difference in urine transfer rates between mini- and standard PCNL. There may also be differences in stone-free rates between mini-PCNL and the standard treatment of lower kidney stones.

34518466.Title: Flexible Ureterorenoscopy under Spinal Anesthesia: Focus on Technique, Results, Complications, and Patients' Satisfaction from a Large Series

abstract.1: Introduction: Although spinal anesthesia (SA) may reduce postoperative morbidity, most urologists perform flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS) under general anesthesia (GA).
abstract.2: The objective of our study is to provide technical details, results, complications, and patients' satisfaction with fURS performed under exclusive SA.
abstract.3: Methods: We analyzed all consecutive fURS performed under SA to treat renal stones from March 2011 to February 2017.
abstract.4: Details of technique, operative time, outcomes, need for further treatments, complications, and patients' satisfaction were evaluated.
abstract.5: Results: Two hundred thirty-four fURS under SA were considered.
abstract.6: SA was performed through L2-L3 vertebral interspace in 64.1%.
abstract.7: Patients were discharged the same day of surgery.
abstract.8: Mean stone burden was 13.5 ± 6.6 mm and mean operative time 76.9 ± 34.6 min.
abstract.9: Single-procedure SFR was 69.7%.
abstract.10: Further treatments were performed in 22.8%. 96.6% had no anesthesia-related complications.
abstract.11: No Clavien-Dindo grade ≥ IIIb complications were noticed.
abstract.12: 99.6% of patients were satisfied with SA.
abstract.13: No cases of conversion from SA to GA occurred.
abstract.14: Conclusion: fURS can be performed safely and efficiently under SA, taking into account a few details of the technique.
abstract.15: Patients' satisfaction with SA is very high, and complications are rare.
abstract.16: Although SA is usually adopted in unfit patients for GA, it may be considered as a viable alternative in fit patients.

adaptation1.1: Spinal anesthesia (SA) are medicines that numbs the back of patients to reduce pain after surgery. However, most urologists (doctors who specialize in conditions of the urinary or urine-related tract) use general anesthesia that puts a patient into a heavy sleep when doing a flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS), a procedure that uses a telescope, and occasionally a laser, to break stones in the kidney into pieces.
adaptation1.2: The objective of this study is to provide technical details, results, complications, and patients' satisfaction with fURS when performed under only spinal anesthesia to numb only parts of the body.
adaptation1.3: Researchers analyzed all flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS) done under spinal anesthesia to treat kidney stones from March 2011 to February 2017.
adaptation1.4: Details of the technique, how long the procedure takes, results, need for additional treatments, complications, and patients' satisfaction are evaluated.
adaptation1.5: There are 234 fURS procedures done under spinal anesthesia considered.
adaptation1.6: SA was done in a certain area of the lower spine in 64.1%.
adaptation1.7: Patients are sent home the same day of surgery.
adaptation1.8: The average stone burden was 13.5 millimeters (± 6.6 millimeters), and the average procedure time is 76.9 minutes ( ± 34.6 minutes).
adaptation1.9: The percentage of patients who are stone free after one procedure is 69.7%.
adaptation1.10: Additional treatments are done in 22.8% of patients. Overall, 96.6% had no anesthesia-related complications.
adaptation1.11: No complications that required general anesthesia or other major complications are noticed.
adaptation1.12: 99.6% of patients are satisfied with spinal anesthesia.
adaptation1.13: No cases of changing from spinal anesthesia to general anesthesia occurred.
adaptation1.14: In conclusion, flexible ureterorenoscopy (fURS)can be performed safely and efficiently under spinal anesthesia when accounting for a few details of the procedure.
adaptation1.15: Patients' satisfaction with spinal anesthesia is very high, and complications are rare.
adaptation1.16: Although spinal anesthesia is usually used in unfit patients for general anesthesia, it may be considered as a good alternative in fit patients.

34540217.Title: The effect of stone and patient characteristics in predicting extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy success rate: A cross sectional study

abstract.1: Introduction: We determine the effect of patient characteristics (age, sex, and body mass index BMI) and stone characteristics (density, location, and size) by non-contrast computed tomography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (CT-KUB) in predicting the success of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) in the treatment of kidney and ureteric stones.
abstract.2: We present this study to further enrich the knowledge of physicians towards the effect of different patient characteristics upon predicting extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy success rates.
abstract.3: Methods: We evaluated 155 patients who received ESWL for renal and ureteric stone measuring 3-20 mm (mm), over a 3-month period.
abstract.4: The stone size in millimeters, density in Hounsfield units (HU) and its location was determined on pre-treatment CT-KUB.
abstract.5: ESWL was successful if post-treatment residual renal stone fragments were ≤3 mm and for ureteric stones should be totally cleared.
abstract.6: Results: The overall success of ESWL treatment was observed in 65.8% of the 155 patients.
abstract.7: There was no significant difference seen when the effect of patients age, sex and BMI were studied with ESWL outcome with P values were 0.155, 0.101 and 0.415 respectively.
abstract.8: Also, stone location either in the kidney or ureter has no statistically significant effect on ESWL response rate.
abstract.9: while stone density and size determined on CT KUB have statistically significant effect on the success rate of ESWL with a P-value of 0.002 and 0.000 respectively.
abstract.10: Conclusions: This study shows that determination of stone density and stone size on CT KUB pre ESWL can help to predict the outcome of ESWL.
abstract.11: We propose that stone density <500 HU and stone size < 5 mm are highly likely to result in successful ESWL.

adaptation1.1: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a procedure to break up stones in the body by using shock waves and an X-ray to target the stones. Researchers search for the effects of patient characteristics (age, sex, and body mass index or BMI) and stone characteristics (density, location, and size) on how successful ESWL procedure is on stones in the kidneys, ureters (tubes that carry urine from the kidney to the urinary bladder), and bladder.
adaptation1.2: This study is intended to increase the knowledge of doctors on the effect of different patient characteristics on predicting how successful using extra-corporal shock wave lithotripsy is.
adaptation1.3: Researchers evaluate 155 patients who receive ESWL for stones in the kidney and ureter (tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) over a 3-month period.
adaptation1.4: The stone size in millimeters (mm), density, and its location is determined using an x-ray scan before patients received treatment.
adaptation1.5: ESWL is considered to be successful if the size of remaining kidney stone fragments after the procedure are ≤3 mm and if ureteric stones are totally cleared.
adaptation1.6: The overall success of ESWL treatment was observed in 65.8% of the 155 patients.
adaptation1.7: There is no major difference seen when the effect of age, sex, and BMI of patients are studied with ESWL outcomes.
adaptation1.8: Also, stone location either in the kidney or ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) has no statistically significant effect (not likely to happen randomly or by chance) on the success of ESWL.
adaptation1.9: Stone density and size based on the scanned images have a statistically significant effect on the success rate of ESWL.
adaptation1.10: In conclusion, this study shows that finding out the density and size of stones using a scanned x-ray image before extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) can help predict the outcome of ESWL.
adaptation1.11: Researchers of this study suggest that low stone density and size are highly likely to result in successful ESWL.

34603756.Title: Controlled Fragmentation of Urinary Stones as a Method of Preventing Inflammatory Infections in the Treatment of Urolithiasis (Experience in Successful Clinical Use)

abstract.1: The introduction of technologically advanced methods of lithotripsy into medical practice changes the nature of postoperative complications.
abstract.2: Among them, the main complications are inflammatory infections.
abstract.3: This largely determines the search for new, improved methods of stone fragmentation avoiding small stone fragments and dissemination of the pelvicalyceal system of the kidney with stone-associated infection.
abstract.4: The authors have developed a method for controlled stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a hot-spot effect at the optical fiber end.
abstract.5: The aim of the study was to evaluate the efficacy of controlled urinary stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a highly heated distal end of the optical fiber light guide as a method of preventing inflammatory infections in clinical practice.
abstract.6: Materials and methods: We analyzed 1666 case histories of urolithiasis patients who underwent percutaneous nephrolithotripsy/ nephrolithoextraction and contact ureterolithotripsy/ureteroextraction, we also performed a prospective analysis of complications based on the Clavien-Dindo classification in 90 patients who underwent fine fragmentation of stones with various lithotripters: ultrasonic, pneumatic, and holmium laser.
abstract.7: The method of controlled stone fragmentation by a diode laser with a hot-spot effect was tested on postoperative samples of 26 renal calculi.
abstract.8: For the first time in clinical practice, this method was tested in the bladder cavity (n=10).
abstract.9: Results: In the percutaneous nephrolithotripsy group, postoperative infectious and inflammatory complications occurred in 34.1% of cases, in the percutaneous nephrolithoextraction group - in 24.6%, in the contact ureterolithotripsy group - in 7.8%, in the ureterolithoextraction group - in 2.5%.
abstract.10: The analysis made it possible to identify factors promoting the development of infectious and inflammatory complications.
abstract.11: For the first time in clinical practice, there were successfully performed ten operations of stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a hot-spot effect.
abstract.12: Controlled coarse fragmentation of stones providing the possibility to reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory complications was performed in the bladder as a model for testing the method.
abstract.13: Conclusion: The method of laser-induced controlled coarse fragmentation of stones with a hot-spot effect, developed and tested in clinical practice, is promising for the prevention of infectious and inflammatory complications in patients with potentially infected stones since their fine fragmentation and, consequently, spread of stone-associated toxins and microflora within the urinary system is avoided.

adaptation1.1: Introducing lithotripsy, a non-surgical method to break masses like kidney stones into pieces, into medical practice changes the type of complications that may occur after operations.
adaptation1.2: The main complications are inflammatory infections that may result in pain, redness, or swelling.
adaptation1.3: New and improved methods of breaking down stones, avoiding small stone fragments and sending them through the kidneys to be released through urine are searched.
adaptation1.4: The authors develop a method to break stones using a continuous-wave diode laser, which is a constant stream of laser light that can also reduce the scattering of stones by using a hot-spot or energy-focused effect.
adaptation1.5: The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of controlling the fragmenting of urinary stones (hard masses of minerals in the bladder), using a continuous-wave diode laser as a method of preventing inflammatory infections.
adaptation1.6: Researchers analyzed 1666 cases of patients with kidney stones who underwent different methods to remove kidney stones. These methods include percutaneous nephrolithotripsy/nephrolithoextraction (removal of stones by a small incision through the skin and stones pulled out of the incision) and ureterolithotripsy/ureteroextraction (when a flexible tube is inserted through the bladder and the ureter which connects the kidneys and bladder and stones are found with a camera and removed). An additional analysis on 90 patients is also done on patients with stones that were fragmented into tiny pieces using different lithotripters, non-surgical devices that crush stones using shock waves.
adaptation1.7: The method of controlled stone fragmentation by a diode laser with a hot-spot effect is tested on samples of 26 kidney stones during or after operations.
adaptation1.8: For the first time in clinical practice, this method is tested in the bladder (with 10 patients).
adaptation1.9: In the group that underwent a small incision to remove the stone, infections and inflammation complications after the procedure occurred in 34.1% of cases. In the group that had stones removed from the incision (nephrolithoextraction) had complications in 24.6%, and in the ureterolithotripsy group where a tube and camera are used, there are 7.8% cases with complications. In the ureterolithoextraction group, there are complications in 2.5%.
adaptation1.10: The analysis makes it possible to find things that lead to the development of infectious or inflammatory complications.
adaptation1.11: For the first time, there are successfully performed ten operations of stone fragmentation using a continuous-wave diode laser with a hot-spot effect.
adaptation1.12: Controlling the scattering of fragments of stones makes it possible to reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory complications and is done in the bladder as an example for testing this method.
adaptation1.13: In conclusion, using a laser to control fragmented stones with the hot spot effect is a promising way to prevent infection and inflammation complications in patients with possibly infected stones since small pieces of stones and their spread within the urinary system is avoided.

adaptation2.1: New advanced technology for breaking up stones in the kidney and the tube to the bladder changes the nature of issues after operation.
adaptation2.2: Among them, the main issues are inflammatory infections.
adaptation2.3: This influences the search for new, improved ways of breaking up stones to avoid small fragments and spreading stone-associated infection in the kidney and bladder system.
adaptation2.4: We have created a method for controlled breaking up of stones with a special laser with a hot-spot at one end.
adaptation2.5: This study evaluates the effectiveness of controlled breaking up of stones in urine using a special laser with a hot-spot at one end to prevent inflammatory infections in clinics.
adaptation2.6: We analyzed 1666 patient cases of patients with kidney stones who had operations to remove the stones in the kidney and urine. We also analyzed any complications in 90 patients who had treatment with various devices to break up stones: sound waves, pressurized air, and lasers.
adaptation2.7: The method of controlled breaking up of stones with a special laser with a hot-spot was tested on 26 kidney stone samples collected after surgery.
adaptation2.8: For the first time in clinical practice, this method was tested in the hole in the bladder of 10 patients.
adaptation2.9: In the group that had a small cut to remove kidney stones, infections and inflammatory issues after surgery occured in 34.1% of cases. In the group that had a cut and small tube to remove stones, infections and issues occured in 24.6%. In the group that had a small cut to remove stones in the urine, infections and issues occured in 7.8%. In the group that had a cut and tube to remove stones, infections and issues occured in 2.5%.
adaptation2.10: The analysis helped identify factors that promoted infectious and inflammatory issues.
adaptation2.11: For the first time in clinical practice, there were 10 successful operations of breaking up stones with a special laser with a hot-spot.
adaptation2.12: Controlled breaking up of stones, which may reduce the number of infectious and inflammatory effects, was done in the bladder to test the method.
adaptation2.13: The method of using a laser with a hot-spot to break up stones, developed and tested in clinical practice, may prevent infectious and inflammatory effects in patients with possibly infected stones since their previous stone fragmentation. This method may also prevent spread of stone-associated toxins and bacteria in the urinary system.

36.question: I have had a kidney stone in for almost three years. It’s killing me and none even noticed it till now, even on ultrasound, how will it be taken out?

20194915.Title: Cognitive effects of pregabalin in healthy volunteers: a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

abstract.1: Background: Antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) can be associated with neurotoxic side effects including cognitive dysfunction, a problem of considerable importance given the usual long-term course of treatment.
abstract.2: Pregabalin is a relatively new AED widely used for the treatment of seizures and some types of chronic pain including fibromyalgia.
abstract.3: We measured the cognitive effects of 12 weeks of pregabalin in healthy volunteers.
abstract.4: Methods: Thirty-two healthy volunteers were randomized in a double-blind parallel study to receive pregabalin or placebo (1:1).
abstract.5: Pregabalin was titrated over 8 weeks to 600 mg/d.
abstract.6: At baseline, and after 12 weeks of treatment, all subjects underwent cognitive testing.
abstract.7: Test-retest changes in all cognitive and subjective measures were Z scored against test-retest regressions previously developed from 90 healthy volunteers.
abstract.8: Z scores from the placebo and pregabalin groups were compared using Wilcoxon tests.
abstract.9: Results: Thirty subjects completed the study (94%).
abstract.10: Three of 6 target cognitive measures (Digit Symbol, Stroop, Controlled Oral Word Association) revealed significant test-retest differences between the pregabalin and placebo groups, all showing negative effects with pregabalin (p < 0.05).
abstract.11: These cognitive effects were paralleled by complaints on the Portland Neurotoxicity Scale, a subjective measure of neurotoxicity (p < 0.01).
abstract.12: Conclusion: At conventional doses and titration, pregabalin induced mild negative cognitive effects and neurotoxicity complaints in healthy volunteers.
abstract.13: These effects are one factor to be considered in the selection and monitoring of chronic AED therapy.
abstract.14: Class of Evidence: This study provides Class I evidence that pregabalin 300 mg BID negatively impacts cognition on some tasks in healthy volunteers.

adaptation1.1: Antiepileptic - or antiseizure - drugs (AEDs) can be associated with neurotoxic (brain damaging) side effects including cognitive dysfunction. Cognitive dysfunction or inability to think properly is a problem of considerable importance given the usual long-term course of treatment.
adaptation1.2: Pregabalin is a relatively new AED widely used for the treatment of seizures and some types of chronic pain, including fibromyalgia - full-body pain.
adaptation1.3: We measured the cognitive effects of 12 weeks of pregabalin administration (use) in healthy volunteers.
adaptation1.4: Thirty-two healthy volunteers were randomly assigned to one of two groups: pregabalin or sham treatment/placebo (1:1).
adaptation1.5: Pregabalin dose was continuously increased over 8 weeks to 600 mg/d.
adaptation1.6: Before treatment and after 12 weeks of treatment, all subjects underwent cognitive testing.
adaptation1.7: Test-retest changes in all cognitive and subjective measures were Z scored against test-retest scores taken from 90 healthy volunteers. Z scores determine how far a data point is away from a dataset average.
adaptation1.8: Z scores from the placebo and pregabalin groups were compared.
adaptation1.9: Thirty subjects completed the study (94%).
adaptation1.10: Three of 6 cognitive measures revealed significant test-retest differences between the pregabalin and placebo groups, all showing negative effects with pregabalin.
adaptation1.11: These cognitive effects were paralleled by complaints on the Portland Neurotoxicity Scale, a subjective measure of neurotoxicity.
adaptation1.12: At standard doses and titration, pregabalin led to mild negative cognitive effects and neurotoxicity complaints in healthy volunteers.
adaptation1.13: These effects are one factor to be considered in the selection and monitoring of chronic AED therapy.
adaptation1.14: This study provides evidence that pregabalin 300 mg negatively impacts cognition on some tasks in healthy volunteers.

24532157.Title: Cognitive effects of pregabalin in the treatment of long-term benzodiazepine-use and dependence

abstract.1: Objective: Long-term benzodiazepine (BDZ) use and dependence affect cognitive functioning adversely and partly irreversibly.
abstract.2: Emerging evidence suggests that pregabalin (PGB) might be a safe and efficacious treatment of long-term BDZ use.
abstract.3: The aim of the present study was to investigate the changes in several core cognitive functions after successful treatment of long-term BDZ use and dependence with PGB.
abstract.4: Methods: Fourteen patients with long-term BDZ use (mean duration >15 years) underwent neuropsychological assessment with the mini-mental state examination and four tests from the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery (CANTAB) battery before the initiation of PGB treatment and at a two months follow-up after the cessation of BDZs.
abstract.5: Patients' CANTAB percentile score distributions were compared with normative CANTAB data.
abstract.6: Results: Patients improved on cognitive measures of global cognitive functioning, time orientation, psychomotor speed, and visuospatial memory and learning with strong effect sizes.
abstract.7: By contrast, they failed to improve on measures of attentional flexibility.
abstract.8: Despite their significant improvement, patients' scores on most tests remained still at the lower percentiles of CANTAB normative scores.
abstract.9: Conclusions: Although preliminary, our findings suggest that successful treatment of long-term BDZ use with PGB is associated with a substantial, though only partial, recovery of BDZ-compromised neuropsychological functioning, at least at a 2-month follow-up.

adaptation1.1: Benzodiazepines (BDZ) are drugs that are often used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seixures. Long-term BDZ use and dependence negatively affect cognitive functioning (thinking ability). These effects can be partially irreversible.
adaptation1.2: New evidence suggests that pregabalin (PGB) might be a safe and effective treatment of long-term BDZ use.
adaptation1.3: The goal of the study was investigate the changes in cognitive function after successful treatment of long-term BDZ use and dependence with PGB.
adaptation1.4: Fourteen patients with long-term BDZ use underwent several neurological (brain-related) and cognititive function tests. These evaluations were conducted before the initiation of PGB treatment and at a two months follow-up after the cessation (stopping) of BDZs.
adaptation1.5: Patients' scores from the tests were compared with control data.
adaptation1.6: Patients improved on several cognitive measures with strong effect sizes.
adaptation1.7: By contrast, they failed to improve on measures of attentional flexibility (the ability to shift focus).
adaptation1.8: Despite their significant improvement, patients' scores on most tests were low when compared to control scores.
adaptation1.9: The study findings suggest that successful treatment of long-term BDZ use with PGB is associated (linked) with a substantial, though only partial, recovery of BDZ-compromised brain function, at least at a 2-month follow-up.

28922287.Title: Pregabalin Toxicity Manifesting as Reversible Encephalopathy With Continuous Triphasic Waves in Electroencephalogram

abstract.1: A 74-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy due to diabetes presented with deliberate ingestion of 450 mg of pregabalin (PBG) over a period of 8 hours followed by altered mental status.
abstract.2: A bedside electroencephalogram was performed to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus, which showed continuous triphasic waves (TWs) with slow background activity.
abstract.3: He recovered after 48 hours of stopping PBG, and his repeat electroencephalogram after 72 hours did not show any TWs.
abstract.4: We present a rare case of PBG-induced TWs thereby highlighting the extent of the etiologic spectrum of TWs and discussing the literature related to this association.

adaptation1.1: A 74-year-old man showed nerve damage due to diabetes (a disease involving high blood sugar). The patient had ingested 450 mg of pregabalin (PBG - a nerve pain medication) over a period of 8 hours which was followed by altered mental status.
adaptation1.2: A bedside test for brain activity was performed to rule out nonconvulsive status epilepticus, or a prolonged seizure. The test showed continuous triphasic waves (TWs), which is abnormal body activity, with slow background activity.
adaptation1.3: The patient recovered after 48 hours of stopping PBG. A repeated brain acitivty test after 72 hours did not show any TWs.
adaptation1.4: This study presents a rare case of PBG-induced TWs. This paper highlighting the extent of the etiologic spectrum of TWs, or how TWs promote disease. Additionally, the paper discusses the literature related to this association (or link).

29671676.Title: Effects of gabapentin, pregabalin and gastroretentive gabapentin on simulated driving, daytime sedation and cognition

abstract.1: Aim: Randomized Phase I study examining the effects of gabapentinoids gabapentin, pregabalin and gastroretentive gabapentin on simulated driving performance, sedation and cognitive function in healthy volunteers (n = 32).
abstract.2: Methods: Driving attentiveness, sleepiness and cognition were evaluated prior to subjects receiving study doses.
abstract.3: Blood samples were collected during each treatment.
abstract.4: Results: Subjects receiving gastroretentive gabapentin showed less change in variation in lateral lane position (p = 0.0275), less tremor (p = 0.0304) and fewer vision disturbances compared with gabapentin (p = 0.0177).
abstract.5: Statistically significant decrease in One Card Learning Test performance was observed after treatment with gastroretentive gabapentin.
abstract.6: Conclusion: Gastroretentive gabapentin demonstrated reduced driving impairment and lower scores on key neurotoxicity measures.
abstract.7: Further studies in patients with postherpetic neuralgia are needed.

adaptation1.1: A study investigated the effects of gabapentinoids, drugs often used to prevent and control seizures. The tested drugs include gabapentin, pregabalin and gastroretentive gabapentin. The study evaluated the effects of the drugs on simulated driving performance, sedation (relaxation) and cognitive function (thinking ability). The study was conducted in 32 healthy volunteers.
adaptation1.2: Driving attentiveness, sleepiness, and cognition were evaluated prior to treatment within participants.
adaptation1.3: Blood samples were collected during each treatment.
adaptation1.4: Subjects receiving gastroretentive gabapentin showed less change in variation (differences) in lateral (side) lane position, less tremors (shaking), and fewer vision disturbances compared with gabapentin.
adaptation1.5: Statistically significant decreases in One Card Learning Test (a test used to test short term memory) performance was observed after treatment with gastroretentive gabapentin.
adaptation1.6: The study concluded gastroretentive gabapentin reduced driving impairment and showed lower scores on key neurotoxicity (abnormal nervous system function) measures.
adaptation1.7: Further studies in patients with postherpetic neuralgia (nerve-related pain from shingles) are needed.

30003357.Title: Cognitive and fatigue side effects of anti-epileptic drugs: an analysis of phase III add-on trials

abstract.1: We aimed to investigate the terms used to refer to cognitive and fatigue related side effects and their prevalence in phase III add-on clinical trials of anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs).
abstract.2: We extracted data from publicly available FDA documents as well as the published literature.
abstract.3: Target drug doses were then calculated as drug loads and divided into three categories (low, average, high).
abstract.4: The odds ratio of developing the side effects was calculated for each drug load, and the presence of a dose-response effect was also assessed.
abstract.5: We found that the cognitive terms used across trials were very variable, and data on discontinuation rates were limited.
abstract.6: Placebo rates for cognitive side effects ranged from 0 to 10.6% while those for fatigue ranged from 2.5 to 37.7%.
abstract.7: Keeping in mind the variable placebo rates and terminology, the majority of AEDs exhibited a clear dose response effect and significant odds ratios at high doses except brivaracetam and zonisamide for the cognitive side effects and tiagabine, topiramate, and zonisamide for the fatigue side effects.
abstract.8: Due to their clinical relevance and impact on quality of life, new trials should make data related to the prevalence and discontinuation rates of these side effects publicly available.
abstract.9: Given the clear dose response effect, physicians should consider aiming for lower drug loads and adjusting doses to improve tolerability.

adaptation1.1: The aim of this study was to investigate the terms used to refer to cognitive (memory-related) and fatigue related side effects. Additionally, the study aimed to understand the terms' prevalence or frequency in phase III add-on clinical trials of anti-epileptic - or antiseizure - drugs (AEDs).
adaptation1.2: The authors extracted data from publicly available Food and Drug Administration of the United States (FDA) documents as well as the published literature.
adaptation1.3: Target drug doses were then calculated as drug loads and divided into three categories (low, average, high).
adaptation1.4: Odds ratio, or the measure of association between drug intake and side effect development, were calculated for each drug load. The presence of a dose-response effect, or when side effects increase when drug dose increases, was also assessed (measured).
adaptation1.5: The authors found that the cognitive terms used across trials were very variable (all over the place). Data on discontinuation rates (stoppings in side effects) were limited.
adaptation1.6: Placebo (harmless pills) rates for cognitive side effects ranged from 0 to 10.6% while those for fatigue ranged from 2.5 to 37.7%.
adaptation1.7: Most of the AEDs exhibited a clear dose-response effect and significant odds ratios for developing side effects at high doses.
adaptation1.8: Due to their clinical (medical) relevance and impact on quality of life, new trials should make data related to the prevalence and discontinuation rates of these side effects publicly available.
adaptation1.9: Due to the clear dose response effect, doctors should consider using lower drug loads and adjusting doses to improve tolerability (or ability to take the drug).

adaptation2.1: We explored the terms used to refer to the mental and tiredness related side effects and their frequency in clinical trials of anti-seizure or anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs).
adaptation2.2: We took data from publicly available government documents and from public literature.
adaptation2.3: Target drug doses were calculated as drug amounts and divided into low, average, and high.
adaptation2.4: We calculated the chances of developing side effects for each drug amount and if there was a link between the amount of dose and the bodily response.
adaptation2.5: We found that mental terms used across trials varied. Data on drug stoppage rates were limited.
adaptation2.6: Dummy treatment rates for mental side effects ranged from 0 to 10.6%. The same rates for fatigue ranged from 2.5 to 37.7%.
adaptation2.7: With the inconsistent dummy treatment rates and terminology in mind, the majority of AEDs showed a link between dose amount and bodily response. Except for the drugs brivaracetam and zonisamide, they also showed increased chance of mental side effects at high doses. Except for the drugs tiagabine, topiramate, and zonisamide, they also showed increased chance of fatigue side effects at high doses.
adaptation2.8: Due to their health-related relevance and impact on life, new trials should make data about the amount and stoppage rates of these side effects publicly available.
adaptation2.9: Given the clear link between dose amount and bodily response, physicians should consider lower drug amount to improve tolerability.

30335626.Title: Cognitive Effects of Perioperative Pregabalin: Secondary Exploratory Analysis of a Randomized Placebo-controlled Study

abstract.1: Background: Pregabalin has shown opioid sparing and analgesic effects in the early postoperative period; however, perioperative effects on cognition have not been studied.
abstract.2: A randomized, parallel group, placebo-controlled investigation in 80 donor nephrectomy patients was previously performed that evaluated the analgesic, opioid-sparing, and antihyperalgesic effects of pregabalin.
abstract.3: This article describes a secondary exploratory analysis that tested the hypothesis that pregabalin would impair cognitive function compared to placebo.
abstract.4: Methods: Eighty patients scheduled for donor nephrectomy participated in this randomized, placebo-controlled study.
abstract.5: Pregabalin (150 mg twice daily, n = 40) or placebo (n = 40) was administered on the day of surgery and the first postoperative day, in addition to a pain regimen consisting of opioids, steroids, local anesthetics, and acetaminophen.
abstract.6: Specific cognitive tests measuring inhibition, sustained attention, psychomotor speed, visual memory, and strategy were performed at baseline, 24 h, and 3 to 5 days after surgery, using tests from the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery.
abstract.7: Results: In the spatial working memory within errors test, the number of errors increased with pregabalin compared to placebo 24 h after surgery; median (25th, 75th percentile) values were 1 (0, 6) versus 0 (0, 1; rate ratio [95% CI], 3.20 [1.55 to 6.62]; P = 0.002).
abstract.8: Furthermore, pregabalin significantly increased the number of errors in the stop-signal task stop-go test compared with placebo; median (25th, 75th percentile) values were 3 (1, 6) versus 1 (0, 2; rate ratio, 2.14 [1.13 to 4.07]; P = 0.020).
abstract.9: There were no significant differences between groups in the paired associated learning, reaction time, rapid visual processing, or spatial working memory strategy tests.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Perioperative pregabalin significantly negatively affected subdomains of executive functioning, including inhibition, and working memory compared to placebo, whereas psychomotor speed was not changed.

adaptation1.1: Pregabalin is a nerve pain medication. The drug has been shown to help reduce opioid use (opioid-sparing) and have pain relieving (analgesic) effects in the early period following a surgery. However, effects before, during, and after surgery on cognition (thinking ability) have not been studied.
adaptation1.2: A study in 80 patients that had one or both of their kidneys removed was previously conducted to evaluate the opioid-sparing, analgesic, and antihyperalgesic (reduction of pain sensitivity) effects of pregabalin.
adaptation1.3: This paper describes a secondary investigation that tested if pregabalin would impair cognitive function when compared to a control (no treatment) group.
adaptation1.4: Eighty patients scheduled for donor nephrectomy (removal of one or both kidneys) participated in this study.
adaptation1.5: Pregabalin (150 mg twice daily) or placebo (a harmless pill) was administered (given) on the day of surgery and the first post-operation day. This was given in addition to a pain regimen consisting of opioids, steroids, local anesthetics, and acetaminophen (pain medication).
adaptation1.6: Cognitive tests measuring inhibition (restraint), sustained attention, psychomotor (movement) speed, visual memory, and strategy were performed before, 24 h, and 3 to 5 days after surgery.
adaptation1.7: The spatial working memory test is used to determine if a participant can recall the configuration of a series of images. During the test, the number of errors increased with pregabalin treatment compared to placebo 24 h after surgery.
adaptation1.8: Furthermore, pregabalin significantly increased the number of errors in the stop-signal task stop-go test compared with placebo.
adaptation1.9: There were no significant differences between treatment groups in the paired associated learning, reaction time, rapid visual processing, or spatial working memory strategy tests.
adaptation1.10: Perioperative (around surgery time) pregabalin significantly negatively affected several aspects of cognitive function when compared to placebo. However, psychomotor speed or movement was not changed.

32377769.Title: The neurotoxic effect of long-term use of high-dose Pregabalin and the role of alpha tocopherol in amelioration: implication of MAPK signaling with oxidative stress and apoptosis

abstract.1: Pregabalin abuse has become an emerging concern; thus, the current study has been designed to study the neurotoxic hazards of prolonged high-dose of pregabalin (akin to that abused by addicts) and to evaluate the effect of alpha tocopherol as a possible ameliorating agent.
abstract.2: The current study evaluated the brain neurotransmitters; dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine.
abstract.3: The study also assessed the expression of the apoptosis-related markers Bax, Bcl2, and caspase 3.
abstract.4: Western-blotted analysis of the three major mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs), the c-JUN N-terminal kinase (JNK), the p38 MAPK, and the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), has also been performed.
abstract.5: The study also evaluated oxidative stress via assessment of the cortical tissue levels of reduced glutathione and malondialdehyde and the activity of superoxide dismutase.
abstract.6: Histopathological examination and histomorphometric evaluation of the darkly degenerated cortical neurons have also been performed.
abstract.7: Pregabalin in high doses (150 mg/kg/day and 300 mg/kg/day) disrupted the ERK/JNK/p38-MAPK signaling, reversed the bax/bcl2 ratio, and induced oxidative stress.
abstract.8: It also diminished the release of dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine and increased the count of degenerated neurons.
abstract.9: Alpha tocopherol treatment significantly attenuated the deleterious effects induced by pregabalin.
abstract.10: The role of alpha tocopherol in ameliorating the oxidative stress injury, and apoptosis induced by pregabalin, along with its role in normalizing neurotransmitters, modulating the ERK/JNK/p38-MAPK signaling pathways and improving the histopathological cortical changes, offers alpha tocopherol as a promising adjunctive therapy in patients undergoing prolonged pregabalin therapy as those suffering from prolonged seizures and neuropathies.

adaptation1.1: Pregabalin, a drug often used to treat nerve damage, abuse has become an emerging concern. The current study aimed to investigate nervous system (brain and spinal cord) damage caused by prolonged high-dose of pregabalin. This dose is similar to that used by addicts. Additionally, the study aimed to evaluate the effect of alpha tocopherol, a type of Vitamin E, as a possible agent to help side effects.
adaptation1.2: The study evaluated the brain neurotransmitters; dopamine, glutamate, and norepinephrine. Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers in the body.
adaptation1.3: The study also assessed (measured) the expression of the cell death-related markers Bax, Bcl2, and caspase 3.
adaptation1.4: Additional tests evaluating three mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) was completed. MAPKs are involved in biological pathways that direct cell response to mitogens, or things that induce cell division.
adaptation1.5: The study also evaluated oxidative stress which is an imbalance between production and accumulation of harmful oxygen reactive species.
adaptation1.6: Evaluations of the degenerated cortical neurons, nerve cells within the brain, were also preformed.
adaptation1.7: Pregabalin in high doses (150 mg/kg/day and 300 mg/kg/day) disrupted the signaling for cellular processes, reversed ratios of proteins needed for cell cycles, and induced oxidative stress.
adaptation1.8: It also diminished the release of neurotransmitters and increased the count of degenerated neurons.
adaptation1.9: Alpha tocopherol treatment significantly reduced the harmful effects induced by pregabalin.
adaptation1.10: Alpha tocopherol plays a role in reducing negative side effects induced by pregabalin. It also normalizes neurotransmitter levels, positively effects signaling pathways for cell function, and improves cortical (brain) structure changes. These reasons make alpha tocopherol a promising therapeutic option in patients undergoing prolonged pregabalin therapy.

32632575.Title: Pregabalin-associated stuttering and frequent blepharospasm: case report and review

abstract.1: Herpes zoster is an acute, painful, herpes skin disease caused by varicella-zoster virus, which may cause viral meningitis.
abstract.2: Pregabalin has been shown to be efficacious in the treatment of pain in patients with herpes zoster.
abstract.3: However, it has the side effects of neurotoxicity.
abstract.4: We describe a 68-year-old female patient with herpes zoster, and she was treated with pregabalin.
abstract.5: The patient presented with stuttering and frequent blepharospasm after 3 days of pregabalin treatment.
abstract.6: Pregabalin was discontinued, the symptoms of stuttering and frequent blepharospasm completely resolved without any special treatment after one week.
abstract.7: In this case, the etiology of stuttering and frequent blepharospasm may be related to pregabalin.
abstract.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms associated with the use of pregabalin.

adaptation1.1: Herpes zoster is an acute, painful, herpes skin disease. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The virus may cause viral meningitis or inflammation of the brain and spinal cord.
adaptation1.2: Pregabalin, a nerve pain medication, has been shown to be effecive in the treatment of pain in patients with herpes zoster.
adaptation1.3: However, it can cause neurotoxicity or alteration of the normal acitivty of the nervous system (brain and spinal cord).
adaptation1.4: This study describes a 68-year-old female patient with herpes zoster, and she was treated with pregabalin.
adaptation1.5: The patient presented with stuttering and frequent, uncontrollable movement of the eyelids after 3 days of pregabalin treatment.
adaptation1.6: Pregabalin was no longer given to the patient. The symptoms of stuttering and frequent eyelid movement completely resolved without any special treatment after one week.
adaptation1.7: In this case, the onset of stuttering and frequent eyelid movement may be related to pregabalin.
adaptation1.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms associated with the use of pregabalin.

adaptation2.1: Herpes zoster (shingles) is an immediate, painful, skin disease involved with reactivating the chickenpox virus. It may cause viral meningitis (inflamation of the brain and spine).
adaptation2.2: Pregabalin, common nerve pain medication, helps treat pain from herpes zoster.
adaptation2.3: However, pregabalin can be toxic to the nervous system.
adaptation2.4: We describe a 68-year-old female with herpes zoster and treated with pregabalin.
adaptation2.5: The patient had stuttering and frequent eye twitching after 3 days of using pregabalin.
adaptation2.6: Pregabalin use was stopped. The symptoms of stuttering and eye twitching completely stopped without any special treatment after one week.
adaptation2.7: In this case, the cause of stuttering and eye twitching may be linked to pregabalin.
adaptation2.8: Clinicians should be alert to the rare symptoms linked with pregabalin use.

33033779.Title: Pregabalin-associated movement disorders: A literature review

abstract.1: Central nervous system adverse effects are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB).
abstract.2: On the other hand, movement disorders (MDs) associated with this drug were rarely described.
abstract.3: However, their occurrence could significantly affect the quality of life of PGB users.
abstract.4: This literature review aims to evaluate the clinical epidemiological profile, pathological mechanisms, and management of PGB-associated MDs.
abstract.5: Relevant reports in six databases were identified and assessed by two reviewers without language restriction.
abstract.6: A total of 46 reports containing 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
abstract.7: The MDs encountered were as follows: 184 individuals with ataxia, 61 with tremors, 39 with myoclonus, 8 with parkinsonism, 1 with restless legs syndrome, 1 with dystonia, 1 with dyskinesia, and 1 with akathisia.
abstract.8: The mean age was 62 years (range: 23-94).
abstract.9: The male sex was slightly predominant with 54.34%.
abstract.10: The mean PGB dose when the MD occurred was 238 mg, and neuropathic pain was the most common indication of PGB.
abstract.11: The time from PGB start to MD was < 1 month at 75%.
abstract.12: The time from PGB withdrawal to recovery was < 1 week at 77%.
abstract.13: All the individuals where the follow-up was reported had a full recovery.
abstract.14: The most common management was PGB withdrawal.
abstract.15: In the literature, the majority of the cases did not report information about timeline events, neurological examination details, or electrodiagnostic studies.
abstract.16: The best management for all MDs is probably PGB withdrawal.
abstract.17: If the patient is on dialysis program, perhaps an increased number of sessions will decrease recovery time.
abstract.18: Furthermore, the addition of a benzodiazepine could accelerate recovery.

adaptation1.1: Central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) adverse effects (side effects) are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB), a drug commonly given for nerve pain.
adaptation1.2: However, movement disorders (MDs) associated with pregabalin were rarely described.
adaptation1.3: However, their occurrence could significantly affect the quality of life of PGB users.
adaptation1.4: This literature review aims to evaluate the clinical incidence, distribution, and control; underlying causative mechanisms; and management of PGB-associated MDs.
adaptation1.5: Relevant scientific papers in six databases were identified and assessed (evaluated) by two reviewers without language restriction.
adaptation1.6: A total of 46 reports containing 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
adaptation1.7: The MDs reported were as follows: 184 individuals with ataxia (loss of full control of body movement), 61 with tremors (shaking), 39 with myoclonus (jerky movement), 8 with Parkinson's disease, 1 with restless legs syndrome, 1 with dystonia (involuntary muscle contraction), 1 with dyskinesia (uncontrolled muscle movement), and 1 with akathisia (feeling of restlessness).
adaptation1.8: The average age was 62 years. The age range was 23 to 94 years old.
adaptation1.9: The male sex was slightly predominant at 54.34% of all cases.
adaptation1.10: The average PGB dose when the MD occurred was 238 mg. Nerve pain was the most common indication of PGB.
adaptation1.11: The time between PGB start and onset of a MD was less than one month for a majority of cases.
adaptation1.12: The time from PGB withdrawal to recovery was less than 1 week for a majority of cases.
adaptation1.13: All the individuals where the follow-up was reported had a full recovery.
adaptation1.14: The most common management was PGB withdrawal.
adaptation1.15: In the literature, the majority of the cases did not report information about timeline events, neurological (brain-related) examination details, or electrodiagnostic studies (using electrical activity to gauge health).
adaptation1.16: The best management for all MDs is probably PGB withdrawal.
adaptation1.17: If the patient is on dialysis (blood filtering and purification) program, perhaps an increased number of sessions will decrease recovery time.
adaptation1.18: Furthermore, the addition of a benzodiazepine (anti-anxiety drug) could speed up recovery.

adaptation2.1: Side effects of the brain and spine are commonly reported with pregabalin (PGB), a common nerve pain medication.
adaptation2.2: However, movement disorders (MDs) linked with this drug were rarely described.
adaptation2.3: Still, their occurence could affect the quality of life of PGB users.
adaptation2.4: This review evaluates the distribution, disease-causing mechanisms, and treatment of PGB-associated MDs.
adaptation2.5: Two reviewers without language issues identified and checked relevant reports in six databases.
adaptation2.6: 46 reports with 305 cases from 17 countries were assessed.
adaptation2.7: The reported MDs include: 184 people with ataxia (impaired coordination), 61 with tremors (shaking movements), 39 with myoclonus (muscle jerks), 8 with parkinsonism (movement abnormalities from a brain disorder), 1 with restless legs syndrome (uncontrollable urge to move legs), 1 with dystonia (repetitive, twisting movements), 1 with dyskinesia (erratic movements), and 1 with akathisia (muscle quivering).
adaptation2.8: Average age was 62 years.
adaptation2.9: Proportion of male sex was 54.34%.
adaptation2.10: Average PGB medication dose when MD occured was 238 mg. Nerve-related pain was the most common effect of PGB.
adaptation2.11: Time from PGB start to MD was <1 month at 75%.
adaptation2.12: Time from PGD drug use withdrawal to recovery was < 1 week at 77%.
adaptation2.13: All individuals with a reported follow-up or later examination had a full recovery.
adaptation2.14: Most common management was PGB drug withdrawal.
adaptation2.15: In the text, many cases did not report information about timeline events, brain-related exam details, or details about the electrical activity of the body.
adaptation2.16: The best treatment for all MDs is likely PGB drug use stoppage.
adaptation2.17: If the patient is on an artificial kidney machine, perhaps more sessions will decrease recovery time.
adaptation2.18: Also, adding a benzodiazepine, an anti-anxiety and anti-seizure drug, could quicken recovery.

33515658.Title: Neurotoxic effects of pregabalin dependence on the brain frontal cortex in adult male albino rats

abstract.1: Pregabalin (PGB) is an analog of the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid.
abstract.2: The currently available evidence favors the misuse and abuse potential of PGB.
abstract.3: However, its neurotoxicity remains unclear.
abstract.4: Therefore, this study assessed the toxic effects of chronic pregabalin dependence as well as withdrawal on the cortical neurons of the frontal lobe.
abstract.5: This study included eighty adult male albino rats which were divided into three groups.
abstract.6: Group I (Control) included 40 rats and was further subdivided into two equal subgroups (IA and IB) as negative and positive controls.
abstract.7: Group II (PGB-dependent) included 20 rats which received PGB starting with the therapeutic dose (300 mg/day), then the doses were gradually increased until they reached the dependent dose (3400 mg/day) by the end of the first month.
abstract.8: Further, the dependent dose was given daily for another 2 months.
abstract.9: Group III (PGB withdrawal) included 20 rats which received PGB as described in group II.
abstract.10: After that, administration of PGB was stopped and the rats were kept for another one month.
abstract.11: By the end of the experiment, all animals were sacrificed by cervical decapitation.
abstract.12: The specimens were taken from the frontal cortex for histologic and immunohistochemical staining as well as morphometric analysis.
abstract.13: Sections of the frontal cortex of group II showed changes in the form of disturbed architectural pattern of cortical layers, apoptotic cells, weak immunoexpression of Bcl-2 and VEGF as well as moderate-strong immunoexpression of iNOS and nestin.
abstract.14: These expressions were significantly different from the control groups, but they were non-significant in comparison with group III.
abstract.15: These findings indicate that chronic PGB dependence induces neurotoxic effects mainly in the form of neuronal apoptosis, gliosis, and oxidative stress injury of the frontal cortex.
abstract.16: The PGB- induced neurotoxic effects persisted after withdrawal.
abstract.17: The influence of these neurotoxic effects and their relevance to the cognitive or neurologic disorders in PGB-dependent individuals warrants further research.
abstract.18: Furthermore, it is recommended to quantify the behavioral changes related to PGB dependence as well as withdrawal in future studies.

adaptation1.1: Pregabalin (PGB) - a nerve pain medication - is an analog of the inhibitory (silencing) neurotransmitter, (chemical messenger in the brain) gamma-aminobutyric acid. Analogs are compounds that have similar structure to other compounds but are not identical.
adaptation1.2: The currently available evidence favors the misuse and abuse potential of PGB.
adaptation1.3: However, its neurotoxicity (poison to the brain) remains unclear.
adaptation1.4: The aim of this study was to assess (measure) the toxic effects of long term dependence on pregabalin. Additionally, the study aimed to assess how withdrawal from (removal of) PGB affects cortical neurons (brain cells) in the front lobe of the brain.
adaptation1.5: This study included eighty adult male albino rats which were divided into three groups.
adaptation1.6: Group I (Control) included 40 rats and was further subdivided into two equal subgroups (IA and IB) as negative and positive controls - groups to compare the treatment group to.
adaptation1.7: Group II (PGB-dependent) included 20 rats. Each rat received PGB starting with the therapeutic (beneficial) dose (300 mg/day). The doses were gradually increased until they reached the dependent (full) dose (3400 mg/day) by the end of the first month.
adaptation1.8: Further, the dependent dose was given daily for another 2 months.
adaptation1.9: Group III (PGB withdrawal) included 20 rats which received PGB as described in Group II.
adaptation1.10: After that, administration (use) of PGB was stopped, and the rats were kept for another one month.
adaptation1.11: By the end of the experiment, all animals were sacrificed by cervical decapitation.
adaptation1.12: Samples were taken from the frontal cortex, a section of the brain, for further analysis.
adaptation1.13: Brain samples showed changes in cortical layer (brain) structure, dying cells, and decreased expression of several critical factors needed for cell function.
adaptation1.14: These expression level changes were significantly different from the Control groups. However, they were non-significant in comparison with Group III.
adaptation1.15: These results indicate that long-term PGB dependence causes neurotoxic effects. These effects include brain cell death, scarring of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), and increased reactive oxidative species (harmful chemicals from oxygen) in the frontal cortex.
adaptation1.16: The PGB- induced neurotoxic effects continued after withdrawal.
adaptation1.17: Further research is needed to understand the impact of these neurotoxic effects and their relevance to the cognitive (memory-related) or neurologic (brain-related) disorders in PGB-dependent individuals.
adaptation1.18: Furthermore, it is recommended to measure the behavioral changes related to PGB dependence and withdrawal in future studies.

37.question: Do memory problems improve over time when taking pregabalin?

1933737.Title: Pressure ulcers. Physical, supportive, and local aspects of management

abstract.1: Pressure ulcers are a common and serious problem predominately among elderly persons who are confined to bed or chair.
abstract.2: Additional factors associated with pressure ulcer development include cerebrovascular accident, impaired nutritional intake, urinary or fecal incontinence, hypoalbuminemia, and previous fracture.
abstract.3: Implementation of preventive measures, such as an in-depth assessment for mobility, a pressure-relieving device combined with adequate repositioning, and thorough evaluation for nutritional status and urinary incontinence, significantly reduce pressure ulcer incidence.
abstract.4: If the pressure ulcer is a partial thickness (stage II) wound, the causative factors are probably friction or moisture.
abstract.5: If the ulcer is full thickness (stage III and IV), it is secondary to pressure or shearing forces.
abstract.6: The development of wound infection is the most common complication in the management approach.
abstract.7: Osteomyelitis is not an uncommon occurrence and must be initially ruled out in all full thickness pressure ulcers.
abstract.8: Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue is necessary prior to further treatment and assessments.
abstract.9: Antibiotic therapy is indicated only upon evidence of infection (cellulitis, osteomyelitis, leukocytosis, bandemia, or fever).
abstract.10: Topical pharmacologic agents may be used to prevent or treat infection but must be carefully controlled to avoid such adverse effects as toxicity to the wound, allergic reaction, and development of resistant pathogens.
abstract.11: Proper use of occlusive dressings increase patient comfort, enhance healing, decrease the possibility of infection, save time, and reduce costs.
abstract.12: A patient presenting an ulcer that fails to improve or, because of its size, will take a great deal of time to heal should be evaluated for surgical closure.

adaptation1.1: Pressure ulcers (skin sores) are a common and serious problem. Pressure ulcers mainly occur among elderly persons who are confined to bed or chair.
adaptation1.2: Additional reasons pressure ulcers develop include cerebrovascular accident (damage to the brain and its blood vessels) or impaired nutritional intake (poor diet). Additionally, reasons include urinary or fecal incontinence (lack of control on bladder or bowels), hypoalbuminemia (low blood albumin - a protein in the blood), and previous fracture.
adaptation1.3: Implementation of preventive measures significantly reduce pressure ulcer incidence (frequency). The measures include in-depth assessment of mobility, relieving pressure on the injured area, and evaluating nutritional status and urinary incontinence.
adaptation1.4: If the pressure ulcer is a partial thickness (stage II) wound, the factors causing the injury are probably friction or moisture.
adaptation1.5: If the ulcer is full thickness (stage III and IV), it is secondary to (caused by) pressure or shearing forces.
adaptation1.6: The wound becoming infected is the most common complication in the management approach.
adaptation1.7: Osteomyelitis, or a bone infection, is not an uncommon occurrence. It must be ruled out in all full thickness pressure ulcers.
adaptation1.8: Removal of dead tissue by surgery is necessary prior to further treatment and assessments (measurements).
adaptation1.9: Taking antibiotics (which fight bacteria) is used if there is evidence of infection.
adaptation1.10: Topical (applied on skin) medicines may be used to prevent or treat infection. However, these medicines must be used carefully to avoid adverse effects (bad side effects) like wound toxicity, allergic reaction, and development of resistant pathogens, or harmful foreign organisms.
adaptation1.11: Proper use of air- and water-tight medical wrappings increase patient comfort, enhance healing, decrease the possibility of infection, save time, and reduce costs.
adaptation1.12: A patient presenting an ulcer that does not improve or, because of its size, will take a great deal of time to heal should be evaluated for surgical closure.

abstract.1: The use of wound dressings that are based on the principles of moist wound healing has recently changed the management of pressure ulcers.
abstract.2: These products may improve healing rates but also offer improved comfort to the patient, reduced dressing time and improved cosmesis.
abstract.3: However, healing is unlikely to be achieved unless the factors that contribute to ulcer formation are addressed.
abstract.4: Principles of management include the elimination or reduction of pressure and other contributing factors, treatment of infection, appropriate wound management, involvement and education of the patient and caregivers, and maintenance of healed tissue.
abstract.5: It is estimated that 95 percent of all pressure ulcers are preventable.
abstract.6: Prevention rather than mere treatment of established ulcers remains a top priority in the effort to reduce the incidence of this common, complex and difficult problem.
abstract.7: Use of assessment tools that quantify the primary risk factors for the development of pressure ulcers is helpful in predicting and preventing compromise of tissue.

adaptation1.1: The use of wound dressings based on moist wound healing principles has recently changed how pressure ulcers (skin sores) are treated. Moist wound healing is when an injury is kept damp to prevent drying out.
adaptation1.2: These products may improve healing rates. They may also offer improved comfort to the patient, reduced dressing time, and improved wound appearance.
adaptation1.3: However, healing is unlikely to occur unless the reasons the ulcer was formed are addressed.
adaptation1.4: There are several principles of ulcer management or healing. These principles include: eliminating or reducing pressure and other contributing factors, treating infection, appropriate wound management, involvement and education of the patient and caregivers, and maintenance of healed tissue.
adaptation1.5: It is estimated that 95% of all pressure ulcers are preventable.
adaptation1.6: Preventing ulcers rather than treating ulcers is a priority in the effort to reduce the incidence (frequency) of this common, complex, and difficult problem.
adaptation1.7: Use of assessment (measurement) tools that identify the main reasons pressure ulcers are caused is helpful to predict and prevent injuries to the skin.

17410826.Title: Prevention and management of pressure ulcers

abstract.1: Pressure ulcers represent complex wounds that are difficult to prevent or manage.
abstract.2: Guidelines for prevention include identifying patients at risk, reducing the effect of pressure, friction, shear forces, and assessing co-morbidities such as nutritional status.
abstract.3: Management should follow eight treatment strategies including accurately assessing the ulcer, relieving pressure, assessing pain and nutritional status, maintaining a moist wound environment, encouraging granulation and epithelial tissue formation, evaluating the need for debridement, and controlling infection.

adaptation1.1: Pressure ulcers, or bedsores, are injuries to the skin and underlying tissues caused by long periods of pressure on the skin. These wounds are complex and are difficult to prevent or manage.
adaptation1.2: Advice on how to prevent getting pressure ulcers include identifying patients at risk, reducing pressure, friction, shear forces, and assessing (measuring) compounding factors such as nutritional status.
adaptation1.3: Management should follow eight treatment strategies. These include accurately assessing the ulcer, relieving pressure, assessing pain and nutritional status, maintaining a damp wound environment, encouraging skin healing, evaluating the need for damaged tissue removal, and controlling infection.

19035067.Title: Pressure ulcers: prevention, evaluation, and management

abstract.1: A pressure ulcer is a localized injury to the skin or underlying tissue, usually over a bony prominence, as a result of unrelieved pressure.
abstract.2: Predisposing factors are classified as intrinsic (e.g., limited mobility, poor nutrition, comorbidities, aging skin) or extrinsic (e.g., pressure, friction, shear, moisture).
abstract.3: Prevention includes identifying at-risk persons and implementing specific prevention measures, such as following a patient repositioning schedule; keeping the head of the bed at the lowest safe elevation to prevent shear; using pressure-reducing surfaces; and assessing nutrition and providing supplementation, if needed.
abstract.4: When an ulcer occurs, documentation of each ulcer (i.e., size, location, eschar and granulation tissue, exudate, odor, sinus tracts, undermining, and infection) and appropriate staging (I through IV) are essential to the wound assessment.
abstract.5: Treatment involves management of local and distant infections, removal of necrotic tissue, maintenance of a moist environment for wound healing, and possibly surgery.
abstract.6: Debridement is indicated when necrotic tissue is present.
abstract.7: Urgent sharp debridement should be performed if advancing cellulitis or sepsis occurs.
abstract.8: Mechanical, enzymatic, and autolytic debridement methods are nonurgent treatments.
abstract.9: Wound cleansing, preferably with normal saline and appropriate dressings, is a mainstay of treatment for clean ulcers and after debridement.
abstract.10: Bacterial load can be managed with cleansing.
abstract.11: Topical antibiotics should be considered if there is no improvement in healing after 14 days.
abstract.12: Systemic antibiotics are used in patients with advancing cellulitis, osteomyelitis, or systemic infection.

adaptation1.1: A pressure ulcer is an injury to the skin or underlying tissue, usually over a bony portion of the body, caused by unrelieved pressure.
adaptation1.2: Factors that make someone more likely to have a pressure ulcer are classified as intrinsic (internal factors) or extrinsic (external factors). Intrinsic factors include limited mobility, poor nutrition, comorbidities, or aging skin. Extrinsic factors include pressure, friction, shear (vertical force), or moisture.
adaptation1.3: There are several preventative protocols for pressure ulcers that can be used. These protocols include identifying at-risk persons and implementing specific prevention measures. Preventative measures include repositioning patients on a schedule, keeping hospital beds at a low and safe elevation to prevent shear, using pressure-reducing surfaces, and assessing (measuring) nutrition and providing supplementation.
adaptation1.4: When an ulcer occurs, wound assessment is needed. When assessing each ulcer, there are several factors that need to be identified. These include ulcer size, location, dead or irregular tissue, discharge, odor, sinus tracts (channels in the skin), wound edge erosion or edge removal, infection, and appropriate staging (I through IV).
adaptation1.5: Treatment involves managing local and spreading infections, removal of dead tissue, maintenance of a moist environment for wound healing, and possibly surgery.
adaptation1.6: Debridement, or removal of damaged tissue from a wound, is indicated when necrotic or dead tissue is present.
adaptation1.7: Urgent sharp debridement should be performed if advancing skin or bleed infection occurs.
adaptation1.8: Mechanical (surgery), enzymatic (chemical agents), and autolytic debridement (body's natural defense system) methods are nonurgent treatments.
adaptation1.9: Wound cleansing, preferably with normal saline (salt water) and appropriate dressings, is common for treatment for clean ulcers and after removal of damaged skin.
adaptation1.10: Bacterial load, or the amount of bacteria within the body, can be managed with cleansing.
adaptation1.11: Topical antibiotics are bacterial-fighting medicines applied to the skin. They should be considered if there is no improvement in healing after 14 days.
adaptation1.12: Systemic antibiotics are medicines normally taken in pill form that effects the whole body. These are used in patients with advancing deep skin infection, bone infection, or whole body infection.

adaptation2.1: A pressure ulcer (bedsore) is a area-limited injury to the skin and neaby body parts, usually over a bone, due to unrelieved pressure.
adaptation2.2: Risk factors can be intrinsic (e.g., limited movement, poor diet, other diseases, aging skin) or extrinsic (e.g, pressure, friction, strain, moisure).
adaptation2.3: Prevention includes identifying at-risk people and applying preventative measures, like regularly moving the patient's position, keeping the bed head low to prevent strain, using pressure-reducing surfaces, evaluating diet and giving diet supplemets, if needed.
adaptation2.4: When an ulcer occurs, examining it (i.e., size, location, type of affected tissue, leaking fluid, odor, wound openings, wear and tea, and infection) and the severity of the ulcer are essential to wound assessment.
adaptation2.5: Treatment includes managing nearby and far-away infetions, removing dead body tissue, maintaining a moist environment for wound healing, and even surgery.
adaptation2.6: Removing damaged body tissue (debridement) is needed when dead tissue is present.
adaptation2.7: Urgent debridement should be done if bacterial skin infections develop.
adaptation2.8: Physical removal, use of a chemical topical, and natural forms of debridement are nonurgent treatments.
adaptation2.9: Wound cleaning, preferably with salt water and appropriate bandages, are common treatment for clean bedsores and after removing damaged body tissue.
adaptation2.10: Bacteria can be managed with cleaning.
adaptation2.11: Antibiotics applied skin-level should be considered if there is no healing after 14 days.
adaptation2.12: Full-body antibiotics are used in those with developing skin infections, inflammation, or full-body infection.

28631809.Title: Anabolic steroids for treating pressure ulcers

abstract.1: Background: Pressure ulcers, also known as bed sores, pressure sores or decubitus ulcers develop as a result of a localised injury to the skin or underlying tissue, or both.
abstract.2: The ulcers usually arise over a bony prominence, and are recognised as a common medical problem affecting people confined to a bed or wheelchair for long periods of time.
abstract.3: Anabolic steroids are used as off-label drugs (drugs which are used without regulatory approval) and have been used as adjuvants to usual treatment with dressings, debridement, nutritional supplements, systemic antibiotics and antiseptics, which are considered to be supportive in healing of pressure ulcers.
abstract.4: Anabolic steroids are considered because of their ability to stimulate protein synthesis and build muscle mass.
abstract.5: Comprehensive evidence is required to facilitate decision making, regarding the benefits and harms of using anabolic steroids.
abstract.6: Objectives: To assess the effects of anabolic steroids for treating pressure ulcers.
abstract.7: Main results: The review contains only one trial with a total of 212 participants, all with spinal cord injury and open pressure ulcers classed as stage III and IV.
abstract.8: The participants were mainly male (98.2%, 106/108) with a mean age of 58.4 (standard deviation 10.4) years in the oxandrolone group and were all male (100%, 104/104) with a mean age of 57.3 (standard deviation 11.6) years in the placebo group.
abstract.9: This trial compared oxandrolone (20 mg/day, administered orally) with a dose of placebo (an inactive substance consisting of 98% starch and 2% magnesium stearate) and reported data on complete healing of ulcers and adverse events.
abstract.10: There was very low-certainty evidence on the relative effect of oxandrolone on complete ulcer healing at the end of a 24-week treatment period (risk ratio RR) 0.81, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.52 to 1.26) (downgraded twice for imprecision due to an extremely wide 95% CI, which spanned both benefit and harm, and once for indirectness, as the participants were mostly male spinal cord injury patients).
abstract.11: Thus, we are uncertain whether oxandrolone improves or reduces the complete healing of pressure ulcers, as we assessed the certainty of the evidence as very low.
abstract.12: There was low-certainty evidence on the risk of non-serious adverse events reported in participants treated with oxandrolone compared with placebo (RR 3.85, 95% CI 1.12 to 13.26) (downgraded once for imprecision and once for indirectness, as the participants were mostly male spinal cord injury patients).
abstract.13: Thus, the treatment with oxandrolone may increase the risk of non-serious adverse events reported in participants.
abstract.14: There was very low-certainty evidence on the risk of serious adverse events reported in participants treated with oxandrolone compared with placebo (RR 0.54, 95% CI 0.25 to 1.17) (downgraded twice for imprecision due to an extremely wide 95% CI, which spanned both benefit and harm, and once for indirectness, as the participants were mostly male spinal cord injury patients).
abstract.15: Of the five serious adverse events reported in the oxandrolone-treated group, none were classed by the trial teams as being related to treatment.
abstract.16: We are uncertain whether oxandrolone increases or decreases the risk of serious adverse events as we assessed the certainty of the evidence as very low.
abstract.17: Secondary outcomes such as pain, length of hospital stay, change in wound size or wound surface area, incidence of different type of infection, cost of treatment and quality of life were not reported in the included trial.
abstract.18: Overall the evidence in this study was of very low quality (downgraded for imprecision and indirectness).
abstract.19: This trial stopped early when the futility analysis (interim analysis) in the opinion of the study authors showed that oxandrolone had no benefit over placebo for improving ulcer healing.
abstract.20: Authors' conclusions: There is no high quality evidence to support the use of anabolic steroids in treating pressure ulcers.
abstract.21: Further well-designed, multicenter trials, at low risk of bias, are necessary to assess the effect of anabolic steroids on treating pressure ulcers, but careful consideration of the current trial and its early termination are required when planning future research.

adaptation1.1: Pressure ulcers, also known as bed sores, pressure sores, or decubitus ulcers develop because of a localized (regionalized) injury to the skin or underlying tissue, or both.
adaptation1.2: The ulcers usually occur in  a bony area of the body. Ulcers are recognized as a common medical problem affecting people confined to a bed or wheelchair for long periods of time.
adaptation1.3: Anabolic (muscle building) steroids are used as off-label drugs. This means they are often used without doctor approval. They have been used to increase healing alongside usual treatment with dressings, debridement (removal of damaged tissue from a wound), nutritional supplements, systemic antibiotics (full-body medicines that fight infection) and antiseptics (antimicrobial skin medication). All of these measures are considered to be supportive in pressure ulcer healing.
adaptation1.4: Anabolic steroids are considered because of their ability to encourage protein synthesis and build muscle mass.
adaptation1.5: Thorough evidence is required to encourage decision making in regards to the benefits and harms of using anabolic steroids.
adaptation1.6: The goal of this study is to evaluate the effects of anabolic steroids for treating pressure ulcers.
adaptation1.7: The review contains a medical trial of 212 participants, all with spinal cord injury and open pressure ulcers classed as stage III and IV.
adaptation1.8: The participants were mainly male with an average age of 58.4 years in the group receiving oxandrolone (synthetic steroid) treatment. Participants were all male with an average age of 57.3 years in the placebo group. Placebos are harmless pills used as control treatments.
adaptation1.9: This trial compared oxandrolone (20 mg/day, administered orally) with placebo treatment. This study reported data on complete healing of ulcers and adverse side effects.
adaptation1.10: There was very low-certainty evidence on the relative effect of oxandrolone on complete ulcer healing at the end of a 24-week treatment period.
adaptation1.11: Therefore, it is unclear if oxandrolone improves or reduces the complete healing of pressure ulcers.
