abstract.4: Results presented as mean ± SEM; statistics: log transformation followed by two-way ANOVA with Bonferroni multiple comparisons, Wilcoxon nonparametric test for comparisons, and the Friedmans' one-way ANOVA; significance: P < 0.05.
abstract.5: Results: Percent blood loss was 40% ± 2, 59% ± 3, 52% ± 3, 49% ± 2, and 54% ± 2 for PTHS-30, PTHS-60, PTHS-60+ST, PTHS-60+ST+FF, and PTHS-D, respectively.
abstract.6: All animals survived to T = 24 h except one in each of the PTHS-60 and PTHS-60+ST+FF groups and seven in the PTHS-D group.
abstract.7: Physiologic, coagulation, and inflammatory parameters demonstrated increasing derangements with increasing model severity.
abstract.8: Conclusion: NHPs exhibit a high degree of resilience to hemorrhagic shock and polytrauma as evidenced by moderate perturbations in metabolic, coagulation, and immunologic outcomes with up to 60 min of profound hypotension regardless of injury pattern.
abstract.9: Extending the duration of PTHS to the point of decompensation in combination with polytraumatic injury, evoked derangements consistent with those observed in severely injured trauma patients which would require ICU care.
abstract.10: Thus, we have successfully established a clinically translatable NHP trauma model for use in testing therapeutic interventions to trauma.

adaptation1.1: This study aimed to develop nonhuman primate (monkey) (NHP) models of severe polytraumatic (many-injury) hemorrhagic (excessive bleeding) shock that are applicable to human health settings.
adaptation1.2: NHPs were placed into five pressure-targeted hemorrhagic shock (PTHS) scenarios. The scenarios were as follows: 30-min PTHS (PTHS-30), 60-min PTHS (PTHS-60), PTHS-60 + soft tissue injury (PTHS-60+ST), PTHS-60+ ST + femur (leg) fracture (PTHS-60+ST+FF), and decompensated PTHS+ST+FF (PTHS-D).
adaptation1.3: Physiologic parameters were recorded. Blood samples were collected at five time points with animal observation through 24 hours.
adaptation1.5: Blood loss percentages were  40%, 59%, 52%, 49%, and 54% for PTHS-30, PTHS-60, PTHS-60+ST, PTHS-60+ST+FF, and PTHS-D, respectively.
adaptation1.6: All animals survived till the end of the study except one in the PTHS-60 and PTHS-60+ST+FF groups. Seven did not survive till the end of the study in the PTHS-D group.
adaptation1.7: Physiologic (overall health), coagulation (blood clotting), and inflammatory (infection-fighting) parameters showed increased disturbance with increasing model severity.
adaptation1.8: NHPs show a high degree of resilience to hemorrhagic shock and polytrauma (more than one injury). This was shown by moderate disturbances in metabolic, coagulation, and immunologic outcomes with low blood pressure in all injury groups.
adaptation1.9: Increasing PTHS duration to the point of organ failure with polytraumatic injury, evoked (led to) disturbances consistent with those observed in severely injured trauma patients requiring ICU care.
adaptation1.10: This study has successfully established a clinically translatable NHP trauma model for use in testing therapeutic interventions to trauma.

abstract.1: The term "shock" refers to a life-threatening circulatory failure caused by an imbalance between the supply and demand of cellular oxygen.
abstract.2: Hypovolemic shock is characterized by a reduction of intravascular volume and a subsequent reduction in preload.
abstract.3: The body compensates the loss of volume by increasing the stroke volume, heart frequency, oxygen extraction rate, and later by an increased concentration of 2,3-diphosphoglycerate with a rightward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve.
abstract.4: Hypovolemic hemorrhagic shock impairs the macrocirculation and microcirculation and therefore affects many organ systems (e.g. kidneys, endocrine system and endothelium).
abstract.5: For further identification of a state of shock caused by bleeding, vital functions, coagulation tests and hematopoietic procedures are implemented.
abstract.6: Every hospital should be in possession of a specific protocol for massive transfusions.
abstract.7: The differentiated systemic treatment of bleeding consists of maintenance of an adequate homeostasis and the administration of blood products and coagulation factors.

adaptation1.1: "Shock" refers to a life-threatening circulatory failure. Shock is caused by an imbalance between the supply and demand of oxygen within cells.
adaptation1.2: Hypovolemic shock is characterized by a decreased volume in blood vessels and a subsequent reduction in preload (volume of blood within the heart when its relaxed).
adaptation1.3: The body compensates the volume loss by increasing stroke volume, heart frequency, and oxygen extraction rate. Following these steps, the body will then increase 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (a chemical that controls oxygen movement) to increase available oxygen.
adaptation1.4: Hypovolemic shock is due to volume loss with blood vessels or blood vascular system. Hypovolemic hemorrhagic shock impairs blood circulation. Because of this, this type of shock affects many organ systems.
adaptation1.5: Vital functions, coagulation (blood) tests, and hematopoietic (blood cell creation) procedures are used to identify a state of shock caused by bleeding.
adaptation1.6: Every hospital should have a specific protocol for massive transfusions (transfers).
adaptation1.7: Treatment of bleeding within the body consists of homeostasis (bodily equilibrium) maintenance and administration (use) of blood products and blood clothing (scabbing) medications.

adaptation2.1: The term "shock" refers to a life-threatening blood-flow-related failure caused by an imbalance between supply and demand of oxygen for cells.
adaptation2.2: Hypovolemic shock is due to a reduced amount of blood in vessels and subsequently reduced amount of blood and oxygen to pump.
adaptation2.3: The body compensates for the loss of volume by increasing blood volume per pump, heart rate, oxygen extraction rate, and increasing the amount of a specific molecule that increases oxygen release.
adaptation2.4: Hypovolemic shock from blood loss impairs blood circulation and affects many organs (e.g., kidneys, hormonal system, and blood vessel tubing).
adaptation2.5: For futher identification of shock due to bleeding, vital functions, blood clotting or thickening tests and procedures assessing blood cell development are used.
adaptation2.6: Every hospital should have a specific guideline for massive transfusions or transfers.
adaptation2.7: The personalized full-body treatment of bleeding includes maintaing a proper balance in the body and administering blood substances and factors for blood clotting.

30068251.Title: Unmasking the Hypovolemic Shock Continuum: The Compensatory Reserve

abstract.1: Hypovolemic shock exists as a spectrum, with its early stages characterized by subtle pathophysiologic tissue insults and its late stages defined by multi-system organ dysfunction.
abstract.2: The importance of timely detection of shock is well known, as early interventions improve mortality, while delays render these same interventions ineffective.
abstract.3: However, detection is limited by the monitors, parameters, and vital signs that are traditionally used in the intensive care unit (ICU).
abstract.4: Many parameters change minimally during the early stages, and when they finally become abnormal, hypovolemic shock has already occurred.
abstract.5: The compensatory reserve (CR) is a parameter that represents a new paradigm for assessing physiologic status, as it comprises the sum total of compensatory mechanisms that maintain adequate perfusion to vital organs during hypovolemia.
abstract.6: When these mechanisms are overwhelmed, hemodynamic instability and circulatory collapse will follow.
abstract.7: Previous studies involving CR measurements demonstrated their utility in detecting central blood volume loss before hemodynamic parameters and vital signs changed.
abstract.8: Measurements of the CR have also been used in clinical studies involving patients with traumatic injuries or bleeding, and the results from these studies have been promising.
abstract.9: Moreover, these measurements can be made at the bedside, and they provide a real-time assessment of hemodynamic stability.
abstract.10: Given the need for rapid diagnostics when treating critically ill patients, CR measurements would complement parameters that are currently being used.
abstract.11: Consequently, the purpose of this article is to introduce a conceptual framework where the CR represents a new approach to monitoring critically ill patients.
abstract.12: Within this framework, we present evidence to support the notion that the use of the CR could potentially improve the outcomes of ICU patients by alerting intensivists to impending hypovolemic shock before its onset.

adaptation1.1: Hypovolemic shock is a spectrum of reactions. In the early stages of hypovolemic shock, there is subtle pathophysiologic tissue insults. In the late stages of hypovolemic shock, there is multi-system organ dysfunction. Hypovolemic shock is due to volume loss with blood vessels or blood vascular system.
adaptation1.2: Timely detection of shock is important. Early interventions (treatments) decrease the chance of death. Intervention delays can make the same interventions ineffective.
adaptation1.3: Detection can be limited by monitoring, parameters, and vital signs that are used in the intensive care unit (ICU).
adaptation1.4: Most parameters barely change during the early stages. When the signs finally become abnormal, hypovolemic shock has already occurred.
adaptation1.5: The compensatory reserve (CR) is a parameter. It is a new model for assessing body function. CR represents all of the mechanisms or ways the body compensates for internal conditions that dysregulate blood flow to vital organs during hypovolemia.
adaptation1.6: When these mechanisms are overwhelmed, unstable blood pressure, and circulatory failure will follow.
adaptation1.7: Previous studies involving CR measurements have shown its use in detecting central blood volume loss before blood pressure parameters and vital signs changed.
adaptation1.8: CR measurements have also been used in clinical studies involving patients with traumatic injuries or bleeding. The results from these clinical studies have been promising.
adaptation1.9: CR measurements can be made at the bedside. They also provide a real-time assessment of blood flow.
adaptation1.10: There is a need for rapid diagnostics when treating critically ill patients. CR measurements would complement parameters that are currently being used.
adaptation1.11: The aim of this article is to introduce a conceptual framework where the CR represents a new approach to monitoring critically ill patients.
adaptation1.12: Within this framework, the authors present evidence to support the how the use of the CR could potentially improve the outcomes of ICU patients. CR could improve alerting doctors to impending hypovolemic shock before its onset.

30573009.Title: The Nomenclature, Definition and Distinction of Types of Shock

abstract.1: Background: A severe mismatch between the supply and demand of oxygen is the common feature of all types of shock.
abstract.2: We present a newly developed, clinically oriented classification of the various types of shock and their therapeutic implications.
abstract.3: Results: There are only four major categories of shock, each of which is mainly related to one of four organ systems.
abstract.4: Hypovolemic shock relates to the blood and fluids compartment while distributive shock relates to the vascular system; cardiogenic shock arises from primary cardiac dysfunction; and obstructive shock arises from a blockage of the circulation.
abstract.5: Hypovolemic shock is due to intravascular volume loss and is treated by fluid replacement with balanced crystalloids.
abstract.6: Distributive shock, on the other hand, is a state of relative hypovolemia resulting from pathological redistribution of the absolute intravascular volume and is treated with a combination of vasoconstrictors and fluid replacement.
abstract.7: Cardiogenic shock is due to inadequate function of the heart, which shall be treated, depending on the situation, with drugs, surgery, or other interventional procedures.
abstract.8: In obstructive shock, hypoperfusion due to elevated resistance shall be treated with an immediate life-saving intervention.
abstract.9: Pathogenesis and pathophysiology: The characteristic feature of both, hemorrhagic and traumatic hemorrhagic shock is bleeding.
abstract.10: However, differences exist between the two subcategories in terms of the extent of soft tissue damage.
abstract.11: Clinically the most significant cause of hemorrhagic shock is acute bleeding from an isolated injury to a large blood vessel, gastrointestinal bleeding, nontraumatic vascular rupture (e.g., aortic aneurysm), obstetric hemorrhage (e.g., uterine atony), and hemorrhage in the region of the ear, nose, and throat (vascular erosion).
abstract.12: The shock is triggered by the critical drop in circulating blood volume; massive loss of red blood cells intensifies the tissue hypoxia.

adaptation1.1: Inequality between the supply and demand of oxygen is the common feature of shock.
adaptation1.2: This study presents a newly developed, patient-treatment oriented classification of the various types of shock and their therapeutic (helpful) implications.
adaptation1.3: There are four major categories of shock. Each category is mainly related to one of four organ systems.
adaptation1.4: One category, known as hypovolemic shock, relates to the blood and fluids compartment. Distributive shock relates to the vascular system or blood vessels. Cardiogenic shock arises from primary cardiac or heart dysfunction. Obstructive shock arises from a blockage of circulation.
adaptation1.5: Hypovolemic shock is due to volume loss with blood vessels or blood vascular system. This type of shock is treated by replacement with balanced fluids.
adaptation1.6: Distributive shock is a state of low blood plasma. This type of shock comes from volume displacement in blood vessels. It is treated with a combination of vasoconstrictors, drugs that constrict blood vessels to increase blood pressure, and fluid replacement.
adaptation1.7: Cardiogenic shock is caused by inadequate function of the heart, which shall be treated, depending on the situation, with drugs, surgery, or other treatment methods.
adaptation1.8: In obstructive shock, circulatory failure due to increased resistance will be treated with an immediate life-saving intervention.
adaptation1.9: Both hemorrhagic (excessive bleeding from a ruptured blood vessel) and traumatic hemorrhagic (internal bleeding from an injury) shock feature bleeding.
adaptation1.10: However, differences exist between the two subcategories in terms of how much soft tissue damage they create.
adaptation1.11: The most significant cause of hemorrhagic shock is bleeding from an isolated injury to a critical portion of the body. Some of examples of this include injuries to blood vessels or blood within the intestines.
adaptation1.12: The shock is caused by a critical drop in circulating blood volume. Massive loss of red blood cells increases tissue hypoxia (below normal level of oxygen).

31030706.Title: Use of Shock Index to Identify Mild Hemorrhage: An Observational Study in Military Blood Donors

abstract.1: Introduction: Hemorrhage is the leading cause of preventable death in combat, although early recognition of hemorrhage is still challenging on the battlefield.
abstract.2: Hypothesis/Problem: The objective of this study was to describe the shock index (SI) in a healthy military population, and to measure its variation during a controlled blood loss, simulated by blood donation.
abstract.3: Methods: A prospective observational study that enrolled military subjects, volunteers for blood donation, was conducted.
abstract.4: Demographic and clinical information, concerning both the patient and the blood collection, were recorded.
abstract.5: Baseline vital signs were measured, before and after donation, in a 45° supine position.
abstract.6: Statistical analysis was performed after calculation of SI.
abstract.7: Results: A total of 483 participants were included in the study.
abstract.8: The mean blood donation volume was 473mL (SD = 44mL).
abstract.9: The median pre- and post-blood donation SI were significantly different: 0.54 (IQR = 0.48-0.63) and 0.57 (IQR = 0.49-0.66), respectively (P = .002).
abstract.10: Changes in pre-/post-donation blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) also reached statistical difference but represented a clinically poor relevance.
abstract.11: The multivariate analysis showed no significant associations between SI variations and age, sex, body mass index (BMI), sport activities, blood donation volume, and enteral volume replacement (EVR).
abstract.12: Conclusion: In this model of mild hemorrhage, SI exhibited significant variations but failed to reach clinical relevance.
abstract.13: Further studies are needed to prove the benefit of SI calculation as a possible parameter for early recognition of hemorrhage in combat casualties at the point of injury.

adaptation1.1: Hemorrhage (excessive bleeding) is the leading cause of preventable death in combat. However, early recognition of hemorrhage is still challenging on the battlefield.
adaptation1.2: The aim of this study was to describe the shock index (SI) in a healthy military population. Additionally, the paper aimed to measure SI variation during a controlled blood loss, simulated by blood donation.
adaptation1.3: A study that enrolled military subjects, volunteers for blood donation, was conducted.
adaptation1.4: Demographic (e.g. age, race) and clinical information, concerning both the patient and the blood collection, were recorded.
adaptation1.5: Vital signs were measured before and after donation.
adaptation1.6: Statistical analysis was performed after calculation of SI.
adaptation1.7: A total of 483 participants were included in the study.
adaptation1.8: The average blood donation volume was 473 mL.
adaptation1.9: The median (average) pre- and post-blood donation SI were significantly different.
adaptation1.10: Changes in pre-/post-donation blood pressure and heart rate were also different. However, the difference was of clinically poor relevance.
adaptation1.11: A statistical analysis showed no significant associations between SI variations and age, sex, body mass index (BMI), sport activities, blood donation volume, and enteral (intestinal) volume replacement (EVR).
adaptation1.12: The study concluding that SI exhibited significant variations (differences) but failed to reach clinical relevance.
adaptation1.13: Further studies are needed to prove the benefit of SI calculation as a possible method of early recognition of hemorrhage in combat casualties.

44.question: What percent of blood loss shows the sign symptom of hypovolemic shocks begin?

28639707.Title: Dressings and topical agents for treating pressure ulcers

abstract.1: Background: Pressure ulcers, also known as bedsores, decubitus ulcers and pressure injuries, are localised areas of injury to the skin or the underlying tissue, or both.
abstract.2: Dressings are widely used to treat pressure ulcers and promote healing, and there are many options to choose from including alginate, hydrocolloid and protease-modulating dressings.
abstract.3: Topical agents have also been used as alternatives to dressings in order to promote healing.
abstract.4: A clear and current overview of all the evidence is required to facilitate decision-making regarding the use of dressings or topical agents for the treatment of pressure ulcers.
abstract.5: Such a review would ideally help people with pressure ulcers and health professionals assess the best treatment options.
abstract.6: This review is a network meta-analysis (NMA) which assesses the probability of complete ulcer healing associated with alternative dressings and topical agents.
abstract.7: Main results: We included 51 studies (2947 participants) in this review and carried out NMA in a network of linked interventions for the sole outcome of probability of complete healing.
abstract.8: The network included 21 different interventions (13 dressings, 6 topical agents and 2 supplementary linking interventions) and was informed by 39 studies in 2127 participants, of whom 783 had completely healed wounds.
abstract.9: We judged the network to be sparse: overall, there were relatively few participants, with few events, both for the number of interventions and the number of mixed treatment contrasts; most studies were small or very small.
abstract.10: The consequence of this sparseness is high imprecision in the evidence, and this, coupled with the (mainly) high risk of bias in the studies informing the network, means that we judged the vast majority of the evidence to be of low or very low certainty.
abstract.11: We have no confidence in the findings regarding the rank order of interventions in this review (very low-certainty evidence), but we report here a summary of results for some comparisons of interventions compared with saline gauze.
abstract.12: We present here only the findings from evidence which we did not consider to be very low certainty, but these reported results should still be interpreted in the context of the very low certainty of the network as a whole.
abstract.13: It is not clear whether regimens involving protease-modulating dressings increase the probability of pressure ulcer healing compared with saline gauze (risk ratio (RR) 1.65, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.92 to 2.94) (moderate-certainty evidence: low risk of bias, downgraded for imprecision).
abstract.14: This risk ratio of 1.65 corresponds to an absolute difference of 102 more people healed with protease modulating dressings per 1000 people treated than with saline gauze alone (95% CI 13 fewer to 302 more).
abstract.15: It is unclear whether the following interventions increase the probability of healing compared with saline gauze (low-certainty evidence): collagenase ointment (RR 2.12, 95% CI 1.06 to 4.22); foam dressings (RR 1.52, 95% CI 1.03 to 2.26); basic wound contact dressings (RR 1.30, 95% CI 0.65 to 2.58) and polyvinylpyrrolidone plus zinc oxide (RR 1.31, 95% CI 0.37 to 4.62); the latter two interventions both had confidence intervals consistent with both a clinically important benefit and a clinically important harm, and the former two interventions each had high risk of bias as well as imprecision.
abstract.16: Authors' conclusions: A network meta-analysis (NMA) of data from 39 studies (evaluating 21 dressings and topical agents for pressure ulcers) is sparse and the evidence is of low or very low certainty (due mainly to risk of bias and imprecision).
abstract.17: Consequently we are unable to determine which dressings or topical agents are the most likely to heal pressure ulcers, and it is generally unclear whether the treatments examined are more effective than saline gauze.
abstract.18: More research is needed to determine whether particular dressings or topical agents improve the probability of healing of pressure ulcers.
abstract.19: The NMA is uninformative regarding which interventions might best be included in a large trial, and it may be that research is directed towards prevention, leaving clinicians to decide which treatment to use on the basis of wound symptoms, clinical experience, patient preference and cost.

adaptation1.1: Bedsores are areas of injury to the skin or underlying tissue, or both, found in a certain part of the body.
adaptation1.2: Doctors often use dressings to treat bedsores and promote healing, and there are many options to choose from.
adaptation1.3: Doctors have also used medications applied to the skin instead of dressings to promote healing.
adaptation1.4: A clear and current summary of the scientific data is needed to help make decisions about the use of dressings or medicines applied to the skin to treat bedsores.
adaptation1.5: This review would ideally help people with bedsores and doctors decide the best treatment options.
adaptation1.6: This review compares multiple studies to measure the likelihood of complete ulcer (bedsore) healing based on different dressings and medicines applied to the skin.
adaptation1.7: We included 51 studies (2947 people) in this review and compared treatments based on the likelihood of complete healing.
adaptation1.8: We compared 21 different treatments (13 dressings, 6 medicines applied to the skin and 2 mixed treatments) and looked at 39 studies in 2127 people, 783 of whom had completely healed wounds.
adaptation1.9: We thought the data were limited, with relatively few participants, with few wounds, both for the number of treatments and the number of mixed treatments, and mostly small or very small studies.
adaptation1.10: We thought that most of the data were low or very low quality due to unclear data combined with high likelihood of misleading results.
adaptation1.11: We are not sure our ranking of interventions (treatments) is correct, but we summarize our results to compare treatments to saline gauze often used to as a wound dressing.
adaptation1.12: We report only results from data we did not think was low quality, but these reported results should be considered keeping in mind the overall low certainty of data used.
adaptation1.13: We are not sure whether protease-modulating (protein-altering) dressings increased the likelihood of bedsore healing compared to saline gauze.
adaptation1.14: For every 1000 people, 102 more people healed with protease modulating dressings than people treated with only saline gauze.
adaptation1.15: We are not sure collagenase (enzyme) ointment, foam dressings, basic wound contact dressings, and polyvinylpyrrolidone (water-soluble biological molecule) plus zinc oxide increased the likelihood of bedsore healing compared to saline gauze.
adaptation1.16: We conclude that comparing data from 39 studies (rating 21 dressings and medicines applied to the skin for bedsores) is limited and the data are not reliable (due to unclear data and high likelihood of misleading results).
adaptation1.17: Therefore, we cannot tell which dressings or medicines applied to the skin are the most likely to heal bedsores nor whether the treatments we looked at work better than saline gauze.
adaptation1.18: More research is needed to find out whether certain dressings or medicines applied to the skin improve the likelihood of bedsore healing.
adaptation1.19: Our study does not help decide which treatments might best be part of a large trial, and studies may need to focus on prevention, leaving doctors to decide which treatment to use based on wound symptoms, professional experience, what the patients want and cost.

adaptation2.1: Pressure ulcers, or bedsores, decubitus ulcers and pressure injuries are restricted areas of injury to the skin or underlying body tissue, or both.
adaptation2.2: Dressings (ointment or gauze to cover wounds) are widely used to treat pressure ulcers and promote healing. THere are many varied dressings to choose from.
adaptation2.3: Skin-level agents also have been used as alternatives to dressings for healing.
adaptation2.4: A clear and current overview of all the evidence is required to help make decisions regarding using dressings or skin-level agents to treat pressure ulcers.
adaptation2.5: This review would ideally help those with pressure ulcers and health professionals choose treatments.
adaptation2.6: This review is a study which assesses the probability of complete ulcer healing associated with alternative dressings and skin-level treatments.
adaptation2.7: We included 51 studies (2947 participants) in this review and analyzed the treatments solely to measure the probability of complete healing.
adaptation2.8: The study included 21 different treatments (13 dressings, 6 skin-level treatments, and 2 additional linking treatments). It included data from 39 studies in 2127 participants, of whom 783 had completely healed wounds.
adaptation2.9: We judged the study network to be scattered. Overall, there were few participants, with few events, both for number of treatments and mixed treatment analysis. Most studies were small or very small.
adaptation2.10: The effect of this sparseness is low reliability in the evidence. This, along with the (mainly) high risk of bias (or prejudice) in the studies, means we judged the majority of evidence to be low or very low quality.
adaptation2.11: We have no confidence in the results regarding the rank order of treatments in this review (very low-quality evidence), but we report a summary of results for some comparisons of treatments compared with standard gauze.
adaptation2.12: We present here only results from evidence we did not consdier to be very low quality, but the reported results should be interpreted while knowing of the very low quality regarding the whole study network.
adaptation2.13: It is not clear if treatments with special protein-breakdown dressings increase the probability of pressure ulcer healing compared with standard gauze.
adaptation2.14: 102 more people were healed with special protein-breakdown dressings per 1000 people than those with standard gauze alone.
adaptation2.15: It is unclear if any of the other treatments examined increase the probability of healing compared with standard gauze (low-quality evidence). Some showed metrics consistent with a clinically important benefit and harm. Others had a high risk of bias and unreliability.
adaptation2.16: A large analysis of data from 39 studies (examining 21 dressings and skin-level agents for pressure ulcers) is scattered. The evidence is also of low or very low quality (due to risk of bias and unreliability).
adaptation2.17: Therefore, we are unable to determine which dressings or skin-level agents are best to heal pressure ulcers. It is unclear whether the treatments are more effective than standard gauze.
adaptation2.18: More research is needed to tell if certain dressings or skin-level agents improve the chance of healing for pressure ulcers.
adaptation2.19: This analysis is uninformative regarding which treatments may best be included in a large trial. It may that research is focused on prevention, leaving clinicians to decide which treatment to use based on wound symptoms, clinical experience, patient preference and cost.

28723796.Title: Moist exposed burn ointment for treating pressure ulcers: A multicenter randomized controlled trial

abstract.1: Background: Pressure ulcers often seriously affect the quality of life of patients.
abstract.2: Moist Exposed Burn Ointment (MEBO) has been developed to treat patients with pressure ulcers.
abstract.3: The present study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MEBO in the treatment of pressure ulcers in Chinese patients.
abstract.4: Methods: Seventy-two patients with pressure ulcers were randomly assigned to 2 groups who received a placebo or MEBO for 2 months.
abstract.5: The primary outcomes included the wound surface area (WSA) and pressure ulcer scale for healing (PUSH) tool.
abstract.6: The secondary outcomes included a visual analog scale (VAS), questionnaire of ulcer status, and adverse effects.
abstract.7: Results: Sixty-seven patients completed the study.
abstract.8: After 2 months of treatment, the difference of mean change from the baseline was greater for MEBO (vs placebo) for WSA mean (SD) -6.0 (-8.8, -3.3), PUSH Tool -2.6 (-4.7, -1.5), and VAS score -2.9 (-4.4, -1.7).
abstract.9: On the basis of the questionnaire, the pressure ulcers were "completely healed" (50.0% vs 16.7%) (P < .05) in patients after 2 months of treatment with MEBO versus placebo.
abstract.10: No major adverse effects were found in the 2 groups.
abstract.11: Conclusion: We showed that MEBO is effective and well tolerated for improving wound healing in Chinese patients with pressure ulcers.

adaptation1.1: Bedsores often seriously affect the quality of life of patients.
adaptation1.2: Bedsores can be treated with Moist Exposed Burn Ointment (MEBO).
adaptation1.3: Our study aimed to rate how well MEBO works and how safe MEBO is in the treatment of bedsores in Chinese patients.
adaptation1.4: We randomly put 72 bedsore patients in two groups and gave them MEBO or ointment with no medicine for 2 months.
adaptation1.5: The most important outcomes were wound surface area and a common bedsore scoring tool.
adaptation1.6: We also looked at a common scoring tool for pain, questionnaire of ulcer (sore) status, and side effects.
adaptation1.7: Sixty-seven patients did the study.
adaptation1.8: After 2 months of treatment, MEBO resulted in a greater average change from the beginning of the study compared to ointment with no medicine for wound surface area and both scoring tools.
adaptation1.9: The questionnaire indicated MEBO "completely healed" bedsores in patients after 2 months of treatment versus ointment with no medicine.
adaptation1.10: We found no major side effects in the 2 groups.
adaptation1.11: We showed that MEBO works with no major side effects for improving would healing in Chinese patients with bedsores.

29295637.Title: Clostridial collagenase ointment and medicinal honey utilization for pressure ulcers in US hospitals

abstract.1: Aims: To describe the utilization of clostridial collagenase ointment (CCO) and medicinal honey debridement methods in real-world inpatient and outpatient hospital settings among pressure ulcer (PU) patients and compare the frequency of healthcare re-encounters between CCO- and medicinal honey-treated patients.
abstract.2: Materials and methods: De-identified hospital discharge records for patients receiving CCO or medicinal honey methods of debridement and having an ICD-9 code for PU were extracted from the US Premier Healthcare Database.
abstract.3: Multivariable analysis was used to compare the frequency of inpatient and outpatient revisits up to 6 months after an index encounter for CCO- vs medicinal honey-treated PUs.
abstract.4: Results: The study identified 48,267 inpatients and 2,599 outpatients with PUs treated with CCO or medicinal honeys.
abstract.5: Among study inpatients, n = 44,725 (93%) were treated with CCO, and n = 3,542 (7%) with medicinal honeys.
abstract.6: CCO and medicinal honeys accounted for 1,826 (70%) and 773 (30%), respectively, of study outpatients.
abstract.7: In adjusted models, those treated with CCO had lower odds for inpatient readmissions (OR = 0.86, 95% CI = 0.80-0.94) after inpatient index visits, and outpatient re-encounters both after inpatient (OR = 0.73, 95% CI = 0.67-0.79) and outpatient (OR = 0.78, 95% CI = 0.64-0.95) index visits in 6 months of follow-up.
abstract.8: Limitations: The study was observational in nature, and did not adjust for reasons why patients were hospitalized initially, or why they returned to the facility.
abstract.9: Although the study adjusted for differences in a variety of demographic, clinical, and hospital characteristics between the treatments, we are not able to rule out selection bias.
abstract.10: Conclusion: Patients with CCO-treated PUs returned to inpatient and outpatient hospital settings less often compared with medicinal honey-treated PUs.
abstract.11: These results from real-world administrative data help to gain a better understanding of the clinical characteristics of patients with PUs treated with these two debridement methods and the economic implications of debridement choice in the acute care setting.

adaptation1.1: We aim to describe the use of clostridial collagenase ointment (CCO - a medication with special proteins) and medical honey to remove damaged tissue in hospitals among bedsore patients and compare how often CCO- and medical honey-treated patients return to the hospital.
adaptation1.2: We obtained hospital discharge records from a national database for patients getting CCO or medical honey methods of removing damaged tissues with an official diagnosis of bedsores.
adaptation1.3: We used statistical models to compare how often patients who did and did not stay at least one night in the hospital returned to the hospital up to 6 months after bedsore treatment with either CCO or medical honey.
adaptation1.4: We looked at 48,267 and 2,599 patients with bedsores treated with CCO or medicine honeys who did and did not stay at least one night at the hospital, respectively.
adaptation1.5: CCO and medical honeys made up 44,725 (93%) and 3,542 (7%), respectively, of people who stayed at least one night in the hospital.
adaptation1.6: CCO and medical honeys made up 1,826 (70%) and 773 (30%), respectively, of people who did not stay a night in the hospital.
adaptation1.7: Based on models, patients treated with CCO were less likely to be readmitted to the hospital after being admitted, and to return to the hospital but not stay a night after either going to the hospital and staying or not staying at least one night over the following 6 months.
adaptation1.8: Study limitations included not considering why patients were hospitalized or why they returned to the hospital.
adaptation1.9: Even though we took into account differences in many population, clinical, and hospital characteristics between the treatments, the study population may have not been completely random.
adaptation1.10: We conclude that bedsore patients treated with CCO returned to the hospital less often than those treated with medical honey.
adaptation1.11: These results based on real-world data help us better understand treatment characteristics of bedsore patients related with these two days to remove damaged tissue and connect to method costs related to short-term care.

30086256.Title: Topical pentoxifylline for pressure ulcer treatment: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial

abstract.1: Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of topical pentoxifylline (PTX) on pressure ulcer (PU) healing in critically ill patients.
abstract.2: Method: In this randomised, double blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial, patients with category I or II PUs were randomly assigned to receive either topical PTX 5% or a placebo twice daily for 14 days.
abstract.3: Changes in PU characteristics (category and size) were assessed.
abstract.4: The category of the PU was determined by the Stirling Pressure Ulcer Severity Scale (two-digit) at baseline (day zero), day seven and day 14 of treatment.
abstract.5: PU length and width was measured with a disposable ruler and expressed as cm2.
abstract.6: Results: A total of 112 adult patients were enrolled in the study.
abstract.7: Median PU size and score at day zero were 32 (10.00-69.33)cm2 and 1(1.00-2.00) respectively.
abstract.8: In the PTX group, the mean differences (95% confidence interval, CI) of all PU scores and sizes decreased significantly across the intervals (day seven versus day zero, day 14 versus day zero, and day 14 versus day seven), compared with the placebo group
abstract.9: Conclusion: The severity and size of PUs improved significantly in patients who received topical PTX 5% ointment twice a day for 14 days compared with those in the placebo group.
abstract.10: Topical PTX may be considered as a potential option in the treatment of categories I and II PUs in critically ill patients.

adaptation1.1: We aimed to rate how well pentoxifylline (PTX) applied to the skin worked to heal bedsores in critically ill patients.
adaptation1.2: This was a medical study involving human participants in which neither side knew who was getting what treatment, and either PTX 5% or ointment with no medicine was applied to the skin twice a day for 14 days.
adaptation1.3: We measured changes in bedsore category and size.
adaptation1.4: We used a common scoring system to measure the severity of bedsores and bedsore stage at the beginning of the study and on study days 7 and 14.
adaptation1.5: We measured bedsore length and width with a disposable ruler.
adaptation1.6: We studied a total of 112 adult patients.
adaptation1.7: Median (average) bedsore size and score at the beginning of the study were 32cm2 and 1, respectively.
adaptation1.8: The average differences of bedsore scores and sizes decreased significantly between measurement days (day seven versus day zero, day 14 versus day zero, and day 14 versus day seven) compared to the ointment with no medicine.
adaptation1.9: We conclude that the seriousness and size of bedsores improved significantly in patients who received PTX 5% ointment applied to the skin twice a day for 14 days compared to those who received ointment with no medicine.
adaptation1.10: PTX applied to the skin may be a potential treatment option for stage I or II bedsores in critically ill patients.

adaptation2.1: The study's objective is to evaulate the success of topical pentoxifylline (PTX) (a blood flow medication) on pressure ulcer (PU), or bedsore, healing in very ill patients.
adaptation2.2: In this study, patients with mild or moderate PUs were randomly assigned to receive either skin-level PTX 5% or a sham treatment twice daily for 14 days.
adaptation2.3: Changes in PU (severity and size) were measured.
adaptation2.4: The severity of PU was determined with a special scale at starting (day zero), day seven, and day 14 of the treatment.
adaptation2.5: PU length and width was measured with a ruler in cm2.
adaptation2.6: 112 adult patients enrolled in the study.
adaptation2.7: Average PU size and score at day 0 were 32 cm2 and 1 respectively.
adaptation2.8: In the PTX group, the average differences of all PU scores and sizes decreased greatly across the intervals (day seven vs day zero, day 14 vs day zero, and day 14 vs day seven), compared with the sham treatment group.
adaptation2.9: The severity and size of PUs improved greatly in patients who received skin-level PTX 5% ointment twice a day for 14 days compared to those in the dummy treatment group.
adaptation2.10: Skin-level PTX may be a possible option to treat mild and moderate PUs in very ill patients.

30767645.Title: Technological features of advanced skin protectants and an examination of the evidence base

abstract.1: Products that provide a protective skin barrier play a vital role in defending the skin against the corrosive effect of bodily fluids, including wound exudate, urine, liquid faeces, stoma output and sweat.
abstract.2: There are many products to choose from, which can be broadly categorised by ingredients.
abstract.3: This article describes the differences in mechanisms of action between barrier products comprising petrolatum and/or zinc oxide, silicone film-forming polymers and cyanoacrylates, and compares the evidence on them.
abstract.4: The literature indicates that all types of barrier product are clinically effective, with little comparative evidence indicating that any one ingredient is more efficacious than another, although film-forming polymers and cyanoacrylates have been found to be easier to apply and more cost-effective.
abstract.5: However, laboratory evidence, albeit limited, indicates that a concentrated cyanoacrylate produced a more substantial and adherent layer on a porcine explant when compared with a diluted cyanoacrylate and was more effective at protecting skin from abrasion and repeated exposure to moisture than a film-forming polymer.
abstract.6: Finally, a silicone-based cream containing micronutrients was found to significantly reduce the incidence of pressure ulceration when used as part of a comprehensive prevention strategy.

adaptation1.1: Products that serve as a barrier to protect the skin are important in defending the skin against chemically damaging effects of bodily fluids, including fluid produced from the healing process, urine, liquid faeces, output from an opening in the body and sweat.
adaptation1.2: Many treatments exist, which can be grouped based on ingredients.
adaptation1.3: This study describes the differences in how barrier products work, including petroleum jelly (Vaseline) and/or zinc oxide, polymers (substances made of very large molecules) that form silicone (type of polymer) film, and cyanoacrylates (group of strong fast-acting adhesives).
adaptation1.4: Studies suggest all barrier products work, with few studies that compare ingredients to show one works better than another. Film-forming polymers and cyanoacrylates are easier to apply and cost less.
adaptation1.5: Limited lab data suggest that a concentrated cyanoacrylate made a more notable layer that stuck more to pig tissue than a less-concentrated cyanoacrylate and protected the skin from rubbing and moisture better than a film-forming polymer.
adaptation1.6: Finally, a silicon-based cream with vitamins and minerals needed by the body in very small amounts significantly reduced bedsore occurrence when used with other approaches.

31237193.Title: Efficacy of a Ceratothoa oestroides Olive Oil Extract in Patients With Chronic Ulcers: A Pilot Study

abstract.1: Chronic wounds unresponsive to existing treatments constitute a serious disease burden.
abstract.2: Factors that contribute to the pathogenesis of chronic ulcers include oxidative stress, comorbid microbial infections, and the type of immune system response.
abstract.3: Preclinically, and in a case study, a formulation containing a Ceratothoa oestroides olive oil extract promoted wound healing.
abstract.4: Patients with chronic venous and pressure ulcers, clinically assessed as being unresponsive to healing agents, were treated for 3 months with an ointment containing the C oestroides extract combined with antibiotic and/or antiseptic agents chosen according to the type of bacterial infection.
abstract.5: Treatment evaluation was performed using the Bates-Jensen criteria with +WoundDesk and MOWA cell phone applications.
abstract.6: After 3 months of treatment, C oestroides resulted in an average decrease of 36% in the Bates-Jensen score of ulcers (P < .000), with the decrease being significant from the first month (P < .007).
abstract.7: The combined use of topically applied antibiotics and antiseptics efficiently controlled microbial ulcer infection and facilitated wound healing.
abstract.8: In relation to other factors such as initial wound size, chronicity appeared to be an important prognostic factor regarding the extent of wound healing.
abstract.9: Future clinical investigations assessing the wound healing efficacy of the C oestroides olive oil extract are warranted.

adaptation1.1: Long-lasting wounds that do not respond to available treatments have serious impacts.
adaptation1.2: Things that determine how bedsores progress include low antioxidant levels, other infections caused by microbes (microorganisms), and the type of immune system response.
adaptation1.3: Before symptoms, and in a detailed study, a mixture containing a Ceratothoa oestroides (fish parasite) olive oil extract increased wound healing.
adaptation1.4: Patients with long-lasting leg ulcers (sores) due to blood flow problems and bedsores, determined by doctors as not responding to healing treatments, were treated for 3 months with an ointment with C oestroides extract combined with antibiotics (kill bacteria) and/or antiseptics (slow bacteria growth) based on type of bacterial infection.
adaptation1.5: We evaluated treatment using a common tool used to track wound healing with two cell phone apps.
adaptation1.6: After 3 months of treatment, C oestroides caused an average score decrease of 36% on a common tool used to track wound healing.
adaptation1.7: Applying both antibiotics and antiseptics controlled ulcer infection by microorganisms and helped wound healing.
adaptation1.8: Compared to things like initial wound size, how long lasting the wound was seemed to be an important factor in predicting how much the wound healed.
adaptation1.9: Future studies looking at how well C oestroides olive oil extract works to heal wounds are needed.

31241491.Title: Topical Nifedipine for the Treatment of Pressure Ulcer: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Clinical Trial

abstract.1: Background: Effect of nifedipine on pressure ulcer (PU) healing has not been evaluated in the human subjects yet.
abstract.2: Study question: In this study, the effect of topical application of nifedipine 3% ointment on PU healing in critically ill patients was investigated.
abstract.3: Study design: This was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical.
abstract.4: Measures and outcomes: In this study, 200 patients with stage I or II PU according to 2-digit Stirling Pressure Ulcer Severity Scale were randomized to receive topical nifedipine 3% ointment or placebo twice daily for 14 days.
abstract.5: Changes in the size and stage of the ulcers were considered as primary outcome of the study.
abstract.6: The stage of the ulcers at baseline and on day 7 and day 14 of study was determined by using 2-digit stirling scale.
abstract.7: In addition, the surface area of the wounds was estimated by multiplying width by length.
abstract.8: Results: In total, 83 patients in each group completed the study.
abstract.9: The groups were matched for the baseline stage and size of PUs.
abstract.10: Mean decrease in the stage of PU in the nifedipine group was significantly higher than the placebo group on day 7 (-1.71 vs. -0.16, respectively, P < 0.001) and day 14 (-0.78 vs. -0.09, respectively, P < 0.001).
abstract.11: Furthermore, the mean decrease in the surface area of PU was significantly higher in the nifedipine group compared with the placebo group on day 7 (-1.44 vs. -0.32, respectively, P < 0.001) and day 14 (-2.51 vs. -0.24, respectively, P < 0.001) of study.
abstract.12: Conclusions: Topical application of nifedipine 3% ointment for 14 days significantly improved the healing process of stage I or II PUs in critically ill patients.

adaptation1.1: Scientists have not yet measured the effect of nifedipine, a drug to treat high blood pressure and chest pain, on bedsores in humans.
adaptation1.2: In this study, we looked at the effect of applying nifedipine 3% ointment to the skin on bedsore healing in critically ill patients.
adaptation1.3: This was a medical study involving human participants in which neither side knew who was getting what treatment and ointment with no medicine was given to a control group.
adaptation1.4: In this study, we randomly gave 200 patients with stage I or II, according to a common scoring system to measure the severity of bedsores, nifedipine ointment applied to the skin or ointment with no medicine two times a day for 14 days.
adaptation1.5: The most important outcome was changes in the size and stage of bedsores.
adaptation1.6: We used the bedsore scoring scale to measure bedsore stage at the beginning of the study and on study days 7 and 14.
adaptation1.7: We estimated the surface area of the bedsores by multiplying width by length.
adaptation1.8: In total, 83 patients in each group completed the study.
adaptation1.9: We compared patients with similar bedsore stage and size at the beginning of the study.
adaptation1.10: The group given nifedipine had significantly higher average decrease in bedsore stage than the group not given nifedipine on days 7 and 14.
adaptation1.11: The group given nifedipine had significantly higher average decrease in bedsore surface area than the group not given nifedipine on days 7 and 14.
adaptation1.12: We conclude that nifedipine 3% ointment applied to the skin for 14 days significantly improved the healing process of stage I or II bedsores in critically ill patients.

adaptation2.1: The effect of nifedipine (a common vasodilator medication that widens blood vessels) on pressure ulcers (PU), or bedsores, has not been measured in humans.
adaptation2.2: In this study, the effect of skin-level application of nifedipine 3% ointment on PU healing in very ill patients was investigated.
adaptation2.3: This was a randomized study with a sham treatment group.
adaptation2.4: In this study, 200 patients with mild and moderate PU were randomzed to receive topical nifedipine 3% ointment or dummy treatment twice daily for 14 days.
adaptation2.5: Changes in the size and severity of ulcers were the main measures of the study.
adaptation2.6: The severity of ulcers at baseline, on day 7, and on day 14 of the study was measured.
adaptation2.7: Also, the area of the wounds was estimated by multiplying width by length.
adaptation2.8: In total, 83 patients in each group completed the study.
adaptation2.9: The groups were matched for starting severity and size of PUs.
adaptation2.10: Average decrease in the severity of PU in the nifedipine group was higher than the dummy treatment group on day 7 and day 14.
adaptation2.11: Also, the average decrease in the area of PU was higher in the nifedipine group compared with the sham treatment group on day 7 and 14 of the study.
adaptation2.12: Skin-level application of nifedipine 3% ointment for 14 days improved the healing process of mild or moderate PUs in very ill patients.

34408570.Title: Evaluation of the therapeutic efficacy of active specialistic medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus

abstract.1: Introduction: Treatment of decubitus ulcers is a grave medical problem.
abstract.2: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer, especially when it is deep and extensive, and prognosis is usually unfavourable.
abstract.3: Treatment of decubitus ulcers requires new specialist dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
abstract.4: Aim: To evaluate therapeutic efficacy of active specialist medical dressings in the treatment of decubitus.
abstract.5: Material and methods: Research involved 40 patients - 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, suffering from decubitus ulcers of different size and depth, localized in the sacral region, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
abstract.6: Patients were randomly assigned to two research groups (20 people each), were treated for 4 weeks with 2 different specialist dressings.
abstract.7: ATRAUMAN Ag, which contains silver ions, was used in the first group, while paraffin gauze of BACTIGRAS type was used in the second group.
abstract.8: An assessment of pressure ulcers' healing progress was done with a planimetric method, which evaluates the wound surface area.
abstract.9: Results: The analysis results showed a significant statistical decrease in an average decubitus ulcer surface area in both research groups: in the first group by 60.2% (p = 0.001), and in the second group by 32.95% (p < 0.001), which speaks in favour of dressings with silver ions as having better therapeutic effectiveness.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Using specialist dressings results in a significant decrease in the decubitus ulcer surface area, depending on the type of dressing and active substances contained within, while silver ions support curative effectiveness of the dressing used.

adaptation1.1: Treatment of bedsores is a serious medical problem.
adaptation1.2: Often, a bedsore is hard to cure, especially when it is deep and covers a large area, and usually has a poor prognosis (plan for recovery).
adaptation1.3: Treating bedsores requires specialized dressings, which play an important role in the healing process.
adaptation1.4: We aim to rate how well active specialized dressings, which promote healing by keeping the wound moist, work to treat bedsores.
adaptation1.5: We looked at 40 patients, 18 (45%) women and 22 (55%) men, with bedsores differing in size and depth, located near the bottom of the spine, lasting from 1.5 to 3.0 months.
adaptation1.6: We randomly assigned patients to two groups of 20 people each and treated them with two different specialist dressings for 4 weeks.
adaptation1.7: We used ATRAUMAN ag, which contains silver ions, in the first group and paraffin (waxy) gauze of BACTIGRAS type in the second group.
adaptation1.8: We measured the progress of bedsore healing by measuring the wound's boundaries, which calculates the surface area.
adaptation1.9: Results showed average bedsore surface area significantly decreased in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, suggesting dressings with silver ions worked better.
adaptation1.10: We conclude that specialist dressings significantly decrease bedsore surface area, and dressings with silver ions work better than those without.

adaptation2.1: Treating decubitus ulcers (bedsores) is a serious medical problem.
adaptation2.2: In many cases, it is difficult to cure a pressure ulcer or bedsore, especially when it is deep and extensive. Recovery is usually poor.
adaptation2.3: Treating bedsores requires new specialized dressings (e.g., ointments, gauze), which are important for healing.
adaptation2.4: We aim to evaluate the success of active specialized medical dressings for treating bedsores.
adaptation2.5: Research included 40 patients - 18 (45% women) and 22 (55%) men, suffering from bedsores of various size and depth, in the lower back, lasting from 1.5 to 30 months.
adaptation2.6: Patients were randomly split to two groups (20 people each) and treated for 4 weeks with either ATRAUMAN Ag, a dressing with silver, or gauze with paraffin (a waxy substance commonly used for coating and sealing candles and rubbers) from BACTIGRAS.
adaptation2.7: Measuring pressure ulcer healing was done by measuring the wound surface area.
adaptation2.8: The results showed a decrease in average bedsore area in both treatment groups: in the first group by 60.2% and in the second group by 32.95%, which speaks in favour of dressings with silver as better treatments.
adaptation2.9: Using specialized dressings leads to a decrease in bedsore area, depending on the dressing type and substances contained within it. Silver supports the healing properties of the dressing used.

34414933.Title: Effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang hemorrhoids cream combined with pearl powder on the pain and complications of severe pressure ulcer patients

abstract.1: Objective: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoids Cream combined with pearl powder on pain and complications in patients with severe pressure ulcers.
abstract.2: Methods: One hundred seventeen patients with severe pressure ulcers hospitalized and treated in our hospital (January 2019--December 2019) were divided into Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream Group (MY Group), Pearl Powder Group (PP Group), and combination with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder Group (MP group), 39 patients in each group.
abstract.3: There was no significant difference in the general data of patients in MY group, PP group, and MP group.
abstract.4: By analyzing the differences in clinical efficacy, secondary effects, scar incidence, pain, and clinical indicators of patients in the MY group, PP group, and MP group, the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and complications in patients with severe pressure ulcers were explored.
abstract.5: Results: After treatment, compared with the MY group and the PP group, the MP group had a higher clinical efficacy than the MY group and the PP group.
abstract.6: Compared with MY group and PP group, the healing time, dressing change times, and dressing change time of MP group were better than MY group (P < .05).
abstract.7: After treatment, the VAS score and incidence of secondary effects of the MP group was significantly lower than that of the MY group and PP group (P < .05).
abstract.8: The incidence and area of scar formation in the MP group were lower than those in the MY group and the PP group (P < .05).
abstract.9: Conclusion: Compared with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream or Pearl Powder, combination of Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder are more effective in treating severe pressure ulcer patients, and can significantly reduce the pain in the affected area and reduce the occurrence of complications.

adaptation1.1: We aimed to study the effect of Ma Yinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoids Cream combined with pearl powder on pain and side effects in patients with serious bedsores.
adaptation1.2: We divided 117 patients hospitalized with serious bedsores in our hospital (January 2019-December 2019) into the Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream Group (MY Group), Pearl Powder Group (PP Group), and combination with Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder Group (MP group), 39 patients in each group.
adaptation1.3: Patients in the three groups generally were similar.
adaptation1.4: We looked at the effects of Mayinglong Shexiang Hemorrhoid Cream combined with pearl powder in the treatment of pain and side effects in patients with serious bedsores based on differences in how well a treatment works, side effects, scar occurrence, pain, and quality of care of patients in the MY, PP, and MP groups.
adaptation1.5: The MP group treatment worked better than the MY and PP groups.
adaptation1.6: The MP group had better healing time and dressing change times than the MY group.
adaptation1.7: The MP group had a better score on a common scoring tool for pain and fewer side effects than the MY and PP groups.
adaptation1.8: The MP group had less occurrence of scars and smaller scar area than the MY and PP groups.
adaptation1.9: A combination of Ma Yinglong Musk Hemorrhoid Cream and Pearl Powder worked better than either treatment by itself in treating severe bedsore patients, and can significantly reduce pain in the affected area and side effects.

34692658.Title: Zwitterionic Hydrogel Activates Autophagy to Promote Extracellular Matrix Remodeling for Improved Pressure Ulcer Healing

abstract.1: Pressure ulcer (PU) is a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because of its prolonged inflammatory response and impaired ECM deposition caused by local hypoxia and repeated ischemia/reperfusion.
abstract.2: Our previous study discovered that the non-fouling zwitterionic sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve PU healing with rapid ECM rebuilding.
abstract.3: However, the mechanism of the SBMA hydrogel in promoting ECM rebuilding is unclear.
abstract.4: Therefore, in this work, the impact of the SBMA hydrogel on ECM reconstruction is comprehensively studied, and the underlying mechanism is intensively investigated in a rat PU model.
abstract.5: The in vivo data demonstrate that compared to the PEG hydrogel, the SBMA hydrogel enhances the ECM remolding by the upregulation of fibronectin and laminin expression as well as the inhibition of MMP-2.
abstract.6: Further investigation reveals that the decreased MMP-2 expression of zwitterionic SBMA hydrogel treatment is due to the activation of autophagy through the inhibited PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway and reduced inflammation.
abstract.7: The association of autophagy with ECM remodeling may provide a way in guiding the design of biomaterial-based wound dressing for chronic wound repair.

adaptation1.1: Bedsores are a worldwide problem that is hard to heal because it causes long-lasting inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) and harms the extracellular matrix (ECM; secreted by cells and surrounds cells in tissues) from not enough oxygen and blood flow.
adaptation1.2: The study we did before found that non-fouling zwitterionic (inner salts to which proteins and bacteria cannot stick) sulfated poly (sulfobetaine methacrylate) (SBMA) hydrogel can improve bedsore healing and quickly rebuild ECM.
adaptation1.3: However, scientists are unsure how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM.
adaptation1.4: In this study, we look at how SBMA hydrogel rebuilds ECM using a rat bedsore model.
adaptation1.5: SMBA hydrogel helps remodel ECM better than PEG hydrogel, another bedsore treatment.
adaptation1.7: The relationship between autophagy (cleaning out of damaged cells) with ECM remodeling may influence the design of wound dressings with substances that interact with biological systems for long-term wound repair.

29402832.Title: The CFTR-Associated Ligand Arrests the Trafficking of the Mutant ΔF508 CFTR Channel in the ER Contributing to Cystic Fibrosis

abstract.1: Background/aims: The CFTR-Associated Ligand (CAL), a PDZ domain containing protein with two coiled-coil domains, reduces cell surface WT CFTR through degradation in the lysosome by a well-characterized mechanism.
abstract.2: However, CAL's regulatory effect on ΔF508 CFTR has remained almost entirely uninvestigated.
abstract.3: Methods: In this study, we describe a previously unknown pathway for CAL by which it regulates the membrane expression of ΔF508 CFTR through arrest of ΔF508 CFTR trafficking in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) using a combination of cell biology, biochemistry and electrophysiology.
abstract.4: Results: We demonstrate that CAL is an ER localized protein that binds to ΔF508 CFTR and is degraded in the 26S proteasome.
abstract.5: When CAL is inhibited, ΔF508 CFTR retention in the ER decreases and cell surface expression of mature functional ΔF508 CFTR is observed alongside of enhanced expression of plasma membrane scaffolding protein NHERF1.
abstract.6: Chaperone proteins regulate this novel process, and ΔF508 CFTR binding to HSP40, HSP90, HSP70, VCP, and Aha1 changes to improve ΔF508 CFTR cell surface trafficking.
abstract.7: Conclusion: Our results reveal a pathway in which CAL regulates the cell surface availability and intracellular retention of ΔF508 CFTR.

adaptation1.1: The CFTR-Associated Ligand (CAL) reduces the cell surface of normal CFTR through destroying it in a well-understood way. The CFTR protein is a channel involved with movement of ions (charged atoms) and fluids in epithelial cells (cells that cover the outer surface of the internal organs).
adaptation1.2: However, few scientists have studied how CAL controls ΔF508 CFTR, a specific gene sequence change seen in the CFTR gene which slightly alters the CFTR protein.
adaptation1.3: In this study, we describe a previously unknown way CAL controls ΔF508 CFTR through stopping ΔF508 CFTR movement in the cell's transportation system.
adaptation1.4: We show that CAL binds to ΔF508 CFTR in one location of the cell and is destroyed in another location of the cell.
adaptation1.5: When CAL is stopped, the amount of ΔF508 CFTR held within the cell decreases and working ΔF508 CFTR is seen on the cell surface.
adaptation1.6: The binding of ΔF508 CFTR to proteins improves the cell surface movement conducted by ΔF508 CFTR.
adaptation1.7: We conclude that CAL controls the cell surface availability and amount held within the cell of ΔF508 CFTR.

29475947.Title: Functional organization of cytoplasmic portals controlling access to the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) chloride channel pore

abstract.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a Cl- channel that apparently has evolved from an ancestral active transporter.
abstract.2: Key to the CFTR's switch from pump to channel function may have been the appearance of one or more "lateral portals."
abstract.3: Such portals connect the cytoplasm to the transmembrane channel pore, allowing a continuous pathway for the electrodiffusional movement of Cl- ions.
abstract.4: However, these portals remain the least well-characterized part of the Cl- transport pathway; even the number of functional portals is uncertain, and if multiple portals do exist, their relative functional contributions are unknown.
abstract.5: Here, we used patch-clamp recording to identify the contributions of positively charged amino acid side chains located in CFTR's cytoplasmic transmembrane extensions to portal function.
abstract.6: Mutagenesis-mediated neutralization of several charged side chains reduced single-channel Cl- conductance.
abstract.7: However, these same mutations differentially affected channel blockade by cytoplasmic suramin and Pt(NO2)42- anions.
abstract.8: We considered and tested several models by which the contribution of these positively charged side chains to one or more independent or non-independent portals to the pore could affect Cl- conductance and interactions with blockers.
abstract.9: Overall, our results suggest the existence of a single portal that is lined by several positively charged side chains that interact electrostatically with both Cl- and blocking anions.
abstract.10: We further propose that mutations at other sites indirectly alter the function of this single portal.
abstract.11: Comparison of our functional results with recent structural information on CFTR completes our picture of the overall molecular architecture of the Cl- permeation pathway.

adaptation1.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride (Cl-) channel descended from an active transporter (requiring energy for movement).
adaptation1.2: One or more "lateral portals" may have appeared, switching the active pump to a channel.
adaptation1.3: "Lateral portals" allow Cl- ions (charged atoms) to move under the influence of an electric field.
adaptation1.4: These portals are the least understood part of Cl- movement. Scientists do not know the number of working portals, and if more than one, which portal does what.
adaptation1.5: We used a cell test to find out how positively charged side chemical groups in CFTR contribute to how the portal works.
adaptation1.6: Neutralization of many charged side chemical groups caused by gene sequence changes reduced movement of Cl- through a single channel.
adaptation1.7: However, these gene sequence changes affected channel blockade by negatively charged atoms differently.
adaptation1.8: We used many models to look at ways these positively charged chemical groups changed one or more portals and its effect on Cl- movement and interaction with blockers.
adaptation1.9: Our results suggest one portal is lined by many positively charged side chemical groups that interact with both CL- and other blocking negatively charged ions.
adaptation1.10: We further suggest that gene sequence changes at other sides change how well the single portal works.
adaptation1.11: We compared our results with recent information on CFTR structure to understand the pathway of Cl- transport at a molecule level.

adaptation2.1: The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CTFR) is a chloride transporter that apparently has evolved from an ancestral active transporter.
adaptation2.2: Key to the CFTR's switch from pump to channel function may have been the appearance of one or more "lateral portals."
adaptation2.3: Lateral portals connect the cell's inner fluid to the channel on the cell boundary, allowing a continuous pathway for chloride ion movement.
adaptation2.4: However, these portals are the least studied part of the chloride transport pathway. Even the number of active portals in unknown, and if multiple portals do exists, their relative contributions are unknown.
adaptation2.5: Here, we use electrical recordings to identify the contributions of positively charged protein segments located in CFTR's extensions to portal function.
adaptation2.6: Mutation-controlled silencing of several charged protein segments reduced single-channel chloride transport.
adaptation2.7: However, these same mutations uniquely affected channel blocking by specific inner-cell, negatively-charged particles.
adaptation2.8: We considered and tested many models by which the contribution of these positive protein segments to one or more independent or non-independent portals to the channel could affect chloride transport and interactions with blockers.
adaptation2.9: Overall, our results suggest the existence of a single portal lined with several positively-charged protein segments that interact electrically with both chloride and negative-charged, blocking particles.
adaptation2.10: We propose that mutations at other sites indirectly affect the function of this one portal.
adaptation2.11: Comparing our results with recent structural information on CTFR completes our picture of the overall molecular architecture of the chloride transport pathway.

30349480.Title: Emerging microRNA Therapeutic Approaches for Cystic Fibrosis

abstract.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene and remains the most common life-shortening diseases affecting the exocrine organs.
abstract.2: The absence of this channel results in an imbalance of ion concentrations across the cell membrane and results in more abnormal secretion and mucus plugging in the gastrointestinal tract and in the lungs of CF patients.
abstract.3: The direct introduction of fully functional CFTR by gene therapy has long been pursued as a therapeutical option to restore CFTR function independent of the specific CFTR mutation, but the different clinical trials failed to propose persuasive evidence of this strategy.
abstract.4: The last ten years has led to the development of new pharmacotherapies which can activate CFTR function in a mutation-specific manner.
abstract.5: Although approximately 2,000 different disease-associated mutations have been identified, a single codon deletion, F508del, is by far the most common and is present on at least one allele in approximately 70% of the patients in CF populations.
abstract.6: This strategy is limited by chemistry, the knowledge on CFTR and the heterogenicity of the patients.
abstract.7: New research efforts in CF aim to develop other therapeutical approaches to combine different strategies.
abstract.8: Targeting RNA appears as a new and an important opportunity to modulate dysregulated biological processes.
abstract.9: Abnormal miRNA activity has been linked to numerous diseases, and over the last decade, the critical role of miRNA in regulating biological processes has fostered interest in how miRNA binds to and interacts explicitly with the target protein.
abstract.10: Herein, this review describes the different strategies to identify dysregulated miRNA opens up a new concept and new opportunities to correct CFTR deficiency.
abstract.11: This review describes therapeutic applications of antisense techniques currently under investigation in CF.

adaptation1.1: Changes in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene cause cystic fibrosis (CF), one of the most common life-shortening diseases affecting organs that make and release substances into transporting ducts.
adaptation1.2: The absence of this protein from the CFTR gene causes an imbalance of ion (charged atom) concentrations across the cell membrane and causes release and buildup of abnormally high levels of mucus in the digestive tract and lungs of CF patients.
adaptation1.3: Scientists have tried transferring working CFTR into a patient's cells regardless of the specific CFTR gene change, but patient trials were not successful.
adaptation1.4: New drugs that can stimulate CFTR function based on the specific gene change have been made in the last ten years.
adaptation1.5: Of the roughly 2,000 different gene changes linked to CF, the most common change is F508del, a deletion of a sequence of three consecutive gene compounds, and about 70% of people with CF have at least one form of it.
adaptation1.6: Chemistry, CFTR knowledge, and genetic differences of patients limit the ability to stimulate CFTR function based on the specific gene change.
adaptation1.7: New CF research aims to develop other treatments that combine different approaches.
adaptation1.8: Looking at RNA (which changes the genetic information of DNA into proteins) is a new and important chance to fix incorrectly functioning biological processes.
adaptation1.9: Scientists have linked abnormal microRNA (miRNA; short type of non-coding RNA that does not encode a protein) to many diseases, and over the last decade, scientists have developed interest in how miRNA interacts with specific proteins.
adaptation1.10: We describe different ways to find incorrectly functioning miRNA that might help correct lack of CFTR.
adaptation1.11: This review describes RNA treatments currently being studied in CF.

30825185.Title: Small molecule-facilitated anion transporters in cells for a novel therapeutic approach to cystic fibrosis

abstract.1: Background and purpose: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a lethal autosomal recessive genetic disease that originates from the defective function of the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein, a cAMP-dependent anion channel involved in fluid transport across epithelium.
abstract.2: Because small synthetic transmembrane anion transporters (anionophores) can replace the biological anion transport mechanisms, independent of genetic mutations in the CFTR, such anionophores are candidates as new potential treatments for CF.
abstract.3: Experimental approach: In order to assess their effects on cell physiology, we have analysed the transport properties of five anionophore compounds, three prodigiosines and two tambjamines.
abstract.4: Chloride efflux was measured in large uni-lamellar vesicles and in HEK293 cells with chloride-sensitive electrodes.
abstract.5: Iodide influx was evaluated in FRT cells transfected with iodide-sensitive YFP.
abstract.6: Transport of bicarbonate was assessed by changes of pH after a NH4 + pre-pulse using the BCECF fluorescent probe.
abstract.7: Assays were also carried out in FRT cells permanently transfected with wild type and mutant human CFTR.
abstract.8: Key results: All studied compounds are capable of transporting halides and bicarbonate across the cell membrane, with a higher transport capacity at acidic pH.
abstract.9: Interestingly, the presence of these anionophores did not interfere with the activation of CFTR and did not modify the action of lumacaftor (a CFTR corrector) or ivacaftor (a CFTR potentiator).
abstract.10: Conclusion and implications: These anionophores, at low concentrations, transported chloride and bicarbonate across cell membranes, without affecting CFTR function.
abstract.11: They therefore provide promising starting points for the development of novel treatments for CF.

adaptation1.1: Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a deadly disease inherited from both parents that is caused when the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein does not work correctly, a channel involved with movement of ions (charged atoms) and fluids in epithelial cells (cells that cover the outer surface of the internal organs).
adaptation1.2: Anionophores, which are small human-made substances that move negative ions (anions) across membranes, can replace biological anion movement regardless of gene changes in the CFTR and are possible treatments for CF.
adaptation1.3: We looked at the movement properties of five anionophore substances.
adaptation1.4: We measured the flow of chloride out of the cell.
adaptation1.5: We measured the flow of iodide into the cell.
adaptation1.6: We measured the movement of bicarbonate (compound).
adaptation1.8: We saw that all five compounds are able to move halides and bicarbonate (compounds) across the cell membrane, with more moved in acidic conditions.
adaptation1.9: Anionophores did not change CFTR activation and did not change the effects of a lumacaftor (corrector that helps the changed protein to move to the cell surface) or ivacaftor (potentiator that holds the gate to the channel open so chloride can flow through the cell membrane).
adaptation1.10: We conclude that anionophores, at low concentrations, moved chloride and bicarbonate (compounds) across cell membranes, without changing CFTR function.
adaptation1.11: New CF treatments could be developed starting from anionophores.

31401006.Title: The role of endothelial cells in cystic fibrosis
