abstract.6: Ranking probability based on surface under the cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA) indicated that belimumab 10 mg was most likely the best treatment for SRI4 response (SUCRA = 0.999), followed by anifrolumab 300 mg (SUCRA = 0.500) and placebo (SUCRA = 0.001).
abstract.7: The number of serious adverse events (SAEs) did not differ significantly among the 4 treatment groups.
abstract.8: Conclusion: Based on the SRI4 response rate, belimumab 10 mg had the best response efficacy, followed by anifrolumab 10 mg.
abstract.9: However, there was no difference in the number of SAEs among the treatment options.

adaptation1.1: The objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab, medications that lower the strength of the body's immune system, in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
adaptation1.2: An analysis using data from different clinical studies is performed to understand the effectiveness and safety of belimumab, anifrolumab, and a placebo (sham treatment) in patients with active SLE.
adaptation1.3: Researchers found 6 relevant clinical studies that together have a total of 2,757 patients.
adaptation1.4: Using an assessment tool to measure how disease reacts to medication and other therapy, the response rate at 52 weeks is much higher in the belimumab and anifrolumab groups than that in the placebo group.
adaptation1.5: The response rate for belimumab is much higher than the response for anifrolumab.
adaptation1.6: Using data, a ranking system suggested that belimumab is most likely the best treatment for a response rate, followed by anifrolumab, and placebo.
adaptation1.7: The number of serious negative events are not significantly different among the 4 treatment groups.
adaptation1.8: In conclusion, based on the assessment (measurement) of response rate, belimumab has the best response effectiveness, followed by anifrolumab.
adaptation1.9: However, there is no difference in the number of serious negative events among the treatment options.

adaptation2.1: The study aimed to determine the relative success and safety of belimumab and anifrolumab, common immunosuppressive drugs, for patients with full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more.
adaptation2.2: An analysis was performed on randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on the success and safety of belimumab 10 mg, anifrolumab 300 mg, and a dummy treatment in patients with active SLE.
adaptation2.3: Six studies (2,757 patients) were analyzed.
adaptation2.4: Patient health at 52 weeks was much higher in the belimumab 10-mg and anifrolumab 300-mg groups than the dummy treatment group.
adaptation2.5: Patient health for the belimumab 10 mg group was higher than that for the anifrolumab 300 mg group.
adaptation2.6: Based on the analysis, belimumab 10 mg was most likely the best treatment, followed by anifrolumab 300 mg, and the sham treatment.
adaptation2.7: The number of harmful side effects did not differ among the 4 treatment groups.
adaptation2.8: Based on patient health measures, belimumab 10 mg had the best success, followed by anifrolumab 10 mg.
adaptation2.9: However, there was no difference in the number of harmful side effects among treatment options.

34615636.Title: B-cell depletion with obinutuzumab for the treatment of proliferative lupus nephritis: a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial

abstract.1: Objective: Randomised trials of type I anti-CD20 antibodies rituximab and ocrelizumab failed to show benefit in proliferative lupus nephritis (LN).
abstract.2: We compared obinutuzumab, a humanised type II anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that induces potent B-cell depletion, with placebo for the treatment of LN in combination with standard therapies.
abstract.3: Methods: Patients with LN receiving mycophenolate and corticosteroids were randomised to obinutuzumab 1000 mg or placebo on day 1 and weeks 2, 24 and 26, and followed through week 104.
abstract.4: The primary endpoint was complete renal response (CRR) at week 52.
abstract.5: Exploratory analyses through week 104 were conducted.
abstract.6: The prespecified alpha level was 0.2. Results: A total of 125 patients were randomised and received blinded infusions.
abstract.7: Achievement of CRR was greater with obinutuzumab at week 52 (primary endpoint, 22 (35%) vs 14 (23%) with placebo; percentage difference, 12% (95% CI -3.4% to 28%), p=0.115) and at week 104 (26 (41%) vs 14 (23%); percentage difference, 19% (95% CI 2.7% to 35%), p=0.026).
abstract.8: Improvements in other renal response measures, serologies, estimated glomerular filtration rate and proteinuria were greater with obinutuzumab.
abstract.9: Obinutuzumab was not associated with increases in serious adverse events, serious infections or deaths.
abstract.10: Non-serious infusion-related reactions occurred more frequently with obinutuzumab.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Improved renal responses through week 104 were observed in patients with LN who received obinutuzumab plus standard therapies compared with standard therapies alone.
abstract.12: Obinutuzumab was well tolerated and no new safety signals were identified.

adaptation1.1: Clinical trials studying the infection-fighting antibodies called rituximab and ocrelizumab failed to show benefit in severe cases of lupus nephritis, a kidney disease caused by lupus (when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
adaptation1.2: Obinutuzumab is an antibody that reduces B-cells, a type of protein that produces antibodies but also associated with diseases such as lupus. Researchers compared obinutuzumab with a placebo (inactive substance that looks like a medicine) for the treatment of lupus nephritis in combination with standard therapies.
adaptation1.3: Patients with lupus nephritis receiving standard treatments such as steroids are randomly put in a group to either receive obinutuzumab or a placebo. The drug or placebo are given on day 1 and weeks 2, 24 and 26, and followed through week 104.
adaptation1.4: The  main result is complete kidney response at week 52.
adaptation1.5: Additional analyses through week 104 are also done.
adaptation1.6: A total of 125 patients are randomly placed into either the obinutuzumab or the placebo group and did not know which group they are in.
adaptation1.7: Achievement of complete kidney response is greater with obinutuzumab at week 52  and at week 104.
adaptation1.8: Improvements in other kidney and blood tests are greater with obinutuzumab.
adaptation1.9: Obinutuzumab is not associated with increases in serious negative events, serious infections or deaths.
adaptation1.10: Reactions related to the infusion (injection) occurred more frequently with obinutuzumab but are not serious reactions.
adaptation1.11: In conclusion, improved kidney responses through week 104 are observed in patients with lupus nephritis who received obinutuzumab plus standard treatment compared with standard treatments alone.
adaptation1.12: Patients were able to tolerate side effects of obinutuzumab, and no new safety issues were identified.

34618348.Title: Low-Dose Interleukin-2 as an Alternative Therapy for Refractory Lupus Nephritis

abstract.1: Introduction: Low-dose interleukin-2 (IL-2) selectively restores disturbances of regulatory T cells (Treg) and conventional T cells, resulting in the induction of remission in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus.
abstract.2: However, to date no research has been carried out on the efficacy of low-dose IL-2 in the treatment of refractory lupus nephritis (LN).
abstract.3: The aim of the study reported here was to investigate the renal response to low-dose IL-2 in patients with refractory LN.
abstract.4: Methods: The study population comprised ten patients with refractory LN who failed to achieve complete response or who had relapsed while being treated with at least two conventional immunosuppressive agents.
abstract.5: One treatment cycle consisted of IL-2 at a dose of 1 million IU administered subcutaneously every other day for 2 weeks followed by a 2-week break.
abstract.6: All patients received three cycles of IL-2 and were then followed up for another 12 weeks without any increase in the dose of previous immunosuppressive agents and steroids.
abstract.7: Results: Of the ten patients enrolled in the study, seven (70%) achieved ≥ 50% improvement in proteinuria at 12 weeks after initiating treatment with IL-2.
abstract.8: Median proteinuria was significantly reduced by 50.3% at week 12, from 1.83 (interquartile range [IQR] 1.23-3.21) g/24 h at baseline to 0.91 (IQR 0.52-1.60) g/24 h at 12 weeks (P = 0.005).
abstract.9: This was accompanied by a 71% reduction in urine erythrocytes, from 64/µl (IQR 24-102/µl) at baseline to 18/µl (IQR 2-20/µl) at 12 weeks (P = 0.018).
abstract.10: Anti-ds DNA was decreased from 27.9 (IQR 7.6-40.28) IU/ml at baseline to 14.1 (IQR 7.3-20.12) IU/ml (P = 0.021) at week 12, while complements C3 and C4 were slightly increased (P = 0.445, P = 0.241, respectively).
abstract.11: A significant expansion of Treg cells, from 9.3% at baseline to 16.6% at 12 weeks, was also found (P < 0.05).
abstract.12: No serious adverse events occurred during the treatment period.
abstract.13: Conclusions: Low-dose IL-2 therapy may have a promising role in the treatment of refractory LN as an alternative and safe therapeutic approach.
abstract.14: It may be used as multi-target combination therapy in clinical practice.

adaptation1.1: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is a type of protein that promotes and develops immune cells at the start of an immune response and keeps them alive. A low-dose of interleukin-2 can restore changes of immune cells called T cells and Treg cells, resulting in the start of remission (recovery) in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
adaptation1.2: However, to date, no research has been carried out on the effectiveness of low-dose IL-2 in the treatment of lupus nephritis, a type of kidney disease caused by lupus.
adaptation1.3: The aim of this study is to investigate the kidney response to low-dose IL-2 in patients with lupus nephritis that is not responding to standard treatment.
adaptation1.4: The study includes 10 patients with lupus nephritis who failed to achieve a  complete response to standard treatment or who improved and then worsened while being treated with at least two standard treatments.
adaptation1.5: One treatment cycle consists of IL-2 given by an injection every other day for 2 weeks followed by a 2-week break.
adaptation1.6: All patients receive three cycles of IL-2 and are then followed up for another 12 weeks without any increase in the dose of the previous treatments or steroids.
adaptation1.7: Of the 10 patients enrolled in the study, 7 (70%) achieved 50% or more improvement in proteinuria (elevated levels of protein in the urine) at 12 weeks after starting IL-2 treatment.
adaptation1.8: Average proteinuria is significantly reduced by 50.3% at week 12.
adaptation1.9: There is also a 71% decrease in red blood cells in urine at 12 weeks.
adaptation1.10: An antibody (infection-fighting molecule) associated with lupus called anti-ds DNA decreased from the start of the study to week 12, while protein complements C3 and C4 used to monitor the immune systems are slightly increased.
adaptation1.11: A significant expansion of the immune Treg cells, from 9.3% at the start of the study to 16.6% at 12 weeks, is also found.
adaptation1.12: No serious negative events occurred while patients receive the treatment.
adaptation1.13: In conclusion, low-dose IL-2 therapy may have a promising role in the treatment of refractory lupus nephritis as an alternative and safe treatment approach.
adaptation1.14: Low-dose IL-2 may be used in combination with other medicines in clinical practice.

34619975.Title: Redox homeostasis involvement in the pharmacological effects of metformin in systemic lupus erythematosus

abstract.1: Significance: Metformin has been proposed as a treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
abstract.2: The primary target of metformin, the electron transport chain complex I in the mitochondria, is associated with redox homeostasis in immune cells, which plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of autoimmune diseases.
abstract.3: This review addresses the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether a beneficial effect of metformin in lupus may be due to a restoration of a balanced redox state.
abstract.4: Recent Advances: Clinical trials in SLE patients with mild to moderate disease activity and preclinical studies in mice have provided encouraging results for metformin.
abstract.5: The mechanism by which this therapeutic effect was achieved is largely unknown.
abstract.6: Metformin regulates redox homeostasis in a context-specific manner.
abstract.7: Multiple cell types contribute to SLE, with evidence of increased mitochondrial oxidative stress in T cells and neutrophils.
abstract.8: Critical issues: The major knowledge gaps are whether the efficacy of metformin is linked to a restored redox homeostasis in the immune system, and if it does, in which cell types it occurs?
abstract.9: We also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and whether it corresponds to a specific mechanism?
abstract.10: Finally, the identification of biomarkers to predict treatment outcomes would be of great value.

adaptation1.1: Metformin is a medication that has been proposed as a treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells).
adaptation1.2: Metformin targets certain cells in the immune system that play a critical role in development of autoimmune diseases, which are diseases where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells and tissues.
adaptation1.3: This review addresses the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether a beneficial effect of metformin in lupus may be due to a restoration of redox homeostasis, a balanced level of reactive oxygen molecules that signal to other cells.
adaptation1.4: Clinical trials in lupus patients with mild to moderate disease activity and studies in mice have provided encouraging results for metformin.
adaptation1.5: The mechanism that creates this therapeutic effect is largely unknown.
adaptation1.6: Metformin regulates redox homeostasis in specific situations.
adaptation1.7: Multiple cell types contribute to lupus.
adaptation1.8: The major knowledge gaps are whether the effectiveness of metformin is linked to a restored redox homeostasis in the immune system, and if it is linked, in which type of cells does it occur.
adaptation1.9: Researchers also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and whether it relates to a specific mechanism or process in the body.
adaptation1.10: Finally, the identification of specific biological factors to predict treatment outcomes would be of great value.

adaptation2.1: Metformin, an anti-diabetic medication, may treat full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more.
adaptation2.2: The primary target of metformin, a specific energy-generator in the cell, is linked with electrical balance in immune cells, which influence the creation of diseases in which immune cells mistakely attack healthy cells.
adaptation2.3: This article reviews the evidence and knowledge gaps on whether metformin's beneficial effects in lupus may be due to a restored, balanced electrical state.
adaptation2.4: Clinical trials in SLE patients with mild to moderate disease severity and mice studies show encouraging results for metformin.
adaptation2.5: How this beneficial effect is achieved is largely unknown.
adaptation2.6: Metformin monitors electrical balance depending on the situation.
adaptation2.7: Multiple cell types contribute to SLE, with evidence of increased cellular stress in certain immune cells called T cells and neutrophils.
adaptation2.8: The major knowledge gaps are whether the success of metformin is linked to a restored electrical balance in the immune system. If it does, in which cell types it occurs?
adaptation2.9: We also need to know which patients may have a better response to metformin, and if it corresponds to a specfic biological process?
adaptation2.10: Finally, identifying markers to predict treatment outcomes would be very useful.

34659214.Title: Mesenchymal Stem Cell Therapy: Hope for Patients With Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

abstract.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease.
abstract.2: Although previous studies have demonstrated that SLE is related to the imbalance of cells in the immune system, including B cells, T cells, and dendritic cells, etc., the mechanisms underlying SLE pathogenesis remain unclear.
abstract.3: Therefore, effective and low side-effect therapies for SLE are lacking.
abstract.4: Recently, mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) therapy for autoimmune diseases, particularly SLE, has gained increasing attention.
abstract.5: This therapy can improve the signs and symptoms of refractory SLE by promoting the proliferation of Th2 and Treg cells and inhibiting the activity of Th1, Th17, and B cells, etc.
abstract.6: However, MSC therapy is also reported ineffective in some patients with SLE, which may be related to MSC- or patient-derived factors.
abstract.7: Therefore, the therapeutic effects of MSCs should be further confirmed.
abstract.8: This review summarizes the status of MSC therapy in refractory SLE treatment and potential reasons for the ineffectiveness of MSC therapy from three perspectives.
abstract.9: We propose various MSC modification methods that may be beneficial in enhancing the immunosuppression of MSCs in SLE.
abstract.10: However, their safety and protective effects in patients with SLE still need to be confirmed by further experimental and clinical evidence.

adaptation1.1: Systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus) is a type of chronic autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells and tissues.
adaptation1.2: The mechanisms and processes of how lupus develops remain unclear.
adaptation1.3: Therefore, effective therapies with low side effects for lupus are lacking.
adaptation1.4: Recently, therapy using mesenchymal stem cells (MSC), cells that are present in adult bone marrow and umbilical cords, for diseases including lupus has gained increasing attention.
adaptation1.5: This therapy can improve the signs and symptoms of lupus by promoting the development of Th2 and Treg cells that are involved in activating the immune system and slowing the activity of other cells that are overactive in cases of lupus (Th1, Th17, and B cells, etc.).
adaptation1.6: However, MSC therapy is also reported ineffective in some patients with lupus, which may be related to the stem cells or patient's factors.
adaptation1.7: Therefore, the treatment effects of MSCs should be further confirmed.
adaptation1.8: This review summarizes the status of MSC therapy in lupus treatment and potential reasons for the ineffectiveness of MSC therapy from three perspectives.
adaptation1.9: Researchers suggest various changes in MSC methods that may be beneficial in slowing the immune effect of MSCs in lupus.
adaptation1.10: However, their safety and protective effects in patients with lupus still need to be confirmed by more evidence.

34659263.Title: Clinical Experience of Proteasome Inhibitor Bortezomib Regarding Efficacy and Safety in Severe Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: A Nationwide Study

abstract.1: As treatment options in advanced systematic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are limited, there is an urgent need for new and effective therapeutic alternatives for selected cases with severe disease.
abstract.2: Bortezomib (BTZ) is a specific, reversible, inhibitor of the 20S subunit of the proteasome.
abstract.3: Herein, we report clinical experience regarding efficacy and safety from all patients receiving BTZ as therapy for SLE in Sweden during the years 2014-2020.
abstract.4: 8 females and 4 males were included with a mean disease duration at BTZ initiation of 8.8 years (range 0.7-20 years).
abstract.5: Renal involvement was the main target for BTZ.
abstract.6: Reduction of global disease activity was recorded by decreasing SLEDAI-2K scores over time and remained significantly reduced at the 6-month (p=0.007) and the 12-month (p=0.008) follow-up visits.
abstract.7: From BTZ initiation, complement protein 3 (C3) levels increased significantly after the 2nd treatment cycle (p=0.05), the 6-month (p=0.03) and the 12-month (p=0.04) follow-up visits.
abstract.8: The urine albumin/creatinine ratio declined over time and reached significance at the 6-month (p=0.008) and the 12-month follow-up visits (p=0.004).
abstract.9: Seroconversion of anti-dsDNA (27%), anti-C1q (50%) and anti-Sm (67%) was observed.
abstract.10: 6 of 12 patients experienced at least one side-effect during follow-up, whereof the most common adverse events were infections.
abstract.11: Safety parameters (C-reactive protein, blood cell counts) mainly remained stable over time.
abstract.12: To conclude, we report favorable therapeutic effects of BTZ used in combination with corticosteroids in a majority of patients with severe SLE manifestations irresponsive to conventional immunosuppressive agents.
abstract.13: Reduction of proteinuria was observed over time as well as seroconversion of some autoantibody specificities.
abstract.14: In most patients, tolerance was acceptable but mild adverse events was not uncommon.
abstract.15: Special attention should be paid to infections and hypogammaglobinemia.

adaptation1.1: Because treatment options in advanced systematic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells) are limited, there is an urgent need for new and effective treatment alternatives for selected cases with severe disease.
adaptation1.2: Bortezomib (BTZ) is a specific, reversible drug that stops the function of the protein complex called proteasome that breaks down unneeded or damaged proteins.
adaptation1.3: This study reports the effectiveness and safety of all patients receiving BTZ for lupus in Sweden during 2014-2020.
adaptation1.4: Eight females and 4 males are included with an average disease duration of 8.8 years when BZT is started.
adaptation1.5: Kidney involvement was the main target for BTZ.
adaptation1.6: Reduction of global disease activity is recorded by decreasing scores over time of the Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Disease Activity Index (SLEDAI-2K) that tracks disease activity and remained significantly reduced at the 6-month and the 12-month follow-up visits.
adaptation1.7: From BTZ initiation, levels of a protein that supports the immune system called complement protein 3 (C3) increased significantly after the 2nd treatment cycle, the 6-month, and the 12-month follow-up visits.
adaptation1.8: The urine test showing albumin protein in urine declined over time and reduced significantly at the 6-month and the 12-month follow-up visits.
adaptation1.9: The presence of certain antibodies (infecting-fighting molecules) related to lupus is observed.
adaptation1.10: Six out of 12 patients experienced at least one side-effect during follow-up, the most common adverse events are infections.
adaptation1.11: Tests to measure safety, including blood cell counts, mainly remained stable over time.
adaptation1.12: In conclusion, researchers found beneficial effects of BTZ when used in combination with corticosteroids (an anti-inflammatory drug also known as steroids) in most patients with severe lupus who do not respond to the standard treatments.
adaptation1.13: Reduction of proteinuria (elevated protein in urine) was observed over time as well as changes to specific antibodies.
adaptation1.14: In most patients, the side effects were tolerable but mild adverse events were not uncommon.
adaptation1.15: Special attention should be paid to infections and low levels of antibodies.

34681945.Title: The Pathogenesis, Molecular Mechanisms, and Therapeutic Potential of the Interferon Pathway in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and Other Autoimmune Diseases

abstract.1: Therapeutic success in treating patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is limited by the multivariate disease etiology, multi-organ presentation, systemic involvement, and complex immunopathogenesis.
abstract.2: Agents targeting B-cell differentiation and survival are not efficacious for all patients, indicating a need to target other inflammatory mediators.
abstract.3: One such target is the type I interferon pathway.
abstract.4: Type I interferons upregulate interferon gene signatures and mediate critical antiviral responses.
abstract.5: Dysregulated type I interferon signaling is detectable in many patients with SLE and other autoimmune diseases, and the extent of this dysregulation is associated with disease severity, making type I interferons therapeutically tangible targets.
abstract.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon-blocking antibody, anifrolumab, by the US Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of patients with SLE demonstrates the value of targeting this pathway.
abstract.7: Nevertheless, the interferon pathway has pleiotropic biology, with multiple cellular targets and signaling components that are incompletely understood.
abstract.8: Deconvoluting the complexity of the type I interferon pathway and its intersection with lupus disease pathology will be valuable for further development of targeted SLE therapeutics.
abstract.9: This review summarizes the immune mediators of the interferon pathway, its association with disease pathogenesis, and therapeutic modalities targeting the dysregulated interferon pathway.

adaptation1.1: Successfully treating patients with systematic lupus erythematosus (lupus - when your immune system attacks healthy cells) is limited by the different causes, its presence in multiple organs and systems, and a complex immune response.
adaptation1.2: Treatments that target certain inflammatory (infection-fighting) processes in the body may be needed for some patients.
adaptation1.3: One such target is the type I interferon pathway, a specific immune system pathway.
adaptation1.4: Type I interferons increase the production of interferon genes (genes that allow communication between cells to activate the immune system) and brings about critical immune responses to fight viruses.
adaptation1.5: Problems with the signaling in type I interferons are found in patients with lupus, and the extent of the problem is connected to how serious the disease is, making type I interferons possible targets for treatment.
adaptation1.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon-blocking antibody medicine, anifrolumab, by the US Food and Drug Administration for treating patients with lupus shows the value of targeting this pathway.
adaptation1.7: Nevertheless, the interferon pathway has multiple cells and signaling parts that are not completely understood.
adaptation1.8: Understanding the type I interferon pathway and how it relates to lupus will be valuable for future development of lupus treatments.
adaptation1.9: This review summarizes the immune process of the interferon pathway, its association with disease development, and therapeutic methods that target problems interferon pathway.

adaptation2.1: Treatment success for patients with full-body or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an inflammatory disease in which immune cells mistakely attack joints, skin, brain cells and more, is limited by muti-factor disease causes, multi-organ damage, full-body effect, and complex causes for immune cell dysfunction.
adaptation2.2: Treatment targeting creation and survival of antibody-creating immune cells are not effective for all patients, indicating a need to target other inflammatory groups.
adaptation2.3: One target group is the type I interferon pathway, a cellular signaling pathway that affects the entire immune system.
adaptation2.4: Type I interferons increase the amount of certain signaling proteins and influence important antiviral responses.
adaptation2.5: Impaired type I interferon signaling is detectable in many with SLE and similar diseases. The extent of this impairment is linked with disease severity, making type I interferons a possible treatment target.
adaptation2.6: The recent approval of the type I interferon blocking molcule or antibody, anifrolumab, by a government agency for treating SLE demonstrates the value of targeting this pathway.
adaptation2.7: Still, the interferon pathway affects multiple targets and signaling pathways that are incompletely understood.
adaptation2.8: Understanding the complex type I interferon pathway and its influence on lupus disease will be valuable for further development of targeted SLE treatments.
adaptation2.9: This review summarizes the immune middlemen of the interferon pathway, its link with disease creation, and treatments targeting the pathway when it is impaired.

48.question: I have lupus. What can i do to stop it?

abstract.1: Edema is an accumulation of fluid in the interstitial space that occurs as the capillary filtration exceeds the limits of lymphatic drainage, producing noticeable clinical signs and symptoms.
abstract.2: The rapid development of generalized pitting edema associated with systemic disease requires timely diagnosis and management.
abstract.3: The chronic accumulation of edema in one or both lower extremities often indicates venous insufficiency, especially in the presence of dependent edema and hemosiderin deposition.
abstract.4: Skin care is crucial in preventing skin breakdown and venous ulcers.
abstract.5: Eczematous (stasis) dermatitis can be managed with emollients and topical steroid creams.
abstract.6: Patients who have had deep venous thrombosis should wear compression stockings to prevent postthrombotic syndrome.
abstract.7: If clinical suspicion for deep venous thrombosis remains high after negative results are noted on duplex ultrasonography, further investigation may include magnetic resonance venography to rule out pelvic or thigh proximal venous thrombosis or compression.
abstract.8: Obstructive sleep apnea may cause bilateral leg edema even in the absence of pulmonary hypertension.
abstract.9: Brawny, nonpitting skin with edema characterizes lymphedema, which can present in one or both lower extremities.
abstract.10: Possible secondary causes of lymphedema include tumor, trauma, previous pelvic surgery, inguinal lymphadenectomy, and previous radiation therapy.
abstract.11: Use of pneumatic compression devices or compression stockings may be helpful in these cases.

adaptation1.1: Edema is a build up of fluid in the body's tissues and does not drain properly, producing noticeable clinical signs and symptoms.
adaptation1.2: The rapid development of pitting edema, which is when pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation, associated with diseases that affects other parts of the body requires timely diagnosis and management.
adaptation1.3: The ongoing build up of edema in one or both lower legs often suggests veins in the lower limbs are not allowing enough blood to flow to the heart, especially in the presence of gravity-related swelling and build up of iron deposits under the skin that has a shade of brown pigment.
adaptation1.4: Skin care is crucial in preventing skin breakdown and venous ulcers, open sores on the skin from abnormal vein function.
adaptation1.5: Inflamed skin in the lower legs called eczematous (stasis) dermatitis is a kind of eczema (skin swelling) caused by poor circulation and can be helped with moisturizers and topical steroid creams.
adaptation1.6: Patients who have had a condition where a blood clot forms in the vein called deep venous thrombosis should wear compression stockings.
adaptation1.7: If a doctor believes a diagnosis for deep venous thrombosis is possible even after negative (no detection) results are noted on tests, further investigation may include imaging scans to rule out pelvic or thigh proximal venous thrombosis or compression.
adaptation1.8: Occasional airflow blockage during sleep called obstructive sleep apnea may cause edema in both legs even in the absence of high blood pressure.
adaptation1.9: Discolored, non-pitting (non-indentable) skin with edema is often a sign of lymphedema, fluid build-up in soft tissues when the lymph system is damaged or blocked, which can present in one or both lower limbs.
adaptation1.10: Possible other causes of lymphedema include tumor, trauma, previous pelvic surgery, inguinal lymphadenectomy (lymph node dissection), and previous radiation therapy.
adaptation1.11: Use of compression devices that are inflatable sleeves worn on the legs or compression stockings may be helpful in these cases.

adaptation2.1: Edema is a buildup of fluid in the body that occurs as the filtration rate exceeds the drainage rate, producing noticeable symptoms.
adaptation2.2: The rapid development of swelling linked with full-body disease needs timely identification and treatment.
adaptation2.3: The long-lasting buildup of fluid in one or both legs often indicates blood vessel impairment, especially in the presence of swelling in the limbs and iron buildup.
adaptation2.4: Skin care is needed in preventing skin breakdown and vein-related open sores.
adaptation2.5: Skin inflammation from swelling in the legs can be managed with specific moisturizers and steroid creams.
adaptation2.6: Patients who have had deep venous thrombosis (deep vein blood clotting) should wear compression socks to prevent its symptoms like pain and swelling.
adaptation2.7: If clinicians remain suspicious of deep venous thrombosis even when lab tests do not detect it, further lab tests may be performed to rule out other forms of blood clotting and compression.
adaptation2.8: Obstructuve sleep apnea (disorder in which breathing is consistently interrupted during sleep by a blockage) may cause swelling in both legs even without lung-related high blood pressure.
adaptation2.9: Sturdy skin with swelling characterizes lymphedema (fluid buildup when the body's drainage system is blocked), which can present in one or both legs.
adaptation2.10: Possible secondary causes of lymphedema include tumor, blunt force, previous hip surgery, lymph node (immune system organ) removal, and previous radiation therapy.
adaptation2.11: Use of compression devices to prevent blood clotting or socks may be helpful in these cases.

23979346.Title: Leg edema detected on comprehensive geriatric assessment for elderly outpatients and its associated risk factors

abstract.1: Aim: Leg edema, observed on comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) of 142 elderly outpatients with a variety of chronic diseases, was studied clinically to clarify its incidence and its associated risk factors.
abstract.2: Methods: The severity of pitting edema was assessed at 3 points, namely, the pretibial edge, medial malleolus, and the dorsum of the foot.
abstract.3: On palpation, edema was graded as 0 to 3 for each point on one leg, the sum of which was used as the edema score.
abstract.4: According to the edema score, subjects were divided into 3 groups; the moderate to severe (MS) group, the slight to mild (SM) group, and the group without pitting edema.
abstract.5: The MS group was defined as having an edema score of 4 or more or edema of grade 2 or more, while the SM group was defined as having an edema score of 2 to 3 points without edema of grade 2 or more.
abstract.6: The status of underlying disease, vascular risks, varicose veins, medications, daily activity, nutrition, total protein (TP), albumin, brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), and the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) were compared among the 3 groups.
abstract.7: Results: There were 36 subjects in the MS group and 19 subjects in the SM group.
abstract.8: Diabetes, atrial fibrillation, varicose veins, and polypharmacy were more frequent in the MS group than in the control group.
abstract.9: Sedentary life style, house-bound, and gait trouble were significantly more frequent in the MS and SM groups.
abstract.10: There were no significant differences in the scores of the Mini-Nutritional Assessment Short Form among the groups, although both the body weight and calf circumference in the MS group were significantly greater than those in the group without pitting edema.
abstract.11: Low serum TP, albumin and eGFR were seen in the MS group as well as high BNP levels.
abstract.12: Multiple regression analysis revealed diabetes, varicose veins, sedentarism, and hypoalbuminemia as risk factors associated with leg edema (R(2)=0.365, p<0.0001).
abstract.13: Conclusion: Leg edema was frequent in the elderly outpatients and was associated strongly with diabetes, varicose veins, sedentarism, and hypoalbuminemia.
abstract.14: These findings suggest that advising against a sedentary life style could help the resolution of edema, and also indicates the clinical usefulness of CGA.
abstract.15: Furthermore, leg edema should be seriously considered along with nutritional assessment because edema could influence various anthropometric parameters.

adaptation1.1: In this study, leg edema (fluid swelling) is studied to understand how frequently it occurs and its associated risk factors. Leg edema is observed on a detailed evaluation of older and frail people called the comprehensive geriatric (elderly) assessment of 142 elderly outpatients with a variety of chronic diseases.
adaptation1.2: The severity of pitting edema, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation, is assessed at 3 places: the shins, the bony bump on the inside of the ankle, and the top part of the foot that faces up when standing.
adaptation1.3: When pressing on the swollen area, edema is graded as 0 to 3 for each point on one leg, the sum of which was used as the edema score.
adaptation1.4: According to the edema score, patients are divided into 3 groups; the moderate to severe group, the slight to mild group, and the group without pitting edema.
adaptation1.5: The moderate to severe group is defined as having an edema score of 4 or more or edema of grade 2 or more, while the slight to mild group is defined as having an edema score of 2 to 3 points without edema of grade 2 or more.
adaptation1.6: The following tests and measurements are compared among the 3 groups: the status of underlying disease, risks to developing heart problems, varicose (twisted, enlarged) veins, medications, daily activity, nutrition, tests for proteins in the body, and tests for how well the kidneys are working.
adaptation1.7: There are 36 patients in the moderate to severe group and 19 subjects in the slight to mild group.
adaptation1.8: Diabetes, an irregular heart beat (atrial fibrillation), varicose veins, and being on multiple drugs at one time are more frequent in the moderate to severe group than in the comparison group.
adaptation1.9: Sedentary life style (no or little physical activity), house-bound, and walking trouble are much more frequent in the moderate to severe and slight to mild groups.
adaptation1.10: There are no significant differences in the scores on malnourishment (poor nutrition) among the groups, although both the body weight and calf circumference (size) in the moderate to severe group are much greater than those in the group without pitting edema.
adaptation1.11: Low levels of total protein in the blood, another protein made by liver called albumin, and kidney function tests are seen in the moderate to severe group as well as high levels of a protein made by heart and blood vessels called BNP.
adaptation1.12: Data analysis revealed diabetes, varicose veins, sedentarism (inactivity), and low levels of the protein albumin as risk factors associated with leg edema.
adaptation1.13: In conclusion, leg edema is frequent in the elderly outpatients and is associated strongly with diabetes, varicose veins, sedentarism, and low levels of albumin in the blood.
adaptation1.14: These findings suggest that advising against an inactive life style could help resolve edema, and also indicates the usefulness of comprehensive geriatric assessment to evaluate older populations.
adaptation1.15: Furthermore, leg edema should be seriously considered along with evaluating the diet of patients because edema could influence various physical measurements of the body.

24159719.Title: Systemic disease as cause of leg swelling

abstract.1: Symmetrical leg swelling formed in the course of the years is a common and in most cases benign phenomenon that is mostly encountered in the aged population, especially in women.
abstract.2: Venous insufficiency of the lower limbs is the most common cause of symmetrical leg swelling among those over 50 years of age.
abstract.3: Diseases of the essential organs such as the heart, the liver and the kidneys are excluded during the initial stage.
abstract.4: Pitting edema occurs both in venous insufficiency and in right-sided heart failure.
abstract.5: Basic tests and drug history are usually sufficient to exclude a host of general causes of the edema.

adaptation1.1: Leg swelling in both legs over time is common, and in most cases unharmful, and is mostly found in the older population, especially in women.
adaptation1.2: Veins in the lower limbs that do not allow enough blood to flow to the heart, called venous insufficiency, is the most common cause of swelling in legs among those over the age of 50.
adaptation1.3: Diseases of the important organs such as the heart, the liver and the kidneys are excluded during the first stage.
adaptation1.4: Pitting edema, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation, occurs both in venous insufficiency and in right-sided heart failure.
adaptation1.5: Basic tests and drug history are usually enough to exclude a number of general causes of the edema.

24786784.Title: Synovitis with pitting edema as the presenting manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus

abstract.1: Rheumatologists are increasingly aware of the entity synovitis with pitting edema.
abstract.2: The remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema (RS3PE) syndrome has been reported with an array of conditions that include polymyalgia rheumatica, rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren's syndrome and psoriatic arthropathy.
abstract.3: Synovitis with pitting edema is now being increasingly recognized with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
abstract.4: We report a patient who presented with edema of hands and feet and was diagnosed eventually with definite SLE.
abstract.5: With magnetic resonance imaging, joint effusions and tenosynovitis were confirmed to be associated with the otherwise-unexplained extremity edema.

adaptation1.1: Specialists who treat diseases in the joints, muscles, and bones, called rheumatologists, are increasingly aware of swollen joints (synovitis) with pitting edema, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation.
adaptation1.2: The remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema (RS3PE) syndrome is a rare disease with swollen joints and pitting edema. RS3PE has been reported with a number of conditions that include polymyalgia rheumatica (a disorder that causes muscle pain and stiffness, mainly in the shoulders and hips), rheumatoid arthritis (arthritis whereby immune cells attack healthy cells), an immune system disorder that causes dry eyes and mouth called Sjögren's syndrome, and a type of arthritis linked to psoriasis (a skin disease causing red, itchy scaly patches).
adaptation1.3: Synovitis with pitting edema is now being increasingly seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (lupus), a chronic disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells and tissues.
adaptation1.4: Researchers report a patient who presented with edema (swelling) of hands and feet and was diagnosed eventually with definite lupus.
adaptation1.5: With imaging tools, fluid build up in the joints and inflammation (redness and swelling from fighting an infection) of the top layer of tendons (tenosynovitis) were confirmed to be associated with the otherwise-unexplained edema in the limbs.

26692738.Title: A rare case of bilateral lower extremity edema due to low dose gabapentin therapy in a young male patient

abstract.1: 46 year old male with past medical history of schizoaffective disorder and chronic lower back pain, was admitted for management of worsening depression and anxiety.
abstract.2: He was started on gabapentin, 300mg twice daily for his back pain and anxiety symptoms.
abstract.3: His only other medication was hydrocodone.
abstract.4: Over next few days, he started developing worsening bilateral lower extremity edema.
abstract.5: He did not have any cardiovascular related symptoms.
abstract.6: Physical exam was only significant for 3+ pitting edema with all laboratory values and imaging being unremarkable.
abstract.7: Gabapentin was discontinued and his lower extremity swelling improved over subsequent days.
abstract.8: Incidence of pedal edema with gabapentin use is approximately 7 to 7.5% with all studies being in elderly patients receiving doses above 1200 mg/day.
abstract.9: This case illustrates that lower doses of gabapentin can also cause this adverse effect.
abstract.10: It is important to recognize this adverse effect because gabapentin is used in conditions like diabetic neuropathy, which is associated with multiple co-morbidities that can give rise to bilateral leg swelling.
abstract.11: Presence of gabapentin induced leg swelling can thus confound the clinical picture.

adaptation1.1: A 46 year old male with past medical history of schizoaffective (reality-distorting) disorder, a mental disorder, and chronic lower back pain, is admitted to a medical facility to manage worsening depression and anxiety.
adaptation1.2: He is started on a medicine called gabapentin (nerve pain medication) for his back pain and anxiety symptoms.
adaptation1.3: His only other medication is an opioid pain reliever called hydrocodone.
adaptation1.4: Over the next few days, he starts developing worsening edema, swelling caused by too much fluid trapped in the body's tissues, in both legs.
adaptation1.5: He does not have any cardiovascular (heart) related symptoms.
adaptation1.6: A physical exam found pitting edema, where pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation. All other lab tests and imaging scans did not show anything significant.
adaptation1.7: Gabapentin is stopped and the swelling in his legs improved over the following days.
adaptation1.8: In other studies, the occurrence of swollen feet (pedal edema) while on gabapentin is about 7 to 7.5% in elderly patients receiving doses above 1200 mg/day.
adaptation1.9: This case illustrates that lower doses of gabapentin can also cause this negative effect.
adaptation1.10: It is important to recognize this negative effect because gabapentin is used in conditions like nerve damage common with diabetes (diabetic neuropathy), which is associated with multiple illnesses that can give rise to swelling in both legs.

adaptation2.1: We admitted a 46 year old male to treat his worsening depression and anxiety. He had a prior history of symptoms of schizophrenia and mood disorders and long-lasting lower back pain.
adaptation2.2: He was started on gabapentin (nerve pain medication), 300 mg twice daily for his back pain and anxiety symptoms.
adaptation2.3: His only other medication was hydrocodone, a pain and cough medication.
adaptation2.4: Over the next few days, he developed worsening swelling in both legs.
adaptation2.5: He did not have any heart-related symptoms.
adaptation2.6: Physical exam only noted serious swelling with all lab values and imaging not being serious.
adaptation2.7: Gabapentin use was stopped, and his leg swelling improved over the next few days.
adaptation2.8: Frequency of leg swelling with gabapentin use is around 7 to 7.5% with all studies being in elderly patients receiving doses above 1200 mg/day.
adaptation2.9: This case shows that lower doses of gabapentin can also cause this harmful effect.
adaptation2.10: This serious effect should be noted since gabapentin is used in conditions like diabetic nerve pain, which is linked with other diseases that can give rise to swelling in both legs.
adaptation2.11: Presence of gabapentin-caused leg swelling can thus confuse the diagnosis.

27586538.Title: Leg edema with (S)-amlodipine vs conventional amlodipine given in triple therapy for hypertension: a randomized double blind controlled clinical trial

abstract.1: Background: Leg edema is a common adverse effect of dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB) that may need dose reduction or drug withdrawal, adversely affecting the antihypertensive efficacy.
abstract.2: Leg edema is reported to occur less often with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional racemic amlodipine.
abstract.3: We aimed to find the incidence of leg edema as a primary outcome and antihypertensive efficacy with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional amlodipine.
abstract.4: Methods: This prospective, double-blind, controlled clinical trial randomized 172 hypertensive patients, not controlled on beta-blockers (BB) and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ACEI/ARB), to either conventional amlodipine (5-10 mg; n = 86) or (S)-amlodipine (2.5-5 mg; n = 86), while continuing their previous anti-hypertensive medications.
abstract.5: Sample was sufficient to find a difference in edema between the interventions with 80 % power at 5 % significance level.
abstract.6: Intension to treat analysis (ITT) for safety data and per protocol analysis for efficacy data was performed.
abstract.7: Fischer's exact test was applied to observe difference between responder rates and proportions of subjects having peripheral edema in the two groups.
abstract.8: Pitting edema test scores were compared using Mann-Whitney test.
abstract.9: Results: Altogether 146 patients (amlodipine, n = 76 and (S)-amlodipine, n = 70) completed 120 days treatment.
abstract.10: Demographic variables and treatment adherence were comparable in the two groups.
abstract.11: Incidence of new edema after randomization was 31.40 % in test group and 46.51 % in control group [p = 0.03; absolute risk reduction (ARR) = 15.1 %; Number Needed to Treat (NNT) = 7, ITT analysis].
abstract.12: Pitting edema score and patient rated edema score increased significantly in the control compared to test group (p = 0.038 and 0.036 respectively) after treatment period.
abstract.13: Edema scores increased significantly in the control group from baseline (p < 0.0001).
abstract.14: Responders in blood pressure were 98.57 % in test and 98.68 % in control group.
abstract.15: Most common adverse events (AE) were pitting edema and increased urinary frequency.
abstract.16: Incidence of all AEs other than edema was similar in both groups.
abstract.17: Two serious AEs occurred unrelated to therapy.
abstract.18: Biochemical and ECG parameters in the two groups were comparable.
abstract.19: Conclusions: In hypertensive patients not controlled on prior BB and ACEI/ARB therapy, addition of (S)-amlodipine besylate at half the dose of conventional amlodipine provides better tolerability with reduced incidence of peripheral edema, and equal antihypertensive efficacy compared to amlodipine given at usual doses.

adaptation1.1: Leg edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB), medicines taken to control blood pressure and other conditions. The dose amount of CBB drugs may need to be reduced or stopped, negatively impacting the drugs' use to control blood pressure.
adaptation1.2: Leg edema (fluid swelling) is reported to occur less often with a type of CBB medicine called (S)-amlodipine compared to the regular racemic amlodipine medicine.
adaptation1.3: Researchers aim to find the number of times leg edema appeared and how well blood pressure is lowered with (S)-amlodipine compared to conventional amlodipine.
adaptation1.4: This clinical trial followed 172 patients with high blood pressure, not controlled by using beta-blockers (BB) drugs or angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors/angiotensin receptor blockers (ACEI/ARB) that keep blood vessels open. These patients are randomly placed in groups to receive either standard amlodipine (86 patients) or (S)-amlodipine (86 patients), while continuing their previous anti-hypertensive medications.
adaptation1.5: The number of patients in this study is sufficient to find a difference in edema between the two groups.
adaptation1.6: Data from both treatment groups are analyzed during the study.
adaptation1.7: Data are analyzed to observe the difference between the two groups on how they responded to the treatment and the number of people who develop peripheral edema (swelling in lower legs and hands).
adaptation1.8: Pitting edema, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation, is measured and scored.
adaptation1.9: Altogether 146 patients completed 120 days treatment: 76 patients in the standard amlodipine group and 70 in the (S)-amlodipine group.
adaptation1.10: Characteristics such as age and sex and how well patients took the medicine as directed are compared between the two groups.
adaptation1.11: New edema is 31.40 % in the (S)-amlodipine group and 46.51 % in the standard group.
adaptation1.12: Pitting edema score and patient rated edema score increase significantly in the amlodipine compared to (S)-amlodipine group after the treatment period.
adaptation1.13: Edema scores increase significantly in the amlodipine group from the start of the study.
adaptation1.14: Responders in blood pressure are 98.57 % in (S)-amlodipine and 98.68 % in amlodipine group.
adaptation1.15: Most common side effects are pitting edema and increase in urinary frequency.
adaptation1.16: Number of all side effects other than edema is similar in both groups.
adaptation1.17: Two serious side effects occur that are unrelated to therapy.
adaptation1.18: Results from other blood and heart tests in the two groups are similar.
adaptation1.19: In patients with high blood pressure not controlled on prior BB and ACEI/ARB therapy, adding (S)-amlodipine besylate at half the dose of standard amlodipine provides few side effects. There is also a reduced number of peripheral edema, and equal ability to lower blood pressure compared to amlodipine given at usual doses.

30524565.Title: Impact of low-dose prednisolone on refractory pitting edema manifesting remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema syndrome

abstract.1: We encountered an elderly male patient who after cardiac surgery for mitral stenosis had refractory pitting edema in both legs involving painful leg joints after a 1-month history of waxing and waning arthralgia.
abstract.2: His family doctor had prescribed a combination of diuretics, 40 mg furosemide and 25 mg spironolactone; however, pitting edema in his lower legs persisted.
abstract.3: He was diagnosed with worsening of congestive heart failure because of a previous cardiac surgery and was transferred to our hospital.
abstract.4: On admission, we closely observed the patient's condition and noticed that his body temperature increased to 38.0 °C every evening.
abstract.5: Furthermore, his ankle joints felt feverish and were swollen.
abstract.6: Therefore, we suspected polyarthritis as an etiology, although we initially suspected rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
abstract.7: Antibody testing did not support RA diagnosis; therefore we concluded the association of remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema (RS3PE) syndrome with his condition.
abstract.8: After daily treatment with 15 mg prednisolone, the refractory edema symptom dramatically improved.
abstract.9: The concept of RS3PE syndrome could explain such as an impressive clinical course.
abstract.10: <Learning objective: Physicians encounter patients with pitting edema of unknown etiology in daily clinical practice.
abstract.11: In particular, cardiologists usually tend to prescribe diuretics for patients with pitting edema in their legs.
abstract.12: Cardiologists should consider RS3PE syndrome as a differential diagnosis, for patients with localized pitting edema in their extremities.
abstract.13: This report cautions regarding arbitrarily prescribing diuretics for localized pitting edema.>.

adaptation1.1: Doctors saw an elderly male patient who after heart surgery had pitting edema in both legs, a condition where excess fluid builds up in part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation. The man also had painful leg joints after a 1-month history of periodic changes in joint stiffness.
adaptation1.2: His family doctor had prescribed a combination of diuretics, medicines that help remove salt and water from the body; however, pitting edema in his lower legs continued.
adaptation1.3: He was diagnosed with worsening of congestive heart failure (inefficient heart pumping) because of a previous heart surgery and transferred to the hospital.
adaptation1.4: On admission to the hospital, doctors closely observed the patient's condition and noticed that his body temperature increased to 100.4 F (38.0 C) every evening.
adaptation1.5: Additionally, his ankle joints felt feverish and were swollen.
adaptation1.6: Therefore, doctors suspected arthritis in at least five joints (polyarthritis) as a potential cause, although doctors first thought it was rheumatoid arthritis (RA - a long-lasting arthritis from immune cells attacking healthy cells).
adaptation1.7: Testing did not support a rheumatoid arthritis diagnosis; therefore, doctors concluded the association of remitting seronegative symmetrical synovitis with pitting edema (RS3PE) syndrome with his condition. RS3PE is a rare disease with swollen joints and pitting edema.
adaptation1.8: After daily treatment with a steroid medication called prednisolone, the edema symptom greatly improved.
adaptation1.9: The concept of RS3PE syndrome could explain such as an impressive clinical result.
adaptation1.10: Doctors encounter patients with pitting edema of unknown cause in daily clinical practice.
adaptation1.11: In particular, heart specialists (cardiologists) usually tend to prescribe diuretics for patients with pitting edema in their legs.
adaptation1.12: Cardiologists should consider RS3PE syndrome as a differential (potential) diagnosis, for patients with pitting edema in one location in their limbs.
adaptation1.13: This report cautions prescribing diuretics for localized pitting edema.

32431556.Title: May-Thurner Syndrome: ﻿A Neglected Cause of Unilateral Leg Swelling

abstract.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the left iliac vein by the right iliac artery.
abstract.2: This condition predisposes the patient to deep venous thrombosis (DVT).
abstract.3: We present the case of a 30-year﻿-old female who arrived at the emergency department of our facility with progressive left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk probability for DVT.
abstract.4: Examination revealed left leg swelling with pitting edema extending up to the knee.
abstract.5: Her calf muscle was tender to palpation.
abstract.6: Dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial pulsations were fairly palpable due to the edema; however, the rest of her pulsations were appropriately felt.
abstract.7: Therefore, the provisional diagnosis of possible DVT was made, and further investigations were requested.
abstract.8: We present this case intending to highlight the clinical presentation of May-Thurner syndrome, its diagnosis, and treatment.

adaptation1.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a clinical condition where the left iliac vein located in the abdomen that goes into the left leg is compressed by the right iliac artery which is a vein that goes into the right leg.
adaptation1.2: Having this condition makes it easier for the patient to develop deep venous thrombosis (DVT), a serious condition where a blood clot forms in the vein.
adaptation1.3: Researchers present the case of a 30-year﻿-old female who arrived at the emergency room with gradual left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk for developing DVT.
adaptation1.4: An exam revealed left leg swelling with pitting edema up to the knee, a condition where excess fluid builds up in one part of the body and pressing into the swollen area leaves a pit or indentation.
adaptation1.5: Her calf muscle was tender to light touch.
adaptation1.6: Veins in the foot, in the leg called the anterior tibial, and in the lower leg can be fairly felt due to the edema; however, the rest of her pulses were appropriately felt.
adaptation1.7: Therefore, the early diagnosis of possible DVT was made, and further investigations were requested.
adaptation1.8: Researchers present this case intending to highlight the clinical signs and symptoms of May-Thurner syndrome, its diagnosis, and treatment.

adaptation2.1: May-Thurner syndrome (MTS) is a condition in which the main right leg blood vessel compresses the main left leg blood vessel.
adaptation2.2: MTS puts the patient at risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), or deep blood clotting.
adaptation2.3: We describe a 30-year-old female who arrived at the emergency department with worsening left leg swelling for four weeks, with low-risk chance for DVT.
adaptation2.4: Exams showed left leg swelling with serious swelling up to the knee.
adaptation2.5: Her lower leg calf muscle was tender to touch.
adaptation2.6: Various blood vessel pulsations in the leg were noticeable due to the swelling. However, the rest of her pulsations were examined by touch.
adaptation2.7: Therefore, the identification of possibly DVT was made. Further invesetigations were requested.
adaptation2.8: We present this case to highlight the symptoms of May-Thurner syndrome, its identification, and treatment.

33714971.Title: A Case of Elephantiasis Nostras Verrucosa Secondary to Lymphedema Praecox Complicated by Congestive Cardiac Failure

abstract.1: BACKGROUND In lymphedema, an imbalance in the formation and absorption of lymph causes accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitium of the most gravity-dependent parts of the body.
abstract.2: Diagnosis is usually made based on patient medical history and a physical examination showing a typical appearance of the affected body part.
abstract.3: Differential diagnosis is confirmed by imaging.
abstract.4: CASE REPORT Primary lymphedema is inherited in through an autosomal dominant pattern.
abstract.5: Congestive cardiac failure and non-filarial infections predispose patients to the secondary form of lymphedema, elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV).
abstract.6: We present the case of a 65-year-old man with lymphedema praecox complicated by congestive cardiac failure.
abstract.7: The patient was experiencing worsening left leg swelling and had a prior history of unilateral leg swelling at puberty.
abstract.8: The condition was inherited through an autosomal dominant pattern, as his father, elder brother, and nephew were diagnosed with the same disease.
abstract.9: The left leg showed non-pitting edema with indurated, woody skin and lichenification.
abstract.10: The right leg had mild pitting edema.
abstract.11: There were numerous verrucous folds and cobblestone-like nodules, and plaques and a painless ulcer on the left leg.
abstract.12: Laboratory evaluation demonstrated an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide.
abstract.13: He was treated with compression stockings and inelastic multi-layer bandaging and was administered limb decongestive treatment.
abstract.14: After 1 week of therapy, his swelling had somewhat improved.
abstract.15: CONCLUSIONS Various conditions can cause ENV and it can superimpose on any form of hereditary lymphedema.
abstract.16: The most effective strategy for this condition seems to be a thorough workup of the underlying cause of the ENV and early intervention.

adaptation1.1: In lymphedema, an imbalance of a fluid called lymph causes a build up of protein-rich fluid, usually in the arms and legs.
adaptation1.2: Diagnosis is usually made based on patient medical history and a physical examination of the affected body part.
adaptation1.3: The diagnosis may be confirmed by imaging, such as x-rays or another scan.
adaptation1.4: Primary lymphedema, also called hereditary lymphedema, is inherited (passed down from parent to child) through genes.
adaptation1.5: Congestive heart failure (inefficient heart pumping) and infections from soil particles make it easier for patients to develop the secondary form of lymphedema, elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV). ENV is a rare chronic condition caused by ongoing infections with bacteria and causes a part of the body, usually the lower part of the body, to be extremely enlarged.
adaptation1.6: Researchers describe the case of a 65-year-old man with lymphedema complicated by congestive heart failure.
adaptation1.7: The patient was experiencing worsening left leg swelling and had a prior history of leg swelling at puberty (when a child's body changes to become an adult) due to disease.
adaptation1.8: The condition was inherited, as his father, elder brother, and nephew were diagnosed with the same disease.
adaptation1.9: The left leg showed non-pitting edema (there was no indentation when the area of swelling is pressed) with woody skin due to scaring that was also thick and leathery.
adaptation1.10: The right leg had mild pitting edema.
adaptation1.11: There were numerous folds and cobblestone-like lumps, raised red patches of the skin, and a painless ulcer (sore) on the left leg.
adaptation1.12: Lab tests showed high levels of a hormone made by the heart called B-type natriuretic peptide.
adaptation1.13: He was treated with compression stockings and bandaging and given decongestive treatment in the limb which includes several techniques such as draining fluid.
adaptation1.14: After 1 week of therapy, his swelling had somewhat improved.
adaptation1.15: In conclusion, various conditions can cause elephantiasis nostras verrucosa (ENV), and it can be an additional condition on any form of hereditary lymphedema.
adaptation1.16: The most effective strategy for this condition seems to be a detailed workup of the underlying cause of the ENV and early treatment and management.

33958571.Title: A 41-Year-Old Woman with Excessive Fat of the Lower Body Since Puberty with Progression to Swollen Ankles and Feet Despite Caloric Restriction, Due to Lipedema and Protein-Calorie Malnutrition: A Case of Stage 3 Lipedema

abstract.1: BACKGROUND Lipedema is a common condition that presents as excessive fat deposition in the extremities, initially sparing the trunk, ankles, and feet, and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty or pregnancy.
abstract.2: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema of the ankles and feet.
abstract.3: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty, with progression to swollen ankles and feet despite dietary caloric restriction.
abstract.4: CASE REPORT A 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.
abstract.5: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 165 kg, and underwent a Roux-En-Y gastric bypass.
abstract.6: Over 12 months, she lost 74.8 kg.
abstract.7: Her trunk significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.
abstract.8: Fifteen years later, during recovery from hysterectomy surgery, she became progressively weaker and swollen over her entire body.
abstract.9: Laboratory test results showed hypoalbuminemia (2.0 g/dL), lymphopenia, and hypolipoproteinemia.
abstract.10: She was diagnosed with protein and calorie malnutrition with marked gut edema requiring prolonged parenteral nutrition.
abstract.11: After restoration of normal protein, her health returned and her pitting edema resolved, but her extremities remained enlarged.
abstract.12: She was subsequently diagnosed with lipedema.
abstract.13: CONCLUSIONS This report demonstrates that early and correct diagnosis of lipedema is important, as women who believe the condition is due to obesity may suffer the consequences of calorie or protein-calorie deficiency in an attempt to lose weight.

adaptation1.1: Lipedema is a common condition where there is too much fat in the arms and legs and is found mainly in women, usually occurring after puberty (when a child's body changes to become an adult) or pregnancy.
adaptation1.2: Lipedema can progress to include lipo-lymphedema, which is a build up of fluid in addition to excess fat, in the ankles and feet.
adaptation1.3: This report is of a 41-year old woman with Stage 3 lipedema and lipo-lymphedema with excessive fat of the lower body since puberty. The woman's condition has advanced to swollen ankles and feet despite being on a low calorie diet.
adaptation1.4: The 41-year-old woman noticed increased fat in her legs since age 12.
adaptation1.5: Her weight and leg size increased until age 21, when she reached a maximum weight of 364 pounds (165 kg), and had a procedure called gastric bypass that involves a doctor placing a small pouch in the stomach and food only goes into that pouch.
adaptation1.6: Over 12 months, she lost 165 pounds (74.8 kg).
adaptation1.7: Her trunk (chest, stomach, and back) significantly reduced in weight, but her legs did not.
adaptation1.8: Fifteen years later, during recovery from surgery, she became continuously weaker and swollen over her entire body.
adaptation1.9: Lab test results showed hypoalbuminemia (low levels of the albumin protein in the blood), making it harder to move substances in the body. Tests also show low levels of white blood cells and low levels of fat lipids in the blood.
adaptation1.10: She was not eating enough protein and energy (through calories) to meet nutritional needs with edema (swelling) in the stomach, requiring that more nutrition be given through the vein.
adaptation1.11: After restoring protein to normal levels, her health returned and her pitting edema due to excess fluid resolved, but her arms and legs remained enlarged.
adaptation1.12: She was later diagnosed with lipedema.
adaptation1.13: In conclusion, this report shows that early and correct diagnosis of lipedema is important. Women who believe the condition is due to obesity may suffer from not enough calorie or protein-calories in an attempt to lose weight.

49.question: What causes pitted edema in legs?

abstract.1: Sarcoidosis is characterized by granuloma formation, the macrophage being the most important building block.
abstract.2: The activated macrophage in sarcoidosis produces interleukin-1 (II-1).
abstract.3: It is well known that interleukin-1, among other functions, stimulates the hepatic production of C-reactive protein.
abstract.4: We therefore prospectively measured the serum C-reactive protein in 17 patients with active pulmonary sarcoidosis, 10 patients with other chronic interstitial lung diseases of unknown etiology, 11 patients with active lung tuberculosis, and 10 healthy volunteers.
abstract.5: Serum C-reactive protein was assayed by enzymoimmunodiffusion test.
abstract.6: The serum C-reactive protein was negative in 13 patients suffering from active sarcoidosis and positive in four.
abstract.7: Patients with other interstitial lung diseases had negative results in 7 and positive in 3 cases.
abstract.8: The analyses of C-reactive protein in patients with sputum positive lung tuberculosis were positive in 10 cases.
abstract.9: All the healthy controls had negative C-reactive protein measurements.
abstract.10: The difference between the groups was statistically significant when sarcoidosis and tuberculosis serum C-reactive protein measurements were compared (p less than 0.01), as well as the difference between the group of other interstitial lung diseases and tuberculosis (p less than 0.01).
abstract.11: In this respect, the measurements of serum C-reactive protein are valuable in the differentiation of sarcoidosis and other chronic interstitial lung diseases of unknown etiology from tuberculosis and other diseases which are known to induce an acute phase response.

adaptation1.1: Sarcoidosis is a disease that is characterized by granuloma formation or the tiny growth collections of inflammation (infection-fighting) cells. One of these cell types is the immune cell, macrophage. Macrophages are one of the most important building blocks of this disease.
adaptation1.2: Macrophage in sarcoidosis produces interleukin-1 (II-1), a protein that helps fight infections.
adaptation1.3: Interleukin-1 has many functions, including the stimulation of the hepatic (liver) production of C-reactive protein. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.4: Serum (blood) C-reactive protein was measured in 48 patients. Seventeen of the patients had active sarcoidosis in the lung. Ten patients had other lung diseases of unknown origin. Eleven patients had active lung tuberculosis (a serious lung infection). Ten patients were healthy volunteers.
adaptation1.5: Serum C-reactive protein was measured.
adaptation1.6: The serum C-reactive protein was negative (no detection) in 13 patients suffering from active sarcoidosis and positive in four.
adaptation1.7: Patients with other lung diseases had negative results in 7 cases and positive (was detected) in 3 cases.
adaptation1.8: The analyses of C-reactive protein in patients with lung tuberculosis were positive in 10 cases.
adaptation1.9: All the healthy controls had negative C-reactive protein measurements.
adaptation1.10: The difference between the groups was statistically significant when sarcoidosis and tuberculosis serum C-reactive protein measurements were compared. There was also a significant difference between the group of other lung diseases and tuberculosis.
adaptation1.11: Levels of serum C-reactive protein are valuable in the identification of sarcoidosis and other lung diseases of unknown origin from tuberculosis and other diseases.

adaptation2.1: Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by growths of inflammatory cells in the body.
adaptation2.2: The activated macrophage, a specialized white blood cell defender against invaders, in sarcoidosis produces interleukin-1 (Il-1), a molecule which signals inflammation.
adaptation2.3: Interleukin-1, among other functions, activates the liver production of C-reactive protein, a marker of inflammation.
adaptation2.4: We measured the blood C-reactive protein in 17 patients with active lung-related sarcoidosis, 10 with other long-lasting lung diseases of unknown cause, 11 with active lung tuberculosis (a bacterial lung infection), and 10 healthy volunteers.
adaptation2.5: Blood C-reactive protein was measured with a specific lab test.
adaptation2.6: The blood C-reactive protein was not detected in 13 patients with active sacroidosis and was detected in four.
adaptation2.7: C-reactive protein was not detected in 7 patients with other lung diseases and was detected in 3 cases.
adaptation2.8: The tests of C-reactive protein in patients with lung tuberculosis-related mucus was detected in 10 cases.
adaptation2.9: No C-reactive protein was detected in healthy patients.
adaptation2.10: There was a difference between groups when sarcoidosis and tuberculosis blood C-reactive protein measurements were compared, along with a difference between the group of other lung diseases and tuberculosis.
adaptation2.11: Measuring blood C-reactive protein is valuable to differentiate sacroidosis and other lung-lasting lung diseases of unknown causes from tuberculosis and other diseases known to cause an immediate response.

1917173.Title: The role of medical treatment of distal type aortic dissection

abstract.1: We analyzed the short-term and long-term outcome of 42 patients with distal type aortic dissection.
abstract.2: Twenty-eight patients underwent intensive medical therapy within two weeks after the onset of pain (acute dissection).
abstract.3: The remaining 14 patients had chronic dissection.
abstract.4: The goals of medical treatment were to control blood pressure and to attain a negative C-reactive protein test result.
abstract.5: Hospital survival rate in the patients with acute dissection was 96% (27/28).
abstract.6: In-hospital complications included changes in mental status, renal dysfunction, bradycardia, orthostatic hypotension, and liver dysfunction, all of which were managed medically.
abstract.7: Three of these patients underwent surgical therapy in the chronic phase and were discharged uneventfully.
abstract.8: Fifteen (62.5%) of the 24 medically treated patients were discharged with negative C-reactive protein tests.
abstract.9: Spontaneous resolution of a dissection was demonstrated by radiological examinations in 8 cases.
abstract.10: Five-year survival rates in 24 medically treated patients was 93%.
abstract.11: Hospital survival rate in the patients with chronic dissection was 100% (14/14).
abstract.12: The rigorous control of blood pressure in the acute phase, and subsequent meticulous evaluation of the dissection by radiological tests and C-reactive protein test provides acceptable short-term and long-term outcomes of patients with acute distal dissection without the need for emergency surgical intervention.

adaptation1.1: This study evaluated the short- and long-term outcome of 42 patients with distal type aortic dissection. Distal type aortic dissection is when an injury occurs to the inner layer of the aorta (main artery of the body), and blood flows between the layers of the aortic wall.
adaptation1.2: Twenty-eight patients underwent intensive medical therapy within two weeks after the onset of pain (acute dissection).
adaptation1.3: The remaining 14 patients had chronic dissection, meaning they were treated after more than 2 weeks had passed since pain onset (started).
adaptation1.4: The goals of treatment were to control blood pressure and to attain a negative (no detected) C-reactive protein test result. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.5: Hospital survival rate in the patients with acute dissection was 96% (27/28).
adaptation1.6: There were several complications that occurred in-hospital during treatment. These complications include changes in mental status, kidney dysfunction, bradycardia (low heart rate), low blood pressure, and liver dysfunction. All of these complications were managed medically.
adaptation1.7: Three of these patients underwent surgical therapy in the chronic phase and were discharged without issue.
adaptation1.8: Fifteen of the 24 medically treated patients were discharged with negative C-reactive protein tests.
adaptation1.9: Spontaneous resolution of a dissection was demonstrated by x-rays in 8 cases.
adaptation1.10: Nearly all of the 24 medically treated patients had five-year survival rates.
