adaptation1.11: Hospital survival rate in the patients with chronic dissection was 100%.
adaptation1.12: Strict control of blood pressure and evaluation of the dissection by x-rays and C-reactive protein tests provide acceptable outcomes of patients with acute distal dissection. These measures eliminate the need for emergency surgical intervention.

adaptation2.1: We analyzed the short- and long-term outcome of 42 patients with distal type aortic dissection (a tear in the major blood vessel near the heart).
adaptation2.2: Twenty-eight patients underwent intense treatment within two weeks after the start of pain (acute dissection or immediate rupture).
adaptation2.3: The remaining 14 patients had long-lasting dissection or gradual breakdown of the major blood vessel near the heart.
adaptation2.4: The goals of treatment were to control blood pressure and detect no C-reactive protein (a measure of inflammation).
adaptation2.5: Hospital survival rate in patients with acute dissection was 96% (27/28).
adaptation2.6: In-hospital issues included changes in mental status, kidney dysfunction, slowed heart beat, low blood pressure from standing, and liver dysfunction, all of which were managed medically.
adaptation2.7: Three of these patients had surgery in the long-lasting phase and were released without issue.
adaptation2.8: Fifteen (62.5%) of the 24 medically treated patients were released with no C-reactive protein detected.
adaptation2.9: Random solving of a dissection (tear) was demonstrated by medical imaging in 8 cases.
adaptation2.10: Five-year survival rates in 24 medically treated patients was 93%.
adaptation2.11: Hospital survival rate in patients with long-lasting dissection was 100% (14/14).
adaptation2.12: The rigorous control of blood pressure in the immediate phase, and subsequent monitoring of the dissection or tear by imaging and C-reactive protein tests provide good short- and long-term outcomes of patients with immediate distal dissection without emergency surgery.

4061533.Title: The association of subclinical infection with preterm labor: the role of C-reactive protein

abstract.1: The role of subclinical intrauterine infection in preterm labor was evaluated prospectively in 40 patients and appropriate control subjects.
abstract.2: The 24 preterm labor patients (60%) with a negative C-reactive protein value responded to tocolysis 95.8% of the time, with a mean delay of delivery of 35.5 days and a mean gestational age of 36.9 weeks.
abstract.3: The 16 patients (40%) with a positive C-reactive protein value responded to tocolysis only 37.5% of the time, with a mean delay of delivery of 14.4 days and a mean gestational age of 33.2 weeks.
abstract.4: Pathologic evidence of chorioamnionitis was present in 32.9% of 310 preterm deliveries as compared to only 22.3% of 1631 term deliveries.
abstract.5: The presence of subclinical infection must be considered in cases of preterm labor, especially among patients for whom tocolytic therapy is unsuccessful.

adaptation1.1: The role of undetected infection within the uterus in preterm labor (between week 20 and 27 of pregnancy) was evaluated in 40 patients and control subjects.
adaptation1.2: The 24 preterm labor patients with a negative (no detection) C-reactive protein value responded to tocolysis, a procedure to delay delivery, most of the time. These patients had an average delay of delivery for 35.5 days and an average gestational (pregnant) age of 36.9 weeks. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.3: The 16 patients with a positive (with detection of) C-reactive protein value responded to tocolysis less than half of the time. These patients had an average delay of delivery of 14.4 days and an average gestational age of 33.2 weeks.
adaptation1.4: Evidence of chorioamnionitis, an infection within the membranes surrounding a fetus, was present in 32.9% of 310 preterm deliveries. Evidence of chorioamnionitis was only found in 22.3% of 1631 term deliveries.
adaptation1.5: The presence of undetected infection must be considered in cases of preterm labor, especially among patients for whom tocolytic therapy is unsuccessful.

10530060.Title: Negative C-reactive protein in children with bacterial infection

abstract.1: Purpose: To evaluate the practical value of initial C-reactive protein (CRP) in the diagnosis of bacterial infection in children.
abstract.2: Methods: The subjects comprised 11 children, six boys and five girls, aged 3 months through to 3 years (median age 16 months), whose initial CRP levels were < 1.0 mg/dL despite bacterial infection.
abstract.3: C-reactive protein was quantitated at the first medical examination by nephelometry.
abstract.4: Results: The diagnosis was urinary tract infection (n = 4), bacterial meningitis (n = 2), sepsis (n = 2), pneumonia (n = 2) and arthritis of the hip joint (n = 1).
abstract.5: The CRP levels were significantly elevated during the course of infection, ranging from 7.6 to 28.5 mg/dL.
abstract.6: The bacterial etiology was non-specific.
abstract.7: Eight patients were examined within 12 h of onset, three exhibited negative CRP values despite the duration of the insult over 12 h.
abstract.8: Six patients were tentatively diagnosed as having a bacterial infection, but the other five were not.
abstract.9: Each patient was treated, leading to a favorable outcome without any serious complications.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Low levels of CRP do not rule out the possibility of bacterial infection in children.
abstract.11: The initial value of CRP may be negative, even in patients with severe bacterial infection or even after 12 h from onset.
abstract.12: The data suggest that pediatricians should consistently be aware of the possibility of bacterial infection even if the initial CRP test result is negative and that serial CRP measurements appear to be practical.

adaptation1.1: The aim of this paper was to determine how C-reactive protein volume in patients can help diagnose bacterial infections in children. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.2: The study evaluated 11 children. The group consisted of six boys and five girls that were between 3 months to 3 years of age. All of the children's' initial CRP levels were < 1.0 mg/dL despite bacterial infection.
adaptation1.3: C-reactive protein was measured at the first medical examination.
adaptation1.4: The eleven children were diagnosed with various illnesses. These include: 4 with urinary tract infection, 2 with bacterial meningitis (inflammation with intense headaches), 2 with sepsis (life-threatening condition when the body's response to infection damages itself), 2 with pneumonia (lung infection) and 1 with arthritis of the hip joint.
adaptation1.5: CRP levels were increased during the course of infection.
adaptation1.6: The cause of the bacterial infections were not specified.
adaptation1.7: Eight patients were examined within 12 h of illness. Three showed negative CRP values despite the duration of the illness over 12 h.
adaptation1.8: Six patients were tentatively diagnosed as having a bacterial infection. The other five were not.
adaptation1.9: Each patient was treated. Treatment led to better health status without any serious complications.
adaptation1.10: Low levels of CRP do not rule out the possibility of bacterial infection in children.
adaptation1.11: The initial value of CRP may be negative, even in patients with severe bacterial infection or even after 12 h from onset.
adaptation1.12: The data suggest that doctors of children should always be aware of the possibility of bacterial infection even if the initial CRP test result is negative (no detection) and that serial (multiple) CRP measurements appear to be practical.

abstract.1: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a phylogenetically highly conserved plasma protein, with homologs in vertebrates and many invertebrates, that participates in the systemic response to inflammation.
abstract.2: Its plasma concentration increases during inflammatory states, a characteristic that has long been employed for clinical purposes.
abstract.3: CRP is a pattern recognition molecule, binding to specific molecular configurations that are typically exposed during cell death or found on the surfaces of pathogens.
abstract.4: Its rapid increase in synthesis within hours after tissue injury or infection suggests that it contributes to host defense and that it is part of the innate immune response.
abstract.5: Recently, an association between minor CRP elevation and future major cardiovascular events has been recognized, leading to the recommendation by the Centers for Disease Control and the American Heart Association that patients at intermediate risk of coronary heart disease might benefit from measurement of CRP.
abstract.6: This review will largely focus on our current understanding of the structure of CRP, its ligands, the effector molecules with which it interacts, and its apparent functions.

adaptation1.1: C-reactive protein (CRP) is a protein that has remained relatively unchanged from evolution. CRP has similar forms in vertebrates and many invertebrates and participates in the systemic (full-body) response to inflammation (infection-fighting).
adaptation1.2: Its plasma (blood) concentration increases during inflammation. This is a characteristic that has long been employed for clinical purposes.
adaptation1.3: CRP is a pattern recognition molecule. This means CRP binds to specific molecular configurations typically found during cell death or on the surfaces of pathogens (foreign organisms).
adaptation1.4: The rapid increase in CRP production within hours after tissue injury or infection suggests that it contributes to host defense. This also indicates that CRP is part of the innate immune response.
adaptation1.5: Recently, an association between minor CRP elevation and future major heart-related events has been recognized. This has lead to government health agencies recommending that patients at intermediate risk of coronary heart disease (damage in the heart's major blood vessels) might benefit from measurement of CRP.
adaptation1.6: This review focuses on the current understanding of the structure of CRP, the molecules it binds and interacts with, and its functions.

18496408.Title: Procalcitonin and C-reactive protein as markers of bacterial infection in critically ill children at onset of systemic inflammatory response syndrome

abstract.1: Objective: To compare the accuracy of procalcitonin and C-reactive protein as diagnostic markers of bacterial infection in critically ill children at the onset of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
abstract.2: Design: Prospective cohort study.
abstract.3: Setting: Tertiary care, university-affiliated pediatric intensive care unit (PICU).
abstract.4: Patients: Consecutive patients with SIRS.
abstract.5: Interventions: From June to December 2002, all PICU patients were screened daily to include cases of SIRS.
abstract.6: At inclusion (onset of SIRS), procalcitonin and C-reactive protein levels as well as an array of cultures were obtained.
abstract.7: Diagnosis of bacterial infection was made a posteriori by an adjudicating process (consensus of experts unaware of the results of procalcitonin and C-reactive protein).
abstract.8: Baseline and daily data on severity of illness, organ dysfunction, and outcome were collected.
abstract.9: Measurements and main results: Sixty-four patients were included in the study and were a posteriori divided into the following groups: bacterial SIRS (n = 25) and nonbacterial SIRS (n = 39).
abstract.10: Procalcitonin levels were significantly higher in patients with bacterial infection compared with patients without bacterial infection (p = .01).
abstract.11: The area under the receiver operating characteristic curve for procalcitonin was greater than that for C-reactive protein (0.71 vs. 0.65, respectively).
abstract.12: A positive procalcitonin level (>or=2.5 ng/mL), when added to bedside clinical judgment, increased the likelihood of bacterial infection from 39% to 92%, while a negative C-reactive protein level (<40 mg/L) decreased the probability of bacterial infection from 39% to 2%.
abstract.13: Conclusions: Procalcitonin is better than C-reactive protein for differentiating bacterial from nonbacterial SIRS in critically ill children, although the accuracy of both tests is moderate.
abstract.14: Diagnostic accuracy could be enhanced by combining these tests with bedside clinical judgment.

adaptation1.1: The aim of this study was to evaluate the accuracy of procalcitonin (involved in calcium balance) and C-reactive protein as measurable, biological indicators, or biomarkers, of bacterial infection. Specifically, this study evaluated the use of these biomarkers in critically ill children at the start of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.2: This study evaluated patients who were alike in many ways but differed by specific characteristics.
adaptation1.3: This study was based in the tertiary care, university-affiliated pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for child care.
adaptation1.4: The study evaluated patients with SIRS.
adaptation1.5: From June to December 2002, all PICU patients were screened daily to include cases of SIRS.
adaptation1.6: At inclusion (onset of SIRS), procalcitonin and C-reactive protein levels, along with several bacterial cultures (bacterial groups grown in a lab), were obtained.
adaptation1.7: Diagnosis of bacterial infection was made following examination of the cultures.
adaptation1.8: Baseline (before study) and daily data on severity of illness, organ dysfunction, and outcome were collected.
adaptation1.9: Sixty-four patients were included in the study. All patients were divided into the one of two groups: bacterial SIRS (25 patients) and nonbacterial SIRS (39 patients).
adaptation1.10: Procalcitonin levels were significantly higher in patients with bacterial infection compared with patients without bacterial infection.
adaptation1.11: Volume of procalcitonin was more predictive of bacterial infection than C-reactive protein.
adaptation1.12: A positive (detected) procalcitonin level increased the likelihood of bacterial infection. A negative (not detected) C-reactive protein level decreased the probability of bacterial infection.
adaptation1.13: Procalcitonin is better than C-reactive protein for differentiating (identifying) bacterial from nonbacterial SIRS in critically ill children. However, the accuracy of both biomarkers is moderate.
adaptation1.14: Diagnostic accuracy could be enhanced by combining these tests with bedside clinical judgment.

adaptation2.1: The study's objective is to compare the accuracy of procalcitonin (a prototype molecule for a calcium-regulating molecule) and C-reactive protein (a marker of inflammation) as markers of bacterial infection in very ill children at the start of full-body or systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), an exaggerated immune response to a harmful stressor.
adaptation2.3: The study takes place at a university-partnered child-care unit.
adaptation2.4: Patients include those with SIRS.
adaptation2.5: Treatment was that from June to December 2002, all hospital patients were tested daily to include cases of SIRS.
adaptation2.6: At inclusion (start of SIRS), we measured procalcitonin, C-reactive protein, and some cell types.
adaptation2.7: Identification of bacterial infection was made based on facts and judgment of experts unaware of the procalcitonin and C-reactive protein measures.
adaptation2.8: Starting and daily data on illness severity, organ dysfunction, and health outcome were collected.
adaptation2.9: Sixty-four patients were included in the study and divided into either bacterial SIRS group, with 25 patients, or nonbacterial SIRS group, with 39 patients.
adaptation2.10: Procalcitonin levels were higher in patients with bacterial infection than those without.
adaptation2.11: Accuracy was higher for procalcitonin than for C-reactive protein.
adaptation2.12: Detecting high procalcitonin, when added to bedside clinical judgment, increased the chance of bacterial infection from 39% to 92%. Not detecting C-reactive protein decreased the chance of bacterial infection from 39% to 2%.
adaptation2.13: Procalcitonin is better than C-reactive protein for detecting bacterial from nonbacterial SIRS in very ill children, although the accuracy of both tests is moderate.
adaptation2.14: Detection accuracy could be enhanced by combining the tests with bedside clinical judgment.

21561990.Title: Role of C-reactive protein velocity in the diagnosis of early bacterial infections in children after cardiac surgery

abstract.1: Fever after cardiac surgery in children may be due to bacterial infection or noninfectious origin like systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) secondary to bypass procedure.
abstract.2: A marker to distinguish bacterial from nonbacterial fever in these conditions is clinically important.
abstract.3: The purpose of our study was to evaluate, in the early postcardiac surgery period, whether serial measurement of C-reactive protein (CRP) and its change over time (CRP velocity) can assist in detecting bacterial infection.
abstract.4: A series of consecutive children who underwent cardiac surgery with bypass were tested for serum levels of CRP at several points up to 5 days postoperatively and during febrile episodes (>38.0°C).
abstract.5: Findings were compared among febrile patients with proven bacterial infection (FWI group; sepsis, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, deep wound infection), febrile patients without bacterial infection (FNI group), and patients without fever (NF group).
abstract.6: In all, 121 children were enrolled in the study, 31 in the FWI group, 42 in the FNI group, and 48 patients in the NF group.
abstract.7: Ages ranged from 4 days to 17.8 years (median 19.0, mean 46 ± 56 months).
abstract.8: There was no significant difference among the groups in mean CRP level before surgery, 1 hour, and 18 hours after.
abstract.9: A highly significant interaction was found in the change in CRP over time by FWI group compared with FNI group (P < .001).
abstract.10: Mean CRP velocity ([fCRP - 18hCRP]/[fever time (days) - 0.75 day]) was significantly higher in the infectious group (4.0 ± 4.2 mg/dL per d) than in the fever-only group (0.60 ± 1.6 mg/dL per d; P < .001).
abstract.11: A CRP velocity of 4 mg/dL per d had a positive predictive value (PPV) of 85.7% for bacterial infection with 95.2% specificity.
abstract.12: Serial measurements of CRP/CRP velocity after cardiac surgery in children may assist clinicians in differentiating postoperative fever due to bacterial infection from fever due to noninfectious origin.

adaptation1.1: Fever after heart surgery in children may be due to bacterial infection. The fever may also be caused by a noninfectious origin like systemic (full-body) inflammatory (infection-fighting) response syndrome (SIRS).
adaptation1.2: A marker to distinguish bacterial from nonbacterial fever in these conditions is important.
adaptation1.3: The aim of this study was to evaluate, in the period after heart surgery, whether measurement of C-reactive protein (CRP) and its change over time (CRP velocity) can help detect bacterial infection. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.4: Children who underwent heart surgery with bypass (diverted blood flow) were tested for serum (blood) levels of CRP at several points up to 5 days after surgery and/or when they had a fever.
adaptation1.5: Evidence was compared among three patient groups. The groups include: patients with fever with proven bacterial infection (FWI group), febrile (near-fever) patients without bacterial infection (FNI group), and patients without fever (NF group).
adaptation1.6: In all, 121 children were enrolled in the study, 31 in the FWI group, 42 in the FNI group, and 48 patients in the NF group.
adaptation1.7: Ages ranged from 4 days to 17.8 years.
adaptation1.8: There was no significant difference among the groups in mean CRP level before surgery, 1 hour, and 18 hours after.
adaptation1.9: A highly significant interaction was found in the change in CRP over time by the FWI group compared with the FNI group.
adaptation1.10: Mean CRP velocity was significantly higher in the infectious group than in the fever-only group.
adaptation1.11: Specific CRP velocity could positively predict bacterial infection with 95.2% specificity (accuracy).
adaptation1.12: Serial (consistent) measurements of CRP/CRP velocity after heart surgery in children may assist clinicians in differentiating (identifying) post-operation fever due to bacterial infection from fever due to noninfectious origin.

28756540.Title: Severe ulcerative colitis: predictors of response and algorithm proposal for rescue therapy

abstract.1: Background: There is no agreeing if rescue therapy can avoid short-term colectomy in patients treated for severe steroid-refractory ulcerative colitis.
abstract.2: Aims: The aim of our study was to identify predictors of response to infliximab and cyclosporine A.
abstract.3: Methods: In this cross-sectional study, 49 patients with severe ulcerative colitis were included.
abstract.4: Response to therapy was defined as three or more point reductions in Mayo score after 6 months of treatment and avoidance of colectomy after 1 year.
abstract.5: The predictors analysed were gender, age, time from ulcerative colitis diagnosis, months of steroid or/and azathioprine therapy before onset of the severe phase, smoking habits, extension of the disease, laboratory analyses and Mayo score.
abstract.6: Results: Patients treated with infliximab showed a statistically significant higher response rate in case of moderate Mayo score (P = 0.04).
abstract.7: Ex-smokers had very low chance of response to infliximab (P = 0.03).
abstract.8: In the group treated with cyclosporine A, patients with C-reactive protein >3 mg/L had a response rate significantly higher than those with C-reactive protein <3 mg/L (P = 0.03); those with negative C-reactive protein and moderate Mayo score did not responded to therapy, while in the ones with elevated C-reactive protein and/or severe Mayo score, 15 versus 4 responded (P = 0.008).
abstract.9: Conclusions: Our data suggest that cyclosporine A is advisable in ex-smokers.
abstract.10: In never smokers or active smokers, infliximab can be prescribed in case of Mayo score ≤10 and/or negative CRP, while cyclosporine A is indicated in case of Mayo score >10 and positive CRP.

adaptation1.1: It is unknown if rescue therapy, or therapy given after an ailment does not respond to normal treatment, can avoid colectomy (removal of all or parts of colon) in patients treated for severe steroid-refractory ulcerative colitis. Steroid-refractory ulcerative colitis is chronic inflammatory bowel disease that no longer responds to steroid treatment.
adaptation1.2: The aim of this study was to identify predictors of response to infliximab and cyclosporine A, drugs that aim to improve the immune system.
adaptation1.3: In this study, 49 patients with severe ulcerative colitis were included.
adaptation1.4: Response to therapy was characterized as three or more point reductions in Mayo score (a disease ranking system) after 6 months of treatment and avoidance of colectomy after 1 year. Increased Mayo score indicated worsened disease condition.
adaptation1.5: The predictors evaluated were gender, age, time from ulcerative colitis diagnosis, months of steroid or/and azathioprine therapy before onset of the severe phase, smoking habits, extension of the disease, laboratory analyses and Mayo score. Azathioprine is a medication given to improve immune function.
adaptation1.6: Patients treated with infliximab showed a statistically significant higher response rate in case of moderate Mayo score.
adaptation1.7: Ex-smokers had very low chance of response to infliximab.
adaptation1.8: In the group treated with cyclosporine A, patients with a higher volume of C-reactive protein had a response rate significantly higher than those with lower C-reactive protein volume. Patients with negative (no detected) C-reactive protein volume and moderate Mayo score did not responded to therapy. Patients with elevated C-reactive protein and/or severe Mayo score predominately respond. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.9: This study suggests that cyclosporine A is advisable as treatment in ex-smokers.
adaptation1.10: In never smokers or active smokers, infliximab can be prescribed in case of Mayo score ≤10 and/or negative CRP. However, cyclosporine A is indicated as a better option in case of Mayo score >10 and positive CRP.

33657772.Title: Tumor Shrinkage as a Prognostic Factor of Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma in the Era of Molecular Targeted Therapy

abstract.1: We evaluated the impact of tumor shrinkage (TS) induced by molecular targeted therapy as the first-line systemic therapy on the survival of patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC).
abstract.2: A total of 67 patients with mRCC who received first-line molecular targeted therapy were included in this study.
abstract.3: Sixty patients were evaluable by response evaluation criteria in solid tumors.
abstract.4: Patients underwent the first evaluation at 8-12 weeks after the start of the therapy.
abstract.5: Twenty patients had TS ≧30%, 32 from 30% to -20%, and 8 ≦-20%.
abstract.6: The median overall survival periods of patients who achieved TS ≧30%, from 30% to -20%, and ≦-20% at first evaluation were 41.0, 35.0, and 11.5 months, respectively.
abstract.7: Univariate and multivariate analyses showed that TS of≧0%, in addition to negative C-reactive protein and the absence of bone metastasis were good predictors of overall survival.
abstract.8: The patients who achieved 0% or more at the initial evaluation had longer survival than those who had no tumor reduction (40.0 months vs 12.0 months, p<0. 001).
abstract.9: These findings suggest that early TS affects overall survival in real practice.
abstract.10: We should consider alternative therapies for patients who have not achieved tumor reduction at the initial evaluation.

adaptation1.1: This study evaluated the impact of tumor shrinkage (TS) caused by molecular targeted therapy as the first-line systemic (full-body) therapy on the survival of patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC). mRCC is kidney cancer that has spread to other organs. Molecular targeted therapy is a treatment type that uses drugs to target specific molecules involved in the growth and spread of cancer cells.
adaptation1.2: A total of 67 patients with mRCC who received molecular targeted therapy were included in this study.
adaptation1.3: Sixty patients were evaluated by response evaluation criteria in solid tumors.
adaptation1.4: Patients underwent the first evaluation at 8-12 weeks after the start of the therapy.
adaptation1.5: Twenty patients had TS ≧ 30%, 32 from 30% to -20%, and 8 ≦ -20%.
adaptation1.6: The median (average) overall survival periods of patients who achieved TS ≧30%, from 30% to -20%, and ≦-20% at first evaluation were 41.0, 35.0, and 11.5 months, respectively.
adaptation1.7: Analyses showed that TS of ≧0%, partnered with negative C-reactive protein and the absence of bone metastasis (cancer spreading), were good predictors of overall survival. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.8: The patients who achieved 0% or more at the initial evaluation had longer survival times than those who had no tumor reduction.
adaptation1.9: These findings suggest that early TS affects overall survival in real practice.
adaptation1.10: Alternative therapies should be considered for patients who have not achieved tumor reduction at the initial evaluation.

34601537.Title: Characteristics and Outcome of Patients with COVID-19 Undergoing Invasive Mechanical Ventilation for Respiratory Failure in a Tertiary Level Hospital in Nepal

abstract.1: Background: Corona virus disease 2019 has become a global health issue.
abstract.2: The goal of this study was to investigate the characteristics and outcomes of patients with corona virus disease 2019 undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation and identify factors associated with mortality.
abstract.3: Methods: Ninety four consecutive critically ill patients with confirmed corona virus disease 2019 undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation were included in this retrospective, single-center, observational study.
abstract.4: The outcome variable was mortality of patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation and factors associated with it during intensive care unit stay.
abstract.5: Results: Seventy nine (84%) out of 94 patients with confirmed corona virus disease 2019 who underwent invasive mechanical ventilation didn't survive.
abstract.6: Ninety four percent of patients who had Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus did not survive in comparison to 72 percent of patients who didn't have Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.
abstract.7: Similarly, 48 (94.1%) out of 51 patients with a positive C-reactive protein value didn't survive in comparison to 31 (72%) out of 43 patients with a negative C-reactive protein.
abstract.8: Conclusions: The presence of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and a positive C-reactive protein value were strongly associated with mortality.
abstract.9: Patients with a Sequential organ failure assessment score of more than eight at intensive care unit admission and peak D-dimer level of more than or equal to two during intensive care unit stay didn't show significant association with mortality.
abstract.10: These findings need further exploration through larger prospective studies.

adaptation1.1: Corona virus disease 2019, or COVID-19 (a viral, respiratory illness), has become a global health issue.
adaptation1.2: The goal of this study was to investigate the characteristics and outcomes of patients with COVID-19 undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation (being helped to breathe by a machine). This study also aimed to identify factors associated with death.
adaptation1.3: Ninety four critically ill COVID-19 patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation were included in this study.
adaptation1.4: The studied variable of interest was death of the patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation and factors associated with death during intensive care unit stay.
adaptation1.5: Seventy nine out of 94 patients with COVID-19 who underwent invasive mechanical ventilation didn't survive.
adaptation1.6: Ninety four percent of patients who had Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus did not survive. This is compared to 72% of patients who didn't have Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.
adaptation1.7: Similarly, 48 out of 51 patients with a positive C-reactive protein value didn't survive in comparison to 31 out of 43 patients with a negative C-reactive protein. C-reactive protein is a type of protein found in the blood that increases during times of internal inflammation (redness and swelling from infection-fighting).
adaptation1.8: The presence of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and a positive C-reactive protein value were strongly associated with death.
adaptation1.9: Patients with a Sequential organ failure assessment score, a ranking system to determine patient's organ function, of >8 at ICU admission and peak D-dimer (protein fragment from dissolved blood clotting) level of ≥ 2 during ICU stay didn't show significant association with death.
adaptation1.10: These findings need further exploration in larger studies.

50.question: What does a negative result of a c-reactive protein test indicate?

62945.Title: Pancreatic islet-cell antibody as a marker for asymptomatic and latent diabetes and prediabetes

abstract.1: Pancreatic islet-cell antibodies (I.C.Ab) were detected in 31 patients with organ-specific autoimmune disorders, 4 first-degree relatives of I.C.Ab-positive diabetics, and 1 apparently normal subject, none of whom had clinical evidence of diabetes.
abstract.2: 10 of these 36 subjects were found to have diabetic glucose-tolerance tests (G.T.T.S), 4 had lag storage, and 22 had normal G.T.T.S.2 had latent diabetes, as evidenced by diabetic G.T.T.S during pregnancy and thyrotoxicosis; another 2 subsequently developed insulin-dependent diabetes (I.D.D.)
abstract.3: Serum from 26 subjects had been stored for 1-11 yr before the G.T.T.S were done.
abstract.4: The titres in some were shown to rise and fall over the years, while in others they remained remarkably constant.
abstract.5: There was no correlation between the titre, change in titre or the duration of I.C.Ab or the presence of HLA-B8, BW15, or CW3 and the result of the G.T.T.
abstract.6: In addition to acting as a marker for asymptomatic and latent diabetes and prediabetes, it seems that the presence of I.C.Ab in the serum may define a new group of potential diabetics with normal G.T.T.S.
abstract.7: Many such subjects have one or more organ-specific autoimmune disorders (irrespective of diabetic family history), but some are first-degree relatives of I.C.Ab-positive subjects (mainly I.D.D.).
abstract.8: About 0-5% of the general population also have I.C.Ab in their serum.

adaptation1.1: We found pancreatic islet-cell antibodies (I.C.Ab; proteins made against insulin-producing cells in the pancreas) in 31 patients with disorders where the body's defense system attacks certain organs; 4 parents, siblings, or children of people with I.C.Ab-positive diabetes, and 1 apparently normal person, none of whom had symptoms of diabetes.
adaptation1.2: Of these 36 people, glucose (sugar molecule)-tolerance tests (G.T.T.S) showed 10 had diabetes, 4 had lag storage (normal glucose levels spike and return to normal), and 22 had normal results. Two people had latent diabetes (slow progressing with features of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes) while pregnant and thyrotoxicosis (too much metabolism-regulating thyroid hormone in the body) and another 2 later developed type 1 diabetes.
adaptation1.3: Blood from 26 people had been stored for 1-11 years before we did the oral (by mouth) tests that measures the body's response to sugar (glucose).
adaptation1.4: I.C.Ab measurements rose and fell in some patients and stayed constant in other patients.
adaptation1.5: No relationship existed between the measurement, change in measurement, or the length of I.C.Ab or the presence of antigens (substances that causes the body to defend itself) and the G.T.T. result.
adaptation1.6: I.C.Ab in the blood can indicate diabetes without symptoms and slow-progressing diabetes and prediabetes and may signal a new group of possible diabetics with normal G.T.T.S.
adaptation1.7: Many possible diabetics with normal G.T.T.S. have at least one disorder where the body's defense system attacks certain organs (regardless of family history of diabetes), but some are parents, siblings, or children of people with I.C.Ab (mainly type 1 diabetes).
adaptation1.8: About 0-5% of the general population also have I.C.Ab in their blood.

1541379.Title: Loss of regular oscillatory insulin secretion in islet cell antibody positive non-diabetic subjects

abstract.1: Basal insulin secretion was compared in nine islet-cell antibody positive, non-diabetic first-degree relatives of children with Type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus and nine normal control subjects matched for age, sex and weight.
abstract.2: Acute insulin responses to a 25 g intravenous glucose tolerance test were similar in the two groups (243 (198-229) vs 329 (285-380) mU.l-1 x 10 min-1, mean (+/- SE), p = 0.25).
abstract.3: Fasting plasma insulin was assayed in venous samples taken at one min intervals for 2 h.
abstract.4: Time series analysis was used to demonstrate oscillatory patterns in plasma insulin.
abstract.5: Autocorrelation showed that regular oscillatory activity was generally absent in the islet-cell antibody-positive group, whereas a regular 13 min cycle was shown in control subjects (p less than 0.0001).
abstract.6: Fourier transformation did, however, show a 13 min spectral peak in the islet-cell antibody positive group, consistent with intermittent pulsatility.
abstract.7: We conclude that overall oscillatory patterns of basal insulin secretion are altered in islet-cell antibody positive subjects even when the acute insulin response is within the normal range.

adaptation1.1: We compared background insulin release in nine islet-cell antibody (protein made against insulin-producing cells) positive, non-diabetic parents or siblings of children with type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes and nine normal people matched for age, sex and weight.
adaptation1.2: Short-term insulin responses to an I.V. (injected) glucose tolerance test were similar in the two groups.
adaptation1.3: We measured blood insulin in people who had not had anything to eat for a period of time in blood samples taken every minute for 2 hours.
adaptation1.4: We looked at blood insulin over time to see how it rises and falls.
adaptation1.5: The islet-cell antibody-positive group (group with the antibody) did not have a regular pattern, but normal people had a 13-minute cycle.
adaptation1.6: The islet-cell antibody-positive group did have a peak every 13 minutes.
adaptation1.7: We conclude that the overall rise and fall of background insulin release is changed in islet-cell antibody positive people even when the short-term insulin response is normal.

1826249.Title: Does knowledge of islet cell antibody status help in managing diabetes presenting in middle and old age?

abstract.1: It has been suggested that screening all patients with diabetes diagnosed in later life for islet cell antibodies (ICA) would help predict insulin dependence.
abstract.2: We have surveyed the case notes of 55 patients (22 male; ages 37-88 years) who were found to be ICA positive over a 9-year screening period to assess what contribution knowledge of ICA status made to their management.
abstract.3: Forty-two patients had been put on insulin (half within 6 months of diagnosis and the rest after up to 6 years).
abstract.4: Of the 13 patients not on insulin, six were on diet alone and seven on oral hypoglycaemic agents after a median follow-up of 3 years.
abstract.5: In 37 of the 42 patients, insulin treatment was started for clinical rather than immunological reasons (diabetic ketoacidosis, ketonuria, weight loss and/or severe symptoms).
abstract.6: Five patients were started on insulin because of ICA status when there was no compelling reason on clinical grounds.
abstract.7: Knowledge that seven non-insulin-treated patients were ICA positive made doctors reluctant to discharge them from clinic.
abstract.8: The data suggest that routine ICA estimation in this age group is unnecessary, as the decision to treat with insulin is best made on clinical grounds, and ICA estimation can lead to unwarranted insulin treatment, or anxiety in patients and doctors who are aware of a positive result.

adaptation1.1: Checking all people with diabetes detected later in life for islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells) may help predict dependence on insulin.
adaptation1.2: We read doctor notes of 55 patients (22 male; ages 37-88 years) who were found to be ICA positive (with ICA) over a 9-year checking period to determine what role ICA status made to their treatment.
adaptation1.3: Forty-two patients had been put on insulin (half within 6 months of diagnosis and half after up to 6 years).
adaptation1.4: Of the 13 patients not on insulin, six were on health diet and seven were on oral (by mouth) medication after about 3 years.
adaptation1.5: In 37 of the 42 patients, insulin treatment was started due to observable symptoms (high levels of blood acids called ketones, high levels of ketones in urine, weight loss, and/or serious symptoms) rather than issues related to the body's defense system.
adaptation1.6: Five patients were started on insulin due to ICA status where no observable symptoms existed.
adaptation1.7: Doctors were hesitant to send home 7 non-insulin-treated, ICA-positive patients.
adaptation1.8: The data suggest that regularly estimating ICA in this age group is not needed, as the decision to treat with insulin should be based on observable symptoms, and ICF estimation can cause unneeded insulin treatment, or anxiety in patients and doctors due to a positive result.

3512340.Title: Islet cell proteins defined by monoclonal islet cell antibody HISL-19

abstract.1: A monoclonal islet cell antibody, HISL-19, reactive with human, bovine, and porcine pancreatic islets has been used to identify and characterize a novel group of islet cell proteins (p120, p69, p67, and p56).
abstract.2: Besides the islets, HISL-19-reactive antigenic determinants are also expressed on selected cell types, namely, gut endocrine cells, thyroid parafollicular cells (p120), anterior pituitary cells (p40 and p24), specific hypothalamic neuroendocrine cells, and a single layer of large pyramidal cells of the cerebral cortex, thus defining a new family of neuroendocrine molecules.

adaptation1.1: A lab-made islet cell antibody (proteins made against insulin-producing cells), HISL-19, that reacts with clusters of cells that produce hormones in the sugar-regulating pancreas of the human, cow, and pig has been used to find and describe a new group of islet (pancreatic) cell proteins (p120, p69, p67, and p56).
adaptation1.2: HISL-19 is also reactive with other related tissues that can be grouped into a new family of neuroendocrine (cells like nerve cells that make hormones) molecules.

abstract.1: Islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells) are a marker of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM).
abstract.2: ICA are detected in 60-80% of the patients with IDDM at the onset of the disease.
abstract.3: The presence of ICA in patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) indicates that the patients are likely to develop IDDM.
abstract.4: However, as ICA are measured by the indirect immunofluorescent method, the reliability of the ICA assay is not high in some institutes.
abstract.5: Use of the pancreas tissue having high antigenicity is recommended as one solution for a reliable assay.
abstract.6: Standardization of the ICA assay is under way with the use of an ICA positive standard sera as 80 JDF units.
abstract.7: Anti-glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) antibody assays using a radioimmunoassay (RIA) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have recently been developed.
abstract.8: The significance of anti-GAD antibodies is comparable to that of ICA.
abstract.9: Since the anti-GAD assay is reproducible and easy to perform, it should be used widely in parallel with the ICA assay.

adaptation1.1: Islet cell antibodies (ICA) are an indicator of type 1 diabetes.
adaptation1.2: ICA are found in 60-80% of patients with type 1 diabetes when symptoms first appear.
adaptation1.3: Type 2 diabetics with ICA are likely to develop type 1 diabetes.
adaptation1.4: The current way to measure ICA is not always reliable.
adaptation1.5: A reliable standardized test could use pancreas tissue, tissue from an organ that monitors blood sugar levels.
adaptation1.6: A standardized test to measure ICA is under way.
adaptation1.7: Scientists have recently developed a standardized test to measure anti-glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) antibody, a rare protein.
adaptation1.8: Anti-GAD antibodies and ICA have similar meanings.
adaptation1.9: The standardized test to measure anti-GAD can be repeated and is easy to do, so it should be used widely at the same time as the test to measure ICA.

8003613.Title: Modulation of beta-cell activity and its influence on islet cell antibody (ICA) and islet cell surface antibody (ICSA) reactivity

abstract.1: Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) is associated with the formation of autoantibodies against different antigens in the islets of Langerhans, so-called islet cell antibodies (ICA).
abstract.2: The expression of a major autoantigen, the beta-cell specific enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), is glucose-dependent in vitro and correlated to insulin release in vitro.
abstract.3: In this study the expression of islet autoantigens was examined in vivo and the relationship between beta-cell function and islet cell surface antibody (ICSA) reactivity was tested.
abstract.4: Rats were fed for 10 days with glipizide or diazoxide, in order to stimulate or inhibit insulin release, respectively.
abstract.5: Frozen sections of pancreata were incubated with ten ICA-positive IDDM sera and analyzed by indirect immunofluorescence.
abstract.6: Two sera with a "beta-cell restricted" staining, five with an "all-islet cell" staining and three with a "mixed" pattern were employed.
abstract.7: In all three groups, the highest end-point titres were obtained when pancreata of rats treated with glipizide were used.
abstract.8: Intermediate titres were seen in control animals and the lowest titres were observed on pancreata from diazoxide-treated rats, regardless of the serum used.
abstract.9: In contrast to these observations, no correlation between ICSA reactivity and islet cell activity could be demonstrated.
abstract.10: Conflicting results concerning ICSA in previous reports and our failure to show a glucose regulation of ICSA reactivity, indicate that ICSA is a phenomenon with a low degree of specificity.

adaptation1.1: Type 1 diabetes is associated with the formation of self-made proteins against different toxins in the islets of Langerhans (a group of insulin-producing cells in the pancreas), known as islet cell antibodies (ICA).
adaptation1.2: The expression of a major self-made marker, glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD; substance found only in insulin-producing cells), depends on glucose (sugar) levels and is related to insulin release when observed in a test tube.
adaptation1.3: We looked at expression of islet self-made markers in pancreatic cells and tested the relationship between beta-cell (insulin-producing cell) function and islet cell surface antibody (ICSA) reactivity.
adaptation1.4: We fed rats glipizide or diazoxide (insulin-treating drugs) for 10 days to increase or decrease insulin release, respectively.
adaptation1.5: Sections of the pancreas were analyzed.
adaptation1.7: We saw the highest measurements in rats given glipizide.
adaptation1.8: We saw medium measurements in animals not given drugs, and the lowest measurements in rats given diazoxide.
adaptation1.9: Opposite to these findings, we could not show a relationship between ICSA reactivity and islet cell activity.
adaptation1.10: Conflicting results concerning ICSA in previous reports and our failure to show an energy regulation of ICSA reactivity, indicate that ICSA is a phenomenon with a low degree of specific detection.

8326015.Title: Decreased insulin response to glucose in islet cell antibody-negative siblings of type 1 diabetic children

abstract.1: Measurement of beta-cell function is an important marker of progression to diabetes in individuals at risk for the disease.
abstract.2: Although the peak incidence for the disease occurs before 17 years of age, normal values for insulin secretion were not available in this age group.
abstract.3: We performed a simplified intravenous glucose tolerance test in 167 normal children, and in 98 islet cell antibody (ICA)-negative and 12 ICA-positive siblings of diabetic patients.
abstract.4: Their age range was 1-16 yr.
abstract.5: The first phase of insulin secretion, evaluated as the sum of plasma insulin concentrations at 1 and 3 min, increased with age and was significantly lower in ICA-negative siblings (86 +/- 6 microU/ml, P < 0.002) than in normal controls (115 +/- 6 microU/ml).
abstract.6: This difference was not apparent before 8 yr of age.
abstract.7: None of the ICA-negative siblings developed diabetes after an average of 4.5 yr.
abstract.8: ICA-positive siblings at first study had a first phase insulin response similar to that of ICA negative siblings, but significantly lower than that of the normal controls (74 +/- 13 microU/ml, P < 0.02).
abstract.9: The reason for the decreased insulin secretion in ICA-negative siblings is unknown, but could involve a defect in the growth of beta-cell mass or insulin secretion that could be part of the multifactorial pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes.

adaptation1.1: Measurement of cells that make insulin is an important indicator of diabetes development in people at risk for diabetes.
adaptation1.2: Although the disease most often happens before 17 years of age, normal values for insulin release were not available for this age group.
adaptation1.3: We did an I.V. (injected) glucose tolerance test in 167 normal children, and in 98 islet cell antibody (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells)-negative (without ICA) and 12 ICA-positive (with ICA) siblings of diabetic patients.
adaptation1.4: The children ranged from 1-16 years of age.
adaptation1.5: The first part of insulin release, measured as the total blood insulin levels at 1 and 3 minutes, increased with age and was significantly lower in ICA-negative siblings than in normal children.
adaptation1.6: We did not see a difference in the first part of insulin release before 8 years of age.
adaptation1.7: None of the ICA-negative siblings developed diabetes after an average of 4.5 years.
adaptation1.8: The first part of insulin response was similar in ICA-positive and ICA-negative siblings, but significantly lower than in normal children.
adaptation1.9: We do not know the reason ICF-negative siblings had lower insulin release, but it could have to do with insulin-producing cells growing incorrectly or insulin release that could be part of the complicated development of type 1 diabetes.

8786012.Title: Insulitis and islet-cell antibody formation in rats with experimentally reduced beta-cell mass

abstract.1: We studied the effect of severe reduction of beta-cell mass by 90% pancreatectomy on the immune tolerance to the endocrine pancreas.
abstract.2: Four months after subtotal pancreatectomy all LEW.Han rats had developed mononuclear infiltration of islets and 9 of 14 rats were positive for islet-cell antibodies.
abstract.3: Electron microscopy revealed lymphocytic invasion of endocrine tissue, lysis of beta cells and phagocytotic macrophages.
abstract.4: None of these changes were seen 2 weeks after 90% pancreatectomy or 4 months after 10% pancreatectomy.
abstract.5: Weekly substitution of islet antigens in the form of a homogenate of 100 islets into 90% pancreatectomized LEW.Han rats almost completely prevented the development of insulitis and autoantibodies.
abstract.6: The dependence of insulitis on T cells was shown when 90% pancreatectomy in LEW.rnu rats (i.e., the congenic athymic nude strain), did not result in islet infiltration.
abstract.7: The exocrine tissue remained normal in all experimental groups.
abstract.8: During the observation period insulitis was not associated with overt diabetes but was accompanied by substantial enlargement of islets and of beta-cell mass, as shown by morphometry.
abstract.9: Suppression of islet inflammation by injection of islet antigens abolished beta-cell regeneration, despite continuing metabolic stress in rats with 90% pancreatectomy.
abstract.10: The findings indicate induction of islet autoimmunity in response to 90% but not to 10% pancreatectomy.
abstract.11: We conclude that severe reduction of the islet-antigen mass allows the development of T-cell-dependent islet autoimmunity which indicates a loss of immune tolerance.
abstract.12: In addition, the data suggest the existence of islet-antigen autoreactive immune cells in rats not genetically predisposed to autoimmune diabetes.
abstract.13: Finally, we conclude that selective beta-cell regeneration occurs in association with insulitis.

adaptation1.1: We studied the effect of drastically reducing beta-cell (insulin-producing cell) mass by removing 90% of the pancreas on immune tolerance (state of unresponsiveness of the body's defense) to the endocrine pancreas, which controls blood sugar levels.
adaptation1.2: Four months after removal of almost all of the pancreas, all rats had developed signs of long-term inflammation (infection-fighting) response of islets (clusters of cells that produce hormones) and 9 of 14 rats had islet-cell antibodies (proteins made against insulin-producing cells).
adaptation1.3: Using microscopes, we saw immune white blood cells going into the part of the pancreas that produces substances (enzymes) that help with digestion, death of beta cells, and white blood cells that remove dying and dead cells.
adaptation1.4: We saw none of these changes 2 weeks after removing 90% of the pancreas or 4 months after removing 10% of the pancreas.
adaptation1.5: Weekly substitution of islet antigens (substances that causes the body to defend itself) in rats with 90% of the pancreas removed prevented insulitis (disease of the pancreas caused by the infiltration of immune white blood cells) and self-made proteins.
adaptation1.6: Insulitis was shown to be dependent on T cells (part of the body's defense system).
adaptation1.7: The tissue that produces substances (enzymes) that help with digestion did not change in any group.
adaptation1.8: During the observation period, insulitis was not related to diabetes, but we saw a sizeable increase in the sizes of islets and beta-cell mass.
adaptation1.9: Decreasing islet inflammation by injecting islet antigens (fragments) stopped beta-cell regrowth, even though low energy continued in rats with 90% of the pancreas removed.
adaptation1.10: The results suggest removing 90% but not 10% of the pancreas causes the body to mistakenly destroy its islets.
adaptation1.11: We conclude that drastically reducing the islet-antigen mass allows the body to mistakenly destroy its islets, which shows a loss of immune tolerance.
adaptation1.12: Also, the results suggest islet-antigen autoreactive immune cells exist in rats not likely to develop autoimmune diabetes (diabetes from the body mistakenly destroying its own cells).
adaptation1.13: Finally, we conclude that some beta-cell regrowth happens with insulitis.

10909610.Title: Islet autoantibody assays in type I diabetes: superiority of passage from use of ICA to traditional tests

abstract.1: Islet cell antibodies (ICA) continue to serve as the basis of the principal serological test for definition of active autoimmunity of beta-cells.
abstract.2: Its disadvantages are the need for human pancreatic tissue and difficulty in obtaining quantitative results.
abstract.3: In the past decade biochemically-defined beta-cell toxins were described, leading to the development of sensitive and specific autoantibody assays, to predict insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM).
abstract.4: We examined the value of combined biochemically-based serological assays, such as autoantibodies to insulin (IAA), glutamic acid decarboxylase (GADA) and ICA512 (ICA512A) to replace the traditional ICA assay.
abstract.5: Blood samples of 114 newly diagnosed IDDM patients, aged 12 +/- 5 yrs (range 2 months-29 years) were tested for ICA (indirect immunofluorescence), IAA, GADA and ICA512A (radiobinding assay).
abstract.6: The latter 2 assays were performed using recombinant human [35S]-labeled antigen produced by in vitro transcription/translation.
abstract.7: We found that fewer sera scored positive for ICA and/or IAA (80.7%, 92/114) than for 1 or more of IAA, GAD, or ICA512 (88.6%, 101/114).
abstract.8: We conclude that combined testing for IAA, GAD and ICA512 can replace the traditional ICA/IAA test to predict IDDM and is helpful in the differential diagnosis of insulin-dependent and noninsulin-dependent diabetes.

adaptation1.1: The main blood test to determine active attack of the insulin-producing beta-cells by the body is based on islet cell antibodies (ICA; proteins made against insulin-producing cells).
adaptation1.2: The main ICA test has drawbacks like needing human tissue from the pancreas and difficulty in getting results in the form of a number.
adaptation1.3: Based on the description of beta-cell proteins in test tubes in the past 10 years, new measuring tools for self-made proteins were made with high accuracy for disease detection and no detection to predict type 1 diabetes.
adaptation1.4: We looked at whether combined blood tests in test tubes, such as self-made proteins to insulin (IAA), the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase (GADA), and ICA512 (ICA512A), could replace the main ICA test.
adaptation1.5: We tested blood samples of 114 newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes patients, aged 12 plus or minus 5 years (ranging from 2 months to 29 year) for ICA, IAA, GADA, and ICA512A.
adaptation1.7: We found that more blood samples scored positive (detected the presence of the disease) for 1 or more of IAA, GAD, or ICA512 than for ICA and/or IAA.
adaptation1.8: We conclude that testing for IAA, GAD and ICA512 together can replace the traditional ICA/IAA test to predict type 1 diabetes and is helpful to doctors in telling the different between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

25482141.Title: Obesity and youth diabetes: distinguishing characteristics between islet cell antibody positive vs. negative patients over time

abstract.1: Objective: Obese youth clinically diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) frequently have evidence of islet cell autoimmunity (proteins made against insulin-producing cells).
abstract.2: We investigated the clinical and biochemical differences, and therapeutic modalities among autoantibody positive (Ab+) vs. autoantibody negative (Ab-) youth at the time of diagnosis and over time in a multi-provider clinical setting.
abstract.3: Study design: Chart review of 145 obese youth diagnosed with T2DM from January 2003 to July 2012.
abstract.4: Of these, 70 patients were Ab+ and 75 Ab-.
abstract.5: The two groups were compared with respect to clinical presentation, physical characteristics, laboratory data, and therapeutic modalities at diagnosis and during follow up to assess the changes in these parameters associated with disease progression.
abstract.6: Results: At presentation, Ab+ youth with a clinical diagnosis of T2DM were younger, had higher rates of ketosis, higher hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) and glucose levels, and lower insulin and c-peptide concentrations compared with the Ab- group.
abstract.7: The Ab- group had a higher body mass index (BMI) z-score and cardiometabolic risk factors at diagnosis and such difference remained over time.
abstract.8: Univariate analysis revealed that treatment modality had no effect on BMI in either group.
abstract.9: Generalized estimating equations for longitudinal data analysis revealed that (i) BMI z-score and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) were significantly affected by duration of diabetes; (ii) systolic blood pressure (SBP) and ALT were affected by changes in BMI z-score; and (iii) changes in HbA1c had an effect on lipid profile and cardiometabolic risk factors regardless of antibody status.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Irrespective of antibody status and treatment modality, youth who present with obesity and diabetes, show no improvement in obesity status over time, with the deterioration in BMI z-score affecting blood pressure (BP) and ALT, but the lipid profile being mostly impacted by HbA1c and glycemic control.
abstract.11: Effective control of BMI and glycemia are needed to lessen the future macrovascular complications irrespective of antibody status.

adaptation1.1: Obese youth diagnosed with type 2 diabetes by a doctor often have islet cell autoimmunity (in which immune cells attack healthy cells).
adaptation1.2: We looked at the observable and biochemical differences, and treatment types of self-made protein positive (Ab+) vs. self-made protein negative (Ab-) youth at diagnosis and over time at a medical facility.
adaptation1.3: We reviewed medical charts of 145 obese youth diagnosed with type 2 diabetes from January 2003 to July 2012.
adaptation1.4: Of these 145 youth, 70 patients were Ab+ and 75 Ab-.
adaptation1.5: We compared the disease symptoms, physical qualities, lab findings, and treatment types of the two groups at diagnosis and during follow up to rate the changes in these things related to disease development.
adaptation1.6: At the doctor, Ab+ youth with a doctor's diagnosis of type 2 diabetes were younger, had higher rates of not enough carbohydrates to burn, higher hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c - which indicates average blood sugar levels) and blood sugar levels, and lower insulin and signs of insulin production compared with the Ab- group.
adaptation1.7: The Ab- group had a higher body mass index (BMI) score adjusted for weight and gender and risk factors for heart disease and metabolic disorders at diagnosis and did not change over time.
adaptation1.8: Treatment type had no effect on BMI in either group.
adaptation1.9: We found that: (i) length of diabetes affected BMI score adjusted for weight and gender and diastolic blood pressure, (ii) changes In BMI score adjusted for weight and gender affected systolic blood pressure and ALT (alanine transaminase; released into the blood when liver cells are damaged), and (iii) changes in HbA1c affected lipid profile (panel of blood tests used to find abnormalities in lipids, such as cholesterol and triglycerides) and risk factors for heart disease and metabolic disorders independent of antibody (infection-fighting protein) status.
adaptation1.10: Regardless of antibody status and treatment type, obese and diabetic youth do not become less obese over time, with higher BMI affecting blood pressure and ALT, and blood sugar levels affecting the lipid profile.
adaptation1.11: Controlling BMI and blood sugar levels are needed to lessen future large blood vessel problems regardless of antibody status.

51.question: What is islet cell antibody group?

24850140.Title: Amniotic fluid RNA gene expression profiling provides insights into the phenotype of Turner syndrome

abstract.1: Turner syndrome is a sex chromosome aneuploidy with characteristic malformations.
abstract.2: Amniotic fluid, a complex biological material, could contribute to the understanding of Turner syndrome pathogenesis.
abstract.3: In this pilot study, global gene expression analysis of cell-free RNA in amniotic fluid supernatant was utilized to identify specific genes/organ systems that may play a role in Turner syndrome pathophysiology.
abstract.4: Cell-free RNA from amniotic fluid of five mid-trimester Turner syndrome fetuses and five euploid female fetuses matched for gestational age was extracted, amplified, and hybridized onto Affymetrix(®) U133 Plus 2.0 arrays.
abstract.5: Significantly differentially regulated genes were identified using paired t tests.
abstract.6: Biological interpretation was performed using Ingenuity Pathway Analysis and BioGPS gene expression atlas.
abstract.7: There were 470 statistically significantly differentially expressed genes identified.
abstract.8: They were widely distributed across the genome.
abstract.9: XIST was significantly down-regulated (p < 0.0001); SHOX was not differentially expressed.
abstract.10: One of the most highly represented organ systems was the hematologic/immune system, distinguishing the Turner syndrome transcriptome from other aneuploidies we previously studied.
abstract.11: Manual curation of the differentially expressed gene list identified genes of possible pathologic significance, including NFATC3, IGFBP5, and LDLR.
abstract.12: Transcriptomic differences in the amniotic fluid of Turner syndrome fetuses are due to genome-wide dysregulation.
abstract.13: The hematologic/immune system differences may play a role in early-onset autoimmune dysfunction.
abstract.14: Other genes identified with possible pathologic significance are associated with cardiac and skeletal systems, which are known to be affected in females with Turner syndrome.
abstract.15: The discovery-driven approach described here may be useful in elucidating novel mechanisms of disease in Turner syndrome.

adaptation1.1: Turner syndrome is a condition where there is an abnormal number of chromosomes (genetic material).
adaptation1.2: Amniotic fluid, the fluid surrounding a fetus, could contribute to the understanding of Turner syndrome development.
adaptation1.3: In this pilot study, gene expression analysis of cell-free RNA (genetic material to create proteins) in amniotic fluid was analyzed. The fluid was evaluated to identify genes/organ systems that may play a role in Turner syndrome development.
adaptation1.4: Cell-free RNA from amniotic fluid of five mid-trimester Turner syndrome fetuses and five control female fetuses was extracted.
adaptation1.5: Significantly differentially (functionally unique) regulated genes were identified.
adaptation1.6: Biological interpretation was performed to determine gene expression.
adaptation1.7: There were 470 statistically significantly differentially expressed genes identified.
adaptation1.8: They were widely distributed across the genome.
adaptation1.9: XIST was significantly down-regulated (decreased in activity). SHOX was not differentially expressed.
adaptation1.10: One of the most highly represented organ systems was the hematologic (blood) and immune system.
adaptation1.11: Organization of the differentially expressed gene list identified genes of possible disease development significance.
adaptation1.12: Transcriptomic (RNA) differences in the amniotic fluid of Turner syndrome fetuses are due to genome-wide dysregulation.
adaptation1.13: The hematologic/immune system differences may play a role in early-onset autoimmune dysfunction (in which infection-fighting cells attack healthy cells).
adaptation1.14: Other genes identified with possible pathologic (harmful) significance were associated with cardiac (heart) and skeletal systems. These systems are known to be affected in females with Turner syndrome.
adaptation1.15: This data may be useful in identifying how Turner syndrome develops.

24932682.Title: Human 45,X fibroblast transcriptome reveals distinct differentially expressed genes including long noncoding RNAs potentially associated with the pathophysiology of Turner syndrome

abstract.1: Turner syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality characterized by the absence of whole or part of the X chromosome in females.
abstract.2: This X aneuploidy condition is associated with a diverse set of clinical phenotypes such as gonadal dysfunction, short stature, osteoporosis and Type II diabetes mellitus, among others.
abstract.3: These phenotypes differ in their severity and penetrance among the affected individuals.
abstract.4: Haploinsufficiency for a few X linked genes has been associated with some of these disease phenotypes.
abstract.5: RNA sequencing can provide valuable insights to understand molecular mechanism of disease process.
abstract.6: In the current study, we have analysed the transcriptome profiles of human untransformed 45,X and 46,XX fibroblast cells and identified differential expression of genes in these two karyotypes.
abstract.7: Functional analysis revealed that these differentially expressing genes are associated with bone differentiation, glucose metabolism and gonadal development pathways.
abstract.8: We also report differential expression of lincRNAs in X monosomic cells.
abstract.9: Our observations provide a basis for evaluation of cellular and molecular mechanism(s) in the establishment of Turner syndrome phenotypes.

adaptation1.1: Turner syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality. The disease is characterized by the absence of the whole or part of the X chromosome in females.
adaptation1.2: This X aneuploidy condition, or condition of having abnormal number of chromosomes, is associated with a diverse set of clinical phenotypes. These phenotypes, or outward characteristics, include ovary dysfunction, short stature, brittle bones, and Type II diabetes mellitus.
adaptation1.3: These phenotypes differ in their severity and penetrance (extent) among those with the syndrome.
adaptation1.4: Haploinsufficiency, or when one copy of a gene is deleted, for a few X linked genes has been associated with some of these disease phenotypes.
adaptation1.5: RNA (special genetic material to create proteins) quantification can provide valuable insights to understand how these diseases form.
adaptation1.6: This study analyzed RNA profiles of human 45,X (abnormal) and 46,XX (normal) cells. This study identified differential (unique function) expression of genes in these two chromosomal types.
adaptation1.7: Analysis revealed that these differentially expressing genes are associated with bone differentiation, glucose metabolism, and gonadal development pathways.
adaptation1.8: This study also reported differential expression of non-coding RNAs (RNAs that cannot be transformed into proteins) in X cells with abnormal chromosome count.
adaptation1.9: This study provides a basis for evaluation of cellular and molecular mechanism(s) in the establishment of Turner syndrome phenotypes.

25535777.Title: Detection of Turner Syndrome by quantitative PCR of SHOX and VAMP7 genes

abstract.1: Turner Syndrome (TS) is an unfavorable genetic condition with a prevalence of 1:2500 in newborn girls.
abstract.2: Prompt and effective diagnosis is very important to appropriately monitor the comorbidities.
abstract.3: The aim of the present study was to propose a feasible and practical molecular diagnostic tool for newborn screening by quantifying the gene dosage of the SHOX, VAMP7, XIST, UBA1, and SRY genes by quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) in individuals with a diagnosis of complete X monosomy, as well as those with TS variants, and then compare the results to controls without chromosomal abnormalities.
abstract.4: According to our results, the most useful markers for these chromosomal variants were the genes found in the pseudoautosomic regions 1 and 2 (PAR1 and PAR2), because differences in gene dosage (relative quantification) between groups were more evident in SHOX and VAMP7 gene expression.
abstract.5: Therefore, we conclude that these markers are useful for early detection in aneuploidies involving sex chromosomes.

adaptation1.1: Turner Syndrome (TS) is a genetic condition found in 1 out of every 2500 newborn girls. Turner syndrome is a condition where there is an abnormal amount of chromosomes (genetic material).
adaptation1.2: Prompt and effective diagnosis is very important to appropriately monitor the comorbidities (two or more diseases in one patient).
adaptation1.3: The aim of the study was to propose a feasible and practical diagnostic tool for newborn screening. The screening would be completed by quantifying (measuring) the dosage of specific genes in individuals with a diagnosis of complete X monosomy and TS variants. The gene doses would be compared to controls without chromosomal abnormalities. Monosomy indicates there is an absence of one member of a chromosome pair; instead of 46 chromosomes in each cell of the body, there is 45.
adaptation1.4: Study results showed the most useful indicators for these chromosomal variants were the genes found in the pseudoautosomic regions 1 and 2 (PAR1 and PAR2).
adaptation1.5: The authors concluded that these markers are useful for early detection in chromosomal imbalances, specifically those involving sex chromosomes.

28627089.Title: Analysis of PTPN22, ZFAT and MYO9B polymorphisms in Turner Syndrome and risk of autoimmune disease

abstract.1: Turner syndrome (TS) is one of the most common sexual chromosome abnormalities and is clearly associated with an increased risk of autoimmune diseases, particularly thyroid disease and coeliac disease (CD).
abstract.2: Single-nucleotide polymorphism analyses have been shown to provide correlative evidence that specific genes are associated with autoimmune disease.
abstract.3: Our aim was to study the functional polymorphic variants of PTPN22 and ZFAT in relation to thyroid disease and those of MYO9B in relation to CD.
abstract.4: A cross-sectional comparative analysis was performed on Mexican mestizo patients with TS and age-matched healthy females.
abstract.5: Our data showed that PTPN22 C1858T (considered a risk variant) is not associated with TS (X2 = 3.50, p = .61, and OR = 0.33 [95% CI = 0.10-1.10]).
abstract.6: Also, ZFAT was not associated with TS (X2 = 1.2, p = .28, and OR = 1.22 [95% CI = 0.84-1.79]).
abstract.7: However, for the first time, rs2305767 MYO9B was revealed to have a strong association with TS (X2 = 58.6, p = .0001, and OR = 10.44 [95% C = 5.51-19.80]), supporting a high level of predisposition to CD among TS patients.
abstract.8: This report addresses additional data regarding the polymorphic variants associated with autoimmune disease, one of the most common complications in TS.

adaptation1.1: Turner syndrome (TS) is one of the most common sexual chromosome abnormalities. TS is associated with an increased risk of autoimmune diseases (in which immune cells attack healthy cells), particularly metabolism-affecting thyroid disease and coeliac disease (CD)--gluten sensitivity.
adaptation1.2: Genetic analyses have provided evidence that correlates specific genes with autoimmune diseases.
adaptation1.3: This report aimed to study the genetic variants of PTPN22 and ZFAT (protein-coding genes) in relation to thyroid disease. Additionally, this study evaluated the variants (gene types) of MYO9B (another protein-coding gene) to CD.
adaptation1.4: An analysis was performed on Mexican, mixed heritage patients with TS. These patients were age-matched to healthy females.
adaptation1.5: Data showed that PTPN22 C1858T, a PTPN22 variant, is not associated with TS.
adaptation1.6: Also, ZFAT was not associated with TS.
adaptation1.7: However, rs2305767 MYO9B, a MYO9B variant, was revealed to have a strong association with TS. This suggests patients with this variant have increased susceptibility to CD among TS patients.
adaptation1.8: This report addresses additional data regarding the genetic variants associated with autoimmune disease. Autoimmune disease is one of the most common complications found in TS patients.

29973620.Title: Assessment of the key regulatory genes and their Interologs for Turner Syndrome employing network approach

abstract.1: Turner Syndrome (TS) is a condition where several genes are affected but the molecular mechanism remains unknown.
abstract.2: Identifying the genes that regulate the TS network is one of the main challenges in understanding its aetiology.
abstract.3: Here, we studied the regulatory network from manually curated genes reported in the literature and identified essential proteins involved in TS.
abstract.4: The power-law distribution analysis showed that TS network carries scale-free hierarchical fractal attributes.
abstract.5: This organization of the network maintained the self-ruled constitution of nodes at various levels without having centrality-lethality control systems.
abstract.6: Out of twenty-seven genes culminating into leading hubs in the network, we identified two key regulators (KRs) i.e. KDM6A and BDNF.
abstract.7: These KRs serve as the backbone for all the network activities.
abstract.8: Removal of KRs does not cause its breakdown, rather a change in the topological properties was observed.
abstract.9: Since essential proteins are evolutionarily conserved, the orthologs of selected interacting proteins in C. elegans, cat and macaque monkey (lower to higher level organisms) were identified.
abstract.10: We deciphered three important interologs i.e. KDM6A-WDR5, KDM6A-ASH2L and WDR5-ASH2L that form a triangular motif.
abstract.11: In conclusion, these KRs and identified interologs are expected to regulate the TS network signifying their biological importance.

adaptation1.1: Turner Syndrome (TS) is a condition where several genes are affected. However, how this occurs remains unknown. Turner syndrome is a condition where there is an abnormal amount of chromosomes (genetic material).
adaptation1.2: Identifying the genes that regulate the TS network is one of the main challenges in understanding its cause.
adaptation1.3: This study evaluated the regulatory network of genes reported in scientific literature and identified essential proteins involved in TS.
adaptation1.4: A statistical evaluation was completed to model a TS network.
adaptation1.6: Out of twenty-seven genes, the authors identified two key regulators (KRs) i.e. KDM6A and BDNF.
adaptation1.7: These KRs serve as the backbone for all the network activities.
adaptation1.8: Removal of KRs does not cause its breakdown, rather a change in the network properties was observed.
adaptation1.9: Essential (necessary) proteins are evolutionarily conserved (kept). Because of this, genes of selected interacting proteins in C. elegans, cat, and macaque monkey were identified.
adaptation1.10: The authors deciphered three important interologs, interactions between pairs of proteins.
adaptation1.11: In conclusion, these KRs and identified interologs are expected to regulate the TS network. This data demonstrates their biological importance.

30779428.Title: How do genes that escape from X-chromosome inactivation contribute to Turner syndrome?

abstract.1: X-chromosome inactivation generally results in dosage equivalence for expression of X-linked genes between 46,XY males and 46,XX females.
abstract.2: The 20-30% of genes that escape silencing are thus candidates for having a role in the phenotype of Turner syndrome.
abstract.3: Understanding which genes escape from silencing, and how they avoid this chromosome-wide inactivation is therefore an important step toward understanding Turner Syndrome.
abstract.4: We have examined the mechanism of escape using a previously reported knock-in of a BAC containing the human escape gene RPS4X in mouse.
abstract.5: We now demonstrate that escape from inactivation for RPS4X is already established by embryonic Day 9.5, and that both silencing and escape are faithfully maintained across the lifespan.
abstract.6: No overt abnormalities were observed for transgenic mice up to 1 year of age despite robust transcription of the human RPS4X gene with no detectable downregulation of the mouse homolog.
abstract.7: However, there was no significant increase in protein levels, suggesting translational compensation in the mouse.
abstract.8: Finally, while many of the protein-coding genes have been assessed for their inactivation status, less is known about the X-linked RNA genes, and we propose that for many microRNA genes their inactivation status can be predicted as they are intronic to genes for which the inactivation status is known.

adaptation1.1: X-chromosome inactivation generally results in gene expression equivalence of X-linked genes between 46,XY males and 46,XX females.
