abstract.2: The focus here is on the role of clinical neurophysiologic and psychophysical tests in the diagnosis, differential diagnosis, and pathophysiological mechanisms of definite trigeminal neuropathic pain and other chronic orofacial pain conditions (excluding headache and temporomandibular disorders).
abstract.3: The International Classification of Headache Disorders 2018 classifies these facial pain disorders under the heading Painful cranial neuropathies and other facial pains.
abstract.4: In addition to unambiguous painful posttraumatic or postherpetic trigeminal neuropathies, burning mouth syndrome, persistent idiopathic facial and dental pain, and trigeminal neuralgia have also been identified with neurophysiologic and quantitative sensory testing to involve the nervous system.
abstract.5: Despite normal clinical examination, these all include clusters of patients with evidence for either peripheral or central nervous system pathology compatible with the subclinical end of a continuum of trigeminal neuropathic pain conditions.
abstract.6: Useful tests in the diagnostic process include electroneuromyography with specific needle, neurography techniques for the inferior alveolar and infraorbital nerves, brain stem reflex recordings (blink reflex with stimulation of the supraorbital, infraorbital, mental, and lingual nerves; jaw jerk; masseter silent period), evoked potential recordings, and quantitative sensory testing.
abstract.7: Habituation of the blink reflex and evoked potential responses to repeated stimuli evaluate top-down inhibition, and navigated transcranial magnetic stimulation allows the mapping of reorganization within the motor cortex in chronic neuropathic pain.
abstract.8: With systematic use of neurophysiologic and quantitative sensory testing, many of the current ambiguities in the diagnosis, classification, and understanding of chronic orofacial syndromes can be clarified for clinical practice and future research.

adaptation2.1: Orofacial pain syndromes are diseases known to cause pain in the face and mouth.
adaptation2.2: We discuss clinical examinations of the neural system that help identifying trigeminal nerve pain and other chronic facial pain conditions, but not headaches and problems with TMJ.
adaptation2.3: The International Classification of Headache Disorders 2018 classifies these facial pain disorders under the heading Painful cranial neuropathies and other facial pains.
adaptation2.4: Clinical examinations of the nervous system help identifying painful conditions of the trigeminal nerve, which carries sensation from the face to the brain. These conditions may start after an injury (posttraumatic trigeminal neuropathy) or herpes infection (postherpetic trigeminal neuropathy). Other related conditions are burning mouth syndrome (a burning, scalding, or tingling feeling in the mouth) and persistent idiopathic facial and dental pain, which is described as continuing pain in the face and teeth of unknown cause.
adaptation2.5: Even patients who appear normal on clinical examination have damage to their nervous system that can cause trigeminal nerve pain.
adaptation2.6: Diagnostic tests include recording electrical signals in the muscles (electroneuromyography), MRI of the nerves around the eyes, blink reflexes and jaw jerk when different nerves are stimulated, recording electrical signals after the nerves are stimulated, and tests for pain sensation.
adaptation2.7: Responsiveness of the blink reflex and records of the electrical signals after repeated nerve stimulation show if the response is suppressed. Medical imaging called navigated transcranial magnetic stimulation shows the areas of the brain that change due to chronic nerve pain.
adaptation2.8: Consistent use of the above tests will help understanding the chronic facial pain conditions.

32791919.Title: Concomitant continuous pain in patients with trigeminal neuralgia is associated with trigeminal nerve root atrophy

abstract.1: Introduction: Trigeminal neuralgia is an exemplary neuropathic pain condition characterized by paroxysmal electric-shock-like pain.
abstract.2: However, up to 50% of patients also experiences concomitant continuous pain.
abstract.3: In this neuroimaging study, we aimed to identify the specific anatomical features of trigeminal nerve root in patients with concomitant continuous pain.
abstract.4: Methods: We enrolled 73 patients with a definitive diagnosis of classical and idiopathic trigeminal neuralgia and 40 healthy participants.
abstract.5: The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia was independently confirmed by two clinicians.
abstract.6: Patients were grouped as patients with purely paroxysmal pain (45 patients) and patients also with concomitant continuous pain (28 patients).
abstract.7: All participants underwent a structured clinical examination and a 3T MRI with sequences dedicated to the anatomical study of the trigeminal nerve root, including volumetric study.
abstract.8: Images analysis was independently performed by two investigators, blinded to any clinical data.
abstract.9: Results: In most patients with concomitant continuous pain, this type of pain, described as burning, throbbing or aching, manifested at the disease onset.
abstract.10: Demographic and clinical variables did not differ between the two groups of patients; the frequency of neurovascular compression and nerve dislocation were similar.
abstract.11: Conversely, trigeminal nerve root atrophy was more severe in patients with concomitant continuous pain than in those with purely paroxysmal pain (p = 0.006).
abstract.12: Conclusions: Our clinical and neuroimaging study found that in patients with trigeminal neuralgia, concomitant continuous pain was associated with trigeminal nerve root atrophy, therefore suggesting that this type of pain is likely related to axonal loss and abnormal activity in denervated trigeminal second-order neurons.

adaptation2.1: Neuralgia is pain in the nerves that feels as bursts of electric-shock-like pain.
adaptation2.2: Up tp half of the patients also experience continuous pain.
adaptation2.3: We study the specific anatomical features of trigeminal nerve root (a part of the nerve that helps the face recognize pain, touch, heat and cold sensations, as well as chewing. We studied patients with continuous pain.
adaptation2.4: We studied 73 patients with trigeminal neuralgia (nerve pain) and 40 healthy participants.
adaptation2.5: The diagnosis of trigeminal neuralgia was independently confirmed by two clinicians.
adaptation2.6: 45 patients had only Burts of pain and 28 patients had continuous pain along with the bursts.
adaptation2.7: All patients had clinical examination and MRI.
adaptation2.8: Two specialists studied the images without losing at the clinical data.
adaptation2.9: In most patients with continuous pain it started as burning, throbbing or aching sensation.
adaptation2.10: The patients in the two groups and the frequency and location of the nerve damage signs in these patients were similar
adaptation2.11: On the contrary, patients with both the bursts and continuous pain had more atrophy ((decrease in size) of the trigeminal nerve than the patients with bursts only.
adaptation2.12: Clinical examination of patients with trigeminal nerve pain and their medical images show that patients who experienced continuous pain along with pain bursts lost some nerve tissues. This type of pain is related to wrong signaling in the nerve that lost tissues.

32918059.Title: Clinical presentations on a facial pain clinic

abstract.1: Introduction: The complex nature of facial pain conditions creates a diagnostic challenge which may necessitate specialist referral.
abstract.2: Aim: To identify the case mix presenting to a specialist tertiary care facial pain clinic.
abstract.3: Methods: A retrospective review of 112 patient records was undertaken.
abstract.4: Trends in provisional diagnoses from referrers and the correlation to diagnoses made following specialist consultation were reviewed.
abstract.5: Results: The most common provisional diagnoses recorded in referral letters were painful temporomandibular disorders, trigeminal neuralgia and persistent idiopathic facial pain (PIFP).
abstract.6: Over a quarter of referrals did not include a provisional diagnosis.
abstract.7: Following assessment, only one case was not given a definitive diagnosis and no patients were diagnosed with PIFP.
abstract.8: A causative factor was identified in all the initially queried PIFP cases, and painful post-traumatic trigeminal neuropathic pain was found in multiple patients.
abstract.9: Conclusions: Painful post-traumatic trigeminal neuropathic pain should be considered if pain onset coincides with dental treatment or other traumatic events.
abstract.10: PIFP is a rare facial pain diagnosis and may be over-diagnosed by dental and medical practitioners.
abstract.11: It is important to systematically exclude other causes before reaching this diagnosis.
abstract.12: This will facilitate effective treatment, manage patient expectations and potentially reduce unnecessary referrals.

adaptation2.1: Facial pain may be hard to recognize and a specialist might need to examine the patient.
adaptation2.2: The study's aim was to identify the mix of patient cases at a specialist facial pain clinic.
adaptation2.3: We reviewed the records of 112 patients who visited the specialists at the facial pain clinic.
adaptation2.4: We compared the reasons for specialist consultation  given by the primary doctors to the diagnoses made by the specialists.
adaptation2.5: Most often the primary doctors thought the patients' pain was caused by problems with the  temporomandibular joints that connect the lower jaw to the skull; pain in the trigeminal nerve that sends signals about sensations in the face to the brain; and other facial pain.
adaptation2.6: Over a quarter of patients referred to the cliniic had no diagnosis.
adaptation2.7: The specialist could not diagnose only one patient and have not diagnosed any patients with unspecified facial pain.
adaptation2.8: The specialists found causes of all previously unspecified facial pain. Many patients had trigeminal nerve pain following an injury (Painful post-traumatic trigeminal neuropathic pain ).
adaptation2.9: Painful post-traumatic trigeminal neuropathic pain should be considered if pain started after dental treatment or injury.
adaptation2.10: Unspecified facial pain is rare and may be overused by dentists and physicians.
adaptation2.11: All other causes should be excluded before diagnosis of the unspecified facial pain.
adaptation2.12: This will improve treatment and patients' expectations. It may reduce unnecessary referrals.

33185371.Title: Use of Radiofrequency Ablation for the Management of Facial Pain: A Systematic Review

abstract.1: Background: Neuropathic facial pain occurs due to pathologic dysfunctions of a nerve responsible for mediating sensory fibers to the head.
abstract.2: Surgical interventions, in cases of failed medical therapy, include microvascular decompression, radiofrequency (RF) ablation, percutaneous balloon decompression, and stereotactic radiosurgery.
abstract.3: In this review, we focused on RF ablation as a treatment for chronic facial pain.
abstract.4: Objectives: The objective of this review was to summarize available evidence behind RF ablation for facial pain, including pain outcome measures, secondary outcomes, and complications.
abstract.5: Study design: Systematic review.
abstract.6: Setting: This systematic review examined studies that applied the use of RF ablation for management of facial pain.
abstract.7: Methods: This systematic review was reported following the guidelines outlined in the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA).
abstract.8: Two reviewers independently scored the methodological quality of the selected studies.
abstract.9: Due to heterogeneity of studies, a best-evidence synthesis of the available prognostic factors was provided.
abstract.10: Results: We reviewed 44 studies and assessed their short- and long-term pain relief measurements, as well as secondary outcomes including patient satisfaction, quality of life improvements, decrease in oral medication use, and recurrence rates.
abstract.11: Maximal pain relief was achieved in treatment groups using combined continuous radiofrequency (CRF) and pulsed radiofrequency (PRF) therapies, followed by CRF therapy alone and finally PRF therapy alone.
abstract.12: All treatment regimens improved secondary outcomes.
abstract.13: Common complications of treatment included facial numbness, masseter weakness, cheek hematomas, diminished corneal reflex, and dry eyes.
abstract.14: Limitations: A large variability in definitions of trigeminal neuralgia, RF technique, and patient selection bias was observed in our selected cohort of studies.
abstract.15: In addition, there was a paucity of strong longitudinal randomized controlled trials and prospective studies.
abstract.16: Conclusions: This systematic review found evidence that RF ablation is efficient in treating patients with facial pain, as well as in improving quality of life and reducing oral medication use.
abstract.17: Maximal pain control is achieved using combined CRF and PRF therapy.
abstract.18: Complications are uncommon and include facial numbness, masseter weakness, cheek hematomas, diminished corneal reflex, and dry eyes.

adaptation2.1: Neural facial pain is caused by the nerves that transmit sensation to the head.
adaptation2.2: If medicines do not help, surgery may be used. Surgeries relieve compressed nerves (microvascular decompression); or shrink tissues using radio waves (radiofrequency (RF) ablation) or local radiation (stereotactic radiosurgery). Other surgeries prevent the nerve from transmitting signals (percutaneous balloon decompression.)
adaptation2.3: We discuss using radio waves (RF ablation) to treat chronic facial pain.
adaptation2.4: We summarize what is known about RF ablation for facial pain, including treatment results and complications.
adaptation2.10: We summarize the pain relief results, patient satisfaction, quality of life, decrease in the drug use, and how often the pain returns.
adaptation2.11: Combining two different types of radio wave treatments (continuous radiofrequency (CRF) and pulsed radiofrequency (PRF))reduced pain the best.  CRF treatment was second best, followed by PRF.
adaptation2.12: All treatments improved patient satisfaction and quality of life, and decreased drug use and return of the pain.
adaptation2.13: Common complications of the treatment included facial numbness,  weakness of facial muscles, bruised cheeks, failure to blink when the eye is touched, and dry eyes.
adaptation2.16: We conclude that radio wave treatment (RF ablation) is efficient in treating patients with facial pain. It also improves quality of life and reduces drug use.
adaptation2.17: Maximal pain control is achieved using combined CRF and PRF therapy.
adaptation2.18: Complications of the treatment were not frequent and included facial numbness,  weakness of facial muscles, bruised cheeks, failure to blink when the eye is touched, and dry eyes.

33853065.Title: What Are the Results and the Prognostic Factors of Motor Cortex Stimulation in Patients with Facial Pain? A Systematic Review of the Literature

abstract.1: Introduction: Facial pain (FP) is a type of neuropathic pain which recognizes both central and peripheral causes.
abstract.2: It can be difficult to treat because it can often become resistant to pharmacological treatments.
abstract.3: Motor Cortex Stimulation (MCS) has been used in selected cases, but the correct indications of MCS in FP have not been fully established.
abstract.4: Here we systematically reviewed the literature regarding MCS in FP analysing the results of this technique and studying the possible role of different factors in the prognosis of these patients.
abstract.5: Methods: A literature search was performed through different databases (PubMed, Scopus, and Embase) according to PRISMA guidelines using the following terms in any possible combination: "facial pain" or "trigeminal" or "anaesthesia dolorosa" and "motor cortex stimulation."
abstract.6: Results: 111 articles were reviewed, and 12 studies were included in the present analysis for a total of 108 patients.
abstract.7: Overall, at latest follow-up (FU), 70.83% of patients responded to MCS.
abstract.8: The preoperative VAS significantly decreased at the latest FU (8.83 ± 1.17 and 4.31 ± 2.05, respectively; p < 0.0001).
abstract.9: Younger age (p = 0.0478) and a peripheral FP syndrome (p = 0.0006) positively affected the definitive implantation rate on univariate analysis.
abstract.10: Younger age emerged as a factor strongly associated to a higher probability to go to a definitive MCS implant on multivariate analysis (p = 0.0415).
abstract.11: Conclusion: Our results evidenced the effectiveness of MCS in treating FP.
abstract.12: Moreover, the younger age emerged as a positive prognostic factor for definitive implantation.
abstract.13: Further studies with longer FU are needed to better evaluate the long-term results of MCS.

adaptation2.1: Facial pain is nerve pain caused by nerves in the spinal cord and outside the spinal cord and brain.
adaptation2.2: It can be difficult to treat because pain relieve drugs may stop working.
adaptation2.3: Motor Cortex Stimulation (MCS), surgical stimulation of the nerves, is sometimes used, but it is not known yet when to use it for facial pain.
adaptation2.4: We review what is known about treating patients with facial pain using MCS and the outcomes of the treatment.
adaptation2.6: We found information about 108 patients.
adaptation2.7: MCS helped almost three quarters of the patients.
adaptation2.8: The patients felt their pain was reduced almost to half of the pain they felt before surgery.
adaptation2.9: The treatment was more effective in younger patients and those with pain on the side of the face.
adaptation2.10: Younger patients were more likely to get MCS implanted devices
adaptation2.11: MCS is an effective treatment for facial pain.
adaptation2.12: Younger patients were more likely to get permanent implanted devices.

34656508.Title: Surgical Management of Post-Traumatic Trigeminal Neuralgia - Case Report and Review of the Literature

abstract.1: Post-traumatic trigeminal neuralgia (PTTN), also known as anesthesia dolorosa, is at times a debilitating affliction, but remains a condition with minimal research and without definitive treatment, specifically in the periorbital and malar regions.
abstract.2: Below we present a case of PTTN in a patient with historic facial trauma who has successfully achieved resolution of pain.
abstract.3: We describe diagnostic and therapeutic anesthesia blocks and ablative procedures targeting the zygomaticofacial and zygomaticotemporal nerves.
abstract.4: We promote awareness for the procedures and the potential large impact on the oral and maxillofacial surgery community when treating those suffering from facial pain.
abstract.5: Finally, we present an algorithm that can aid surgeons in diagnosing and treating patients with PTTN.

adaptation2.1: Post-traumatic trigeminal neuralgia (PTTN), also known as anesthesia dolorosa, refers to the pain in the trigeminal nerve, a three-part nerve in the head that provides sensation. PTTN is a crippling pain that has no established treatments, specifically for the pain around the eyes and back teeth.
adaptation2.2: We describe how trigeminal nerve pain was treated in a patient who had it due to an old injury to his face.
adaptation2.3: We describe surgery and treatment that blocked sensation in the facial nerves around the temples and cheek bones.
adaptation2.4: This treatment could be used by dental surgeons who treat patients with facial pain.
adaptation2.5: We also describe a decision support tool for recognizing and treating PTTN.

34753868.Title: An Update on the Diagnosis, Treatment, and Management of Occipital Neuralgia

abstract.1: The current understanding of ON is that it causes neuropathic pain in the distribution of the greater occipital nerve, the lesser occipital nerve, the third occipital nerve or a combination of the 3.
abstract.2: It is currently a subset of headaches although there is some debate if ON should be its own condition.
abstract.3: Occipital neuralgia causes chronic, sharp, stabbing pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears that can radiate to the front of the head.
abstract.4: Diagnosis is typically clinical and patients present with intermittent, painful episodes associated with the occipital region and the nerves described above.
abstract.5: Most cases are unilateral pain, however bilateral pain can be present and the pain can radiate to the frontal region and face.
abstract.6: Physical examination is the first step in management of this disease and patients may demonstrate tenderness over the greater occipital and lesser occipital nerves.
abstract.7: Anesthetics like 1% to 2% lidocaine or 0.25% to 0.5% bupivacaine can be used to block these nerves and anti-inflammatory drugs like corticosteroids can be used in combination to prevent compressive symptoms.
abstract.8: Other treatments like botulinum toxin and radiofrequency ablation have shown promise and require more research.
abstract.9: Surgical decompression through resection of the obliquus capitis inferior is the definitive treatment however there are significant risks associated with this procedure.

adaptation2.1: Occipital Neuralgia is the pain in the occipital nerves, the nerves that run from the top of the spinal cord up in the back of the head.
adaptation2.2: It is considered a type of headaches, but some doctors suggest pain in the nerves in the back of the head is a different problem.
adaptation2.3: Occipital neuralgia is a continuing, sharp, stabbing pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears. It can also extend to the front of the head.
adaptation2.4: The doctors decide the patients have the disease if the pain in the back of the patients' heads comes and goes.
adaptation2.5: Most patients have pain on one side of their head, but the pain could also be on both sides and extend to the front of the head and face.
adaptation2.6: When the doctors examine the patients, the patients' skin over the nerves in the back of the head  may be tender.
adaptation2.7: Drugs like lidocaine can block the feeling of pain in these nerves. Drugs that reduce inflammation, such as steroids may be added to keep the signs from happening.
adaptation2.8: Other treatments like botulinum toxin that blocks the nerve signals and radiofrequency ablation that uses radio waves to shrink tissues may be promising but need to be studied more.
adaptation2.9: Surgeons may permanently relieve the pressure on the nerve by removing a small muscle between the neck vertebra at the base of the head, but this treatment is risky.

34962970.Title: Longitudinal dynamics of SARS-CoV-2-specific cellular and humoral immunity after natural infection or BNT162b2 vaccination

abstract.1: The timing of the development of specific adaptive immunity after natural SARS-CoV-2 infection, and its relevance in clinical outcome, has not been characterized in depth.
abstract.2: Description of the long-term maintenance of both cellular and humoral responses elicited by real-world anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccination is still scarce.
abstract.3: Here we aimed to understand the development of optimal protective responses after SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination.
abstract.4: We performed an early, longitudinal study of S1-, M- and N-specific IFN-Î³ and IL-2 T cell immunity and anti-S total and neutralizing antibodies in 88 mild, moderate or severe acute COVID-19 patients.
abstract.5: Moreover, SARS-CoV-2-specific adaptive immunity was also analysed in 234 COVID-19 recovered subjects, 28 uninfected BNT162b2-vaccinees and 30 uninfected healthy controls.
abstract.6: Upon natural infection, cellular and humoral responses were early and coordinated in mild patients, while weak and inconsistent in severe patients.
abstract.7: The S1-specific cellular response measured at hospital arrival was an independent predictive factor against severity.
abstract.8: In COVID-19 recovered patients, four to seven months post-infection, cellular immunity was maintained but antibodies and neutralization capacity declined.
abstract.9: Finally, a robust Th1-driven immune response was developed in uninfected BNT162b2-vaccinees.
abstract.10: Three months post-vaccination, the cellular response was comparable, while the humoral response was consistently stronger, to that measured in COVID-19 recovered patients.
abstract.11: Thus, measurement of both humoral and cellular responses provides information on prognosis and protection from infection, which may add value for individual and public health recommendations.

adaptation3.1: The timing of the development of immunity after natural SARS-CoV-2 infection has not been studied in depth.
adaptation3.2: Data about long-term immunity following anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccination is still scarce.
adaptation3.3: We studied the the development of the strongest protective immune responses after SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination.
adaptation3.4: We performed a long-term study of the immune responses and antibody blood levels in patients with mild, moderate or severe acute COVID-19 infection.
adaptation3.5: Immune response was also studied in 234 COVID-19 recovered subjects, 28 uninfected BNT162b2 (Pfizer)-vaccinees and 30 uninfected healthy unvaccinated people.
adaptation3.6: During natural infection, immune responses were early and coordinated in patients with mild COVID-19, while the immune responses were weak and inconsistent in patients with severe illness.
adaptation3.7: Immunity in patients was measured at hospital arrival. Patients with a strong cellular immune response against the virus spike protein had a less severe illness.
adaptation3.8: In COVID-19 recovered patients, four to seven months post-infection, cellular immunity was maintained but antibody blood levels and the capacity of the antibodies to block the virus declined.
adaptation3.9: In uninfected BNT162b2-vaccinees, a strong cellular immune response developed.
adaptation3.10: Three months post-vaccination, the cellular immune response was comparable to that measured in patients who recovered from COVID-19. In vaccinated people, the antibody response was consistently stronger to that measured in COVID-19 recovered patients.
adaptation3.11: Our study of the cellular immune response and the antibody response provides information about protection from infection and the likelihood of developing severe infection. This information could be used to influence public health recommendations.

34976499.Title: Waning of Anti-spike Antibodies in AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) Vaccinated Healthcare Providers: A Prospective Longitudinal Study

abstract.1: Introduction: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccines are nothing short of a miracle story halting the pandemic across the globe.
abstract.2: Nearly half of the global population has received at least one dose.
abstract.3: Nevertheless, antibody levels in vaccinated people have shown waning, and breakthrough infections have occurred.
abstract.4: Our study aims to measure antibody kinetics following AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) vaccination six months after the second dose and the factors affecting the kinetics.
abstract.5: Materials and methods: We conducted a prospective longitudinal study monitoring for six months after the second of two AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) vaccine doses in healthcare professionals and healthcare facility employees at Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research (included doctors, nurses, paramedical staff, security and sanitary workers, and students).
abstract.6: Two 0.5-mL doses of the vaccine were administered intramuscularly, containing 5 x 1010 viral particles 28 to 30 days between doses.
abstract.7: We collected blood samples one month after the first dose (Round 1), one month after the second dose (Round 2), and six months after the second dose (Round 3).
abstract.8: We tested for immunoglobulin G (IgG) levels against the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) by chemiluminescence microparticle immunoassay.
abstract.9: We conducted a linear mixed model analysis to study the antibody kinetics and influencing factors.
abstract.10: Results: Our study included 122 participants (mean age, 41.5 years; 66 men, 56 women).
abstract.11: The geometric mean IgG titers were 138.01 binding antibody units (BAU)/mL in Round 1, 176.48 BAU/mL in Round 2, and 112.95 BAU/mL in Round 3.
abstract.12: Seven participants showed seroreversion, and 11 had breakthrough infections.
abstract.13: Eighty-six participants showed a substantial decline in antibody titer from Rounds 2 to 3.
abstract.14: Persons aged 45 or older had higher mean titer than people aged younger than 45 years.
abstract.15: Overweight and obese (BMI â‰¥ 25 kg/m2) had a higher mean titer than average or underweight persons.
abstract.16: The only significant predictor of IgG titers at six months was SARS-CoV-2 infection on mixed model analysis.
abstract.17: Conclusion: We found a substantial decline in antibody levels leading to seven cases of seroreversion in healthcare professionals who received the ChAdOx1 vaccine.
abstract.18: History of prior COVID-19 was the only significant factor in antibody levels at six months.
abstract.19: Seroreversion and breakthrough infection warrant further research into the optimal timing and potential benefits of booster doses of the AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) COVID-19 vaccine.

adaptation3.1: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccines are nothing short of a miracle story halting the pandemic across the globe.
adaptation3.2: Nearly half of the global population has received at least one dose.
adaptation3.3: Nevertheless, antibody blood levels in vaccinated people drop over time, and breakthrough infections have occurred.
adaptation3.4: We studied the trends in antibody blood levels six months after the second dose of the AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) AstraZeneca vaccine.
adaptation3.5: We conducted a 6 month study after the second of two AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) vaccine doses in healthcare professionals and healthcare facility employees at Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research. The study population included doctors, nurses, paramedical staff, security and sanitary workers, and students.
adaptation3.6: Two doses of the vaccine were injected into the upper arm, with 28 to 30 days between doses.
adaptation3.7: We collected blood samples one month after the first dose (Round 1), one month after the second dose (Round 2), and six months after the second dose (Round 3).
adaptation3.8: We measured blood levels of antibodies against the spike protein of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
adaptation3.9: We used statistical methods to measure the change in antibody blood levels over time.
adaptation3.10: Our study included 122 participants (mean age, 41.5 years; 66 men, 56 women).
adaptation3.11: Antibody blood levels were 138.01 in Round 1, increased to 1,176.48 in Round 2, and dropped to 112.95 in Round 3.
adaptation3.12: Seven participants showed a complete loss of measurable blood antibodies, and 11 had breakthrough infections.
adaptation3.13: Eighty-six participants showed a substantial decline in antibody levels from Rounds 2 to 3.
adaptation3.14: Persons aged 45 or older had higher antibody levels than people aged younger than 45 years.
adaptation3.15: Overweight and obese people (body mass index larger than 25) had higher antibody levels than average or underweight persons.
adaptation3.16: The only people who maintained high levels of antibodies at 6 months were in people who had been infected with SARS-CoV2.
adaptation3.17: We found a substantial decline in antibody levels leading to seven cases of loss of antibodies in healthcare professionals who received the ChAdOx1 vaccine.
adaptation3.18: A history of prior COVID-19 infection was the only significant reason for high antibody levels at six months.
adaptation3.19: More research needs to be conducted on the optimal timing and potential benefits of booster doses of the AZD1222 (ChAdOx1) COVID-19 vaccine to avoid breakthrough infections or loss of immunity.

35085224.Title: Effectiveness of a Third Dose of mRNA Vaccines Against COVID-19-Associated Emergency Department and Urgent Care Encounters and Hospitalizations Among Adults During Periods of Delta and Omicron Variant Predominance - VISION Network, 10 States, August 2021-January 2022

abstract.1: Estimates of COVID-19 mRNA vaccine effectiveness (VE) have declined in recent months because of waning vaccine induced immunity over time, possible increased immune evasion by SARS-CoV-2 variants, or a combination of these and other factors.
abstract.2: CDC recommends that all persons aged â‰¥12 years receive a third dose (booster) of an mRNA vaccine â‰¥5 months after receipt of the second mRNA vaccine dose and that immunocompromised individuals receive a third primary dose.
abstract.3: A third dose of BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech) COVID-19 vaccine increases neutralizing antibody levels, and three recent studies from Israel have shown improved effectiveness of a third dose in preventing COVID-19 associated with infections with the SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617.2 (Delta) variant.
abstract.4: Yet, data are limited on the real-world effectiveness of third doses of COVID-19 mRNA vaccine in the United States, especially since the SARS-CoV-2 B.1.1.529 (Omicron) variant became predominant in mid-December 2021.
abstract.5: The VISION Network examined VE by analyzing 222,772 encounters from 383 emergency departments (EDs) and urgent care (UC) clinics and 87,904 hospitalizations from 259 hospitals among adults aged â‰¥18 years across 10 states from August 26, 2021 to January 5, 2022.
abstract.6: Analyses were stratified by the period before and after the Omicron variant became the predominant strain (>50% of sequenced viruses) at each study site.
abstract.7: During the period of Delta predominance across study sites in the United States (August-mid-December 2021), VE against laboratory-confirmed COVID-19-associated ED and UC encounters was 86% 14-179 days after dose 2, 76% â‰¥180 days after dose 2, and 94% â‰¥14 days after dose 3.
abstract.8: Estimates of VE for the same intervals after vaccination during Omicron variant predominance were 52%, 38%, and 82%, respectively.
abstract.9: During the period of Delta variant predominance, VE against laboratory-confirmed COVID-19-associated hospitalizations was 90% 14-179 days after dose 2, 81% â‰¥180 days after dose 2, and 94% â‰¥14 days after dose 3.
abstract.10: During Omicron variant predominance, VE estimates for the same intervals after vaccination were 81%, 57%, and 90%, respectively.
abstract.11: The highest estimates of VE against COVID-19-associated ED and UC encounters or hospitalizations during both Delta- and Omicron-predominant periods were among adults who received a third dose of mRNA vaccine.
abstract.12: All unvaccinated persons should get vaccinated as soon as possible.
abstract.13: All adults who have received mRNA vaccines during their primary COVID-19 vaccination series should receive a third dose when eligible, and eligible persons should stay up to date with COVID-19 vaccinations.

adaptation3.1: It is estimated that the effectiveness of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines has declined in recent months. There are several possible reasons for this. Vaccine-induced immunity decreases over time. New strains of the SARS-CoV-2 virus can become resistant to the vaccine, a process called immune evasion. A combination of these two phenomena or other factors could also cause decreased vaccine effectiveness.
adaptation3.2: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all people 12 years and older receive a third booster shot of an mRNA vaccine 5 months or later after receiving the second primary shot. Patients with a weakened immune system should receive a third primary shot.
adaptation3.3: A third dose of the Pfizer vaccine (BNT162b2 COVID-19 vaccine) increases the blood level of antibodies that neutralize the virus and prevent infection. Three recent studies from Israel have shown that a third booster dose helps prevent COVID-19 caused by the Delta variant (SARS-CoV-2 B.1.617.2).
adaptation3.4: However, in the United States there is little data to prove the effectiveness of third booster shots to prevent COVID-19, especially since the Omicron variant (SARS-CoV-2 B.1.1.529) became the most common strain in mid-December 2021.
adaptation3.5: From August 26, 2021 to January 5, 2022, the VISION Network examined vaccine effectiveness among adults 18 and older across 10 states in the US by studying over 222,000 patients in 383 emergency departments and urgent care clinics, and over 87,000 hospitalized inpatients from 259 hospitals.
adaptation3.6: The analysis was split apart at each study site by looking at the periods before and after the Omicron strain became the most common strain.
adaptation3.7: During the time when the Delta strain was most common in the US (August to mid-December 2021), in emergency departments and urgent care clinics vaccine effectiveness in preventing infection was 86% effective 14-179 days after dose 2, dropped to 76% more than 180 days after dose 2, but increased up to 94% 14 days or more after dose 3.
adaptation3.8: When the Omicron strain was most common, vaccine effectiveness for the same time intervals was only 52%, 38%, and 82%, respectively.
adaptation3.9: In hospitalized patients, during the Delta strain period vaccine effectiveness was 90% 14-179 days after dose 2, 81% 180 days or longer after dose 2, and 94% 14 days or more after dose 3.
adaptation3.10: During the Omicron period, estimates for the same time intervals after vaccination were 81%, 57%, and 90%, respectively.
adaptation3.11: The highest estimates of vaccine effectiveness in both patient populations during both the Delta and Omicron periods were in adults who had received a third dose of mRNA vaccine.
adaptation3.12: Based on this data, we recommed that all unvaccinated persons should get vaccinated as soon as possible.
adaptation3.13: All adults who have received their first two doses of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines should receive a third dose as soon as they are eligible, and eligible persons should stay up to date with COVID-19 vaccinations and boosters.

35087066.Title: Extended interval BNT162b2 vaccination enhances peak antibody generation

abstract.1: The BNT162b2 vaccine is highly effective against COVID-19 infection and was delivered with a 3-week time interval in registration studies 1.
abstract.2: However, many countries extended this interval to accelerate population coverage with a single vaccine.
abstract.3: It is not known how immune responses are influenced by delaying the second dose.
abstract.4: We provide the assessment of immune responses in the first 14 weeks after standard or extended-interval BNT162b2 vaccination and show that delaying the second dose strongly boosts the peak antibody response by 3.5-fold in older people.
abstract.5: This enhanced antibody response may offer a longer period of clinical protection and delay the need for booster vaccination.
abstract.6: In contrast, peak cellular-specific responses were the strongest in those vaccinated on a standard 3-week vaccine interval.
abstract.7: As such, the timing of the second dose has a marked influence on the kinetics and magnitude of the adaptive immune response after mRNA vaccination in older people.

adaptation3.1: The BNT162b2 vaccine (Pfizer) is highly effective against COVID-19 infection. In registration studies, the two doses were delivered 3 weeks apart..
adaptation3.2: However, many countries extended the time between the first and second doses to maximize the number of people vaccinated with one dose.
adaptation3.3: It is not known how antibody responses or cellular immune responses are influenced by delaying the second dose.
adaptation3.4: We studied the immune response in the first 14 weeks after the standard 3-week interval or the extended interval BNT162b2 vaccination. We showed that delaying the second dose strongly boosts the peak antibody response by 3.5-fold in older people.
adaptation3.5: This enhanced antibody response may offer a longer period of protection against infection and delay the need for booster vaccination.
adaptation3.6: In contrast, peak cellular-specific responses were the strongest in those vaccinated on a standard 3-week vaccine interval.
adaptation3.7: The timing of the second dose has a strong influence on the antibody response after BNT162b2 vaccination in older people.

35123028.Title: Evaluation of Immunogenicity by Pseudovirus Neutralization Assays for Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Variants after Primary and Booster Immunization

abstract.1: Objectives: To determine the status of immune responses after primary and booster immunization for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) variants and evaluate the differences in disease-resistance based upon titers of neutralizing antibodies (NAbs) against the variants.
abstract.2: Methods: Participants aged 18 - 59 y received two doses of inactivated COVID-19 vaccine, 14 days apart, and a booster dose after 12 m.
abstract.3: Blood samples were collected before vaccination (baseline), 1 and 6 m after primary immunization, and at multiple instances within 21 d of booster dose.
abstract.4: NAbs against the spike protein of Wuhan-Hu-1 and three variants were measured using pseudovirus neutralization assays.
abstract.5: Results: Out of 400 enrolled participants, 387 completed visits scheduled within 6 m of the second dose, and 346 participated received the booster dose in the follow-up research.
abstract.6: After 1 m of primary immunization, geometric mean titers (GMTs) of NAbs peaked for Wuhan-Hu-1, while GMTs of other variants were < 30.
abstract.7: After 6 m of primary immunization, GMTs of NAbs against all strains were < 30.
abstract.8: After 3 d of booster immunization, GMTs were unaltered, seroconversion rates reached approximately 50% after 7 d, and GMTs of NAbs against all strains peaked at 14 d.
abstract.9: Conclusion: Two-dose of inactivated COVID-19 vaccine induced the formation of NAbs and memory-associated immune responses, and high titers of NAbs against the variants obtained after booster immunization may further improve the effectiveness of the vaccine.

adaptation3.1: We studied the immune response after primary and booster immunization for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) variants. We evaluated the differences in disease resistance based upon blood levels of neutralizing antibodies (antibodies that inactivate the virus) against the variants.
adaptation3.2: Participants aged 18 - 59 years old received two doses of inactivated COVID-19 vaccine, 14 days apart, and a booster dose after 12 months.
adaptation3.3: Blood samples were collected before vaccination, 1 and 6 months after primary immunization, and several times within 21 days of booster dose.
adaptation3.4: Neutralizing antibodies against the spike protein of the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant and three other variants were measured.
adaptation3.5: Out of 400 enrolled participants, 387 completed visits scheduled within 6 months of the second dose, and 346 participants received the booster dose in the follow-up research.
adaptation3.6: After 1 month of primary immunization, blood levels of neutralizing antibodies peaked for Wuhan-Hu-1, while blood levels against other variants were lower.
adaptation3.7: After 6 months of primary immunization, blood levels against all strains were reduced.
adaptation3.8: After 3 days of booster immunization, blood levels were unchanged. However, blood levels increased approximately 50% after 7 days, and peaked at 14 days for all strains.
adaptation3.9: Two doses of inactivated COVID-19 vaccine produced neutralizing antibodies and immunity, and high levels of neutralizing antibodies against the variants after booster immunization could further improve the effectiveness of the vaccine.

35131043.Title: Risk of infection, hospitalisation, and death up to 9 months after a second dose of COVID-19 vaccine: a retrospective, total population cohort study in Sweden

abstract.1: Background: Vaccine effectiveness against COVID-19 beyond 6 months remains incompletely understood.
abstract.2: We aimed to investigate the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccination against the risk of infection, hospitalisation, and death during the first 9 months after vaccination for the total population of Sweden.
abstract.3: Methods: This retrospective, total population cohort study was done using data from Swedish nationwide registers.
abstract.4: The cohort comprised all individuals vaccinated with two doses of ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, mRNA-1273, or BNT162b2, and matched unvaccinated individuals, with data on vaccinations and infections updated until Oct 4, 2021.
abstract.5: Two outcomes were evaluated.
abstract.6: The first was SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity from Jan 12 to Oct 4, 2021.
abstract.7: The second was severe COVID-19, defined as hospitalisation for COVID-19 or all-cause 30-day mortality after confirmed infection, from March 15 to Sept 28, 2021.
abstract.8: Findings: Between Dec 28, 2020, and Oct 4, 2021, 842 974 individuals were fully vaccinated (two doses), and were matched (1:1) to an equal number of unvaccinated individuals (total study cohort n=1 685 948).
abstract.9: For the outcome SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity, the vaccine effectiveness of BNT162b2 waned progressively over time, from 92% (95% CI 92 to 93; p<0Â·001) at 15-30 days, to 47% (39 to 55; p<0Â·001) at 121-180 days, and to 23% (-2 to 41; p=0Â·07) from day 211 onwards.
abstract.10: Waning was slightly slower for mRNA-1273, with a vaccine effectiveness of 96% (94 to 97; p<0Â·001) at 15-30 days and 59% (18 to 79; p=0Â·012) from day 181 onwards.
abstract.11: Waning was also slightly slower for heterologous ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 plus an mRNA vaccine, for which vaccine effectiveness was 89% (79 to 94; p<0Â·001) at 15-30 days and 66% (41 to 80; p<0Â·001) from day 121 onwards.
abstract.12: By contrast, vaccine effectiveness for homologous ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccine was 68% (52 to 79; p<0Â·001) at 15-30 days, with no detectable effectiveness from day 121 onwards (-19% [-98 to 28]; p=0Â·49).
abstract.13: For the outcome of severe COVID-19, vaccine effectiveness waned from 89% (82 to 93; p<0Â·001) at 15-30 days to 64% (44 to 77; p<0Â·001) from day 121 onwards.
abstract.14: Overall, there was some evidence for lower vaccine effectiveness in men than in women and in older individuals than in younger individuals.
abstract.15: Interpretation: We found progressively waning vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity across all subgroups, but the rate of waning differed according to vaccine type.
abstract.16: With respect to severe COVID-19, vaccine effectiveness seemed to be better maintained, although some waning became evident after 4 months.
abstract.17: The results strengthen the evidence-based rationale for administration of a third vaccine dose as a booster.

adaptation3.1: The effectiveness of a vaccine against COVID-19 6 months after vaccination is not fully understood.
adaptation3.2: We studied the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccination against the risk of infection, hospitalisation, and death during the first 9 months after vaccination for the total population of Sweden.
adaptation3.3: We took our data from Swedish nationwide registers.
adaptation3.4: The data were from all individuals vaccinated with two doses of ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 (AstraZeneca), mRNA-1273 (Moderna), or BNT162b2 (Pfizer) vaccines, and matched unvaccinated individuals, with data on vaccinations and infections updated until Oct 4, 2021.
adaptation3.5: Two outcomes were evaluated.
adaptation3.6: The first was SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity from Jan 12 to Oct 4, 2021.
adaptation3.7: The second was severe COVID-19, defined as hospitalisation for COVID-19 or death from any cause 30 days after confirmed infection, from March 15 to Sept 28, 2021.
adaptation3.8: Between Dec 28, 2020, and Oct 4, 2021, 842 974 individuals were fully vaccinated (two doses). We compared these individuals to an equal number of unvaccinated individuals. The total number of people studied was 1,685,948.
adaptation3.9: In patients who had SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity, the vaccine effectiveness of BNT162b2 dropped progressively over time, from 92% at 15-30 days after vaccination, to 47% at 121-180 days, and to 23% from day 211 onwards.
adaptation3.10: Reduced vaccine effectiveness was slightly slower for the mRNA-1273 vaccine, with a vaccine effectiveness of 96% at 15-30 days and 59% from day 181 onwards.
adaptation3.11: Reduction of vaccine effectiveness was also slightly slower for the combination of the ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccine plus an mRNA vaccine, for which vaccine effectiveness was 89% at 15-30 days and 66% from day 121 onwards.
adaptation3.12: By contrast, vaccine effectiveness for the ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 vaccine only (not combined with another vaccine) was 68% at 15-30 days, with no detectable effectiveness from day 121 onwards.
adaptation3.13: In patients who had severe COVID-19, vaccine effectiveness dropped from 89% at 15-30 days to 64% from day 121 onwards.
adaptation3.14: Overall, there was some evidence for lower vaccine effectiveness in men than in women and in older individuals than in younger individuals.
adaptation3.15: We found progressively reduced vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 infection of any severity across all subgroups of patients, but the rate of reduction differed according to vaccine type.
adaptation3.16: In patients who had severe COVID-19, vaccine effectiveness seemed to be better maintained, although some reduction became evident after 4 months.
adaptation3.17: Our study provides evidence that a third vaccine dose as a booster will improve immunity against COVID-19.

35132427.Title: Comparison of total and neutralizing SARS-CoV-2 spike antibodies against omicron and other variants in paired samples after two or three doses of mRNA vaccine

abstract.1: Recognizing that anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody levels wane over time following the 2-dose SARS-CoV-2 mRNA series, the FDA approved a booster dose for people greater than 12 years old.
abstract.2: Limited data exist on whether a booster dose of the mRNA vaccine results in greater antibody protection than the primary series.
abstract.3: We examined total and neutralizing antibodies to the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, and neutralizing antibodies against Washington-1 (WA-1) and variants of concern (VOC) including Beta, Delta and Omicron in a longitudinal cohort.
abstract.4: Healthcare workers (HWs) were included in the analysis if serum was collected 1) within 14-44 days post-dose2 of an mRNA SARS-CoV-2 vaccine (Timepoint 1, TP1), or 2) at least 8 months post-dose2 (Timepoint 2, TP2), or 3) within 14-44 days following mRNA booster (Timepoint 3, TP3).
abstract.5: HWs with prior covid-positive PCR were excluded.
abstract.6: We found that there is little to no neutralizing capability following a 2-dose mRNA vaccine series against the omicron variant, and neutralizing capacity to any variant strain tested has been lost by 8-months post two-dose vaccination series.
abstract.7: However, the mRNA booster series eliminates the immune escape observed by the omicron variant with the two-dose series.
abstract.8: Neutralizing titers were significantly higher for all variants post-boost compared to the titers post two-dose series.
abstract.9: The longitudinal nature of our cohort facilitated the analysis of paired samples pre and post boost, showing a greater than 15-fold increase in neutralization against omicron post-boost in these paired samples.
abstract.10: An mRNA booster dose provides greater quantity and quality of antibodies compared to a two-dose regimen and is critical to provide any protection against the omicron variant.

adaptation3.1: After vaccination with the 2-dose COVID-19 mRNA vaccine, blood levels of antibodies against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 drop over time. To increase blood levels of antibodies again, the FDA approved a booster dose for people greater than 12 years old.
adaptation3.2: However, limited data exist on whether a booster dose of the mRNA vaccine results in greater antibody protection than the primary series.
adaptation3.3: We measured the blood levels of all types of antibodies against the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, and a specific type of antibodies - called neutralizing antibodies - against Washington-1 and other variants of concern including Beta, Delta and Omicron. We followed the trends in antibody levels at several points in time after vaccination.
adaptation3.4: Healthcare workers were included in the analysis if serum was collected within 14-44 days post-dose 2 of an mRNA SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, or at least 8 months post-dose 2, or within 14-44 days following an mRNA booster shot.
adaptation3.5: Healthcare workers who had previously tested positive to COVID-19 were excluded from this study.
adaptation3.6: We found that there are few to no neutralizing antibodies produced against the omicron variant following a 2-dose mRNA vaccine series. By 8-months post two-dose vaccination series, no neutralizing antibodies remain in blood circulation.
adaptation3.7: However, the mRNA booster reactivates immunity to the omicron variant after the two-dose vaccination.
adaptation3.8: Neutralizing antibody blood levels were significantly higher for all variants post-booster compared to the levels after the first two shots.
adaptation3.9: The long-term nature of our study helped us to analyze the trends of antibody blood levels over time. We saw a 15-fold increase in neutralizing antibodies against the omicron variant following the booster shot.
adaptation3.10: An mRNA booster dose provides greater quantity and quality of antibodies compared to a two-dose vaccine and is critical to provide any protection against the omicron variant.

35139036.Title: SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination trigger long-lived B and CD4+ T lymphocytes: implications for booster strategies

abstract.1: Background: Immunization against SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of coronavirus disease-19 (COVID-19) occurs via natural infection or vaccination.
abstract.2: However, it is currently unknown how long infection- or vaccination-induced immunological memory will last.
abstract.3: Methods: We performed a longitudinal evaluation of immunological memory to SARS-CoV-2 up to one year post infection and following mRNA vaccination in naÃ¯ve and COVID-19 recovered individuals.
abstract.4: Results: We found that memory cells are still detectable 8 months after vaccination, while antibody levels decline significantly especially in naÃ¯ve subjects.
abstract.5: We also found that a booster injection is efficacious in reactivating immunological memory to spike protein in naÃ¯ve subjects, while it results ineffective in previously SARS-CoV-2 infected individuals.
abstract.6: Finally, we observed a similar kinetics of decay of humoral and cellular immunity to SARS-CoV-2 up to one year following natural infection in a cohort of unvaccinated individuals.
abstract.7: Conclusion: Short-term persistence of humoral immunity, together with the reduced neutralization capacity versus the currently prevailing SARS-CoV-2 variants, may account for reinfections and breakthrough infections.
abstract.8: Long-lived memory B and CD4+ T cells may protect from severe disease development.
abstract.9: A booster dose restores optimal anti-spike immunity in naÃ¯ve subjects, while the need for vaccinated COVID-19 recovered subjects has yet to be defined.

adaptation3.1: Immunity to SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes coronavirus disease-19 (COVID-19) occurs from natural infection or vaccination.
adaptation3.2: However, it is currently unknown how long infection- or vaccination-induced immunity will last.
adaptation3.3: We performed a long-term study of immunity to SARS-CoV-2 up to one year post infection and following mRNA vaccination in unexposed people and in people who have recovered from COVID-19 infection.
adaptation3.4: We found that memory cells (immune cells that "remember" having encountered an infection before) are still detectable 8 months after vaccination, while viral antibody blood levels decline significantly, especially in previously unexposed people.
adaptation3.5: We also found that a booster shot is effective in reactivating immunity to the virus spike protein in previously unexposed people, while it is ineffective in people who were previously infected with SARS-CoV-2.
adaptation3.6: Finally, we found a similar reduction of immunity to SARS-CoV-2 up to one year following natural infection in a group of unvaccinated individuals.
adaptation3.7: We conclude that short-term immunity, together with the reduced ability of the immune system to block the newer strains of SARS-CoV-2, might account for breakthrough infections in vaccinated people and reinfections in people who were previously infected.
adaptation3.9: A booster dose restores the strongest immunity against the viral spike protein in unexposed people, but it is not clear if people who have recovered from COVID-19 need to have a booster.

35140406.Title: Vaccine effectiveness of heterologous CoronaVac plus BNT162b2 in Brazil

abstract.1: There is considerable interest in the waning of effectiveness of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccines and vaccine effectiveness (VE) of booster doses.
abstract.2: Using linked national Brazilian databases, we undertook a test-negative design study involving almost 14 million people (~16 million tests) to estimate VE of Corona Vac over time and VE of BNT162b2 booster vaccination against RT-PCR-confirmed severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and severe COVID-19 outcomes (hospitalization or death).
abstract.3: Compared with unvaccinated individuals, CoronaVac VE at 14-30 d after the second dose was 55.0% (95% confidence interval (CI): 54.3-55.7) against confirmed infection and 82.1% (95% CI: 81.4-82.8) against severe outcomes.
abstract.4: VE decreased to 34.7% (95% CI: 33.1-36.2) against infection and 72.5% (95% CI: 70.9-74.0) against severe outcomes over 180 d after the second dose.
abstract.5: A BNT162b2 booster, 6 months after the second dose of CoronaVac, improved VE against infection to 92.7% (95% CI: 91.0-94.0) and VE against severe outcomes to 97.3% (95% CI: 96.1-98.1) 14-30 d after the booster.
abstract.6: Compared with younger age groups, individuals 80 years of age or older had lower protection after the second dose but similar protection after the booster.
abstract.7: Our findings support a BNT162b2 booster vaccine dose after two doses of CoronaVac, particularly for the elderly.

adaptation3.1: We are interested in studying the waning effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines and the effectiveness of booster doses.
adaptation3.2: Using national Brazilian databases, we studied the trends of negative test results of almost 14 million people (representing about 16 million tests) to estimate the reduced effectiveness of CoronaVac COVID-19 vaccines over time. We also studied the effects of the Pfizer BNT162b2 booster dose on the rates of confirmed COVID-19 infection and severe outcomes (hospitalization or death).
adaptation3.3: Compared with unvaccinated individuals, the effectiveness of the CoronaVac vaccine at 14-30 days after the second dose was 55% against confirmed infection and 82.1% against severe outcomes.
adaptation3.4: Vaccine effectiveness decreased to 34.7% against infection and 72.5% against severe outcomes over 180 days after the second dose.
adaptation3.5: A Pfizer BNT162b2 booster shot given 6 months after the second dose of CoronaVac, improved vaccine effectiveness by 92.7% against infection and 97.3% against severe outcomes 14-30 days after the booster.
adaptation3.6: Compared with younger age groups, individuals 80 years of age or older had lower protection after the second dose but similar protection after the booster.
adaptation3.7: Based on these results, we recommend a BNT162b2 booster vaccine dose after two doses of CoronaVac, particularly for the elderly.

35144968.Title: Effectiveness of mRNA vaccines and waning of protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe covid-19 during predominant circulation of the delta variant in Italy: retrospective cohort study

abstract.1: Objectives: To estimate the effectiveness of mRNA vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe covid-19 at different time after vaccination.
abstract.2: Design: Retrospective cohort study.
abstract.3: Setting: Italy, 27 December 2020 to 7 November 2021.
abstract.4: Participants: 33 250 344 people aged â‰¥16 years who received a first dose of BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech) or mRNA-1273 (Moderna) vaccine and did not have a previous diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.5: Main outcome measures: SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe covid-19 (admission to hospital or death).
abstract.6: Data were divided by weekly time intervals after vaccination.
abstract.7: Incidence rate ratios at different time intervals were estimated by multilevel negative binomial models with robust variance estimator.
abstract.8: Sex, age group, brand of vaccine, priority risk category, and regional weekly incidence in the general population were included as covariates.
abstract.9: Geographic region was included as a random effect.
abstract.10: Adjusted vaccine effectiveness was calculated as (1-IRR)Ã—100, where IRR=incidence rate ratio, with the time interval 0-14 days after the first dose of vaccine as the reference.
abstract.11: Results: During the epidemic phase when the delta variant was the predominant strain of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 infection significantly decreased (P<0.001) from 82% (95% confidence interval 80% to 84%) at 3-4 weeks after the second dose of vaccine to 33% (27% to 39%) at 27-30 weeks after the second dose.
abstract.12: In the same time intervals, vaccine effectiveness against severe covid-19 also decreased (P<0.001), although to a lesser extent, from 96% (95% to 97%) to 80% (76% to 83%).
abstract.13: High risk people (vaccine effectiveness -6%, -28% to 12%), those aged â‰¥80 years (11%, -15% to 31%), and those aged 60-79 years (2%, -11% to 14%) did not seem to be protected against infection at 27-30 weeks after the second dose of vaccine.
abstract.14: Conclusions: The results support the vaccination campaigns targeting high risk people, those aged â‰¥60 years, and healthcare workers to receive a booster dose of vaccine six months after the primary vaccination cycle.
abstract.15: The results also suggest that timing the booster dose earlier than six months after the primary vaccination cycle and extending the offer of the booster dose to the wider eligible population might be warranted.

adaptation3.1: We studied the effectiveness of mRNA vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe COVID-19 at different times after vaccination.
adaptation3.2: This study was performed in Italy from December 27, 2020 to November 7, 2021.
adaptation3.4: The participants included people aged 16 years and older who received a first dose of BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech) or mRNA-1273 (Moderna) vaccine and did not have a previous diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
adaptation3.5: We tracked the number of people with SARS-CoV-2 infection and severe COVID-19 (admission to hospital or death).
adaptation3.6: The data was calculated for each week following vaccination.
adaptation3.7: The incidence rate of infection at different time intervals was estimated using statistical models.
adaptation3.8: We recorded the sex, age group, brand of vaccine, and priority risk category of patients, and recorded the regional weekly incidence in the general population.
adaptation3.9: We tracked the number of cases according to geographic region.
adaptation3.10: Using infection rates at 0-14 days after the first dose of vaccine as our starting point, we followed the trend of vaccine effectiveness
adaptation3.11: During the epidemic phase when the delta variant was the most common strain of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 infection significantly decreased from 82% at 3-4 weeks after the second dose of vaccine to 33% at 27-30 weeks after the second dose.
adaptation3.12: In the same time range, vaccine effectiveness against severe COVID-19 also decreased, although to a lesser extent, from an average of 96% to an average of 80%.
adaptation3.13: High risk people, those aged more than 80 years old, and those aged 60-79 years did not seem to be protected against infection at 27-30 weeks after the second dose of vaccine.
adaptation3.14: Our results support vaccinating high risk people, those older than 60 years, and healthcare workers with a booster dose of vaccine six months after the primary vaccination cycle.
adaptation3.15: Our results also suggest that giving the booster dose earlier than six months after the primary vaccination cycle and extending the offer of the booster dose to other groups of people might be a good idea.

58.question: How often can i get a covid-19 vaccine?

34370971.Title: Safety and immunogenicity of heterologous versus homologous prime-boost schedules with an adenoviral vectored and mRNA COVID-19 vaccine (Com-COV): a single-blind, randomised, non-inferiority trial

abstract.1: Background: Use of heterologous prime-boost COVID-19 vaccine schedules could facilitate mass COVID-19 immunisation.
abstract.2: However, we have previously reported that heterologous schedules incorporating an adenoviral vectored vaccine (ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, AstraZeneca; hereafter referred to as ChAd) and an mRNA vaccine (BNT162b2, Pfizer-BioNTech; hereafter referred to as BNT) at a 4-week interval are more reactogenic than homologous schedules.
abstract.3: Here, we report the safety and immunogenicity of heterologous schedules with the ChAd and BNT vaccines.
abstract.4: Methods: Com-COV is a participant-blinded, randomised, non-inferiority trial evaluating vaccine safety, reactogenicity, and immunogenicity.
abstract.5: Adults aged 50 years and older with no or well controlled comorbidities and no previous SARS-CoV-2 infection by laboratory confirmation were eligible and were recruited at eight sites across the UK.
abstract.6: The majority of eligible participants were enrolled into the general cohort (28-day or 84-day prime-boost intervals), who were randomly assigned (1:1:1:1:1:1:1:1) to receive ChAd/ChAd, ChAd/BNT, BNT/BNT, or BNT/ChAd, administered at either 28-day or 84-day prime-boost intervals.
abstract.7: A small subset of eligible participants (n=100) were enrolled into an immunology cohort, who had additional blood tests to evaluate immune responses; these participants were randomly assigned (1:1:1:1) to the four schedules (28-day interval only).
abstract.8: Participants were masked to the vaccine received but not to the prime-boost interval.
abstract.9: The primary endpoint was the geometric mean ratio (GMR) of serum SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG concentration (measured by ELISA) at 28 days after boost, when comparing ChAd/BNT with ChAd/ChAd, and BNT/ChAd with BNT/BNT.
abstract.10: The heterologous schedules were considered non-inferior to the approved homologous schedules if the lower limit of the one-sided 97·5% CI of the GMR of these comparisons was greater than 0·63.
abstract.11: The primary analysis was done in the per-protocol population, who were seronegative at baseline.
abstract.12: Safety analyses were done among participants receiving at least one dose of a study vaccine.
abstract.13: The trial is registered with ISRCTN, 69254139.
abstract.14: Findings: Between Feb 11 and Feb 26, 2021, 830 participants were enrolled and randomised, including 463 participants with a 28-day prime-boost interval, for whom results are reported here.
abstract.15: The mean age of participants was 57·8 years (SD 4·7), with 212 (46%) female participants and 117 (25%) from ethnic minorities.
abstract.16: At day 28 post boost, the geometric mean concentration of SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG in ChAd/BNT recipients (12 906 ELU/mL) was non-inferior to that in ChAd/ChAd recipients (1392 ELU/mL), with a GMR of 9·2 (one-sided 97·5% CI 7·5 to ∞).
abstract.17: In participants primed with BNT, we did not show non-inferiority of the heterologous schedule (BNT/ChAd, 7133 ELU/mL) against the homologous schedule (BNT/BNT, 14 080 ELU/mL), with a GMR of 0·51 (one-sided 97·5% CI 0·43 to ∞).
abstract.18: Four serious adverse events occurred across all groups, none of which were considered to be related to immunisation.
abstract.19: Interpretation: Despite the BNT/ChAd regimen not meeting non-inferiority criteria, the SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG concentrations of both heterologous schedules were higher than that of a licensed vaccine schedule (ChAd/ChAd) with proven efficacy against COVID-19 disease and hospitalisation.
abstract.20: Along with the higher immunogenicity of ChAd/BNT compared with ChAD/ChAd, these data support flexibility in the use of heterologous prime-boost vaccination using ChAd and BNT COVID-19 vaccines.

adaptation2.1: Boosters that are not of the same type as the first COVID-19 vaccine can make global COVID-19 immunization easier.
adaptation2.2: However, we know that getting AstraZeneca and Pfizer 4 weeks apart causes more side effects than getting the same vaccine.
adaptation2.3: We report the safety and protective strength of different ways to combine AstraZeneca and Pfizer vaccines.
adaptation2.5: Healthy adults aged 50 years and older that did not have COVID-19 participated in a clinical trial.
adaptation2.6: Most participants got two doses of AstraZeneca or Pfizer or a combination of Pfizer/AstraZeneca or AstraZeneca/Pfizer 28 or 84 days apart.
adaptation2.7: 100 of the participants that had the vaccines 28 days apart was checked for the protective chemicals in the blood more often.
adaptation2.8: Participants did not know which vaccines they got.
adaptation2.9: 28 days after boost, chemicals that fight the SARS-CoV-2 virus were measured in patients' blood.
adaptation2.10: Different-vaccine boosters were considered to be as good as the same-vaccine if the increase in the protective chemicals after the booster was the same or higher for the different vaccines.
adaptation2.11: Protection against COVID-19 was measured in all participants.
adaptation2.12: Safety of the vaccine was measured among participants that had at least one dose of the vaccine.
adaptation2.14: For 463 participants with 28 days between the first vaccine and the booster, the results are reported here.
adaptation2.15: The participants were 54 to 65 years old. About half (212) were women and a quarter (117) were from ethnic minorities.
adaptation2.16: 28 days after the booster, in people who got boosted with Pfizer after AstraZeneca, protection against the SARS-CoV-2 virus was not worse than in those who got the same AstraZeneca booster.
adaptation2.17: Boosting with AstraZeneca after Pfizer was not as good as getting the second dose of the same Pfizer vaccine.
adaptation2.18: Four people had serious health problems during the trial. The problems were not related to getting the vaccines.
adaptation2.19: Although getting AstraZeneca after Pfizer was not as good as getting only Pfizer or Pfizer after AstraZeneca, there were still more protective chemicals against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood compared to getting only AstraZeneca. Getting only AstraZeneca is known to protect against COVID-19 and hospitalization.
adaptation2.20: This trial supports using boosters that are not the same as the first COVID-19 vaccine.

34671773.Title: Heterologous SARS-CoV-2 Booster Vaccinations - Preliminary Report

abstract.1: Background: While Coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines are highly effective, breakthrough infections are occurring.
abstract.2: Booster vaccinations have recently received emergency use authorization (EUA) for certain populations but are restricted to homologous mRNA vaccines.
abstract.3: We evaluated homologous and heterologous booster vaccination in persons who had received an EUA Covid-19 vaccine regimen.
abstract.4: Methods: In this phase 1/2 open-label clinical trial conducted at ten U.S. sites, adults who received one of three EUA Covid-19 vaccines at least 12 weeks prior to enrollment and had no reported history of SARS-CoV-2 infection received a booster injection with one of three vaccines (Moderna mRNA-1273 100-μg, Janssen Ad26.COV2.S 5×10 10 virus particles, or Pfizer-BioNTech BNT162b2 30-μg; nine combinations).
abstract.5: The primary outcomes were safety, reactogenicity, and humoral immunogenicity on study days 15 and 29.
abstract.6: Results: 458 individuals were enrolled: 154 received mRNA-1273, 150 received Ad26.CoV2.S, and 153 received BNT162b2 booster vaccines.
abstract.7: Reactogenicity was similar to that reported for the primary series.
abstract.8: Injection site pain, malaise, headache, and myalgia occurred in more than half the participants.
abstract.9: Booster vaccines increased the neutralizing activity against a D614G pseudovirus (4.2-76-fold) and binding antibody titers (4.6-56-fold) for all combinations; homologous boost increased neutralizing antibody titers 4.2-20-fold whereas heterologous boost increased titers 6.2-76-fold.
abstract.10: Day 15 neutralizing and binding antibody titers varied by 28.7-fold and 20.9-fold, respectively, across the nine prime-boost combinations.
abstract.11: Conclusion: Homologous and heterologous booster vaccinations were well-tolerated and immunogenic in adults who completed a primary Covid-19 vaccine regimen at least 12 weeks earlier.

adaptation2.1: Coronavirus disease 2019 vaccines protect against Covid-19 well, but some vaccinated people may get sick, which is called breakthrough infections.
adaptation2.2: Boosters with the same Pfizer or Moderna vaccines are approved as an emergency measure for some people.
adaptation2.3: We evaluated boosters with the same and different vaccines in people who got the emergency Covid-19 vaccination.
adaptation2.4: In this clinical trial, adults in ten U.S. locations got Moderna, Janssen or Pfizer boosters at least 12 weeks after getting the first vaccine.
adaptation2.5: We evaluated the vaccine safety and protection against COVID-19 on study days 15 and 29.
adaptation2.6: Out of 458 people, 154 got Moderna, 150 got Janssen and 153 got Pfizer boosters.
adaptation2.7: Adverse reactions to the booster were similar to those reported for the first vaccine.
adaptation2.8: More than half of the participants had pain at the injection site, overall weakness, headache, and muscle pains.
adaptation2.9: Boosters with the same and different vaccines increased protection against the virus. The increase in protection after a different booster was higher.
adaptation2.11: Boosters with the same and different vaccines were well-tolerated and increased protection against COVID-19 in adults who had the first vaccine at least 12 weeks earlier.

34883053.Title: Immunogenicity, safety, and reactogenicity of heterologous COVID-19 primary vaccination incorporating mRNA, viral-vector, and protein-adjuvant vaccines in the UK (Com-COV2): a single-blind, randomised, phase 2, non-inferiority trial

abstract.1: Background: Given the importance of flexible use of different COVID-19 vaccines within the same schedule to facilitate rapid deployment, we studied mixed priming schedules incorporating an adenoviral-vectored vaccine (ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 [ChAd], AstraZeneca), two mRNA vaccines (BNT162b2 [BNT], Pfizer-BioNTech, and mRNA-1273 [m1273], Moderna) and a nanoparticle vaccine containing SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein and Matrix-M adjuvant (NVX-CoV2373 [NVX], Novavax).
abstract.2: Methods: Com-COV2 is a single-blind, randomised, non-inferiority trial in which adults aged 50 years and older, previously immunised with a single dose of ChAd or BNT in the community, were randomly assigned (in random blocks of three and six) within these cohorts in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive a second dose intramuscularly (8-12 weeks after the first dose) with the homologous vaccine, m1273, or NVX.
abstract.3: The primary endpoint was the geometric mean ratio (GMR) of serum SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG concentrations measured by ELISA in heterologous versus homologous schedules at 28 days after the second dose, with a non-inferiority criterion of the GMR above 0·63 for the one-sided 98·75% CI.
abstract.4: The primary analysis was on the per-protocol population, who were seronegative at baseline.
abstract.5: Safety analyses were done for all participants who received a dose of study vaccine.
abstract.6: The trial is registered with ISRCTN, number 27841311.
abstract.7: Findings: Between April 19 and May 14, 2021, 1072 participants were enrolled at a median of 9·4 weeks after receipt of a single dose of ChAd (n=540, 47% female) or BNT (n=532, 40% female).
abstract.8: In ChAd-primed participants, geometric mean concentration (GMC) 28 days after a boost of SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG in recipients of ChAd/m1273 (20 114 ELISA laboratory units [ELU]/mL [95% CI 18 160 to 22 279]) and ChAd/NVX (5597 ELU/mL [4756 to 6586]) was non-inferior to that of ChAd/ChAd recipients (1971 ELU/mL [1718 to 2262]) with a GMR of 10·2 (one-sided 98·75% CI 8·4 to ∞) for ChAd/m1273 and 2·8 (2·2 to ∞) for ChAd/NVX, compared with ChAd/ChAd.
abstract.9: In BNT-primed participants, non-inferiority was shown for BNT/m1273 (GMC 22 978 ELU/mL [95% CI 20 597 to 25 636]) but not for BNT/NVX (8874 ELU/mL [7391 to 10 654]), compared with BNT/BNT (16 929 ELU/mL [15 025 to 19 075]) with a GMR of 1·3 (one-sided 98·75% CI 1·1 to ∞) for BNT/m1273 and 0·5 (0·4 to ∞) for BNT/NVX, compared with BNT/BNT; however, NVX still induced an 18-fold rise in GMC 28 days after vaccination.
abstract.10: There were 15 serious adverse events, none considered related to immunisation.
abstract.11: Interpretation: Heterologous second dosing with m1273, but not NVX, increased transient systemic reactogenicity compared with homologous schedules.
abstract.12: Multiple vaccines are appropriate to complete primary immunisation following priming with BNT or ChAd, facilitating rapid vaccine deployment globally and supporting recognition of such schedules for vaccine certification.

adaptation2.1: It is important to have flexibility in using different COVID-19 vaccines for additional doses. We studied mixing AstraZeneca, Pfizer, Moderna and Novavax, which work differently.
adaptation2.2: In this clinical trial, adults aged 50 years and older who received the first dose of AstraZeneca or Pfizer vaccine got a second dose of the same vaccine or Moderna or Novavax 8-12 weeks after the first dose.
adaptation2.3: 28 days after the second dose, chemicals the body produces to protect itself against COVID-19 were measured in the blood.
adaptation2.4: These people did not have these chemicals before the study.
adaptation2.5: We also studied safety of the vaccines.
adaptation2.7: 1072 people participated in the study 9.4 weeks after getting the first vaccine. 540 people got the first dose of AstraZeneca and 532 got Pfizer. There were somewhat more men than women in both groups.
