19306923.Title: Comparative in vitro toxicity of seven zinc-salts towards neuronal PC12 cells

abstract.1: Currently much attention has been given to the neurotoxicity of zinc, yet little is known about the influence of the counterions present.
abstract.2: Therefore, we investigated the influence of different Zn(2+)-salts (concentrations range 0.05-0.3 mM) on cell viability, ATP and glutathione concentration and caspase activation in differentiated PC12 cells as a model for neuronal cells.
abstract.3: Generally, at concentrations of 0.05 mM most Zn(2+)-salts were not cytotoxic except for zinc-citrate.
abstract.4: At concentrations between 0.1 and 0.3 mM Zn(2+) a significant decrease in GSH and ATP levels preceded cell death induced by all salts, except of zinc-histidinate.
abstract.5: Zinc-citrate and zinc-sulphate turned out to be the most toxic salts particularly at low concentrations.
abstract.6: Analyses of caspase 3/7 activity showed that dependent on the concentration and the type of the salt used cell death may show more or less signs of both, necrosis and apoptosis.
abstract.7: Interestingly, the uptake of Zn(2+) from zinc-sulphate and zinc-citrate was significantly higher than that of other salts, implicating a correlation between uptake and toxicity.
abstract.8: In conclusion, Zn(2+)-salts could be divided into three categories with high (zinc-citrate, zinc-sulphate), moderate (zinc-orotate, zinc-acetate, zinc-chloride(,) zinc-gluconate) and low cytotoxicity (zinc-histidinate).

adaptation3.1: Research is focused on the ways that zinc is bad for the body's cells, but researchers don't how everything works.
adaptation3.2: This study looks at how various forms of zinc effect cells in the body by testing the zinc on rat cells.
adaptation3.3: The various forms of zinc did not have bad effects on the cells when used at small sizes, except for the form called zinc citrate.
adaptation3.4: All of the various forms of zinc caused cells to die at high amounts except for the form called zinc histidinate.
adaptation3.5: The most toxic of the zinc forms were zinc-citrate and zinc-sulphate. They had bad effects even when used in low amounts.
adaptation3.6: The type of zinc and how much was used affected the way cells died.
adaptation3.7: The cells absorbed more zinc from the zinc-sulphate and zinc-citrate forms. This means that there may be a relationship between the amount of zinc absorbed and how bad it is for the cells.
adaptation3.8: The forms of zinc can be divided into three different categories based on how toxic they are to cells.

adaptation2.1: Much attention is given to toxic effect of zinc on the neural system, but little is known about about the other chemicals that accompany zinc.
adaptation2.2: We study how different zinc salts affect nerve cells' ability to work and live.
adaptation2.3: In very small doses, zinc salts were no toxic, except for zinc-citrate.
adaptation2.4: At higher doses of all salts except of zinc-histidinate, the levels of protective cell chemicals decreased and the cells died.
adaptation2.5: Zinc-citrate and zinc-sulphate turned out to be the most toxic salts particularly at low doses.
adaptation2.6: Depending on the dose and type of salt, cells die of different combinations of lack of blood supply to the cell or a pre-determined cell death mechanism.
adaptation2.7: Zinc-sulphate and zinc-citrate provided free zinc in higher doses then other salts, possibly indicating there is a connection between taking in zinc and its toxic effect on the cell.
adaptation2.8: Zinc salts could be divided into three categories with high (zinc-citrate, zinc-sulphate), moderate (zinc-orotate, zinc-acetate, zinc-chloride, zinc-gluconate) and low cell totoxicity (zinc-histidinate).

abstract.1: Zinc has earned recognition recently as a micronutrient of outstanding and diverse biological, clinical, and global public health importance.
abstract.2: Regulation of absorption by zinc transporters in the enterocyte, together with saturation kinetics of the absorption process into and across the enterocyte, are the principal means by which whole-body zinc homeostasis is maintained.
abstract.3: Several physiologic factors, most notably the quantity of zinc ingested, determine the quantity of zinc absorbed and the efficiency of absorption.
abstract.4: Other factors are age and the time over which zinc is ingested.
abstract.5: Zinc from supplements has not been shown to be absorbed differently from that taken with meals that lack inhibitors of zinc absorption.
abstract.6: The principal dietary factor known to impair zinc bioavailability is inositol hexa- (and penta-) phosphate or phytate.
abstract.7: Modeling of zinc absorption as a function of dietary zinc and phytate accounts for >80% of the variability in the quantity of zinc absorbed.
abstract.8: Fitting the model to new data has resulted in continual improvement in parameter estimates, which currently indicate a maximal absorption in adults of approximately 6 mg Zn/d and that the average estimated dietary requirement doubles with 1000 mg dietary phytate/d.
abstract.9: Intestinal excretion of endogenous zinc is regulated in response to recent absorption and to zinc status.
abstract.10: The quantitative relation of intestinal excretion of endogenous zinc to zinc absorption is currently considered to be of major importance in the determination of zinc requirements.
abstract.11: The effects of phytate on intestinal losses of endogenous zinc merit further investigation but are probably not of the same magnitude as its inhibitory effects on absorption of exogenous zinc.

adaptation3.1: Doctors have realized recently that zinc is very important to health.
adaptation3.2: The cells in the intestines keep the body's zinc level balanced.
adaptation3.3: Many factors determine how much and how well zinc is absorbed by the body. The most important factor is the amount of zinc a person gets.
adaptation3.4: Two other factors are a person's age and the length of time zinc is taken.
adaptation3.5: The amount of zinc absorbed by the body is not different whether the zinc comes from supplements like pills or from food.
adaptation3.6: Some compounds found in certain foods can make it harder for the body to absorb zinc.
adaptation3.7: The body absorbs zinc differently depending on the amount of zinc or the amount of phytate in the amount already.
adaptation3.8: The results were added to previous data and now we know that adults can absorb at most 6mg of zinc a day. A person needs to take double the normal amount of zinc if getting 1000mg of phytate through food and medication.
adaptation3.9: The body gets rid of zinc according to how much zinc is already in the body and how much has been absorbed recently.
adaptation3.10: How much zinc is lost and how much is absorbed is important to know so that people get the right amount of zinc.
adaptation3.11: The way that phylate affects how much zinc is removed from the body needs to be looked at more. But that effect is probably not as important as the way phylate affects how much zinc gets absorbed in the body.

adaptation2.1: Zinc is now believed to be an extremely important micronutrient. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals that are needed for healthy development, disease prevention, and wellbeing.
adaptation2.2: The body maintains the balance of zinc through special chemicals that take the zinc into cells according to needs.
adaptation2.3: How much and how well zinc is taken into the body depends on its amount in the food and other factors.
adaptation2.4: Other factors are age and the time over which zinc is ingested.
adaptation2.5: There is no difference between the ways zinc from supplements and the meals are taken into the body.
adaptation2.6: The foods, such as grains, which contain phytates, chemicals that prevent minerals from getting into the body, may prevent zinc from getting into the body.
adaptation2.7: Models show that the majority of differences in how much zinc will get into the body is due to the presence of zinc and phytate in the food.
adaptation2.8: Our model shows that an adult body takes in about 6 milligrams a day.  If the daily meals contain a gram of phytate, twice the recommended daily amount of zinc is needed.
adaptation2.9: Zinc is removed with stools depending on how much zinc the body took in and how much was present.
adaptation2.10: The relation between zinc that is taken in and removed determines how much zinc should be taken.
adaptation2.11: Phytate might play a role on how much zinc that is already in the body is removed with stools. This role is probably not as important as in preventing zinc in the food from getting into the body.

21462113.Title: Does zinc absorption reflect zinc status?

abstract.1: Unlike iron, zinc absorption is influenced by dietary zinc intake, not zinc status.
abstract.2: As dietary zinc increases, the total amount of absorbed zinc increases while the percent absorbed declines.
abstract.3: The gastrointestinal tract maintains whole-body zinc homeostasis by adjusting endogenous zinc losses to the amount absorbed.
abstract.4: At intakes below about 9 mg/day, zinc absorption occurs primarily by a saturable (carrier) process involving ZIP4, ZnT1, and other transporters.
abstract.5: There is no evidence that past zinc intakes, or status, influences zinc absorption.
abstract.6: Instead, current zinc intake is the chief determinant of zinc absorption.
abstract.7: Supplemental zinc taken with water in the post-absorptive state initially is absorbed more efficiently than food zinc, but absorption efficiency declines within 24 hours presumably due to down-regulation of the zinc transporters.
abstract.8: More research is needed to understand the effect of physiological state on zinc absorption.

adaptation3.1: The amount of zinc a person's body absorbs is affected by the amount of zinc a person takes in through food or supplements.
adaptation3.2: The body absorbs more zinc when zinc is larger part of a person's diet. The percentage of zinc absorbed by the body is less however.
adaptation3.3: The body's digestive system makes sure that the body has the zinc it needs by absorbing enough zinc to make up for what the body has lost.
adaptation3.4: Zinc is absorbed in the body through special proteins when 9mg or less is gotten in a day.
adaptation3.5: There is no evidence that the amount of zinc a person had in the past affects the way zinc is absorbed in the body now.
adaptation3.6: The amount of zinc a person takes in now is what mainly affects the absorption of zinc.
adaptation3.7: The zinc in zinc supplements is better absorbed than zinc brought into the body by food. The different in absorption disappears within 24 hours though.
adaptation3.8: More research needs to be done to understand how the body absorbs zinc in different situations.

adaptation2.1: Unlike iron, zinc gets into the body proportionately to taking it in with food, not depending on zinc presence in the body.
adaptation2.2: As the amount of zinc in the food increases, the total amount of zinc that the body takes in increases, while the proportion of zinc that the body takes in goes down.
adaptation2.3: The digestive system maintains the balance of zinc in the body by adjusting how much zinc it removes from the body while taking in zinc from the food.
adaptation2.4: If the amount of zinc in food is below 9 milligrams a day, the body uses special chemicals to take zinc into the body.
adaptation2.5: The process of taking in zinc does not depend on how much zinc the body took in the past or currently has.
adaptation2.6: Instead, zinc consumed with food determines how much zinc will get into the body.
adaptation2.7: Zinc supplements taken with water get into the body more efficiently than food zinc. This efficiency goes down within 24 hours, maybe because the body slows down the special chemicals that take zinc in.

24259556.Title: Zinc absorption by young adults from supplemental zinc citrate is comparable with that from zinc gluconate and higher than from zinc oxide

abstract.1: The water-soluble zinc salts gluconate, sulfate, and acetate are commonly used as supplements in tablet or syrup form to prevent zinc deficiency and to treat diarrhea in children in combination with oral rehydration.
abstract.2: Zinc citrate is an alternative compound with high zinc content, slightly soluble in water, which has better sensory properties in syrups but no absorption data in humans.
abstract.3: We used the double-isotope tracer method with (67) Zn and (70) Zn to measure zinc absorption from zinc citrate given as supplements containing 10 mg of zinc to 15 healthy adults without food and compared absorption with that from zinc gluconate and zinc oxide (insoluble in water) using a randomized, double-masked, 3-way crossover design.
abstract.4: Median (IQR) fractional absorption of zinc from zinc citrate was 61.3% (56.6-71.0) and was not different from that from zinc gluconate with 60.9% (50.6-71.7).
abstract.5: Absorption from zinc oxide at 49.9% (40.9-57.7) was significantly lower than from both other supplements (P < 0.01).
abstract.6: Three participants had little or no absorption from zinc oxide.
abstract.7: We conclude that zinc citrate, given as a supplement without food, is as well absorbed by healthy adults as zinc gluconate and may thus be a useful alternative for preventing zinc deficiency and treating diarrhea.
abstract.8: The more insoluble zinc oxide is less well absorbed when given as a supplement without food and may be minimally absorbed by some individuals.

adaptation3.1: Various types of zinc are commonly used as supplements in tablet or syrup forms. These supplements prevent the body from lacking zinc and help treat children's diarrhea along with liquids.
adaptation3.2: Zinc citrate is a form of zinc that dissolves slightly in water and allows more zinc into the body. It is better in syrup form but there is no data on how well its zinc is absorbed in the human body.
adaptation3.3: This study compared how well zinc from zinc citrate is absorbed in the body by giving 15 people 10 mg of the zinc citrate without requiring them to take it along with food. The results were compared to how well zinc gulconate and zinc oxide were absorbed.
adaptation3.4: Zinc citrate was as good as zinc gluconate at being absorbed by the body.
adaptation3.5: Zinc oxide was the worst of the three at being absorbed by the body.
adaptation3.6: Three people did not absorb or barely absorbed any zinc from the zinc oxide.
adaptation3.7: The results show that zinc citrate is as good as zinc gulconate at being absorbed by the human body. It is another good option to prevent lack of zinc in the body and for treating diarrhea.
adaptation3.8: The zinc oxide form is not absorbed as well by the human body when given without food. Some people may not absorb any zinc at all or may barely absorb any.

adaptation2.1: Zinc salts that dissolve in water are commonly used as supplements. Tablets or syrup with zinc  gluconate, zinc sulfate or zinc acetate are used to prevent zinc deficiency and to treat diarrhea (Loose stools) in children.
adaptation2.2: Another source of zinc is zinc citrate that somewhat dissolves in water. It tastes better in syrups, but it is not known if it gets into the body.
adaptation2.3: We measured how much zinc gets into the body of 15 healthy adults after they took zinc supplements without food. The supplements were zinc citrate, zinc gluconate and zinc oxide, which does not mix with water).
adaptation2.4: Same as for zinc gluconate, about half of the zinc from zinc citrate got into the body.
adaptation2.5: Much smaller amounts of zinc got into the body from zinc oxide.
adaptation2.6: Three people did not get any zinc from zinc oxide.
adaptation2.7: Zinc citrate supplement taken without food  provided as much zinc to healthy adults as zinc gluconate. It may be another useful supplement for preventing zinc deficiency and treating diarrhea.
adaptation2.8: Zinc oxide, which doesn't mix with water, does not get into the body that well, or not at all in some people.

24619814.Title: The bioavailability of different zinc compounds used as human dietary supplements in rat prostate: a comparative study

abstract.1: The normal human prostate accumulates the highest levels of zinc (Zn) of any soft tissue in the body.
abstract.2: The pool of zinc available to the body is known to significantly decrease with age.
abstract.3: It is suggested that dietary Zn supplementation protects against oxidative damage and reduces the risk of cancer.
abstract.4: Zinc sulfate and zinc gluconate were the most frequently mentioned in per os administration in studies on Zn supplementation.
abstract.5: The major aim of the study was to compare the bioavailability of different Zn compounds (sulfate, gluconate and citrate) in the prostate after their daily administration to male rats at three different doses (3.0; 15.0; and 50.0 mg Zn/kg b.w.) for 30 days.
abstract.6: The results show that bioavailability in the prostate differs significantly between individual zinc preparations.
abstract.7: A significantly elevated Zn concentration in the dorso-lateral lobe of the prostate, compared to controls, was found in the rats supplemented with two compounds only: zinc gluconate and zinc citrate.
abstract.8: However, after administration of zinc gluconate, this effect occurred even at the lowest dose.
abstract.9: The lowest zinc bioavailability in the prostate was found in the rats administered zinc sulfate: no significant Zn increase was seen in particular zones of the prostate.
abstract.10: To sum up, the use of zinc gluconate is worth considering as a possible means of zinc supplementation in men.

adaptation3.1: Men collect the most zinc in their prostate.
adaptation3.2: The amount of zinc in the body decreases as a person gets older.
adaptation3.3: Taking zinc pills protects the body from chemical imbalance and lessens the risk of cancer.
adaptation3.4: The two types of zinc pills most often studied are zinc sulfate and zinc gluconate.
adaptation3.5: This study compared the different types of zinc pills and doses when taken by rats for 30 days.
adaptation3.6: The results show that the amount of zinc in prostate was different depending on the type of zinc pill taken.
adaptation3.7: The rats had a lot more zinc in their prostates when taking zinc gluconate and zinc citrate compared to rats that did not take any zinc pills.
adaptation3.8: The amount of zinc in the prostate was high even when the rats took zinc gluconate at the lowest dose.
adaptation3.9: There was no increase of zinc in rats that took zinc sulfate.
adaptation3.10: To sum up, zinc gluconate is a worthwhile zinc pill for men who need more zinc.

adaptation2.1: Prostate, a a small gland below the bladder that helps men make semen, contains the highest amount of zinc in the body.
adaptation2.2: The amount of zinc available to the body decreases with age.
adaptation2.3: Taking zinc supplements may protect the body against damage caused by the environment and reduces the risk of cancer.
adaptation2.4: The most frequently discussed supplements are zinc sulfate and zinc gluconate
adaptation2.5: We compare the amounts of available zinc in the prostate of male rats after giving them three different doses of zinc sulfate, zinc gluconate, or zinc citrate for 30 days.
adaptation2.6: The availability of zinc in the prostate was very different for different zinc supplements.
adaptation2.7: The availability of zinc in rat prostate was higher only after taking zinc gluconate and zinc citrate.
adaptation2.8: For zinc gluconate, the availability was higher even at the lowest dose.
adaptation2.9: In the rats that got zinc sulfate, availability of zinc has not increased in some parts of the prostate.
adaptation2.10: To sum up, zinc gluconate is worth considering as a zinc supplement for men.

28665969.Title: Potentiated virucidal activity of pomegranate rind extract (PRE) and punicalagin against Herpes simplex virus (HSV) when co-administered with zinc (II) ions, and antiviral activity of PRE against HSV and aciclovir-resistant HSV

abstract.1: Background: There is a clinical need for new therapeutic products against Herpes simplex virus (HSV).
abstract.2: The pomegranate, fruit of the tree Punica granatum L, has since ancient times been linked to activity against infection.
abstract.3: This work probed the activity of pomegranate rind extract (PRE) and co-administered zinc (II) ions.
abstract.4: Materials and methods: PRE was used in conjunction with zinc (II) salts to challenge HSV-1 and aciclovir-resistant HSV in terms of virucidal plaque assay reduction and antiviral activities in epithelial Vero host cells.
abstract.5: Cytotoxicity was determined by the MTS assay using a commercial kit.
abstract.6: Results: Zinc sulphate, zinc citrate, zinc stearate and zinc gluconate demonstrated similar potentiated virucidal activity with PRE against HSV-1 by up to 4-fold.
abstract.7: A generally parabolic relationship was observed when HSV-1 was challenged with PRE and varying concentrations of ZnSO4, with a maximum potentiation factor of 5.5.
abstract.8: Punicalagin had 8-fold greater virucidal activity than an equivalent mass of PRE.
abstract.9: However, antiviral data showed that punicalagin had significantly lower antiviral activity compared to the activity of PRE (EC50 = 0.56 μg mL-1) a value comparable to aciclovir (EC50 = 0.18 μg mL-1); however, PRE also demonstrated potency against aciclovir-resistant HSV (EC50 = 0.02 μg mL-1), whereas aciclovir showed no activity.
abstract.10: Antiviral action of PRE was not influenced by ZnSO4.
abstract.11: No cytotoxicity was detected with any test solution.
abstract.12: Conclusions: The potentiated virucidal activity of PRE by coadministered zinc (II) has potential as a multi-action novel topical therapeutic agent against HSV infections, such as coldsores.

adaptation3.1: New treatments are needed for Herpes.
adaptation3.2: The pomegranate fruit has been used to fight infections since ancient times.
adaptation3.3: This study looked at how zinc and extract from pomegranate rinds (PRE) affect herpes.
adaptation3.4: PRE and zinc were used against herpes and drug resistant herpes in monkey cells.
adaptation3.6: Four types of zinc pills with PRE were strong against the herpes virus.
adaptation3.8: Another compound found in certain plants including pomegranates called punicalagin is 8 times more active against viruses than the same amount of PRE.
adaptation3.9: However, other data showed that punicalagin was less active against viruses than PRE and was comparable to the drug aciclovir. PRE was still effective against drug resistant herpes unlike aciclovir.
adaptation3.10: Zinc sulfate did not affect the ability of PRE to fight the herpes virus.
adaptation3.11: There were no bad effects on the cells from any of the test treatments.
adaptation3.12: The ability of PRE to fight viruses with zinc could be a new treatment for herpes infections such as cold sores.

adaptation2.1: New treatments are needed for Herpes simplex virus (HSV) that causes cold sores or genital herpes.
adaptation2.2: Pomegranate is considered to help against infection since ancient times.
adaptation2.3: We studied the activity of pomegranate rind extract (PRE)  combined with zinc.
adaptation2.4: PKE and zinc salts were used against different types of HSV.
adaptation2.5: Toxic effect on cells was measured by identifying working cells using commercial chemicals.
adaptation2.6: Zinc sulphate, zinc citrate, zinc stearate and zinc gluconate worked similarly against HSV that causes cold sores, and increased the effect of PKE up to 4-fold.
adaptation2.7: Punicalagin, a chemical extracted from pomegranate, was 8 times more effective against the virus than an equivalent amount of PKE.
adaptation2.8: Punicalagin, a chemical extracted from pomegranate, was 8 times more effective killing the virus than an equivalent amount of PKE.
adaptation2.9: Punicalagin was less effective than PKE in fighting the virus and suppressing its growth. PKE was comparable to the drug aciclovir. PKE also worked against the viruses that are resistant to aciclovir.
adaptation2.10: Zinc sulfate did not affect how PKE worked against the virus and its growth.
adaptation2.11: None of the zinc-PKE combinations had toxic effects on cells.
adaptation2.12: Zinc increases PKE ability to kill viral cells. The combination could become a new treatment applied locally to cold sores.

61.question: Is zinc gluconate or zinc citrate easiest to metabolize by the body?

234488.Title: Suppression of histamine-induced pruritus by three antihistaminic drugs

abstract.1: A double-blind crossover study of inhibition of histamine-induced pruritus by three commonly prescribed antihistamines was conducted on 28 normal subjects.
abstract.2: Drugs used included diphenhydramine HCl (Benadryl), cyproheptadine (Periactin), hydroxyzine HCl (Atarax), and a lactose placebo in identical capsules.
abstract.3: Intradermal histamine dose-response thresholds of pruritus were obtained before and after pretreatment with the three antihistamines and placebo in each subject.
abstract.4: Analysis of data revealed a fivefold increase above baseline of the histamine dose required to produce pruritus following both cyproheptadine and placebo.
abstract.5: This compared to a tenfold increase following diphenhydramine and a 750-fold increase following hydroxyzine HCl.
abstract.6: The most common side effect was drowsiness, which occurred with all three drugs.

adaptation2.1: Three commonly prescribed drugs (antihistamines) for itching caused by histamine, a chemical  the body releases during allergic reactions, were studied on 28 healthy people.
adaptation2.2: The drugs in identical capsules included Benadryl, Periactin, Atarax, and a placebo (a pill that contains no drug).
adaptation2.3: The thresholds of itching due to histamine were measured before and after taking the drugs.
adaptation2.4: For Periactin and placebo, the dose of histamine that caused itching increased fivefold.
adaptation2.5: For Benadryl, the dose had to be 10 times higher, and for Atarax 750 times higher.
adaptation2.6: The most common side effect was drowsiness, which occurred with all three drugs.

1683192.Title: Objective antihistamine side effects are mitigated by evening dosing of hydroxyzine

abstract.1: First-generation antihistamines have potency, pharmacokinetic, and cost advantages compared with nonsedating second-generation antihistamines.
abstract.2: Bedtime dosing of hydroxyzine was investigated as a dosing strategy to minimize reaction time degradation and adverse subjective symptoms previously documented for hydroxyzine in divided doses.
abstract.3: Hydroxyzine, 50 mg qhs, was compared with terfenadine, 60 mg bid, in this double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study of 15 healthy, asymptomatic adults.
abstract.4: Computer-based eye-hand reaction time tests of simple reaction time (SRT) and choice reaction time (CRT) were not statistically different among the three drugs.
abstract.5: Drowsiness, dry mouth, and irritability were significant for hydroxyzine (P = .0001, .001 and .02, respectively) compared with terfenadine or placebo, but less than seen in a previous study of hydroxyzine, 25 mg bid.
abstract.6: Symptom scores with terfenadine were comparable to placebo.
abstract.7: Histamine skin test wheal and flare were both significantly and comparably suppressed by hydroxyzine and terfenadine (P = .0001).
abstract.8: While wheal suppression by hydroxyzine was universal, four of the 15 subjects showed little or no suppression with terfenadine (P = .03).
abstract.9: Although bedtime dosing of hydroxyzine did not eliminate subjective symptoms, it maintained skin H1-receptor antagonism the following morning and alleviated the prolongation of reaction times previously reported with hydroxyzine in divided doses.
abstract.10: The significant adverse subjective symptoms and psychomotor performance degradations caused by first-generation antihistamines can be mitigated by creative dosing schedules.

adaptation2.1: First-generation antihistamines (allergy drugs that cause drowsiness) are more powerful and cheaper than the second-generation antihistamines that do not cause drowsiness.
adaptation2.2: Hydroxyzine is an antihistamine that is used to relieve itching caused by allergies. We studied if taking hydroxyzine at bedtime reduces the side effects known to be caused by taking this drug divided in small doses.
adaptation2.3: 15 healthy adults took hydroxyzine every night at bedtime or another antihistamine  terfenadine or a pill that contained no drugs two times a day.
adaptation2.5: Hydroxyzine caused drowsiness, dry mouth and moodiness more than terfenadine or placebo, but less than taking  hydroxyzine twice a day.
adaptation2.6: Symptoms caused by terfenadine and placebo were about the same.
adaptation2.7: Both hydroxyzine and terfenadine lessened allergic reactions.
adaptation2.8: Hydroxyzine lessened allergic reactions in all people, but terfenadine failed to lessen the reaction in four of the 15 people.
adaptation2.9: Taking hydroxyzine at bedtime somewhat lessened the symptoms and relieved skin itching the next morning. The side effects lasted not as long as with taking the drug twice daily.
adaptation2.10: The side effects and sluggish movements caused by the first-generation antihistamines can be lessened by changing when the drug is taken.

2866055.Title: Clinical pharmacokinetics of H1-receptor antagonists (the antihistamines)

abstract.1: This article reviews clinical pharmacokinetic data on the H1-receptor antagonists, commonly referred to as the antihistamines.
abstract.2: Despite their widespread use over an extended period, relatively little pharmacokinetic data are available for many of these drugs.
abstract.3: A number of H1-receptor antagonists have been assayed mainly using radioimmunoassay methods.
abstract.4: These have also generally measured metabolites to greater or lesser extents.
abstract.5: Thus, the interpretation of such data is complex.
abstract.6: After oral administration of H1-receptor antagonists as syrup or tablet formulations, peak plasma concentrations are usually observed after 2 to 3 hours.
abstract.7: Bioavailability has not been extensively studied, but is about 0.34 for chlorpheniramine, 0.40 to 0.60 for diphenhydramine, and about 0.25 for promethazine.
abstract.8: Most of these drugs are metabolised in the liver, this being very extensive in some instances (e.g. cyproheptadine and terfenadine).
abstract.9: Total body clearance in adults is generally in the range of 5 to 12 ml/min/kg (for astemizole, brompheniramine, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, hydroxyzine, promethazine and triprolidine), while their elimination half-lives range from about 3 hours to about 18 days [cinnarizine about 3 hours; diphenhydramine about 4 hours; promethazine 10 to 14 hours; chlorpheniramine 14 to 25 hours; hydroxyzine about 20 hours; brompheniramine about 25 hours; astemizole and its active metabolites about 7 to 20 days (after long term administration); flunarizine about 18 to 20 days].
abstract.10: They also have relatively large apparent volumes of distribution in excess of 4 L/kg.
abstract.11: In children, the elimination half-lives of chlorpheniramine and hydroxyzine are shorter than in adults.
abstract.12: In patients with alcohol-related liver disease, the elimination half-life of diphenhydramine was increased from 9 to 15 hours, while in patients with chronic renal disease that of chlorpheniramine was very greatly prolonged.
abstract.13: Little, if any, published information is available on the pharmacokinetics of these drugs in neonates, pregnancy or during lactation.
abstract.14: The relatively long half-lives of a number of the older H1-receptor antagonists such as brompheniramine, chlorpheniramine and hydroxyzine suggest that they can be administered to adults once daily.

adaptation2.1: This is a review of the drugs called antihistamines because they help with allergies caused by the body chemical histamine.
adaptation2.2: These drugs are used widely, but little is known about their interactions with human body.
adaptation2.6: The max amount of antihistamines gets into the blood 2 to 3 hours after taking a pill or syrup.
adaptation2.7: The amounts of the drug that made it into the blood were about a third of the taken pill for chlorpheniramine, about half for diphenhydramine, and about a quarter for promethazine.
adaptation2.8: Most of these drugs are processed in the body by the liver.
adaptation2.9: These drugs are usually removed from the body at a rate of  5 to 12 milliliters per minute for each kilogram of body weight. Half of the total amount of the drug is taken out of the body from about 3 hours to about 20 days. For cinnarizine it's about 3 hours; diphenhydramine about 4 hours; promethazine 10 to 14 hours; chlorpheniramine 14 to 25 hours; hydroxyzine about 20 hours; brompheniramine about 25 hours; astemizole about 7 to 20 days, when taken for a long time; and for flunarizine about 18 to 20 days.
adaptation2.10: These drugs tend to go from the blood into the body tissues, meaning that a higher dose of a drug is needed to keep its levels in the blood.
adaptation2.11: In children, chlorpheniramine and hydroxyzine go to half of the amount in the body faster than in adults.
adaptation2.12: In patients with liver disease due to alcohol, time to get half of the diphenhydramine  out lengthens from 9 to 15 hours.  In patients with kidney disease, time to get out chlorpheniramine was very greatly prolonged.
adaptation2.13: Almost nothing is known about these drugs in the bodies of newborns, and pregnant or breastfeeding women.
adaptation2.14: Because half of the drug stays in the body longer for the older antihistamines such as brompheniramine, chlorpheniramine and hydroxyzine, they can be given to adults once daily.

7486360.Title: Outpatient management of acute urticaria: the role of prednisone

abstract.1: Study objective: To evaluate the efficacy of a 4-day "burst" course of prednisone added to standard treatment with H1 antihistamines for the management of acute urticaria in outpatients.
abstract.2: Design: Prospective, randomized, double-blinded, clinical trial.
abstract.3: Setting: Emergency department of an urban tertiary care teaching hospital.
abstract.4: Participants: Adult patients with urticarial rash of no more than 24 hours' duration, regardless of cause.
abstract.5: Patients were excluded if they manifested wheezing, stridor, or angioedema or if they had taken antihistamines or glucocorticoids within 5 days of arrival at the ED.
abstract.6: Patients also were excluded if there was a history of diabetes or active peptic ulcer disease.
abstract.7: Interventions: All patients were asked to evaluate the severity of pruritus ("itch score") on a 10-cm visual analog scale.
abstract.8: Patients were then given diphenhydramine, 50 mg intramuscularly, and discharged home on a regimen of hydroxyzine, 25 mg orally, every 4 to 8 hours for pruritus, plus either prednisone, 20 mg, or placebo orally every 12 hours for 4 days.
abstract.9: Patients' conditions were reassessed clinically, with itch score calculated again 2 days later, and again at 5 days by telephone.
abstract.10: Results: Forty-three patients were enrolled; 24 received prednisone and 19 received placebo.
abstract.11: The two groups had similar itch scores at enrollment (prednisone, 8.1 +/- 1.7; placebo, 7.4 +/- 2.1, P = .25 [ANOVA]), but at 2- and 5-day follow-up the prednisone group had significantly lower itch scores (1.3 +/- 1.3 and .0 +/- .0 versus 4.4 +/- 2.2 and 1.6 +/- 1.0, respectively; P < .0001 [ANCOVA] at each interval) and greater clinical improvement in rash.
abstract.12: Response did not correlate with age, sex, or identification of an allergen.
abstract.13: No adverse effects were noted in either group.
abstract.14: Conclusion: The addition of a prednisone burst improves the symptomatic and clinical response of acute urticaria to antihistamines.
abstract.15: Patients' conditions improved more quickly and more completely when prednisone was administered, without any apparent adverse effects.

adaptation2.1: This study added hormone prednisone to antihistamines, the drugs that are usually used to treat hives (itchy skin rash).
adaptation2.4: Adults with the rash that started no more than 24 hours ago participated in the study.
adaptation2.5: Patients with wheezing, raspy breathing, swelling or those who took antihistamines or hormones within 5 days before coming to the emergency room were not included in the study.
adaptation2.6: Diabetics and people with ulcers (open sores in the stomach) were not included too.
adaptation2.7: All patients were asked to give their itch an "itch score" on a scale.
adaptation2.8: Patients then got a shot of an antihistamine diphenhydramine and were sent home. They  took an antihistamine hydroxyzine  every 4 to 8 hours for their itch. Patients also took another pill every 12 hours for 4 days. For some that pill was the hormone prednisone, and for some it was a placebo (did not contain any drug).
adaptation2.9: Patients came back to evaluate their each score 2 days later. 5 days later the score was evaluated by phone.
adaptation2.10: Out of f43 patients, 24 got prednisone and 19 placebo.
adaptation2.11: All had similar each scores at the beginning. After 2 and 5 days, those who had prednisone had lower itch scores and less rash.
adaptation2.12: Patients' age, sex, and substances that caused allergies did not effect the itch score.
adaptation2.13: No patients had adverse reactions.
adaptation2.14: Adding prednisone improves antihistamine treatment of hives.
adaptation2.15: When prednisone was added, the skin cleared faster and more completely. There were no side effects.

7913608.Title: H1-receptor antagonists. Comparative tolerability and safety

abstract.1: First-generation histamine H1-receptor antagonists, such as diphenhydramine, triprolidine, hydroxyzine or chlorpheniramine (chlorphenamine), frequently cause somnolence or other CNS adverse effects.
abstract.2: Second-generation H1-antagonists, such as terfenadine, astemizole, loratadine and cetirizine, represent a true advance in therapeutics.
abstract.3: In manufacturers' recommended doses, they have a more favourable benefit/risk ratio than their predecessors with regard to lack of CNS effects, and do not exacerbate the adverse CNS effects of alcohol or other CNS-active chemicals.
abstract.4: Rarely, some of the newer H1-antagonists may cause cardiac dysrhythmias after overdose or under other specific conditions.
abstract.5: The concept of a risk-free H1-antagonist is proving to be an oversimplification.
abstract.6: An H1-antagonist absolutely free from adverse effects under all circumstances is not yet available for use.
abstract.7: The magnitude of the beneficial effects of each H1-antagonist should be related to the magnitude of the unwanted effects, especially in the CNS and cardiovascular system, and a benefit-risk ratio or therapeutic index should be developed for each medication in this class.

adaptation2.1: First-generation antihistamines, drugs that help with allergies caused by histamine, a chemical profited by our bodies, often cause sleepiness and disturb brain functions in other ways. These drugs include diphenhydramine, triprolidine, hydroxyzine and chlorpheniramine (chlorphenamine).
adaptation2.2: Second-generation antihistamines, such as terfenadine, astemizole, loratadine and cetirizine, are better.
adaptation2.3: These drugs do not disturb brain functions when taken alone, and do not strengthen the disturbances caused by alcohol or other chemicals.
adaptation2.4: Not often, the new antihistamines may cause heart rhythm disturbances; if a person takes too much of the drug or has other specific conditions.
adaptation2.5: Taking any antihistamines includes some risks.
adaptation2.7: When taking antihistamines, people should consider the benefits and the risks carefully.

8792380.Title: Adverse central nervous system effects of older antihistamines in children

abstract.1: Although older, potentially sedating, "first-generation" antihistamines (H1-receptor antagonists) are commonly used in childhood, their central nervous system (CNS) effects have not been well-documented in young subjects.
abstract.2: We hypothesized that diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine would affect CNS function adversely in this population.
abstract.3: Our objective was to evaluate the effects of these medications on central and peripheral histamine H1-receptors in children.
abstract.4: Fifteen subjects with allergic rhinitis were tested before and 2-2.5 h after administration of diphenhydramine, hydroxyzine, or placebo in a double-blind, single-dose, three-way crossover study.
abstract.5: Impairment of cognitive processing was assessed objectively by the latency of the P300 event-related potential (P300).
abstract.6: Somnolence was assessed subjectively by a visual analog scale.
abstract.7: Peripheral H1-blockade was assessed by suppression of the histamine-induced wheals and flares.
abstract.8: At the central (Cz) and frontal (Fz) electrodes, diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine increased the P300 latency significantly (P < 0.05) compared to baseline.
abstract.9: Hydroxyzine increased somnolence, as recorded on the visual analog scale, significantly compared to baseline (P < 0.05), with a similar trend for diphenhydramine (P = 0.07).
abstract.10: Both antihistamines reduced histamine-induced wheals and flares significantly compared to baseline and compared to placebo.
abstract.11: In children, diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine are effective H1-receptor antagonists, but both these medications cause CNS dysfunction, as evidenced by increased P300 latency, a measure of cognitive function, and by increased subjective somnolence.

adaptation2.1: First generation antihistamines, drugs that stop allergies due to the body chemical histamine, may cause drowsiness. They are often given to children, but it is not known how they effect the children's brains
adaptation2.2: We believe that first generation antihistamines diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine may disturb  children's brain function.
adaptation2.3: We evaluated how these drugs effect body cells in children.
adaptation2.4: Fifteen children with seasonal allergy (hay fever) had tests before and after they took diphenhydramine, hydroxyzine, or placebo (a pill that contains no drugs.)
adaptation2.5: Their brain functions were evaluated by measuring the delays in response to events.
adaptation2.6: They were also asked to evaluate how sleepy they felt.
adaptation2.8: Diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine significantly increased the time it took to respond to the events.
adaptation2.9: Hydroxyzine and diphenhydramine also increased sleepiness.
adaptation2.10: Both antihistamines also reduced the allergies.
adaptation2.11: In children, diphenhydramine and hydroxyzine help against allergies, but interfere with brain functions. These drugs cause longer response times, increase sleepiness and disturb mental processes.

15507061.Title: Inappropriate medication administration to the acutely ill elderly: a nationwide emergency department study, 1992-2000

abstract.1: Objectives: To determine the national rate and trend of inappropriate medication administration to elderly emergency department (ED) patients.
abstract.2: Secondary objectives were to identify risk factors for receiving an inappropriate medication and to determine whether administration is sometimes justified based on diagnosis.
abstract.3: Design: Retrospective analysis of ED visits in the 1992-2000 National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey.
abstract.4: Inappropriate medications identified using Beers' 1997 explicit criteria.
abstract.5: Setting: EDs of U.S. noninstitutionalized general and short-stay hospitals.
abstract.6: Participants: ED survey patients aged 65 and older.
abstract.7: Measurements: Magnitude and rate of administration of 36 medications.
abstract.8: Results: Inappropriate medications were administered in an estimated 16.1 million (95% confidence interval (CI)=14.9-17.3 million) or 12.6% (95% CI=11.6-13.5%) of elderly ED visits from 1992 to 2000.
abstract.9: The rate of inappropriate administration was unchanged throughout the study period (P=.40).
abstract.10: Six drugs accounted for 70.8% of inappropriate administration: promethazine (22.2%), meperidine (18.0%), propoxyphene (17.2%), hydroxyzine (10.3%), diphenhydramine (7.1%), and diazepam (6.0%).
abstract.11: In multivariate analysis, number of ED medications was the strongest predictor, with an odds ratio for two to three medications of 6.0 (95% CI=5.3-6.7) and for four to six medications of 8.1 (95% CI=7.2-9.2).
abstract.12: Diagnoses indicating potentially appropriate uses of these medications were rarely present.
abstract.13: For example, only 42.4% of patients receiving diphenhydramine and 7.4% receiving hydroxyzine were diagnosed with an allergic process.
abstract.14: Conclusion: Elderly ED patients are frequently administered inappropriate medications.
abstract.15: Potentially appropriate uses of generally inappropriate drugs cannot account for such administrations.
abstract.16: Inappropriate administration rates remain unchanged despite the 1997 publication of explicit criteria.

adaptation2.1: We studied inappropriate use of drugs in elderly patients in the emergency departments.
adaptation2.2: We also find out what causes inappropriate use of drugs and if it is sometimes done for a good reason.
adaptation2.3: We studied visits to emergency departments in 1992-2000.
adaptation2.4: Drugs that are dangerous for elderly and should be used with caution were listed by Dr. Beers in 1997.
adaptation2.8: Drugs from the Beers' list were given about 16 million times (over a tenth of emergency visits by elderly) from 1992 to 2000.
adaptation2.10: Six drugs accounted for the majority of inappropriate use: promethazine, meperidine, propoxyphene, hydroxyzine, diphenhydramine, and diazepam.
adaptation2.12: There were almost no indications that the use of these drugs was potentially appropriate.
adaptation2.13: For example, less than half of patients that got diphenhydramine and less than 10th that got hydroxyzine had allergies.
adaptation2.14: Elderly patients often get inappropriate drugs in the emergency room.
adaptation2.15: Potentially appropriate uses do not account for the given drugs.
adaptation2.16: Although the list of inappropriate drugs was published in 1997, it has not changed how the drugs are given.

28480041.Title: Risk of QT prolongation and torsade de pointes associated with exposure to hydroxyzine: re-evaluation of an established drug

abstract.1: Several noncardiac drugs have been linked to cardiac safety concerns, highlighting the importance of post-marketing surveillance and continued evaluation of the benefit-risk of long-established drugs.
abstract.2: Here, we examine the risk of QT prolongation and/or torsade de pointes (TdP) associated with the use of hydroxyzine, a first generation sedating antihistamine.
abstract.3: We have used a combined methodological approach to re-evaluate the cardiac safety profile of hydroxyzine, including: (1) a full review of the sponsor pharmacovigilance safety database to examine real-world data on the risk of QT prolongation and/or TdP associated with hydroxyzine use and (2) nonclinical electrophysiological studies to examine concentration-dependent effects of hydroxyzine on a range of human cardiac ion channels.
abstract.4: Based on a review of pharmacovigilance data between 14th December 1955 and 1st August 2016, we identified 59 reports of QT prolongation and/or TdP potentially linked to hydroxyzine use.
abstract.5: Aside from intentional overdose, all cases involved underlying medical conditions or concomitant medications that constituted at least 1 additional risk factor for such events.
abstract.6: The combination of cardiovascular disorders plus concomitant treatment of drugs known to induce arrhythmia was identified as the greatest combined risk factor.
abstract.7: Parallel patch-clamp studies demonstrated hydroxyzine concentration-dependent inhibition of several human cardiac ion channels, including the ether-a-go-go-related gene (hERG) potassium ion channels.
abstract.8: Results from this analysis support the listing of hydroxyzine as a drug with "conditional risk of TdP" and are in line with recommendations to limit hydroxyzine use in patients with known underlying risk factors for QT prolongation and/or TdP.

adaptation2.1: Several drugs can cause heart problems. It is important to monitor and evaluate risks of traditional drugs.
adaptation2.2: We study if taking hydroxyzine, a drug that relieves anxiety and also itch caused by allergies, is associated with fast, chaotic heartbeats.
adaptation2.3: We reviewed data from a drug safety database and the basic studies of hydroxyzine interactions with human cells.
adaptation2.4: The drug safety data had 59 reports between December 1955 and August 2016 that linked fast chaotic heartbeats to hydroxyzine use.
adaptation2.5: Some people took too much of the drug (overdose). All other cases had medical problems or were taking other drugs along with hydroxyzine.
adaptation2.6: People who have heart problems and take drugs that can cause irregular heartbeat are at the greatest risk of complications due to hydroxyzine.
adaptation2.7: Studies show hydroxyzine can effect some heart functions.
adaptation2.8: Hydroxyzine should be listed as drug with "conditional risk of torsade de pointes". Hydroxyzine use in patients who are at risk for heart problems  should be limited.

29532516.Title: Effects of levocetirizine and diphenhydramine on regional glucose metabolic changes and hemodynamic responses in the human prefrontal cortex during cognitive tasks

abstract.1: Objective: Antihistamines often have sedative side effects.
abstract.2: This was the first study to measure regional cerebral glucose (energy) consumption and hemodynamic responses in young adults during cognitive tests after antihistamine administration.
abstract.3: Methods: In this double-blind, placebo-controlled, three-way crossover study, 18 healthy young Japanese men received single doses of levocetirizine 5 mg and diphenhydramine 50 mg at intervals of at least six days.
abstract.4: Subjective feeling, task performances, and brain activity were evaluated during three cognitive tests (word fluency, two-back, and Stroop).
abstract.5: Regional cerebral glucose consumption changes were measured using positron emission tomography with [18 F]fluorodeoxyglucose.
abstract.6: Regional hemodynamic responses were measured using near-infrared spectroscopy.
abstract.7: Results: Energy consumption in prefrontal regions was significantly increased after antihistamine administration, especially diphenhydramine, whereas prefrontal hemodynamic responses, evaluated with oxygenated hemoglobin levels, were significantly lower with diphenhydramine treatment.
abstract.8: Stroop test accuracy was significantly impaired by diphenhydramine, but not by levocetirizine.
abstract.9: There was no significant difference in subjective sleepiness.
abstract.10: Conclusions: Physiological "coupling" between metabolism and perfusion in the healthy human brain may not be maintained under pharmacological influence due to antihistamines.
abstract.11: This uncoupling may be caused by a combination of increased energy demands in the prefrontal regions and suppression of vascular permeability in brain capillaries after antihistamine treatment.
abstract.12: Further research is needed to validate this hypothesis.

adaptation2.1: Antihistamines, drugs that help with allergies, often cause drowsiness.
adaptation2.2: We studied young adults' brains during tests of mental processes after taking antihistamines.
adaptation2.3: 18 healthy young Japanese men took antihistamines levocetirizine and diphenhydramine  at least six days apart.
adaptation2.4: Their well-being, task performances, and brain activity were measured while checking their mental functions.
adaptation2.7: After diphenhydramine, the brains consumed more energy but responded slower.
adaptation2.8: Diphenhydramine, but not levocetirizine, lowered the accuracy of mental processes.
adaptation2.9: There was no  difference in  sleepiness.
adaptation2.10: Antihistamines may effect human brain.

33141610.Title: Association of H1-antihistamines with torsade de pointes: a pharmacovigilance study of the food and drug administration adverse event reporting system

abstract.1: Background: This study aimed to measure the association of various H1-antihistamines (H1A) with Torsade de Pointes (TdP), and present a comprehensive overview of H1A-induced TdP cases reported to the Food and Drug Administration Adverse Event Reporting System (FAERS).
abstract.2: Methods: All H1A-induced TdP cases (n = 406) were retrieved from the FAERS database using the preferred term 'Torsade de Pointes' of MedDRA version-22 from 1990 to 2019.
abstract.3: Four data-mining algorithms were used for disproportionality analysis: Reporting Odds Ratio (ROR); Proportional Reporting Ratio (PRR), Empirical Bayes Geometric Mean (EBGM), and Information Content (IC).
abstract.4: H1A with >3 TdP cases were included.
abstract.5: Results: A total of 12 signals (Astemizole, cetirizine, chlorpheniramine, clemastine, desloratadine, diphenhydramine, hydroxyzine, loratadine, meclizine, promethazine, terfenadine, and trimeprazine) were identified including six new signals (cetirizine, chlorpheniramine, clemastine, desloratadine, loratadine, and meclizine).
abstract.6: The number of risk factors (p = 0.031) and concomitant QT-prolonging drugs (p = <0.001) were significantly lower among new signals vs old signals.
abstract.7: Moreover, new signals were strongly associated with QT-prolongation, cardiac reactions, and electrolyte abnormalities as compared with old signals.
abstract.8: Conclusions: Our study found the increased torsadogenic potential of new signals compared with previously known old signals, hence necessitating clinical studies to determine the actual torsadogenic potential of newly identified signals.

adaptation2.1: We studied relations between antihistamines (drugs for treating allergies)  and Torsade de Pointes (very fast heart rhythm) as reported to the FDA.
adaptation2.2: We found 406 reports on Torsade de Pointes and antihistamines.
adaptation2.3: We used four different statistical methods to study the cases.
adaptation2.4: Antihistamines that had more than three reports of torsade de pointes were included in the analysis.
adaptation2.5: We found 12 drugs associated with torsade de pointes. Six of the drugs were not known before to cause torsade de pointes.
adaptation2.6: Getting antihistamines with other drugs that cause heart complications was lower than for the known antihistamines.
adaptation2.7: The new antihistamines were associated with heart complications stronger than the known ones.
adaptation2.8: The new antihistamines were associated with torsade de pointes stronger.
