17679728.Title: A phase II placebo-controlled trial of neoadjuvant anastrozole alone or with gefitinib in early breast cancer

abstract.1: Purpose: Increased epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression may promote breast cancer resistance to endocrine therapy.
abstract.2: We have therefore investigated whether neoadjuvant gefitinib, an EGFR inhibitor, might overcome biologic and clinical resistance to neoadjuvant anastrozole in a phase II placebo-controlled trial.
abstract.3: Patients and methods: Postmenopausal women with stage I to IIIB hormone receptor-positive early breast cancer received anastrozole 1 mg daily for 16 weeks and were randomly assigned at a ratio of 2:5:5 to receive, in addition, gefitinib 250 mg/d orally for 16 weeks: placebo 1 tablet/d orally for 2 weeks and then gefitinib for 14 weeks or placebo for 16 weeks.
abstract.4: The primary end point was biologic change in proliferation as measured by Ki67 at 2 and 16 weeks; the main secondary end point was overall objective response (OR).
abstract.5: Results: Two hundred six women were randomly assigned.
abstract.6: Mean changes in Ki67 with anastrozole and gefitinib versus anastrozole alone were -77.4% and -83.6%, respectively, between baseline and 16 weeks (geometric mean ratio = 1.37; 95% CI, 0.79 to 2.39; P = .26), -80.1% and -71.3% between baseline and 2 weeks (geometric mean ratio = 0.70; 95% CI, 0.39 to 1.25; P = .22) and -19.3% and -43% (geometric mean ratio = 1.42; 95% CI, 0.86 to 2.35; P = .16) between 2 and 16 weeks.
abstract.7: ORs in the combination and anastrozole alone groups were 48% and 61% (estimated difference = -13.1%; 95% CI, -27.3% to 1.2%), respectively, with a nonsignificant trend against the combination (P = .08) and 48% versus 72% (estimated difference = -24.1%; 95% CI, -45.3% to -2.9%) in the progesterone-receptor-positive subgroup, which was significant (P = .03) and consistent with Ki67 changes.
abstract.8: Common treatment-related adverse events included diarrhea, rash, alopecia, dry skin, and nausea.
abstract.9: There was no evidence of a pharmacokinetic interaction.
abstract.10: Conclusion: Addition of gefitinib to neoadjuvant anastrozole had no additional clinical or biologic effect, failing to support our original hypothesis.

adaptation2.1: For the study's purpose, increased skin-related or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) expression may promote breast cancer resistance to hormonal therapy.
adaptation2.2: We have studied if giving gefitinib, an EGFR blocker, first might overcome biologic and medical resistance to pre-treatment anastrozole (a drug commonly used for breast cancer) in a medical trial.
adaptation2.3: The study included postmenopausal women (women who had their last period) with hormone receptor-specific, early breast cancer received anastrozole 1 mg daily for 16 weeks. Then, they were randomly assigned at a ratio of 2:5:5 to also receive (1) gefitinib 250 mg/d by mouth for 16 weeks, (2) dummy treatment 1 tablet/d by mouth for 2 weeks and then gefitinib for 14 weeks, or (3) dummy treatment for 16 weeks.
adaptation2.4: The main measure was biologic change in cancer cell growth at 2 and 16 weeks. The main secondary measure was overall health improvement or objective response (OR).
adaptation2.5: For the study's results, two hundred six women were randomly assigned.
adaptation2.6: Average changes in cancer cell growth with anastrozole and gefitinib versus anastrozole alone were -77.4% and -83.6%, respectively, between start and 16 weeks, -80.1% and -71.3% between start and 2 weeks, and -19.3% and -43% between 2 and 16 weeks.
adaptation2.7: ORs in the 2-drug-group and anastrozole alone group were 48% and 61%, respectively, and 48% versus 72% in the female-sex-hormone-specific subgroup, which was  consistent with cancer cell growth changes.
adaptation2.8: Common treatment-related side effects included diarrhea, rash, alopecia (hair loss or thinning), dry skin, and nausea.
adaptation2.9: There was no evidence of a drug interaction.
adaptation2.10: In conclusion, adding gefitinib to pre-treatment anastrozole had no additional clinical or biologic effect, failing to support our original theory.

20821047.Title: Anastrozole and letrozole: an investigation and comparison of quality of life and tolerability

abstract.1: Previous studies have demonstrated that both anastrozole and letrozole are well tolerated.
abstract.2: Letrozole suppresses estrogen to a greater degree than anastrozole in the serum and breast tumor.
abstract.3: Concerns have been raised that greater potency may adversely affect patients' quality of life (QOL).
abstract.4: One hundred eighty-one postmenopausal women with invasive estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers were randomized to receive either 12 weeks of letrozole followed by 12 weeks of anastrozole or the reverse sequence.
abstract.5: One hundred and six received immediate adjuvant aromatase inhibitors (AIs) following surgery, and 75 received extended adjuvant therapy.
abstract.6: The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Endocrine Subscale (FACT-B-ES) QOL questionnaires were completed to assess QOL on each drug.
abstract.7: Additional side-effect profiles were collected.
abstract.8: Each patient completed a patient preference form.
abstract.9: Twenty-one patients withdrew before study end, 10/179 (5.6%) while taking letrozole and 4/173 (2.3%) while taking anastrozole (P = 0.12).
abstract.10: Tamoxifen-naïve patients had a higher mean ES (endocrine symptoms subscale) score at entry versus those having extended therapy (66.0 vs. 61.9; P = 0.001).
abstract.11: There was no significant change in FACT-B-ES (overall) scores or ES scores while patients were taking anastrozole or letrozole and no significant differences between drugs.
abstract.12: Nearly 80% of patients reported one or more side effects with either agent.
abstract.13: No differences in frequency, grade, or range of side effects were seen between drugs.
abstract.14: Of 160 patients, 49 (30.6%) preferred letrozole, 57 (35.6%) preferred anastrozole, and 54 (33.8%) had no preference (P = 0.26, Pearson's Chi-squared test).
abstract.15: In conclusion, both AIs are equally well tolerated.
abstract.16: There were no significant differences in QOL scores between the two drugs.

adaptation2.1: Previous studies showed that both anastrozole and letrozole (drugs to treat breast cancer) are well tolerated.
adaptation2.2: Letrozole reduces estrogen (a female sex hormone) more than anastrozole in the blood and breast tumor.
adaptation2.3: There are concerns that its greater strength may harm patients' quality of life (QOL).
adaptation2.4: One hundred eighty-one women who have finished their last period and with harmful estrogen-related breast cancers received either 12 weeks of letrozole followed by 12 weeks of anastrozole or the reverse.
adaptation2.5: One hundred and six received immediate, secondary aromatase inhibitors (Ais) (drugs used to treat breast cancer) after surgery. 75 received extended secondary therapy.
adaptation2.6: Hormonal-cancer-therapy-specific questionnaires were completed to measure QOL on each drug.
adaptation2.7: Descriptions of side effects were collected.
adaptation2.8: Each patient completed a patient preference form.
adaptation2.9: Twenty-one patients quit before the study's end. 10/179 (5.6%) quit while taking letrozole, and 4/173 (2.3%) quit while taking anastrozole.
adaptation2.10: Pateints treated with tamoxifen (an estrogen-influencing medication) had a higher hormonal symptom score at the start versus those with long-term therapy.
adaptation2.11: There was no change in hormonal therapy scores while patients were taking anastrozole or letrozole. There was also no significant differences between drugs.
adaptation2.12: Almost 80% of patients mentioned one or more side effects with either agent.
adaptation2.13: No difference in frequency, severity, or range of side effects were seen between drugs.
adaptation2.14: Of 160 patients, 49 (30.6%) preferred letrozole, 57 (35.6%) preferred anastrozole, and 54 (33.8%) had no preference.
adaptation2.15: In conclusion, both Ais are equally tolerated.
adaptation2.16: There were no differences in QOL scores between the two drugs.

24037977.Title: Alopecia with endocrine therapies in patients with cancer

abstract.1: Background: Whereas the frequency of alopecia to cytotoxic chemotherapies has been well described, the incidence of alopecia during endocrine therapies (i.e., anti-estrogens, aromatase inhibitors) has not been investigated.
abstract.2: Endocrine agents are widely used in the treatment and prevention of many solid tumors, principally those of the breast and prostate.
abstract.3: Adherence to these therapies is suboptimal, in part because of toxicities.
abstract.4: We performed a systematic analysis of the literature to ascertain the incidence and risk for alopecia in patients receiving endocrine therapies.
abstract.5: Results: Data from 19,430 patients in 35 clinical trials were available for analysis.
abstract.6: Of these, 13,415 patients had received endocrine treatments and 6,015 patients served as controls.
abstract.7: The incidence of all-grade alopecia ranged from 0% to 25%, with an overall incidence of 4.4% (95% confidence interval: 3.3%-5.9%).
abstract.8: The highest incidence of all-grade alopecia was observed in patients treated with tamoxifen in a phase II trial (25.4%); similarly, the overall incidence of grade 2 alopecia by meta-analysis was highest with tamoxifen (6.4%).
abstract.9: The overall relative risk of alopecia in comparison with placebo was 12.88 (p < .001), with selective estrogen receptor modulators having the highest risk.
abstract.10: Conclusion: Alopecia is a common yet underreported adverse event of endocrine-based cancer therapies.
abstract.11: Their long-term use heightens the importance of this condition on patients' quality of life.
abstract.12: These findings are critical for pretherapy counseling, the identification of risk factors, and the development of interventions that could enhance adherence and mitigate this psychosocially difficult event.

adaptation2.1: For the study's background, while the frequency of alopecia (hair loss or thinning) to powerful chemotherapies (cancer-treating treatments) has been well described, the frequency of alopecia during hormonal therapies (i.e., anti-estrogens, aromatase inhibitors used to treat breast cancer) has not been described.
adaptation2.2: Hormonal agents are widely used in the treatment and prevention of many solid tumors, mainly those of the breast and prostrate.
adaptation2.3: Sticking to these therapies is not the best, In part due to toxicities.
adaptation2.4: We analyzed scientific papers to measure the frequency and risk for alopecia in patients receiving hormonal therapies.
adaptation2.5: Data from 19,430 patients in 35 clinical trials were available for analysis.
adaptation2.6: Of these, 13,415 patients got hormonal treatments. 6,015 did not.
adaptation2.7: The frequency of any alopecia ranged from 0% to 25%, with an overall frequency of 4.4%.
adaptation2.8: The highest frequency of any alopecia was seen in patients treated with tamoxifen (an estrogen-influencing drug) in a clinical trial (25.4%). Similarly, the overall frequency of severe alopecia in the analysis was highest with tamoxifen (6.4%).
adaptation2.9: The overall risk of alopecia compared with sham treatment was 12.88, with specific estrogen-receptor influencers having the highest risk.
adaptation2.10: In conclusion, alopecia is a common yet rarely-mentioned side effect of hormonal cancer therapies.
adaptation2.11: Their long-term use increases the importance of this condition on patients' quality of life.
adaptation2.12: These findings are important for pre-therapy counseling, identifying risk factors, and creating treatments that could improve sticking to the plan and lowering this emotionally difficult event.

24197658.Title: Aromatase inhibitor therapy and hair loss among breast cancer survivors

abstract.1: The objective of this study was to examine the associations between aromatase inhibitor therapy and hair loss or hair thinning among female breast cancer survivors.
abstract.2: Data were analyzed from 851 female breast cancer survivors who responded to a hospital registry-based survey.
abstract.3: Data on hair loss, hair thinning, demographic characteristics, and health habits were based on self-report; data on aromatase inhibitor therapy were collected on the survey and verified using medical record review.
abstract.4: Logistic regression was used to estimate the odds ratios (ORs) and 95 % confidence intervals (CIs) for the associations between aromatase inhibitor therapy and the hair outcome variables adjusted for potential confounders, including age and chemotherapy treatment.
abstract.5: The results showed that 22.4 % of the breast cancer survivors reported hair loss and 31.8 % reported hair thinning.
abstract.6: In the confounder-adjusted analyses, breast cancer survivors who were within 2 years of starting aromatase inhibitor treatment at the time of survey completion were approximately two and a half times more likely to report reporting hair loss (OR 2.55; 95 % CI 1.19-5.45) or hair thinning (OR 2.33; 95 % CI 1.10-4.93) within the past 4 weeks compared to those who were never treated with an aromatase inhibitor.
abstract.7: Current aromatase inhibitor use for two or more years at the time of the survey and prior use were significantly associated with hair thinning (current users, ≥2 years: OR 1.86; prior users: OR 1.62), but not hair loss.
abstract.8: Findings from this study suggest that aromatase inhibitor use is associated with an increased risk of hair loss and hair thinning independent of chemotherapy and age; these side effects are likely due to the substantial decrease in estrogen concentrations resulting from treatment with this drug.
abstract.9: Future research should focus on examining these associations in a prospective manner using more detailed and objective measures of hair loss and thinning.

adaptation2.1: This study examines the links between aromatase inhibitor therapy (drugs commonly used to treat breast cancer) and hair loss or hair thinning among female breast cancer survivors.
adaptation2.2: We analyzed data from 851 female breast cancer survivors who responded to a hospital survey.
adaptation2.3: Data on hair loss, hair thinning, background information, and health habits were self-reported. Data on aromatase inhibitor therapy were collected by the survey and verified with medical records.
adaptation2.4: The relationship between aromatase inhibitor therapy and hair outcome was mathematically estimated and adjusted for possible misleading variables, like age and chemotherapy treatment.
adaptation2.5: 22.4% of the breast cancer survivors reported hair loss. 31.8% reported hair thinning.
adaptation2.6: Breast cancer survivors who were within 2 years of starting aromatase inhibitor treatment at the time of the survey were around two and a half times more likely to report hair loss or thinning in the past 4 weeks compared to those never treated with an aromatase inhibitor.
adaptation2.7: Current aromatase inhibitor use for 2 or more years at the time of the survey and past use were linked with hair thinning but not hair loss.
adaptation2.8: Findings from the study suggest that aromatase inhibitor use is linked with an increased risk of hair loss and thinning regardless of chemotherapy and age. These side effects are likely from the reduction in estrogen (a female sex hormone) from the drug treatment.
adaptation2.9: Future research should examine the links in a future-oriented manner with more detailed and measurable measures of hair loss and thinning.

25473228.Title: Pattern Alopecia during Hormonal Anticancer Therapy in Patients with Breast Cancer

abstract.1: We report five cases of pattern alopecia in female patients who are undergoing hormonal anticancer therapy for the prevention of recurrence of breast cancer after surgery.
abstract.2: Three patients demonstrated male pattern alopecia with receding frontal hairlines, and two patients demonstrated female pattern alopecia without receding hairlines.
abstract.3: The detailed clinical history showed that the pattern alopecia of the patients developed after the full recovery of global hair loss of the entire scalp due to previous cytotoxic chemotherapy.
abstract.4: All of the adjuvant hormonal anticancer drugs that were used in the patients are antiestrogenic agents, either aromatase inhibitors or selective estrogen receptor modulators.
abstract.5: Considering androgen effect on the hair follicles of the fronto-parietal scalp, the androgen-estrogen imbalance caused by the drugs was thought to be the reason for the onset of pattern alopecia in the patients.
abstract.6: In general, alopecia that develops during cytotoxic chemotherapy is well known to both physicians and patients; however, the diagnosis of pattern alopecia during hormonal anticancer therapy in breast cancer patients seems to be overlooked.

adaptation2.1: We report 5 cases of common alopecia (hair loss or thinning) in female patients undergoing hormonal anticancer therapy to prevent reoccuring breast cancer after surgery.
adaptation2.2: Three patients showed alopecia common to males with receding hairlines in the front. Two patients showed alopecia common to females without receding hairlines.
adaptation2.3: The patient history showed that common alopecia of the patients developed after full recovery of complete hair loss of the scalp due to prior, severe chemotherapy (cancer treatment).
adaptation2.4: All of the secondary hormonal anticancer drugs used in patients are antiestrogenic agents (which influence levels of estrogen, a female sex hormone). These agents include aromatase inhibitors or selective estrogen receptor modulators.
adaptation2.5: Considering the effect of hormones on hair follicles in the front scalp, the estrogen-hormone imbalance caused by the drugs was thought to be the reason for visible alopecia in patients.
adaptation2.6: In general, alopecia that develops during severe chemotherapy (cancer therapy) is known to physicians and patients. However, the identification of alopecia during hormonal anticancer therapy in breast cancer patients seems to be overlooked.

26108239.Title: Adjuvant aromatase inhibitor therapy in early breast cancer: what factors lead patients to discontinue treatment?

abstract.1: Background: Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) are standard hormone therapy (HT) for the adjuvant treatment of postmenopausal endocrine-sensitive early breast cancer.
abstract.2: Treatment discontinuation due to toxicity is an important issue that may help clinicians identify effective clinical interventions to allow adequate treatment duration.
abstract.3: We reviewed the main reasons for interruption of AIs at our institution from 2006 to 2009.
abstract.4: Methods: 236 patients treated with adjuvant AIs were eligible for analysis.
abstract.5: Median age was 64 years (35-89), median follow-up 53 months (6-60).
abstract.6: Prior adjuvant chemotherapy was taxane based in 47 patients and anthracycline based in 43 patients.
abstract.7: 118 patients had received letrozole, 101 anastrozole, and 17 exemestane.
abstract.8: Results: Twenty-four patients (10%) needed discontinuation of the first AI assigned as a result of toxicity.
abstract.9: Grade 2/3 arthralgia was the main reason for discontinuation in 13/24 patients.
abstract.10: No differences in the incidence of arthralgia were noted in patients who had received taxanes or anthracyclines.
abstract.11: Headache, alopecia, itching, diffuse skin reaction, allergic reaction with hypertensive crisis, xerostomia and xerophthalmia, insomnia and somnolence were the other reasons for discontinuation.
abstract.12: In multivariate logistic regression analysis, age (65 years) and HT were independent factors associated with the onset of arthralgia (p = 0.006 and p = 0.008, respectively; OR 2.65, 95% CI 1.32-5.31).
abstract.13: Alternative HT (AI or tamoxifen) was offered to patients who wanted or needed to permanently interrupt the ongoing drug.
abstract.14: Conclusions: In our analysis, 10% of patients discontinued the first AI assigned because of toxicity.
abstract.15: Median time course of all adverse events leading to HT discontinuation was 155 days and 135 days for arthralgia.
abstract.16: A switch to alternative HT with toxicity monitoring is a recommended option for avoiding premature and permanent interruption of an effective treatment.

adaptation2.1: For the study's background, aromatase inhibitors (Ais) are common hormone therapy (HT) for the secondary treatment of postmenopausal hormone-sensitive early breast cancer.
adaptation2.2: Treatment stoppage due to toxicitiy is an important issue that may help clinicians find effective clinical treatments to allow proper treatment duration.
adaptation2.3: We reviewed the main reasors for interruption of Ais at our center from 2006 to 2009.
adaptation2.4: For the study's methods, 236 patients treated with secondary Ais were analyzed.
adaptation2.5: Average age was 64 years (ranging from 35 to 89 years). Average treatment follow-up was 53 months (ranging from 6 to 60).
adaptation2.6: Prior secondary chemotherapy (cancer-specific drugs) was taxane for 47 patients and anthracycline for 43 patients.
adaptation2.7: 118 patients received letrozole, 101 anastrozole, and 17 exemestane (breast cancer-treating drugs).
adaptation2.8: Twenty-four patients (10%) needed stoppage of the first AI assigned due to toxicity.
adaptation2.9: Severe arthralgia (joint stiffness) was the main reason for stoppage in 13/24 patients.
adaptation2.10: No differences in the frequency of arthralgia were noted in patients who received taxanes or anthracyclines.
adaptation2.11: Headache, alopecia (hair loss or thinning), itching, skin reactions, allergic reactions with high-blood-pressure events, xerostomia (dry mouth), xerophthalmia (eye dryness), lack of sleep, and sleepiness were other reasons for stopping treatment.
adaptation2.12: With mathematical analysis, age (65 years) and HT were linked with the start of arthralgia.
adaptation2.13: Alternative HT (AI or tamoxifen - an estrogen-influencing drug) was offered to patients who wanted or needed to permanently stop the ongoing drug.
adaptation2.14: In conclusion, 10% of patients stopped the first AI assigned because of toxicity.
adaptation2.15: Average time course of all side effects leading to HT stoppage was 155 days and 135 days for arthralgia.
adaptation2.16: A switch to another HT with toxicity monitoring is recommended for avoiding premature and permanent stoppage of an effective treatment.

27247882.Title: Management of hair loss associated with endocrine therapy in patients with breast cancer: an overview

abstract.1: Endocrine therapy-induced hair loss (ETIHL) associated with aromatase inhibitors and tamoxifen treatment is currently mostly reported but remained an unresolved therapeutic issue in patients with breast cancer (BC) since the number of studies regarding the management is limited in literature.
abstract.2: Herein we investigated the possible causes of this clinical problem and its relation with endocrine therapies widely used for BC survivors and made some modest practical recommendations in light of the literature review in order to provide an optimal management.
abstract.3: On the basis of literature findings, common causes of hair loss apart from endocrine therapies should be investigated with an initial evaluation workup and then should be corrected, if observed.
abstract.4: Treatment with topical 5-alpha reductase inhibitors and supplementation of Vitamin C and omega-3 fatty acids are likely appeared to be the most appropriate treatment agents for ETIHL without causing an adverse effect on BC prognosis.
abstract.5: However, more prospective, randomised, placebo-controlled studied are required in order to confirm our results and also identify the clinical effects of this problem on patients with BC.

adaptation2.1: Endocrine therapy-induced hair loss (ETIHL) (hair loss from hormonal therapy) linked with aromatase inhibitors (drugs used to treat breast cancer) and tamoxifen (estrogen-influencing medication) is reported but remains unsolved in patients with breast cancer (BC). This is largely because the number of studies regarding this hair loss management is limited.
adaptation2.2: We checked the possible causes of this medical problem and its link to hormonal therapies used for BC survivors. We also made practical recommendations based on relevant medical studies to provide optimal management.
adaptation2.3: Based on medical papers, common causes of hair loss besdies hormonal therapies should be checked with a starting evaluation workup and then corrected if found.
adaptation2.4: Treatment with 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (drugs for treating hair loss) applied on skin and Vitamin C and omega-3 fatty acid supplements may be the best treatment for ETIHL without causing serious side effects on BC recovery.
adaptation2.5: However, more in-depth studies are needed to confirm our results and identify the effects of this problem on BC patients.

29641806.Title: Endocrine Therapy-Induced Alopecia in Patients With Breast Cancer

abstract.1: Importance: Endocrine therapy-induced alopecia (EIA) has been anecdotally reported but not systematically described.
abstract.2: Objective: To characterize EIA in patients with breast cancer.
abstract.3: Design, setting, and participants: Retrospective cohort study of 112 patients with breast cancer, diagnosed with EIA from January 1, 2009, to December 31, 2016, the patients were examined at the dermatology service in a large tertiary care hospital and comprehensive cancer center.
abstract.4: Main outcomes and measures: The clinical features, alopecia-related quality of life (QoL), and response to minoxidil of EIA in patients with breast cancer were assessed.
abstract.5: Data from the Hairdex Questionnaire was used to assess the impact of the alopecia on patients QoL.
abstract.6: Higher score indicates lower QoL (0-100 score).
abstract.7: Efficacy of minoxidil was measured at 3 or 6 months by a single-blinded investigator through standardized clinical photographs of the scalp.
abstract.8: Results: A total of 112 female patients with breast cancer were included (median [range] age, 60 [34-90] years).
abstract.9: A total of 104 patients (93%) had standardized clinical photographs; of these, 59 patients (53%) had trichoscopy images available at baseline, and 46 patients (41%) were assessed for response to minoxidil.
abstract.10: Alopecia was attributed to aromatase inhibitors in 75 patients (67%) and tamoxifen in 37 (33%).
abstract.11: Severity was grade 1 in 96 of 104 patients (92%), and the pattern was similar to androgenetic alopecia.
abstract.12: The predominant trichoscopic feature at baseline was the presence of vellus hairs and intermediate- and thick-diameter terminal hair shafts.
abstract.13: A negative impact on QoL was reported, with a higher effect in the emotion domain according to the Hairdex score (mean [SD], 41.8 [21.3]; P < .001).
abstract.14: After treatment with topical minoxidil, moderate or significant improvement in alopecia was observed in 37 of 46 patients (80%).
abstract.15: Conclusions and relevance: Endocrine therapies are associated with a pattern alopecia similar to androgenetic-type, consistent with the mechanism of action of causal agents.
abstract.16: A significant negative impact on QoL was reported by patients, despite mostly mild alopecia severity.

adaptation2.1: The study's importance is based on the fact that endocrine therapy-induced alopecia (EIA) (hair loss or thinning from hormonal therapy) has been mentioned but not measured.
adaptation2.2: The study's objective is to describe EIA thoroughly in patients with breast cancer.
adaptation2.3: The study's design is a study of 112 patients with breast cancer, diagnosed with EIA from January 1, 2009 to December 31, 2016. The patients were examined at a skin center in a large, specialized hospital and professional cancer center.
adaptation2.4: The study's main variables included common hospital measures, hair-loss- or hair-thinning-related quality of life (QoL), and reaction to minoxidil (hair regrowth medication) of EIA in patients with breast cancer.
adaptation2.5: We used data from the Hairdex Questionnaire (a questionnaire for disease-specific quality of life measurements) to measure the impact of hair loss or thinning (alopecia) on patients QoL.
adaptation2.6: Higher scores indicate lower QoL (0-100 score).
adaptation2.7: The success of minoxidil was measured at 3 or 6 months by an investigator unaware of the treatment groups through standard photographs of the scalp.
adaptation2.8: 112 female patients with breast cancer were included. Their median age was 60 years with a range from 34-90 years.
adaptation2.9: 104 patients (93%) had standard photographs. Of these, 59 patients (53%) had images from special hair and scalp evaluations at the start. 46 patients (41%) were measured for response to minoxidil.
adaptation2.10: Alopecia was linked to aromatase inhibitors in 75 patients (67%) and tamoxifen (estrogen-influencing medication) in 37 (33%).
adaptation2.11: Severity was low in 96 of 104 patients (92%). The pattern was similar to common, receding hair loss.
adaptation2.12: The most common scalp and hair-related feature at the start were peach fuzz and mid- and thick, long hairs on the scalp.
adaptation2.13: QoL was negatively reported, especially in the emotional part of life.
adaptation2.14: After treatment with minoxidil on the skin, medium or noticeable improvement in hair loss and thinning was seen in 37 of 46 patients (80%).
adaptation2.15: In conclusion, hormonal therapies are linked with commonly-seen hair loss and thinning, similar to agents that actively cause alopecia.
adaptation2.16: Despite mostly mild alopecia, QoL was negatively impacted for patients.

30464397.Title: Pharmacokinetic evaluation of a transdermal anastrozole-in-adhesive formulation

abstract.1: Background and objective: Anastrozole is a well-established active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) used for the treatment of hormone-sensitive breast cancer (BC) in postmenopausal women.
abstract.2: However, treatment with the only available oral formulation is often associated with concentration-dependent serious side effects such as hot flashes, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, nausea, diarrhea, headache, and others.
abstract.3: In contrast, a sustained-release system for the local application of anastrozole should minimize these serious adverse drug reactions.
abstract.4: Methods: Anastrozole-in-adhesive transdermal drug delivery systems (TDDS) were developed offering efficient loading, avoidance of inhomogeneity or crystallization of the drug, the desired controlled release kinetics, storage stability, easy handling, mechanical stability, and sufficient stickiness on the skin.
abstract.5: In vitro continuous anastrozole release profiles were studied in Franz diffusion cells.
abstract.6: In vivo, consecutive drug plasma kinetics from the final anastrozole transdermal system was tested in beagle dogs.
abstract.7: For drug analysis, a specific validated liquid chromatography- mass spectrometry method using fragment ion detection was developed and validated.
abstract.8: Results: After efficient drug loading, a linear and sustained 65% drug release from the TDDS over 48 h was obtained.
abstract.9: In vivo data showed a favorable anastrozole plasma concentration-time course, avoiding side effect-associated peak concentrations as obtained after oral administration but matching therapeutic plasma levels up to 72 h.
abstract.10: Conclusion: These results provide the basis for establishing the transdermal application of anastrozole with improved pharmacokinetics and drug safety as novel therapeutic approach and promising option to treat human BC by decreasing the high burden of unwanted side effects.

adaptation2.1: For background, anastrozole is an important drug ingredient for treatment of hormone-sensitive breast cancer (BC) in women who have finished their last period.
adaptation2.2: However, treatment with the only available drug taken by mouth is linked with serious side effects that worsen with greater doses. These side effects include hot flashes, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, nausea, diarrhea, headache, and others.
adaptation2.3: In contrast, a steady release of anastrozole could minimize these serious side effects from the drug.
adaptation2.4: Anastrozole administered by a patch on the skin was created for efficient administration, avoiding drug crystals in the body, desired drug release, storage ease, easy handling, stability, and stickiness on the skin.
adaptation2.5: Continuous anastrozole treatment was studied in cells designed to measure the success of oils, creams, and gels.
adaptation2.6: Drug reactions in blood from the final anastrozole treatment on skin was tested in beagle dogs.
adaptation2.7: To analyze the drug, a specific filtration method was created and verified.
adaptation2.8: After enough drug exposure, a sustained 65% drug release from the skin treatment over 48 hours was obtained.
adaptation2.9: Data in living animals showed good anastrozole blood concentration overtime, avoiding the worst of side effects linked with treatment by mouth but matching its helpful blood levels up to 72 hours.
adaptation2.10: In conclusion, applying anastrozole by skin shows improved drug reactions and safety. The treatment is a promising option to treat human BC by reducing unwanted side effects.

32869880.Title: Aromatase inhibitor-induced hair loss in two adolescents

abstract.1: Hair loss and thinning are possible complications in those undergoing endocrine therapies with aromatase inhibitors.
abstract.2: Alopecia in pediatric patients undergoing endocrine therapy has not been previously reported.
abstract.3: We describe two adolescents, 14 and 16 years of age, who developed androgenetic alopecia following treatment with anastrozole for idiopathic short stature.
abstract.4: Accordingly, the possible adverse event of alopecia should be considered in the pediatric population undergoing treatment with aromatase inhibitors.

adaptation2.1: Hair loss and thinning are possible side effects in those undergoing hormonal therapies with aromatase inhibitors (drugs commonly used to treat breast cancer).
adaptation2.2: Alopecia (hair loss and thinning) in young patients undergoing hormonal therapy has not been previously studied.
adaptation2.3: We describe two adolescents, 14 and 16 years of age, who got androgenetic alopecia (common hair loss or thinning) after receiving treatment with anastrozole (a durg usually used to treat breast cancer) for unusally short height.
adaptation2.4: Therefore, the possible side effect of alopecia should be considered in the young population undergoing treatment with aromatase inhibitors.

31765958.Title: Mutation spectrum of the SCN1A gene in a Hungarian population with epilepsy

abstract.1: Purpose: The vast majority of mutations responsible for epilepsy syndromes such as genetic epilepsy with febrile seizures plus (GEFS+) and Dravet syndrome (DS) occur in the gene encoding the type 1 alpha subunit of neuronal voltage-gated sodium channel (SCN1A).
abstract.2: Methods: 63 individuals presenting with either DS or GEFS + syndrome phenotype were screened for SCN1A gene mutation using Sanger sequencing and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA).
abstract.3: Results: Our research study identified 15 novel pathogen mutations in the SCN1A gene of which 12 appeared to be missense mutations with addition of two frameshift-deletions and one in-frame deletion.
abstract.4: The distribution of clinical phenotypes in patients carrying SCN1A mutations was as follows: twelve patients had classical DS, three patients had GEFS + syndrome and two relatives of DS patients were suffering from febrile seizures.
abstract.5: Conclusions: Our study highlights the phenotypic and genotypic heterogeneities of DS and GEFS + with the important aim of gaining a deeper understanding of SCN1A-related disorders.
abstract.6: This study also represents the first genetic analysis of the SCN1A gene in a Hungarian cohort with the DS and GEFS + syndrome phenotype.

adaptation2.1: For the study's purpose, the vast majority of mutations for epilepsy (a brain disease causing seizures) syndromes such as genetic epilepsy with fever-related seizures plus (GEFS+) and Dravet syndrome (DS) (lifelong epilepsy) occur in the specific gene SCN1A.
adaptation2.2: For the study's methods, 63 individuals with either DS or GEFS + syndrome were tested for SCN1A gene mutation using gene labeling techniques.
adaptation2.3: Our research study found 15 new disease-cuasing mutations in the SCN1A gene, of which 12 appeared to be mutations with three deletions, two of which shifted the entire gene.
adaptation2.4: The distribution of clinical physical effects in patients carrying SCN1A mutations was as follows: twelve patients had classical DS, three patients had GEFS + syndrome and two relatives of DS patients were suffering from fever-related seizures.
adaptation2.5: In conclusion, our study highlights the physical effects and gene-related differences of DS and GEFS + with the important aim of gaining a deeper understanding of SCN1A-related disorders.
adaptation2.6: This study also represents the first genetic analysis of the SCN1A gene in a Hungarian group with the DS and GEFS + syndrome physical make-up.

32032478.Title: Modifier genes in SCN1A-related epilepsy syndromes

abstract.1: Background: SCN1 A is one of the most important epilepsy-related genes, with pathogenic variants leading to a range of phenotypes with varying disease severity.
abstract.2: Different modifying factors have been hypothesized to influence SCN1A-related phenotypes.
abstract.3: We investigate the presence of rare and more common variants in epilepsy-related genes as potential modifiers of SCN1A-related disease severity.
abstract.4: Methods: 87 patients with SCN1A-related epilepsy were investigated.
abstract.5: Whole-exome sequencing was performed by the Beijing Genomics Institute (BGI).
abstract.6: Functional variants in 422 genes associated with epilepsy and/or neuronal excitability were investigated.
abstract.7: Differences in proportions of variants between the epilepsy genes and four control gene sets were calculated, and compared to the proportions of variants in the same genes in the ExAC database.
abstract.8: Results: Statistically significant excesses of variants in epilepsy genes were observed in the complete cohort and in the combined group of mildly and severely affected patients, particularly for variants with minor allele frequencies of <0.05.
abstract.9: Patients with extreme phenotypes showed much greater excesses of epilepsy gene variants than patients with intermediate phenotypes.
abstract.10: Conclusion: Our results indicate that relatively common variants in epilepsy genes, which would not necessarily be classified as pathogenic, may play a large role in modulating SCN1A phenotypes.
abstract.11: They may modify the phenotypes of both severely and mildly affected patients.
abstract.12: Our results may be a first step toward meaningful testing of modifier gene variants in regular diagnostics for individual patients, to provide a better estimation of disease severity for newly diagnosed patients.

adaptation2.1: Background: SCN1 A is one of the most important epilepsy-related genes, with disease-causing variants leading to a range of physical effects with varying disease severity.
adaptation2.2: Different attributes have been hypothesized to influence SCN1A-related physical effects.
adaptation2.3: We investigate the presence of rare and more common gene types in epilepsy-related genes as possible influencers of SCN1A-related disease severity.
adaptation2.4: In the study's methods, 87 patients with SCN1A-related epilepsy were investigated.
adaptation2.5: Whole-body gene labeling was performed by the Beijing Genomics Institute (BGI).
adaptation2.6: Functional gene types in 422 genes linked with epilepsy and/or brain excitability were checked.
adaptation2.7: Differences in amounts of gene types between the epilepsy genes and four unrelated gene sets were calculated and compared to the amounts of gene types in the same genes in a specific gene database.
adaptation2.8: The study results show that excesses of gene types in epilepsy genes were observed in the complete group and in the combined group of mildly and severely affected patients, espeically for gene types with minor gene frequencies of <0.05.
adaptation2.9: Patients with severe physical effects showed much greater excesses of epilepsy gene types than patients with medium physical effects.
adaptation2.10: In conclusion, our results show that relatively common gene types in epilepsy genes, which would not necessarily be classified as disease-causing, may play a large role in influencing SCN1A physical effects.
adaptation2.11: They may influence the physical effects of both severely and mildly affected patients.
adaptation2.12: Our results may be a first step toward meaningful testing of influencing gene types in regular diagnostics for individual patients, to provide a better estimation of disease severity for newly identified patients.

33728858.Title: Experience in the management of patients with genetic epilepsies and epileptic encephalopathies in the outpatient practice

abstract.1: Objective: To describe the spectrum of being detected gene mutations in patients with epilepsy in clinical practice of neurologists specializing in epilepsy with an analysis of diagnosed epileptic syndromes, the characteristics of seizures, the timing of a genetic diagnosis, options and treatment effectiveness.
abstract.2: Patients and methods: The study included 100 patients (40 boys, 60 girls) with epilepsy and/or epileptic encephalopathy and a gene mutation identified.
abstract.3: The average age was 6.9Â±5.1 years.
abstract.4: Through remote access, epilepsy specialists filled out a specially designed unified table containing information from outpatient case history.
abstract.5: Results and discussion: There are patients with a wide range of gene mutations, the leading of which is a mutation in the SCN1A gene (15%).
abstract.6: The main method (85%) of detection remains the sequencing of the last generation in the Â«Hereditary EpilepsyÂ» panel.
abstract.7: Years pass from the onset of the disease to the genetic diagnosis (Me - 3 years).
abstract.8: In most cases, patients with severe (52% have epileptic encephalopathy, 88% have developmental disorders) and pharmacoresistant (mean amount of anti-epileptic drugs - 3.8Â±2.2, multitherapy - 70%) syndromes have undergone genetic testing.
abstract.9: In the treatment of these patients epileptologists are increasingly (52%) use alternative methods: steroids, ketogenic diet and others.
abstract.10: The absence of seizures was observed only in 46% of patients.
abstract.11: Conclusion: Thus, in the outpatient practice of epileptologists, patients with a wide range of gene mutations are found.
abstract.12: As a rule, these are patients with severe, therapy-resistant epileptic syndromes.

adaptation2.2: The study included 100 patients (40 boys, 60 girls) with epilepsy and/or epileptic encephalopathy (epilepsy that leads to brain damage) and a gene mutation identified.
adaptation2.3: The average age was 6.9Â±5.1 years.
adaptation2.4: Through remote access, epilepsy specialists filled out a specially designed data table containing information from patient history.
adaptation2.5: The results show there are patients with a wide range of gene mutations, the leading of which is a mutation in the specific gene called SCN1A (15%).
adaptation2.6: The main method (85%) of detection remains the gene labeling of the last group in the Â«Hereditary EpilepsyÂ panel, groups of genes linked with epilepsy.
adaptation2.7: Years pass from the start of the disease to the genetic diagnosis (average number is 3 years).
adaptation2.8: In most cases, patients with severe (52% have epileptic encephalopathy, 88% have growth disorders) and drug-resistant (average amount of anti-epileptic drugs - 3.8Â±2.2, multi-treatment - 70%) diseases have undergone genetic testing.
adaptation2.9: In the treatment of these patients, epilepsy specialists are increasingly (52%) using alternative methods: steroids, ketogenic (low-carb) diet and others.

33820833.Title: Phenotypic spectrum and genomics of undiagnosed arthrogryposis multiplex congenita

abstract.1: Background: Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC) is characterised by congenital joint contractures in two or more body areas.
abstract.2: AMC exhibits wide phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity.
abstract.3: Our goals were to improve the genetic diagnosis rates of AMC, to evaluate the added value of whole exome sequencing (WES) compared with targeted exome sequencing (TES) and to identify new genes in 315 unrelated undiagnosed AMC families.
abstract.4: Methods: Several genomic approaches were used including genetic mapping of disease loci in multiplex or consanguineous families, TES then WES.
abstract.5: Sanger sequencing was performed to identify or validate variants.
abstract.6: Results: We achieved disease gene identification in 52.7% of AMC index patients including nine recently identified genes (CNTNAP1, MAGEL2, ADGRG6, ADCY6, GLDN, LGI4, LMOD3, UNC50 and SCN1A).
abstract.7: Moreover, we identified pathogenic variants in ASXL3 and STAC3 expanding the phenotypes associated with these genes.
abstract.8: The most frequent cause of AMC was a primary involvement of skeletal muscle (40%) followed by brain (22%).
abstract.9: The most frequent mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive (66.3% of patients).
abstract.10: In sporadic patients born to non-consanguineous parents (n=60), de novo dominant autosomal or X linked variants were observed in 30 of them (50%).
abstract.11: Conclusion: New genes recently identified in AMC represent 21% of causing genes in our cohort.
abstract.12: A high proportion of de novo variants were observed indicating that this mechanism plays a prominent part in this developmental disease.
abstract.13: Our data showed the added value of WES when compared with TES due to the larger clinical spectrum of some disease genes than initially described and the identification of novel genes.

adaptation2.1: Background: Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC) is characterised by deforemed, rigid joints at birth in two or more body areas.
adaptation2.2: AMC exhibits wide physical attributes and genetic types.
adaptation2.3: Our goals were to improve the genetic identification rates of AMC, to test the added value of whole gene labeling compared with targeted gene labeling and to identify new genes in 315 unrelated undiagnosed AMC families.
adaptation2.4: Several gene-related tools were used including gene mapping of disease-related genes in various groups, first in targeted gene labeling and then whole gene labeling.
adaptation2.5: Gene sequencing was performed to identify or verify gene variants.
adaptation2.6: We achieved disease gene identification in 52.7% of AMC patients including nine recently identified genes (CNTNAP1, MAGEL2, ADGRG6, ADCY6, GLDN, LGI4, LMOD3, UNC50 and SCN1A).
adaptation2.7: Moreover, we identified disease-causing variants in ASXL3 and STAC3, expanding the physical attributes linked with these genes.
adaptation2.8: The most frequent cause of AMC was linked to skeletal muscle (40%) followed by brain (22%).
adaptation2.9: The most frequent mode of inheritance is from both parents (66.3% of patients).
adaptation2.10: In irregular patients born to non-related parents (n=60), new, inherited or sex chromosome linked types were observed in 30 of them (50%).
adaptation2.11: In conclusion, new genes recently identified in AMC represent 21% of causing genes in our group.
adaptation2.12: A high amount of new gene types were observed, indicating that genes plays a prominent part in this developmental disease.
adaptation2.13: Our data showed the added value of whole gene labeling when compared with targeted gene labeling due to the larger medical variance of some disease genes than expected and the identification of new genes.

33851778.Title: Parental mosaicism in de novo neurodevelopmental diseases

abstract.1: Neurodevelopmental diseases are increasingly recognized to be caused by "de novo" variants with the expanding use of next-generation sequencing.
abstract.2: The apparent de novo variants may actually be low-level hereditary parental mosaic variants, which could increase the recurrence risk of disease by >50% and is thought to be an underappreciated cause of neurodevelopmental diseases.
abstract.3: Our study aimed to investigate the frequency of parental mosaicism in "de novo" neurodevelopmental diseases.
abstract.4: A total of 237 patients (and parents) with neurodevelopmental diseases carrying apparent de novo pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants were recruited consecutively.
abstract.5: Deep next-generation sequencing was performed on parental samples to identify parental mosaicism.
abstract.6: Fourteen parental disease-causing mosaicism variants (3.0%) in 11 genes were detected with alternate allele frequency (AAF) 0.22%-34%.
abstract.7: Three parents showed milder clinical phenotypes than their offspring with relatively high AAF (23.33%, 25%, 34% separately).
abstract.8: One recurrent variant was identified prenatally.
abstract.9: A review of cohort study on parental mosaicism in neurodevelopmental diseases was performed.
abstract.10: Our study highlights that identifying the parental mosaic disease-causing variants especially the low-level mosaicism will contribute to improving the accuracy of genetic counseling and prenatal diagnosis for reproductive risks.

adaptation2.1: Brain-related development (neurodevelopment) diseases are increasingly recognized to be caused by new gene mutations (de novo variants) with the use of state-of-the-art gene labeling.
adaptation2.2: These de novo variants may actually be inherited, which could increase the reapparance risk of disease by >50% and is thought to be an underappreciated cause of neurodevelopment diseases.
adaptation2.3: Our study aimed to find the amount of inheritance in "de novo" neurodevelopmental diseases.
adaptation2.4: A total of 237 patients (and parents) with neurodevelopmental diseases carrying apparent de novo disease-causing (pathogenic) or likely pathogenic variants were included.
adaptation2.5: Gene labeling was performed on parental samples to identify parental gene make-up.
adaptation2.6: Fourteen parental disease-causing gene types (3.0%) in 11 genes were detected with the amount of gene types ranging from 0.22%-34%.
adaptation2.7: Three parents showed milder disease-related physical attributes than their offspring with relatively high amounts of gene types (23.33%, 25%, 34% separately).
adaptation2.8: One reoccuring gene type was identified before birth.
adaptation2.9: A review of group study on gene inheritance in neurodevelopmental diseases was performed.
adaptation2.10: Our study highlights that identifying the inherited disease-causing gene types will contribute to improving the accuracy of genetic treatment and before-birth diagnosis for reproductive risks.

34135856.Title: CACNA1A-Linked Hemiplegic Migraine in GLUT 1 Deficiency Syndrome: A Case Report

abstract.1: Background: Glucose-transporter-1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1-DS), due to SLC2A1 gene mutation, is characterized by early-onset seizures, which are often drug-resistant, developmental delay, and hypotonia.
abstract.2: Hemiplegic migraine (HM) is a rare form of migraine, defined by headache associated with transient hemiplegia, and can be caused by mutations in either CACNA1A, ATP1A2, or SCN1A.
abstract.3: Paroxysmal movements, other transient neurological disorders, or hemiplegic events can occur in GLUT1-DS patients with a mild phenotype.
abstract.4: Case: We report on a girl with GLUT1-DS, due to SLC2A1 mutation, with a mild phenotype.
abstract.5: In early childhood, she developed epilepsy and mild cognitive impairment, balance disorders, and clumsiness.
abstract.6: At the age of 9, the patient reported a first hemiplegic episode, which regressed spontaneously.
abstract.7: Over the next 3 years, two similar episodes occurred, accompanied by headache.
abstract.8: Therefore, in the hypothesis of HM, genetic testing was performed and CACNA1A mutation was identified.
abstract.9: The treatment with Lamotrigine avoided the recurrence of HM episodes.
abstract.10: Discussion: To our knowledge, among the several cases of GLUT1-DS with HM symptoms described in the literature, genetic testing was only performed in two of them, which eventually proved to be negative.
abstract.11: In all other cases, no other genes except for SLC2A1 were examined.
abstract.12: Consequently, our patient would be the first description of GLUT1-DS with HM due to CACNA1A mutation.
abstract.13: We would emphasize the importance of performing specific genetic testing in patients with GLUT1-DS with symptoms evocative of HM, which may allow clinicians to use specific pharmacotherapy.

adaptation2.1: Background: Glucose-transporter-1 deficiency syndrome (GLUT1-DS), an inability to transport sugar in the blood due to a change in the specific gene SLC2A1, is characterized by early-onset seizures, which are often drug-resistant, delay proper growth, and reduce muscle tone.
adaptation2.2: Hemiplegic migraine (HM) is a rare form of migraine, defined by headache linked with temporary paralysis on one side of the body (hemiplegia). It can be caused by mutations in either CACNA1A, ATP1A2, or SCN1A, specific genes.
adaptation2.3: Paroxysmal movements (or suddent fits), other temporary brain-related disorders, or hemiplegic events can occur in GLUT1-DS patients with mild effects.
adaptation2.4: We describe a girl with GLUT1-DS, due to SLC2A1 mutation, with mild effects.
adaptation2.5: In early childhood, she developed epilepsy and mild intelligence impairment, balance disorders, and clumsiness.
adaptation2.6: At the age of 9, the patient reported a first hemiplegic episode, which healed randomly.
adaptation2.7: Over the next 3 years, two similar episodes occurred, followed by headache.
adaptation2.8: Therefore, in the theory of HM, genetic testing was performed and a specific CACNA1A gene mutation was found.
adaptation2.9: The treatment with Lamotrigine (anti-seizure medication) avoided the reapparance of HM episodes.
adaptation2.10: To our knowledge, among the several cases of GLUT1-DS with HM symptoms in the medical studies, genetic testing was only performed in two of them, which eventually found nothing.
adaptation2.11: In all other cases, no other genes except for SLC2A1 were examined.
adaptation2.12: Thus, our patient would be the first description of GLUT1-DS with HM due to the CACNA1A gene mutation.
adaptation2.13: We would highlihgt the importance of performing specific genetic testing in patients with GLUT1-DS with symptoms similar to HM, which may allow clinicians to use specific drugs.

34395220.Title: Genetic Diagnosis in Children with Epilepsy and Developmental Disorders by Targeted Gene Panel Analysis in a Developing Country

abstract.1: Background and purpose: In childhood epilepsy, genetic etiology is increasingly recognized in recent years with the advent of next generation sequencing.
abstract.2: This has broadened the scope of precision medicine in intractable epilepsy, particularly epileptic encephalopathy (EE).
abstract.3: Developmental disorder (DD) is an integral part of childhood uncontrolled epilepsy.
abstract.4: This study was performed to investigate the genetic etiology of childhood epilepsy and DD.
abstract.5: Methods: In this study, 40 children with epilepsy and DD with positive genetic mutation were included retrospectively.
abstract.6: It was done in a tertiary care referral hospital of Bangladesh from January 2019 to December 2020.
abstract.7: Genetic study was done by next generation sequencing.
abstract.8: In all cases electroencephalography, neuroimaging was done and reviewed.
abstract.9: Results: In total, 40 children were enrolled and the average age was 41.4Â±35.850 months with a male predominance (67.5%).
abstract.10: Generalized seizure was the predominant type of seizure.
abstract.11: Regarding the association, intellectual disability and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder was common.
abstract.12: Seventeen cases had genetically identified early infantile EE and common mutations observed were SCN1A (3), SCN8A (2), SLC1A2 (2), KCNT1 (2), and etc.
abstract.13: Five patients of progressive myoclonic epilepsy were diagnosed and the mutations identified were in KCTD7, MFSD8, and CLN6 genes.
abstract.14: Three cases had mitochondrial gene mutation (MT-ND5, MT-CYB).
abstract.15: Some rare syndromes like Gibbs syndrome, KohlschÃ¼tter-TÃ¶nz syndrome, Cockayne syndrome, Pitt-Hopkins syndrome and cerebral creatine deficiency were diagnosed.
abstract.16: Conclusions: This is the first study from Bangladesh on genetics of epilepsy and DD.
abstract.17: This will help to improve the understanding of genetics epilepsy of this region as well as contribute in administering precision medicine in these patients.

adaptation2.1: For the study's background, in childhood epilepsy, genetic causes are increasingly recognized in recent years with the use of gene labeling or sequencing.
adaptation2.2: This has increased the scope of individualized medicine in unmanageable epileptic seizures or epilepsy, particularly epileptic encephalopathy (EE) (epilepsy that damages the brain).
adaptation2.3: Developmental disorder (DD) (impairments in a child's growth) is an important part of childhood uncontrolled epilepsy.
adaptation2.4: This study was performed to measure the genetic causes of childhood epilepsy and DD.
adaptation2.5: In this study, 40 children with epilepsy and DD with genetic mutations were included via prior records.
adaptation2.6: It was done in a specialized care hospital of Bangladesh from January 2019 to December 2020.
adaptation2.7: Genetic study was done by state-of-the-art gene labeling or sequencing.
adaptation2.8: In all cases electroencephalography (measuring electrical acitvity of the brain) and neuroimaging (imaging the brain) was done and reviewed.
adaptation2.9: In total, 40 children were enrolled. The average age was 41.4Â±35.850 months with a male majority (67.5%).
adaptation2.10: Generalized seizure was the main type of seizure.
adaptation2.11: Regarding the links, reduced intelligence and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or ADHD was common.
adaptation2.12: Seventeen cases had genetically identified EE developed during infancy. Common gene mutations observed were SCN1A (3), SCN8A (2), SLC1A2 (2), KCNT1 (2), and etc (genes linked with epilepsy).
adaptation2.13: Five patients of worsening, muscle-jerk-related epilepsy were identified. The mutations identified were in KCTD7, MFSD8, and CLN6 genes.
adaptation2.14: Three cases had mitochondrial gene mutation (MT-ND5, MT-CYB) (genes that affect the mitochondria or the powerhouse of the cell).
adaptation2.15: Some rare diseases like Gibbs syndrome (brain disorder with weak muscle tone), KohlschÃ¼tter-TÃ¶nz syndrome (genetic disorder with seizures), Cockayne syndrome (delayed development disorder), Pitt-Hopkins syndrome (child development disorder) and cerebral creatine deficiency (creatine-metabolizing disorder) were identified.
adaptation2.16: In conclusion, this is the first study from Bangladesh on genetics of epilepsy and DD.
adaptation2.17: This will help to improve the understanding of genetics epilepsy of this region and contribute in giving individualized medicine in these patients.

34755109.Title: Persistent sodium currents in SCN1A developmental and degenerative epileptic dyskinetic encephalopathy

abstract.1: Pathogenic variants in the voltage-gated sodium channel gene (SCN1A) are amongst the most common genetic causes of childhood epilepsies.
abstract.2: There is considerable heterogeneity in both the types of causative variants and associated phenotypes; a recent expansion of the phenotypic spectrum of SCN1A associated epilepsies now includes an early onset severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy with regression and a hyperkinetic movement disorder.
abstract.3: Herein, we report a female with a developmental and degenerative epileptic-dyskinetic encephalopathy, distinct and more severe than classic Dravet syndrome.
abstract.4: Clinical diagnostics indicated a paternally inherited c.5053G>T; p. A1685S variant of uncertain significance in SCN1A.
abstract.5: Whole-exome sequencing detected a second de novo mosaic (18%) c.2345G>A; p. T782 I likely pathogenic variant in SCN1A (maternal allele).
abstract.6: Biophysical characterization of both mutant channels in a heterologous expression system identified gain-of-function effects in both, with a milder shift in fast inactivation of the p. A1685S channels; and a more severe persistent sodium current in the p. T782I.
abstract.7: Using computational models, we show that large persistent sodium currents induce hyper-excitability in individual cortical neurons, thus relating the severe phenotype to the empirically quantified sodium channel dysfunction.
abstract.8: These findings further broaden the phenotypic spectrum of SCN1A associated epilepsies and highlight the importance of testing for mosaicism in epileptic encephalopathies.
abstract.9: Detailed biophysical evaluation and computational modelling further highlight the role of gain-of-function variants in the pathophysiology of the most severe phenotypes associated with SCN1A.

adaptation2.1: Disease-causing variants in the sodium transporter gene (SCN1A) are amongst the most common genetic causes of childhood epilepsies (a brain disorder leading to seizures).
adaptation2.2: There is considerable variation in both the types of causative gene types and associated physical effects. A recent increase of the physical effects of SCN1A-related epilepsies now includes an early severe growth and epileptic encephalopathy (epilepsy leading to brain damage) with reduction in growth and a abnormal movement disorder.
adaptation2.3: We report a female with a growth-related and worsening epileptic-movement-related encephalopathy, distinct and more severe than classic Dravet syndrome (lifelong epilepsy).
adaptation2.4: Medical diagnostics indicated a inherited gene type of SCN1A.
adaptation2.5: Whole-body gene labeling found a second inherited, likely disease-causing gene type of SCN1A.
adaptation2.6: Biophysical measurements of both mutant gene types found gain-of-function effects in both SCN1A products; and a more severe persistent physical effect from the second gene type.
adaptation2.7: Using mathematical analysis, we show that large persistent electrical activity from sodium in the body causes hyper-excitability in brain neurons, thus linking the severe physical effects to the sodium current dysfunction.
adaptation2.8: These findings further broaden the spectrum of physical effects of SCN1A linked epilepsies and highlight the importance of testing for inheritance in epileptic encephalopathies.
adaptation2.9: Detailed biophysical tests and mathematical analysis further highlight the role of gain-of-function gene types in the disease-causing attributes of the most severe physical effects linked with SCN1A.

35074891.Title: Development and Validation of a Prediction Model for Early Diagnosis of SCN1A-Related Epilepsies

abstract.1: Background and objectives: Pathogenic variants in the neuronal sodium-channel Î±1-subunit gene (SCN1A) are the most frequent monogenic cause of epilepsy.
abstract.2: Phenotypes comprise a wide clinical spectrum including the severe childhood epilepsy, Dravet syndrome, characterized by drug-resistant seizures, intellectual disability and high mortality, and the milder genetic epilepsy with febrile seizures plus (GEFS+), characterized by normal cognition.
abstract.3: Early recognition of a child's risk for developing Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+ is key for implementing disease-modifying therapies when available before cognitive impairment emerges.
abstract.4: Our objective was to develop and validate a prediction model using clinical and genetic biomarkers for early diagnosis of SCN1A-related epilepsies.
abstract.5: Methods: Retrospective multicenter cohort study comprising data from SCN1A-positive Dravet syndrome and GEFS+ patients consecutively referred for genetic testing (March 2001-June 2020) including age of seizure onset and a newly-developed SCN1A genetic score.
abstract.6: A training cohort was used to develop multiple prediction models that were validated using two independent blinded cohorts.
abstract.7: Primary outcome was the discriminative accuracy of the model predicting Dravet syndrome versus other GEFS+ phenotypes.
abstract.8: Results: 1018 participants were included.
abstract.9: The frequency of Dravet syndrome was 616/743 (83%) in the training cohort, 147/203 (72%) in validation cohort 1 and 60/72 (83%) in validation cohort 2.
abstract.10: A high SCN1A genetic score 133.4 (SD, 78.5) versus 52.0 (SD, 57.5; p < 0.001) and young age of onset 6.0 (SD, 3.0) months versus 14.8 (SD, 11.8; p < 0.001) months, were each associated with Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+.
abstract.11: A combined 'SCN1A genetic score and seizure onset' model separated Dravet syndrome from GEFS+ more effectively (area under the curve [AUC], 0.89 [95% CI, 0.86-0.92]) and outperformed all other models (AUC, 0.79-0.85; p < 0.001).
abstract.12: Model performance was replicated in both validation cohorts 1 (AUC, 0.94 [95% CI, 0.91-0.97]) and 2 (AUC, 0.92 [95% CI, 0.82-1.00]).
abstract.13: Discussion: The prediction model allows objective estimation at disease onset whether a child will develop Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+, assisting clinicians with prognostic counseling and decisions on early institution of precision therapies (http://scn1a-prediction-model.broadinstitute.org/).
abstract.14: Classification of evidence: This study provides Class II evidence that a combined 'SCN1A genetic score and seizure onset' model distinguishes Dravet syndrome from other GEFS+ phenotypes.

adaptation2.1: For the study's background, we studied disease-causing types of the brain-located gene called SCN1A, which is the most frequent cause of epileptic seizures or epilepsy.
adaptation2.2: Physical attributes make up a wide spectrum including the severe childhood epilepsy, Dravet syndrome, epilepsy characterized by drug-resistant seizures, lower intelligence, and high death risk, and the milder genetic epilepsy with fever-like seizures plus (GEFS+), characterized by normal intelligence.
adaptation2.3: Early identification of a child's risk for developing Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+ is key for giving disease-modifying treatments when available before intelligence impairment come up.
adaptation2.4: Our objective was to develop and verify a disease prediction model using medical and genetic biomarkers for early identification of SCN1A-related epilepsies.
adaptation2.5: For the study's methods, it was a multicenter group study comprising data from previous SCN1A-positive Dravet syndrome and GEFS+ patients consistently treated with genetic testing (March 2001-June 2020). Data includes age of seizure start and a newly-developed SCN1A genetic score.
adaptation2.6: A training group was used to develop multiple disease prediction models that were verified using two independent groups.
adaptation2.7: The main measure was the accuracy of the model predicting Dravet syndrome versus other GEFS+ phenotypes.
adaptation2.8: 1018 participants were included.
adaptation2.9: The frequency of Dravet syndrome was 616/743 (83%) in the training group, 147/203 (72%) in test group 1 and 60/72 (83%) in test group 2.
adaptation2.10: A high SCN1A genetic score - 133.4 versus 52.0 - and young age of start - 6.0 months versus 14.8 months -  were each linked with Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+.
adaptation2.11: A combined 'SCN1A genetic score and seizure onset' model separated Dravet syndrome from GEFS+ more effectively and outperformed all other models.
adaptation2.12: Model performance was replicated in both test group 1 and 2.
adaptation2.13: In short, the prediction model allows measurable estimation at disease start whether a child will develop Dravet syndrome versus GEFS+, helping clinicians with treatment counseling and decisions on early use of specific treatments.
adaptation2.14: This study provides strong evidence that a combined 'SCN1A genetic score and seizure onset' model identifies Dravet syndrome from other GEFS+ phenotypes.

35091117.Title: The EPIGENE network: A French initiative to harmonize and improve the nationwide diagnosis of monogenic epilepsies

abstract.1: Background: The EPIGENE network was created in 2014 by four multidisciplinary teams composed of geneticists, pediatric neurologists and neurologists specialized in epileptology and neurophysiology.
abstract.2: The ambition of the network was to harmonize and improve the diagnostic strategy of Mendelian epileptic disorders using next-generation sequencing, in France.
abstract.3: Over the years, five additional centers have joined EPIGENE and the network has been working in close collaboration, since 2018, with the French reference center for rare epilepsies (CRÃ©ER).
abstract.4: Results: Since 2014, biannual meetings have led to the design of four successive versions of a monogenic epilepsy gene panel (PAGEM), increasing from 68 to 144 genes.
abstract.5: A total of 4035 index cases with epileptic disorders have been analyzed with a diagnostic yield of 31% (n = 1265/4035).
abstract.6: The top 10 genes, SCN1A, KCNQ2, STXBP1, SCN2A, SCN8A, PRRT2, PCDH19, KCNT1, SYNGAP1, and GRIN2A, account for one-sixth of patients and half of the diagnoses provided by the PAGEM.
abstract.7: Conclusion: These results suggest that a gene-panel approach is an efficient first-tier test for the genetic diagnosis of Mendelian epileptic disorders.
abstract.8: In a near future, French patients with "drug-resistant epilepsies with seizure-onset in the first two-years of life" can benefit from whole-genome sequencing (WGS), as a second line genetic screening with the implementation of the 2025 French Genomic Medicine Plan.
abstract.9: The EPIGENE network has also promoted scientific collaborations on genetic epilepsies within CRÃ©ER.

adaptation2.1: As the article's background, the EPIGENE network was created in 2014 by four multi-specialty teams made up of geneticists, neurologists treating young children and neurologists specialized in epileptic seizures (or epilepsy) and brain make-up.
adaptation2.2: The goal of the network was to group together and improve the identification strategy of genetic epileptic disorders using state-of-the-art gene tagging, in France.
adaptation2.3: Over the years, five additional centers have joined EPIGENE. The network has been working closely, since 2018, with the French reference center for rare epilepsies (CRÃ©ER).
adaptation2.4: Since 2014, biannual meetings have created four successive versions of a single-gene epilepsy gene panel (PAGEM), increasing from 68 to 144 genes.
adaptation2.5: A total of 4035 patient cases with epileptic disorders have been analyzed with an identification accuracy of 31% (n = 1265/4035).
adaptation2.6: The top 10 epileptic-related genes, SCN1A, KCNQ2, STXBP1, SCN2A, SCN8A, PRRT2, PCDH19, KCNT1, SYNGAP1, and GRIN2A, account for one-sixth of patients and half of the identifications provided by the PAGEM.
adaptation2.7: In conclusion, these results suggest that a gene-panel approach is an efficient, gold-standard test for the genetic identification of genetic epileptic disorders.
adaptation2.8: In a near future, French patients with "drug-resistant epilepsies with seizure-onset in the first two-years of life" can benefit from tagging their entire genome, as a secondary genetic screening with the use of the 2025 French Genomic Medicine Plan.
adaptation2.9: The EPIGENE network has also promoted scientific partnerships on genetic epilepsies within CRÃ©ER.

19329391.Title: Mental retardation is associated with plasma omega-3 fatty acid levels and the omega-3/omega-6 ratio in children

abstract.1: There is evidence that alteration in plasma fatty acid composition may play a role in certain neurological disorders.
abstract.2: This case control study was conducted to evaluate the association between plasma fatty acid levels and mental retardation in Korean children.
abstract.3: Plasma phospholipid fatty acids, plasma lipids, dietary fatty acids and selected nutrients were measured in 31 mentally retarded boys (mean age 9.93 +/-1.5 yrs) and matched controls.
abstract.4: Total plasma omega-3 fatty acids (Sigmaw3), docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and high density lipoprotein (HDL) concentrations were significantly lower and the Sigmaomega-6/Sigmaomega-3 ratio was significantly higher in cases than in controls.
abstract.5: The odds in favor of mental retardation increased by 69 % for each unit increase in the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio (adjusted odds ratio = 1.69, 95% CI = 1.25-2.29).
abstract.6: Significant variation in plasma Sigmaomega-3 and the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio was explained by mental retardation and plasma HDL concentrations (45% and 37 % respectively).
abstract.7: There was a significant inverse association between plasma DHA and mental retardation.
abstract.8: For each unit increase in plasma DHA, odds of mental retardation decreased by 74 %.
abstract.9: There was no significant difference in either total dietary fat or fatty acids intakes between cases and controls.
abstract.10: The energy intake of cases was significantly higher than the controls.
abstract.11: These results suggest that proportion of plasma Sigmaomega-3 fatty acids, particularly, DHA, and the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio are associated with mental retardation in children in this study.

adaptation2.1: There is evidence that changes in blood fatty acid make-up may play a role in certain brain disorders.
adaptation2.2: This patient study was conducted to test the link between blood fatty acid levels and mental retardation in Korean children.
adaptation2.3: Blood fatty acids, blood fat levels, dietary fatty acids and selected nutrients were measured in 31 mentally retarded boys (average age 9.93 +/-1.5 yrs) and normal boys.
adaptation2.4: Total blood omega-3 fatty acids (Sigmaw3), docosahexaenoic acid (DHA; specific omega-3 fatty acids) and high density lipoprotein (HDL - good cholesterol) concentrations were much lower. The Sigmaomega-6/Sigmaomega-3 ratio was much higher in affectedpatients than in normal patients.
adaptation2.5: The odds in favor of mental retardation increased by 69 % for each unit increase in the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio.
adaptation2.6: Significant variation in blood Sigmaomega-3 and the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio was explained by mental retardation and blood HDL concentrations (45% and 37 % respectively).
adaptation2.7: There was a significant opposite link between blood DHA and mental retardation. As one goes up, the other goes down.
adaptation2.8: For each unit increase in blood DHA, odds of mental retardation decreased by 74 %.
adaptation2.9: There was no significant difference in either total dietary fat or fatty acids intakes between affected patients and normal patients.
adaptation2.10: The energy intake of affected patients was significantly higher than the healthy patients.
adaptation2.11: These results suggest that amount of plasma Sigmaomega-3 fatty acids, particularly, DHA, and the Sigmaomega-6/ Sigmaomega-3 ratio are linked with mental retardation in children in this study.

27852615.Title: Executive functions and the ω-6-to-ω-3 fatty acid ratio: a cross-sectional study

abstract.1: Background: The ω-6 (n-6) to ω-3 (n-3) fatty acid (FA) ratio (n-6:n-3 ratio) was previously shown to be a predictor of executive function performance in children aged 7-9 y.
abstract.2: Objective: We aimed to replicate and extend previous findings by exploring the role of the n-6:n-3 ratio in executive function performance.
abstract.3: We hypothesized that there would be an interaction between n-3 and the n-6:n-3 ratio, with children with low n-3 performing best with a low ratio, and those with high n-3 performing best with a high ratio.
abstract.4: Design: Children were recruited on the basis of their consumption of n-6 and n-3 FAs.
abstract.5: The executive function performance of 78 children aged 7-12 y was tested with the use of the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery and a planning task.
abstract.6: Participants provided blood for plasma FA quantification, and the caregiver completed demographic and activity questionnaires.
abstract.7: We investigated the role of the n-6:n-3 ratio in the entire sample and separately in children aged 7-9 y (n = 41) and 10-12 y (n = 37).
abstract.8: Results: Dietary and plasma n-6:n-3 ratio and n-3 predicted performance on working memory and planning tasks in children 7-12 y old.
abstract.9: The interaction between dietary n-6:n-3 ratio and n-3 predicted the number of moves required to solve the most difficult planning problems in children aged 7-9 y and those aged 10-12 y, similar to results from the previous study.
abstract.10: There was also an interaction between the plasma n-6:n-3 ratio and n-3 predicting time spent thinking through the difficult 5-move planning problems.
abstract.11: The n-6:n-3 ratio and n-3 predicted executive function performance differently in children aged 7-9 y and in those aged 10-12 y, indicating different optimal FA balances across development.
abstract.12: Conclusions: The n-6:n-3 ratio is an important consideration in the role of FAs in cognitive function, and the optimal balance of n-6 and n-3 FAs depends on the cognitive function and developmental period studied.

adaptation2.1: As the study's background, the ω-6 (n-6) to ω-3 (n-3) fatty acid (FA) ratio (n-6:n-3 ratio) was previously shown to be a predictor of brain function performance in children aged 7-9 y.
adaptation2.2: For the objective, we aimed to replicate and extend previous findings by exploring the role of the n-6:n-3 ratio in brain function performance.
adaptation2.3: We hypothesized that there would be an link between n-3 and the n-6:n-3 ratio, with children with low n-3 performing best with a low ratio, and those with high n-3 performing best with a high ratio.
adaptation2.4: For the study design, children were recruited on the basis of their consumption of n-6 and n-3 FAs.
adaptation2.5: The brain function performance of 78 children aged 7-12 y was tested with the use of specific brain health tests and a planning task.
adaptation2.6: Participants provided blood for FA quantification, and the caregiver completed basic background and activity questionnaires.
adaptation2.7: We investigated the role of the n-6:n-3 ratio in the entire sample and separately in children aged 7-9 y and 10-12 y.
adaptation2.8: For the study results, diet and blood n-6:n-3 ratio and n-3 predicted performance on short-term memory and planning tasks in children 7-12 y old.
