abstract.1: Background: Rehabilitation, with an emphasis on physiotherapy and exercise, is widely promoted after total knee replacement.
abstract.2: However, provision of services varies in content and duration.
abstract.3: The aim of this study is to update the review of Minns Lowe and colleagues 2007 using systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate the effectiveness of post-discharge physiotherapy exercise in patients with primary total knee replacement.
abstract.4: Methods: We searched MEDLINE, Embase, PsycInfo, CINAHL and Cochrane CENTRAL to October 4(th) 2013 for randomised evaluations of physiotherapy exercise in adults with recent primary knee replacement.
abstract.5: Outcomes were: patient-reported pain and function, knee range of motion, and functional performance.
abstract.6: Authors were contacted for missing data and outcomes.
abstract.7: Risk of bias and heterogeneity were assessed.
abstract.8: Data was combined using random effects meta-analysis and reported as standardised mean differences (SMD) or mean differences (MD).
abstract.9: Results: Searches identified 18 randomised trials including 1,739 patients with total knee replacement.
abstract.10: Interventions compared: physiotherapy exercise and no provision; home and outpatient provision; pool and gym-based provision; walking skills and more general physiotherapy; and general physiotherapy exercise with and without additional balance exercises or ergometer cycling.
abstract.11: Compared with controls receiving minimal physiotherapy, patients receiving physiotherapy exercise had improved physical function at 3-4 months, SMD -0.37 (95% CI -0.62, -0.12), and pain, SMD -0.45 (95% CI -0.85, -0.06).
abstract.12: Benefit up to 6 months was apparent when considering only higher quality studies.
abstract.13: There were no differences for outpatient physiotherapy exercise compared with home-based provision in physical function or pain outcomes.
abstract.14: There was a short-term benefit favouring home-based physiotherapy exercise for range of motion flexion.
abstract.15: There were no differences in outcomes when the comparator was hydrotherapy, or when additional balancing or cycling components were included.
abstract.16: In one study, a walking skills intervention was associated with a long-term improvement in walking performance.
abstract.17: However, for all these evaluations studies were under-powered individually and in combination.
abstract.18: Conclusion: After recent primary total knee replacement, interventions including physiotherapy and exercise show short-term improvements in physical function.
abstract.19: However this conclusion is based on meta-analysis of a few small studies and no long-term benefits of physiotherapy exercise interventions were identified.
abstract.20: Future research should target improvements to long-term function, pain and performance outcomes in appropriately powered trials.

adaptation2.1: Rehab, with an emphasis on physiotherapy and exercise, is widely promoted after total knee replacement.
adaptation2.2: However, how services are given varies in content and duration.
adaptation2.3: The aim of this study is to provide an updated summary of the research to evaluate how effective physiotherapy (PT) exercise is for patients that had knee replacements.
adaptation2.4: We searched several medical literature databases, up to October 4th, 2013, for studies of PT exercise in adults that had knee replacements.
adaptation2.5: The outcomes we looked at were: patient-reported pain and function, knee range of motion, and functional performance.
adaptation2.6: We contacted the researchers for missing data and outcomes.
adaptation2.7: We also looked at whether the study results could be misleading.
adaptation2.9: Our searches found 18 studies including 1,739 patients with total knee replacement.
adaptation2.10: The treatments that were compared were: PT exercise without care; home and outpatient care; pool and gym-based care; walking skills and more general PT; and general PT exercise with and without additional balance exercises or a stationary bike.
adaptation2.11: Compared with people with little or no PT, patients that got PT exercise had improved physical function at 3-4 months.
adaptation2.12: When considering only higher quality studies, there was a clear benefit up to 6 months.
adaptation2.13: There were no differences for outpatient PT exercise compared with home-based care in physical function or pain outcomes.
adaptation2.14: There was a short-term benefit in favor of home-based PT exercise for range of motion.
adaptation2.15: There were no differences in outcomes for pool-based care, or when additional balancing or cycling components were included.
adaptation2.16: In one study, a walking skills treatment plan was associated with a long-term improvement in walking performance.
adaptation2.17: However, for all these evaluations, studies did not have enough patients to be sure of their significance, even taken altogether.
adaptation2.18: In conclusion, after recently having knee replacement, care including PT and exercise improve physical function short-term.
adaptation2.19: However, this conclusion is based on a few small studies, and we found no long-term benefits of PT exercise.
adaptation2.20: Future research should focus on improving long-term function, pain and performance with larger studies.

27401004.Title: Efficacy and safety of home-based exercises versus individualized supervised outpatient physical therapy programs after total knee arthroplasty: a systematic review and meta-analysis

abstract.1: Purpose: The aim of the present study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of non-supervised home-based exercise versus individualized and supervised programs delivered in clinic-based settings for the functional recovery immediately after discharge from a primary TKA.
abstract.2: Methods: Medline, Embase, Cochrane, and PEDro databases were screened, from inception to April 2015, in search for randomized clinical trials (RCT) of home-based exercise interventions versus individualized and supervised outpatient physical therapy after primary TKA.
abstract.3: Target outcomes were: knee range of motion (ROM), patient-reported pain and function, functional performance, and safety.
abstract.4: Risk of bias was assessed with the PEDro scale.
abstract.5: After assessing homogeneity, data were combined using random effects meta-analysis and reported as standardized mean differences or mean differences.
abstract.6: We set a non-inferiority margin of four points in mean differences.
abstract.7: Results: The search and selection process identified 11 RCT of moderate quality and small sample sizes.
abstract.8: ROM active extension data suitable for meta-analysis was available from seven studies with 707 patients, and ROM active flexion from nine studies with 983 patients.
abstract.9: Most studies showed no difference between groups.
abstract.10: Pooled differences were within the non-inferiority margin.
abstract.11: Most meta-analyses showed significant statistical heterogeneity.
abstract.12: Conclusion: Short-term improvements in physical function and knee ROM do not clearly differ between outpatient physiotherapy and home-based exercise regimes in patients after primary TKA; however, this conclusion is based on a meta-analysis with high heterogeneity.

adaptation2.1: The aim of this study was to see how effective and safe different functional recovery strategies were immediately after discharge from knee replacement surgery. It compared non-supervised, home-based exercise to individualized and supervised programs delivered in clinic-based settings.
adaptation2.2: We searched several medical literature databases for papers published up until April 2015. We were looking for clinical trials of home-based exercise programs versus individualized and supervised outpatient physical therapy (PT) after knee replacement.
adaptation2.3: The outcomes we compared were knee range of motion (ROM), patient-reported pain and function, functional performance, and safety.
adaptation2.7: Our search and selection process found 11 clinical trials of decent quality but that looked at small numbers of patients.
adaptation2.8: Seven studies, with a total of 707 patients, had data on ROM for extending the leg that could be used. Nine studies, with a total of 983 patients, had data on ROM for bending the leg.
adaptation2.9: Most studies showed no difference between groups.
adaptation2.10: Even taken altogether, differences between the treatment types were small enough to be by chance.
adaptation2.12: In conclusion, short-term improvements in physical function and knee ROM are not clearly different between outpatient PT and home-based exercise regimes in patients after knee replacement. However, this conclusion is based on combining studies with many differences.

28901118.Title: Randomized controlled trial of maximal strength training vs. standard rehabilitation following total knee arthroplasty

abstract.1: Background: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) alleviates pain, but muscle strength and function is reduced for a long period postoperatively.
abstract.2: Aim: To investigate whether maximal strength training (MST) is more effective in improving muscle strength than standard rehabilitation (SR) after TKA.
abstract.3: Design: A randomized, controlled study.
abstract.4: Setting: Community physical therapy centers and University hospital research department.
abstract.5: Population: Forty-one adults <75 years with primary, unilateral osteoarthritis of the knee scheduled for TKA.
abstract.6: Methods: Participants were randomized to supervised MST of the lower extremities 3 times/week for 8 weeks and physiotherapy session1/week (N.=21) or to SR, including physiotherapy sessions/telephone contact 1/week and writing home exercise logs (N.=20).
abstract.7: Maximal strength in leg press and knee extension, 6-minute walk test, patient-reported functional outcome score and pain were assessed preoperatively, 7 days, 10 weeks and 12 months postoperatively.
abstract.8: Results: The MST group exceeded preoperative levels of muscle strength in leg press and knee extension by 37% and 43%, respectively at 10 weeks' follow-up, and the increase was higher than in the SR group (P≤0.001).
abstract.9: Strength differences persisted up to 12-months follow-up.
abstract.10: At 12 months, both groups recovered to normative levels in the 6-Minute Walk Test, with no statistically significantly difference between the groups.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Participants undergoing MST experienced superior increases in leg press and knee extension muscle strength compared with those managed with SR from 7-day to 10-week follow-up.
abstract.12: The difference in muscle strength was maintained at 12-month follow-up.
abstract.13: No differences in functional performance were found at any time-point.
abstract.14: Clinical rehabilitation impact: Exercises after TKA should be performed with high intensity and target the operated leg specifically.

adaptation2.1: Complete knee replacement surgery alleviates pain, but muscle strength and function is reduced for a long period after the operation.
adaptation2.2: Our aim was to investigate whether Maximal Strength Training (MST) is more effective in improving muscle strength than standard rehab knee replacement.
adaptation2.3: This study involved two groups who randomly got either the standard care or the experimental care.
adaptation2.4: It was done in community physical therapy centers and a university hospital research department.
adaptation2.5: The study included 41 adults under 75 with arthritis in one knee and who were scheduled for knee replacement surgery.
adaptation2.6: Participants randomly got either supervised MST for the legs 3 times a week for 8 weeks and one physiotherapy session per week or the standard rehab, including physiotherapy sessions and/or telephone contact once a week and writing home exercise logs. The MST group had 21 patients, while the standard rehab group had 20 patients.
adaptation2.7: We measured maximum strength in leg press and knee extension, 6-minute walk test, patient-reported functional outcome score and pain. We looked at these 7 days after the operation, 10 weeks after, and 12 months after.
adaptation2.8: The MST group had 37% more strength in leg press and 43% more strength in knee extension at 10 weeks. These increases were higher than for the group that had standard rehab.
adaptation2.9: Strength differences continued up to the 12-month follow-ups.
adaptation2.10: At 12 months, both groups recovered to normal levels in the 6-Minute Walk Test, with no significant difference between the groups.
adaptation2.11: In conclusion, participants getting Maximal Strength Training (MST) had better increases in leg press and knee extension muscle strength compared to those who had standard rehab, as measured at 7-day to 10-week follow-ups after surgery.
adaptation2.12: The difference in muscle strength was maintained at 12-month follow-up.
adaptation2.13: No differences in functional performance were found at any point.
adaptation2.14: The impact of this on clinical rehab is that exercises after knee replacement should be done with high intensity and should target the operated leg specifically.

29548061.Title: The Role of Virtual Rehabilitation in Total and Unicompartmental Knee Arthroplasty

abstract.1: This study evaluated the use of telerehabilitation during the postoperative period for patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA) or unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA).
abstract.2: Specifically, this study evaluated the following: (1) patient compliance and adherence to the program, (2) time spent performing physical therapy exercises, (3) the usability of the virtual rehabilitation platform, and (4) clinical outcome scores in a selected primary knee arthroplasty cohort.
abstract.3: A total of 157 consecutive patients underwent TKA (n = 18) or UKA (n = 139).
abstract.4: These patients used a telerehabilitation system with an instructional avatar, three-dimensional motion measurement and analysis software, and real-time televisit capability designed for arthroplasty patients.
abstract.5: Compliance was determined by how many times the patients followed prescribed repetitions of exercises.
abstract.6: The total time spent performing exercises for each patient was collected.
abstract.7: The usability of the virtual rehabilitation platform (on the patient's end) was evaluated using the system usability scale (SUS) questionnaire.
abstract.8: The number of in-person and televisits was recorded for each patient.
abstract.9: Patient-reported outcomes were collected through the patient and clinician interfaces and included the Knee Society Score (KSS) for pain and functions, the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) score, and Boston University Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) score.
abstract.10: Patients spent an average of 29.5 days partaking in the therapy.
abstract.11: TKA and UKA patients had a mean of 3.5 and 3.2 outpatient follow-up visits, each, for in-office therapy with a physical therapist, respectively.
abstract.12: This figure exceeded the mean number of real-time virtual patient-clinician visits by 0.8 visits per patient in the TKA cohort and by 1 visit per patient in the UKA cohort.
abstract.13: Patients spent on average 26.5 minutes per day conducting an average of 13.5 exercises.
abstract.14: By the end of rehabilitation, patients had spent an average of 10.8 hours performing exercises, and of all the exercises performed, approximately 21 exercises were uniquely designed.
abstract.15: Mean SUS score in the cohort was 93 points, which was interpreted as being above the 50th percentile point of the scale.
abstract.16: Following therapy, KSS pain and function scores improved markedly and the improvements were measured at 368% for TKA and 350% for UKA (pain) and 27% for UKA and 33% for TKA (function).
abstract.17: In addition, WOMAC scores improved by 57% and 66% for UKA and TKA patients while the improvement in AM-PAC scores was at 22% and 24%.
abstract.18: This telerehabilitation platform encouraged clinician-patient interaction beyond the hospital setting and offers the advantage of cost savings, convenience, at-home monitoring, and coordination of care, all of which are geared to improve adherence and overall patient satisfaction.
abstract.19: Additionally, the biometric data can be used to develop custom physical therapy regimens to assure proper rehabilitation, which is lacking in other telerehabilitation applications that use noninteractive videos that can be watched on mobile devices and tablets.

adaptation2.1: This study looked at using tele-rehab (where providers interact with patients remotely using the internet) after complete or partial knee replacement surgery.
adaptation2.2: Specifically, the study looked at: (1) how well patients kept up with the program, (2) time spent performing physical therapy exercises, (3) how easy it was to use the virtual rehab software, and (4) outcomes for a certain group of patients that had knee replacement surgery.
adaptation2.3: A total of 157 patients in a row had complete (18) or partial (139) knee replacement.
adaptation2.4: These patients used a tele-rehab system with an instructional avatar, three-dimensional motion measurement and analysis software, and real-time tele-visit capability designed for joint surgery patients.
adaptation2.5: We measured how well patients kept up with the program by how many times the patients followed the recommended repetitions of exercises.
adaptation2.6: We collected the total each patient time spent performing exercises.
adaptation2.7: We evaluated how easy it was for patients to use the virtual rehab software using a questionnaire.
adaptation2.8: We also recorded the number of in-person and virtual visits for each patient.
adaptation2.9: We collected patient-reported outcomes through patient/doctor portals. Measurements included were the Knee Society Score (KSS) for pain and functions, the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) score, and Boston University Activity Measure for Post-Acute Care (AM-PAC) score.
adaptation2.10: Patients spent an average of about 30 days participating in the therapy.
adaptation2.11: Complete knee replacement patients, on average, had 3.5 outpatient follow-up visits each for in-office therapy with a physical therapist. Partial knee replacement patients had, on average, 3.2 of these visits.
adaptation2.12: For complete knee replacement patients, this was on average 0.8 more visits than for real-time virtual patient-clinician. For partial hip replacement patients, it was 1 more visit.
adaptation2.13: Patients spent, on average, 26.5 minutes per day doing an average of 13.5 exercises.
adaptation2.14: By the end of rehab, patients had spent an average of 10.8 hours doing exercises, and of all the exercises performed, around 21 were uniquely designed.
adaptation2.16: After therapy, KSS pain and function scores improved notably. The scores for pain improved by 368% for complete knee replacement and 350% for partial. The scores for function improved by 33% for complete knee replacement 27% for partial.
adaptation2.17: Additionally, WOMAC scores improved by 57% for partial knee replacement and 66% for compete knee replacement. The improvement in AM-PAC scores was at 22% for partial and 24% for complete.
adaptation2.18: This tele-rehab platform encouraged interaction between doctors and patients beyond the hospital setting. It offers the advantage of cost savings, convenience, at-home monitoring, and coordination of care. All of these are geared to improve how well patients keep up and overall patient satisfaction.
adaptation2.19: Additionally, the data from the platform can be used to make custom physical therapy regimens to assure proper rehabilitation. This is lacking in other tele-rehab applications that use non-interactive videos that can be watched on mobile devices and tablets.

30281207.Title: Characteristics of Usual Physical Therapy Post-Total Knee Replacement and Their Associations With Functional Outcomes

abstract.1: Objective: Although total knee replacement (TKR) surgery is highly prevalent and generally successful, functional outcomes post-TKR vary widely.
abstract.2: Most patients receive some physical therapy (PT) following TKR, but PT practice is variable and associations between specific content and dose of PT interventions and functional outcomes are unknown.
abstract.3: Research has identified exercise interventions associated with better outcomes but studies have not assessed whether such evidence has been translated into clinical practice.
abstract.4: We characterized the content, dose, and progression of usual post-acute PT services following TKR, and examined associations of specific details of post-acute PT with patients' 6-month functional outcomes.
abstract.5: Methods: Post-acute PT data were collected from patients who were undergoing primary unilateral TKR and participating in a clinical trial of a phone-based coaching intervention.
abstract.6: PT records from the terminal episode of care were reviewed and utilization and exercise content data were extracted.
abstract.7: Descriptive statistics and linear regression models characterized PT treatment factors and identified associations with 6-month outcomes.
abstract.8: Results: We analyzed 112 records from 30 PT sites.
abstract.9: Content and dose of specific exercises and incidence of progression varied widely.
abstract.10: Open chain exercises were utilized more frequently than closed chain (median 21 [interquartile range (IQR) 4-49] versus median 13 [IQR 4-28.5]).
abstract.11: Median (IQR) occurrence of progression of closed and open chain exercise was 0 (0-2) and 1 (0-3), respectively.
abstract.12: Shorter timed stair climb was associated with greater total number of PT interventions and use and progression of closed chain exercises.
abstract.13: Discussion: Data suggest that evidence-based interventions are underutilized and dose may be insufficient to obtain optimal outcomes.

adaptation2.1: Although knee replacement surgery is very common and usually turns out well, amount of function after varies widely.
adaptation2.2: Most patients have some physical therapy (PT) after knee replacement, but PT practice varies. We don’t know which amounts and kinds of PT are associated with which outcomes.
adaptation2.3: Research has shown that exercise is associated with better outcomes, but studies have not looked at whether this has made its way into clinical practice.
adaptation2.4: We looked at the content, amount, and progression of usual PT services after knee replacement. We also examined associations of specific details of PT after surgery with how much function patients had after 6 months.
adaptation2.5: We collected PT data from patients who were having knee replacement surgery on one side and participating in a clinical trial of a phone-based coaching program.
adaptation2.6: We reviewed PT records from final sessions to find how much patients used the PT and what exercises were done.
adaptation2.7: We used statistical methods to see which parts of PT treatment were associated with 6-month outcomes.
adaptation2.8: In all, we looked at 112 records from 30 PT sites.
adaptation2.9: The types and amounts of exercises, and how they progressed, varied widely.
adaptation2.10: Exercises that used weights or other resistance were use more than body-weight exercises (on average 21 versus 13).
adaptation2.11: Progression of exercises was used on average 0 times for exercises with resistance and 1 time for exercises that just used body weight.
adaptation2.12: Climbing stairs faster was associated with more PT sessions and the use and progression of body-weight exercises.
adaptation2.13: The evidence suggests that treatments backed by studies are not used as much as they should be and the amount of PT may not be enough to create the best possible outcomes.

31427131.Title: Same-Day Physical Therapy Following Total Knee Arthroplasty Leads to Improved Inpatient Physical Therapy Performance and Decreased Inpatient Opioid Consumption

abstract.1: Background: Early ambulation with physical therapy (PT) following total knee arthroplasty (TKA) has demonstrated benefits in the literature.
abstract.2: However, the impact of early PT on rehabilitation performance and opioid consumption has not been elucidated.
abstract.3: We evaluate the effect of same-day PT on inhospital functional outcomes and opioid consumption.
abstract.4: Methods: We retrospectively identified 2 cohorts of primary TKA patients from July 2016 to December 2017: PT0 (n = 295) received PT on the day of surgery, and PT1 (n = 392) received PT on postoperative day (POD) 1.
abstract.5: Outcomes studied included number of feet walked on POD0-3, visual analog scale pain scores, morphine equivalents (ME) consumed, length of stay, and discharge disposition.
abstract.6: Analysis was conducted using the Student t-test and Fisher exact test.
abstract.7: Results: In comparison to the PT1 group, the PT0 group walked significantly more steps on POD1 (347.6 vs 167.4 ft, P < .0001), POD2 (342.1 vs 203.5 ft, P < .0001), and POD3 (190.3 vs 128.9 ft, P = .00028).
abstract.8: There was no difference between the 2 groups for visual analog scale.
abstract.9: The PT0 group also consumed significantly fewer total ME when compared to the PT1 group (149.0 vs 200.3 mg, P = .0002).
abstract.10: The PT0 group had a significantly shorter length of stay when compared to the PT1 group (2.7 vs 3.2 days, P = .00075).
abstract.11: More patients were discharged home in the PT0 group (81.7% vs 54.8%, P < .0001).
abstract.12: Conclusion: We observed that initiation of PT on POD0 led to better PT performance, reduced ME during hospitalization, and more patients discharged home.

adaptation2.1: Research has shown that having patients walk early with physical therapy (PT) after knee replacement has benefits.
adaptation2.2: However, the impact of early PT on rehab performance and opioid use is still unclear.
adaptation2.3: We looked at the effect of same-day PT on how well patients functions and opioid use while in the hospital.
adaptation2.4: To do this, we looked at 2 past groups of knee replacement patients from July 2016 to December 2017. The first group had 295 patients and had PT on the day of surgery. The second group had 392 patients and received PT on the day after surgery.
adaptation2.5: The outcomes we looked at included the number of feet walked in the first 3 days after surgery, patient reported pain scores, amount of morphine or similar drugs used, length of stay, and where the patient was sent on discharge.
adaptation2.7: In comparison to the second group (which had PT the day of after surgery), the first group (which had PT the day of the surgery) walked significantly more steps on the first 3 days after surgery. The first group walked, on average, 348 feet the first day after, while the second group walked 167 feet. The second day, the first group walked 342 feet while the second group walked 203. The third day after surgery, the first group walked 190 feet while the second group walked 129 feet.
adaptation2.8: There was no difference between the 2 groups for pain reported.
adaptation2.9: The first group (which had PT the day of the surgery) also used significantly less morphine or similar drugs when compared to the second group (which had PT the day after surgery).
adaptation2.10: The first group also had a significantly shorter length of stay compared to the second group (on average 2.7 days vs 3.2 days).
adaptation2.11: More patients were discharged home in the first group (81.7% vs 54.8%).
adaptation2.12: In conclusion, we observed that starting PT the day of surgery led to better PT performance, reduced drug use during hospitalization, and more patients discharged home.

31728379.Title: Rehabilitation protocols following total knee arthroplasty: a review of study designs and outcome measures

abstract.1: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is among the most common elective procedures performed worldwide.
abstract.2: Recent efforts have been made to significantly improve patient outcomes, specifically with postoperative rehabilitation.
abstract.3: Despite the many rehabilitation modalities available, the optimal rehabilitation strategy has yet to be determined.
abstract.4: Therefore, this systematic review focuses on evaluating existing postoperative rehabilitation protocols.
abstract.5: Specifically, this review analyses the study designs, rehabilitation methods, and outcome measures of postoperative rehabilitation protocols for TKA recipients in the past five years.
abstract.6: The PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane Library databases were queried for studies evaluating rehabilitation protocols following primary TKA.
abstract.7: Of the 11,013 studies identified within the last five years, 70 met the inclusion and exclusion criteria.
abstract.8: After assessing for relevance and removing duplicates, a final count of 20 studies remained for analysis.
abstract.9: Level-of-evidence was determined by the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) classification system.
abstract.10: Our findings demonstrated that continuous passive motion and inpatient rehabilitation may not provide additional benefit to the patient or healthcare system.
abstract.11: However, early rehabilitation, telerehabilitation, outpatient therapy, high intensity, and high velocity exercise may be successful forms of rehabilitation.
abstract.12: Additionally, weight-bearing biofeedback, neuromuscular electrical stimulation, and balance control appear to be beneficial adjuncts to conventional rehabilitation.
abstract.13: Postoperative rehabilitation following TKA facilitates patient recovery and improves quality of life.
abstract.14: This systematic review analyzed the existing rehabilitation protocols from the past five years.
abstract.15: Some studies did not accurately describe the conventional rehabilitation protocols, the duration of therapy sessions, and the timing of these sessions.
abstract.16: As such, future studies should explicitly describe their methodology.
abstract.17: This will allow high-quality assessments and the conception of standardized protocols.

adaptation2.1: Knee replacement is one of the most common types of surgery that people choose to have worldwide.
adaptation2.2: Recently, doctors have tried to make big improvements in outcomes, especially during the rehab process.
adaptation2.3: Even though there are lots of ways to do rehab, doctors have not figured out the best strategy.
adaptation2.4: Because of this, we will focus on rating different rehab strategies that are in published papers.
adaptation2.5: Specifically, we will look at how studies were done, which rehab methods they used, and what the measured outcomes were. We will do this for rehab strategies for people that had knee replacement in the last 5 years.
adaptation2.6: We searched several databases of biomedical literature for studies that looked at rehab strategies after knee replacement.
adaptation2.7: Out of more than 11,000 from our search, 70 met our criteria for including them.
adaptation2.8: After considering relevance and removing duplicates, we were left with 20 studies.
adaptation2.10: We found that Continuous Passive Motion (CPM), where a device moves the leg for the patient, and inpatient rehab may not provide any benefit to the patient or the healthcare system.
adaptation2.11: However, early rehab, tele-rehab, where providers interact with patients remotely using the internet, and outpatient therapy may be successful types of rehab. Exercise at high intensity and high speeds may also be successful types of rehab.
adaptation2.12: One method that seems to help as a supplement is “weight-bearing biofeedback,” where the patient puts some weight on the joint while wearing sensors to ensure it is not too much. Electrical stimulation of the muscles and balancing exercises also appear to be helpful supplements to typical rehab methods.
adaptation2.13: Rehab after knee replacement surgery helps patients recover and improves their quality of life.
adaptation2.14: This article looked at published rehab strategies used in the last 5 years.
adaptation2.15: Some studies did not accurately describe standard rehab methods, duration of therapy sessions, and the timing of these sessions.
adaptation2.16: Studies done in the future should be more explicit about their methods.
adaptation2.17: This will let doctors know what the methods are and evaluate them.

34331766.Title: Phase 3 Trials of Enhanced Versus Usual Care Physical Therapy for Patients at Risk of Poor Outcome Following Knee Arthroplasty: A Perspective on Meaning and a Way Forward

abstract.1: Physical therapy is routinely delivered to patients after discharge from the hospital following knee arthroplasty.
abstract.2: Posthospitalization physical therapy is thought to be beneficial, particularly for those patients most at risk of poor outcome, the subgroup with persistent function-limiting pain, despite an apparently successful surgery.
abstract.3: Research teams have undertaken 3 large-scale multicenter Phase 3 randomized clinical trials designed specifically for patients at risk of poor outcome following knee arthroplasty.
abstract.4: All 3 trials screened for poor outcome risk using different methods and investigated different physical therapist interventions delivered in different ways.
abstract.5: Despite the variety of types of physical therapy and mode of delivery, all trials found no effects of the enhanced treatment compared with usual care.
abstract.6: In all cases, usual care required a lower dosage of physical therapy compared with the enhanced interventions.
abstract.7: This Perspective compares and contrasts the 3 trials, speculates on factors that could explain the no-effect findings, and proposes areas for future study designed to benefit the poor outcome phenotype.

adaptation2.1: Physical therapy (PT) is often given to patients that had knee replacement after after leaving the hospital.
adaptation2.2: PT after leaving the hospital is thought to be helpful, especially for patients with high risk of bad outcomes. These are patients with persistent pain that impairs function, even though the surgery seemed to go well.
adaptation2.3: Research teams have done 3 large-scale trials across different health care facilities, designed specifically for patients at risk of poor outcome following knee replacement.
adaptation2.4: All 3 trials checked for poor outcome risk using different methods and looked at different ways for physical therapists to try to help.
adaptation2.5: Despite the variety of types of physical therapy and how they were given, all trials found no effects of the enhanced treatment compared with usual care.
adaptation2.6: In all cases, usual care required a lower amount of physical therapy compared with the enhanced interventions.
adaptation2.7: This article expresses our opinions on recent research. It compares and contrasts the 3 trials, guesses what could explain the findings that there were no effects, and proposes areas for future studies that could help the people at high risk of bad outcomes.

67.question: How much physical therapy for knee replacement is needed?

32681497.Title: COVID-19 as part of the hyperferritinemic syndromes: the role of iron depletion therapy

abstract.1: SARS-CoV-2 infection is characterized by a protean clinical picture that can range from asymptomatic patients to life-threatening conditions.
abstract.2: Severe COVID-19 patients often display a severe pulmonary involvement and develop neutrophilia, lymphopenia, and strikingly elevated levels of IL-6.
abstract.3: There is an over-exuberant cytokine release with hyperferritinemia leading to the idea that COVID-19 is part of the hyperferritinemic syndrome spectrum.
abstract.4: Indeed, very high levels of ferritin can occur in other diseases including hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, macrophage activation syndrome, adult-onset Still's disease, catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome and septic shock.
abstract.5: Numerous studies have demonstrated the immunomodulatory effects of ferritin and its association with mortality and sustained inflammatory process.
abstract.6: High levels of free iron are harmful in tissues, especially through the redox damage that can lead to fibrosis.
abstract.7: Iron chelation represents a pillar in the treatment of iron overload.
abstract.8: In addition, it was proven to have an anti-viral and anti-fibrotic activity.
abstract.9: Herein, we analyse the pathogenic role of ferritin and iron during SARS-CoV-2 infection and propose iron depletion therapy as a novel therapeutic approach in the COVID-19 pandemic.

adaptation2.1: SARS-CoV-2 infection (a viral lung infection) can cause effects ranging from patients with no symptoms to life-threatening conditions.
adaptation2.2: Severe COVID-19 patients often display a severe lung effect and develop altered levels of immune cells and strikingly increased levels of IL-6 (an immune signaling molecule called a cytokine).
adaptation2.3: There is an increased cytokine release with hyperferritinemia (high levels of ferritin - an iron-containing protein). This leads to the idea that COVID-19 is part of the hyperferritinemic syndrome disease group.
adaptation2.4: Indeed, very high levels of ferritin can occur in other diseases including hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, macrophage activation syndrome, adult-onset Still's disease, catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome and septic shock (immune- or infection-related diseases).
adaptation2.5: Many studies have shown the immune-system-regulating effects of ferritin and its links with death risks and high inflammation.
adaptation2.6: High levels of free iron are harmful in the body, especially through damage that can lead to scarring.
adaptation2.7: Iron binding represents a pillar in the treatment of iron overload.
adaptation2.8: Also, it was proven to have an anti-viral and anti-scarring activity.
adaptation2.9: Herein, we analyse the disease-causing role of ferritin and iron during SARS-CoV-2 infection and propose iron depletion treatment as a new treatment in the COVID-19 pandemic.

33380357.Title: Association between iron status and the risk of adverse outcomes in COVID-19

abstract.1: Background and aims: Iron is an essential trace element to almost all organism, and the delicate balance between host defend system and viral proliferation plays an important role in infective conditions.
abstract.2: While the association of the iron metabolism with the prognosis of COVID-19 remains poorly understood.
abstract.3: We aimed to estimate the associations of systemic iron metabolism parameters with the severity and risks of adverse outcomes in COVID-19.
abstract.4: Methods: In this retrospective cohort study, we included 158 confirmed COVID-19 patients in Tongji Hospital, Wuhan, China (27 January to 5 April, 2020).
abstract.5: Demographic data, comorbidities, laboratory examinations, treatments, and clinical outcomes were all collected.
abstract.6: Multivariable Poisson regression was used to estimate the association of iron parameter levels with the severity and risks of adverse outcomes in COVID-19 patients.
abstract.7: Results: We identified 60 (38%) severe cases in 158 COVID-19 patients.
abstract.8: The median age was 63 years (interquartile range [IQR]: 54-73) and the median length of hospital stay was 28 days (IQR: 17-40).
abstract.9: After adjusting for age, sex, IL-6, and pre-existing comorbidities, all iron parameters were associated with the severity of COVID-19 with adjusted risk ratio of 0.42 [95% CI: 0.22-0.83], 4.38 [95% CI: 1.86-10.33], 0.19 [95% CI: 0.08-0.48], and 0.25 [95% CI: 0.10-0.58] for serum iron, ferritin, transferrin, and total iron-binding capacity, respectively.
abstract.10: These iron indices were also related to the risk of ARDS, coagulopathy, acute cardiac injury, acute liver injury, and acute kidney injury in COVID-19 patients and high cytokine concentrations.
abstract.11: Conclusions: Patients with low serum iron status likely suffered from severe condition and multiple-organ injury in COVID-19.
abstract.12: The iron metabolism parameters might be risk factors and clinical biomarkers for COVID-19 prognosis.

adaptation2.1: The background of this study is that iron is a necessary element to almost all living beings. The delicate balance between host immune system and viral growth plays an important role in infections.
adaptation2.2: The link between iron metabolism and recovery from COVID-19 (a viral lung infection) remains poorly understood.
adaptation2.3: We aimed to estimate the links between full-body iron metabolism with the severity and risks of side effects in COVID-19.
adaptation2.4: In this clinical study, we included 158 confirmed COVID-19 patients in Tongji Hospital, Wuhan, China (27 January to 5 April, 2020).
adaptation2.5: Basic background data, other diseases, lab tests, treatments, and clinical results were all collected.
adaptation2.6: A specific mathematical test was used to estimate the links between iron levels with the severity and risks of side effects in COVID-19 patients.
adaptation2.7: As a result, we identified 60 (38%) severe cases in 158 COVID-19 patients.
adaptation2.8: The average age was 63 years, and the average length of hospital stay was 28 days.
adaptation2.9: After adjusting for age, sex, immune signals, and pre-existing diseases, all iron measures were linked with the severity of COVID-19 for blood iron and iron-containing proteins.
adaptation2.10: These iron measures were also linked to the risk of a serious lung condition that leads to low blood oxygen, excessive bleeding or clotting, immediate heart-related injury, immediate liver injury, and immediate kidney injury in COVID-19 patients and high immune signal levels.
adaptation2.11: In conclusion, patients with low blood iron likely suffered from severe effects of and multiple-organ injury in COVID-19.
adaptation2.12: The iron metabolism measures might be risk factors and clinical markers for COVID-19 recovery.

34048587.Title: Optimal serum ferritin level range: iron status measure and inflammatory biomarker

abstract.1: This report provides perspectives concerning dual roles of serum ferritin as a measure of both iron status and inflammation.
abstract.2: We suggest benefits of a lower range of serum ferritin as has occurred for total serum cholesterol and fasting blood glucose levels.
abstract.3: Observations during a prospective randomized study using phlebotomy in patients with peripheral arterial disease offered unique insights into dual roles of serum ferritin both as an iron status marker and acute phase reactant.
abstract.4: Robust positive associations between serum ferritin, interleukin 6 [IL-6], tissue necrosis factor-alpha, and high sensitivity C-reactive protein were discovered.
abstract.5: Elevated serum ferritin and IL-6 levels associated with increased mortality and with reduced mortality at ferritin levels <100 ng mL-1.
abstract.6: Epidemiologic studies demonstrate similar outcomes.
abstract.7: Extremely elevated ferritin and IL-6 levels also occur in individuals with high mortality due to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
abstract.8: Disordered iron metabolism reflected by a high range of serum ferritin level signals disease severity and outcomes.
abstract.9: Based upon experimental and epidemiologic data, we suggest testing the hypotheses that optimal ferritin levels for cardiovascular mortality reduction range from 20 to 100 ng mL-1 with % transferrin levels from 20 to 50%, to ensure adequate iron status and that ferritin levels above 194 ng mL-1 associate with all-cause mortality in population cohorts.

adaptation2.1: This report talks about dual roles of blood ferritin (an iron-containing protein) as a measure of both iron status and inflammation (an infection-fighting process in the body).
adaptation2.2: We suggest benefits of a lower range of blood ferritin like with total blood cholesterol and fasting blood sugar levels.
adaptation2.3: Studying phlebotomy (vein puncturing) in patients with peripheral arterial disease (blockage of veins to the blood) offered unique insights into dual roles of blood ferritin both as an iron status marker and inflammation marker.
adaptation2.4: We found links between higher blood ferritin, higher interleukin 6 [IL-6] and tissue necrosis factor-alpha (immune signaling molecules), and high sensitivity C-reactive protein (a marker of inflammation).
adaptation2.5: Increased blood ferritin and IL-6 levels were linked with increased death rates and with reduced death rates at low ferritin levels.
adaptation2.6: Other large-population studies show similar results.
adaptation2.7: Extremely increased ferritin and IL-6 levels also occur in individuals with high death risks due to SARS-CoV-2 infection (infection from a virus causing a lung disease).
adaptation2.8: Disordered iron metabolism seen in a high range of blood ferritin level signals disease severity and results.
adaptation2.9: Based upon experiments and large patient group data, we suggest testing the idea that optimal ferritin levels for heart-related death rate reduction range from 20 to 100 ng/mL with % transferrin levels from 20 to 50%. This is to ensure a healthy iron status and that ferritin levels above 194 ng/mL link with all-cause death risk in patient groups.

34389110.Title: Iron metabolism in infections: Focus on COVID-19

abstract.1: Iron is a micronutrient essential for a wide range of metabolic processes in virtually all living organisms.
abstract.2: During infections, a battle for iron takes place between the human host and the invading pathogens.
abstract.3: The liver peptide hepcidin, which is phylogenetically and structurally linked to defensins (antimicrobial peptides of the innate immunity), plays a pivotal role by subtracting iron to pathogens through its sequestration into host cells, mainly macrophages.
abstract.4: While this phenomenon is well studied in certain bacterial infections, much less is known regarding viral infections.
abstract.5: Iron metabolism also has implications on the functionality of cells of the immune system.
abstract.6: Once primed by the contact with antigen presenting cells, lymphocytes need iron to sustain the metabolic burst required for mounting an effective cellular and humoral response.
abstract.7: The COVID-19 pandemic has boosted an amount of clinical and translational research over the possible influences of nutrients on SARS-CoV-2 infection, in terms of either susceptibility or clinical course.
abstract.8: Here we review the intersections between iron metabolism and COVID-19, belonging to the wider domain of the so-called "nutritional immunity".
abstract.9: A better understanding of such connections has potential broad implications, either from a mechanistic standpoint, or for the development of more effective strategies for managing COVID-19 and possible future pandemics.

adaptation2.1: Iron is a necessary nutrient for many metabolic processes in almost all living organisms.
adaptation2.2: During infections, a battle for iron takes place between the human and disease-causing organisms (pathogens).
adaptation2.3: The liver protein hepcidin, which is linked to defensins (bacteria-fighting proteins of the immune system), plays an important role by taking iron from pathogens by moving iron into human cells, mainly immune cells.
adaptation2.4: While this event is well known in certain bacterial infections, much less is known about viral infections.
adaptation2.5: Iron metabolism may also affect the function of cells of the immune system.
adaptation2.6: Once stimulated by touching cells with parts of foreign organisms attached to them, immune cells need iron to sustain the energy needed for an effective cellular and immune response.
adaptation2.7: The COVID-19 pandemic (caused by a virus causing a lung infection) has boosted clinical and medical research over the possible influences of nutrients on SARS-CoV-2 infection, in terms of either contracting or aiding the infection.
adaptation2.8: Here we review the links between iron metabolism and COVID-19, belonging to the wider field of study of the so-called "nutritional immunity".
adaptation2.9: A better understanding of these links may help develop more effective strategies for managing COVID-19 and possible future pandemics.

34883281.Title: Ferritin - from iron, through inflammation and autoimmunity, to COVID-19

abstract.1: While it took decades to arrive to a conclusion that ferritin is more than an indicator of iron storage level, it took a short period of time through the COVID-19 pandemic to wonder what the reason behind high levels of ferritin in patients with severe COVID-19 might be.
abstract.2: Unsurprisingly, acute phase reactant was not a satisfactory explanation.
abstract.3: Moreover, the behavior of ferritin in patients with severe COVID-19 and the subsequent high mortality rates in patients with high ferritin levels necessitated further investigations to understand the role of ferritin in the diseases.
abstract.4: Ferritin was initially described to accompany various acute infections, both viral and bacterial, indicating an acute response to inflammation.
abstract.5: However, with the introduction of the hyperferritinemic syndrome connecting four severe pathological conditions such as adult-onset Still's disease, macrophage activation syndrome, catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome, and septic shock added another aspect of ferritin where it could have a pathogenetic role rather than an extremely elevated protein only.
abstract.6: In fact, suggesting that COVID-19 is a new member in the spectrum of hyperferritinemic syndrome besides the four mentioned conditions could hopefully direct further search on the pathogenetic role of ferritin.
abstract.7: Doubtlessly, improving our understanding of those aspects of ferritin would enormously contribute to better coping with severe diseases in terms of treatment and prevention of complications.
abstract.8: The origin, history, importance, and the advances of searching the role of ferritin in various pathological and clinical processes are presented hereby in our article.
abstract.9: In addition, the implications of ferritin in COVID-19 are addressed.

adaptation2.1: While it took decades to learn that ferritin (an iron-containing protein) is more than a marker of iron storage level, it took some time during the COVID-19 pandemic (a pandemic caused by a virus that causes lung infections) to wonder why there are high levels of ferritin in patients with severe COVID-19.
adaptation2.2: Unsurprisingly, inflammation markers were not a satisfactory explanation.
adaptation2.3: Also, how ferritin acts in patients with severe COVID-19 and the resulting high death rates in patients with high ferritin levels forced further studies to understand the role of ferritin in the diseases.
adaptation2.4: Ferritin was at first described to accompany many immediate infections, both viral and bacterial, indicating an immediate response to inflammation.
adaptation2.5: However, with hyperferritinemic syndrome (high ferritin levels) linking four severe disease conditions such as adult-onset Still's disease, macrophage activation syndrome, catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome, and septic shock (immune- or infection-related diseases) added another aspect of ferritin where it could have a disease-causing role rather than an extremely increased protein only.
adaptation2.6: In fact, suggesting that COVID-19 is a new member in the range of hyperferritinemic syndrome besides the four mentioned conditions could hopefully direct further search on the disease-causing role of ferritin.
adaptation2.7: Without doubt, improving our understanding of those aspects of ferritin would enormously contribute to better treatment and side effect management with severe diseases.
adaptation2.8: We present the origin, history, importance, and the advances of searching the role of ferritin in various disease-causing and clinical processes in our article.
adaptation2.9: Also, the possibilities of ferritin in COVID-19 are addressed.

34924800.Title: Therapeutic Potential Of Induced Iron Depletion Using Iron Chelators In Covid-19

abstract.1: Ferritin, which includes twenty-four light and heavy chains in varying proportions in different tissues, is primarily responsible for maintaining the body's iron metabolism.
abstract.2: Its normal value is between 10 and 200 ngmL-1 in men and between 30-300 ngmL-1 in women.
abstract.3: Iron is delivered to the tissue via them, and they act as immunomodulators, signaling molecules, and inflammatory markers.
abstract.4: When ferritin level exceeds 1000 µgL-1, the patient is categorized as having hyperferritinemia.
abstract.5: Iron chelators such as deferiprone, deferirox, and deferoxamine are currently FDA approved to treat iron overload.
abstract.6: The inflammation cascade and poor prognosis of COVID-19 may be attributed to high ferritin levels.
abstract.7: Critically ill patients can benefit from deferasirox, an iron chelator administered orally at 20-40 mgkg-1 once daily, as well as intravenous deferoxamine at 1000 mg initially followed by 500 mg every 4 to 12 hours.
abstract.8: It can be combined with monoclonal antibodies, antioxidants, corticosteroids, and lactoferrin to make iron chelation therapy effective for COVID-19 victims.
abstract.9: In this article, we analyze the antiviral and antifibrotic activity of iron chelators, thereby promoting iron depletion therapy as a potentially innovative treatment strategy for COVID-19.

adaptation2.1: Ferritin (an iron-containing protein), which has 24 light and heavy parts in varying proportions in different tissues, is primarily responsible for maintaining the body's iron metabolism.
adaptation2.2: Its normal value is between 10 and 200 ngmL-1 in men and between 30-300 ngmL-1 in women.
adaptation2.3: Iron is delivered to the tissue via them, and they act as immune-system-regulators, signaling molecules, and inflammatory markers.
adaptation2.4: When ferritin level exceeds 1000 µgL-1, the patient is categorized as having hyperferritinemia (high ferritin levels).
adaptation2.5: Iron binders such as deferiprone, deferirox, and deferoxamine are currently FDA approved to treat iron overload (or high levels of iron).
adaptation2.6: The inflammation process and poor recovery of COVID-19 (a viral lung infection) may be linked to high ferritin levels.
adaptation2.7: Critically ill patients can benefit from deferasirox, an iron binder given by mouth at 20-40 mgkg-1 once daily, as well as deferoxamine initially given at 1000 mg in the vein followed by 500 mg every 4 to 12 hours.
adaptation2.8: It can be combined with antibodies (immune system products to fight infections), antioxidants, corticosteroids (specific steroids), and lactoferrin (a protein in mammalian milk) to make iron binding treatment effective for COVID-19 victims.
adaptation2.9: In this article, we analyze the antiviral and antiscarring activity of iron binders, thereby promoting iron depletion therapy as a possibly new treatment for COVID-19.

34960751.Title: Iron Related Biomarkers Predict Disease Severity in a Cohort of Portuguese Adult Patients during COVID-19 Acute Infection

abstract.1: Large variability in COVID-19 clinical progression urges the need to find the most relevant biomarkers to predict patients' outcomes.
abstract.2: We evaluated iron metabolism and immune response in 303 patients admitted to the main hospital of the northern region of Portugal with variable clinical pictures, from September to November 2020.
abstract.3: One hundred and twenty-seven tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and 176 tested negative.
abstract.4: Iron-related laboratory parameters and cytokines were determined in blood samples collected soon after admission.
abstract.5: Demographic data, comorbidities and clinical outcomes were recorded.
abstract.6: Patients were assigned into five groups according to severity.
abstract.7: Serum iron and transferrin levels at admission were lower in COVID-19-positive than in COVID-19-negative patients.
abstract.8: The levels of interleukin (IL)-6 and monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (MCP-1) were increased in COVID-19-positive patients.
abstract.9: The lowest serum iron and transferrin levels at diagnosis were associated with the worst outcomes.
abstract.10: Iron levels negatively correlated with IL-6 and higher levels of this cytokine were associated with a worse prognosis.
abstract.11: Serum ferritin levels at diagnosis were higher in COVID-19-positive than in COVID-19-negative patients.
abstract.12: Serum iron is the simplest laboratory test to be implemented as a predictor of disease progression in COVID-19-positive patients.

adaptation2.1: Large changes in COVID-19 (a viral lung infection) disease progression urges the need to find the most relevant markers to predict patients' outcomes.
adaptation2.2: We tested iron metabolism and immune response in 303 patients of the main hospital of the northern region of Portugal with different clinical needs, from September to November 2020.
adaptation2.3: One hundred and twenty-seven had SARS-CoV-2 and 176 did not.
adaptation2.4: Iron-related lab measures and immune signaling molecules were measured in blood samples collected soon after admission.
adaptation2.5: Basic background data, other diseases, and clinical results were recorded.
adaptation2.6: Patients were assigned into five groups according to severity.
adaptation2.7: Blood iron and transferrin (an iron-containing protein) levels at admission were lower in patients with COVID-19 than those without.
adaptation2.8: The levels of interleukin (IL)-6 and monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (MCP-1) (certain immune signaling molecules) were increased in patients with COVID-19.
adaptation2.9: The lowest blood iron and transferrin levels at diagnosis were linked with the worst outcomes.
adaptation2.10: Iron levels were lower with higher IL-6. Higher levels of this immune signaling molecule were linked with a worse recovery.
adaptation2.11: Blood ferritin (iron-containing protein) levels at diagnosis were higher in patients with COVID-19 than those without.
adaptation2.12: Blood iron is the simplest lab test to be used as a predictor of disease progression in COVID-19 patients.

35008695.Title: H-Ferritin Produced by Myeloid Cells Is Released to the Circulation and Plays a Major Role in Liver Iron Distribution during Infection

abstract.1: During infections, the host redistributes iron in order to starve pathogens from this nutrient.
abstract.2: Several proteins are involved in iron absorption, transport, and storage.
abstract.3: Ferritin is the most important iron storage protein.
abstract.4: It is composed of variable proportions of two peptides, the L- and H-ferritins (FTL and FTH).
abstract.5: We previously showed that macrophages increase their expression of FTH1 when they are infected in vitro with Mycobacterium avium, without a significant increase in FTL.
abstract.6: In this work, we investigated the role of macrophage FTH1 in M. avium infection in vivo.
abstract.7: We found that mice deficient in FTH1 in myeloid cells are more resistant to M. avium infection, presenting lower bacterial loads and lower levels of proinflammatory cytokines than wild-type littermates, due to the lower levels of available iron in the tissues.
abstract.8: Importantly, we also found that FTH1 produced by myeloid cells in response to infection may be found in circulation and that it plays a key role in iron redistribution.
abstract.9: Specifically, in the absence of FTH1 in myeloid cells, increased expression of ferroportin is observed in liver granulomas and increased iron accumulation occurs in hepatocytes.
abstract.10: These results highlight the importance of FTH1 expression in myeloid cells for iron redistribution during infection.

adaptation2.1: During infections, the human moves around iron in order to starve disease-causing molecules (pathogens) from this nutrient.
adaptation2.2: Several proteins are involved in iron absorption, transport, and storage.
adaptation2.3: Ferritin is the most important iron storage protein.
adaptation2.4: It is made up of different amounts of two proteins, the L- and H-ferritins (FTL and FTH).
adaptation2.5: We previously showed that macrophages (specific immune cells) increase their amount of FTH1 when they are infected as cells in a test tube with Mycobacterium avium (bacteria related to tuberculosis), without a significant increase in FTL.
adaptation2.6: In this work, we tested the role of macrophage FTH1 in M. avium infection as cells in a living organism.
adaptation2.7: We found that mice low in FTH1 in myeloid cells (specific bone marrow cells) are more resistant to M. avium infection. They have lower bacterial amounts and lower levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines (infection signaling molecules) than normal mice, due to the lower levels of available iron in their bodies.
adaptation2.8: Importantly, we also found that FTH1 made by myeloid cells due to infection may be found in blood and that it plays a key role in iron redistribution.
adaptation2.9: Specifically, without FTH1 in myeloid cells, increased amounts of ferroportin (iron-transporting proteins) is observed in liver granulomas (small areas of inflammation) and increased iron storage occurs in liver cells.
adaptation2.10: These results show the importance of FTH1 in myeloid cells for iron redistribution during infection.

35136706.Title: Evaluation of ferritin level in COVID-19 patients and its inflammatory response

abstract.1: The importance of ferritin as an inflammatory marker is well recognized.
abstract.2: However, it is unknown whether this differs between Covid-19 and non-Covid-19 patients.
abstract.3: The blood levels of ferritin, white blood cells (WBC), C-reactive protein (CRP), and lactate dehydrogenase may all be measured to check whether there is a difference.
abstract.4: The researchers want to see if the inflammatory process changes between these two kinds (LDH).
abstract.5: Methodology: Blood samples were collected from 119 COVID-19 patients in the hospital and 50 healthy persons.
abstract.6: Corona virus was discovered when a nasopharyngeal swab was collected and tested using the RT-PCR technique.
abstract.7: Ferritin, LDH, WBC, and CRP were also tested using Min Vidus, AccEnT 200, Ruby system, and Latx in that sequence.
abstract.8: The study revealed that COVID-19 patients had higher levels of ferritin, WBC, CRP, and LDH in their blood than healthy people, with values of 539,08 ng/mL, 44.7109/L, 22.95 mg/L, and 403.95 U/L for COVID-19 patients versus 77.103 ng/mL, 4.9.4109/L, 6.53 mg/L, and 171.56 U/L for healthy people.
abstract.9: According to the existing data, males are more likely to be infected with COVID-19 (81%) than females (32%), and females had greater ferritin, CRP, WBC, and LDH levels than males.
abstract.10: Because they are related to an optimum test for predicting COVID-19 infection, the recommended cut-off values for ferritin, WBC, CRP, and LDH are 109.8 ng/mL, 14.9109/L, 10.15 mg/L, and 229.33 U/L, respectively.
abstract.11: Finally, an increase in ferritin levels in the inflammatory response to COVID-19 is linked to an increase in inflammatory markers including CRP, WBC, and LDH, which may assist in the diagnosis of COVID-19 infection.

adaptation2.1: The importance of ferritin (an iron-containing protein) as an inflammatory marker is well known.
adaptation2.2: However, it is unknown whether this differs between Covid-19 (a viral lung infection) and non-Covid-19 patients.
adaptation2.3: The blood levels of ferritin, white blood cells (WBC - specific immune cells), C-reactive protein (CRP - a marker of inflammation), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH; an enzyme that helps make energy) may all be measured to check whether there is a difference.
adaptation2.4: The researchers want to see if the inflammatory process changes between these two kinds.
adaptation2.5: Blood samples were collected from 119 COVID-19 patients in the hospital and 50 healthy persons.
adaptation2.6: Corona virus (which causes COVID-19) was discovered when a nose swab was collected and tested for fragments of the virus.
adaptation2.7: Ferritin, LDH, WBC, and CRP were also tested in that sequence.
adaptation2.8: The study revealed that COVID-19 patients had higher levels of ferritin, WBC, CRP, and LDH in their blood than healthy people.
adaptation2.9: From the existing data, males are more likely to be infected with COVID-19 (81%) than females (32%). Females had greater ferritin, CRP, WBC, and LDH levels than males.
adaptation2.10: Because they are related to a test for predicting COVID-19 infection, the recommended cut-off values for ferritin, WBC, CRP, and LDH are 109.8 ng/mL, 14.9109/L, 10.15 mg/L, and 229.33 U/L, respectively.
adaptation2.11: Finally, an increase in ferritin levels in the inflammatory response to COVID-19 is linked to an increase in inflammatory markers including CRP, WBC, and LDH. This understanding  may assist in the identification of COVID-19 infection.

35240553.Title: Trace element homeostasis in the neurological system after SARS-CoV-2 infection: Insight into potential biochemical mechanisms

abstract.1: Background: Several studies have suggested that COVID-19 is a systemic disease that can affect several organs, including the brain.
abstract.2: In the brain, specifically, viral infection can cause dyshomeostasis of some trace elements that promote complex biochemical reactions in specialized neurological functions.
abstract.3: Objective: Understand the neurovirulence of SARS-CoV-2 and the relationship between trace elements and neurological disorders after infection, and provide new insights on the drug development for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infections.
abstract.4: Methods: The main databases were used to search studies published up September 2021, focusing on the role of trace elements during viral infection and on the correct functioning of the brain.
abstract.5: Results: The imbalance of important trace elements can accelerate SARS-CoV-2 neurovirulence and increase the neurotoxicity since many neurological processes can be associated with the homeostasis of metal and metalloproteins.
abstract.6: Some studies involving animals and humans have suggested the synapse as a vulnerable region of the brain to neurological disorders after viral infection.
abstract.7: Considering the combined evidence, some mechanisms have been suggested to understand the relationship between neurological disorders and imbalance of trace elements in the brain after viral infection.
abstract.8: Conclusion: Trace elements play important roles in viral infections, such as helping to activate immune cells, produce antibodies, and inhibit virus replication.
abstract.9: However, the relationship between trace elements and virus infections is complex since the specific functions of several elements remain largely undefined.
abstract.10: Therefore, there is still a lot to be explored to understand the biochemical mechanisms involved between trace elements and viral infections, especially in the brain.

adaptation2.1: As background for this article, several studies have suggested that COVID-19 (a viral lung infection) is a full-body disease that can affect several organs, including the brain.
adaptation2.2: In the brain, specifically, viral infection can cause imbalances of some nutrients that promote complex biochemical reactions in certain brain functions.
adaptation2.3: The study's objective is to understand the disease-causing ability of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus causing COVID-19) in the brain and the link between certain nutrients and brain disorders after infection. The objective is also to provide new insights on the drug creation for the treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infections.
adaptation2.4: Databases were used to search studies published up September 2021, focusing on the role of specific elements during viral infection and on the correct functioning of the brain.
adaptation2.5: The imbalance of important elements can increase SARS-CoV-2 effects in the brain and increase the damage to the brain since many brain processes can be linked with the balance of metal and metal-carrying proteins.
adaptation2.6: Some studies involving animals and humans have suggested the link between brain cells as a vulnerable region of the brain to brain disorders after viral infection.
adaptation2.7: Considering all the evidence, some mechanisms have been suggested to understand the link between brain disorders and imbalance of specific elements in the brain after viral infection.
adaptation2.8: In conclusion, certain elements play important roles in viral infections, such as helping to activate immune cells, produce antibodies that fight infections, and block virus growth.
adaptation2.9: However, the link between specific elements and virus infections is complex since the specific functions of several elements is largely unknown.
adaptation2.10: Thus, there is much to be explored to understand the biochemical processes involved between specific elements and viral infections, especially in the brain.

68.question: Why is transferrin and iron low in covid patients but ferritin high?

11707664.Title: What interventions may reduce postpartum depression

abstract.1: Postnatal depression is a major public health problem affecting about one in seven women after childbirth.
abstract.2: Depression is also common during pregnancy and throughout the perinatal period it is associated with symptoms of anxiety.
abstract.3: Apart from the adverse consequences for women themselves becoming depressed when they are going through demanding physical and social changes, there are additional concerns.
abstract.4: There is the possible negative impact of maternal depression on the relationship between mother and child and on the child's emotional, behavioural and cognitive development.
abstract.5: Primary prevention and early intervention/secondary prevention strategies are potentially important in view of the frequent contact pregnant women, new mothers and infants have with health services, but the effectiveness of these strategies needs to be tested.
abstract.6: In the past year there have been five new studies of antenatal screening for postnatal depression.
abstract.7: These studies are consistent with nine earlier studies in showing that there is no evidence to support routine antenatal screening for postnatal depression.
abstract.8: Seven new primary prevention/early intervention trials add evidence on a wide range of interventions ranging from practical support to individual interpersonal therapy, but without identifying significant differences in depression as an outcome.
abstract.9: Two new trials of secondary prevention, one involving interpersonal therapy and the other including partners in a series of psychoeducational visits, show promise but neither is large enough to form a basis for practice change.
abstract.10: Novel interventions, or promising findings, with a strong basis in theory need to be tested in trials which are appropriately sized and which comply with internationally accepted design and reporting guidelines.

adaptation3.1: Postnatal depression (depression after childbirth) is a major public health problem. It affects about one in seven women after childbirth.
adaptation3.2: Depression is also common during pregnancy and throughout the perinatal period (time of pregnancy and after childbirth ). it is associated with symptoms of anxiety.
adaptation3.3: There are harmful effects for women themselves to become depressed when they are going through demanding physical and social changes. But there are also other concerns.
adaptation3.4: Maternal depression can cause problems with the relationship between mother and child. There can also be problems with the child's emotional, behavioral and cognitive (thinking) development.
adaptation3.5: Prevention and early interventions may be important in view of the frequent contact pregnant women, new mothers and infants have with health services. The effectiveness of these interventions needs to be tested.
adaptation3.6: In the past year there have been five new studies of antenatal (during pregnancy) screening for postnatal depression.
adaptation3.7: These studies agree with nine earlier studies showing that there is no evidence to support routine antenatal screening for postnatal depression.
adaptation3.8: Seven new prevention and early intervention studies add evidence on a wide range of treatments ranging from practical support to individual interpersonal therapy.  These studies have not found significant differences in the outcome of depression.
adaptation3.9: Two new studies on the prevention of the recurrence of depression show promise of success. One invention study involves interpersonal therapy and the other includes partners in psychoeducational visits. Neither study is large enough to form a basis for practice change.
adaptation3.10: New interventions, or promising findings, with a strong basis in theory need to be tested in trials (human studies) which are large enough and which meet internationally accepted standards and guidelines.

23394227.Title: Postpartum depression: current status and future directions

abstract.1: Postpartum depression (PPD) is a common and serious mental health problem that is associated with maternal suffering and numerous negative consequences for offspring.
abstract.2: The first six months after delivery may represent a high-risk time for depression.
abstract.3: Estimates of prevalence range from 13% to 19%.
abstract.4: Risk factors mirror those typically found with major depression, with the exception of postpartum-specific factors such as sensitivity to hormone changes.
abstract.5: Controlled trials of psychological interventions have validated a variety of individual and group interventions.
abstract.6: Medication often leads to depression improvement, but in controlled trials there are often no significant differences in outcomes between patients in the medication condition and those in placebo or active control conditions.
abstract.7: Reviews converge on recommendations for particular antidepressant medications for use while breastfeeding.
abstract.8: Prevention of PPD appears to be feasible and effective.
abstract.9: Finally, there is a growing movement to integrate mental health screening into routine primary care for pregnant and postpartum women and to follow up this screening with treatment or referral and with follow-up care.
abstract.10: Research and clinical recommendations are made throughout this review.

adaptation3.1: Postpartum depression (PPD-depression after childbirth) is a common and serious mental health problem. It is associated with maternal suffering and numerous negative consequences for offspring.
adaptation3.2: The first six months after delivery may represent a high-risk time for depression.
adaptation3.3: Estimates of occurrence range from 13% to 19%.
adaptation3.4: Risk factors mirror those typically found with major depression, except the hormone changes found after childbirth.
adaptation3.5: Studies of psychological treatments have proved a variety of individual and group interventions work.
adaptation3.6: Medication often leads to depression improvement. But In research studies, there are often no significant differences in outcomes between patients on medication and those not on medication (placebo or active control groups).
adaptation3.7: Reviews meet up on recommendations for particular antidepressant medications for use while breastfeeding.
adaptation3.8: Prevention of PPD can be done and treatments are effective.
adaptation3.9: There is a growing movement to add mental health screening into routine primary care for pregnant and postpartum women. This screening should be followed-up with treatment or referral and with follow-up care.
adaptation3.10: Research and patient recommendations are made throughout this review.

25422150.Title: Preventing postpartum depression: review and recommendations

abstract.1: Nearly 20% of mothers will experience an episode of major or minor depression within the first 3 months postpartum, making it the most common complication of childbearing.
abstract.2: Postpartum depression (PPD) is significantly undertreated, and because prospective mothers are especially motivated for self-care, a focus on the prevention of PPD holds promise of clinical efficacy.
abstract.3: This study is a qualitative review of existing approaches to prevent PPD.
abstract.4: A PubMed search identified studies of methods of PPD prevention.
abstract.5: The search was limited to peer-reviewed, published, English-language, randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of biological, psychological, and psychosocial interventions.
abstract.6: Eighty articles were initially identified, and 45 were found to meet inclusion criteria.
abstract.7: Eight RCTs of biological interventions were identified and 37 RCTs of psychological or psychosocial interventions.
abstract.8: Results were mixed, with 20 studies showing clear positive effects of an intervention and 25 showing no effect.
abstract.9: Studies differed widely in screening, population, measurement, and intervention.
abstract.10: Among biological studies, anti-depressants and nutrients provided the most evidence of successful intervention.
abstract.11: Among psychological and psychosocial studies, 13/17 successful trials targeted an at-risk population, and 4/7 trials using interpersonal therapy demonstrated success of the intervention versus control, with a further two small studies showing trends toward statistical significance.
abstract.12: Existing approaches to the prevention of PPD vary widely, and given the current literature, it is not possible to identify one approach that is superior to others.
abstract.13: Interpersonal therapy trials and trials that targeted an at-risk population appear to hold the most promise for further study.

adaptation3.1: Nearly 20% of mothers will experience an episode of major or minor depression within the first 3 months after childbirth (postpartum depression). This shows it is the most common complication of childbearing.
adaptation3.2: Many times postpartum depression (PPD) is not treated adequately. Because people planning to become mothers are especially motivated for self-care, focusing on preventing PPD brings hope for the best outcome.
adaptation3.3: This research reviews the accepted ways to prevent PPD.
adaptation3.4: A search of articles written about ways to prevent PPD was done using the PubMed search engine.
adaptation3.5: The search only included published articles, written in English, that were evaluated by experts in the same field as the authors.  These articles were on studies about the psychology, biology (bodily function), and social aspects of PPD.
adaptation3.6: This search found 88 studies. Only 45 of them met the rules to be included in this research.
adaptation3.7: Of the 45 studies that were included, 8 studies were about biological treatments, and 37 were about psychological or social treatments.
adaptation3.8: Of these 45 studies, 20 studies showed good effects from the treatment and 25 studies showed no effect from the treatment.
