29360984.Title: Regulation of ciliary function by fibroblast growth factor signaling identifies FGFR3-related disorders achondroplasia and thanatophoric dysplasia as ciliopathies

abstract.1: Cilia project from almost every cell integrating extracellular cues with signaling pathways.
abstract.2: Constitutive activation of FGFR3 signaling produces the skeletal disorders achondroplasia (ACH) and thanatophoric dysplasia (TD), but many of the molecular mechanisms underlying these phenotypes remain unresolved.
abstract.3: Here, we report in vivo evidence for significantly shortened primary cilia in ACH and TD cartilage growth plates.
abstract.4: Using in vivo and in vitro methodologies, our data demonstrate that transient versus sustained activation of FGF signaling correlated with different cilia consequences.
abstract.5: Transient FGF pathway activation elongated cilia, while sustained activity shortened cilia.
abstract.6: FGF signaling extended primary cilia via ERK MAP kinase and mTORC2 signaling, but not through mTORC1.
abstract.7: Employing a GFP-tagged IFT20 construct to measure intraflagellar (IFT) speed in cilia, we showed that FGF signaling affected IFT velocities, as well as modulating cilia-based Hedgehog signaling.
abstract.8: Our data integrate primary cilia into canonical FGF signal transduction and uncover a FGF-cilia pathway that needs consideration when elucidating the mechanisms of physiological and pathological FGFR function, or in the development of FGFR therapeutics.

adaptation3.2: Continuous activation of FGFR3 signaling produces the bone growth disorders achondroplasia (ACH) and thanatophoric dysplasia (TD), but many of the molecular mechanisms underlying these remain unresolved.
adaptation3.3: Here, the authors report that primary cilia in ACH and TD cartilage growth regions are significantly shorter.
adaptation3.4: Data demonstrate that transient versus continuous activation of fibrblast growth factor (FGF) signaling correlates with size of the cilia.
adaptation3.5: Transient FGF pathway activation elongated cilia, while continuous activity shortened cilia.
adaptation3.6: FGF signaling extended primary cilia via  a pathway involving ERK MAP kinase and mTORC2, but not through mTORC1.
adaptation3.8: Authors uncover a FGF-cilia pathway that is involved in the mechanisms of FGFR function, and should be considered in the development of therapies for FGFR function.

71.question: What happens in the body to cause achondroplasia?

9483156.Title: Newborn screening for inborn errors of metabolism: a systematic review

abstract.1: OBJECTIVES. To establish a database of literature and other evidence on neonatal screening programmes and technologies for inborn errors of metabolism.
abstract.2: To undertake a systematic review of the data as a basis for evaluation of newborn screening for inborn errors of metabolism.
abstract.3: To prepare an objective summary of the evidence on the appropriateness and need for various existing and possible neonatal screening programmes for inborn errors of metabolism in relation to the natural history of these diseases.
abstract.4: To identify gaps in existing knowledge and make recommendations for required primary research.
abstract.5: To make recommendations for the future development and organisation of neonatal screening for inborn errors of metabolism in the UK.
abstract.6: HOW THE RESEARCH WAS CONDUCTED. There were three parts to the research.
abstract.7: A systematic review of the literature on inborn errors of metabolism, neonatal screening programmes, new technologies for screening and economic factors.
abstract.8: Inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied, and a working database of relevant papers was established.
abstract.9: All selected papers were read by two or three experts and were critically appraised using a standard format.
abstract.10: Seven criteria for a screening programme, based on the principles formulated by Wilson and Jungner (WHO, 1968), were used to summarise the evidence.
abstract.11: These were as follows.
abstract.12: Clinically and biochemically well-defined disorder.
abstract.13: Known incidence in populations relevant to the UK.
abstract.14: Disorder associated with significant morbidity or mortality.
abstract.15: Effective treatment available.
abstract.16: Period before onset during which intervention improves outcome.
abstract.17: Ethical, safe, simple and robust screening test.
abstract.18: Cost-effectiveness of screening.
abstract.19: A questionnaire which was sent to all newborn screening laboratories in the UK.
abstract.20: Site visits to assess new methodologies for newborn screening.
abstract.21: The classical definition of an inborn error of metabolism was used (i.e., a monogenic disease resulting in deficient activity in a single enzyme in a pathway of intermediary metabolism).
abstract.22: RESEARCH FINDINGS. INBORN ERRORS OF METABOLISM. Phenylketonuria (PKU) (incidence 1:12,000) fulfilled all the screening criteria and could be used as the 'gold standard' against which to review other disorders despite significant variation in methodologies, sample collection and timing of screening and inadequacies in the infrastructure for notification and continued care of identified patients.
abstract.23: Of the many disorders of organic acid and fatty acid metabolism, a case can only be made for the introduction of newborn screening for glutaric aciduria type 1 (GA1; estimated incidence 1:40,000) and medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency (estimated incidence 1:8000-1:15,000).
abstract.24: Therapeutic advances for GA1 offer prevention of neurological damage but further investigation is required into the costs and benefits of screening for this disorder.
abstract.25: MCAD deficiency is simply and cheaply treatable, preventing possible early death and neurological handicap.
abstract.26: Neonatal screening for these diseases is dependent upon the introduction of tandem mass spectrometry (tandem MS).
abstract.27: This screening could however also simultaneously detect some other commonly-encountered disorders of organic acid metabolism with a collective incidence of 1:15,000.
abstract.28: Neonatal screening for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency (incidence 1:17,000) has been shown to be beneficial in other countries and similar benefits should accrue in the UK.
abstract.29: A national programme of neonatal screening for CAH would be justified, with reassessment after an agreed period.
abstract.30: Biotinidase deficiency is of low incidence in the UK (estimated 1:100,000), but this may be outweighed by the simplicity of the screening methodology and the benefits in prevention.

adaptation2.1: Our first goal in this article was to establish a database of literature and other evidence on newborn screening programmes and technology for genetic disorders related to metabolism.
adaptation2.2: We also aimed to rigorously review data to evaluate newborn screening for genetic disorders related to metabolism.
adaptation2.3: We aimed to summarize the evidence for whether various newborn screening programs for genetic disorders related to metabolism are appropriate and necessary. We aimed to make this summary in relation to the natural history of these diseases, and for both existing and possible programs.
adaptation2.4: We further aimed to identify gaps in knowledge and make recommendations for further research that is needed.
adaptation2.5: Finally, we aimed to make recommendations for the future development and organisation of newborn screening for genetic disorders related to metabolism in the UK.
adaptation2.6: There were three parts to this research.
adaptation2.7: We rigorously reviewed research papers on genetic disorders related to metabolism, newborn screening programs, new technologies for screening, and economic factors.
adaptation2.8: We decided how we would include or exclude papers, and made a working database of relevant papers.
adaptation2.9: All the papers we selected were read by two or three experts and were critically assessed using a standard format.
adaptation2.10: Seven criteria for a screening programme, based on the principles formulated by Wilson and Jungner (WHO, 1968), were used to summarise the evidence.
adaptation2.11: These were the following:
adaptation2.12: The disorder is well defined by signs and symptoms.
adaptation2.13: The disease occurs in populations relevant to the UK.
adaptation2.14: The disorder is associated with serious health problems or death.
adaptation2.15: Effective treatment is available for the disease.
adaptation2.16: The disorder can be helped by addressing it in the time before it appears.
adaptation2.17: There is an ethical, safe, simple and robust screening test for the disorder.
adaptation2.18: Screening for the disorder is cost-effective.
adaptation2.19: A questionnaire was sent to all newborn screening laboratories in the UK.
adaptation2.20: There are site visits to assess new methodologies for newborn screening.
adaptation2.21: We used the traditional way of defining a genetic disorder related to metabolism. This was that the disorder was caused by a single mutated gene that affected a single type of enzyme needed for metabolism.
adaptation2.22: We found that phenylketonuria matched all the                                  criteria. This disorder could be used as a gold standard when comparing other disorders, even though the screening process can vary and systems for notifying patients are not good enough.
adaptation2.23: Of the many disorders of metabolism of organic and fatty acids, we can only make the case for newborn screening of Glutaric Aciduria type 1 (GA1) and Medium-Chain Acy-CoA Dehydrogenase (MCAD deficiency).
adaptation2.24: Advancements in therapy for GA1 can prevent damage to the brain and nerves but more research into the costs and benefits of screening for this disorder is needed.
adaptation2.25: MCAD deficiency can be treated simply and cheaply, preventing possible early death and brain handicap.
adaptation2.26: Newborn screening for these diseases depends on the introduction of tandem Mass Spectrometry (tandem MS) technology.
adaptation2.27: But, this screening could also detect some other disorders at the same time. These other disorders are related to organic acid metabolism and happen to one in 15,000 people.
adaptation2.28: Newborn screening for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) has worked well in other countries and the UK should see similar benefits. This disease occurs in one in 17,000 people.
adaptation2.29: A national programme of newborn screening for CAH would be justified, and could be looked at again after an agreed period of time.
adaptation2.30: Another disorder, biotinidase deficiency, is rare in the UK (estimated at one in 100,000), but that may be outweighed by how simple the screening process is and the benefits of preventing the disease.

17183568.Title: The clinical aspects of newborn screening: importance of newborn screening follow-up

abstract.1: The aim of newborn screening is to identify presymptomatic healthy infants that will develop significant metabolic or endocrine derangements if left undiagnosed and untreated.
abstract.2: The goal of ultimately reducing or eliminating irreversible sequelae is reached by maximizing test sensitivity of the primary newborn screening that measures specific analytes by a number of methodologies.
abstract.3: Differentiation of true from false negatives is accomplished by the test specificity.
abstract.4: This review discusses disorders for which, in general, there are available therapies and that are detected by routine and expanded newborn screening.
abstract.5: Recommendations are presented for evaluation by a primary care physician, with confirmation by a metabolic or endocrinology specialist.
abstract.6: Disorders are organized in tabular format by class of pathway or analyte, with attention to typical clinical presentations, confirmatory biochemical and molecular tests, and therapies.
abstract.7: There are numerous challenges in clinical follow-up, including diagnosis and appropriate understanding of the consequences of the disorders.
abstract.8: The data required to meet these challenges can be acquired only by large scale longitudinal comprehensive studies of outcome in children identified by newborn screening.
abstract.9: Only with such data can newborn screening fully serve families.

adaptation2.1: The aim of newborn screening is to identify healthy infants that will develop significant metabolic or endocrine disorders if left undiagnosed and untreated.
adaptation2.2: Newborn screening measures specific substances in various ways. Using the most sensitive screening tests can ultimately reduce or eliminate permanent consequences.
adaptation2.3: Specificity of a test distinguishes true negative results from false negative results (when the test is negative but the patient actually has the disease).
adaptation2.4: In general, this article discusses disorders that have treatments and that can be detected by routine and expanded newborn screening.
adaptation2.5: We give recommendations for testing by a general practice doctor, with confirmation by a metabolic or endocrine specialist.
adaptation2.6: We organize disorders in a table by the physical process they affect in the body or by the substance that is tested. In doing this we also pay attention to how the disease first appears, lab tests that can confirm the disorders, and treatments available.
adaptation2.7: There are many challenges for following up with patients, including diagnosis and appropriate understanding of the consequences of the disorders.
adaptation2.8: Meeting these challenges will require information. This can only be gained with large-scale studies that follow children identified by newborn screening over time to see their outcomes.
adaptation2.9: Newborn screening can only fully serve families once we have this knowledge.

abstract.1: The aim of newborn screening is to detect newborns with serious, treatable disorders so as to facilitate appropriate interventions to avoid or ameliorate adverse outcomes.
abstract.2: Mass biochemical testing of newborn babies was pioneered in the 1960s with the introduction of screening for phenylketonuria, a rare inborn error of metabolism, tested by using a dried blood spot sample.
abstract.3: The next disorder introduced into screening programs was congenital hypothyroidism and a few more much rarer disorders were gradually included.
abstract.4: Two recent advances have greatly changed the pace: modification of tandem mass spectrometry and DNA extraction and analysis from newborn screening dried blood spot.
abstract.5: These two technologies make the future possibilities of newborn screening seem almost unlimited.
abstract.6: Newborn screening tests are usually carried out on a dried blood spot sample, for which there are special analytical considerations.
abstract.7: Dried blood spot calibrators and controls, prepared on the same lot number of filter paper, are needed.
abstract.8: Methods have a co-efficient of variation of about 10% due to the increased variability of a dried filter paper sample compared with other biochemical samples.
abstract.9: The haematocrit is an additional variable not able to be measured.
abstract.10: Also of importance is obtaining a balance between the sensitivity and specificity of each assay.
abstract.11: Fixing cut-off points for action needs consideration of what is an acceptable percentage of the population to recall for further testing.
abstract.12: Few assays are 100% discriminatory.
abstract.13: Programs in Australasia currently screen for at least 30 disorders.
abstract.14: Detection of these requires not only the assay of a primary marker but often determination of a ratio of that marker with another, or possibly an alternative assay, for example a DNA mutation.
abstract.15: The most important disorders screened for are described briefly: phenylketonuria, primary congenital hypothyroidism, cystic fibrosis, the galactosaemias, medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency and congenital adrenal hyperplasia, together with several other disorders detectable by tandem mass spectrometry.
abstract.16: Newborn screening deals with rare disorders and benefit cannot be shown easily without very large pilot studies.
abstract.17: There have been randomised controlled trials of screening for cystic fibrosis, and now several studies are beginning to establish the benefit of tandem mass spectrometry screening for disorders of fatty acid and amino acid metabolism.
abstract.18: Two things will influence the new directions for newborn screening: the development of effective treatments for hitherto untreatable disorders, and advancing technology, enabling new testing strategies to be developed.
abstract.19: There are novel treatments on the horizon for many discrete disorders.
abstract.20: Susceptibility testing has recently been considered for newborn screening application, but is more controversial.
abstract.21: Newborn screening has entered a new and exciting phase, with an explosion of new treatments, new technologies, and, possibly in the future, new preventive strategies.

adaptation2.1: The goal of newborn screening is to detect newborns with serious, treatable disorders. This allows appropriate action to be taken to prevent or lessen bad outcomes.
adaptation2.2: Large-scale lab testing of newborn babies was pioneered in the 1960s with the introduction of screening for phenylketonuria, a rare, inherited metabolic disorder. This testing was done by using dried blood spot samples.
adaptation2.3: The next disorder introduced into screening programs was congenital hypothyroidism, which is an inherited disorder of the thyroid gland, which controls metabolism. A few more much rarer disorders were gradually included.
adaptation2.4: Two recent advances have greatly change the pace. These are modification of tandem mass spectrometry (an advanced chemical detection technique, also known as MS/MS) and DNA analysis from newborn screening dried blood spots.
adaptation2.5: These two technologies make the future possibilities of newborn screening seem almost unlimited.
adaptation2.6: Newborn screening test are usually done with a dried blood spot sample, which needs to be considered when analyzing.
adaptation2.7: Extra dried blood spots need to be prepared on the same filter paper to calibrate the tests.
adaptation2.8: Since dried filter paper samples have more variability than other types of samples, the results of these tests can vary by about 10% or more.
adaptation2.9: Additionally, the amount of red blood cells cannot be measured.
adaptation2.10: It is also important to balance how sensitive the test is (how good it is at finding a problem) with how specific it is (how sure you can be when a problem is found).
adaptation2.11: In deciding how to balance these, we need to consider how many people it is acceptable to bring back for more testing.
adaptation2.12: Not many tests are perfectly accurate.
adaptation2.13: Programs in Australasia currently screen for at least 30 disorders.
adaptation2.14: Detecting these disorders often requires more than just knowing one amount. It can require knowing relative amounts of two different things, or could require an additional alternative test, like a genetic test.
adaptation2.15: In this article we will briefly describe the most important disorders that are screened for. These are phenylketonuria, hypothyroidism, Cystic Fibrosis (CF), galactosaemias, Medium-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency, Glutaryl-CoA Dehydrogenase (GCDH) deficiency and Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), along with several other disorders detectable by MS/MS.
adaptation2.16: Newborn screening deals with rare disorders and it is hard to see the benefit without very large studies.
adaptation2.17: There have been randomised controlled trials of screening for cystic fibrosis. Also, several studies are now beginning to show the benefit of MS/MS screening for disorders relating to fatty acid and amino acid metabolism.
adaptation2.18: Two things will influence the new directions for newborn screening. The first is the development of effective treatments for disorders that don’t currently have them. The second is advancing technology that will enable new testing strategies to be developed.
adaptation2.19: There are new treatments on the horizon for many distinct disorders.
adaptation2.20: Testing for being at risk for disorders has recently been considered for newborn screening, but this is more controversial.
adaptation2.21: Newborn screening has entered a new and exciting phase, with an explosion of new treatments, new technologies, and, possibly in the future, new preventive strategies.

abstract.1: Early detection of many disorders, mainly inherited, is feasible with population-wide analysis of newborn dried blood spot samples.
abstract.2: Phenylketonuria was the prototype disorder for newborn screening (NBS) and early dietary treatment has resulted in vastly improved outcomes for this disorder.
abstract.3: Testing for primary hypothyroidism and cystic fibrosis (CF) was later added to NBS programs following the development of robust immunoassays and molecular testing.
abstract.4: Current CF testing usually relies on a combined immunoreactive trypsin/mutation detection strategy.
abstract.5: Multiplex testing for approximately 25 inborn errors of metabolism using tandem mass spectrometry is a relatively recent addition to NBS.
abstract.6: The simultaneous introduction of many disorders has caused some re-evaluation of the traditional guidelines for NBS, because very rare disorders or disorders without good treatments can be included with minimal effort.
abstract.7: NBS tests for many other disorders have been developed, but these are less uniformly applied or are currently considered developmental.
abstract.8: This review focuses on Australasian NBS practices.

adaptation2.1: Many disorders (but mostly ones that are inherited) can be detected early by looking at dried blood spot samples of newborns across the population.
adaptation2.2: Phenylketonuria is an inherited disorder that can cause many issues with the brain. This disorder was the original example of how newborn screening can result in big improvements for health outcomes.
adaptation2.3: After improved lab tests for hypothyroidism (a gland disorder) and Cystic Fibrosis (CF), an inherited disorder that causes lung infections, these diseases were added to newborn screening programs.
adaptation2.4: Current testing for CF usually relies on a combination of testing for genetic mutations that cause CF and testing for an enzyme that is reduced by CF.
adaptation2.5: Combined testing for about 25 genetic mutations relating to metabolism is a relatively recent addition to newborn screening.
adaptation2.6: The addition of many disorders all at once has led to some reconsideration of the way newborn screening is usually done. This is because it is easy to include tests for disorders that are very rare or don’t have good treatments.
adaptation2.7: Newborn screening for many other disorders have been developed, but these aren’t applied as evenly or are consider to be still under development.
adaptation2.8: This article focuses on newborn screening practices in Australasia.

22891501.Title: Newborn screening: ethical, legal, and social implications

abstract.1: Newborn dried blood spot screening (NBS) is a core public health service and is the largest application of genetic testing in the United States.
abstract.2: NBS is conducted by state public health departments to identify infants with certain genetic, metabolic, and endocrine disorders.
abstract.3: Screening is performed in the first few days of life through blood testing.
abstract.4: Several drops of blood are taken from the baby's heel and placed on a filter paper card.
abstract.5: The dried blood, on the filter cards, is sent from the newborn nursery to the state health department laboratory, or a commercial partner, where the blood is analyzed.
abstract.6: Scientific and technological advances have lead to a significant expansion in the number of tests-from an average of 6 to more than 50--and there is a national trend to further expand the NBS program.
abstract.7: This rapid expansion has created significant ethical, legal, and social challenges for the health care system and opportunity for scholarly inquiry to address these issues.
abstract.8: The purpose of this chapter is to provide an overview of the NBS programs and to provide an in-depth examination of two significant concerns raised from expanded newborn screening, specifically false-positives and lack of information for parents.
abstract.9: Implications for nursing research in managing these ethical dilemmas are discussed.

adaptation2.1: Newborn dried blood spot screening (or simply “newborn screening”) is an essential public health service and is the largest application of genetic testing in the United States.
adaptation2.2: Newborn screening is done by state public health departments to identify infants with certain genetic, metabolic, and endocrine disorders.
adaptation2.3: Screening is done in the first few days of life through blood testing.
adaptation2.4: Several drops of blood are taken from the baby's heel and placed on a filter paper card.
adaptation2.5: The dried blood, on the filter cards, is sent from the newborn nursery to the state health department laboratory, or a commercial partner, where the blood is analyzed.
adaptation2.6: Scientific and technological advances have lead to a significant expansion in the number of tests—from an average of 6 to more than 50—and there is a national trend to further expand the newborn screening program.
adaptation2.7: This rapid expansion has created significant ethical, legal, and social challenges for the health care system. It has also created opportunity for research to address these issues.
adaptation2.8: The purpose of this chapter is to provide an overview of the newborn screening programs and to provide an in-depth examination of two significant concerns raised from expanded newborn screening. Specifically, these concerns are false positives (when the test is positive but the person does not actually have the disease) and lack of information for parents.
adaptation2.9: We also discuss what newborn screening means for nursing research in managing these ethical dilemmas.

abstract.1: Newborn screening is the largest genetic screening program in the United States with approximately four million newborns screened yearly.
abstract.2: It has been available and in continuous development for more than 50 years.
abstract.3: Each state manages, funds, and maintains its own individual program, which encompasses newborn screening as well as the diagnosis and coordination of care for affected infants and children.
abstract.4: The ideal disorder for screening is one in which newborn intervention prevents later disabilities or death for infants who may appear normal at birth.
abstract.5: There are 31 core conditions that are currently recommended for incorporation into state screening programs.
abstract.6: To obtain a sample, several drops of blood are collected from the newborn's heel and applied to filter paper.
abstract.7: Although testing for core disorders is fairly standardized, more extensive screening varies by state and the rigorous evaluation of new disorders for inclusion in state screening panels is ongoing.
abstract.8: As genomic medicine becomes more accessible, screening newborns for chronic diseases that may affect their long-term health will need to be addressed as well as the use of the residual blood spots for research.
abstract.9: Obstetric providers should, at some time during pregnancy, review the basic process of newborn screening with parents to prepare them for this testing in the neonatal period.
abstract.10: This information can be reviewed as it best suits incorporation in an individual's practice; verbal discussion and the distribution of written materials with resources for further information are encouraged.

adaptation2.1: Newborn screening is the largest genetic screening program in the United States with approximately four million newborns screened every year.
adaptation2.2: It has been available and continuously being improved for more than 50 years.
adaptation2.3: Each state manages, funds, and maintains its own individual program. This involves newborn screening as well as the diagnosis and coordination of care for affected infants and children.
adaptation2.4: The ideal disorder for screening is one where taking action for newborns that appear normal prevents later disabilities or death.
adaptation2.5: There are 31 main conditions that are currently recommended for inclusion in state screening programs.
adaptation2.6: To get a sample, several drops of blood are collected from the newborn's heel and applied to filter paper.
adaptation2.7: Testing for the main disorders is fairly standardized. However, more extensive screening varies by state. Additionally, new disorders are always being carefully considered for being included in state screening panels.
adaptation2.8: Healthcare based on genetics is becoming more widely available. As this happens we need to think about screening newborns for chronic diseases that may affect their long-term health. We also need to think about the use of the leftover blood spots for research.
adaptation2.9: At some time during pregnancy, obstetricians should review the basic process of newborn screening with parents to prepare them for this testing when the child is born.
adaptation2.10: Reviewing this information can depend on how it fits into each doctor’s individual practice. Talking with patients and giving out of written materials with resources for further information are encouraged.

23183752.Title: Expanded newborn screening and confirmatory follow-up testing for inborn errors of metabolism detected by tandem mass spectrometry

abstract.1: Newborn screening (NBS) of inborn errors of metabolism (IEM) is a coordinated comprehensive system consisting of education, screening, follow-up of abnormal test results, confirmatory testing, diagnosis, treatment, and evaluation of periodic outcome and efficiency.
abstract.2: The ultimate goal of NBS and follow-up programs is to reduce morbidity and mortality from the disorders.
abstract.3: Over the past decade, tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) has become a key technology in the field of NBS.
abstract.4: It has replaced classic screening techniques of one-analysis, one-metabolite, one-disease with one analysis, many-metabolites, and many-diseases.
abstract.5: The development of electrospray ionization (ESI), automation of sample handling and data manipulation have allowed the introduction of expanded NBS for the identification of numerous conditions on a single sample and new conditions to be added to the list of disorders being screened for using MS/MS.
abstract.6: In the case of a screened positive result, a follow-up analytical test should be performed for confirmation of the primary result.
abstract.7: The most common confirmatory follow-up tests are amino acids and acylcarnitine analysis in plasma and organic acid analysis in urine.
abstract.8: NBS should be integrated with follow-up and clinical management.
abstract.9: Recent improvements in therapy have caused some disorders to be considered as potential candidates for NBS.
abstract.10: This review covers some of the basic theory of expanded MS/MS and follow-up confirmatory tests applied for NBS of IEM.

adaptation2.1: Inborn Errors of Metabolism (IEM) are hereditary diseases that affect how the body processes nutrients. Newborn screening of IEM is a coordinated, comprehensive system. It is made up of education, screening, follow-up of abnormal test results, confirmatory testing, diagnosis, treatment, and evaluation of outcome and efficiency.
adaptation2.2: The ultimate goal of newborn screening and follow-up programs is to reduce poor health and death from the disorders.
adaptation2.3: Over the past decade, tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) has become a key technology in the field of newborn screening.
adaptation2.4: It has replaced classic screening techniques, which screen for one disease per lab test, with lab tests that screen for many diseases at once.
adaptation2.5: Several factors have allowed expanded newborn screening for identifying many conditions with a single sample. These factors are the development of Electrospray Ionization (ESI), automation of sample handling, and data manipulation. These factors have also allowed new conditions to be added to the list of disorders being screened for using MS/MS.
adaptation2.6: In the case of a positive result from a screen, a follow-up lab test should be done to confirm the first result.
adaptation2.7: The most common follow-up tests for confirmation are blood tests for amino acids (building blocks of protein) and acylcarnitine (a chemical in the body important for metabolism), and urine tests for certain acids.
adaptation2.8: Newborn screening should be integrated with follow-up and clinical management.
adaptation2.9: Recent improvements in therapy have caused some disorders to be considered as potential candidates for newborn screening.
adaptation2.10: This article reviewing newborn screening covers some of the basic theory of expanded MS/MS. It also covers follow-up tests for confirmation used for newborn screening of IEM.

24295058.Title: Inborn errors of metabolism and expanded newborn screening: review and update

abstract.1: Inborn errors of metabolism (IEM) are a phenotypically and genetically heterogeneous group of disorders caused by a defect in a metabolic pathway, leading to malfunctioning metabolism and/or the accumulation of toxic intermediate metabolites.
abstract.2: To date, more than 1000 different IEM have been identified.
abstract.3: While individually rare, the cumulative incidence has been shown to be upwards of 1 in 800.
abstract.4: Clinical presentations are protean, complicating diagnostic pathways.
abstract.5: IEM are present in all ethnic groups and across every age.
abstract.6: Some IEM are amenable to treatment, with promising outcomes.
abstract.7: However, high clinical suspicion alone is not sufficient to reduce morbidities and mortalities.
abstract.8: In the last decade, due to the advent of tandem mass spectrometry, expanded newborn screening (NBS) has become a mandatory public health strategy in most developed and developing countries.
abstract.9: The technology allows inexpensive simultaneous detection of more than 30 different metabolic disorders in one single blood spot specimen at a cost of about USD 10 per baby, with commendable analytical accuracy and precision.
abstract.10: The sensitivity and specificity of this method can be up to 99% and 99.995%, respectively, for most amino acid disorders, organic acidemias, and fatty acid oxidation defects.
abstract.11: Cost-effectiveness studies have confirmed that the savings achieved through the use of expanded NBS programs are significantly greater than the costs of implementation.
abstract.12: The adverse effects of false positive results are negligible in view of the economic health benefits generated by expanded NBS and these could be minimized through increased education, better communication, and improved technologies.
abstract.13: Local screening agencies should be given the autonomy to develop their screening programs in order to keep pace with international advancements.
abstract.14: The development of biochemical genetics is closely linked with expanded NBS.
abstract.15: With ongoing advancements in nanotechnology and molecular genomics, the field of biochemical genetics is still expanding rapidly.
abstract.16: The potential of tandem mass spectrometry is extending to cover more disorders.
abstract.17: Indeed, the use of genetic markers in T-cell receptor excision circles for severe combined immunodeficiency is one promising example.
abstract.18: NBS represents the highest volume of genetic testing.
abstract.19: It is more than a test and it warrants systematic healthcare service delivery across the pre-analytical, analytical, and post-analytical phases.
abstract.20: There should be a comprehensive reporting system entailing genetic counselling as well as short-term and long-term follow-up.
abstract.21: It is essential to integrate existing clinical IEM services with the expanded NBS program to enable close communication between the laboratory, clinicians, and allied health parties.
abstract.22: In this review, we will discuss the history of IEM, its clinical presentations in children and adult patients, and its incidence among different ethnicities; the history and recent expansion of NBS, its cost-effectiveness, associated pros and cons, and the ethical issues that can arise; the analytical aspects of tandem mass spectrometry and post-analytical perspectives regarding result interpretation.

adaptation2.1: Inborn Errors of Metabolism (IEM) are hereditary diseases that affect how the body processes nutrients. They vary both in how they appear in a patient and in they underlying genetic causes.
adaptation2.2: To date, more than 1000 different IEM have been identified.
adaptation2.3: Though each individual disease is rare, taken altogether the rate has been shown to be upwards of 1 in 800.
adaptation2.4: The way the diseases appear in patients can vary. This makes it difficult it diagnose them.
adaptation2.5: IEM are present in all ethnic groups and across every age.
adaptation2.6: Some IEM can be treated, with promising outcomes.
adaptation2.7: However, doctors suspecting these diseases from patient exams is not enough alone to reduce health problems and death.
adaptation2.8: In the last decade, expanded newborn screening has become a mandatory public health strategy in most developed and developing countries. This is due to the advent of a chemical detection technology called tandem mass spectrometry.
adaptation2.9: This technology allows more than 30 different metabolic disorders to be detected at low cost in one single blood spot specimen. The cost is about 10 dollars per baby, and the tests are highly accurate.
adaptation2.11: Studies of cost-effectiveness have confirmed that the savings from expanded newborn screening programs are much greater than the costs of running them.
adaptation2.12: The side effects of false positives (when the test is positive but the patient does not have the disease) are not significant in light of the economic and health benefits produced by expanded newborn screening. Further, these side effects could be lessened with more education, better communication, and improved technology.
adaptation2.13: Local screening agencies should be given the freedom to create their own screening programs so they can keep up with international advancements.
adaptation2.14: Improvements in knowledge of genes and how they affect the body are closely linked with expanded newborn screening.
adaptation2.15: This knowledge is growing because of advancements in nanotechnology (working with things at the microscopic level) and molecular genomics (the study of how changes DNA drive hereditary outcomes).
adaptation2.16: The potential of tandem mass spectrometry is extending to cover more disorders.
adaptation2.17: In fact, one promising example is the use of genetic markers for Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), a disease that makes people extremely vulnerable to germs.
adaptation2.18: Newborn screening represents the highest volume of genetic testing.
adaptation2.19: It is more than a test and it calls for providing organized healthcare before, during, and after the test.
adaptation2.20: There should be a comprehensive reporting system requiring genetic counselling as well as short-term and long-term follow-up.
adaptation2.21: It is essential to integrate existing clinical IEM services with the expanded newborn screening program. This is to enable close communication between the laboratory, clinicians, and allied health parties.
adaptation2.22: In this article reviewing the topic, we will discuss the history of IEM, how it appears in children and adults, and its rate among different ethnicities. We will also discuss the history and recent expansion of newborn screening, its cost-effectiveness, associated pros and cons, and the ethical issues that can arise. Finally, we will discuss the technical aspects of tandem mass spectrometry and considerations for  interpreting results.

28671437.Title: Expanded Newborn Screening: Information and Resources for the Family Physician

abstract.1: Each year, 4 to 5 million newborns receive state-mandated screening.
abstract.2: Although the Advisory Committee on Heritable Disorders in Newborns and Children has identified 34 core conditions that should be incorporated into screening programs, each state manages, funds, and maintains its own program.
abstract.3: State programs encompass screening, as well as the diagnosis and coordination of care for newborns with positive findings.
abstract.4: Testing for core disorders is fairly standardized, but more extensive screening varies widely by state, and the rigorous evaluation of new screening panels is ongoing.
abstract.5: The core panel includes testing for three main categories of disorders: metabolic disorders (e.g., amino acid and urea cycle, fatty acid oxidation, and organic acid disorders); hemoglobinopathies; and a group of assorted conditions, including congenital hearing loss.
abstract.6: Family physicians must be familiar with the expanded newborn screening tests to effectively communicate results to parents and formulate interventions.
abstract.7: They must also recognize signs of metabolic disorders that may not be detected by screening tests or that may not be a part of standard newborn screening in their state.
abstract.8: For infants with positive screening results leading to diagnosis, long-term follow-up involves ongoing parental education, regular medical examinations, management at a metabolic treatment center, and developmental and neuropsychological testing to detect associated disorders in time for early intervention.

adaptation2.1: Each year, 4 to 5 million newborns receive state-mandated screening.

Long-term follow-up also involves tests of brain development to detect relevant disorders in time for early action.

72.question: What is newborn metabolic screening? what can the results tell doctors?

PMC3872591.Title: Newborn Screening for inherited metabolic disorders; news and views

abstract.1: Newborn screening is important for the early detection of many congenital genetic and metabolic disorders, aimed at the earliest possible recognition and management of affected newborns, to prevent the morbidity, mortality, and disabilities associated with an inherited metabolic disorder.
abstract.2: This comprehensive system includes; testing, education, follow up, diagnosis, treatment, management, and evaluation.
abstract.3: There are major differences among many of the disorders being considered for inclusion in newborn screening programs.
abstract.4: In recent times, advances in laboratory technology such as tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS), which is more specific, sensitive, reliable, and comprehensive than traditional assays, has increased the number of genetic conditions that can be diagnosed through neonatal screening programs at birth.
abstract.5: With a single dried filter paper blood spot, MS/MS can identify more than 30 inherited metabolic disorders in around two to three minutes.
abstract.6: Advances in the diagnosis and treatment and an increased understanding of the natural history of inborn errors of metabolism have produced pressure to implement expanded newborn screening programs in many countries.
abstract.7: Even as many countries throughout the world have made newborn screening mandatory, in Iran, nationwide newborn screening for inherited metabolic disorders other than hypothyroidism has not been initiated, hence, there is little information about these diseases.
abstract.8: This article aims to review the recent advances in newborn metabolic screening and its situation in Iran and other countries.

adaptation2.1: Newborn screening is important for the early detection of many hereditary and metabolic disorders. It is aimed at the earliest possible recognition and management of affected newborns, to prevent the health problems, deaths, and disabilities associated with an inherited metabolic disorder.
adaptation2.2: This comprehensive system includes; testing, education, follow up, diagnosis, treatment, management, and evaluation.
adaptation2.3: There are major differences among many of the disorders being considered for inclusion in newborn screening programs.
adaptation2.4: In recent times, advances in laboratory technology such as tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS), has increased the number of genetic conditions that can be diagnosed through newborn screening programs at birth.
adaptation2.5: With a single dried filter paper blood spot, MS/MS can identify more than 30 inherited metabolic disorders in around two to three minutes.
adaptation2.6: Advances have been made in the diagnosis and treatment of genetic disorders related to metabolism. Our understanding of the natural history of these disorders has also increased. Both these improvements have produced pressure to implement expanded newborn screening programs in many countries.
adaptation2.7: Even as many countries throughout the world have made newborn screening mandatory, in Iran, nationwide newborn screening for inherited metabolic disorders has not been started, except for hypothyroidism. Because of this, there is not much information about these diseases.
adaptation2.8: This article aims to review the recent advances in newborn metabolic screening and its situation in Iran and other countries.

24996539.Title: Local anaesthetic infiltration for peri-operative pain control in total hip and knee replacement: systematic review and meta-analyses of short- and long-term effectiveness.

abstract.1: Background: Surgical pain is managed with multi-modal anaesthesia in total hip replacement (THR) and total knee replacement (TKR).
abstract.2: It is unclear whether including local anaesthetic infiltration before wound closure provides additional pain control.
abstract.3: Methods: We performed a systematic review of randomised controlled trials of local anaesthetic infiltration in patients receiving THR or TKR.
abstract.4: We searched MEDLINE, Embase and Cochrane CENTRAL to December 2012.
abstract.5: Two reviewers screened abstracts, extracted data, and contacted authors for unpublished outcomes and data.
abstract.6: Outcomes collected were post-operative pain at rest and during activity after 24 and 48 hours, opioid requirement, mobilisation, hospital stay and complications.
abstract.7: When feasible, we estimated pooled treatment effects using random effects meta-analyses.
abstract.8: Results: In 13 studies including 909 patients undergoing THR, patients receiving local anaesthetic infiltration experienced a greater reduction in pain at 24 hours at rest by standardised mean difference (SMD) -0.61 (95% CI -1.05, -0.16; p = 0.008) and by SMD -0.43 (95% CI -0.78 -0.09; p = 0.014) at 48 hours during activity.
abstract.9: In TKR, diverse multi-modal regimens were reported.
abstract.10: In 23 studies including 1439 patients undergoing TKR, local anaesthetic infiltration reduced pain on average by SMD -0.40 (95% CI -0.58, -0.22; p < 0.001) at 24 hours at rest and by SMD -0.27 (95% CI -0.50, -0.05; p = 0.018) at 48 hours during activity, compared with patients receiving no infiltration or placebo.
abstract.11: There was evidence of a larger reduction in studies delivering additional local anaesthetic after wound closure.
abstract.12: There was no evidence of pain control additional to that provided by femoral nerve block.
abstract.13: Patients receiving local anaesthetic infiltration spent on average an estimated 0.83 (95% CI 1.54, 0.12; p = 0.022) and 0.87 (95% CI 1.62, 0.11; p = 0.025) fewer days in hospital after THR and TKR respectively, had reduced opioid consumption, earlier mobilisation, and lower incidence of vomiting.
abstract.14: Few studies reported long-term outcomes.
abstract.15: Conclusions: Local anaesthetic infiltration is effective in reducing short-term pain and hospital stay in patients receiving THR and TKR.
abstract.16: Studies should assess whether local anaesthetic infiltration can prevent long-term pain.
abstract.17: Enhanced pain control with additional analgesia through a catheter should be weighed against a possible infection risk.

adaptation2.1: In Total Hip Replacement (THR) and Total Knee Replacement (TKR), pain from surgery is managed with multiple types of anaesthesia used together.
adaptation2.2: It is not clear if applying a local anaesthetic directly to the wound before sewing it up provides additional pain control.
adaptation2.3: We systematically reviewed randomised controlled trials of using local anaesthetic in patients having THR or TKR.
adaptation2.4: We searched several medical literature databases up to December 2012.
adaptation2.6: The information we gathered from the studies was: pain after surgery, both at rest and during activity after 24 and 48 hours, whether opioids were needed, when and how much patients walked, hospital stay, and additional problems cause by the surgery.
adaptation2.8: In 13 studies including 909 patients having THR, patients that got local anaesthetic had a bigger reduction in pain at 24 hours at rest and at 48 hours during activity.
adaptation2.9: In TKR, various regimens using multiple types of anesthesia were reported.
adaptation2.10: In 23 studies including 1439 patients having TKR, using local anaesthetic reduced pain at 24 hours at rest and at 48 hours during activity, compared with patients receiving no local anesthetic, or placebo (sham treatment so patients were not biased).
adaptation2.11: In studies where more local anaesthetic was used after closing the wound, there was evidence of a bigger reduction.
adaptation2.12: There was no evidence of pain control on top of what was provided by femoral nerve block, a type of local anesthetic applied directly to a large nerve in the thigh.
adaptation2.13: Patients that got local anaesthetic spent, on average, an estimated 0.83 fewer days in hospital after THR and 0.87 fewer days in hospital after TKR. They also had took fewer opioids, walked earlier, and vomited less.
adaptation2.14: Not many studies reported long-term outcomes.
adaptation2.15: Our first conclusion is that local anaesthesia is effective in reducing short-term pain and hospital stay in patients having THR and TKR.
adaptation2.16: Second, studies should assess whether local anaesthesia can prevent long-term pain.
adaptation2.17: Finally, enhanced pain control with additional medicine through a catheter should be weighed against a possible infection risk.

28870302.Title: Perioperative Pain Management in Hip and Knee Arthroplasty

abstract.1: Total hip and knee arthroplasty is associated with significant perioperative pain, which can adversely affect recovery by increasing risk of complications, length of stay, and cost.
abstract.2: Historically, opioids were the mainstay of perioperative pain control.
abstract.3: However, opioids are associated with significant downsides.
abstract.4: Preemptive use of a multimodal pain management approach has become the standard of care to manage pain after hip and knee arthroplasty.
abstract.5: Multimodal pain management uses oral medicines, peripheral nerve blocks, intra-articular injections, and other tools to reduce the need for opioids.
abstract.6: Use of a multimodal approach promises to decrease complications, improve outcomes, and increase patient satisfaction after hip and knee arthroplasty.

adaptation2.1: Hip and knee replacement surgery is associated with significant pain around the time of the procedure. This can make recovery worse by increasing the risk of additional problems, length of stay, and cost.
adaptation2.2: Historically, opioids were the main way to control pain around the time of surgery.
adaptation2.3: However, opioids are associated with significant downsides.
adaptation2.4: Using several pain treatments at once (called multimodal pain management) before pain starts has become the standard way to manage pain after hip and knee replacement.
adaptation2.5: Multimodal pain management uses drugs taken by mouth, injections into nerves, injections into joints, and other tools to reduce the need for opioids.
adaptation2.6: Using several treatments at once promises to decrease additional problems, improve outcomes, and increase patient satisfaction after hip and knee replacement.

30066029.Title: Course of pain after total hip arthroplasty within a standardized pain management concept: a prospective study examining influence, correlation, and outcome of postoperative pain on 103 consecutive patients

abstract.1: Introduction: Postoperative pain management options are of great importance for patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty, as joint replacement surgery is reported to be one of the most painful surgical procedures.
abstract.2: This study demonstrates pain outcome until 4 weeks postoperatively and evaluates factors influencing pain in the postoperative course after total hip arthroplasty.
abstract.3: Materials and methods: A total of 103 patients were included in this prospective cohort trial and underwent total hip arthroplasty.
abstract.4: Postoperative pain was described using a numerical rating scale (NRS); demographic data and perioperative parameters were correlated with postoperative pain.
abstract.5: Results: Evaluation of pain scores in the postoperative course showed a constant decrease in the first postoperative week (mean NRS 3.1 on day 1 to mean NRS 2.3 on day 8) and, then, a perpetual increase for 3 days (mean NRS 2.6 on day 9 to mean NRS 2.3 on day 12).
abstract.6: Afterwards, a continuous pain-level decrease was stated (continuous to a mean NRS 0.9 on day 29).
abstract.7: No correlation was found between the potential influencing factors sex, age, body mass index, duration of surgery, ASA score, and postoperative pain levels, but a high significant correlation could be stated for preoperative pain levels and postoperative pain intensity (pain while moving p < 0.02 to p < 0.05 depending on the time period "week 1 postoperatively", "week 2-4", or "week 1-4"; pain while resting p < 0.001, in all the measured time intervals, respectively).
abstract.8: Conclusion: Increasing pain levels after the first week postoperatively, for 3 days, are most likely to be caused by the change to more extensive mobilization and physiotherapy in the rehabilitation unit.
abstract.9: No significant influence or correlation on the intensity of postoperative pain could be found while evaluating potential predictors except preoperative pain levels.
abstract.10: Pain management has to take these findings into account in the future to further increase patients' satisfaction in the postoperative course after total hip arthroplasty and to adapt pain management programs.

adaptation2.1: Options for managing pain after surgery are very important for patients having a hip replacement. This is because joint replacement surgery is reported to be one of the most painful surgical procedures.
adaptation2.2: This study shows pain outcome until 4 weeks after surgery and evaluates factors that influence pain during followup after a hip replacement.
adaptation2.3: This was a study that followed a group of patients over time. It included a total of 103 patients that had a hip replacement.
adaptation2.4: Pain following surgery was described using a Numerical Rating Scale (NRS). Demographic information and ways in which the surgery was done were correlated with the amount of pain after surgery.
adaptation2.5: Looking at pain scores following surgery showed a constant decrease in the first week after surgery (average NRS 3.1 on day 1 to average NRS 2.3 on day 8). After that, there was a continuous increase for 3 days (average NRS 2.6 on day 9 to average NRS 2.3 on day 12).
adaptation2.6: Afterwards, a continuous pain-level decrease was stated (continuous to a mean NRS 0.9 on day 29).
adaptation2.7: No correlation was found between the potential factors of sex, age, body mass index, duration of surgery, ASA score (used to measure fitness for surgery), and pain levels following the operation. However, a there was a significant correlation between pain levels before surgery and after.
adaptation2.8: In conclusion, pain levels increased after the first week following surgery, for 3 days. This is most likely caused by the change to more extensive mobilization and physiotherapy in the rehabilitation unit.
adaptation2.9: We did not find any significant association of several potential predictors with the intensity of pain following surgery. The only exception was the amount of pain before surgery.
adaptation2.10: When managing pain, doctors need to account for these results in the future. This is needed to further increase patients' satisfaction following hip replacement and to adapt pain management programs.

30290604.Title: Pain monitoring and management in a rehabilitation setting after total joint replacement

abstract.1: Total hip replacement (THR) and, particularly, total knee replacement (TKR), are painful surgical procedures.
abstract.2: Effective postoperative pain management leads to a better and earlier functional recovery and prevents chronic pain.
abstract.3: Studies on the control of pain during the postoperative rehabilitation period are not common.
abstract.4: The aim of this study is to present results of a perioperative anesthetic protocol, and a pain treatment protocol in use in the Orthopaedic and the Rehabilitation intensive units of our Hospital.
abstract.5: 100 patients (50 THR and 50 TKR) were retrospectively included in this observational study.
abstract.6: Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) for pain at rest registered in the clinical sheet was retrieved for all patients and analyzed with respect to the spinal anaesthesia given for the surgery, local analgesia, analgesia protocol adopted during the postoperative days in the Orthopaedic Unit, the antalgic treatment given during the stay within the Rehabilitation Unit, the postoperative consumption of rescue pain medication, and any collateral effect due to the analgesic therapy.
abstract.7: Patients reached standard functional abilities (walking at least 50 meters and climbing/descending stairs) at a mean length of 8 days without medication-related complications.
abstract.8: Mean NRS during the time of stay was 1.3 ± 0.3 for THR and 1.3 ± 0.2 for TKR) and maximum mean NRS was 1.8 ± 0.5 for TKR and 1.8 ± 0.6 for THR.
abstract.9: The use of rescue therapy in the rehabilitation guard was correlated with the mean NRS pain and the maximum NRS pain.
abstract.10: A very good control of pain with the perioperative anesthetic protocol and pain treatment protocol in use was obtained.

adaptation2.1: Total Hip Replacement (THR) and Total Knee Replacement (TKR) are painful surgical procedures, especially TKR.
adaptation2.2: Managing pain well after surgery leads to gaining back function better and earlier and prevents chronic pain.
adaptation2.3: Studies on the control of pain during the rehabilitation period after surgery are not common.
adaptation2.4: The goal of this study is to present results of a protocol for anesthesia at the time of surgery, and a pain treatment protocol in use in the Orthopaedic and the Rehabilitation intensive units of our Hospital.
adaptation2.5: This study looked at outcomes from past procedures without intervening. It included 100 patients, 50 that had THR and 50 that had TKR.
adaptation2.6: From the medical records, we looked at the Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) for pain for all patients. We analyzed this pain measurement with respect to the spinal anaesthesia given for the surgery, local anaesthesia, and the regimen of pain medicine used in the Orthopaedic Unit after the surgery. We also analyzed the pain ratings with respect to pain medicine given while in the Rehabilitation Unit, additional pain medication given as needed because of more intense pain, and any side effects of the pain treatment.
adaptation2.7: Patients reached normal function (walking at least 50 meters and climbing/descending stairs) in 8 days on average without medication-related side effects.
adaptation2.9: How much extra pain medicine was used to address more intense pain during rehabilitation was correlated with how pain was recorded on the NRS.
adaptation2.10: Pain was controlled very well with the protocols for anesthesia at the time of surgery and pain treatment.

30562208.Title: Total Hip and Knee Arthroplasty Perioperative Pain Management: What Should Be in the Cocktail

abstract.1: There are multiple available agents and modalities for controlling pain perioperatively during total joint arthroplasty to improve the patient experience, and their unique mechanisms and applications should be considered for use preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively, keeping in mind that each has differing efficacy and side-effect profiles.
abstract.2: Preoperative pain control or preemptive analgesia using anti-inflammatory drugs and opioid analgesics appears to be effective in reducing postoperative pain, although the recommended timing and type of agents are unclear.
abstract.3: With regard to intraoperative anesthetic choice and pain control, spinal anesthesia appears to have fewer systemic risks than general anesthesia, and periarticular injections of local anesthetic agents, regardless of technique, and with or without the addition of sympathetic modulators, opioids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids, have been shown to improve pain scores postoperatively and to overall carry a low risk profile.
abstract.4: When considering postoperative pain control, there are several modalities including cryotherapy, peripheral nerve blockade, and parenteral and enteral medication options including acetaminophen, cyclooxygenase inhibitors, neuromodulators, tramadol, ketamine, and opioid patches, but there is no clearly preferred medication regimen and individual patient risk profiles must be considered when choosing appropriate pain management agents.
abstract.5: Multimodal pain management can decrease opioid usage, improve pain scores, increase patient satisfaction, and enhance early recovery.
abstract.6: The ideal preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative pain medication regimen remains unclear, and an individualized approach to perioperative pain management is recommended.
abstract.7: Despite this, good results are demonstrated with the existing variations in pain management protocols in the literature.
abstract.8: Treatment of severe postoperative pain in a multimodal fashion carries the risk for serious side effects, including respiratory depression, mental status changes influencing safe gait mechanics, hypotension, renal and hepatic dysfunction, hematologic variations, gastrointestinal considerations including gastric ulcers, constipation or ileus, nausea or vomiting, infection at injection sites, and peripheral nerve injury with peripheral blockade.

adaptation2.1: There are many options to control pain during joint replacement surgery to improve the patient experience. Doctors should consider the unique ways that each of these options works when using them before, during, and after surgery. Doctors should also keep in mind that each has different efficacy and side-effects.
adaptation2.2: Pain control before surgery or using anti-inflammatory drugs and opioid painkillers before the pain starts seems to work well to reduce pain after surgery. However, it is not clear what the recommended timing and type of treatment are.
adaptation2.3: Regarding the choice of anesthetic during surgery and pain control, anesthesia applied directly to the spine seems to have fewer general risks to the body than general anesthesia. In addition, injections of local anesthetics around the joint, regardless of technique, have been shown to improve pain scores following surgery and to have low risk overall. This is true whether the injections are used with or without adding other drugs, including those that control the body’s fight-or-flight response, opioids, NSAIDs or corticosteroids.
adaptation2.4: When considering pain control following surgery, there are several methods. These include cold therapy, disabling nerves with injection or electrical stimulation, and medicines take by mouth or otherwise. Options for medicines include Tylenol®, COX inhibitors, drugs that affect the brain, tramadol (sold as Ultram or Zytram), ketamine, and opioid patches. However, there is no clearly preferred treatment, and doctors need to consider individual risks faced by patients when choosing appropriate pain treatments.
adaptation2.5: Using multiple pain treatments at once can decrease opioid usage, improve pain scores, increase patient satisfaction, and enhance early recovery.
adaptation2.6: It is still not clear what the ideal medication plan to use before, during, and after surgery is. We recommend using an individualized approach to pain management around the time of surgery.
adaptation2.7: In spite of this, changes to existing ways of treating pain in the scientific literature have shown good results.
adaptation2.8: Using a multi-pronged approach to treat severe pain following surgery has the risk for serious side effects. These including slow or shallow breathing, changes in mental state that can affect walking, low blood pressure, kidney and liver problems, blood problems, stomach problems, including ulcers, constipation or bowel obstruction. Possible side effects also include nausea or vomiting, infection at injection sites, and nerve injury if nerves are disabled (peripheral blockade).

31352132.Title: An integrative review of multimodal pain management on patient recovery after total hip and knee arthroplasty

abstract.1: Background: Pain management after total knee arthroplasty and total hip arthroplasty is pivotal, as it determines the outcome of the recovery process after surgery.
abstract.2: Ineffective pain control results in many postoperative complications and hinders successful recovery.
abstract.3: In recent years, the transition from opioids to a multimodal pain management approach after total knee and total hip arthroplasty has increasingly become an alternative.
abstract.4: This is due to the multitude of adverse effects associated with opioids.
abstract.5: As a result, the use of non-opioid interventions such as acetaminophen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, gabapentinoids, and ketamine, and techniques such as peripheral nerve block and local infiltration analgesia have become more favorable.
abstract.6: Objectives: This paper aims to summarize literature around the effectiveness of non-opioid interventions as part of a multimodal pain management after total knee and total hip arthroplasty.
abstract.7: Methods: A literature review was conducted to provide evidence-based information with respect to pain management during the postoperative period in order to enhance the pain recovery process.
abstract.8: The literature chosen was extracted through the electronic databases PubMed, CINAHL, and Embase.
abstract.9: Twenty-seven eligible articles were identified that met the inclusion and exclusion criteria.
abstract.10: Results: Literary evidence shows that non-opioid interventions such as acetaminophen, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors, gabapentinoids, ketamine, peripheral nerve blocks, and local infiltration analgesia benefit patients after total knee and total hip arthroplasty for pain management.
abstract.11: However, further quality research trials are necessary for more conclusive evidence-based information.
abstract.12: Conclusion: Selective literature supports the use of non-opioid interventions as part of a multimodal analgesics regimen for effective pain management after total knee and total hip arthroplasty.

adaptation2.1: Taking care of pain after knee replacement and and hip replacement is critical because it determines the how the patient recovers after surgery.
adaptation2.2: Ways of controlling pain that are not effective causes many additional problems after surgery and hinders successful recovery.
adaptation2.3: In recent years, changing from opioids after knee and hip replacement to using multiple pain medicines at once has increasingly become an alternative.
adaptation2.4: This is because of the many side effects of opioids.
adaptation2.5: As a result, the use of non-opioid treatments and techniques such as peripheral nerve block, which directly numbs a large nerve, and local anesthetic have become more favorable. Non-opioid treatments include acetaminophen (Tylenol®), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitors, gabapentinoids (such as Lyrica or Neurontin), and ketamine.
adaptation2.6: This paper aims to summarize literature about the effectiveness of non-opioid treatments as part of a multi-pronged pain management plan after knee and hip replacement.
adaptation2.7: We reviewed the scientific research on pain management to improve recovery following surgery. We did this to provide evidence-based information with respect to this pain management.
adaptation2.8: The scientific papers we chose were taken from several electronic databases.
adaptation2.9: We found 27 articles that met our standards for being included in this review.
adaptation2.10: Evidence in scientific literature shows that non-opioid pain treatments such as acetaminophen, NSAIDs, COX-2 inhibitors, gabapentinoids, ketamine, peripheral nerve blocks, and local anesthesia benefit patients after knee and hip replacement.
adaptation2.11: However, further quality research trials are needed to be more sure.
adaptation2.12: In conclusion, certain scientific research papers support the use of non-opioid treatments as part of a multi-pronged pain medication plan for effective pain management after knee and hip replacement.

31957218.Title: Rapid recovery following hip and knee arthroplasty using local infiltration analgesia: length of stay, rehabilitation protocol and cost savings

abstract.1: Background: We implemented local infiltration analgesia (LIA) as a technique of providing post-operative pain management and early mobilization after arthroplasty surgery and have progressively found patients able to go home earlier.
abstract.2: This study compares the national data on hip and knee arthroplasty provided by the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons and Medibank Private with our outcomes using LIA and rapid recovery.
abstract.3: Methods: Prospective study of one surgeon including 200 knees, and 165 hips in the two years till June 2016.
abstract.4: Variables included in comparison to the two groups were: length of stay, percentage of patients transferred to rehabilitation or intensive care unit (ICU), readmitted within 30 days and average separation cost.
abstract.5: Results: Hip replacement median length of stay in our series was two nights versus five nights, inpatient rehabilitation 7% versus 36%, ICU admission zero versus 4%, and readmissions 3.9% versus 6.0%, the average hospital separation cost in our series was $17 813 versus $26 734.
abstract.6: Knee replacement median length of stay in our study was one night versus five nights, ICU 0.5% versus 3%, rehabilitation 4.5% versus 43%, and readmission 6% versus 7%, the average hospital separation cost in our group was $16 437 versus $27 505.
abstract.7: Conclusion: The comprehensive approach of LIA and rapid recovery enables patients to have shorter hospitalization, lower rehabilitation incidence and a resultant reduction in health expenditure.

adaptation2.1: Local Infiltration Analgesia (LIA) a method for managing pain and encouraging walking early after joint surgery. It involves injecting several painkillers directly into the surgical wound during and after the procedure. We applied LIA and have found more and more that patients are able to go home earlier.
adaptation2.2: This study uses national data on hip and knee surgery provided by the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons and Medibank Private. It compares the national data with our outcomes using LIA and rapid recovery.
adaptation2.3: This study followed patients over time and was done by one surgeon. It included surgery on knees and 165 hips in the two years leading up to June 2016.
adaptation2.4: We compared the two groups using several factors. These included length of stay, number of patients either transferred to rehabilitation or intensive care unit (ICU) or readmitted within 30 days, and average total cost upon leaving the hospital.
adaptation2.5: We found that the average length of stay for hip replacement in our data was nights, compared to five nights for national data. Inpatient rehabilitation was 7% versus 36%, ICU admission was zero versus 4%, and readmission rate was 4% versus 6%. The average total cost on leaving the hospital was $17,813 for our data, versus $26,734 for national data.
adaptation2.6: For knee replacement, we found that the average length of stay in our study was one night versus five nights for national data. Rate of transfer to ICU was 0.5% versus 3% Rate of transfer to rehabilitation was 4.5% versus 43%. The rate of patient readmission was 6% versus 7%, and the average total cost upon leaving the hospital in our group was $16,437 versus $27,505 for the national data.
adaptation2.7: In conclusion, the comprehensive approach of LIA and rapid recovery allows patients to have shorter hospitalization, lower rates of rehabilitation and, as a result, a reduction in healthcare expenses.

33204789.Title: Reducing Opioid Prescriptions Lowers Consumption Without Detriment to Patient-Reported Pain Interference Scores After Total Hip and Knee Arthroplasties

abstract.1: Background: Opioid addiction is endemic in the United States.
abstract.2: We developed a standardized opioid-prescribing schedule (SOPS) after total hip arthroplasty (THA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and evaluated opioid usage alongside Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) pain interference scores.
abstract.3: We hypothesized that opioid usage would be less than prescribed and reducing prescription would decrease consumption without negatively impacting the PROMIS scores.
abstract.4: Methods: A prospective observational study was performed on all patients undergoing primary THA and TKA from April 7, 2018, to August 10, 2019.
abstract.5: Opioid consumption and pain interference were determined 2 weeks after discharge via telephone and email surveys.
abstract.6: SOPSs were implemented during the study.
abstract.7: Outcomes were compared in patients before and after the SOPS.
abstract.8: Results: A total of 715 patients met inclusion criteria; 201 patients completed surveys.
abstract.9: Before the SOPS, the mean opioid prescription was 81.2 ± 15.3 tablets for THA and 82.9 ± 10.6 for TKA.
abstract.10: The mean usage was 35.1 ± 29.4 tablets and 35.4 ± 33.4, respectively.
abstract.11: After the SOPS, the mean usage decreased to 19.4 ± 16.8 (P = .04) and 31.6 ± 20.9 (P = .52), respectively.
abstract.12: After implementation of a second SOPS for THA, the mean number of tablets consumed was 21.5 ± 18.6 (P = .05 compared with pre-SOPS).
abstract.13: The PROMIS 6B responses in patients who underwent THA demonstrated no significant changes.
abstract.14: PROMIS 6B responses for TKA showed an increase in interference with recreational activities (P = .04) and tasks away from home (P = .04), but otherwise had no significant impact on reported scores.
abstract.15: Conclusions: Implementation of the SOPS reduced postoperative opioid prescription and consumption without significantly impacting the reported pain interference, supporting the need to decrease opioid prescription after THA and TKA.

adaptation2.1: Opioid addiction is commonplace in the United States.
adaptation2.2: We created a standard for prescribing opioids to treat pain after hip and knee replacement. We also studied opioid usage alongside a system of measuring pain as reported by patients.
adaptation2.3: We assumed that people would use opioids less than prescribed. We also assumed that reducing prescriptions of opioids would reduce the amount taken without increasing the amount of pain reported.
adaptation2.4: This study followed patients over time, without intervening. It was done on all patients that had hip and knee replacement from April 7, 2018, to August 10, 2019.
adaptation2.5: We determined the amount of opioids used and how pain interfered with patients’ lives 2 weeks after discharge using telephone and email surveys.
adaptation2.6: Standards for prescribing opioids were used during the study.
adaptation2.7: Outcomes were compared in patients before and after following these standards.
adaptation2.8: A total of 715 patients were able to be in the study. Of those, 201 patients completed surveys.
adaptation2.9: Before the standards were followed, the average opioid prescription was about 81 tablets for hip replacement and about 83 tablets for knee replacement.
adaptation2.10: The average number of tablets used for both hip replacement and knee replacement was 35.
adaptation2.11: After the standards were followed, the average number of tables taken dropped to about 19 for hip replacement and about 32 for knee replacement.
adaptation2.12: After following a second standard for hip replacement, the average number of tablets taken was about 22.
adaptation2.13: There was not a significant changed in pain reported by patients that had hip replacement.
adaptation2.14: For knee replacement, there was an increase in patient-reported interference with recreational activities and tasks away from home, but otherwise there was no significant impact.
adaptation2.15: We conclude that following our standards for prescribing opioids reduced the amount of opioids both prescribed and taken, without significantly impacting the reported pain interference. This supports the need to decrease opioid prescription after hip and knee replacement surgery.

33709165.Title: Implementing fast-track in total hip arthroplasty: rapid mobilization with low need for pain medication and low pain values : Retrospective analysis of 102 consecutive patients

abstract.1: Introduction: Total hip arthroplasty (THA) is reported to be one of the most painful surgical procedures.
abstract.2: Perioperative management and rehabilitation patterns are of great importance for the success of the procedure.
abstract.3: The aim of this cohort study was the evaluation of function, mobilization and pain scores during the inpatient stay (6 days postoperatively) and 4 weeks after fast-track THA.
abstract.4: Materials and methods: A total of 102 consecutive patients were included in this retrospective cohort trial after minimally invasive cementless total hip arthroplasty under spinal anesthesia in a fast-track setup.
abstract.5: The extent of mobilization under full-weight-bearing with crutches (walking distance in meters and necessity of nurse aid) and pain values using a numerical rating scale (NRS) were measured.
