abstract.6: Function was evaluated measuring the range of motion (ROM) and the ability of sitting on a chair, walking and personal hygiene.
abstract.7: Furthermore, circumferences of thighs were measured to evaluate the extent of postoperative swelling.
abstract.8: The widespread Harris Hip Score (HHS) was used to compare results pre- and 4 weeks postoperatively.
abstract.9: Results: Evaluation of pain scores in the postoperative course showed a constant decrease in the first postoperative week (days 1-6 postoperatively).
abstract.10: The pain scores before surgery were significantly higher than surgery (day 6), during mobilization (p < 0.001), at rest (p < 0.001) and at night (p < 0.001).
abstract.11: All patients were able to mobilize on the day of surgery.
abstract.12: In addition, there was a significant improvement in independent activities within the first 6 days postoperatively: sitting on a chair (p < 0.001), walking (p < 0.001) and personal hygiene (p < 0.001).
abstract.13: There was no significant difference between the measured preoperative and postoperative (day 6 after surgery) thigh circumferences above the knee joint.
abstract.14: Compared to preoperatively, there was a significant (p < 0.001) improvement of the HHS 4 weeks after surgery.
abstract.15: In 100% of the cases, the operation was reported to be successful and all of the treated patients would choose a fast-track setup again.
abstract.16: Conclusion: Application of a fast-track scheme is effective regarding function and mobilization of patients.
abstract.17: Low pain values and rapid improvement of walking distance confirms the success of the fast-track concept in the immediate postoperative course.
abstract.18: Future prospective studies have to confirm the results comparing a conventional and a fast-track pathway.

adaptation2.1: Total Hip Arthroplasty (THA, or hip replacement) is reported to be one of the most painful surgical procedures.
adaptation2.2: How the patient is cared for and rehabilitated around the time of surgery are very important for the success of the procedure.
adaptation2.3: This was a study of a group of patients that all had fast-track THA. The aim of the study was to evaluate function, ability to walk, and pain scores during the inpatient stay (6 days following surgery) and 4 weeks after the procedure.
adaptation2.4: To perform the study, we included a total of 102 consecutive patients that had previously had minimally invasive cementless THA under spinal anesthesia in a fast-track setup.
adaptation2.5: We measured how far patients could walk under their full weight with crutches, and how much a nurse had to help. We also measured pain using a Numerical Rating Scale (NRS).
adaptation2.6: We looked at function as measured by the range of motion (ROM) and the ability to sit on a chair, to walk and to maintain personal hygiene.
adaptation2.7: On top of that, we measured circumferences of patients’ thighs to look at how much swelling there was after surgery.
adaptation2.8: We used the widely used Harris Hip Score (HHS) to compare results before surgery and 4 weeks after surgery.
adaptation2.9: Looking at pain scores following surgery showed a constant decrease in the first week (days 1-6 after surgery).
adaptation2.10: The pain scores before surgery were significantly higher than day 6 after surgery, when attempting to walk, at rest, and at night.
adaptation2.11: All patients were able to walk on the day of surgery.
adaptation2.12: In addition, there was a significant improvement in independent activities within the first 6 days following surgery. These activities were sitting on a chair, walking and personal hygiene.
adaptation2.13: There was no significant difference between the thigh circumferences above the knee joint, measured before surgery and on day 6 after surgery.
adaptation2.14: Compared to before surgery, there was a significant improvement of the HHS 4 weeks after surgery.
adaptation2.15: In 100% of the cases, the operation was reported to be successful and all of the treated patients would choose a fast-track setup again.
adaptation2.16: In conclusion, application of a fast-track program is effective for function and ability of patients to walk.
adaptation2.17: Further, low pain values and fast improvement of walking distance confirms that the fast-track plan immediately after surgery is a success.
adaptation2.18: Finally, future studies that follow patients over time have to confirm the results by comparing a conventional and a fast-track plan.

34232932.Title: An Update on Multimodal Pain Management After Total Joint Arthroplasty

abstract.1: Multimodal analgesia has become the standard of care for total joint arthroplasty as it provides superior analgesia with fewer side effects than opioid-only protocols.
abstract.2: Systemic medications, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, acetaminophen, corticosteroids, and gabapentinoids, and local anesthetics via local infiltration analgesia and peripheral nerve blocks, are the foundation of multimodal analgesia in total joint arthroplasty.
abstract.3: Ideally, multimodal analgesia should begin preoperatively and continue throughout the perioperative period and beyond discharge.
abstract.4: There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of intravenous acetaminophen or liposomal bupivacaine as part of multimodal analgesia protocols.

adaptation2.1: Using several types of pain treatment at once has become the standard way to care for patients having joint replacement surgery. This is because this approach reduces pain better with fewer side effects than only using opioids.
adaptation2.2: Some pain medicines affect the whole body, including NSAIDs, Tylenol®, corticosteroids, and gabapentinoids (such as Lyrica or Neurontin). These medicines, local anesthetics, and peripheral nerve blocks, are the foundation of the multi-pronged approach for joint replacement surgery.
adaptation2.3: Ideally, this multi-pronged approach should start before the operation and continue throughout the time of surgery and beyond discharge.
adaptation2.4: There is not enough evidence to be in favor of the routine use of IV Tylenol® or liposomal bupivacaine (a type of local anesthetic) as part of multi-pronged pain treatment approaches.

73.question: In adult patients with total hip replacements how effective is pain medication in recovery?

14703441.Title: Etiological diagnosis of chronic cough with unknown causes

abstract.1: Objective: To explore the spectrum and frequency of causes for chronic cough in Chinese patients.
abstract.2: Methods: 86 patients with chronic cough were enrolled in the study.
abstract.3: The diagnostic procedure was based on the anatomical protocol for diagnosing chronic cough designed by Irwin, and additional cytological assay was performed for sputum induced by hypertonic saline aerosol inhalation.
abstract.4: The efficacy of therapy specific to the diagnosis was evaluated.
abstract.5: Results: Definite diagnosis was made in 77 (89.5%) out of the 86 patients with chronic cough.
abstract.6: The most common causes included cough variant asthma (CVA) (24/86, 27.9%), postnasal drip syndrome (PNDs) (22/86, 25.6%), eosinophilic bronchitis (EB) (13/86, 15.1%), and gastroesophageal reflux (GER) (12/86, 14.0%).
abstract.7: After active management based on the diagnosis, cough improved in 72 patients (93.5%).
abstract.8: Conclusions: In addition to CVA, PNDs and GER, eosinophilic bronchitis is also an important cause of chronic cough.
abstract.9: A positive response to the specific therapy is essential to a definite diagnosis.

adaptation3.1: Researchers studied the causes of chronic cough in Chinese patients.
adaptation3.2: This study included 86 patients with chronic cough.
adaptation3.3: The rules for finding the cause of chronic cough included a test to study cells in sputum, as well as other tests.
adaptation3.4: Researchers also studied how well treatments worked according to the cause (diagnosis).
adaptation3.5: The diagnosis was made in about 90% of the patients.
adaptation3.6: The most common causes included: cough variant asthma (CVA), postnasal drip syndrome (PND), eosinophilic bronchitis (inflammation of airways-EB), and gastroesophageal relux (GER).
adaptation3.7: Cough improved in about 94% of patients after treatment based on the cause.
adaptation3.8: Besides CVA, PNDs, and GER, eosinophilic bronchitis (EB) is also an important cause of chronic cough.
adaptation3.9: A good response to treatment based on the cause is very important to making the correct diagnosis.

15895778.Title: Chronic cough as a sign of laryngeal sensory neuropathy: diagnosis and treatment

abstract.1: Chronic cough is often attributed to reflux, postnasal drip, or asthma.
abstract.2: We present 28 patients who had chronic cough or throat-clearing as a manifestation of sensory neuropathy involving the superior or recurrent laryngeal nerve.
abstract.3: They had been identified as having sudden-onset cough, laryngospasm, or throat-clearing after viral illness, surgery, or an unknown trigger.
abstract.4: Cough and laryngospasm were the most common complaints.
abstract.5: Seventy-one percent of the patients had concomitant superior laryngeal nerve or recurrent laryngeal nerve motor neuropathy documented by laryngeal electromyography or videostroboscopy.
abstract.6: After a negative workup for reflux, asthma, or postnasal drip, these patients were treated with gabapentin at 100 to 900 mg/d.
abstract.7: Symptomatic relief was achieved in 68% of the patients.
abstract.8: Sensory neuropathy of the recurrent laryngeal nerve or superior laryngeal nerve should be considered in the workup for chronic cough or larynx irritability.
abstract.9: Symptomatic management of patients with cough and laryngospasm due to a suspected sensory neuropathy may include the use of antiseizure medications such as gabapentin.

adaptation3.1: Chronic cough is often due to reflux, postnasal drip, or asthma.
adaptation3.2: We studied 28 patients with chronic cough or throat-clearing as a symptom of sensory neuropathy (nerve damage of nerves supplying sensation) to the throat and voice box (larynx). This sensory neuropathy involved the superior or recurrent laryngeal nerves.
adaptation3.3: These patients had sudden-onset cough, muscle spasm of the voice box (laryngospasm), or throat-clearing after viral illness, surgery, or due to an unknown reason.
adaptation3.4: Cough and laryngospasm were the most common complaints.
adaptation3.5: 71% of the patients also had motor neuropathy (nerve damage to the nerves that control the muscles) of the throat. This damage was shown by special tests that measure the function of the larynx and vocal cords.
adaptation3.6: The patients were treated with the drug,  gabapentin (a drug used to treat seizures), if the workup did not show reflux, asthma, or postnasal drip.
adaptation3.7: Relief of the symptoms was achieved in 68% of these patients.
adaptation3.8: Sensory neuropathy of the throat and voice box should be considered in the workup for chronic cough or irritation of the larynx.
adaptation3.9: If doctors suspect that cough and laryngospasm may due to a sensory neuropathy, use of antiseizure drugs such as gabapentin may help with these symptoms.

16677450.Title: Etiology and a diagnostic protocol for patients with chronic cough

abstract.1: Objective: The spectrum and frequency of causes and the diagnostic protocol for chronic cough were explored.
abstract.2: Methods: A total of 194 patients with at least 3 weeks of chronic cough and normal chest radiographs were recruited from the outpatient clinic of Guangzhou Institute of Respiratory Diseases between July 2003 to June 2004.
abstract.3: The causes were investigated using a well-established protocol.
abstract.4: The diagnostic protocol included history inquiring and physical examination, pulmonary function tests, induced sputum cell differentials, 24 h esophageal pH monitoring, CT of the paranasal sinuses or chest, fiberoptic rhinoscopy or bronchoscopy.
abstract.5: The final diagnosis was made based on clinical manifestation, examination findings and a positive response to therapy.
abstract.6: Results: The cause of chronic cough was defined in 95.4% of the patients, with a single cause found in 153 patients (82.7%), and multiple causes in 32 patients (17.3%).
abstract.7: The five most important causes of cough were: eosinophilic bronchitis (n = 51, 22.4%), rhinitis and/or paranasal sinusitis (PNDs, n = 39, 17.1%), cough-variant asthma (n = 31, 13.6%), atopic cough (n = 28, 12.3%), and gastroesophageal reflux (n = 27, 11.8%).
abstract.8: Conclusions: The spectrum and frequency of causes of chronic cough in our study is different from the previous reports in western countries.
abstract.9: Eosinophilic bronchitis and atopic cough are important causes of chronic cough.
abstract.10: A modified diagnostic protocol was established accordingly.

adaptation3.1: Researchers studied the causes of chronic cough using specific rules for making the diagnosis.
adaptation3.2: A total of 194 patients with chronic cough for at least 3 weeks  and normal chest X-rays were included from an outpatient clinic in China.
adaptation3.3: The causes of chronic cough were studied using well established rules.
adaptation3.4: The diagnostic tests included: medical history, physical exam, lung function tests, sputum cell counts, esophagus acid test, CAT scan of sinuses or chest, and looking into the nose or lungs with the endoscope.
adaptation3.5: The final diagnosis of the cause of chronic cough was made based on all of these tests plus how patients responded to treatment.
adaptation3.6: The cause of chronic cough was found in about 95% of patients. About 83% had one cause, about 17% hadmore than one cause.
adaptation3.7: The 5 most important causes of cough were: eosinophilc bronchitis (inflammation of the airways), inflammation of the nose (rhinitis) and/or sinuses (sinusitis), cough variant asthma, allergic cough (atopic cough), and gastroesophageal reflux.
adaptation3.8: In this study in China, the types and amount of occurrences of the causes of chronic cough is different from studies done before in western countries.
adaptation3.9: Eosinophilic bronchitis and atopic cough are important causes of chronic cough.
adaptation3.10: Researchers changed the diagnostic rules for this reason.

16995969.Title: Ice cold carbonated water: a therapy for persistent hyperawareness of pharyngeal mucus and throat clearing

abstract.1: Chronic throat clearing or a feeling of 'something' at the back of the oropharynx or nasopharynx is a common cause for referral to otorhinolaryngology services.
abstract.2: While treatment of an underlying causative condition might be expected to improve these symptoms, in many cases a clear underlying cause is not found.
abstract.3: Currently, there is no recognized treatment which is effective against these troublesome symptoms.
abstract.4: This observational study investigated the effectiveness of a regime of sipping ice cold carbonated water to try to break the vicious cycle of throat clearing.
abstract.5: Seventy-two patients with these symptoms who had previously been advised to use the regime were contacted with a postal questionnaire.
abstract.6: Sixty-three per cent of patients documented an improvement in their symptom severity score.
abstract.7: The most severely and most frequently affected patients had the greatest benefit.
abstract.8: We conclude that the suggested regime can be effective in breaking the vicious cycle of persistent throat-clearing.

adaptation3.1: Chronic throat clearing or a feeling of 'something' at the back of the throat (or nose) is a common cause for referral to ear, nose, and throat dostors.
adaptation3.2: Treatment of the problem causing these symptoms may help. But in many cases the cause is not found.
adaptation3.3: Currently, there is no accepted treatment which is effective against these symptoms.
adaptation3.4: Researchers studied a plan of sipping ice cold sparkling, fizzy (carbonated) water to help stop the cycle of throat-clearing.
adaptation3.5: A questionnaire was mailed to 72 patients that had been told to use this plan.
adaptation3.6: Improvement was seen in the severity of the symptoms in 63% of these patients
adaptation3.7: The greatest improvement was seen in patients who had the worse symptoms and who had them most often.
adaptation3.8: Doctors advise that sipping ice cold carbonated water can help to break the cycle of throat-clearing.

19957775.Title: Diagnostic values of the clinical characteristics of chronic cough

abstract.1: Objective: To evaluate whether the clinical characteristics of chronic cough were helpful in determining its specific causes.
abstract.2: Methods: Patients with chronic cough were evaluated by a validated systematic diagnostic protocol.
abstract.3: The patients with identified single cause were divided into 4 groups accordingly: cough-variant asthma (CVA), upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) or post-nasal drip syndrome (PNDS), eosinophilic bronchitis (EB), gastroesophageal reflux related cough (GERC), and the characteristics of the timing, character, onset and associated manifestations of chronic cough in different causes were compared.
abstract.4: Results: A total of 196 patients met the inclusion criteria, including 55 with EB, 45 with UACS, 50 with CVA and 46 with GERC.
abstract.5: No significant difference was found in age, gender and course among EB, UACS, CVA and GERC.
abstract.6: The incidence of nocturnal cough in CVA was 26.0% (13/44), significantly higher than in EB (9.1% (5/55), chi2 = 5.272, P<0.05), UACS (2.2% (1/45), chi2 = 10.657, P<0.01) and GERC (0% (0/46), chi2 = 13.833, P<0.01).
abstract.7: The specificity of nocturnal cough for CVA was 95.9%.
abstract.8: The sensitivity and specificity of cough associated with meals in GERC was 52.2% (24/46) and 83.3%, and regurgitation associated symptom in GERC were 69.6% (32/46) and 80.0%, which were significantly higher than other groups.
abstract.9: The incidence of postnasal drip, rhinitis associated symptom and case history of nasal diseases in UACS were 66.7% (30/45), 88.9% (40/45) and 82.2% (37/45), and the specificity of them were 89.4%, 65.6% and 63.6% respectively.
abstract.10: Conclusion: The timing character and some associated symptoms of chronic cough are useful in predicting a single cause.

adaptation3.1: Researchers studied whether the signs and symptoms associated with chronic cough were helpful in finding out the disease that caused it.
adaptation3.2: Patients with chronic cough were studied by a specific set of rules in order to make a diagnosis.
adaptation3.3: The signs and symptoms of chronic cough caused by a single disease were compared. These patients were divided into 4 groups: cough-variant asthma (CVA), upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), post-nasal drip syndrome (PNDS), eosinophilic bronchitis (EB), and  gastroesophageal reflux related cough (GERC).
adaptation3.4: A total 196 patients met the rules: 55 had EB, 45 had UACS, 50 had CVA, and 46 had GERC.
adaptation3.5: No important difference was found in age, gender, and course of disease among EB, UACS, CVA, and GERC.
adaptation3.6: Nighttime cough (nocturnal cough) occurred much more often in CVA than in EB, UACS, and GERC.
adaptation3.7: Nocturnal cough was very highly associated with CVA.
adaptation3.8: Cough associated with meals and backflow of stomach contents was more highly associated with GERC than the other groups.
adaptation3.9: UACS was more associated with postnasal drip, symptoms of nose inflammation , and history of nose diseases.
adaptation3.10: The signs and symptoms of chronic cough are useful in the diagnosis of a single underlying cause.

19957776.Title: The spectrum and clinical features of causes for chronic cough

abstract.1: Objective: To explore the spectrum and clinical features of causes for chronic cough.
abstract.2: Methods: A total of 103 patients with at least 8 weeks of chronic cough and normal chest radiographs were recruited from the outpatient clinic of China-Japan Friendship Hospital Department of Respiratory Diseases between Oct 2005 to Feb 2009.
abstract.3: The causes were investigated using a well established protocol according to The Chinese Respiratory Society guidelines for management of cough.
abstract.4: The diagnostic protocol included history inquiring and physical examination, pulmonary function tests, induced sputum cell differentials, 24 h esophageal pH monitoring, CT of the paranasal sinuses or chest, fiberoptic rhinoscopy or bronchoscopy.
abstract.5: The final diagnosis was made based on clinical manifestations, examination findings and a positive response to therapy.
abstract.6: The results were compared with those reported in Guangzhou before.
abstract.7: Results: The cause of chronic cough was defined in 95.1% of the patients, of which 83 patients (83.5%) with a single cause, 32 (13.6%) with 2 causes, and 3 (2.9%) with 3 causes.
abstract.8: The most important causes of cough were: cough variant asthma (CVA) (n = 41, 33.3%), rhinitis and/or sinusitis (n = 30, 24.4%), gastroesophageal reflux (GERC) (n = 25, 20.3%), medicine related (n = 7, 5.7%), eosinophilic bronchitis (EB) (n = 6, 4.9%), atopic (n = 4, 3.3%), and idiopathic (n = 6, 4.9%).
abstract.9: Other causes included pulmonary interstitial fibrosis (n = 2, 1.6%), left heart insufficiency (n = 1, 0.8%) and bronchiectasis (n = 1, 0.8%).
abstract.10: There was more nocturnal cough in CVA (80.9%, 36/41) than in other causes (chi2 = 19.81, P<0.01).
abstract.11: In CVA, 63.4% (26/41) was complicated with atopic rhinitis, 68.3% (28/41) showed seasonal variations, and 67.8% (19/28) aggravated in the autumn.
abstract.12: GERC manifested more day coughs, with 56.0% (14/25) cough associated with taking food and 68.0% (17/25) with reflux symptoms.
abstract.13: There was more productive cough in rhinitis and/or sinusitis (73.3% (22/30) ,chi2 = 24.99, P<0.01).
abstract.14: The percentages of CVA and GERC were significantly higher than those reported in Guangzhou (chi2 value were 9.52 and 4.56 respectively, P<0.01), but those of EB and atopic cough were significantly lower (p values were 17.61 and 7.86 respectively, P<0.01).
abstract.15: Conclusions: The most common causes of chronic cough in our study were CVA, rhinitis and/or sinusitis, GERC, medicine related cough, EB and atopic cough, which were different from previous reports in other cities such as Guangzhou.
abstract.16: The spectrum and clinical features of causes for chronic cough are important in the diagnostic procedure of chronic cough.

adaptation3.1: Researcher studied the range of signs and symptoms to find out the causes of chronic cough.
adaptation3.2: A total of 103 patients with chronic cough for at least 8 weeks and normal chest X-rays were studied from a hospital outpatient clinic in China.
adaptation3.3: The causes of the chronic cough were studied using well established rules and guidelines.
adaptation3.4: The diagnostic tests included: medical history, physical exam, lung function tests, sputum cell counts, esophagus acid test, CAT scan of sinuses or chest, and looking into the nose or lungs with the endoscope.
adaptation3.5: The final diagnosis of the cause of chronic cough was made based on all of these tests plus how patients responded to treatment.
adaptation3.6: The results were compared with patients studied before in another city in China.
adaptation3.7: The cause of chronic cough was found in about 95% of patients. About 83% had one cause, about 13% had 2 causes, and about 3% had 3 causes.
adaptation3.8: The most important causes of chronic cough were (most to least): cough variant asthma (CVA), inflammation of the nose (rhinitis) and/or sinuses (sinusitis), gastroesophageal reflux (GERC), medicine related, inflammation of airways (eosinophilic bronchitis -EB), allergies, and unknown cause.
adaptation3.9: Other lung and heart diseases caused chronic cough in a small number of patients
adaptation3.10: Nighttime cough occurred the most in CVA than the other diseases.
adaptation3.11: CVA was associated with nose allergy (atopic rhinitis) which changed with the seasons and increased in autumn.
adaptation3.12: GERC was associated with daytime cough, cough with eating, and with reflux.
adaptation3.13: Productive cough occurred more in rhinnitis and/or sinusitis.
adaptation3.14: There were more patients with CVA and GERC in this study than in the study before in another city. But there were less patients with EB and allergic cough in this study.
adaptation3.15: The most common causes of chronic cough in this study were CVA, rhinitis and/or sinusitis, GERC, medicine related, EB, and allergy related. This was different from studies done before in other cities.
adaptation3.16: The range of signs and symptoms of chronic cough are important in order to find out the causes.

20392032.Title: Management of recurrent laryngeal sensory neuropathic symptoms

abstract.1: Objectives: We identify management strategies for the treatment of upper respiratory tract symptoms stemming from dysfunction of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
abstract.2: Methods: We present a retrospective case series of patients who had symptoms of sensory neuropathy, including persistent dysphonia, laryngospasm, and chronic cough.
abstract.3: The patients were followed for symptomatic improvement after initiation of treatment with a neuromodulator.
abstract.4: Treatment outcome was defined by improvement or resolution of symptoms on a self-reported outcome scale.
abstract.5: Results: Of 12 patients identified, 75% exhibited evidence of motor neuropathy on laryngoscopy and 83% had symptoms related to chronic cough treated with neuromodulator therapy over a mean follow-up of 20.4 months.
abstract.6: The median dose of amitriptyline hydrochloride was 25 mg daily, and that of gabapentin was 300 mg 3 times daily.
abstract.7: The mean time from the initiation of therapy to a complete response was 2 months.
abstract.8: Conclusions: Patients with suspected neuropathy of the recurrent laryngeal nerve frequently respond to neuromodulator therapy.
abstract.9: The addition of reflux precautions and acid suppression therapy is helpful in cases of chronic and recurrent laryngospasm.
abstract.10: Patients with evidence of motor neuropathy appear to have better outcomes with neuromodulator therapy.

adaptation3.1: Researchers studied ways to treat patients with upper respiratory tract symptoms due to disorder of a nerve supplying sensation (sensory neuropathy) to the throat-the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
adaptation3.2: Researchers studied patients who had symptoms of sensory neuropathy including disorders of speech (dysphonia), spasms of the muscles of the voice box (laryngospasm), and chronic cough.
adaptation3.3: The patients were followed to see if their symptoms improved after starting a neuromodulator (a drug that has an effect on nerves).
adaptation3.4: Patients were asked if the drug improved their symptoms.
adaptation3.5: In 12 patients, tests showed 75% had motor neuropathy (disorder of the nerves controlling the muscles) of the throat.  Also, 83% had chronic cough treated with a neuromodulator. They were followed for about 20 months.
adaptation3.6: Two neuromodulator drugs were used in the study, amitriptyline hydrochloride (about 25 mg a day) and gabapentin (about 300 mg three times a day).
adaptation3.7: It took about 2 months for complete symptom improvement after the drugs were first started.
adaptation3.8: These neuromodulator drugs often help the symptoms if doctors suspect neuropathy of the recurrent laryngeal nerve as the cause.
adaptation3.9: In patients with chronic cough and recurrent laryngospasm, doctors may add therapy to prevent reflux and decrease stoamch acid.
adaptation3.10: Patient who have motor neuropathy seem to have better improvement with neuromodulator drugs.

26576953.Title: Laryngopharyngeal symptoms in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

abstract.1: The aim of the study was to report on the prevalence and severity of laryngopharyngeal symptoms in patients with COPD compared to controls.
abstract.2: A total of 27 patients with COPD and 13 controls matched according to age and gender were included.
abstract.3: Demographic data included age, gender, history of smoking and history of allergic rhinitis.
abstract.4: The Reflux symptom Index described by Belafsky et al. was used.
abstract.5: The frequency and average score of each of the laryngopharyngeal symptoms were computed.
abstract.6: The mean age of patients was 61.67 Â± 11.09 years.
abstract.7: Ninety-two percent were smokers and 11.1 % had allergy rhinitis.
abstract.8: The mean of Total Reflux Symptom index in patients was significantly higher compared to controls (12.70 Â± 7.06 vs. 3.00 Â± 2.94).
abstract.9: In the COPD group, 18 subjects had a positive Reflux symptom index (>11) compared to one in the control group (p value <0.05).
abstract.10: There was also a significant difference between the means of six laryngopharyngeal symptoms in patients vs.
abstract.11: Controls: COPD patients had higher degree of hoarseness, throat clearing, excessive throat mucus, cough and sticking sensation in the throat.
abstract.12: Laryngopharyngeal reflux is more prevalent in patients vs. Controls: The frequency and severity of laryngopharyngeal symptoms is significantly higher in COPD patients.

adaptation3.1: This study reports on how often and how severe symptoms of the throat and voice box occur in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) compared to those without COPD (controls).
adaptation3.2: A total of 27 patients with COPD and 13 controls were included, comparing their age and gender.
adaptation3.3: Facts about the patients and controls include age, gender, history of smoking, and history of allergic rhinitis (irritation of the nose due to allergies).
adaptation3.4: The severity of reflux symptoms was given a score (Reflux Symptom Index).
adaptation3.5: The Reflux Symptom Index and how often each of the throat and voice box (laryngopharyngeal) symptoms occurred was scored.
adaptation3.6: The average age of patients was 61 years.
adaptation3.7: Ninety-two percent of the patients were smokers . About 11% had allergic rhinitis.
adaptation3.8: The average of Total Reflux Symptom Index in patients was significantly higher compared to controls.
adaptation3.9: In the COPD group, 18 patients had a positive Reflux symptom index compared to one in the control group.
adaptation3.10: There was also a significant difference between the average of 6 laryngopharyngeal symptoms in patients compared to controls.
adaptation3.11: COPD patients had higher amounts of hoarseness, throat-clearing, excesss throat mucus, cough and sticking sensation in the throat.
adaptation3.12: Laryngopharygeal reflux (LPR) is a disorder caused by the backflow of stomach contents into the throat. It is more common in patients compared to controls. LPR occurs a lot more often and it is more severe in COPD patients.

26687670.Title: Chronic cough as a symptom of laryngopharyngeal reflux--two case reports

abstract.1: Laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) is a complex of symptoms caused by the backflow of gastric contents into the larynx, pharynx, nasopharynx, sinuses and even to the middle ear space.
abstract.2: The symptomatology of LPR includes: chronic cough, hoarseness, throat clearing, laryngitis,"globus pharyngeus", swallowing disturbances, postnasal drip, "fetor ex ore".
abstract.3: In the article, the authors present two boys with chronic cough, in one of them the asthma was suspected and antiasthmatic treatment was administrated; in our patients according to the 24-hour pharyngeal pH-metry LPR was diagnosed.
abstract.4: The aim of this study was to emphasise that pediatricians should be able to recognise symptoms of LPR.
abstract.5: The appropriate diagnosis and treatment leads the symptoms to subside.

adaptation3.1: A disorder caused by backflow of stomach contents into the back of the throat, nose, sinuses, and even the middle ear space is called laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR).
adaptation3.2: The symptoms of LPR include: chronic cough, hoarseness, throat clearing, sore throat, feeling of a lump in throat, problems swallowing, postnasal drip, and bad breath.
adaptation3.3: In this study, two boys with chronic cough are discussed. One boy was thought to have asthma and given medicine for it. The other boy was found to have LPR by a test for acid in the throat.
adaptation3.4: Pediatricians should be able to recognize the symptoms of LPR.
adaptation3.5: The correct diagnosis and treatment results in improvement of the symptoms.

28081319.Title: Chronic cough: clinical characteristics and etiologies of 510 cases

abstract.1: Background/aim: To investigate the clinical features and underlying etiologies of chronic cough (CC).
abstract.2: Materials and methods: Five hundred and ten CC patients were enrolled.
abstract.3: The phases, characteristics and associated clinical manifestations of CC among the gastroesophageal reflux cough (GERC), cough-variant asthma (CVA), and upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) groups were compared, and the diagnostic values of each group were evaluated by multiple regression analysis.
abstract.4: Results: In the 510 patients, 404 had CC with single etiology-GERC (n = 175), CVA (n = 134), and UACS (n = 95).
abstract.5: The characteristic features of GERC included gastric acid backflow symptoms such as sour-tasting regurgitation, heartburn, endoscopic esophagitis, poststimulation cough, frequent throat clearing, daytime mono-cough, and feelings of heaviness and pain in the chest.
abstract.6: Patients with CVA typically exhibited sensitivity to smog and other irritants; the cough occurred mostly at night, and was associated with positive bronchodilator and provocation test results.
abstract.7: The typical features of UACS included a history and/or symptoms of rhinitis, retropharyngeal postnasal drip, and wet cough occurring mostly during the daytime.
abstract.8: The diagnostic specificities of above factors were >70%.
abstract.9: Conclusion: The most common causes of CC include GERC, CVA, and UACS, and their diagnosis is based on the characteristics of the underlying disease.

adaptation3.1: Researchers studied the signs, symptoms and underlying causes of chronic cough (CC).
adaptation3.2: There were 510 patients that took part in the study.
adaptation3.3: The features in patients with different causes of chronic cough (CC) were compared. The different causes were gastroesophageal reflux cough (GERC), cough-variant asthma (CVA), and upper airway cough syndrome (UACS).
adaptation3.4: In the 510 patients, 404 had CC caused by a single disorder. In these patients, CC was caused by GERC in 175 patients, by CVA in 134 patients, and by UACS in 95 patients.
adaptation3.5: GERC patients have stomach acid backflow symptoms such as sour-tasting backflow, heartburn, inflammation of food tube (esophagus) on examination with an instrument (endoscopy), cough when the throat is touched, throat-clearing, daytime cough, and feelings of heaviness and pain in the chest.
adaptation3.6: CVA patients are sensitive to smog and other irritants. They coughed mostly at night and they reacted to drugs that cause the airways to open or close up.
adaptation3.7: UACS patients have a history and symptoms of inflammation of the nose, postnasal drip in the back of the throat, and wet coughing mostly during the daytime.
adaptation3.8: The facts allowed doctors to correctly diagnose the cause more than 70% of the time.
adaptation3.9: The most common causes of CC include GERC, CVA, and UACS. Doctors can diagnose which of these underlying  diseases cause CC by their signs and symptoms.

74.question: Why do i have to constantly clear my throat and cough up flem?

18667698.Title: DNA polymorphisms at the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and beta-globin loci associate with fetal hemoglobin levels and pain crises in sickle cell disease

abstract.1: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a debilitating monogenic blood disorder with a highly variable phenotype characterized by severe pain crises, acute clinical events, and early mortality.
abstract.2: Interindividual variation in fetal hemoglobin (HbF) expression is a known and potentially heritable modifier of SCD severity.
abstract.3: High HbF levels are correlated with reduced morbidity and mortality.
abstract.4: Common single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at the BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB loci have been implicated previously in HbF level variation in nonanemic European populations.
abstract.5: We recently demonstrated an association between a BCL11A SNP and HbF levels in one SCD cohort [Uda M, et al. (2008) Proc Natl Acad Sci USA 105:1620-1625].
abstract.6: Here, we genotyped additional BCL11A SNPs, HBS1L-MYB SNPs, and an SNP upstream of (G)gamma-globin (HBG2; the XmnI polymorphism), in two independent SCD cohorts: the African American Cooperative Study of Sickle Cell Disease (CSSCD) and an SCD cohort from Brazil.
abstract.7: We studied the effect of these SNPs on HbF levels and on a measure of SCD-related morbidity (pain crisis rate).
abstract.8: We strongly replicated the association between these SNPs and HbF level variation (in the CSSCD, P values range from 0.04 to 2 x 10(-42)).
abstract.9: Together, common SNPs at the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and beta-globin (HBB) loci account for >20% of the variation in HbF levels in SCD patients.
abstract.10: We also have shown that HbF-associated SNPs associate with pain crisis rate in SCD patients.
abstract.11: These results provide a clear example of inherited common sequence variants modifying the severity of a monogenic disease.

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a disabling genetic blood disorder caused by a single mutation. SCD can have various outcomes,but it can result in severe pain crises, acute symptoms, and early death.
adaptation3.2: The severity of the problems that occur in SCD can vary depending on the amount of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the blood.
adaptation3.3: High HbF levels are associated with decreased problems and death in patients with SCD.
adaptation3.4: Common single mutations in two genes, BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB, are thought to cause the changes in HbF levels seen in European populations without anemia.
adaptation3.5: Research has shown a connection between a single BCL11A gene mutation and HbF levels in some SCD patients.
adaptation3.6: In this paper, researchers found more single mutations in the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and HBC2 genes in two other groups of patients (a study in African Americans SCD patients and a study of SCD patients from Brazil).
adaptation3.7: We studied the effect of these single gene mutations on HbF levels and the number of pain crises in SCD.
adaptation3.8: We showed a strong connection between the single mutations in these genes and different HbF levels.
adaptation3.9: Common single mutations in the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, beta-globin (HBB) genes explain >20% of the different HbF levels in SCD patients.
adaptation3.10: These mutations, associated with HbF levels, are also associated with the number of pain crises in SCD patients.
adaptation3.11: This shows a clear example that inherited common gene mutations can change the severity of a genetic disease.

18695233.Title: Genetic complexity in sickle cell disease

abstract.1: Sickle cell disease (SCD) was the first human monogenic disorder to be characterized at the molecular level.
abstract.2: It results from the substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-chain of hemoglobin.
abstract.3: The clinical manifestations of SCD arise from the tendency of sickle hemoglobin (known as HbS or α2βS2) to polymerize at reduced oxygen tensions and deform red cells into the characteristic rigid sickle cell shape.
abstract.4: Such inflexible red cells cannot pass through the microcirculation efficiently, and this results in anemia (due to destruction of the red cells) and intermittent vasoocclusion causing tissue damage and pain.
abstract.5: Although all patients with homozygous SCD have exactly the same molecular defect, there is considerable clinical variation, ranging from death in early childhood to a normal life span with few complications.
abstract.6: Genetic modifiers of SCD include α-thalassemia, and it has been known for many years that patients with increased levels of fetal Hb (HbF or α2γ2) often tend to have a relatively mild clinical course because HbF reduces the tendency of HbS to polymerise within the red cell.
abstract.7: Increased HbF may result from rare deletions within the β-globin gene cluster or from point mutations in the promoters of the fetal γ-globin genes (hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, HPFH), but additional loci are known to increase HbF levels in adult life.
abstract.8: Identifying such loci has been a painstaking task, but a combination of genome-wide analysis within a large kindred and within twin pairs has identified two quantitative trait loci (QTL) with major influences on fetal hemoglobin levels in adults.
abstract.9: A significant proportion of the variation in HbF levels and the frequency of painful crises in patients with SCD is accounted for by five common single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at these loci.

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) was the first human genetic disorder caused by a mutation in a single gene to be described at the chemical level.
adaptation3.2: SCD occurs when a mutation of the Beta-hemoglobin gene causes the amino acid, glutamic acid, to be replaced by valine in the beta chain of the hemoglobin protein.
adaptation3.3: The signs and symptoms in SCD occur because these sickle hemoglobin (HbS) proteins tend to join together where oxygen levels are lower in the body. This causes the red blood cells to change into the typical abnormal rigid sickle cell shape.
adaptation3.4: These rigid red blood cells cannot pass through the smallest blood vessels well.This causes the vessels to be blocked, resulting in tissue damage and pain.These sickle red blood cells are also destroyed, which causes anemia.
adaptation3.5: Patients with the same genetic defect in SCD can have many different outcomes, ranging from death in early childhood to a normal life span with few problems.
adaptation3.6: Alpha-Thalassemia is a genetic disease that can change the outcome of patients with SCD. Also, patients with increased levels of another type of hemoglobin protein, fetal hemoglobin (HbF), tend to have a milder disease. The presence of fetal hemoglobin decreases the tendency of the sickle hemoglobin to join together in the red blood cells.
adaptation3.7: Increased levels of HbF may be due to other mutations in various hemoglobin genes.
adaptation3.8: Identifying these mutations in the hemoglobin genes has been very difficult.  But researchers have been able to identify two areas on the genes that have major influences on fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels in adults.
adaptation3.9: A large part of the different HbF levels and number of painful crises in Sickle Cell Disease patients is due to five common mutations in the hemoglobin gene.

29205277.Title: Clinical and genetic factors are associated with pain and hospitalisation rates in sickle cell anaemia in Cameroon

abstract.1: We aimed to investigate the clinical and genetic predictors of painful vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) in sickle cell disease (SCD) in Cameroon.
abstract.2: Socio-demographics, clinical variables/events and haematological indices were acquired.
abstract.3: Genotyping was performed for 40 variants in 17 pain-related genes, three fetal haemoglobin (HbF)-promoting loci, two kidney dysfunctions-related genes, and HBA1/HBA2 genes.
abstract.4: Statistical models using regression frameworks were performed in R® .
abstract.5: A total of 436 hydoxycarbamide- and opioid-naïve patients were studied; median age was 16 years.
abstract.6: Female sex, body mass index, Hb/HbF, blood transfusions, leucocytosis and consultation or hospitalisation rates significantly correlated with VOC.
abstract.7: Three pain-related genes variants correlated with VOC (CACNA2D3-rs6777055, P = 0·025; DRD2-rs4274224, P = 0·037; KCNS1-rs734784, P = 0·01).
abstract.8: Five pain-related genes variants correlated with hospitalisation/consultation rates.
abstract.10: The 3·7 kb HBA1/HBA2 deletion correlated with increased VOC (P = 0·002).
abstract.11: HbF-promoting loci variants correlated with decreased hospitalisation (BCL11A-rs4671393, P = 0·026; HBS1L-MYB-rs28384513, P = 0·01).
abstract.12: APOL1 G1/G2 correlated with increased hospitalisation (P = 0·048).
abstract.13: This first study from Africa has provided evidence supporting possible development of genetic risk model for pain in SCD.

adaptation3.1: This research studies factors that may predict painful blood vessel blockages (VOC-vaso-occlusive crises) in Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) patients in Cameroon.
adaptation3.2: Researchers found out facts about the population, signs and symptoms, and their blood.
adaptation3.3: Genetic testing was done for 40 mutations in 17 pain-relating genes, three fetal hemoglobin areas on genes, two genes related to kidney disease, and the HBA1/HBA2 (alpha-globin)genes.
adaptation3.4: Models were performed to predict outcomes.
adaptation3.5: A total of 436 patients that had not taken hydroxycarbamide or opioids were studied. Half the patients were younger than 16 years old and half were older.
adaptation3.6: Female sex, body mass index, Hb/HbF (hemoglobin/fetal hemoglobin), blood transfusions, higher white blood cell count, and consultations or hospitalisations are significantly linked with blood vessel blockages (vaso-occlusive crises (VOC)).
adaptation3.7: Three pain-related gene variants (mutations) are linked to VOC.
adaptation3.8: Five pain-related gene variants are linked to the amount of hospitalisations/consultations.
adaptation3.9: These gene variants are specific mutations in COMT, FAAH, OPRM1, ADRB2, and UGT2B7 genes.
adaptation3.10: A specific mutation in the HBA1/HBA2 genes are linked to increased VOC.
adaptation3.11: Specific gene variants on the BCL11A gene and the HBS1L-MYB gene increase HbF and are linked to decreased hospitalisation.
adaptation3.12: The APOL1 G1/G2 genes (related to kidney disease) are linked to increased hospitalisation.
adaptation3.13: This first study from an African country has provided evidence supporting the  possible development of a genetic risk model for pain in Sickle Cell Disease.

29555644.Title: Biological impact of α genes, β haplotypes, and G6PD activity in sickle cell anemia at baseline and with hydroxyurea

abstract.1: Sickle cell anemia (SCA), albeit monogenic, has heterogeneous phenotypic expression, mainly related to the level of hemoglobin F (HbF).
abstract.2: No large cohort studies have ever compared biological parameters in patients with major β-globin haplotypes; ie, Senegal (SEN), Benin (BEN), and Bantu/Central African Republic (CAR).
abstract.3: The aim of this study was to evaluate the biological impact of α genes, β haplotypes, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) activity at baseline and with hydroxyurea (HU).
abstract.4: Homozygous HbS patients from the Créteil pediatric cohort with available α-gene and β-haplotype data were included (n = 580; 301 females and 279 males) in this retrospective study.
abstract.5: Homozygous β-haplotype patients represented 74% of cases (37.4% CAR/CAR, 24.3% BEN/BEN, and 12.1% SEN/SEN).
abstract.6: HU was given to 168 cohort SCA children.
abstract.7: Hematological parameters were recorded when HbF was maximal, and changes (ΔHU-T0) were calculated.
abstract.8: At baseline, CAR-haplotype and α-gene numbers were independently and negatively correlated with Hb and positively correlated with lactate dehydrogenase.
abstract.9: HbF was negatively correlated with CAR-haplotype numbers and positively with BEN- and SEN-haplotype numbers.
abstract.10: The BCL11A/rs1427407 "T" allele, which is favorable for HbF expression, was positively correlated with BEN- and negatively correlated with CAR-haplotype numbers.
abstract.11: With HU treatment, Δ and HbF values were positively correlated with the BEN-haplotype number.
abstract.12: BEN/BEN patients had higher HbF and Hb levels than CAR/CAR and SEN/SEN patients.
abstract.13: In conclusion, we show that BEN/BEN patients have the best response on HU and suggest that this could be related to the higher prevalence of the favorable BCL11A/rs1427407/T/allele for HbF expression in these patients.

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA) is caused by a single gene mutation. SCA varies in different patients mainly due to the fetal hemoglobin (HbF) level in the blood.
adaptation3.2: No large research studies have ever compared factors seen in patients with the major different beta-globin genetic types; for example, Senegal (SEN), Benin (BEN), and Bantu/Central African Republic (CAR).
adaptation3.3: This research studies the importance of alpha genes, different beta gene types, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD-an enzyme that protects red blood cells from damage) activity in patients before and after treatment with the medicine,  hydroxyurea.
adaptation3.4: This study included boys and girls who inherited the sickle hemoglobin (HbS) from both parents (SS -Creteil pediatric group). Facts about the alpha-gene and beta-globin genetic types were known.
adaptation3.5: Children who inherited the major different beta-globin genetic types from both parents made up 74% all patients CAR/CAR, BEN/BEN, and SEN/SEN.
adaptation3.6: Hydroxyurea (HU) was given to 168 children with Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA).
adaptation3.7: Factors in the blood were recorded when HbF was highest. Changes were analyzed after hydroxyurea (HU) was given.
adaptation3.8: Before HU, the CAR beta-globin genetic type and the alpha-gene were separately linked to lower hemoglobin and higher lactate dehydrogenase (an enzyme from tissue damage).
adaptation3.9: Higher HbF was linked to lower CAR genetic type numbers but higher BEN and SEN genetic type numbers.
adaptation3.10: A BCL11A gene mutation is linked to the favorable higher HbF levels. This gene mutation was also linked to higher BEN, but lower CAR genetic type numbers.
adaptation3.11: With HU treatment, positive changes and higher HbF numbers were linked to the BEN genetic type.
adaptation3.12: BEN/BEN patients had higher HbF and hemoglobin (Hb) levelsthan CAR/CAR and SEN/SEN patients.
adaptation3.13: This research shows that children inheriting BEN mutations from both parents (BEN/BEN) have the best response on hydroxyurea. This could be related to the more likely presence of favorable genetic mutations for HbF production in these patients.

30216683.Title: The association of HBG2, BCL11A, and HMIP polymorphisms with fetal hemoglobin and clinical phenotype in Iraqi Kurds with sickle cell disease

abstract.1: Introduction: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is the major modifier for sickle cell disease (SCD) severity.
abstract.2: HbF is modulated mainly by three major quantitative trait loci (QTL) on chromosomes 2, 6, and 11.
abstract.3: Methods: Five SNPs in the three QTLs (HBG2, rs7482144; BCL11A, rs1427407 and rs10189857; and HBS1L-MYB intergenic region, rs28384513 and rs9399137) were investigated by multiplex PCR and reverse hybridization, and their roles in HbF and clinical phenotype variability in Iraqi Kurds with SCD were assessed.
abstract.4: Results: HBG2 rs7482144 with minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.133 was the most significant contributor to HbF variability, contributing 18.1%, followed by rs1427407 (MAF of 0.266) and rs9399137 (MAF of 0.137) at 14.3% and 8.8%, respectively.
abstract.5: The other two SNPs were not significant contributors.
abstract.6: Furthermore, when the cumulative numbers of minor alleles in the three contributing SNPs were assessed, HbF% and hemoglobin concentration increased with increasing number of minor alleles (P < 0.0005 and 0.001, respectively), while serum lactic dehydrogenase, reticulocytes, leukocytes, transfusion, and pain frequencies decreased (P = 0.003, 0.004, <0.0005, <0.0005, and 0.017, respectively).
abstract.7: Conclusions: It was demonstrated that SNPs in all three major HbF QTLs contribute significantly to HbF and clinical variability in Iraqi Kurds with SCD and that the cumulative number of minor alleles at contributing SNPs may serve as a better predictor of such variability in this population.

adaptation3.1: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is an important protein that affects the severity of Sickle Cell Disease (SCD).
adaptation3.2: HbF is changed mainly by three important quantitative trail loci (QTL-special sections of DNA) on chromosomes 2, 6, and 11.
adaptation3.3: Five single mutations in the three QTLs were studied. The roles of these mutations in HbF were studied. The research evaluated how these mutations affected the variety of characteristics seen in Iraqui Kurds with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD).
adaptation3.4: Three minor single mutations of the HBG2 gene resulted in the most important changes in HbF.
adaptation3.5: The other two single mutations did not contribute significantly.
adaptation3.6: An increase in the number of these minor single mutations resulted in an increase in the amount of HbF and hemoglobin. This also resulted in a decrease in blood lactic dehydrogenase (an enzyme from tissue damage), white blood cells, transfusions, and occurences of pain.
adaptation3.7: Research showed these mutations in all three major HbF QTLs are important to HbF. These mutations also contribute to the variety of disease outcomes in Iraqui Kurds with SCD. The added amount of these minor single mutations may better predict variety of disease outcome in this population.

31322815.Title: Combined and differential effects of alpha-thalassemia and HbF-quantitative trait loci in Senegalese hydroxyurea-free children with sickle cell anemia

abstract.1: Background: Our objective was to investigate the combined and differential effects of alpha-thalassemia -3.7 kb deletion and HbF-promoting quantitative trait loci (HbF-QTL) in Senegalese hydroxyurea (HU)-free children and young adults with sickle cell anemia (SCA).
abstract.2: Procedure: Steady-state biological parameters and vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) requiring emergency admission were recorded over a 2-year period in 301 children with SCA.
abstract.3: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was also recorded.
abstract.4: These data were correlated with the alpha-globin and HbF-QTL genotypes.
abstract.5: For the latter, three different genetic loci were studied (XmnI, rs7482144; BCL11A, rs1427407; and the HBS1L-MYB region, rs28384513) and a composite score was calculated, ranging from zero (none of these three polymorphisms) to six (all three polymorphisms at the homozygous state).
abstract.6: Results: A positive clinical impact of the HbF-QTL score on VOC rate, HbF, leucocytes, and C-reactive protein levels was observed only for patients without alpha-thalassemia deletion.
abstract.7: Conversely, combination of homozygous -3.7 kb deletion with three to six HbF-QTL was associated with a higher VOC rate.
abstract.8: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was delayed for patients with one or two alpha-thalassemia deletions and at least two HbF-QTL.
abstract.9: Conclusion: Alpha-thalassemia -3.7 kb deletion and HbF-QTL are modulating factors of SCA clinical severity that interact with each other.
abstract.10: They should be studied and interpreted together and not separately, at least in HU-free children.

adaptation3.1: Researchers analyzed the effects of an alpha-thalassemia (another genetic blood disease) mutation and fetal hemoglobin-promoting quantitative trait loci (HbF-QTL (special section of DNA)) in Senegalese children and young adults with Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA) who have not received the medicine, hydroxyurea.
adaptation3.2: Steady biological signs and crises from blood vessel blockages (vaso-occlusive crises-VOC) requiring emergency admission were recorded over a 2-year period in 301 children with Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA).
adaptation3.3: The age of the first hospitalized VOC was also recorded.
adaptation3.4: These facts were compared to patients who had alpha-globin and HbF-QTL genes.
adaptation3.5: Three different gene regions on the HbF-QTL gene were studied in detail. A score was given to patients from zero to six depending on the different changes (mutations) at the 3 gene regions.
adaptation3.6: A higher HbF-QTL score resulted in better signs of SCA disease outcome only for patients without the alpha-thalassemia mutation.
adaptation3.7: With the alpha-thalassemia mutation, a higher HbF-QTL score was linked to more VOC (vaso-occlusive crises).
adaptation3.8: The age of the first hospitalization for VOC was older in patients with the alpha-thalassemia mutation and at least 2 HbF-QTL gene region mutations.
adaptation3.9: The alpha-thalassemia mutation and the HbF-QTL gene mutations react with each other and can change the severity of Sickle Cell Anemia.
adaptation3.10: These genes and their mutations should be studied together, not separately, at least in children who have not received hydroxyurea.

32447424.Title: Functional polymorphisms of BCL11A and HBS1L-MYB genes affect both fetal hemoglobin level and clinical outcomes in a cohort of children with sickle cell anemia

abstract.1: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) ameliorates clinical severity of sickle cell anemia (SCA).
abstract.2: The major loci regulating HbF levels are HBB cluster, BCL11A, and HMIP-2 (HBS1L-MYB).
abstract.3: However, the impact of noncoding single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in these loci on clinical outcomes and their functional role on regulating HbF levels should be better elucidated.
abstract.4: Therefore, we performed comprehensive association analyses of 14 noncoding SNPs in five loci with HbF levels and with clinical outcomes in a cohort of 250 children with SCA from Southeastern Brazil, and further performed functional annotation of these SNPs.
abstract.5: We found SNPs independently associated with HbF levels: rs4671393 in BCL11A (β-coefficient = 0.28), rs9399137 in HMIP-2A (β-coefficient = 0.16), and rs4895441 in HMIP-2B (β-coefficient = 0.15).
abstract.6: Patients carrying minor (HbF-boosting) alleles for rs1427407, rs93979137, rs4895441, rs9402686, and rs9494145 showed reduced count of reticulocytes (p < 0.01), while those carrying the T allele of rs9494145 showed lower white blood cell count (p = 0.002).
abstract.7: Carriers of the minor allele for rs9402686 showed higher peripheral saturation of oxygen (p = 0.002).
abstract.8: Patients carrying minor alleles in BCL11A showed lower risk of transfusion incidence rate ratio (IRR ≥ 1.3; p < 0.0001).
abstract.9: This effect was independent of HbF effect (p = 0.005).
abstract.10: Carriers of minor alleles for rs9399137 and rs9402686 showed lower risk of acute chest syndrome (IRR > 1.3; p ≤ 0.01).
abstract.11: Carriers of the reference allele for rs4671393 showed lower risk of infections (IRR = 1.16; p = 0.01).
abstract.12: In conclusion, patients carrying HbF-boosting alleles of BCL11A and HMIP-2 were associated with milder clinical phenotypes.
abstract.13: Higher HbF concentration may underlie this effect.

adaptation3.1: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) makes the severity of Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA) better.
adaptation3.2: The major specific genetic areas effecting HbF levels are in the HBB cluster, BCL11A, and HMIP-2 (HBS1L-MYB) genes.
adaptation3.3: Researchers need to know more about how the areas of these genes effect the process of HbF levels and the outcome of disease in SCA.
adaptation3.4: Researchers analyzed the function and relationship of 14 mutations in 5 specific genetic areas of the genes with HbF levels and disease outcomes in 250 children with SCA in Southeastern Brazil.
adaptation3.5: They found single mutations that were linked to HbF levels in BCL11A and HMIP-2A and HMIP-2B genes.
adaptation3.6: Patients who had minor mutations (carriers) that increased HbF levels (HbF-boosting) had reduced white blood cells counts.
adaptation3.7: Carriers of other minor mutations (genetic differences) showed higher levels of oxygen in the blood.
adaptation3.8: Patients carrying still other minor genetic differences in BCL11A showed lower risk of transfusions.
adaptation3.9: These findings were separate from the HbF effect.
adaptation3.10: Carriers of other minor mutations showed lower risk of acute chest syndrome.
adaptation3.11: Carriers of the standard minor genetic change showed lower risk of infection.
adaptation3.12: Patients carrying HBF-boosting minor mutations of BCL11A and HMIP-2 genes had milder disease.
adaptation3.13: Higher HbF levels may be the cause of this effect.

32772141.Title: Association between BCL11A, HSB1L-MYB, and XmnI γG-158 (C/T) gene polymorphism and hemoglobin F level in Egyptian sickle cell disease patients

abstract.1: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a monogenic disease characterized by multisystem morbidity and highly variable clinical course.
abstract.2: Inter-individual variability in hemoglobin F (HbF) levels is one of the main modifiers that account for the clinical heterogeneity in SCD.
abstract.3: HbF levels are affected by, among other factors, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at the BCL11A gene and the HBS1L-MYB intergenic region and Xmn1 gene.
abstract.4: Our aim was to investigate HbF-enhancer haplotypes at these loci to obtain a first overview of the genetic situation of SCD patients in Egypt and its impact on the severity of the disease.
abstract.5: The study included 100 SCD patients and 100 matched controls.
abstract.6: Genotyping of BCL11A (rs1886868 C/T), HBS1L-MYB (rs9389268 A/G) and Xmn1 γG158 (rs7842144 C/T) SNPs showed no statistically significant difference between SCD patients and controls except for the hetero-mutant genotypes of BCL11A which was significantly higher in SCD patients compared with controls.
abstract.7: Baseline HbF levels were significantly higher in those with co-inheritance of polymorphic genotypes of BCL11A + HSB1L-MYB and BCL11A + Xmn1.
abstract.8: Steady-state HbF levels, used as an indicator of disease severity, were significantly higher in SCD-Sβ patients having the polymorphic genotypes of HSB1L-MYB.
abstract.9: Fold change of HbF in both patient groups did not differ between those harboring the wild and the polymorphic genotypes of the studied SNPs.
abstract.10: In conclusion, BCL11A, HSB1L, and Xmn1 genetic polymorphisms had no positive impact on baseline HbF levels solely but had if coexisted.
abstract.11: Discovery of the molecular mechanisms controlling HbF production could provide a more effective strategy for HbF induction.

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a genetic blood disease that can affect many areas of the body. The course of the disease can vary between patients.
adaptation3.2: Different levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is a main reason that explains the variation in the course of SCD.
adaptation3.3: HbF levels are affected by single gene mutations in the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and Xmn1 genes.
adaptation3.4: Our research focused on specific areas in these genes that affected HbF and also affected the disease severity in SCD patients in Egypt.
adaptation3.5: The study compared 2 groups, 100 SCD patients and 100 patients without SCD (controls).
adaptation3.6: Generally, closer analysis of the BCL11A, HBS1L-MYB, and Xmn1 genes didn't show important differences between the 2 groups. But certain specific genetic mutations in the BCL11A gene were higher in SCD patients.
adaptation3.7: Baseline HbF levels were significantly higher in those who inherited mutations of both BCL11A + HSB1L-MYB and BCL11A+ Xmn1 genes.
adaptation3.8: Steady HbF levels, (a sign of disease severity) in both groups, were significantly higher in SCD-Sbeta patients having the different genetic mutations of the HSB1L-MYB gene.
adaptation3.9: The protein folding chemistry of HbF in both groups didn’t change between patients with the normal or mutant genes.
adaptation3.10: BCL11A, HSB1L, and Xmn1 gene mutations did not have a positive effect on baseline HbF levels unless the mutations occurred together.
adaptation3.11: If researchers could discover the underlying chemistry of HbF production we might be able to increase it in patients.

33072979.Title: Sickle Cell Disease-Genetics, Pathophysiology, Clinical Presentation and Treatment

abstract.1: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a monogenetic disorder due to a single base-pair point mutation in the β-globin gene resulting in the substitution of the amino acid valine for glutamic acid in the β-globin chain.
abstract.2: Phenotypic variation in the clinical presentation and disease outcome is a characteristic feature of the disorder.
abstract.3: Understanding the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of the disorder is central to the choice of therapeutic development and intervention.
abstract.4: In this special edition for newborn screening for haemoglobin disorders, it is pertinent to describe the genetic, pathologic and clinical presentation of sickle cell disease as a prelude to the justification for screening.
abstract.5: Through a systematic review of the literature using search terms relating to SCD up till 2019, we identified relevant descriptive publications for inclusion.
abstract.6: The scope of this review is mainly an overview of the clinical features of pain, the cardinal symptom in SCD, which present following the drop in foetal haemoglobin as young as five to six months after birth.
abstract.7: The relative impact of haemolysis and small-vessel occlusive pathology remains controversial, a combination of features probably contribute to the different pathologies.
abstract.8: We also provide an overview of emerging therapies in SCD.

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is a genetic disorder due to a single mutation in the Beta-globin gene. This mutation causes a change in an amino acid in the Beta-hemoglobin protein that decreases the ability of oxygen to be carried out to the body.
adaptation3.2: Patients with Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) may experience a variety of signs, symptoms and disease outcomes from this disorder.
adaptation3.3: Understanding the causes, progression, and functional problems that result in patients with SCD are very important in finding and choosing treatments.
adaptation3.4: In this special paper, doctors discuss the importance of screening newborns for SCD. They also describe the genes, the pathology, and the signs and symptoms of Sickle Cell Disease.
adaptation3.5: This paper is the result of a very thorough research of the literature on SCD.
adaptation3.6: The paper focuses on the pain SCD can cause after the decrease in fetal hemoglobin which occurs in infants as young as five to six months after birth.
adaptation3.7: The features seen in Sickle Cell Disease is probably due to a combination of the red blood cells being destroyed and the small blood vessels being blocked.
adaptation3.8: This paper also discusses new therapies for Sickle Cell Disease.

33216016.Title: HbF-promoting polymorphisms may specifically reduce the residual risk of cerebral vasculopathy in SCA children with alpha-thalassemia

abstract.1: Sickle cell anemia (SCA) is a disease characterized by abnormal red blood cell rheology.
abstract.2: Because of their effects on HbS polymerization and red blood cell deformability, alpha-thalassemia and the residual HbF level are known genetic modifiers of the disease.
abstract.3: The aim of our study was to determine if the number of HbF quantitative trait loci (QTL) would also favor a specific sub-phenotype of SCA as it is the case for alpha-thalassemia.
abstract.4: Our results confirmed that alpha-thalassemia protected from cerebral vasculopathy but increased the risk for frequent painful vaso-occlusive crises.
abstract.5: We also showed that more HbF-QTL may provide an additional and specific protection against cerebral vasculopathy but only for children with alpha-thalassemia (-α/αα or -α/-α genotypes).

adaptation3.1: Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA) is a genetic blood disease that causes abnormal red blood cell flow through blood vessels.
adaptation3.2: Due to their effects on sickle hemoglobin (HbS) chemistry and red blood cell shape changes, alpha-thalassemia (another genetic blood disease)and HbF (fetal hemoglobin) levels are known to change the course of SCA.
adaptation3.3: The aim of our study was to find out if the number of HbF-QTL, quantitative trait loci (QTL-special sections of DNA) would influence the severity of SCA as seen in alpha-thalassemia.
adaptation3.4: Results showed that alpha-thalassemia protected SCA patients from cerebral vasculopathy (diseases of blood vessels in the brain). But, it increased the risk for more painful crises due to blood vessel blockages.
adaptation3.5: We also showed that more HbF-QTL may protect more against cerebral vasculopathy, but only for children with certain genetic types of alpha-thalassemia.

75.question: What is a gene affected by sickle cell anemia?
